ORDINANCE NO. 9106
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR MARIA SHEILAH "HONEY" LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, AUTHORITY TO ENTER INTO NEGOTIATION, SIGN THE DEED OF SALE FOR THE ACQUISITION OF THOSE PARCELS OF LAND CONSISTING OF ONE THOUSAND SIXTY-FOUR SQUARE METERS (1,064 SQ. M.), REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF EMILIA WARREN VDA. DE AGUILAR, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 47140, OF THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS OF THE CITY OF MANILA FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE MEMBERS OF APO SAN JUAN NEIGHBORHOOD ASSOCIATION, INC., BARANGAY 709, ZONE 78, AGNO STREET, MALATE, MANILA AND/OR BONA FIDE RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND APPROPRIATING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR


Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Requirements Before Negotiation.
The favorable recommendations of the following offices are required before the start of negotiation for the acquisition of the parcel of land for the benefit of the beneficiaries under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila:
a) City Planning and Development Office – to verify if the intended acquisition of land is in line with the city’s five (5) or ten (10) year development plan.
b) Urban Settlements Office – to conduct a feasibility study on the subject property as a site for the city's Land-for-the-Landless Program, to survey the property and the structures built therein, to profile the actual residents, and to initially determine the qualification for the program.
c) City Budget Officer – to determine the availability of appropriation.
d) City Assessor’s Office – to determine the fair market value of the property.
e) City Treasurer's Office – to determine the fair market value of the property.

SEC. 2. Authority to Enter into Negotiation.
The Honorable City Mayor Maria Sheilah "Honey” Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, is hereby authorized to enter into negotiation for the purchase and acquisition of a parcel of land consisting of One Thousand Sixty-Four Square Meters (1,064 Sq. M.), more or less, located in Barangay 709, Zone 78, Agno Street, Malate, Manila, covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 47140, registered under the name of Emilia Warren Vda. De Aguilar, in the Registry of Deeds Manila.
Once the City Mayor and the landowner or their duly authorized representatives have finally agreed on the purchase price, the City Mayor shall sign the Deed of Absolute Sale and thereafter cause the payment of the purchase price.

SEC. 3. Purchase Price.
The purchase price of the subject parcel of land shall be based either on the preliminary appraisal report issued by the City Assessor's Office, Manila, dated March 14, 2024, which is pegged at Eighty-Three Thousand Six Hundred Thirty Pesos and Seventy-Six Centavos (PhP83,630.76) per square meter assessed value of the property or the negotiated price agreed by the City Mayor and the landowner or their duly authorized representative.

SEC. 4. Appropriation or Funding.
The amount of Eighty-Eight Million Nine Hundred Eighty-Three Thousand One Hundred Twenty-Eight Pesos and Sixty-Four Centavos (PhP88,983,128.64) is hereby appropriated from the available funds under the “land account” of the Urban Settlements Office (USO), Manila. If not sufficient, the City of Manila, through USO-Manila, may secure a loan from a reputable government institution upon the approval of the City Mayor, subject to prior authority from the Sangguniang Panlungsod or other legal requirements.

SEC. 5. Beneficiaries.
The final determination of the qualifications of the beneficiaries by USO-Manila shall constitute the official list of beneficiaries from the Apo San Juan Community Neighborhood Association, Inc. of Agno Street, Malate, Barangay 709, Zone 78, District V, Manila, and/or bona fide residents of the City of Manila to benefit from the acquisition of the subject land.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 25, 2025.
short_text: The City of Manila has passed a law giving Mayor Honey Lacuna-Pangan the authority to negotiate and purchase a 1,064 square meter piece of land on Agno Street, Malate. This land, currently owned by Emilia Warren Vda. de Aguilar, will be used for the city's Land-for-the-Landless Program to help qualified residents. The purchase will only go ahead after reviews by different city offices, including planning, budget, and housing. The cost will be based on the city's appraisal or through negotiation. Around PhP88.98 million is set aside for this, and a loan may be taken if needed. The Urban Settlements Office will decide who qualifies for the housing program.

ORDINANCE NO. 9104
AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE POSITION OF MUSEUM CURATOR 1 — SG 22 UNDER THE DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM, CULTURE AND ARTS MANILA (DTCAM) AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR
SPONSORED BY:
HON. BENNY FOG T. ABANTE III, Acting Majority Floor Leader
EXPLANATORY NOTE
The Manila Clock Tower was unveiled in the 1930s and is considered the tallest clock tower in the Philippines. The 100-foot Manila Clock Tower was designed by Antonio Toledo and featured three red-faced clocks on top. But, like most buildings in Manila, it was intensely damaged during World War II.
Today, the Manila Clock Tower Museum is one of the capital's newest attractions. It was opened to the public in October 2022 and offers an immersive experience curated to tell the history of Manila. It has been gaining recognition and prominence and has garnered numerous awards, to wit:
1.        Presidential Award of the Philippine Leaf Awards
2.        National Commission of Culture and the Arts Competition Grand Winner
MGM Museum AVP
3.        Association of Tourism Officers of the Philippines Best Brochures: Timeless Treasures, Manila Clock Tower Museum Brochure (Grand Winner)
4.        Best Institutionalized Culture and the Arts Program - Grand Winner
Moreover, the museum garnered 46 exhibits from 2022-2024 with an estimated worth of 100,000,000 pesos of paintings, sculptures, various art pieces, installations, galleries, the Wall of Heroes, and portraits of previous mayors of Manila.
This Ordinance seeks to preserve the vital operation of DTCAM's Manila Clock Tower. In view of the foregoing, approval of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Principles and Policies. — Sections 14, 15, 16, and 17, Article XIV of the 1987 Constitution, declare that the State shall foster the preservation, enrichment, and dynamic evolution of a Filipino national culture based on the principle of unity in diversity in a climate of free artistic and intellectual expression. The Constitution likewise mandates the State to conserve, develop, promote, and popularize the nation's historical and cultural heritage and resources, as well as artistic creations. It further provides that all the country's artistic and historic wealth constitutes the cultural treasure of the nation and shall be under the protection of the State, which may regulate its disposition. Moreover, local government units (LGUs) are encouraged to enact ordinances for the protection of historical landmarks within their jurisdiction.
SEC. 2. Creation of Position. — Under the Index of Occupational Services, Position Titles, and Salary Grades in the Local Government, particularly in Education, Library, Museum, and Archival Services, the position of Museum Curator 1 with salary grade 22 shall be created, as follows:
1.) Basic Salary: 74,736.00 | PERA: 2,000 | Mid Year/ Year End: 149,672 | GSIS/Gov’t Share: 8,980.32 | Cash Gift: 5,000 | Pag-IBIG: 200 | ECC: 100 | PhilHealth: 1,870 | Clothing: 7,000
Amount Annual:
1.) Basic Salary: 898,032 | PERA: 24,000 | Mid-Year/ Year End: 149,672 | GSIS/Gov’t Share: 107,763.84 | Cash Gift: 5,000 | Pag-IBIG: 2,400 | ECC: 1,200 | PhilHealth: 22,450 | Clothing: 7,000
Total: 1,217,518.64
SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers, and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC) Rules and Regulations, and other relevant laws.
SEC. 4. Appointments. — The employment and appointment of those who will be occupying the herein-created positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission and other relevant agencies.
SEC. 5. Appropriations. — The amount necessary for the creation of Museum Curator 1 — SG 22 shall be charged against the Special Activities Fund (SAF) — Personal Services (PS) of the FY 2025 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject-created positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla of Personnel of the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM).
SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations or parts thereof inconsistent thereto are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.
SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.
This Ordinance was enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 25, 2025.
PRESIDED BY:
BAGONG PILIPINAS
Republic of the Philippines
CITY COUNCIL
Manila

ERRATUM
Please be informed of the following corrections in Ordinance No. 9104, entitled, An Ordinance Creating the Position of Museum Curator 1 - SG 22 under the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts Manila (DTCAM) and Appropriating Funds Therefore, enacted by the City Council of Manila last February 25, 2025.
On Section 5, Appropriations, the source of funds for the creation of the said position will be changed as per recommendation, which is underlined below:
SEC 5. Appropriations. — The amount necessary for the creation of Museum Curator 1 — SG 22 shall be sourced from the available City Executive Funds for the 2026 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject-created positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla of Personnel of the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM).
As corrected, it should be read as follows:
SEC 5. Appropriations. — The amount necessary for the creation of Museum Curator 1— SG 22 shall be charged against the Special Activities Fund (SAF) — Personal Services (PS) of the FY 2025 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject-created positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla of Personnel of the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM).
short_text: The City of Manila has created a new position called Museum Curator 1 under the Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts Manila (DTCAM), with a salary grade of 22. This position will help keep the Manila Clock Tower Museum running smoothly. The museum, which highlights Manila's history, is a popular cultural spot and has won several awards. The new position will help ensure the museum continues to thrive and preserve its valuable exhibits.

ORDINANCE NO. 9103

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE PROJECT TITLE OF A PROJECT UNDER THE SPECIAL PURPOSE APPROPRIATIONS OF THE FY 2025 EXECUTIVE BUDGET AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Ordinance No. 9075 or the FY 2025 Annual Executive Budget included the project,
entitled: "Completion of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center" under the Special
Purpose Appropriations.

However, the Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW) requested the
change of project title from "Completion of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center" to "Continuation of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center (Phase II)" while maintaining the same approved budget under the FY 2025 Annual Budget.

The Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW) deemed it necessary
due to revision in the structural design, particularly in the foundation works of the building, which has impacted the overall project scope of works. The changes are essential to ensure the structural integrity and long-term stability of the facility, aligning with the safety standards and engineering best practices.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT.

SECTION 1. The project title of a project included under the Special Purpose
Appropriations of the FY 2025 Executive Budget is hereby amended to read as follows:

FROM 

Other Infrastructure Assets:

Completion of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center

TO

Other Infrastructure Assets:

Continuation of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center Maynila Center (Phase II)


SEC. 2. Amendatory and Repealing Clause. — All local ordinances, resolutions,
rules and regulations or part thereof that are inconsistent with the provisions of this
Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 25, 2025.
short_text: This ordinance changes the project title in the Special Purpose Appropriations of the 2025 Manila Executive Budget from “Completion of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center” to “Continuation of Ten (10) Storey Kalinga sa Maynila Center (Phase II)”. The change reflects updates in the building’s foundation and structural design to meet safety standards. The budget remains unchanged.

ORDINANCE NO. 9101
AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING KATUWANG SA DIWA AT GAWA SA MASAGANANG ANI AT MATAAS NA KITA (KADIWA) NG PANGULO (KNP) IN THE CITY OF MANILA



EXPLANATORY NOTE

This Ordinance aims to institutionalize the Katuwang sa Diwa at Gawa para sa Masaganang Ani at Mataas na Kita (KADIWA) program in the City of Manila, in line with Republic Act No. 7160 or the “Local Government Code of 1991” and the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) Memorandum Circular No. 2024-003. The program is designed to foster inclusive economic growth by encouraging local business incubation, enterprise development, market linkages, and facilitating job creation and livelihood. As part of the National Government's efforts to alleviate the effects of the calamities, disasters, and the COVID-19 pandemic and revive the economic growth and development of local enterprises, the Department of Agriculture (DA) launched the Katuwang sa Diwa at Gawa para sa Masaganang Ani at Mataas na Kita (KADIWA) program. This initiative aligns with the 2019 program of the Department of Agriculture (DA) by virtue of the "Sagip Saka Act,” which promotes food security, sustainable local economic activities, and direct support to farmers, fisherfolk, and micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs).

The KADIWA program, as an ordinance in the City of Manila, could significantly benefit residents by enhancing access to affordable and high-quality agricultural products while supporting local farmers. The program can reduce intermediaries and establish lower prices of goods for low-income households. Aside from promoting sustainability in the consumption of local products, this program supports public welfare goals, addressing food affordability and livelihood in the city.

This Ordinance shall provide a framework for the collaboration of various government agencies, including the Department of Agriculture (DA), Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE), and local government units (LGUs), to enhance the farm-to-consumer supply chain. By institutionalizing KADIWA, Manila aims to empower the local farming and business community through direct market access, delivery of affordable goods, and economic sustainability. This measure also seeks to promote food security and sustainability while benefiting both producers and consumers in the locality.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Councilor, Second District
Manila

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “KADIWA Institutionalization Ordinance of the City of Manila.”

SEC. 2. Purpose. — This Ordinance is intended to institutionalize the implementation of KADIWA ng Pangulo (KNP) in the City of Manila in partnership with the Department of Agriculture (DA), Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE), and Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) with the aim of attaining the following:
a. To ensure food security, stabilize prices, and guarantee availability of affordable, fresh, and nutritious food for the residents of the city;
b. To provide opportunity for MSMEs to market their products through local product promotion and eliminating as many marketing layers, allowing producers to earn bigger income directly selling their products instead of using trader-intermediaries;
c. To support local farmers and fisherfolk by providing them with a stable market for their product; and
d. To create a direct link between producers and consumers.

SEC. 3. Scope and Coverage. — For this purpose, the KNP shall cover three (3) market areas or product clusters, particularly:
a. Agricultural products, such as rice, vegetables, and fruits of farmers from various provinces;
b. Processed goods, both food and non-food, produced by MSMEs as One Town, One Product (OTOP) of different localities; and
c. Mercato stalls (ready-to-eat food) for micro-enterprises of the City of Manila.

SEC. 4. Definition of Terms. — The City Government of Manila shall establish and maintain KADIWA Outlet, a designated marketplace or facility where agricultural products are sold directly by farmers and fisherfolk to consumers, in strategic locations within the City, running every 15th and 30th of the month beginning January 30, 2024, to ensure accessibility to all residents.

As used in this Ordinance, KADIWA refers to Katuwang sa Diwa at Gawa para sa Masaganang Ani at Mataas na Kita (KADIWA), launched and spearheaded by the Department of Agriculture (DA) in 2019, in collaboration with farmers and enterprises registered in the Sagip Saka registry or Registry System for Basic Sectors Agriculture (RSBSA), which seeks to empower the farming community by providing a direct and effective farm-to-consumer food supply chain. The implementation of this program is reiterated by President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. during his State of the Nation Address (SONA), citing “The KNP system enabled the public to buy goods at cheaper rates and the farmers to sell their crops without having to worry about transportation costs.”

One Town, One Product (OTOP) is a priority stimulus program for Micro, Small, and Medium-scale enterprises (MSMEs) as the government's intervention to drive inclusive local economic growth. Through the leadership of the Department of Trade and Industry, OTOP enables localities and communities to determine, develop, support, and promote products or services that are rooted in its local culture, community resources, creativity, connection, and competitive advantage.

SEC. 5. Content and Guidelines. —
a. KNP shall run every 15th and 30th of every month starting January 30, 2024.
b. The grand launch held on July 17, 2023, commenced the opening of KNP nationwide.
c. KNP shall have 3 market areas or product clusters:

Agricultural products such as rice, vegetables, and fruits of farmers for the various provinces;

Processed goods, both food and non-food products by MSMEs as OTOP products of different localities;

Mercato stalls (ready-to-eat food) for micro-enterprises of the host LGU.
d. The venue of the KNP may be in a closed or an open space area, provided there are available tents, tables, chairs. It should be well-ventilated and with areas that can accommodate stalls for selling products, an area for eating, and parking.
e. No registration fee shall be collected from participating farmer/MSME merchants nor from visiting consumers.

SEC. 6. Implementing Agency. — With the support of key implementing agencies within the Manila City Hall, the program seeks to strengthen local industries, empower farmers and MSMEs, and create accessible markets for high-quality, affordable products, benefiting both producers and the community.

Implementing Agency/City Departments

Market Administration

Bureau of Permits

Manila Public and Employment Service Office (PESO)

Manila Barangay Bureau

Public Information Office

Department of Public Services

Social Welfare Bureau

Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau

Manila Tourism and Cultural Affairs

City Treasurer’s Office

Parks Development Office

Roles and Responsibilities

Identify and allocate market spaces for vendors

Expedite permits for vendors and ensure compliance with local regulations

Recruit and mobilize TUPAD beneficiaries for labor support (e.g., set-up, logistics)

Facilitate barangay-level coordination for venue preparation and crowd management

Organize information and education campaigns (IECs) to raise awareness about KNP

Oversee sanitation and clean-up of KNP venues before, during, and after events

Identify and mobilize low-income families, MSMEs, and cooperatives as beneficiaries

Ensure smooth traffic flow around the sites by deploying traffic enforcers

Promote KNP as a local and economic cultural event

Monitor and manage financial transactions

Allocate and prepare public spaces such as parks and open areas for market stalls

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect within sixty (60) days after its publication in any newspaper of local or general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 13, 2025.
short_text: This law makes the KADIWA program official in Manila. The program is focused on improving food security, lowering prices, and helping local businesses grow by allowing farmers and small businesses (MSMEs) to sell directly to consumers. It aims to provide affordable, fresh, and healthy food while supporting local farmers. By cutting out middlemen, the program helps reduce costs for consumers and gives local producers a better income.

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING THE HONORABLE MAYOR MARIA SHEILAH “HONEY” H. LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, THE AUTHORITY TO CAUSE THE ACQUISITION, EITHER BY EXPROPRIATION, NEGOTIATED SALE, OR BY ANY OTHER LEGAL MEANS, OF THOSE CERTAIN PARCELS OF LAND COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 287144 WITH A TOTAL LAND AREA OF EIGHT HUNDRED FIFTY-SIX SQUARE METERS AND FIFTEEN SQUARE DECIMETERS (856.15 SQ. M.) AND TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 002-2022000657 WITH AN AREA OF EIGHT HUNDRED FIFTY-SIX SQUARE METERS AND FIFTEEN SQUARE DECIMETERS (856.15 SQ. M.), OR WITH A COMBINED AGGREGATE TOTAL LAND AREA OF ONE THOUSAND SEVEN HUNDRED TWELVE SQUARE METERS AND THIRTY SQUARE DECIMETERS (1,712.30 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, SITUATED AT LAGUNA EXTENSION, ABAD SANTOS, TONDO IN THE SECOND DISTRICT OF MANILA, INTENDED FOR THE LANDLESS PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND FOR ITS EVENTUAL DISTRIBUTION TO THE MEMBERS OF LAGUNA EXTENSION-ABAD SANTOS TENANTS ASSOCIATION (LEASTA) INC., APPROPRIATING AN AMOUNT NECESSARY THEREOF
SPONSORED BY:
HON. ERNESTO C. ISIP, JR.
Majority Floor Leader

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Her Honor, Maria Sheilah "Honey" H. Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, the City Mayor, is hereby authorized to cause the acquisition, either by negotiation, expropriation purchase, or by any other legal means, of those certain parcels of land with a combined aggregate total land area of One Thousand Seven Hundred Twelve Square Meters and Thirty Decimeters (1,712.30 SQ. M.), more or less, situated at Laguna Extension, Abad Santos, Tondo in the Second District of Manila, covered by Transfer Certificate Title No. 287144, registered under the names of Elena G. Yu, Alexander Dimson G. Yu, and Carter Dennis G. Yu and Transfer Certificate Title No. 002-2022000657, under the names of Ed Bernard S. Cai, Jess Marlon S. Cai, and Claire Noreen S. Cai, for the benefit of the actual and bonafide tenants/occupants thereat, under the Land-for-the Landless Program of the City of Manila, appropriating an amount necessary thereof, identified as follows:

TCT No.: 287144 | Lot No.: 1 LRA PCS 34946 | Measurement: 856.15 Sq. M.

TCT No.: 002-2022000657 | Lot No.: 2 LRA PCS 3496 | Measurement: 856.15 Sq. M.

SECTION 2.
The aforementioned parcels of land, when acquired, shall be subdivided and resold at cost and/or payable on installment basis for a term not exceeding twenty (20) years to the qualified actual and bonafide tenants or occupants thereat.

SECTION 3.
Appropriation Clause. — The amount of Seventy-Five Million Six Hundred Eighty-One Thousand Four Hundred Sixty-Eight Pesos and Twenty-Six Centavos (PhP75,681,468.26), or as may be necessary, is hereby recommended to be appropriated out of the unappropriated funds existing in the City Treasury for the implementation of this Ordinance, subject to the availability of funds as may be certified to by the City Treasurer.

SECTION 4.
Beneficiaries. — The final determination of the qualified beneficiaries by USO-Manila shall come from the official list of individuals from the Laguna Ext.-Abad Santos Tenants Association (LEASTA) Inc.

SECTION 5.
Separability Clause. — If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 6.
Repealing Clause. — All Ordinances, rules and regulations that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby amended accordingly.

SECTION 7.
Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 30, 2025.
short_text: The City of Manila has passed a law that gives Mayor Maria Sheilah "Honey" H. Lacuna-Pangan the power to acquire land in the Laguna Extension area, Abad Santos, Tondo. The land, totaling 1,712.30 square meters, will be used for the Land-for-the-Landless Program to help qualified tenants in the area. The land will be purchased through negotiation or other legal means, and then resold to the tenants at its original price. The total amount set aside for this land acquisition is PhP75,681,468.26.

d.) The Project shall create and/or protect a beneficial local economic trend by providing livelihood and/or employment to its Barangay and/or District residents;

e.) The Project shall continuously be socially acceptable to the nearby residents by
assuring that its existence and operation shall not adversely affect community heritage,
public health, safety and welfare:

ORDINANCE NO. 9097

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF GRATUITY PAY TO CONTRACT OF SERVICE AND JOB ORDER WORKERS IN THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 28, SERIES OF 2024 AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF FIFTY MILLION NINE HUNDRED FIFTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PhP50,955,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES



EXPLANATORY NOTE
On December 19, 2024, President Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr. issued Administrative Order (AO) No. 28, Series of 2024, entitled “Authorizing the Grant of Gratuity Pay to Contract of Service and Job Order Workers in the Government for Fiscal Year 2024”.

AO No. 28 provided that granting a year-end Gratuity Pay to Contract of Service (COS) and Job Order (JO) workers is a well-deserved recognition of their hard work in implementing programs, projects, and activities, and their pivotal role in the delivery of government services amidst the present socio-economic challenges, considering that they do not enjoy benefits accorded to government employees as they have no employer-employee relationship with the government.

Section 5 of AO No. 28 mandated that local government units (LGUs) are enjoined to adopt in their respective offices the grant of Gratuity Pay to workers whose services are engaged through COS and JO, utilizing appropriate and available funding sources from their respective local government funds. The corresponding supplemental budget for the purpose shall be enacted by the local Sangguniang concerned within FY 2024.

On December 20, 2024, the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) issued Budget Circular No. 2024-8 regarding the guidelines on the grant of Gratuity Pay to COS and JO workers for FY 2024.

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that the LGUs shall exercise the powers that are essential to the promotion of general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other things, the enhancement of economic prosperity, full employment, and social justice, and preserve the comfort and convenience of its inhabitants.

In view of the foregoing, I seek the support of my colleagues for the passage of this proposed ordinance.

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:

SECTION 1. Gratuity Pay.
The grant of the one-time Gratuity Pay for FY 2024 not exceeding Five Thousand Pesos (PhP5,000.00) to Job Order and Contract of Service personnel in the City Government of Manila is hereby authorized subject to the conditions under Administrative Order No. 28, s. 2024 and Budget Circular No. 2024-8 of the Department of Budget and Management.

SECTION 2. Fund Source.
The Gratuity Pay in the total amount of Fifty Million Nine Hundred Fifty-Five Thousand Pesos (PhP50,955,000.00) shall be funded from the Special Activities Fund - Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (SAF-MOOE) under Special Purpose Appropriations (SPAs) of the FY 2024 Executive Budget.

Attached are the following details:
Annex A – Budgetary Requirement for Gratuity Pay under the SAF-MOOE of the SPAs of the FY 2024 Executive Budget.

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 26, 2024.
short_text:
Giving One-Time Bonus to Contract and Job Order Workers in Manila

This ordinance allows the City Government of Manila to give a one-time bonus of up to PhP5,000 to workers hired on a contract or job order basis for the year 2024. These workers play an important role in helping the government carry out various programs and services, but they don't receive the same benefits as regular employees. The total money needed for this bonus is PhP50,955,000, which will be taken from the city's 2024 budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 9093

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE CITY INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE/UNIT UNDER THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES
EXPLANATORY NOTE

Republic Act No. 3456 otherwise known as the "Internal Auditing Act of 1962",
provided for the creation, organization and operation of an Internal Audit Services/Unit
(IAS/U) in all government agencies which shall assist management to achieve an efficient
and effective fiscal administration and performance of agency affairs and functions.

Department of Budget and Management (DBM) Budget Circular No. 2004-4 dated
March 22, 2004 provided for the policy guidelines in the organization, staffing, positions and salary grades of the IAS/U in departments, agencies, GOCCS and including the local government units (LGUs) concerned.

Section 3(b) of Republic Act No. 7160 otherwise known as the Local Government
Code of 1991, mandated the establishment of an accountable, efficient and dynamic
organizational structure and operating mechanism that will meet the priority needs and
service requirements of its communities in every local government unit.

The creation therefore of the City Internal Audit Service/Unit is necessary since it
provides independent assurance that the City of Manila's overall operations is effective
and that it is ensured that there is compliance by the City Government of relevant laws,
rules and regulations.

I seek the support of my colleagues in this august Chamber for the passage of this
proposed ordinance.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. - This Ordinance shall be called the "The Internal Audit
Service/Unit Ordinance of the City of Manila" for brevity.

Legal Bases for the Creation of Internal Audit Service/Unit:

a. Republic Act No. 3456 (Internal Auditing Act of 1962), as amended by
Republic Act No. 4177, which created and organized an IAS/U in all
government agencies to help management achieve an efficient and
effective fiscal administration and assist in the performance of agency
affairs and functions.

b. Presidential Decree No. 1 (Reorganizing the Executive Branch of the
National Government), which abolished the IAS/U created under R.A.
No. 3456, as amended by R.A. No. 4177. The function was subsequently
merged with the Management Division of the Financial and Management
Service in the Department pursuant to Item 3, Article IV, Chapter I, Part IV
of the P.D.

c. Section 1 of Administrative Order No. 119 dated 29 March 1989, which
mandated government entities to strengthen their internal control systems
and organize systems and procedures coordination with DBM.

d. Memorandum Order No. 277 dated 17 January 1990, directing the DBM to
promulgate the necessary rules, regulations, and circulars for the
strengthening of the internal control systems of government offices,
agencies, government-owned or controlled corporations (GOCCs), and
LGUs.

e. Section 3(b) of R.A. 7160 (The Local Government Code of 1991), which
mandated the establishment of an accountable, efficient and dynamic
organizational structure and operating mechanisms that will meet the
priority needs and service requirements of its communities in every LGU,
Section 474(b) further provides for the qualifications, powers and duties of
an Accountant, among which is the mandate to take charge of both the
accounting and internal audit services of the LGU.

f. Administrative Order No. 278 dated 28 April 1992 (Directing the
Strengthening of the Internal Control Systems of Government Financial
Institutions (GFIs) and LGUs, in their Operations), which provided for the
functions, duties and activities of the IAS/U it also provides that IAS shall be
detached from all functions of routine operating character.

g. Administrative Order No. 70 dated 14 April 2003 (Strengthening of the
Internal Control Systems of Government Offices, Agencies, GOCCs,
including GFIs, State Universities and Colleges (SUCs) and LGUs, which
reiterated the authority for the creation of the IAS/U and its functions.

h. DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4 dated 22 March 2004 (Guidelines on the
Organization and Staffing of IASs) which provided for the policy guidelines
in the organization, staffing, positions and salary grades of the IAS/U in
Departments/Agencies/GOCCS/GFIs/LGUs concerned.

i. DBM-CSC Joint Resolution No. 1 dated 12 May 2006 (Rationalization
Program's Organization and Staffing Standards and Guidelines), which
provided for the creation of the IAS/U with its functions in line with Executive
Order No. 366, as supplemented by CSC MC No. 12 s. 2006 issued on 22 June 2006.

SEC. 2. Creation. — The Office of the City Internal Audit Service/Unit under the
Office of the Mayor is hereby created.
SEC. 3. Functions of the City Internal Audit Service/Unit. -

a. Advise the Local Chief Executive (LCE) or Sanggunian on all matters relating to management control and operations audit of the executive or legislative branches;

b. Conduct management and operations audit of the city's functions, programs, projects, activities and outputs and determine the degree of compliance with their mandate, policies, government regulations, established objectives, systems and procedures/processes, and contractual obligations;

c. Review and appraise systems and procedures, organizational structures,
asset management practices, financial and management records, reports,
and performance standards of the City;

d. Analyze and evaluate management deficiencies and assist top management by recommending realistic courses of action; and

e. Perform such other related duties and responsibilities as may be assigned or delegated by the LCE or as required by law.

The City Internal Audit Service/Unit shall consist of two (2) sections, namely: the
Management Audit Section and the Operations Audit Section.

Management Audit Section

The Management Audit Section shall evaluate the achievement of the control
objectives, which include the safeguarding of assets, checking the accuracy and
reliability of accounting data, adherence to managerial policies, compliance with laws,
rules, and regulations by utilizing internal auditing methods. It has the following functions:

a. Conduct management audit of activities of the City and determine the
degree of compliance with the mandate, policies, government regulations,
established objectives, systems and procedures/processes, and contractual
obligations (Section 2.4b, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5 and Section
1.1.2, AO 278, s. 1992);

b. Review and appraise systems and procedures/processes, organizational
structure, assets management practices, financial and management
records, reports, performance standards of the City (Section 2.4c, DBM
Circular Letter No. 2008-5);

c. Verification and analysis of financial and management data to ascertain if
attendant management information systems generate data or reports that
are complete, accurate, and valid (Section 4.1.1.2, DBM Budget Circular
No. 2004-4);

d. Ascertain the reliability and integrity of financial and management
information and the means used to identify, measure, classify, and report
such information (Section 1.1.1, AO No. 278, s. 4992);

e. Ascertain the extent to which the assets and other resources of the institutions are accounted for and safeguarded from losses of all kinds (Section 1.1.3, AO 278, s. 1992):

f. Review and evaluate the soundness, adequacy and application of
accounting, financial and management controls and promote the most
effective control at reasonable cost (Section 1.1.4, AO 278, s. 1992);

g. Evaluate the quality of performance of groups/individuals in carrying out
their assigned responsibilities (Section 1.1.6, AO 278, s. 1992):

h. Perform functions of a protective nature, such as prevention and detection
of fraud or dishonesty; review cases involving misuse of agency property;
and checking of transactions with outside parties (Section 4,1,1,4, DBM
Budget Circular No. 2004-4); and
i. Perform miscellaneous services, including special investigations and
assistance to outside contacts such as COA (Section 4.1.1.5, DBM Budget
Circular No. 2004-4).

Operations Audit Section

The Operations Audit Section shall evaluate the extent of compliance and
ascertain the effective, efficient, ethical and economical execution of operations by
utilizing internal auditing methods. This Section is tasked to perform the following
functions:

a. Conduct operations of activities of the City and its departments and
determine the degree of compliance with the mandate, policies, government
regulations, established objectives, systems and procedures and processes
and contractual obligations (Section 2.4b, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5);

b. Review and appraise systems and procedures/processes, organizational
structure, operations practices, operations records, reports, and
performance standards of the city and the departments covered
(Section 2.4c, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5);

c. Verify and analyze operations data to ascertain if attendant management
information systems generate data or reports that are complete, accurate,
and valid (Section 4.1.1.2, DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4);

d. Ascertain the reliability and integrity of operational information and the means used to identify, measure, classify, and report such information
(Section 1.1.1, A.O No.278 s, 1992);

e. Review operations or programs to ascertain whether or not results are
consistent with established objectives and goals, and whether or not such
programs are being carried out as planned (Section 1.1.5, A.O. 278
8. 1992);

f. Evaluate the quality of performance of groups/individuals in carrying out
their assigned responsibilities (Section 1.1.6, A.O. 278 s. 1992);

g. Recommend courses of action on operational deficiencies observed
(Section 1.1.7, AO. 278 s, 1992):

h. Perform functions of a protective nature, such as prevention and detection
of fraud or dishonesty; review of cases involving misuse of agency property;
and checking of transactions with outside parties (Section 4.1.1.4, DBM
Circular No. 2004-04: and

i. Perform miscellaneous services, including special investigations and
assistance to outside contacts such as COA (Section 4.1.1.5, DBM Budget
Circular No. 2004-4).

SEC. 4. Organizational Structure. — The City Internal Audit Service/Unit shall be headed by an Internal Auditor V with salary grade 24-1 with an Internal Auditor IV at salary grade 22-1 as assistant.

The City Internal Audit Service shall be staffed as follows:
Position Title                 Number of Personnel        Salary Grade        Rate(annual)
                     CITY INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE
Internal Auditor V                1                    24                PHP 1,1129,584.00
Internal Auditor IV                1                    24                PHP 898,032.00

                     MANAGEMENT AUDIT SECTION
Internal Auditor II                1                    15                PHP 460,956.00
Internal Auditor I                1                    11                PHP 342,144.00

                     Operations Audit Section
Internal Auditor II                1                     15                PHP 460,956.00
Internal Auditor I                1                     11                PHP 342,144.00


SEC. 5. Coordination with Offices and other agencies. —

The City Internal Audit Service/Unit shall be afforded independence and
cooperation to carry out its powers and function to render impartial and unbiased
judgement essential in the conduct of internal audit and in the gathering of evidence to
support its findings and recommendations.

The City Internal Audit Service shall coordinate with all departments within the City
Government of Manila and other government agencies as well as NGOs to effectively
carry out its powers and functions.

SEC. 6. Funding Requirements. — The amount necessary for the effective and
continuous implementation of this ordinance shall be sourced from any unprogrammed
funds of the City.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — All other laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and
regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of the Ordinance are hereby
repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.
short_text: This ordinance establishes the City Internal Audit Service/Unit (IAS/U) in Manila to ensure effective, accountable, and law-compliant operations of the city government. The IAS/U is tasked with conducting management and operations audits, advising the mayor, and evaluating compliance, efficiency, and fraud prevention across departments. The ordinance includes detailed staffing, functions, structure, and funding provisions.

ORDINANCE NO. 9091
AN ORDINANCE EXEMPTING FROM PAYMENT OF TRANSPORT FARE IN RIDING CITY-OPERATED E-TRIKE VEHICLES OF ALL THE SENIOR CITIZENS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES (PWDs) CURRENTLY RESIDING IN THE CITY OF MANILA, AND PROVIDING DISCOUNT RATES TO ALL STUDENTS CURRENTLY ENROLLED IN EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA

Explanatory Note
It is the policy of the City Government of Manila to recognize the rights of senior citizens, PWDs, and all City of Manila students for their contribution to nation-building.

The Office of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) has formally endorsed to the Committee on Transportation the Fare Matrix of E-Trike Vehicles in the City of Manila.

All senior citizens, PWDs, and students must present their respective IDs to the E-Trike driver to avail of the free or discounted fare.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title.
This Ordinance shall be known as the "2024 Senior Citizens Free E-Trike Rides and Students Discounted E-Trike Rides Ordinance," for brevity.

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy.
It shall be the policy of the City of Manila to give priority in providing basic services to the elderly, differently-abled persons, and students.

SEC. 3. Scope of Coverage.
Senior citizen residents in the City of Manila shall be exempted from paying transport fares in e-trike vehicles, and students enrolled in educational institutions shall be provided a 20% discount.

SEC. 4. Penalties.
The following penalties shall be imposed on drivers and operators of e-trike vehicles for violation of this Ordinance:

1st Offense – Two Thousand Pesos (PhP2,000.00)

2nd Offense – Three Thousand Pesos (PhP3,000.00)

3rd Offense – Five Thousand Pesos (PhP5,000.00) and Revocation of rights to drive or operate an E-Trike Vehicle

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 10, 2024.
short_text:
Free E-Trike Rides for Manila Seniors and PWDs, Fare Discount for Students

The City of Manila has passed a law that gives free E-Trike rides to senior citizens and persons with disabilities (PWDs) who live in the city. It also gives students a 20% discount on E-Trike fares, as long as they are enrolled in schools within Manila.

To get the free or discounted ride, passengers must show a valid ID to the E-Trike driver.

E-Trike drivers or operators who do not follow this rule will be fined:

PhP2,000 for the first offense

PhP3,000 for the second offense

PhP5,000 and their license to drive or operate the E-Trike will be revoked on the third offense

ORDINANCE NO. 9089

AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING AND STRENGTHENING THE SOCIAL PROGRAMS AND SERVICES OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES
EXPLANATORY NOTE

Under Section 2 of Republic Act No. 11292 otherwise known as the "The Seal of
Good Local Governance Act of 2019", "it is hereby declared the policy of the State to
recognize the good performance of local government units (LGUs) in transparency and
accountability in the use of public funds, preparedness for challenges posed by disasters, sensitivity to the needs of vulnerable and marginalized sectors of society, implementation of health programs, investment and employment promotion, protection of constituency from threats to life and damage to property and safeguarding the integrity of the environment..."

On December 9, 2024, the City of Manila was awarded with the Seal of Good Local
Governance (SGLG) for the very first time during the National Awarding Ceremony for
National Capital Region - LGU. The SGLG award was approved by the Department of the
Interior and Local Government (DILG) Secretary and Chairperson of the Council of Good
Local Governance Juanito Victor C. Remulla.

The City of Manila was able to secure the said SGLG award through the
cooperative efforts of the different executive departments, offices, bureaus, committees
and councils of the Manila City Government and the Manila City Council led by Honorable
City Mayor Maria Sheilah "Honey" H. Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS and Honorable
Vice-Mayor John Marvin C. “Yul Servo" Nieto, respectively.

It may be emphasized that the social programs and services being implemented
by the City Government of Manila played a significant role in clinching the SGLG award
considering that Section 3 of R.A. No. 11292 required the improved "performance in the
following areas by:

(c) Demonstrating the readiness to help and sensitivity to the needs of vulnerable
and marginalized sectors of society;

(d) Setting-up, implementing and sustaining health policies and programs that
would strengthen and promote the well-being, healthy lifestyle and safety of the
public, ensuring that all individuals especially the vulnerable have fair
opportunities for better health;

(e) Instituting education reforms and programs to improve the quality of education
in the country;

(g) Protecting constituents from threats to life and damage to property;"

Accordingly, this Ordinance seeks. to institutionalize and strengthen the social
programs and services of the City of Manila pursuant to the provisions of Section 3 of
R.A. No. 11292 which mandates the City's commitment to continually progress and
improve our performance in the above-enumerated areas of local governance to promote
the general welfare and improve the quality of life of all residents of Manila.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. - This Ordinance shall be known as "An Ordinance to
Institutionalize and Strengthen the Social Programs and Services of the City of Manila”.

SEC. 2. Purpose. - The social programs and services of the City of Manila is
hereby institutionalized and strengthened by ensuring its continuing implementation and
committing to the operational improvement of said programs and services. These social
programs and services are enumerated, but not limited to, as follows:

1. Implementation of the programs for senior citizens to address the needs of the
elderly resident of Manila to protect and recognize them for the attainment of
more meaningful and productive lifestyle including the senior citizens' One
Thousand Pesos (PhP1,000.00) monthly allowance, birthday gifts and
Christmas gifts, as well as One Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP100,000.00)
centenarian cash gifts.

2. Program services for person with disability (PWD) which covers the implementation of the Magna Carta for disabled persons and processing of new/renewal of applications for PWD identification cards, including the Five Hundred Pesos (PhP500.00) monthly allowance for PWDS.

3. Women Welfare Program (women on especially difficult circumstances), which covers the implementation of the Solo Parent's Welfare Act of 2000 and the processing of new/renewal of applications for solo parent identification cards, including the Five Hundred Pesos (PhP500.00) monthly allowance for solo parents.

4. Free quality and complete basic education for Manileños at public schools in the City of Manila, including Five Hundred Pesos (PhP500.00) monthly allowance
for senior public high school students to defray their expenses for school work.

5. Free quality higher education for Manileños at the Universidad De Manila (UdM) and the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM), including the Two Thousand Pesos (PhP2,000.00) cash gift for college graduates and One Thousand Pesos (PhP1,000.00) monthly allowance for college students of the said universities to defray their expenses for job hunting and school work, respectively.

6. Pamaskong Handog sa Pamilyang Manileño which aims to distribute Christmas food boxes to Manileño families to foster close knit relations among family members and support them with food and sustenance specially during the celebration of the yuletide season.

7. Unang Abuloy ng Maynila aims to provide Three Thousand Pesos
(PhP3,000.00) and sympathy card and token equivalent of One Thousand
Pesos (PhP1,000.00) death benefit welfare assistance to express sympathy and
gratitude to its departed constituents and provide emotion and financial support
to their families considering the rising cost of burial services nowadays.

8. Kalinga sa Maynila Program is the flagship program of the Manila City Government which encompasses all its programs, projects and services specially referring to social protection and social amelioration which directly benefits its constituents including its community-based activities to bring the services of the Manila City Government directly to its residents.

9. Kasama Program provides emergency employment for displaced workers,
underemployed and seasonal workers in the City of Manila. There are also
livelihood programs, vocational and technical skills training, employment
regeneration assistance program for the promotion of full employment among
the resident of Manila.

10. People's Day which is compassionately dedicated to attend to cancer and
dialysis patients and those with critical illnesses who are residents of Manila
by providing them with premium medical services and financial assistance to
promote a dignified and better quality of life for said patients.

11. Crisis Intervention Program (CIP) which gives financial and other assistance
to the poor, vulnerable and marginalized like burial, medical, transportation
and other aid as well as referral to National Government Agency like the
Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) and Philippine
Charity Sweepstakes Office (PCSO), etc.

12. City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund which is an inclusive social protection program to serve as safety net in the form of financial assistance of One Thousand Pesos (PhP1,000.00) given directly to Manileños to augment their income and enable the people of Manila to purchase much needed food and other supplies for their daily needs and subsistence to immediately and effectively cushion the economic risks and shocks of the high prices of basic commodities and high cost of living due to the rising inflation.

13. Early Childhood Care and Development Program serving pre-schoolers in
daycare centers, home-based and mobile daycare centers including feeding
programs.

14. Programs for victims of disaster wherein all affected families are rendered
services such as evacuation, food assistance, and other amenities, including
financial aid for victims of fire and other disasters.

15. Programs for informal settlers wherein all affected individuals and families are
provided with food assistance/food stuff, census during dialogue and
organization of relocation.

16. Social protection program implemented in the different residential caring
institutions of the City for the stronger deterrence against abuse, exploitation
and discrimination of abandoned, neglected, rescued, abused and orphaned
babies, children, and elderly or aged.

17. Protection of children in need of special protection where all reported cases of
abuse, neglect and abandonment are rescued and managed. After care
services are also provided for children who are victims of abuse, neglect, and
abandonment as well as children in conflict with the law (CICL).

SEC. 3. Implementing Departments. - The implementation of this Ordinance is subject to the guidelines from the relevant departments, offices and bureaus of the City Government of Manila and all existing budgeting, accounting and auditing laws, rules and regulations.

SEC. 4. Appropriations. - The sources of funds for the aforementioned social programs and services shall be derived from the maintenance and other operating expenses - donation account and other relevant accounts under the Annual Appropriations Ordinance including the FYs 2024 and 2025 Executive Budgets and succeeding budgets of Manila City.
SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances, rules and regulations, or parts
thereof, in conflict or inconsistent with any provisions of this Ordinance are hereby
repealed and modified or amended accordingly.

SEC. 6. Separability Clause. - If any provision of this Ordinance is declared
invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and
subsisting.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 10,
2024.
short_text: The City of Manila has officially institutionalized its various social programs and services to ensure their continuous implementation and improvement. These include monthly financial aid for senior citizens, PWDs, solo parents, and students; free education; employment programs; disaster response; early childhood development; health assistance for critical patients; and welfare services for the vulnerable such as abused children and the elderly. The ordinance also strengthens community-based programs and offers financial support for burial costs, emergencies, and inflation-related expenses. The goal is to enhance the overall quality of life and promote inclusive development for all residents of Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 9088

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 2 FOR THE VARIOUS PRIORITY PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF ONE HUNDRED FIFTY MILLION (PHP150,000,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES
EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160 otherwise known as the Local Government
Code (LGC) of 1991 provides that "every local government unit shall exercise the powers
expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary,
appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare."

It further provides that "within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local
government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and
enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a
balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant
scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic
prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain
peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.

Further, Section 17(a) of the LGC mandates "local government units shall
endeavor to be self-reliant and shall continue exercising the powers and discharging the
duties and functions currently vested upon them. They shall also discharge the functions
and responsibilities of national agencies and offices devolved to them pursuant to this
Code.

Local government units shall likewise exercise such other powers and discharge
such other functions and responsibilities as are necessary, appropriate, or incidental to efficient and effective provisions of the basic services and facilities enumerated herein."

In line with the promotion of the general welfare and safety of the residents of
Manila through the installation of streetlights in major streets and thoroughfares, there is a need to enact a Supplemental Budget for FY 2024 to fund the implementation of the subject priority projects of the Manila City Government for the benefit of its residents pursuant to Sections 16 and 17 of the LGC.

To fund priority projects of the city, a supplemental budget may be enacted "when
supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources" (Section 321 of R.A. No. 7160) to ensure the implementation of the said priority projects for the general welfare of the residents of the City of Manila.

Pursuant to the foregoing statutory provisions, the City Treasurer and the City
Accountant has issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds as supporting document to
the promulgation of this Supplemental Budget.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The FY 2024 Supplemental Budget of the City of
Manila in the total amount of One Hundred Fifty Million Pesos (P150,000,000.00) is
hereby appropriated to fund the following priority projects of the City of Manila, to wit:

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE:

GENERAL FUND- PROPER
Department of Engineering and Public Works

Capital Outlay
Special Purpose Appropriations 20% Development Fund

Object of Expenditures:

Other Infrastructure Assets

Particulars/Purpose:
Installation of Streetlights in the following areas

1.Quinno Ext. from U.N. Ave. to Plaza Dilao 
2.Quirino Ave. from Plaza Dilao to Paz Mendoza Guanzon St.
3.Mabini Bridge from Paz Mendoza Guanzon St.Nagtahan Bridge Approach
4.New Panaderos St. from Sta.Ana Church to City Boundary
5. Juan Luna St from Moriones St. to H. Lopez Blvd.

AMOUNT:
   
1. 20,000,000.00
2. 36,000,000.00
3. 15,000,000.00
4. 45,000,000.00
5. 34,000,000.00
   150,000,000.00



Attached are the following details:

LBP Form No. 8 marked as "Annex A" - Statement of Funding Source as Certified
by the City Treasurer and City Accountant; and

LBP Form No. 9 marked “Annex B" - Statement of Supplemental Appropriation.

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared
invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.
short_text: This ordinance approves a supplemental budget of PhP150,000,000 for FY 2024 to fund the installation of streetlights in key areas of Manila. The funds, certified as available by the City Treasurer and Accountant, aim to promote public safety and urban development through infrastructure upgrades in streets such as Quirino Ave., Mabini Bridge, and Juan Luna St., among others.

ORDINANCE NO. 9087
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE REVERSION TO THE GENERAL FUND OF THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF ONE HUNDRED FIFTY MILLION PESOS (PHP150,000,000.00) UNDER SPECIAL PURPOSE APPROPRIATIONS (SPAs) - CAPITAL OUTLAY: 20% DEVELOPMENT FUND UNDER THE FY 2024 ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS ORDINANCE AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991, provides that:
“Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation, and the Sangguniang concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations subject to the provisions of this Section.”

Consistent with the foregoing statutory provision, there is a need to revert to the general fund the total amount of One Hundred Fifty Million Pesos (PhP150,000,000.00) under the Special Purpose Appropriation - Capital Outlay: 20% Development Fund under the FY 2024 Annual Appropriations Ordinance, as the said fund is free from any obligation or encumbrance and is still available to fund priority projects for the general welfare of the residents of Manila.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Reversion. — The fund under the Special Purpose Appropriations (SPAs) - Capital Outlay: 20% Development Fund under the FY 2024 Annual Appropriations Ordinance is hereby reverted to the General Fund, to wit:
Particulars Amount
Reversion of Appropriations
General Fund
Capital Outlay FY 2024 — Ord. No. 9009, aa 20% Development Fund
Other Infrastructure Assets Installation of Solar Studs (Phase V) PhP 150,000,000.00
Total PhP 150,000,000.00
Attached as Annex A — Statement of Availability of Funds

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On the motion presented by the Hon. Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly seconded, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on December 3, 2024.
short_text: The City of Manila has passed a law to return PhP150,000,000 from a fund meant for specific development projects (like installing solar studs) back to the General Fund. This amount was originally allocated for a 20% Development Fund under the city’s budget for 2024 but remains unused as the associated projects have not yet required these funds. The returned funds will now be available to support other priority projects for the welfare of the residents of Manila.

This ordinance establishes the Tourism Code of Manila, setting the official framework for promoting, regulating, and developing the city’s tourism sector. It mandates that all tourism-related businesses—including hotels, restaurants, travel agencies, transport services, theme parks, museums, and other tourist-oriented establishments—must register with the Committee on Tourism (COT) and obtain a License to Operate (Diploma) Certificate, followed by a business permit from the Business Permit and Licensing Office (BPLO).

The ordinance outlines a comprehensive registration process, which includes inspections by the Department of Engineering and Public Works, Manila Health Department, and Bureau of Fire Protection. Businesses must also submit a variety of documents such as organizational details, ownership or lease agreements, and proper immigration and labor permits for foreign staff. For primary tourism enterprises, accreditation with the Department of Tourism (DOT) is mandatory. Tourist transport operators must also secure a franchise from the Land Transport Franchise and Regulatory Board (LTFRB).

Strict compliance with national and local safety, health, and structural standards is required, and failure to meet these requirements or operate without proper licensing is subject to penalties. The ordinance emphasizes that its provisions are to be liberally construed to support the goals of economic development, cultural promotion, and enhanced national pride through tourism.
fines:

ORDINANCE NO. 9084
AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING TWO (2) VACANT POSITIONS IN THE VETERINARY INSPECTION BOARD BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD SCHEME TO GIVE WAY TO THE CREATION OF SUPERVISING ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER POSITION

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 325(d) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the “Local Government Code of 1991,” provides that:
"In cases of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations."

Furthermore, Section 76 of the same Act provides that:
"Every local government unit shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern, taking into consideration its service requirements and financial capability, subject to the minimum standards and guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission."

The Veterinary Inspection Board (VIB) was established through Republic Act No. 3865, which amended Republic Act No. 1842. Its function was further amended with the enactment of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, which provides that the Office shall formulate measures to ensure the delivery of basic services related to veterinary activities, such as during the outbreak of highly contagious and deadly diseases, and in situations resulting in the depletion of animals for work and human consumption, particularly those arising from and in the aftermath of man-made and natural disasters and calamities.

VIB seeks to enhance, support, and promote public health through the conduct of inspection of animal food products for human consumption and the provision of animal care and welfare.

The Veterinary Inspection Board of Manila, through its Officer-in-Charge, Mr. Nicanor M. Santos, Jr., DVM, is requesting the creation of a Supervising Administrative Officer position, which is essential for the operation of its Collection Division. The reason is that such a position was not available in the said division, unlike the other five (5) divisions in its current plantilla. The proposed creation of the Supervising Administrative Officer position is much-needed to sustain the delivery of basic regulatory services throughout the City of Manila and ensure that programs are consistently enforced.

In view of the foregoing, the approval of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy.
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability.
The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling down, phasing out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions.
The following positions are hereby abolished under the Veterinary Inspection Board (VIB):

TITLE OF POSITION: Veterinarian II

ITEM NO.: 77

SALARY GRADE: 16-1

RATE PER MONTH: PhP41,616.00

AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM): PhP499,392.00

TITLE OF POSITION: Veterinarian II

ITEM NO.: 78

SALARY GRADE: 16-1

RATE PER MONTH: PhP41,616.00

AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM): PhP499,392.00

TOTAL: PhP998,784.00

SEC. 3. New Plantilla Positions.
The new plantilla item is hereby created under the Veterinary Inspection Board (VIB):

TITLE OF POSITION: Supervising Administrative Officer

ITEM NO.: 37

SALARY GRADE: 22-1

RATE PER MONTH: PhP74,836.00

AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM): PhP898,032.00

SEC. 4. Qualifications, Powers, and Duties and Responsibilities.
The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. Appointments.
The employment and appointment for the created position shall be based on qualification standards and guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 6. Appropriation.
The amount necessary for the creation of the new plantilla position shall be sourced from available savings generated from the two (2) positions to be abolished for this purpose as provided for under the 2024 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the new position shall be automatically funded in the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the plantilla of personnel of the Veterinary Inspection Board (VIB).

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 29, 202
short_text:
The City of Manila has passed a law to abolish two vacant positions of Veterinarian II under the Veterinary Inspection Board (VIB). These positions are being removed to create a new position: Supervising Administrative Officer, which will help manage the operations of the VIB’s Collection Division.

The goal of this change is to improve the efficiency and quality of services provided by the VIB. The funds saved from abolishing the two positions will be used to pay for the new position.

ORDINANCE NO. 9083

AN ORDINANCE RESCHEDULING THE AMORTIZATION, CONSOLIDATION OF PROMISSORY NOTES, AND EXTENSION OF THE GRACE PERIOD ON PRINCIPAL PAYMENTS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA’S LOANS FROM THE DEVELOPMENT BANK OF THE PHILIPPINES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The City of Manila borrowed from the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) Five Billion Pesos (PhP5,000,000,000.00) as documented under Term Loan Agreements on a per project basis and Amendment to the Term Loan Agreement executed on December 18, 2019, as amended, to finance Tondominium 1, Tondominium 2, Binondominium 1, Bagong Ospital ng Maynila, and the Manila Zoological and Botanical Garden.

Likewise, the City of Manila borrowed from the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) Ten Billion Pesos (PhP10,000,000,000.00) as documented under an Omnibus Loan Agreement executed on May 28, 2021, as amended, to finance Dr. Albert Elementary School, Rosauro Almario Elementary School, Manila Science High School, San Sebastian Residences, Pedro Gil Residences, and San Lazaro Residences.

The City of Manila was heavily affected by a series of natural calamities, including typhoons and floods, which placed an extraordinary burden on the city’s financial resources. Aside from this, the city also needs to finance the mandated salary increase tranche for its employees and the increasing demand for social services.

The City of Manila, to prioritize the above, requested the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) to help the city by re-scheduling its loan amortization.

It is therefore imperative to seek the support of my dear colleagues in this August Chamber.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. The re-scheduling of the City of Manila’s Five Billion Pesos (PhP5,000,000,000.00) Term Loan and Ten Billion Pesos (PhP10,000,000,000.00) Omnibus Loan from the Development Bank of the Philippines is hereby approved and ratified.

SEC. 2. The extension of the grace period for the unreleased portion under the Ten Billion Pesos (PhP10,000,000,000.00) Omnibus Loan is hereby approved and ratified.

SEC. 3. The consolidation of the promissory notes of the City of Manila’s Five Billion Pesos (PhP5,000,000,000.00) Term Loan and Ten Billion Pesos (PhP10,000,000,000.00) Omnibus Loan is hereby approved and ratified.

SEC. 4. Any and all existing and subsequent requests by the city for modification/revision and/or amendment to be made on the loan’s approved terms and conditions specified in the Loan Agreement, Security Agreement, and Loan Documents are hereby authorized and ratified.

SEC. 5. Any ordinance or parts thereof, inconsistent with this enactment, is hereby repealed or amended accordingly.

SEC. 6. Should this Ordinance or any part thereof be declared unlawful, invalid, or unconstitutional, the original terms and conditions of the Loan Agreements with the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) shall be reinstated.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect after its publication in two newspapers of general circulation shall have been complied with.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 29, 2024.
short_text:
This ordinance allows the City of Manila to reschedule its loan payments for two large loans from the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP), totaling PhP15 billion. The loans were used to fund major city projects like Tondominium, Binondominium, public hospitals, schools, and housing developments. Due to financial strain from natural disasters and increasing city expenses, the ordinance approves:

Delayed loan amortization payments,

An extended grace period for unreleased loan funds, and

The merging of all loan promissory notes into a single payment structure.

Any future changes the city may need for these loans are also pre-approved. If any part of this ordinance is found invalid, the original loan terms will apply again.
