ORDINANCE NO. 9082
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING TAX AMNESTY ON PENALTIES AND INTERESTS INCURRED FROM DELINQUENT REAL PROPERTY TAXES, WITH AVAILMENT PERIOD ENDING DECEMBER 31, 2024, AND PAYMENT OPTIONS EXTENDED UNTIL JUNE 30, 2026, PURSUANT TO RECENTLY ENACTED REPUBLIC ACT NO. 12001, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “REAL PROPERTY VALUATION AND ASSESSMENT REFORM ACT”

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Republic Act No. 12001 or the Real Property Valuation and Assessment Reform Act (RPVARA), provides, among other things, for the grant of real property tax amnesty. Section 30 of this law states that:
“Sec. 30. Grant of Tax Amnesty on Real Property Taxes and Special Levies on Real Property. — There is hereby granted a real property tax amnesty which shall cover penalties, surcharges, and interests from all unpaid real property taxes, including Special Education Fund, idle land tax, and other special levy taxes, prior to the effectivity of this Act: Provided, That the real property tax amnesty hereby authorized and granted can only be availed within a period of two (2) years after the effectivity of this Act.”

The law, which was signed last June 13, 2024, took effect fifteen (15) days after its publication. The tax amnesty specifically covers only the penalty interest "prior to the effectivity" of the law, and the Omnibus Revenue Code (Ordinance No. 8331) imposes interest on unpaid real property tax at two percent (2%) per month [Sec. 73].

SEC. 2. Scope. The proper assessment for delinquent real properties availing of such tax amnesty shall be:
a. All penalty charges incurred up to the last working day of December 2024 shall be waived.
b. The period within which the delinquent property owner or administrator may avail of the amnesty is up to June 30, 2026.
c. The taxpayer may be allowed to pay the outstanding delinquent basic real property tax, including the corresponding Special Education Fund, idle land tax, and other special levy, through a one-time payment or in installments up to June 30, 2026. However, the delinquent realty tax — including subsequent real property taxes — shall be subject to the 2% monthly penalty interest commencing on January 1, 2025 until the delinquent tax is fully paid, but the total interest on such unpaid taxes shall not exceed thirty-six (36) months.

SEC. 3. Who May Avail the Tax Amnesty. The tax amnesty may be availed by:
a. Those who own or administer any delinquent real property (land, building, or machinery), with or without Notices of Delinquency.
b. Those who own or administer real property declared for the first time subject to back taxes. The property shall be assessed on the basis of the applicable Schedule of Values, Assessment Levels, and Tax Rates in force during the corresponding period pursuant to Section 36 of Ordinance No. 8331.

SEC. 4. This tax amnesty shall not extend to the following real properties:
a. Delinquent real properties which have been disposed of at public auction to satisfy the real property tax delinquencies.
b. Real properties with tax delinquencies which are being paid pursuant to a compromise agreement.
c. Real properties subject of pending cases in court for real property tax delinquencies.

SEC. 5. Implementing Rules and Regulations. The Office of the City Treasurer is hereby directed to issue, within five (5) days upon the approval of this Ordinance, the necessary rules and regulations including other administrative guidelines for the implementation of the same.

SEC. 6. Information Dissemination. An intensified and widespread information dissemination program shall be implemented to encourage taxpayers, including those residing outside the City of Manila, to avail the benefits of this Ordinance. The Secretary to the City Council is hereby directed to publish a notice of the gist of this Ordinance in any newspaper of general circulation once every week throughout its effectivity. Likewise, the Manila Public Information Office is hereby directed to coordinate with national news agencies to inform the general public of this Ordinance. Further, the Manila Barangay Bureau shall issue a memorandum instructing all barangays to inform their constituents regarding this measure.

SEC. 7. Repealing Clause. All ordinances or portions thereof which are contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby deemed repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 8. Separability Clause. If any part, section, or provision of this Ordinance shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by a competent court, other parts or portions that are not affected thereby shall remain valid.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall be effective upon its approval until June 30, 2026 only.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 29, 2024.
short_text: This ordinance grants a tax amnesty for penalties and interest charges on unpaid real property taxes in Manila, in line with the Real Property Valuation and Assessment Reform Act (RA 12001). If you owe property taxes before June 2024, you can have your penalties waived if you apply by December 31, 2024, and pay the owed taxes in full or in installments by June 30, 2026. However, interest starts accumulating again at 2% monthly starting January 1, 2025, if you haven’t settled the full amount. The amnesty does not apply to properties already auctioned, under court cases, or under compromise agreements.
fines: Penalty interests are waived under certain conditions

ORDINANCE NO. 9081
AN ORDINANCE INCREASING THE MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE OF ALL BONAFIDE SENIOR CITIZENS OF THE CITY OF MANILA FROM FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP 500.00) TO ONE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 1,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The policy of the State to protect and serve the rights of the elderly is enshrined in the 1987 Philippine Constitution, specifically under Article XIII, Section 11, which expressly provides that the State shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health, and other social services available to all the people at affordable cost, and further give priority to the needs of the elderly, among others.

With the aforesaid provisions of the Constitution and the Local Government Code (LGC), it is ensured that the elderly are accorded the primary opportunity to have access to essential goods, health, and social services in accordance with their needs.

Further, the provisions of the LGC empower the City Government of Manila to adopt measures to ensure the protection of health, social, and moral welfare of its inhabitants, especially the senior citizens.

Hence, in pursuit of the above mandate, the increase of the monthly monetary allowance of senior citizens from the current five hundred pesos (PHP 500.00) to one thousand pesos (PHP 1,000.00) is a significant support to our senior citizens to enable them to have access to the best quality of healthcare services as well as necessary medicines and essential goods.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Increase in Monthly Monetary Allowance for Senior Citizens.
The present monetary allowance for senior citizens is hereby increased from five hundred pesos (PHP 500.00) to one thousand pesos (PHP 1,000.00) per month, which shall be given to all bonafide senior citizens of the City of Manila.

SEC. 2. Appropriation.
The herein monetary allowance for senior citizens shall be charged against available appropriations in the FY 2025 Executive Budget and thereafter shall become a regular appropriation in the succeeding preparation of the Annual Executive Budget of the City of Manila.

SEC. 3. Separability Clause.
If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause.
The provisions or parts of Ordinance No. 8565, including ordinances amending the same, as well as all other ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules or regulations, or issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2025.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 17, 2024.
short_text: Starting January 1, 2025, all legitimate senior citizens in Manila will receive a monthly allowance of PhP1,000, doubled from the previous PhP500. This increase aims to help seniors afford better healthcare, medicines, and basic necessities. The funds for this allowance will come from the city's 2025 budget and will continue to be included in future annual budgets.

The Manila Film Development Commission was created to promote Filipino culture and values through filmmaking. It aims to support both commercial and non-commercial film production, fostering the development of the film industry in Manila. The Commission will organize film festivals, offer incentives for quality productions, and develop programs to enhance skills in the local film industry. The Manila Film Festival will also continue annually under this ordinance.

ORDINANCE NO. 9076

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE POSITION OF CITY GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENT HEAD III — PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT SERVICE OFFICE MANAGER (PESO MANAGER), UNDER THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR — MANILA PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT SERVICE OFFICE IN COMPLIANCE WITH CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION RESOLUTION NO. 1900905 PROMULGATED ON AUGUST 6, 2019 AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 458 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, empowers the Sangguniang Panlungsod to create and determine positions in the local government unit to provide for its needs for the general welfare of the city and its inhabitants.

Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 20, Series of 2019, states that, pursuant to CSC Resolution No. 1900905 promulgated on August 6, 2019, the Commission approved the amendment of the qualification standards (QS) for various positions under the Labor and Employment group in the local government units (LGUs). The new QS for Department Head and Assistant Department Head positions in the Public Employment Service Office (PESO) positions in the LGUs pursuant to Republic Act No. 8759, as amended by Republic Act No. 10691, is as follows:

POSITION: City Government Department Head III (PESO Manager)
SALARY GRADE: 27
LEVEL: 2
EDUCATION: Bachelor's Degree, preferably in Operations Management (HRM), Human Resource Development, or allied fields
EXPERIENCE: 5 years of supervisory/management experience in programs related to employment facilitation
TRAINING: None required
ELIGIBILITY: Career Service (Professional)/Second Level Eligibility
OTHER REMARKS: With parenthetical position of PESO Manager for special cities only (Manila and Quezon City), including the requirement of Filipino citizenship, good moral character, and residency in the local government unit concerned, as provided in the Local Government Code of 1991.
Concurrence of the Local Sanggunian shall be required for appointment to Local Government Department Head positions as provided under R.A. No. 7160 (Local Government Code of 1991).

Paragraphs 4 and 5 of the Civil Service Commission Resolution No. 1900905

Paragraphs 4 and 5 of the Civil Service Commission Resolution No. 1900905 state that:

“WHEREAS, Section 3 of Republic Act No. 8759, as amended by Republic Act No. 10691, otherwise known as the 'Public Employment Service Office Act of 1999,' provides that there shall be established in all provinces, cities, and municipalities a Public Employment Service Office (PESO), which shall be operated and maintained by local government units (LGUs). The PESOs shall be linked to the regional offices of the Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE) for coordination and technical supervision, and to the DOLE central office, to constitute the national public employment service network.”

“The PESO shall be under the office of the governor, city, or municipal mayor. The PESO shall be initially organized by and composed of a PESO manager and may be assisted by a labor and employment officer (LEO) as determined by the LGU.”

Section 2 of CSC Resolution No. 1900905 — Functions and Salary Grade of LGU Department Head (PESO Manager) states:

1. Functions:
The primary function of the PESO Manager is to manage all technical and administrative activities of the PESO.

Develop action plans, proposals, and other documents needed for implementing programs and services.

Identify training needs and arrange staff training as needed (e.g., in-house or block release training, or delegate to appropriate unit/staff).

Responsible for informal stages of staff discipline, including coaching and counseling.

Maintain a systematic process flow to ensure effective and efficient management of the office and avoid complaints from clients.

Conduct reviews of daily procedures being implemented to update and trim down unnecessary processes and carry out remedial actions.

Maintain effective communication with Local Executives to appraise and provide recommendations for policy directions.

2. Salary grade of LGU Department Head (PESO Manager):
The salary grade of PESO Manager shall be equivalent to that of a Department Head according to the income classification of the LGU.

The Public Employment Service Office was created by virtue of Manila City Ordinance No. 8166, also known as "AN ORDINANCE CREATING A MANILA PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT SERVICE OFFICE (PESO) TO IMPLEMENT THE EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS OF THE CITY GOVERNMENT AS ENACTED BY LAW UNDER REPUBLIC ACT NO. 8759 PROVIDING FOR ITS FUNCTIONS AND APPROPRIATING THE SUM OF TEN MILLION PESOS (PHP 10,000,000.00) FOR ITS INITIAL OPERATION," and was enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 8, 2008.

On September 10, 2024, the City Legal Office issued its legal opinion stating that it is timely to create the position of City Government Department Head III — Public Employment Service Office Manager (PESO Manager) under the Office of the Mayor — Manila Public Employment Service Office.
Also on September 10, 2024, the City Budget Office issued its recommendation and interposes no objection on the subject matter.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy.
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability. The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs while simultaneously cutting, scaling-down, phasing-out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SECTION 2. Purpose.
To meet the needs of the present demands for a functional and responsive component of the Office of the Mayor — the Manila Public Employment Service Office (PESO).

SECTION 3. Creation of New Position.
The following new plantilla position is hereby created to effect the purpose of this Ordinance:
POSITION: City Government Department Head III - Public Employment Service Office Manager (PESO Manager)
SALARY GRADE: 27
OFFICE: Office of the Mayor - Manila Public Employment Service Office

SECTION 4. Qualifications, Powers, Duties, and Responsibilities.
The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the position shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code and Civil Service Commission (CSC) laws, rules, and regulations.

SECTION 5. Appointments.
Appointments for the position shall be within the qualification standards prescribed by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant laws.

SECTION 6. Abolished Plantilla Positions.
For the implementation of this Ordinance, the following positions under the Office of the Mayor are hereby abolished:
OFFICE: Manila Public Employment Service Office
POSITION TITLE: Psychologist I
QUANTITY: 1
ITEM NO. FY 2024 EXECUTIVE BUDGE: 165
SALARY GRADE: 11
AMOUNT (INCLUDING MANDATORIES): PHP 527,798
ACTION: Abolition

OFFICE: Office of the Secretary to the Mayor
POSITION TITLE: City Government Assistant Department Head III
QUANTITY: 1
ITEM NO. FY 2024 EXECUTIVE BUDGE: 44
SALARY GRADE: 25
AMOUNT (INCLUDING MANDATORIES): PHP 1,764,311.52
ACTION: This position shall be automatically abolished once vacant.

SECTION 7. Appropriations.
The amount necessary for the effective and continuous implementation of this Ordinance shall be sourced from the FY 2024 and succeeding appropriation ordinances.

SECTION 8. Repealing Clause.
All ordinances, rules, and regulations or parts thereof inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 9. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon approval, and the position of City Government Department Head III — Public Employment Service Office Manager (PESO Manager) shall be included under the Office of the Mayor — Manila Public Employment Service Office as head of the said office.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 24, 2024.
short_text: This ordinance creates a new position in the City of Manila: City Government Department Head III — Public Employment Service Office (PESO) Manager. This position will oversee the Manila Public Employment Service Office (PESO), which helps the city's residents find jobs and other employment-related services. The role will have a salary grade of 27 and will be responsible for managing PESO's activities, developing plans, and ensuring smooth operations.

The goal of these changes is to strengthen the council’s role in promoting tourism, culture, and the arts in Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 9072

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE INCREASE IN THE COMPENSATION RATE FOR CONTRACT OF SERVICE PERSONNEL AND JOB ORDER WORKERS OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND AUGMENTING THE OTHER GENERAL SERVICES ACCOUNT THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2024 ANNUAL BUDGET TO FUND ITS IMPLEMENTATION AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 77 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991 mandates the responsibility for human resources and development for local government units. It provides that the chief executive of every local government unit shall be responsible for human resources and development in his unit and shall take all personnel actions in accordance with the constitutional provisions on civil service, pertinent laws, and rules and regulations thereon, including such policies, guidelines, and standards as the Civil Service Commission may establish. Provided, that the local chief executive may employ emergency or casual employees or laborers paid on a daily wage or piecework basis and hired through job orders for local projects authorized by the Sangguniang concerned, without need of approval or attestation by the Civil Service Commission. Provided further, that the period of employment of emergency or casual laborers as provided in this section shall not exceed six (6) months.

The Commission on Audit - Department of Budget and Management Joint Circular (COA-DBM JC) No. 2, s. 2020, entitled "Updated Rules and Regulations Governing Contract of Service (COS) and Job Order (JO) Workers in the Government," provides that government agencies are authorized to enter into service contracts with other government agencies, private firms, non-government agencies, or individuals for services related or incidental to their respective functions and operations, whether on a part-time or full-time basis.

The payment of services under individual COS is provided under Item 8.0 (Payment of Services under individual COS) of COA-DBM JC No. 2, s. 2020 and thus provides that individuals hired through COS shall be paid the prevailing market rates, subject to the provisions of RA No. 9184 and its Implementing Rules and Regulations. The same shall be charged against the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) in the approved agency budget.

In the same manner, the payment of services for those hired under the JO basis is charged against the MOOE in the approved agency budget and under Item 9.0 (Payment of Services under JO), individuals hired through JO shall be paid wages equivalent to the daily wage/salary of comparable positions in government and a premium of up to 20% of such wage/salary, subject to the availability of funds.

As the cost of goods and services has risen over time, an increase in the compensation of COS personnel and JO workers is necessary to help mitigate the impact of inflation and to enable them to meet their daily basic needs.

After due consideration, there is a need to augment the MOOE — Other General Services account, against which the compensation of COS personnel and JO workers are charged, through savings from other accounts of the FY 2024 Annual Budget to ensure the implementation of the increase in the aforementioned compensation rates.

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash as supporting documents to this savings and augmentation ordinance.

As provided under Section 336 of the Local Government Code of 1991, Use of Appropriated Funds and Savings, funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sangguniang concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.

INCREASE IN THE COMPENSATION RATE FOR CONTRACT OF SERVICE PERSONNEL AND JOB ORDER WORKERS

The Local Legislative Body approved Resolution No. 4, by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: “A Resolution Approving the Amendment of the Annual Investment Program and the Issuance of a Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2024 in relation to the Increase in Compensation Rate for Contract of Service Personnel and Job Order Workers requiring Augmentation of the Other General Services Account under the FY 2024 Executive Budget in the total amount of Seventy-One Million Seven Hundred Four Thousand Pesos (P71,704,000.00) for the implementation of remuneration adjustments.”

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:

SECTION 1. Increase in Compensation Rate.

short_text:
This ordinance increases the monthly compensation for Contract of Service (COS) personnel and Job Order (JO) workers in various city departments, including the Manila Department of Social Welfare and Manila Health Department. Each worker will receive an additional PhP2,000 per month to help cope with rising living costs.

The funds will cover workers' compensation and be sourced from various departments, including the Office of the Mayor, the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau, and the Manila Health Department. The goal is to provide fairer compensation to city workers and ensure their well-being in the face of inflation.

ORDINANCE NO. 9071

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FIRST TRANCHE OF THE MODIFIED SALARY SCHEDULE FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT PERSONNEL STARTING SEPTEMBER 1, 2024 PURSUANT TO EXECUTIVE ORDER NO. 64, S. 2024 AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Ordinance No. 9009 appropriated funds for the Personal Services (PS) requirement of the City Government of Manila under the FY 2024 Executive Budget.

On August 2, 2024, President Ferdinand “Bongbong” R. Marcos, Jr., issued Executive Order (E.O.) No. 64, s. 2024, entitled: “Updating the Salary Schedule for Civilian Government Personnel and Authorizing the Grant of an Additional Allowance, and for Other Purposes.”

Section 4 thereof provided that the updated Salary Schedule authorized for civilian government personnel may likewise be granted to personnel of the local government units (LGUs).

Relatedly, the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) issued Local Budget Circular No. 160 on August 12, 2024, entitled: “Implementation of the First Tranche of the Modified Salary Schedule for Local Government Personnel Pursuant to Executive Order (EO) No. 64, s. 2024.”

After due consideration, there is a need to augment the following accounts under the FY 2024 Executive Budget of the City of Manila in connection with the implementation of the aforementioned First Tranche of the Modified Salary Schedule for Local Government Personnel: (a) Salaries and Wages-Regular, (b) Year-End Bonus; (c) Retirement and Life
Insurance Premiums; and (d) PHILHEALTH Contributions.

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Declaration of Savings as supporting documents to this savings and augmentation ordinance.

As provided under Section 336 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991, Use of Appropriated Funds and Savings, funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.

ORDINANCE NO. 9068
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A CASH GIFT OF TWO THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 2,000.00) TO THE GRADUATES OF THE UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA AND THE PAMANTASAN NG LUNGSOD NG MAYNILA, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The City of Manila, by virtue of its commitment to uphold the mandate of the 1987 Philippine Constitution to protect and promote the physical, moral, spiritual, intellectual, and social well-being of its youth, operates two (2) public higher education institutions. The Dalubhasaan ng Maynila (City College of Manila), now known as the Universidad de Manila, was established in 1995 through Ordinance No. 7885, and the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) was established by virtue of Republic Act No. 4196 in 1965.

The Universidad de Manila and Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila are established, funded, and run by the City of Manila, with the primary vision to provide free education to the Manileno youth seeking to pursue further education without straining their limited financial resources.

Both premier universities in the City of Manila have produced graduates that have become significant contributors to nation-building, bearing the ideals and aspirations of every Manileno.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as the "Taas-Noo Manileno Graduation Gift Ordinance of 2024."

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. — Pursuant to Section 9, Article II of the Constitution, it is the policy of the State to promote a just and dynamic social order in fulfillment of the objective of poverty alleviation, national prosperity, and independence through policies that provide adequate social services, full employment, a rising standard of living, and improved quality of life for all citizens.

Similarly, in accordance with the said constitutional provision, the City Government of Manila recognizes the vital role of the youth in society and nation-building; such recognition shall be the backbone of the promotion and protection of the physical, moral, spiritual, intellectual, and social well-being of the youth.

In pursuance of the welfare of the youth and the fulfillment of its duties to its citizens, the City of Manila decided to provide incentives to graduates from the tertiary-level educational institutions, namely: the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila and the Universidad de Manila.

SEC. 3. Beneficiaries of this Ordinance. — The official graduates from the academic year 2023-2024 and onwards of the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila and Universidad de Manila.

SEC. 4. Requirements for the Availment of the Graduation Gift:

a. Must be a duly enrolled student, in good standing, of either the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila or Universidad de Manila;
b. Must be a bona fide resident and registered voter of the City of Manila;
c. Must be a qualified recipient of the One Thousand Pesos (PHP. 1,000.00) monthly allowance under the City of Manila as governed by Ordinance No. 8568; and
d. Must be an official graduate of either the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila or Universidad de Manila.

SEC. 5. Taas-Noo Manileno Graduation Gift. — An amount of Two Thousand Pesos (PHP. 2,000.00) shall be given to the successful graduates of the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila and Universidad de Manila.

SEC. 6. Appropriation. — The City Government shall appropriate funds therefor, which shall be used for the above purposes mandated by this Ordinance in the City's Annual Budget or any other available funding source and in every succeeding budget year thereafter.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions thereof not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.
This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 8, 2024.
short_text:
This ordinance grants a cash gift of PhP2,000 to graduates from the Universidad de Manila and Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. To qualify for the gift, the graduate must be a resident and registered voter of Manila, a recipient of the city's PhP1,000 monthly allowance, and a graduate of the 2023-2024 academic year or later.

The City Government will appropriate the funds for this program from the city's annual budget. The goal is to support the educational achievements of Manileno youth and provide them with a token of appreciation for their hard work.

ORDINANCE NO. 9067

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 1 IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF EIGHTY-THREE MILLION SEVENTY-SIX THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 83,076,000.00) AS ADDITIONAL APPROPRIATION UNDER THE OTHER GENERAL SERVICES ACCOUNT OF THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR FOR FY 2024 ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS ORDINANCE, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.) No. 7160 or the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991 provides that “every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare."

It further provides that “within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants."

Further, Section 17 of the LGC mandates "local government units shall endeavor to be self-reliant and shall continue exercising the powers and discharging the duties and functions currently vested upon them. They shall also discharge the functions and responsibilities of national agencies and offices devolved to them pursuant to this Code. Local government units shall likewise exercise such other powers and discharge such other functions and responsibilities as are necessary, appropriate, or incidental to efficient and effective provisions of the basic services and facilities enumerated herein."

To fund priority programs and activities of the City, a supplemental budget may be enacted “when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources" (Section 321 of R.A. No. 7160) to ensure the implementation of the above-mentioned programs, activities, and projects for the general welfare of the residents of the City of Manila.

Pursuant to the foregoing statutory provisions, the City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds as supporting document to the promulgation of this Supplemental Budget.

The City Council likewise approved Resolution No. 2, Series of 2024 of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled "A RESOLUTION."

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The FY 2024 Supplemental Budget of the City of Manila in the total amount of Eighty-Three Million Seventy-Six Thousand Pesos (PhP. 83,076,000.00) is hereby appropriated to fund the following programs, activities, and projects of the City of Manila, to wit:

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE:

GENERAL FUND-PROPER
Office of the Mayor 

Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses:

Other General Services — to fund priority programs, activities and projects of the
Manila City Government for the general welfare of the residents of the City of Manila
pursuant to Sections 16 and 17 of the Local Government Code of 1991

AMOUNT:
P 83,076,000.00

TOTAL: P 83,076,000.00.

Attached are the following details:

LBP Form No. 8 marked as “Annex A” — Statement of Funding Source as Certified by the City Treasurer and City Accountant; and

LBP Form No. 9 marked as “Annex B” — Statement of Supplemental Appropriation.

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On the motion presented by the Hon. Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly seconded, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on July 23, 2024.
short_text: Ordinance No. 9067 approves a supplemental budget of Php 83,076,000.00 for the City of Manila, to be allocated to the Office of the Mayor under the General Services account. This budget will fund various priority programs and projects aimed at improving the welfare of Manila residents. The appropriation follows the Local Government Code, which ensures the city’s responsibilities for promoting public health, safety, and general well-being. The budget was certified by the City Treasurer and City Accountant, and it was approved by the City Council of Manila on July 23, 2024.

ORDINANCE NO. 9066

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE REVERSION TO THE GENERAL FUND THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF EIGHTY-THREE MILLION SEVENTY-SIX THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 83,076,000.00) APPROPRIATED UNDER THE OTHER GENERAL SERVICES ACCOUNT OF THE OFFICE OF THE SANGGUNIANG PANLUNGSOD AUTHORIZED THROUGH THE FY 2024 ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS ORDINANCE AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991, provides that:

"Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation, and the Sangguniang concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations, subject to the provisions of this Section."

Consistent with the foregoing statutory provision, there is a need to revert to the general fund the total amount of Eighty-Three Million Seventy-Six Thousand Pesos (PHP 83,076,000.00) under the Other General Services Account of the Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod under the FY 2024 Annual Appropriations Ordinance, as the said fund is free from any obligation or encumbrance and still available to fund priority programs, activities, and projects for the general welfare of the residents of Manila. Pursuant to the LGC, the implementation of the aforementioned priority programs, activities, and projects falls within the powers of the chief executive, who is conferred with executive powers, rather than the Sangguniang Panlungsod, which is assigned legislative duties (Sections 48, 455, and 456 of the LGC).

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Reversion. — The fund under the FY 2024 Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses - Other General Services Account of the Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod under the FY 2024 Annual Appropriations Ordinance is hereby reverted to the General Fund, to wit:

Particulars        Amount
Reversion of Appropriations        PHP 83,076,000.00
General Fund        
Sangguniang Panlungsod Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses        
Other General Services        
Attached as Annex A — Statement of Availability of Funds

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On the motion presented by Hon. Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly seconded, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on July 23, 2024.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the reversion of PhP83,076,000 from the Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod's Other General Services account back to the General Fund. The funds were part of the FY 2024 annual budget but were unspent and are now available for other important programs and projects that will benefit the people of Manila. This action follows the guidelines of the Local Government Code, which requires unspent funds to be returned to the general fund at the end of the fiscal year.

ORDINANCE NO. 9064

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING SECTION 2.A OF ORDINANCE NO. 7755 (UNDER TRICYCLE TERMINALS), AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THEREIN THE LOADING AND UNLOADING AREAS OF ROSARITO, PALAWAN, DOMINGO SANTIAGO TRICYCLE OPERATORS AND DRIVERS’ ASSOCIATION (ROPADO TODA), INC., AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7871, AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THEREIN ITS ROUTE MEASURE CAPACITY

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The Rosarito, Palawan, Domingo Santiago Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association, Inc., is a duly registered corporation with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).

The said association has met its routine transportation requirements of commuters along the said route.

The operation of the said tricycle association will not create an adverse effect on the smooth and orderly flow of traffic in the aforesaid area since the loading and unloading zones located at Domingo Santiago Street to España Street in Sampaloc, Manila, are within easy traffic control.

The enactment of this Ordinance will give a chance and equal opportunity to the members of the transport group to engage in the tri-wheel business and certainly will empower them to become responsible and productive members of the community.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

ORDINANCE NO. 9060

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING SECTION 2.A OF ORDINANCE NO. 7755 (UNDER TRICYCLE TERMINALS), AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THEREIN THE LOADING AND UNLOADING AREAS OF GERONIMO, G. TUAZON TRICYCLE OPERATORS AND DRIVERS ASSOCIATION (GERZONTODA), INC., AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7871, AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THEREIN ITS ROUTE MEASURE CAPACITY
EXPLANATORY NOTE
Tricycles have been one of the modes of transportation in the Philippines. They are accessible in both rural and urban areas but are usually seen within barangays and are considered essential, especially for daily commuters. Filipinos utilize tricycles to go to work, market, school, or any place since they are efficient and practical, as well as a hassle-free way to get to your desired location. Tricycles play a vital role in the movement of passengers, particularly in remote areas and/or subdivisions where other modes of transportation are not accessible to the public.

Under Section 16 of Republic Act 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted to them, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare of their people. Local Government Units shall then identify and designate viable routes and terminals within their jurisdiction and shall be in proximity to public buildings, public markets, commercial centers and other similar places in order to ensure accessibility to the public and to provide a better mode of transportation.”

The City Government of Manila recognizes the importance of maintaining order in traffic, decreasing congestion, and increasing accessibility and mobility of citizens, since this may also serve as an avenue for economic opportunities. Having an accessible mode of transportation such as tricycles also saves more travel time. In addition, due to their smaller size compared to other vehicles, they have the ability to negotiate narrow streets and maneuver more easily on crowded roads, providing door-to-door service.

This Ordinance seeks to include the Geronimo, G. Tuazon Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association (GERZONTODA), Inc. in the registered list of TODAs that can serve the public within their vicinity. This also includes their Route Measure Capacity, as well as their Loading and Unloading Areas.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is sought.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 2.a (Tricycle Terminals) of Ordinance No. 7755, as amended, is hereby furthermore amended by including therein the loading and unloading areas of Geronimo, G. Tuazon Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association (GERZONTODA), Inc., to read as follows:

“GERONIMO, G. TUAZON TRICYCLE OPERATORS AND DRIVERS
ASSOCIATION (GERZONTODA), INC.

Loading and Unloading Areas:

a. Geronimo Street, in front of Ospital ng Sampaloc;
b. Geronimo Street, between Geronimo Elementary School and Moises Salvador Elementary School;
c. Geronimo Street corner G. Tuazon Street, beside Chill Top Restobar;
d. G. Tuazon Street corner Loreto Street, beside St. Mark Memorial Chapel; and
e. G. Tuazon Street corner M. Dela Fuente Street, beside Security Bank.

SEC. 2. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 7871, as amended, is hereby furthermore amended by including therein the Route Measure Capacity and authorized route lines of Geronimo, G. Tuazon Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association (GERZONTODA), Inc., to read as follows:

ASSOCIATION
Geronimo, G. Tuazon Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association (GERZONTODA), Inc.

R.M.C.:
40 units

ROUTE:

The authorized route lines of operation shall be via Geronimo Street, Carola Street, Honrades Street, G. Tuazon Street, M. Dela Fuente, and vice versa.


SEC. 3. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in at least two (2) newspapers of local circulation..

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 18, 2024.

It designates specific loading and unloading areas for the association along Geronimo and G. Tuazon Streets, and it also sets the route capacity to 40 units. AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING SEVEN (7) VACANT POSITIONS IN THE OFFICE OF THE CITY ACCOUNTANT BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD TO GIVE WAY TO THE CREATION OF THIRTEEN (13) MORE ESSENTIAL POSITIONS

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 325(d) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that:
“In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this code and the civil service laws, rules and regulations.”

Furthermore, Section 76 of the same act provides that,
“Every local government unit shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern taking into consideration its service requirements and financial capability, subject to the minimum standards and guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission.”

The Office of the City Accountant (OCAT) is mandated to be in charge of both accounting and internal audit services of the city government in compliance with Section 474, Article IV, Title Five of Republic Act No. 7160 and the requirements of the Commission on Audit’s Philippine Public Sector Accounting System. It is therefore a continuous objective of the office to come up with an efficient and effective organization with systematic pre-auditing procedures of the financial operations of the City of Manila in order to live up to its mandate.

Through Officer-in-Charge, Assistant City Accountant Jonathan R. Galorio, the OCAT is requesting that seven (7) of their plantilla positions be abolished to make way for the creation of thirteen (13) more essential positions in order to fulfill its mandated functions.

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability.

ORDINANCE NO. 9056

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A HOSPITAL EPIDEMIOLOGY AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE UNIT (HESU) FOR EVERY PUBLIC AND PRIVATE HOSPITAL IN THE CITY OF MANILA, AMENDING FOR THE PURPOSE THE TITLE AND SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8761

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government, in line with its forehanded approach to future disease outbreaks, to reinforce the establishment of the City Epidemiology and Surveillance Unit (CESU) through the involvement of all essential medical institutions within its jurisdiction.

SEC. 2. — The Title of Ordinance No. 8761, Series of 2021, is hereby amended to read as follows:

“AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE CITY EPIDEMIOLOGY AND SURVEILLANCE UNIT (CESU) UNDER THE MANILA HEALTH DEPARTMENT, DEFINING ITS POWERS AND FUNCTIONS IN COMPLIANCE WITH REPUBLIC ACT NO. 11332, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE ‘MANDATORY REPORTING OF NOTIFIABLE DISEASES AND HEALTH EVENTS OF PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERN ACT’, ESTABLISHING ITS MANPOWER COMPLEMENT THROUGH THE FILLING UP OF VACANT POSITIONS ALREADY EXISTING IN THE DEPARTMENT, AND CONVERTING VARIOUS ABOLISHED ITEMS FOR NEW PLANTILLA POSITIONS OF ONE (1) MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIST IV, FOUR (4) DISEASE SURVEILLANCE OFFICER III, AND SIX (6) DISEASE SURVEILLANCE OFFICER II; PROVIDING FUNDS NECESSARY THEREFOR, AND PROVIDING FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A HOSPITAL EPIDEMIOLOGY AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE UNIT (HESU) FOR EVERY PUBLIC AND PRIVATE HOSPITAL IN THE CITY OF MANILA.”

SEC. 3. — Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8761, Series of 2021, is hereby amended by introducing Section 1-A, to read as follows:

SECTION 1-A. ESTABLISHMENT OF HESU. — In line with Section 1 of this Ordinance, every public and privately owned hospital in the City of Manila shall establish its own Hospital Epidemiology and Disease Surveillance Unit (HESU), whose basic function is to complement the duties of the CESU as the first line of defense in the event of any disease outbreak. The specific functions of each HESU are as follows:

Establish and maintain special surveillance operations for communicable and non-communicable diseases;

Manage an early warning public health surveillance and response system in coordination with CESU, utilizing the Philippine Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response System (PIDSR) and Event-Based Surveillance (EBS);

Provide epidemiological reports on diseases, including vaccine-preventable diseases and health events, to the Office of the Mayor;

Establish a communication network with appropriate government and international agencies, including but not limited to the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD), Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW), and the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO).

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. — Any ordinance, implementing rule or regulation, or provision thereof contrary to or inconsistent with this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 16, 2024.
short_text: This ordinance amends Ordinance No. 8761 by requiring every public and private hospital in Manila to establish a Hospital Epidemiology and Disease Surveillance Unit (HESU). These units will assist the City Epidemiology and Surveillance Unit (CESU) in detecting and responding to disease outbreaks. Their responsibilities include monitoring communicable and non-communicable diseases, issuing early warnings, submitting health reports to the Mayor’s Office, and coordinating with government agencies to strengthen the city’s public health response.

ORDINANCE NO. 9055
AN ORDINANCE PROMOTING THE CREATION, USE, AND MAINTENANCE OF HEALTHY OPEN SPACES IN COMMUNITIES, AND OTHER HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT INITIATIVES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the “Local Government Code of 1991,” specifies centers, public parks, bridges, and other similar facilities as basic services that local governments must provide for constituents.

Section 30 of Republic Act No. 11223, otherwise known as the Universal Health Care Act, and its Implementing Rules and Regulations strengthen the adoption of an integrated and comprehensive approach to ensure that all Filipinos are health literate, provided with healthy living conditions, and protected from hazards and risks affecting their health status. This law mandates Local Government Units (LGUs) to implement effective health promotion policies and programs promoting health literacy, healthy lifestyles, and the prevention of key risk factors.

The Department of Health (DOH), Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Trade, Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), Department of Human Settlements and Urban Development (DHSUD), Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH), Philippine Commission on Women (PCW), and National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) issued Joint Administrative Order No. 2023-0001 entitled “Guidelines on the Creation, Use, and Management of Parks and Public Open Spaces for the Promotion of Physical and Mental Health and Social Well-being,” mandating local government units to review existing urban, land use, and environmental plans to promote and support public open spaces.

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the promotion of urban green spaces to improve mental and physical health, as well as social and environmental conditions.

The Health Promotion Framework Strategy 2030 (DOH Administrative Order No. 2021-0063) outlines the Healthy Settings strategy, which emphasizes designing environments in communities to promote and protect health.

The DOH-DILG Joint Administrative Order No. 2021-0002, or the National Policy Framework on the Promotion and Recognition of Healthy Communities, identifies the qualities of a health-promoting environment, including the presence of open public spaces that encourage active mobility, physical activity, and leisure.


CHAPTER I. GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION 1. Short Title.
This Ordinance shall be known as the “Healthy Public Open Spaces Initiative of 2024” for brevity.

SEC. 2. Declaration of Principles and Policies.
The City of Manila is committed to ensuring the health and well-being of its constituents by improving their physical and social environment. The following principles and policies shall guide the development of public open spaces:

A. Equity and Inclusivity - Public open spaces shall be designed to meet the needs of all individuals, especially vulnerable groups. This includes ensuring accessibility for people of all ages, abilities, ethnicities, genders, sexual orientations, and socio-economic statuses.

B. Sustainability - Public open spaces shall be developed with sustainability in mind, ensuring they meet present environmental, social, and economic needs without compromising future generations’ ability to meet theirs.

C. Environmental and Cultural Protection - Public open spaces shall promote sustainability, conserve local biodiversity, and protect cultural heritage.

SEC. 3. General Objectives.
This Ordinance aims to guide the identification, assessment, use, and management of public open spaces to promote sustainability and support the health and well-being of residents in the City of Manila.

SEC. 4. Definition of Terms.
The following terms are defined for the purpose of this Ordinance:

A. Public Open Spaces - Land spaces provided by local or national government units, designated for public use. These spaces may include:

Blue, Green, and Urban Spaces:

Blue spaces refer to public spaces with water features (e.g., ponds, beaches, riparian zones).

Green spaces are natural spaces (e.g., parks, gardens, wildlife areas).

Urban spaces include streets, plazas, theme parks, historic spaces, and other man-made environments accessible to the public.

Active and Passive Spaces:

Active open spaces are designed for structured physical activities (e.g., sports complexes, courts).

Passive open spaces are used for leisure or informal play (e.g., neighborhood parks, conservation areas).

People’s Streets:

Streets that prioritize pedestrians and non-motorized vehicles for physical activity, leisure, and community use.

CHAPTER II. SPECIFIC PROVISIONS
SEC. 5. Establishment of the Ad Hoc Healthy Public Open Spaces Unit.
An ad hoc unit under the City Development Board will oversee the development of policies, review plans, and enforce local ordinances related to healthy public open spaces. It will coordinate with national agencies and ensure proper management and maintenance.

SEC. 6. Identification and Development of Open Spaces.
The City Planning and Development Office (CPDO) will identify existing and new spaces that can be used as public open spaces. Public consultations will be held to ensure inclusivity.

SEC. 7. Risk and Impact Assessments.
All project proposals must undergo a review, including Environmental Impact Assessments (EIA), Health Impact Assessments (HIA), and Climate and Disaster Risk Assessments (CDRA).

SEC. 8. Standards for Creation and Operation of Healthy Public Open Spaces.
Public open spaces must comply with the following standards:

Open and accessible

Friendly to children, elderly, persons with disabilities (PWD), and pets

Free from smoke, vape, drugs, and alcohol

Promoting eco-friendly practices

Resilient to climate change and disasters

Promoting local culture, arts, and biodiversity

Well-maintained with sufficient staffing

SEC. 9. Use of Endemic Species.
Endemic plant species, identified by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), shall be used in public open spaces to support local biodiversity.

SEC. 10. Health Promotion.
The City Health Office shall provide health-promoting activities in public open spaces and encourage physical activity and other healthy behaviors.

SEC. 11. Management and Maintenance.
The City will ensure adequate staffing and resources for the upkeep of public open spaces, including the use of rangers as needed. Public open spaces will be free for public access, though fees may be charged for tourist destinations.

SEC. 12. Citizen Safety and Reporting.
Peace and Order Officers will be stationed near public open spaces to maintain safety. The City will also provide a women’s and children’s help desk and ensure the availability of a complaint hotline. CCTV cameras will be installed in public open spaces for monitoring.

CHAPTER III. ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES
SEC. 13. Department of Public Services (Environment and Natural Resources Office)
This department will oversee environmental protection, the maintenance of blue and green spaces, and biodiversity protection in public open spaces.

SEC. 14. Department of Engineering and Public Works
This department will handle engineering designs, feasibility studies, and infrastructure related to public open spaces, ensuring compliance with national construction standards.

SEC. 15. Manila Health Department
This department will manage health assessments, provide health services in public spaces, and conduct health promotion campaigns on physical activity and other healthy behaviors.

SEC. 16. City Planning and Development Office
This office will develop and implement the Comprehensive Development Plan, ensuring the allocation of resources for public open spaces and integrating universal design principles for accessibility.

SEC. 17. Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau
This bureau will ensure the safety and accessibility of roads and pedestrian pathways leading to public open spaces.

SEC. 18. Manila Public Information Office / Health Education and Promotion Unit
This office will distribute health promotion materials and monitor community feedback on the use of public open spaces.

SEC. 19. Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts of Manila
This department will promote the cultural significance of public open spaces and ensure the protection of heritage sites within these spaces.

SEC. 20. Manila Police District
The Police will ensure safety and order in public open spaces, stationing officers as necessary.

SEC. 21. Use of Public Open Spaces.
Public open spaces shall be used for a variety of activities, including but not limited to physical exercise, recreation, social events, cultural activities, and environmental education. These spaces must be accessible to all members of the community, and special events shall be organized regularly to encourage usage.

SEC. 22. Management of Public Open Spaces.
The management of public open spaces shall be coordinated between the City Government and various stakeholders, including the private sector and non-governmental organizations. A Public Open Space Management Plan shall be developed and reviewed every three years to ensure the spaces are kept safe, clean, and functional. The plan will include provisions for:

Regular maintenance schedules

Emergency response protocols

Staff and volunteer training programs

Public involvement initiatives

SEC. 23. Environmental Sustainability and Green Infrastructure.
Public open spaces shall integrate green infrastructure, such as rain gardens, green roofs, permeable pavements, and sustainable water management systems. These measures will contribute to reducing the urban heat island effect, improving air quality, and enhancing the aesthetic value of these spaces.

SEC. 24. Monitoring and Evaluation.
The City of Manila will conduct regular monitoring and evaluation of public open spaces to assess their effectiveness in promoting health, safety, and sustainability. Key performance indicators (KPIs) will be established, such as:

Frequency of public use

Satisfaction rates of community members

Environmental impact measures

Economic benefits such as tourism or local business growth

Annual reports will be submitted to the City Council to ensure transparency and accountability in the implementation of this Ordinance.

SEC. 25. Funding.
The City of Manila shall allocate funds for the development, maintenance, and management of public open spaces. Additional funding may be sourced from grants, donations, or public-private partnerships. A dedicated Public Open Space Fund will be established to ensure long-term sustainability and proper utilization of resources for these spaces.

SEC. 26. Penalties and Enforcement.
Violators of the provisions of this Ordinance, including those engaging in illegal activities in public open spaces (e.g., illegal vending, littering, unauthorized constructions), shall be penalized. Penalties may include fines, community service, or imprisonment, depending on the severity of the violation. Enforcement will be carried out by the Manila Police District, with assistance from other relevant departments.

SEC. 27. Separability Clause.
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the other provisions not affected by such declaration shall remain in full force and effect.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 16, 2024.
short_text: This ordinance introduces a structured process to reduce overcrowding in Manila’s police detention facilities caused by frequent violations of common city ordinances like drinking alcohol in public, being half-naked in public, curfew violations, smoking, and urinating in public. To ease congestion, it allows violators to pay a fine within 5 days through a "No Contest Provision" without going to court. If they cannot pay, they may do community service instead. Minors are exempt from punishment but their guardians may be held accountable. A centralized database will be used to track violations. Some of the fine collections will be shared as incentives with the police and barangay officers

short_text: Ordinance No. 9054, also known as the KADA Ordinance of 2024, aims to institutionalize key assistance for developing adolescents (KADA) in the City of Manila. The ordinance is designed to protect the rights of adolescents, particularly regarding their sexual and reproductive health, and promote their overall well-being. It establishes a participatory, life-course, adolescent-oriented, and settings-based approach to address adolescent health concerns such as STI, HIV, early pregnancy, and risky behaviors.

ORDINANCE NO. 9053

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING A FUNCTIONAL DISASTER RISK REDUCTION AND MANAGEMENT IN HEALTH (DRRM-H) SYSTEM WITHIN THE CITY-WIDE HEALTH SYSTEMS (CWHS) OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE

In May 2010, RA No. 10121, the "Philippine Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Act of 2010," was signed, mandating disaster risk reduction and management (DRRM) approaches involving all sectors and stakeholders.

In February 2019, RA No. 11223, the "Universal Health Care Act," was enacted to ensure that all Filipinos are health-literate, live in healthy conditions, and are protected from health risks.

In March 2019, the Department of Health (DOH) emphasized the country’s vulnerability to disasters, calling for local support in disaster preparedness, response, and management to reduce health risks.

In October 2019, DOH issued Administrative Order No. 2019-0046, which called for institutionalizing the DRRM-H system to strengthen health systems' capacity to manage health risks and promote community resilience.

This Ordinance establishes a functional DRRM-H system in the City of Manila, transitioning to the "New Normal" while ensuring the operationalization of health emergency responses.

CHAPTER I. GENERAL PROVISIONS

SECTION 1. Short Title
This Ordinance shall be known as the "DRRM-H System in the CWHS Ordinance of Manila, 2024."

SEC. 2. Declaration of Principles and Policies
The City of Manila commits to promoting health and safety through:

Science-based, scalable methods to institutionalize a resilient DRRM-H system.

A people-centered, equitable, and accessible DRRM-H system ensuring timely preparedness and response to health emergencies.

SEC. 3. General Objectives
This Ordinance aims to:

Institutionalize a functional DRRM-H system to manage and mitigate the effects of emergencies.

Develop procedures and technical specifications for operationalization.

Promote involvement and participation from all sectors and stakeholders.

Allocate necessary resources for DRRM-H system implementation.

SEC. 4. Scope and Coverage
This Ordinance applies to the City-wide Health System of Manila and all relevant public and private stakeholders.

SEC. 5. Definition of Terms

Disaster Risk Reduction and Management in Health (DRRM-H): An integrated process to reduce health risks from disasters, improve preparedness, and protect vulnerable groups.

DRRM-H Institutionalization: Establishing a functional DRRM-H system, including plans, trained response teams, and operations centers.

Functional DRRM-H System: An operational system managing health risks from emergencies through governance, service delivery, resource management, and timely responses.

CHAPTER II. ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

SEC. 6. Roles and Responsibilities

City Health Board: Supervises health facilities, personnel, and resources.

City Health Office (CHO): Implements the DRRM-H system and represents health in DRRM activities.

Health Care Provider Network (HCPN): Delivers essential health services, especially during emergencies.

Public Health Unit in Hospitals: Coordinates with local operation centers during emergencies.

Contracted Apex Hospitals: Provide specialized care during emergencies.

CHAPTER III. IMPLEMENTATION MECHANISM

SEC. 7. Institutionalizing the DRRM-H System in CWHS
The City Health Office shall develop an organizational structure for the DRRM-H Unit in accordance with Civil Service Commission standards and the IRR of RA No. 11223. The DRRM-H Unit shall:

Lead the development of disaster risk reduction plans, protocols, and health emergency management standards.

Conduct advocacy, training, and simulations.

Coordinate with concerned agencies during health emergencies.

Maintain a public health emergency operations center with early warning systems and communication tools.

Staffing of the DRRM-H Unit:

Medical Officer V (DRRM-H Manager): Leads operations, requiring at least one year of experience in emergency operations.

Assistant DRRM-H Manager (SHPO/Nurse V): Oversees response and recovery, with at least one year of disaster management experience.

Nurse IV: Oversees prevention, mitigation, and preparedness efforts.

Health Program Officer (Emergency Operations Center Officer): Coordinates operations with six months of emergency management experience.

Administrative Officer IV: Manages logistics and supply management.

Ambulance Driver: Handles logistics and patient transport.

All medical staff shall receive appropriate training in Health Emergency Management Systems by the DOH or recognized institutions.

DRRM-H System Structure and Roles
A Functional DRRM-H (Disaster Risk Reduction and Management for Health) system is led by the DRRM-H Manager.

1. DRRM-H Manager:
Acts as the Operations Chief.

2. Assistant DRRM-H Manager (Senior Health Program Officer or Nurse V):
Focuses on Response, Recovery, and Rehabilitation.

Disseminates and monitors policies/standards from National Guidelines or local policies for health emergency and disaster response.

Mobilizes resources such as technical experts, HERTs (Health Emergency Response Teams), and logistics for emergency and disaster health services.

Manages health emergency and disaster information, ensuring coordination between partner agencies.

Provides support for recovery and rehabilitation through technical and financial assistance.

3. Prevention, Mitigation, and Preparedness Officer (Nurse V):
Focuses on Health Risk Prevention and Mitigation.

Disseminates and monitors policies for disaster risk prevention/mitigation and preparedness.

Facilitates capability-building activities and partnerships with stakeholders.

Provides technical/financial assistance for promotion, awareness, monitoring, and research.

4. Health Program Officer (Nurse III):
Acts as Operations Center Officer, on call 24/7.

Assists in monitoring health emergencies and disasters.

Provides technical support and recommends actions for disaster/emergency contingency plans.

Supports the DRRMO (Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office) with health service delivery.

Validates incidents and updates HEARS (Health Emergency and Assessment Reporting System) and other official records.

Coordinates mobilization of medical assistance for emergency responses.

Prepares communication letters and reports related to DRRM-H activities.

Coordinates with stakeholders and partners for guideline dissemination.

5. Administration and Finance Officer (AO IV):
Oversees performance monitoring for managerial, technical, and financial integration.

Manages the budget and ensures the availability of essential equipment, medicines, and supplies.

Maintains an inventory of logistics and prepares procurement requests.

6. Support Staff - Admin Aide I:
Maintains the Operations Center and equipment.

7. Ambulance Driver:
Drives and maintains the ambulance.

DRRM-H Framework and Operationalization
The DRRM-H system is guided by DOH Administrative Orders (No. 2019-0046 and No. 2020-0036), focusing on the integration of health systems at the local level.

Managerial Integration: Health resources such as facilities, personnel, and equipment are integrated to ensure a functional DRRM-H system.

DRRM-H Plan: A strategic plan updated annually and tested through drills, to be approved by the local chief executive.

Health Emergency Response Team (HERT): Organized and mobilized based on event type and needs, ensuring safety and self-sufficiency. Continuous training and professional development are encouraged.

Health Emergency Commodities (HECs): Procured or stockpiled based on essential guidelines, to be made available in emergencies or disasters.

Emergency Operations Center (EOC): Established within the City Health Office for coordination, communication, and control during emergencies.

System Management and Monitoring
Risk Analysis and Management: Routine monitoring to identify potential threats and develop action plans.

Quality Assurance: Development of standard operating procedures, performance monitoring, and training programs.

Knowledge Management: Maintain access to health emergency information for trend analysis, early warning systems, and best practice documentation.

Financial Integration
Resource Allocation: Financial resources, including Special Health Funds and DRRMO budgets, will support the DRRM-H system’s operations and ensure sustainability.

Monitoring and Reporting
Regular Monitoring: The City Health Office leads the monitoring of the DRRM-H system's implementation, consolidating data for reporting to relevant authorities.

Appropriations
The funding for the DRRM-H system can come from:

Local Government’s Internal Revenue Allotment (IRA).

DRRMO funds (5% allocation).

National Government Agency subsidies and relevant grants.

Supplemental funding requests as needed.

Miscellaneous and Final Provisions
Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR): The City Mayor may issue necessary regulations for the proper implementation of the ordinance.

Repealing Clause: Inconsistent orders and issuances are repealed or amended.

Effectivity: The ordinance takes effect immediately upon approval.
short_text:
This ordinance establishes a Disaster Risk Reduction and Management in Health (DRRM-H) system within Manila’s health services to improve the city’s readiness for health emergencies. It aims to reduce health risks during disasters, enhance preparedness, and protect vulnerable groups through an organized response system.

The ordinance mandates that the City Health Office oversee the development and implementation of this system, including creating disaster response teams, health emergency protocols, and the necessary resources for rapid action during health crises. It also ensures that health personnel are trained for emergency management and that the city’s health services are well-prepared and resilient.

Funds for the system will come from local government budgets, national grants, and additional resources as needed. This initiative will improve Manila's ability to manage health risks and respond swiftly to emergencies, ensuring the safety and well-being of its residents.

ORDINANCE NO. 9052

AN ORDINANCE MANDATING THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE (MDSW), THROUGH THE CHILD DEVELOPMENT WORKER, TO REQUIRE THE PARENTS/GUARDIANS TO PRESENT THE CHILD'S IMMUNIZATION CARD UPON ENROLLMENT AT THE DAY CARE CENTERS IN THE CITY OF MANILA, AND PROVIDING FOR MECHANISMS SHOULD THE CHILD BE NOT IMMUNIZED OR PARTIALLY IMMUNIZED

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Republic Act No. 10152, otherwise known as the “Mandatory Infants and Children Health Immunization Act of 2011," provides for mandatory basic immunization, which covers the following vaccine-preventable diseases:

(a) Tuberculosis
(b) Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis (DPT)
(c) Poliomyelitis
(d) Measles
(e) Mumps
(f) Rubella or German Measles
(g) Hepatitis B
(h) Influenza Type B (HIB)
(i) Other diseases as determined by the Secretary of Health

Immunization boosts a child's immune system, greatly reducing the severity of diseases and protecting against serious complications. The mandatory basic immunization is provided for free at government hospitals and health centers for infants and children up to five (5) years of age, according to the recommended schedule. However, some infants and children may not have received the required immunizations for various reasons or beliefs.

Vaccination not only protects the vaccinated individual but also the surrounding community, especially vulnerable groups. Thus, it is important that children receive vaccination to protect themselves and prevent spreading infections.

This proposal aims to encourage parents to have their children receive mandatory vaccinations according to protocol. It is also intended to protect children from infections and prevent the spread of diseases to other children.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 2 of Republic Act No. 10152 states that: "The State shall adopt a comprehensive, mandatory, and sustainable immunization program for vaccine-preventable diseases for all infants and children." Section 15, Article II of the Philippine Constitution further provides that: “The State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them.”

In line with this, the Child Development Centers of the City Government of Manila shall ensure the implementation of this mandate.

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. — As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall mean:

a. Child Development Center — A community-based flagship program under the Early Childhood Care and Development (ECCD) Council. The center serves as the venue for early learning and family support programs under the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW), accepting children aged three (3) to four (4) years and eleven (11) months old. The ECCD aims to nurture the physical and mental development of children.

b. Child Development Worker — A service provider in the Child Development Center under the supervision of a Social Worker.

SEC. 3. Responsibility of the Manila Department of Social Welfare and Development (MDSW). — The Manila Department of Social Welfare, through the Child Development Worker, is hereby mandated to require the parent/guardian of a child to present the Child Immunization Record (CIR) or vaccination card upon enrollment at the City Day Care Center.

SEC. 4. Undertaking. — If the parent/guardian fails to present the child's immunization record or presents an incomplete record, the Child Development Worker shall refer the parent/guardian to the City Health Services Office (CHSO) or District Health Center for counseling.

Upon referral, if the parent/guardian consents to immunization, health personnel shall prepare and administer the vaccines per schedule, free of charge. If the parent/guardian refuses to vaccinate the child after counseling, the following documents shall be submitted based on the reason(s) for refusal:

a. For religious reasons — Certification from an authorized church official
b. For medical reasons — Certification from a government physician
c. For personal principles — Certification from the parent/guardian assuming responsibility for the child's health

The specified documents shall be included in the child's health record at the Child Development Center.

Children entering the Child Development Center, aged three (3) to four (4) years old, who have not been fully vaccinated, shall receive catch-up vaccines for Mumps, Measles, Rubella (MMR), and Oral Polio.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. — If any provision or section of this Ordinance, or its application to any person or circumstance, is held invalid, the remaining provisions shall not be affected.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. — All prior ordinances, executive orders, administrative orders, rules, and regulations, or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 16, 2024.
short_text:
This ordinance requires parents or guardians to show a child's immunization card when enrolling at a Day Care Center in Manila. If a child has not received all the necessary vaccinations, the Child Development Worker will refer the parent or guardian to a health center for counseling. If the parent agrees, the vaccinations will be provided for free. However, if the parent refuses the vaccines, they must submit a written statement explaining their reasons, which could be religious, medical, or personal.

The ordinance aims to ensure that children are protected from serious diseases and prevent outbreaks in the community. It also allows for catch-up vaccines for children aged 3 to 4 years old who have missed some of their required immunizations.
