ORDINANCE NO. 9051

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING FOUR (4) VACANT POSITIONS IN THE PARKS DEVELOPMENT OFFICE BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD TO GIVE WAY TO THE CREATION OF ONE CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 325 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that in cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this code and the civil service laws, rules, and regulations.

Furthermore, Section 76 of the same act provides that, “Every local government unit shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern taking into consideration its service requirements and financial capability, subject to the minimum standards and guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission (CSC)."

The Parks Development Office (PDO) is responsible for implementing and carrying out development and improvement plans for parks and plazas, tree-planting activities, cleanliness, and beautification of center islands and side streets pertaining to socio-environmental services in the City of Manila.

In order to come up with ways to further serve the public in the most effective and efficient manner, the PDO deems it fit to abolish some vacant positions to pave the way for the creation of a Chief Administrative Officer. The PDO sees that such creation would be necessary to be at par with other offices in the City Government and to solidify the functions of the different sections of the office.

In view of the foregoing, the approval of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SEC. 1. Declaration of Policy. - It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability. The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting and scaling-down, phasing-out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby abolished in the Parks Development Office (PDO):

ITEM NO.: 64
TITLE OF POSITION: Engineer III
SALARY GRADE: 19-1
MONTHLY SALARY: PHP 49,835.00

ITEM NO.: 6
TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide IV
SALARY GRADE: 4-1
MONTHLY SALARY: PHP 14,993.00

ITEM NO.: 33
TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide IV
SALARY GRADE: 4-1
MONTHLY SALARY: PHP 14,993.00

ITEM NO.: 35
TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide IV
SALARY GRADE: 4-1
MONTHLY SALARY: PHP 14,993.00

TOTAL: PHP 94,814.00

SEC. 3 . New Plantilla Position - The following new plantilla item is hereby created in the Parks Development Office (PDO):

TITLE OF POSITION: Chief Administrative Officer
SALARY GRADE: 24-1
MONTHLY SALARY: PHP 88,410.00

TOTAL: PHP 88,410.00

SEC. 4. Qualifications, Powers, and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein specified position shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Law, and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. — Appointment. — The employment and appointment of the individual for the herein subject position shall be with the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set forth by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.        

SEC. 6. Appropriations. — The amount necessary for the creation of one (1) new plantilla position shall be derived from the available savings generated from the four (4) abolished vacant items in the 2023 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject new position shall be automatically funded through the succeeding annual City Budget as part of the plantilla personnel of the Parks Development Office (PDO).

SEC. 7. Repealing Clause. — Any provision of ordinances, executive orders, issuances, or rules and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 8. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 16, 2024.
short_text: Ordinance No. 9051 aims to improve the efficiency of the Parks Development Office (PDO) in the City of Manila by abolishing four vacant positions and creating one new position: Chief Administrative Officer. This restructuring is in line with the Local Government Code and the need to enhance service delivery while optimizing resources. The new position will have a salary grade of 24-1, with a monthly salary of PhP88,410. The creation of this role is expected to help streamline operations and solidify the functions within PDO.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 325 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that, “In cases of abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of the Code and the Civil Service Law, Rules, and Regulations.”

The goal of the MCL is to make Manilenos more resilient, knowledgeable, and connected with a wide range of information, thus enabling their success.

SEC. 7. Appointment. — The employment and appointment of the individuals for the herein subject positions shall be in accordance with the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. — Any provision of ordinances, executive orders, issuances, or rules and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 16, 2024.
short_text:
This ordinance abolishes six vacant positions at the Manila City Library (MCL) and creates three new Librarian I positions to enhance the library's services. The abolished positions are mostly administrative roles, while the new positions will focus on improving the quality of library services, aligning with the city’s goal to offer better educational resources to Manilenos.

The MCL is also undergoing an organizational restructuring to streamline its operations and improve efficiency. This ordinance aims to ensure that the library's staffing better supports its core functions in the digital age, taking effect immediately upon approval.

Thereafter, the herein subject new positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla Personnel of the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital (JJASGH).

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 325 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that, “In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations.”

Furthermore, Section 76 of the same act provides that, “Every local government unit shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern taking into consideration its service requirements and financial capability, subject to the minimum standards and guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission (CSC)."

To bring the best service to our constituents, the Sta. Ana Hospital, as headed by Officer-In-Charge — Hospital Director Grace H. Padilla, continues to come up with ways to improve their services. One such way is by ensuring that the staffing pattern of the hospital caters to their current needs and that the budget allocated to them is spent wisely.

Sta. Ana Hospital currently has five hundred sixteen (516) plantilla positions. However, upon review and reassessment of the hospital's organizational chart, the institution sees that there is a need to abolish some plantilla items in order to replace them with much more needed ones.

In view of the foregoing, the approval of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

ORDINANCE NO. 9047

An Ordinance Promoting Health and Wellness, and Introducing a Pollution-Free Fitness Program in the City of Manila (Walking, Jogging, Running, and Cycling) by Temporarily Closing a Portion of Roxas Boulevard (Both North and South Bound) from Padre Burgos Avenue to Quirino Avenue to All Motorized Vehicles Every Sunday from 5:00 A.M. Until 9:00 A.M.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The City of Manila recognizes the importance of physical activities in promoting a healthy and active lifestyle among its constituents, while also maintaining harmony with the city's natural and man-made environment. This led to the creation of the MOVE MANILA Program.

According to Section 21(a) of the Local Government Code of 1991, a local government unit may, through an ordinance, temporarily close or open any local road, alley, park, or square within its jurisdiction.

Participating in carless programs like walking, jogging, running, and cycling has several health benefits, including:

Increased Physical Activity: Encourages regular exercise, improving cardiovascular health and reducing the risk of obesity.

Reduced Air Pollution Exposure: By reducing reliance on cars, these programs help lower air pollution, improving respiratory health and reducing asthma rates.

Improved Mental Well-being: Active transportation methods like walking or cycling can boost mood and reduce stress levels, contributing to better mental health.

Lowered Risk of Chronic Diseases: Regular physical activity helps prevent chronic diseases like heart disease, diabetes, and certain cancers.

Enhanced Community Engagement: Walking and cycling encourage social interaction and strengthen community bonds, positively affecting emotional well-being.

The 1987 Constitution of the Philippines, Article XII, Section 11, states that the State shall adopt an integrated approach to health development, making essential services available to all at an affordable cost. Article XIV, Section 19 states that the State shall promote physical education and encourage sports programs to foster self-discipline, teamwork, and the development of a healthy citizenry.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1: Short Title
This Ordinance shall be known as the Move Manila Ordinance, a motor-vehicle and pollution-free health and wellness program for the City of Manila.

SECTION 2: Purpose
The Move Manila Program encourages Filipinos to engage in age-appropriate physical activities, in line with the Philippine National Guidelines on Physical Activity (2010) by the Department of Health (DOH). It also promotes mental well-being, as stated in the Mental Health Act (Republic Act 11036).

The program supports the Supreme Court's continuing mandate regarding Manila Bay, promoting environmental awareness and making the Manila Bay area an integral part of a livable and walkable city. The program also aligns with Manila's tourism goals, promoting the natural beauty of Manila Bay, its world-famous view, and the architectural design of Roxas Boulevard.

SECTION 3: Implementation
The City of Manila will temporarily close a portion of Roxas Boulevard (both North and South Bound) from Padre Burgos Avenue to Quirino Avenue every Sunday from 5:00 A.M. to 9:00 A.M. to promote health and wellness through a pollution-free fitness program.

SECTION 4: Contingencies
Traffic flow during the closure will be carefully managed by the appropriate agencies to ensure timely travel and efficient delivery of goods and services. Light motor vehicles will be diverted to parallel service roads, while heavy motor vehicles will be rerouted to main thoroughfares like Taft Avenue.

Emergency responders and hydration stations will be placed along Roxas Boulevard to support program participants and the public. Waste management measures will be implemented before and after each event to ensure a clean and healthy environment.

SECTION 5: Key Agencies
The following agencies will coordinate the safe and efficient implementation of the Move Manila Program:

Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) - Lead Agency

Manila Sports Council (MASCO)

Manila Health Department (MHD)

Department of Public Services - Manila (DPS)

Manila Disaster and Risk Reduction Management Office (MDRRMO)

Manila Barangay Bureau (MBB)

Manila Public Information Office (MPIO)

Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts of Manila (DTCAM)

Manila Police District (MPD)

SECTION 6: Funding
The City of Manila shall allocate funds from its annual budget for the implementation of this Ordinance.

SECTION 7: Repealing Clause
All ordinances, rules, and regulations in conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or amended accordingly.

SECTION 8: Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 2, 2024.
short_text:
This ordinance introduces the Move Manila Program, a health and wellness initiative aimed at promoting physical activities like walking, jogging, running, and cycling in a pollution-free environment. Every Sunday from 5:00 A.M. to 9:00 A.M., a section of Roxas Boulevard (from Padre Burgos Avenue to Quirino Avenue) will be temporarily closed to motorized vehicles. This initiative encourages the public to engage in fitness activities while reducing air pollution and fostering mental well-being.

The program aligns with national health guidelines and environmental goals, supporting both individual health and the improvement of Manila Bay's surrounding area. The program is supported by several city agencies, including the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau, the Manila Health Department, and the Department of Tourism. It is designed to create a safer, cleaner, and more active environment for the people of Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 9046

An Ordinance Granting Exemption to the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) from Payment of Amusement Tax for the Holding of the 89th Season Volleyball Tournament at San Andres Sports Complex, Malate, Manila on April 9–10, 2024

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), founded in 1924, is the oldest athletic association in the Philippines. The NCAA oversees eleven (11) sports categories and organizes competitions in both junior (high school) and senior (college) divisions.

For the 99th season of the NCAA, hosted by Jose Rizal University, the association is seeking an exemption from amusement tax to facilitate the holding of the volleyball tournament at the San Andres Sports Complex, located in Malate, Manila, on April 9–10, 2024.

This exemption will help minimize the financial burden on the NCAA and support the successful execution of the tournament. The event aims to promote camaraderie and sportsmanship among Filipino athletes, fostering physical and psychological development.

In light of the city’s continuous support for student activities and its role in promoting sports development, the City Council of Manila is requested to approve the exemption from the amusement tax for this event.

SECTION 1
The City Council of Manila hereby grants an exemption from the payment of amusement tax to the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) for the holding of the 89th Season Volleyball Tournament at the San Andres Sports Complex, Malate, Manila, from April 9–10, 2024.

SECTION 2
This ordinance shall take effect immediately upon approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 2, 2024.
short_text:
This ordinance grants the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) an exemption from the payment of amusement tax for hosting the 89th Season Volleyball Tournament at the San Andres Sports Complex in Malate, Manila, on April 9–10, 2024. The NCAA, which oversees college and high school sports in the country, is organizing the tournament as part of its 99th season to promote sportsmanship and camaraderie among Filipino athletes.

The exemption will reduce the financial burden on the NCAA, ensuring the successful execution of the event. This initiative aligns with the city’s ongoing support for student activities and sports development, aiming to foster physical and psychological growth among the youth.

ORDINANCE NO. 9045

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION TO THE PARTICIPANTS OF THE MANILA FILM FESTIVAL 2024 FROM PAYMENT OF NECESSARY MAYOR'S PERMIT FEE, AMUSEMENT TAX AND OTHER INCIDENTAL EXPENSES FOR FILM SHOOTING FEATURING IMPORTANT LANDSCAPES AND HISTORICAL SITES WITHIN THE JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA UNTIL MAY 15, 2024
EXPLANATORY NOTE

The city-wide Film Festival was a brainchild in the 1960s of the former Manila Mayor Antonio Villegas. The film festival was an initiative to showcase and give a platform to the talents of the participants in the film-making industry. However, this film festival was put into halt in 29 years. By the will of the City Government of Manila, the film festival returns for its second edition, this time, inviting students nationwide in an even greater effort to encourage and empower the youth by engaging them with activities that will further develop their skills and capacities as young artists.

This ordinance seeks to exempt the participating students nationwide for the completion of their official entries to the upcoming The Manila Film Festival 2024 from the payment of Mayor's Permit, amusement tax, and other incidental expenses for the venues that they will be featuring within the City of Manila. This will subsidize and promote the participants of The Manila Film Festival to produce a world-class film without hampering their financial capacity to produce one.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Exemption from payment of the necessary Mayor's Permit fee, amusement tax and other incidental expenses is hereby granted and authorized in favor of The Manila Film Festival (TMFF) 2024 for the filming of their entries that will be featuring important landscapes and historical sites within the jurisdiction of the City of Manila until May 15, 2024.

SEC. 2. Participants. — The participants of the TMFF are as follows:
  1. De La Salle - College of Saint Benilde
  2. UP Film Institute
  3. Colegio De San Juan De Letran - Manila
  4. iACADEMY
  5. Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila
  6. Adamson University
  7. Bicol University
  8. Dwein Baltazar
  9. JP Habac
  10. Sigrid Bernardo
  11. Jose Lorenzo "Pepe" Diokno

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon approval.



This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 30, 2024.
short_text: This ordinance grants an exemption from paying the Mayor's Permit fee, amusement tax, and other incidental expenses for participants of the Manila Film Festival 2024. The exemption applies to filming activities within Manila's jurisdiction featuring important landscapes and historical sites and is valid until May 15, 2024. The goal is to support student filmmakers and promote cultural heritage through accessible film production.

ORDINANCE NO. 9038

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A MORATORIUM ON THE COLLECTION OF AMUSEMENT TAXES FOR LOCALLY PRODUCED FILIPINO FILMS IN THE CITY OF MANILA COVERING THE PERIOD JANUARY 8 TO DECEMBER 24 FOR CALENDAR YEARS 2024, 2025, AND 2026

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The proposed measure is in consonance with MMDA Resolution No. 24-11, Series of 2024, declaring a moratorium for Filipino films in Metro Manila from January 8 to December 24 of every year for the next three (3) years, and reflects the city's responsibility to provide support and help promote the local film industry. The city recognizes the importance of the local film industry in contributing to the economic development of Manila. The instant measure's purpose is to increase the regulatory fee schedules to further protect the business activities happening in the City of Manila. 

In a chance meeting on the 13th of March 2024, with Ms. Rachel Villaluna, representative from the Film Development Council of the Philippines, she expressed support and gratefulness for the passing of this proposed ordinance. She shared that in order to compensate for the decrease in patronage of Filipino films, support and encouragement from the cities of Metro Manila is indispensable. This Sanggunian should consider the propriety of granting a moratorium on the collection of amusement tax to help alleviate the financial burden on the local film industry. We should always adhere to the patriotic message of "Tangkilikin ang sariling atin!".

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Grant of Moratorium.
A moratorium on the collection of Amusement Tax levied on locally produced Filipino films is hereby granted and authorized.
SEC. 2. Duration.
The Moratorium shall be effective covering the period from January 8 to December 24 for Calendar Years 2024, 2025, and 2026.
SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 19, 2024.
short_text: The City of Manila will not collect amusement taxes on locally produced Filipino movies from January 8 to December 24 during the years 2024, 2025, and 2026. This aims to support and boost the local film industry, helping it recover and thrive. The moratorium was passed to encourage more support for Filipino-made films and reduce their financial burden.

ORDINANCE NO. 9030

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION TO DR PRODUCTIONS, HEADED BY
ITS PRESIDENT, DAISY ROMUALDEZ, FROM PAYMENT OF MAYOR'S PERMIT, AMUSEMENT TAX, AND OTHER INCIDENTAL EXPENSES IN THE UPCOMING EVENT, ENTITLED: "TRIBUTE TO THE QUEEN" IN HONOR OF MS. GLORIA ROMERO, A PILLAR OF THE PHILIPPINE MOVIE INDUSTRY, TO BE HELD AT THE MANILA HOTEL ON FEBRUARY 28, 2024

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Ms. Gloria Romero is a Filipino actress known for her work in film and television.
She has appeared in numerous movies and TV shows since the 1950s and is considered one of the most respected and talented actresses in Philippine cinema. Some of her notable films include "Sisa," "Sa Bawat Pintig ng Puso," and "Ganito Kami Noon, Paano Kayo Ngayon?" Romero has received numerous awards throughout her career, including several FAMAS Awards (Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards) for Best Actress. Her contributions to the Philippine entertainment industry have made her a legendary figure in Filipino cinema.

Ms. Romero is one of the major stars of Philippine cinema's Golden Age and is one of the longest-working Filipino actresses in Philippine entertainment. She has been a significant figure, influencing many to pursue a career in the film industry.

This upcoming event aims to honor the legendary Ms. Gloria Romero, a pillar of the entertainment industry, with a career spanning over 50 years. As such, this ordinance seeks to exempt the upcoming event hosted by Ms. Daisy Romualdez on February 28, 2024, at the Manila Hotel, from payment of amusement tax and other incidental expenses for the event, in recognition of the contributions of Ms. Gloria Romero to the entertainment industry, as well as an expression of gratitude for the charitable event held in her name.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Exemption from of mayor's permit, amusement tax, and other incidental expenses for the upcoming event, entitled: “Tribute to the Queen” in honor of Ms. Gloria Romero, a pillar of the Philippine movie industry to be held at the Manila Hotel on February 28, 2024, is hereby granted and authorized.

SECTION 2. The grantee shall, within twenty (20) days after the holding of the event, submit a full accounting of the proceeds thereof to Her Honor, the Mayor, and the City Council of Manila.

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 22, 2024.
short_text: The Manila City Council passed an ordinance allowing DR Productions, led by Daisy Romualdez, to skip paying the mayor's permit, amusement tax, and other event-related fees for their "Tribute to the Queen" event honoring legendary actress Gloria Romero at the Manila Hotel on February 28, 2024. DR Productions must submit a full report of the event’s earnings to the Mayor and City Council within 20 days after the event. The ordinance took effect immediately after approval.

ORDINANCE NO. 9029

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 1 AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO. 6507, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 7716, AND INSERTING SEVERAL SECTIONS THERETO

EXPLANATORY NOTE
There have been instances in the past and recent times wherein law enforcement units/elements, in the guise of an inspection, ended in business owners being harassed, which gave rise to the enactment of City Ordinance No. 6507, amended by Ordinance No. 7716.

Section 1 of Ordinance No. 7716 clearly shows that the prohibition to inspect business establishments in the City of Manila, for the purpose of enforcing sanitary rules and regulations, as well as their licenses and permits, and/or enforcing internal revenue and customs laws and regulations, applies solely to the then Western Police District (WPD), now the Manila Police District.

The said provision is restrictive and insufficient in character as it does not cover other law enforcement agencies who may commit the proscribed act, thereby rendering the efforts of the City Government of Manila to avert police harassment — the very evil that Ordinance No. 7716 seeks to deter.

Perusal of Section 2 of Ordinance No. 6507 likewise reveals the inadequacy of the penalties for its violation to prevent, preclude, and stop the corruption resulting from police harassment, as well as in securing and protecting owners and operators of business establishments in the City of Manila.

Considering that Ordinance No. 6507 and Ordinance No. 7716 are both deficient and lack coercive power to deter police personnel from violating their commandments, it will have a deleterious effect on the business sector and the public welfare unless revised, improved, and modified.

Section 5, Article II of the 1987 Philippine Constitution declares that the maintenance of peace and order, the protection of life, liberty and property, and the promotion of general welfare are essential for the enjoyment by all the people of the blessings of democracy.

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, emphatically declares that “every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare.”

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. PROHIBITED ACTS. — Section 1 of Ordinance No. 6507, as amended by Ordinance No. 7716, is hereby further amended to read as follows:
“Section 1. No member of the Philippine National Police and other law enforcement agencies shall conduct inspection of any store, business, industrial, and commercial establishments in the City of Manila, including, but not limited to, permits and licenses duly and regularly issued to them by the City Government of Manila, for the purpose of or in the guise of enforcing sanitary, internal revenue, and customs laws, rules, and regulations without proper coordination with, knowledge and assistance of, and authority from the concerned departments, bureaus, and offices of the National or Local Government, as the case may be, pursuant to existing and applicable guidelines.”

SEC. 2. PENALTIES. — Section 2 of Ordinance No. 6507 is hereby amended to read as follows:
“Sec. 2. Any violation of this Ordinance shall be punishable as follows:
FIRST OFFENSE: A fine of One Thousand Pesos (PhP 1,000.00) or imprisonment of not less than 10 days or more than 30 days, or both, at the discretion of the court.

SECOND OFFENSE: A fine of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 3,000.00) or imprisonment of not less than 20 days nor more than 30 days, or both, at the discretion of the court.

THIRD AND SUCCEEDING OFFENSES: A fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00) and imprisonment of not less than 1 month nor more than 6 months, or both, at the discretion of the court.”

SEC. 3. SHORT TITLE. — This Ordinance shall now be known and cited as the “Anti-Business Harassment Ordinance of 2024” for brevity.

SEC. 4. SCOPE. — This Ordinance shall cover all employees, uniformed personnel, and units of the Philippine National Police (PNP) and other law enforcement agencies.

SEC. 5. DEFINITION OF TERMS. — As used in this Ordinance, the following shall mean:
•        a) Store — any business facility that sells goods directly to the consumer including, but not limited to, retail shops, restaurants, pharmacies, and supermarkets, whether seasonal or temporary;
•        b) Business Establishment — any person, natural or juridical, whether single proprietorship or corporation, engaged in or doing business, either in selling goods or providing services;
•        c) Commercial Establishment — any establishment where people are employed to provide services or do office work, including, but not limited to, banks, insurance and trading companies, hotels, cafes, boarding houses, dormitories, and institutions of similar nature;
•        d) Industrial Establishment — any establishment engaged in manufacturing or processing business, including, but not limited to, factories, slaughterhouses, mills, refineries, processing plants, and enterprises of similar nature;
•        e) Law Enforcement Agency — any government agency responsible for the enforcement of laws, as well as discovering, deterring, rehabilitating, or penalizing those violating the same.

SEC. 6. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE.  —  In the event any part or provision of this Ordinance is declared illegal or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. REPEALING CLAUSE. —  All previous ordinances and rules/regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby deemed modified or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. — This Ordinance shall take effect after all requirements for official posting prescribed in Section 511 of R.A. No. 7160, otherwise known as “The Local Government Code of 1991”, have been met.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 13, 2024.
short_text: The Manila City Council updated an ordinance to strengthen protections for business owners against harassment by police and other law enforcement during inspections. Law enforcers are now prohibited from inspecting business permits or licenses without proper coordination and approval from the concerned government offices. This ordinance, now called the “Anti-Business Harassment Ordinance of 2024,” also sets clear fines and jail time for violators, increasing penalties for repeated offenses. It applies to all employees and units of the Philippine National Police (PNP) and other law enforcement agencies.

ORDINANCE NO. 9027

AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE
PANTAWID PAMILYA PILIPINO PROGRAM (4PS) IN THE CITY OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The State shall promote a just and dynamic social order, thereby uplifting its
citizens and marginalized sectors from poverty through policies that provide adequate
social services, promote full employment, a rising standard of living, and an improved
quality of life for all. The State further recognizes the need to foster social justice as
provided for in Article XIII of the 1987 Constitution.

The Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program (4PS) is the national poverty reduction
strategy and a human capital investment program that provides conditional cash transfers
to poor households for a maximum period of seven (7) years, to improve the health,
nutrition, and education aspects of their lives as provided for under Republic Act No. 11310
pursuant to the above constitutional mandate.

The City Government of Manila recognizes its role in ensuring inclusive
development and commits to address the needs of the poor within its jurisdiction.

The Sangguniang Panlungsod of the City of Manila, in support of the Pantawid
Pamilyang Pilipino Program of the National Government, hereby (institutionalized) and
expanded the benefits of this program in order to further improve the gains reached by
the 4Ps beneficiary-residents in the City of Manila.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Short Title. - This shall otherwise be known as the “Expanded
Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program (4Ps) Ordinance of the City of Manila”.

SEC. 2. Applicability. - This Ordinance is applicable to all qualified Pantawid
Pamilyang Pilipino Program (4Ps) Beneficiaries under Republic Act No. 11310 residing
in the City of Manila.

SEC. 3. Definition of Terms. - As used in this Ordinance, the following terms
are hereby defined as follows:
a. Beneficiaries refers to the households identified by the DSWD for entitlement
to the monthly conditional cash grants as provided under Republic Act
No. 11310 residing in the City of Manila.
b. Benefits refers to the expanded benefits described in Section 4 of this
Ordinance.
c. Institutionalization refers to the expansion of the benefits of the Pantawid
Pamilyang Pilipino Program (4Ps) to be received by the qualified beneficiaries
of the program who are residents of the City of Manila.
d. Kilos Unlad Care Management Framework refers (to) the social case
management strategy which aims to guide the households in achieving
improved well-being from survival to subsistence to eventually self-sufficiency.

SEC. 4. Expanded Benefits of the Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program
(4Ps). - Notwithstanding that the mandate under Republic Act No. 11310 is unto the
National Government, its agencies and instrumentalities, by this local legislation, the
City of Manila formally imposes unto itself the obligation of providing interventions to the
4Ps beneficiaries and their families such as:
a. Guaranteed and continued preferential access to the City Social Services and
Welfare Programs.
b. Grant of city scholarships or educational support to 4Ps Beneficiaries’ Qualified
Dependents under the existing Education Program of the City.
c. Employment assistance for the 4Ps beneficiaries and their Qualified Dependents
through the City's Public Employment Service Office (PESO).
d. Medical assistance through the City Health Department and Social Welfare
Department.
e. Social protection services to qualified sectors (person with disability, senior
citizen, solo parent) provided by the City Government of Manila.
f. Other needed interventions/services which can be provided by the City's Local
Advisory Council members based on assessment and qualifications. Specifically,
in the conduct of 4Ps graduation ceremonies of all Manila City candidates for exit/
graduation from the program.

SEC. 5. Strengthening the Local Advisory Council and Its Sub
Committee/Teams. - The City Government created the Local Advisory Council, headed
by the Local Chief Executive as Chairperson and the concerned Heads of Offices as
Members providing social protection programs on education, skills, health, nutrition,
housing, employment, economic, and the like. They convene as scheduled and report
their respective accomplishments in aiding the 4Ps beneficiaries.
The Local Advisory Council shall recognize sub-committees/teams which are
deemed necessary for the support of institutionalizing the expanded benefits of the 4Ps
beneficiaries in the City of Manila, to wit:
a. Case Management Team - An aggrupation whose function is to plan
interventions to be provided to 4Ps households based on assessed needs
using the Kilos Unlad Case Management tools to help them improve their
level of well-being upon entry and until they graduate/exit from the program.
b. Family Development Session (FDS) Team - The FDS Team shall act as
subject matter experts or resource persons on (afeas) of concerns. They shall
likewise aim to provide a venue for 4Ps beneficiaries to enhance and acquire
new skills and knowledge in response to their parental roles and
responsibilities, promoting the concept of shared parenting.
The DSWD-NCR implementer of the FDS shall monitor the overall conduct of
the FDS including its impact on the beneficiaries and prepare reportorial
requirements in accordance with the set templates and timelines. It shall also
propose enhancements and/or new developments to existing policies and FDS
materials.
c. Barangay Local Action Team (LAT)/Committee - The Barangay LAT/Committee shall
replicate the function of the Local Advisory Council at the barangay level, with
its funding included in the Barangay Plan.

SEC. 6. Funding. - The City Government shall allocate the funds necessary to
cover the expenses needed for the implementation of this Ordinance and its projects,
programs, and activities.

SEC. 7. Formulation of Internal Rules and Regulations. - The Local Advisory
Council, in coordination with the City Legal Office, shall formulate within sixty (60) days
upon the effectivity of this Ordinance the corresponding Internal Rules and Regulations
(IRR) for the proper implementation of this Ordinance and submit the same to the City
Council of Manila for its ratification.
The IRR shall include the creation of a Technical Working Group composed of
representatives from the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW), the City Legal
Office, City Planning and Development Office (CPDO), the Public Employment Service
Office (PESO), and the Manila Health Department (MHD) among others.

SEC. 8. Governing Law. - In the implementation of this Ordinance, the
provisions of Republic Act No. 11310, otherwise known as the Pantawid Pamilyang
Pilipino Program (4Ps) Act and its implementing rules and regulations, shall be deemed
written unto this Ordinance.

SEC. 9. Separability Clause. - In the event that any section or provision of this
Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, other sections or provisions unaffected
shall remain valid and effective.

SEC. 10. Repealing Clause. - All prior inconsistent ordinances are hereby
repealed and/or modified accordingly.

SEC. (11). Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately, and
shall continue to be in force and effect until revoked or set aside.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 30, 2024.
short_text: The City of Manila officially supports and strengthens the national 4Ps program, which gives cash aid to poor families to help with their children’s health, nutrition, and education. Aside from the national benefits, the city will now also give additional help like easier access to scholarships, job assistance, free medical help, and social services for special sectors like seniors and persons with disabilities. The city will also have teams at both city and barangay levels to personally guide and support 4Ps families until they become self-sufficient. Funds will be provided by the City Government, and rules will be created to make sure everything runs properly.

The City of Manila passed the Barangay Nutrition Program Strengthening Ordinance of 2023, requiring every barangay to have one Barangay Nutrition Scholar (BNS) to provide health, nutrition, and community services. BNS must render 100 hours monthly for a year, undergo a training and practicum, and meet specific qualifications like being a resident for 6 years and at least an elementary graduate. After completing service, they are eligible for second-grade civil service eligibility and possible allowances. The Manila Health Department and other local offices will manage the program.

ORDINANCE NO. 9025

AN ORDINANCE FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF PRE-EMPTIVE AND/OR FORCED EVACUATIONS IN THE CITY OF MANILA BEFORE AND DURING A DISASTER OR CALAMITY

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 2(a) of Republic Act No. 10121, otherwise known as the “Philippine Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Act of 2010”, declares it as a State policy to uphold the people’s constitutional rights to life and property by addressing the root causes of vulnerabilities to disasters, strengthening the country’s institutional capacity for disaster risk reduction and management, and building the resilience of local communities to disasters, including the impacts of climate change.

The General Welfare Clause of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as “The Local Government Code of 1991,” authorizes Local Government Units (LGUs) to exercise powers necessary, appropriate and/or incidental to the effective and efficient governance essential for promoting the general welfare of the public.

Sections 455(b)(vii) and 389(b) [f] of the same Code mandate City Mayors and Punong Barangays to carry out emergency measures deemed necessary during and in the aftermath of man-made or natural disasters and calamities.

Memorandum Circular No. 2012-35 dated February 21, 2012, issued by the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), enjoins local legislators to enact ordinances providing for the enforcement of pre-emptive and forced evacuation of endangered residents during a declared emergency or disaster that may result in loss of lives and destruction of properties.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. DECLARATION OF POLICY —  It is the declared policy of the City of Manila to protect the lives and properties of its residents at all times, and whenever possible, to mitigate the effects of human-induced and natural disasters within its locality.

SECTION 2. DEFINITION OF TERMS:
As used in this Ordinance:
•        2.1. Disaster — A serious disruption of the functions in a community or society involving widespread human, material, economic, or environmental losses and impacts, which exceed the community's capacity to cope using its own resources. Impacts may include loss of life, injury, disease, social disruption, and environmental degradation;

•        2.2. Evacuation — The temporary relocation, whether voluntary or organized, of all or part of a particular population from a disaster-stricken or imminently dangerous area to a safer place;

•        2.3. Forced Evacuation — An order by a competent authority to forcibly evacuate residents to protect their lives during a disaster;

•        2.4. Imminent Danger — An immediate threat of harm to a community or specific area;

•        2.5. Incident Commander (IC) — The person responsible for all aspects of emergency response operations, including developing incident objectives, managing resources, and ensuring accountability for all involved personnel;

•        2.6. Pre-emptive Evacuation — An order by a competent authority to evacuate residents before a disaster strikes to forestall exposure to imminent danger.

SECTION 3. ENFORCEMENT OF PRE-EMPTIVE EVACUATION - Upon reasonable assessment by the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (MDRRMC) or the Incident Commander (IC), pre-emptive evacuation shall be enforced in high-risk areas, with prior approval from the City Mayor (Chairman of the MDRRMC).

SECTION 4. DECLARATION OF FORCED EVACUATION — Upon reasonable evaluation by the MDRRMC or the Incident Commander (IC) that a force evacuation of local resident/s is/are necessary, a recommendation to the City Mayor (MDRRMC Chairman) shall be made for an immediate-declaration of force evacuation.

On the basis of such recommendation, the City Mayor may immediately declare implementation of force evacuation and perform other functions not limited to the following:
•        4.1. Establish evacuation centers or relocation sites to temporarily shelter displaced persons under the supervision of the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW).
•        4.2. Designate vehicle staging areas for transport to evacuation centers.
•        4.3. Secure affected properties against looting or theft.
•        4.4. Direct the MDSW to provide for the needs of the evacuees.
•        4.5. Mobilize the City Pound under the Veterinary Inspection Board (VIB) to take custody of affected animals.

SECTION 5. MOBILIZATION OF OTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES
The City Mayor may mobilize the Philippine National Police (PNP), Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP), Philippine Coast Guard (PCG), Philippine Navy (PN), and Bureau of Jail Management and Penology (BJMP) to aid in evacuation efforts.

SECTION 6. REFUSAL TO EVACUATE
If residents refuse to evacuate or return to their homes without an authorized order:
•        The City Mayor and mobilized units may use reasonable and necessary force to evacuate residents.
•        Special care must be given to vulnerable groups (children, women, the elderly, and PWDs).
•        Residents who refuse to evacuate shall release the City Government from liability for any resulting injury or death.
•        Priority will be given to residents who comply voluntarily.

SECTION 7. TRAINING AND ORIENTATION
The MDRRMO, BFP, and PNP shall conduct basic training and orientation seminars at least once a year on pre-emptive and forced evacuation procedures. Topics shall include:
•        The provisions of this Ordinance
•        Republic Act 10121 (Philippine Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Act of 2010)
•        DILG Memorandum Circular No. 2012-35
•        Other relevant laws, rules, and regulations

SECTION 8. REPORTORIAL CLAUSE
Within twenty-four (24) hours after the declaration of a pre-emptive or forced evacuation, the City Mayor must communicate the declaration to the MDRRMC and the Sangguniang Panlungsod for appropriate action.

SECTION 9. ROLE OF BARANGAY ON DISASTER PREPAREDNESS
Each barangay shall:
•        9.a. Develop a Barangay Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Plan.
•        9.b. Conduct vulnerability assessments and identify hazards and affected populations.
•        9.c. Formulate intervention measures for post-disaster scenarios.
•        9.d. Coordinate closely with the MDRRMO before, during, and after disasters.

SECTION 10. PROHIBITED ACTS
It shall be unlawful for any public officer, employee, or any person to:
•        10.a. Neglect duties leading to loss of life, destruction of property, or waste of public funds.
•        10.b. Disobey lawful evacuation orders or return to dwellings without clearance.
•        10.c. Engage in looting or offenses against persons or properties during calamities.
•        10.d. Sell, divert, forcibly seize, or misdeliver relief goods intended for disaster victims.

SECTION 11. PENAL CLAUSE
Any violation of Section 10 shall be punishable by:
•        A fine of not less than ₱2,000.00 but not more than ₱5,000.00; or
•        Imprisonment of not more than one (1) year; or
•        Both, at the court's discretion.
If the offender is a public officer or employee, administrative sanctions such as suspension or dismissal from office may also apply.

SECTION 12. IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS (IRR)
The MDRRMO, MDSW, Manila Barangay Bureau (MBB), Manila Health Department (MHD), Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW), and Department of Public Services (DPS) shall draft and promulgate the IRR to effectively implement this Ordinance.

SECTION 13. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE
If any part of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining provisions shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 14. REPEALING CLAUSE
All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules, and regulations or parts thereof which are inconsistent with any of the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.





SECTION 15. EFFECTIVITY
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval 

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
January 30, 2024.
short_text: The City of Manila passed a law allowing pre-emptive and forced evacuations before or during disasters to protect residents' lives and properties. If the situation is dangerous, the City Mayor can order evacuations, set up shelters, and mobilize agencies like the police and fire department to assist. Residents who refuse to leave can be forcibly evacuated for their safety, and anyone violating evacuation rules, looting, or mishandling relief goods can be fined, jailed, or both. Barangays must create their own disaster plans and undergo regular training to prepare for emergencies.
fines: Fine of PhP2,000 to PhP5,000, imprisonment up to 1 year, or both; additional administrative sanctions for public officials like suspension or dismissal.

full_text: MISSING

ORDINANCE NO. 9022
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF GRATUITY PAY TO CONTRACT
OF SERVICE AND JOB ORDER WORKERS IN THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA
PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATVE ORDER NO0. 13, SERIES OF
2023, AND
PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF FIFTY MILLION
FIVE
HUNDRED THIRTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP.
50,535,000.00) AND FOR
OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

On December 7, 2023, President Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr. issued Administrative
Order (A.0.) No. 13, Series of 2023, entitled: "Authorizing the Grant of Gratuity Pay to
Contract of Service and Job Order Workers in the Government for Fiscal Year 2023".
A.0. No. 13 stated that while Contract of Service (COS) and Job Order (JO)
workers in the government are paid salaries/wages equivalent to those received by
personnel occupying comparable positions in government and a premium of up to 20%
of such salary/wage, they do not enjoy benefits accorded to government employees as
they have no employer-employee relationship with the govermment.

It further provided that granting a year-end Gratuity Pay to COS and JO workers
is a well-deserved recognition of their hard work in implementing programs, projects and
activities, and pivotal role in the delivery of government services amidst the present socio economic challenges.

Section 5 of A.0. No. 13 mandated that local government units (LGUs) are
enjoined to adopt in their respective offices the grant of Gratuity Pay to workers whose
services are engaged through COS and J0, utilizing appropriate and available funding
sources from their respective local government funds. The corresponding supplemental
budget for the purpose shallbe enacted by the local sanggunian concened within FY
2023.

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991
provides that the LGUs shal exercise the powers that are essential to the promotion of
the general welfare. it shal ensure and support, among other things, the enhancerment of

ORDINANCE NO. 9021

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF THE SERVICE RECOGNITION INCENTIVE FOR QUALIFIED GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 2023, PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 12, SERIES OF 2023, AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE AMOUNT OF NINETY MILLION THREE HUNDRED NINETY THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 90,390,000.00), AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

On December 7, 2023, President Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr., issued Administrative Order (AO) No. 12, authorizing the grant of a one-time Service Recognition Incentive (SRI) for each qualified government employee for fiscal year (FY) 2023.

AO No. 12 recognizes the collective and invaluable contributions of all government employees to the government's ongoing efforts in achieving the objectives, commitments, targets, and deliverables under the Philippine Development Plan 2023-2028 and the President’s 8-Point Socioeconomic Agenda.

Section 6 of AO No. 12 provides for the grant of SRIs to employees in Local Government Units (LGUs) as follows:
“The grant of the one-time SRI to employees in LGUs, including those in barangays, shall be determined by their respective Sanggunians depending on the LG's financial capability, subject to the Personal Services (PS) limitation in LGU budgets under RA No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991, and the conditions set forth in Section 2 hereof, at a uniform rate not exceeding PHP 20,000.00, chargeable against their respective FY 2023 local government funds. If the identified funding source is insufficient to cover the full amount of the SRI, a lower but uniform amount shall be paid to all qualified employees of the LGU.”

In determining the SRI amount, the Sanggunians shall ensure prudence and the judicious use of government funds, ensuring that the expenditure is reasonable and will not negatively impact the delivery of public services.

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, the Local Government Code of 1991, states:
“Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare.”

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:

SECTION 1.
The grant of a one-time Service Recognition Incentive (SRI) for FY 2023, not exceeding PHP 10,000.00 to qualified government employees, is hereby authorized, subject to the conditions outlined in Administrative Order No. 12, s. 2023, and appropriate guidelines that may be issued by the Department of Budget and Management.

SECTION 2.
The SRI, totaling PHP 90,390,000.00, shall be funded from the Special Activities Fund-Personal Services (SAF-PS) Account under the Special Purpose Appropriations (SPAs) of the FY 2023 Executive Budget.

SECTION 3.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 14, 2023.
short_text:
This ordinance authorizes the grant of a one-time Service Recognition Incentive (SRI) for qualified government employees in Manila for fiscal year 2023, in accordance with Administrative Order No. 12, Series of 2023. The incentive is provided as a recognition of the employees' valuable contributions to the government's goals and the Philippine Development Plan 2023-2028.

The total amount allocated for this SRI is PHP 90,390,000, with each qualified employee receiving up to PHP 10,000, depending on available funds. The payment will be charged against the city's Special Activities Fund in the 2023 budget.

The ordinance ensures that the distribution of the incentive will be done responsibly, without affecting the delivery of public services, and takes effect immediately upon approval.

ORDINANCE NO. 9019

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING DEATH BENEFIT WELFARE ASSISTANCE IN THI
AMOUNT OF THREE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 3,000.00) TO THE BEREAVED
FAMILIES OF ALL BONA FIDE RESIDENTS OR REGISTERED VOTERS OF THE CITY
OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Stated on Section 16 of the Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as “The Local
Government Code of 1991” states that: “every local government unit shall exercise the
powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied there from, as well as powers
necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance and those are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things...”

In the last three (3) years (2020-2022), the Manila City Civil Registry Office has
recorded an average of eleven thousand (11,000) Death Certificates applications per
annum, which are mostly bona fide residents of the City of Manila.

To express sympathy and gratitude to its dearly departed constituents, and
considering the escalating costs of burial services nowadays, the City Government of
Manila recognizes the need to further support its citizens by providing primary financial
assistance as well as emotional support to their bereaved families.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as the “UNANG
ABULOY NG MAYNILA" - DEATH BENEFIT ORDINANCE OF 2023.

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. — As used in this Ordinance the following terms are
defined as follows:

a. Financial Assistance - any form of grant or other form of direct or indirect
assistance extended by any agency.

b. Bona Fide - genuine; legitimate.

c. Decedent - a person who has died.

d. Bereaved - deprived of a close relation through their death.

e. Claimant - a person making a claim for a government-sponsored benefit.

SEC. 3. Coverage. — The City of Manila shall allocate and appropriate Funeral
Assistance in the amount of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) plus and/or Sympathy Card or any token equivalent to/or amounting not more than One Thousand
Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00).

SEC. 4. Beneficiary. — The "Unang Abuloy ng Maynila” death benefit shail be
primarily given to the legal spouse of the deceased. Should there be no spouse who
survives the decedent, the benefit granted under this Ordinance shall be given to relatives in the following order of degree of kinship: children, parents, siblings, grandchildren, aunts
and uncles.

SEC. 5. Eligibility for Availment. — The deceased shail be established by
competent documents of residency, who, at the time of death, was a bona fide resident
of the City of Manila or duly registered voter of the City of Manila. And for minors, aged under 18 years who met their untimely deaths, any of the parents should be a registered voter or a resident of the City of Manila.

SEC. 6. Processing of Claim. — The following shall be submitted by the claimant
of the "Unang Abuloy sa Maynila" Death Benefit:

a. Duly filled-up Claimants’ Form issued by the Manila Department of Social
Welfare (MDSW);

b. Certified true copy of Death Certificate;

c. Valid government issued identification card of the relative/representative.
d. Barangay Certificate of Residency of the deceased.

SEC. 7. implementing Department. — The Manila Department of Social Welfare
(MDSW) shall be the lead department in the implementation of this Ordinance with
assistance from the Civil Registry Office of Manila. The MDSW will also be tasked to draft
the Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR) of this Ordinance.

Moreover, The Manila Barangay Bureau (MBB) together with the officers of the
Liga ng mga Barangay ng Maynila will provide assistance in gathering pertinent data such
as reports of death from Barangays and assist in the distribution of said “Unang Abuloy"
benefits.

SEC. 8. Appropriation. — The City of Manila shall allocate a substantial amount
for the implementation of this Ordinance under its Maintenance and Other Operating
Expenses (MOOE).

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. - Ail ordinances, rules and regulations, or part thereof, in conflict with or inconsistent with any provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed
and modified or amended accordingly;

SEC. 10. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect in the next Fiscal
Year budget after its public hearing and posting requirements in newspaper of general
circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 14,
2023.
short_text: The "Unang Abuloy ng Maynila" Ordinance grants a death benefit of PhP3,000 and a sympathy token worth up to PhP1,000 to the bereaved families of bona fide residents or registered voters of Manila. The benefit prioritizes the legal spouse, followed by close relatives in a defined order. The Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) will handle implementation, with support from other local offices. This ordinance will take effect in the next fiscal year following its publication and public hearing.

ORDINANCE NO. 9018

AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE PROVISIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 7883, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “BARANGAY HEALTH WORKERS’ BENEFITS AND INCENTIVES ACT OF 1995,” AS WELL AS ITS IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS, PROVIDING FOR THE REQUIREMENTS FOR THE ACCREDITATION OF BARANGAY HEALTH WORKERS AND THE CREATION OF THE BARANGAY HEALTH WORKER REGISTRATION AND ACCREDITATION COMMITTEE, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy.
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila, in upholding the constitutional right of the people to health, to strengthen the primary health care approach through the active participation of Barangay Health Workers (BHWs) as frontline personnel. Thus, they are recognized as an essential component of the healthcare system.

SECTION 2. Adoption of Republic Act No. 7883.
The provisions of Republic Act No. 7883, otherwise known as the “Barangay Health Workers’ Benefits and Incentives Act of 1995”, along with its Implementing Rules and Regulations, are hereby adopted by the City Government of Manila. This includes the provision for the accreditation of Barangay Health Workers under the following guidelines:

A. Registration
To be entitled to the benefits and incentives under this Act, barangay health workers must register with the Local Health Board of Manila, which will maintain a registry of those rendering service in the city. The Local Health Board shall furnish a copy of this registry to the Department of Health (DOH), which shall keep a national register. Accredited barangay health workers shall be issued appropriate proof of accreditation.

B. Number of Barangay Health Workers
The DOH shall determine the ideal ratio of barangay health workers to the number of households. Provided, however, that the total number of barangay health workers nationwide shall not exceed one percent (1%) of the total population.

C. Incentives and Benefits
All accredited barangay health workers who are actively and regularly performing their duties shall be entitled to the following incentives and benefits:

Hazard Allowance
Volunteer barangay health workers in both rural and urban areas who are exposed to hazardous situations that endanger their health or safety shall receive a hazard allowance, in an amount determined by the Local Health Board and the Local Peace and Order Council.

Subsistence Allowance
Barangay health workers assigned to isolated barangay health stations, to ensure their availability at all times, shall be entitled to a subsistence allowance equivalent to the value of meals consumed during duty. This shall be computed based on prevailing conditions, as determined by the local government unit concerned.

Training, Education, and Career Enrichment Programs
In coordination with the DOH, DepEd, NCCA, PSC, and relevant NGOs, barangay health workers shall have access to:

a) Educational programs recognizing years of service as credits toward higher education (e.g., midwifery, nursing, medicine).
b) Continuing education, training, immersion programs, and scholarships.
c) Tuition scholarships for one child of each barangay health worker in state colleges.
d) Special training programs in traditional medicine, disaster preparedness, and emerging community health issues.

Civil Service Eligibility
Barangay health workers who render five (5) years of continuous service shall be granted second-grade Civil Service Eligibility. Should they become regular government employees, their years of service as BHWs shall count toward retirement benefits.

Preferential Access to Loans
Within 180 days of effectivity, the DOH, with other relevant agencies, shall develop a mechanism to provide barangay health worker organizations with access to loan services, setting aside 1% of loanable funds for community-based income-generating projects supporting health programs.

Review by the Local Health Board
All incentives or benefits requiring local government funding shall be reviewed and approved by the Local Health Board to ensure that only deserving barangay health workers receive them.

SECTION 3. Funding Source.
Compensation and incentives for accredited barangay health workers shall be charged to the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the Manila Health Department (MHD), provided they meet the accreditation requirements and have rendered the necessary service.

SECTION 4. Effectivity.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA on December 12, 2023.
short_text:
This ordinance adopts Republic Act No. 7883, also known as the Barangay Health Workers’ Benefits and Incentives Act of 1995, in the City of Manila. It officially recognizes Barangay Health Workers (BHWs) as vital frontline health personnel and aims to strengthen their role in the city’s healthcare system.

To qualify for the benefits, BHWs must register and be accredited by the Local Health Board of Manila. The ordinance also mandates the creation of a Barangay Health Worker Registration and Accreditation Committee.

Accredited BHWs will receive various benefits and incentives, including:

Hazard allowance for those working in risky areas

Subsistence allowance (meal allowance) for those assigned to remote areas

Access to education and training, including scholarships and recognition of service as academic credits

Civil Service Eligibility after five years of continuous service

Retirement credit if they become regular government employees

Access to loans for health-related community projects

The funding for these benefits will come from the Manila Health Department's operational budget, and only those who meet accreditation requirements and provide active service will be eligible.

ORDINANCE NO. 9017
AN ORDINANCE BEQUEATHING HONORS TO THE LATE VICE MAYOR DANILO B. LACUNA BY NAMING THE AUDITORIUM OF THE MAIN BUILDING OF DR. ALEJANDRO ALBERT ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN HIS NAME, LOCATED AT 2110 DAPITAN STREET IN THE FOURTH DISTRICT OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The late Vice Mayor Danilo Bautista Lacuna is an icon in the City of Manila. He once served as an alderman representing what was then the 4th District of Manila from 1967 to 1975 during the now-defunct Manila Municipal Board.

During his stint as Vice Mayor, he spearheaded the passage of notable ordinances that truly benefited the Manileños.

Danny Lacuna, as he is fondly addressed by his peers, is not only the founder of the ruling local party Asenso Manileño but also the father of successful children in their respective fields.

He was always fair and proactive in dealing with his contemporaries in the City Council. He was a friend to all and enemy to none, regardless of political affiliation.

It is only fitting to immortalize the man as a simple token of gratitude for his indelible contribution to the progress of the City of Manila.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The auditorium of the main building of Dr. Alejandro Albert Elementary School, located at 2110 Dapitan Street in the Fourth District of the City of Manila, shall hereby be named the "DANILO B. LACUNA AUDITORIUM."

SEC. 2. The City Engineer of Manila is hereby directed to cause the installation of markers/signages in conspicuous corners visible to the naked eye along the specified hallway.

SEC. 3. Copies of this Ordinance shall be furnished to the Department of Education, the Division of City Schools, the Office of the Mayor, and the City Engineer's Office.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 12, 2023.

ERRATUM

Please be informed of the following corrections in Ordinance No. 9017, entitled:
"An Ordinance Bequeathing Honors to the Late Vice Mayor Danilo B. Lacuna by Naming the Hallway of the Main Building of Dr. Alejandro Albert Elementary School in His Name, Located at 2110 Dapitan Street in the Fourth District of Manila," enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 12, 2023.

The title of the Ordinance should be corrected to read as follows:
"An Ordinance Bequeathing Honors to the Late Vice Mayor Danilo B. Lacuna by Naming the Auditorium of the Main Building of Dr. Alejandro Albert Elementary School in His Name, Located at 2110 Dapitan Street in the Fourth District of Manila."

Furthermore, in Section 1, the word "Hallway" must be replaced with "Auditorium." The corrected section shall read as follows:

SECTION 1. The auditorium of the main building of Dr. Alejandro Albert Elementary School, located at 2110 Dapitan Street in the Fourth District of the City of Manila, shall hereby be named the "DANILO B. LACUNA AUDITORIUM."

We apologize for any confusion this may have caused.
short_text:
This ordinance honors the late Vice Mayor Danilo B. Lacuna for his outstanding public service and contributions to the City of Manila. As a tribute, the auditorium of the main building of Dr. Alejandro Albert Elementary School, located at 2110 Dapitan Street, Fourth District, Manila, is officially named the "DANILO B. LACUNA AUDITORIUM."

Vice Mayor Lacuna was a respected leader and legislator who authored meaningful ordinances and was known for his fairness and dedication. He also founded the local political group Asenso Manileño and raised children who have succeeded in their respective fields.

The City Engineer of Manila is tasked with installing visible markers or signages displaying the new name of the auditorium.

Copies of this ordinance will be given to the Department of Education, the Division of City Schools, the Office of the Mayor, and the City Engineer's Office for implementation.

This ordinance takes effect immediately upon approval.

Note: An error in the original ordinance mistakenly referred to a “hallway” instead of the “auditorium.” This has since been corrected.

ORDINANCE NO. 9015

ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE REVISED ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE AND PERSONNEL SCHEDULE OF THE MANILA HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND CEMETERY IN COMPLIANCE WITH REPUBLIC ACT NO. 11223, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE UNIVERSAL HEALTH CARE ACT
EXPLANATORY NOTE

On 20 February 2019, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte signed into law Republic Act No. 11223, entitled: “An Act instituting Universal Health Care for all Filipinos, Prescribing Reforms in the Health Care System, and Appropriating Funds Therefor”.

RA11223, otherwise known as the Universal Health Care Act, provides under Section 17, Chapter IV (Health Services Delivery) that city-wide health systems contracted for the delivery of population-based health services shall have the following minimum components:
(a) primary care provider network with patient records accessible throughout the health system,
(b) accurate, sensitive and timely epidemiologic surveillance systems, and
(c) proactive and effective health promotion programs and campaigns.

Section 19, Chapter V (Organization of Local Health Systems) directs the Department of Health (DOH), Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Philippine Health Insurance Corporation (PHIC) and the Local Government Units (LGUs) to integrate health services to province-wide and city-wide health systems, manage the Special Health Fund and exercise administrative and technical supervision over health facilities and health human resources in their respective jurisdictions.

Pursuant to Section 76 of Republic Act No. 7160 (Local Government Code of 1991) and Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, the Local Government Units (LGUs) shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern taking into consideration its service requirements and financial capability, subject to the minimum standards and guidelines prescribed by the CSC.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability and affordability.

The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling-down, phasing out or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Updated Organizational Structure. — The proposed Updated Organizational Structure of the Manila Health Department, Office of Public Cemetery and District Health Offices is hereby ratified and attached hereto as Annex “A”.

SEC. 3. Revised Plantilla of Positions. — The Revised Personnel Schedule (LBP Form No. 3-A) of the Manila Health Department (MHD) is accordingly adopted and marked herewith as Annex “B” for the purpose of fully complying with the pertinent provisions of Republic Act No. 11223, otherwise known as the Universal Health Care Act.

SEC. 4. Re-Organizing Certain Sections, Offices and Divisions. — To better streamline the day-to-day operations of the MHD and fully address its updated tasks and functions, the following sections, offices or divisions are hereby re-organized, as follows:

a) The Emerging/Re-Emerging Diseases, TB Control and Prevention, HIV/STD/AIDS Program, Office of Public Cemetery (North, South, Islamic), Vector Control Office and Other Communicable Diseases shall all be placed under the Division of Communicable Diseases;
b) The Lifestyle Related Diseases and Office of Drugs and Substance Abuse Treatment and Rehabilitation shall be integrated under the Division of Non-Communicable Diseases;
c) The Property Section and Transportation and General Services Office will be merged as one section and fall under the Division of Administration; and
d) The Division of School Health Services shall be collapsed, while its services will be absorbed by the respective health centers.

SEC. 5. Re-naming of Different Units. — For purposes of clarity and define official functions, the following MHD units are hereby renamed accordingly:
a) From City Epidemiological and Surveillance to Division of City Epidemiological and Surveillance; and
b) From Manila Muslim Cemetery to Manila Islamic Cemetery.

SEC. 6. Creation of New Offices. — The following new offices are hereby organized and whose mandated services are to be devolved to every district of Manila, namely:
(a) Local Health System Support Division
(b) Division of Disaster Risk Reduction Management for Health
(c) Office of Mental Health Clinic
(d) Geriatric Services
(e) Wellness Clinic
(f) Social Hygiene Clinic
(g) Office for Epidemiologic and Surveillance, created by virtue of City Ordinance No. 8761 to streamline and strengthen implementation of robust public health surveillance and response system in the city.

The manpower complement needed to staff the newly-created units shall be sourced from filled-up and vacant regular items re-assigned from other offices within the MHD plantilla. The personnel holding such items shall continue to enjoy the same equivalent rank, level and salary and without gap in their creditable service.

SEC. 7. Redeployment of MHD Personnel by way of Transfer. — In order to augment and strengthen the current workforce of the various offices and districts, the City Health Officer is authorized to redeploy by way of transfer of plantilla item the necessary MHD personnel based on the new organizational set-up, subject to existing Civil Service rules and regulations.

SEC. 8. Scrap-and-Build. — The following vacant items in the Plantilla Position of the Manila Health Department, are hereby abolished:

SEC. 9. Qualifications, Powers, Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated new positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant laws.

SEC. 10. Appointments. — The employment and appointment for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standard and guidelines set forth by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 11. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the creation of the twenty (20) new regular positions shall be taken from the available savings generated from the abolished thirteen (13) vacant items in the 2023 Executive Budget and from other available sources which may be allowed.

SEC. 12. Separability Clause. — In the event any provision of this Ordinance is declared unlawful or invalid, such parts or portions not affected thereon shall remain in full force and effect.

It aims to enhance service delivery, workforce efficiency, and compliance with national health integration policies.
