ORDINANCE NO. 9014

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING VARIOUS ITEMS UNDER MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2023 ANNUAL BUDGET TO FUND THE ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF VARIOUS ACCOUNTS UNDER MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES APPROPRIATIONS IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SIXTY-FOUR MILLION SIX HUNDRED FORTY-TWO THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED FORTY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP 64,642,447.00), AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Ordinance No. 8919 appropriated funds for various items under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the FY 2023 Annual Budget.

However, after due consideration, there is a need to augment certain items through savings from other accounts within the FY 2023 Annual Budget to ensure the effective and continuous delivery of priority programs, activities, and basic services in the City of Manila.

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued a Declaration of Savings as supporting documentation for the said savings and augmentation.

As provided under Section 336 of the Local Government Code (Use of Appropriated Funds and Savings), funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purposes for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sangguniang concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.

The various offices, bureaus, and departments of the City Government of Manila require the use of basic utilities for daily operations. Hence, to maintain proper and continuous operations, augmentation of the accounts Electricity Expenses and Water Expenses is deemed necessary.

Furthermore, the Department of Labor and Employment–National Wages and Productivity Commission approved Wage Order No. NCR-24 on 26 June 2023, providing for a minimum wage increase of Forty Pesos (PHP 40.00) in the National Capital Region for all minimum wage earners in the private sector. Therefore, augmentation of funds for Janitorial Services and Security Services accounts is inevitable to cover the increased wages of workers contracted by the City Government.

Lastly, augmentation of Advertising Expenses is necessary, as City Council Resolutions and Ordinances require publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Augmentation.
The following items under Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses in the total amount of Sixty-Four Million Six Hundred Forty-Two Thousand Four Hundred Forty-Seven Pesos (PHP 64,642,447.00) shall be augmented through savings from the FY 2023 Annual Budget:

Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses:

A. Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod

Advertising Expenses – PHP 3,000,000.00

B. Department of Social Welfare

Security Services – PHP 2,171,420.00

C. Gat Andres Bonifacio Medical Center

Janitorial Services – PHP 446,664.00

Security Services – PHP 473,663.00

D. Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital

Janitorial Services – PHP 289,019.00

ORDINANCE NO. 9012

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR, MARIA SHEILAH “HONEY” H. LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, TO ENTER INTO NEGOTIATION, SIGN THE DEED OF SALE, PAY THE PURCHASE PRICE FOR THE ACQUISITION OF PARCELS OF LAND CONSISTING OF A TOTAL LAND AREA OF ONE THOUSAND FIFTY SQUARE METERS (1,050 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, COVERED BY DIFFERENT TITLES SITUATED AT DISTRICT IV, SAMPALOC, MANILA, NAMELY: (1) TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 002-2020001352 IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA (BLOCK 37 OF LOTS 23 AND 24), REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF MICHAEL JOHN H. PRIETO, CONSISTING OF THREE HUNDRED SQUARE METERS (300 SQ. M.), SITUATED AT SUSAN STREET, BARANGAY 525, ZONE 52, DISTRICT IV, SAMPALOC, MANILA; (2) TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 291763 IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF BENPRIE REALTY CORPORATION, CONSISTING OF ONE HUNDRED FIFTY SQUARE METERS (150 SQ. M.), SITUATED AT ALEX STREET, BARANGAY 529, ZONE 52, DISTRICT IV, SAMPALOC, MANILA; (3) TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NOS. 274736, 274735, AND 274737, ALL IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA AND REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF IONIAN REALTY CORPORATION, CONSISTING OF ONE HUNDRED FIFTY SQUARE METERS (150 SQ. M.), ONE HUNDRED FIFTY SQUARE METERS (150 SQ. M), AND ONE HUNDRED FIFTY SQUARE METERS (150 SQ. M.), RESPECTIVELY, ALL LOCATED AT BASILIO STREET, BARANGAY 524, ZONE 52, DISTRICT IV, SAMPALOC, MANILA; (4) TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 227142 IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF MARTIN LOPEZ PRIETO, CONSISTING OF ONE HUNDRED FIFTY SQUARE METERS (150 SQ. M.), SITUATED AT STO. TOMAS STREET, BARANGAY 525, ZONE 52, DISTRICT IV, SAMPALOC, MANILA, FOR THE BENEFIT OF ACTUAL AND BONA FIDE RESIDENTS THEREAT UNDER THE LAND-FOR-THE-LANDLESS PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA, APPROPRIATING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR
EXPLANATORY NOTE

This Ordinance seeks to authorize the acquisition of certain privately-owned real properties through negotiation.

The undersigned is much aware of the enduring need of residents validly occupying the said subject properties, which has lasted in terms of decades but without financial resources, to secure for themselves the ownership of properties. In order to address such situation, the City Government of Manila, invoking the General Welfare Clause of the Local Government Code, would take the initiative by way of a land acquisition agreement with the subject of the property owners for the benefit of the residents, it being part of the Land-for-the-Landless Program of Manila, hence the proposed measure.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Requirements before negotiation. — The favorable recommendations of the following offices are hereby required before the start of the negotiation for the acquisition of land for beneficiaries under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila:

a) City Planning and Development Office (CPDO) — To verify whether the intended acquisition of lands is in line with the city's five (5) or ten (10)-year development plan;

b) Urban Settlements Office (USO) — To conduct a feasibility study on the subject properties as sites for the city’s Land-for-the-Landless Program; to survey the properties and the structures built therein; and to profile the actual residents and to initially determine the qualification for the Land-for-the-Landless Program;

c) City Budget Office — To determine the availability of appropriation;

d) Department of Assessment — To determine the total fair market value of the properties; and

e) City Treasurer's Office — To determine the financial capacity of the city to purchase or acquire the subject property.


SEC. 2. Authority to enter into negotiation. — The Honorable City Mayor, Maria Sheilah “Honey” H. Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, is hereby authorized to enter into negotiation, for the purchase and acquisition of parcels of land, consisting of a total land area of One Thousand Fifty Square Meters (1,050 Sq. M.), more or less, covered by different titles situated at District IV, Sampaloc, Manila, namely:

(1) Transfer Certificate of Title No. 002-2020001352 of the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila (Block 37 of Lots 23 and 24), registered under the name of Michael John H. Prieto, consisting of Three Hundred Square Meters (300 Sq. M.), situated at Susan Street, Barangay 525, Zone 52, District IV, Sampaloc, Manila;
(2) Transfer Certificate of Title No. 291763 of the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila registered under the name of Benprie Realty Corporation, consisting of One Hundred Fifty Square Meters (150 Sq. M.), situated at Alex Street, Barangay 529, Zone 52, District IV, Sampaloc, Manila;
(3) Transfer Certificate of Title Nos. 274736, 274735, and 274737, all of the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila and registered under the name of Ionian Realty Corporation, consisting of One Hundred Fifty Square Meters (150 Sq. M.), One Hundred Fifty Square Meters (150 Sq. M), and One Hundred Fifty Square Meters (150 Sq. M.), respectively, all located at Basilio Street, Barangay 524, Zone 52, District IV, Sampaloc, Manila;
(4) Transfer Certificate of Title No. 227142 of the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila, registered under the name of Martin Lopez Prieto, consisting of One Hundred Fifty Square Meters (150 Sq. M.), situated at Sto. Tomas Street, Barangay 525, Zone 52, District IV, Sampaloc, Manila.
Once the City Mayor and the landowners or their duly authorized representatives have finally agreed on the purchase price, the City Mayor shall sign the Deed of Absolute Sale, and thereafter cause the payment of the purchase price.

SEC. 3. Purchase Price. — The purchase price of the subject parcels of land shall be based either on the preliminary appraisal reports issued by the Department of Assessment dated 13 March 2023 as prescribed hereinbelow, their respective values, or the negotiated price agreed upon by the City Mayor and the landowners or their duly authorized representatives.

a) Subject property at Susan Street, Sampaloc, Manila (Barangay 525, Zone 52) per Preliminary Appraisal Report dated March 13, 2023:

Total Area: 300 Sq. M.
Average Value: PHP 32,018.58/Sq. M.
Total Value :PHP. 9,605,574.00

b) Subject property at Alex and Sto. Tomas Streets, Sampaloc, Manila (Barangays 529 and 525, Zone 52) per Preliminary Appraisal Report dated March 13, 2023:

Total Area: 300 Sq. M.
Average Value: PHP. 42,861.94/Sq. M.
Total Value: PHP. 12,858,582.00

c) Subject property at Basilio Street, Sampaloc, Manila (Barangay 524, Zone 52) per Preliminary Appraisal Report dated March 13, 2023:

Total Area: 450 Sq. M.
Average Value: PHP 34,051.87/Sq. M.
Total Value: PHP, 15,323,341.50

SEC. 4. Appropriation or Funding. — The amount of Thirty-Seven Million Seven Hundred Eighty-Seven Thousand Four Hundred Ninety-Seven Pesos and Fifty Centavos (PhP 37,787,497.50) is hereby appropriated from funds available under the “Land Account” of the Urban Settlements Office (USO) of Manila, and if the same is not sufficient, the City of Manila through USO-Manila may secure a loan from any reputable government institution upon the approval of the City Mayor, subject however to the prior authority to be secured from the Sangguniang Panlungsod, or other legal means.

SEC. 5. Beneficiaries. — The final determination of the qualifications of beneficiaries by USO-Manila shall be official list constituting the actual and bona fide residents in the subject properties herein specified to benefit from the acquisition of the subject lands.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 30, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the Manila City Mayor to negotiate and purchase multiple parcels of land totaling 1,050 sq. m. in Sampaloc, District IV, for the Land-for-the-Landless Program. The properties are owned by various individuals and corporations and are located on Susan, Alex, Basilio, and Sto. Tomas Streets. A total budget of PHP 37,787,497.50 is appropriated for this acquisition, with loan options if necessary. The Urban Settlements Office (USO) will identify and qualify the beneficiaries who are actual, long-time residents.

short_text:
This ordinance appropriates PHP 23.2 billion from the estimated income for FY 2024 to fund the operations and programs of the Manila City Government. It outlines the allocation of funds for health care, social services, infrastructure, sanitation, public safety, and sustainable development initiatives. The budget prioritizes inclusivity, good governance, and environmental protection.

Key provisions include:

No creation or abolition of plantilla positions without ordinance and proper funding.

Strict guidelines for the use of contingency funds, garbage hauling payments, procurement of eco-friendly cleaning agents, and infrastructure accessibility for persons with disabilities.

Budget caps: Personal Services must not exceed 45% of the previous year's income; discretionary funds of the Mayor are limited to 2% of the prior year's real property tax revenue.

Intelligence funds are restricted to legal and audited disbursements.

Salary modifications and organizational changes follow DBM Circulars and RA 11466.

20% of the budget is reserved as a Development Fund, and another 20% as Contingency Reserve (excluding utilities and food supplies).

Departments must submit Work and Financial Plans before funds are released, ensuring proper quarterly allotment control based on income performance.

ORDINANCE NO. 9004
AN ORDINANCE MANDATING THE INSTALLATION OF AUDIBLE TRAFFIC SIGNALS AND PUSH BUTTONS WITH BRAILLE TO ASSIST PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES, SENIOR CITIZENS, AND PREGNANT WOMEN IN THE CITY OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE
When it is safe to cross the street, an electronic device called an audible traffic signal produces a sound for pedestrians. It is frequently used alongside visual cues such as flashing "Don't Walk" signs. This ordinance aims to support the independence and safety of blind or visually impaired individuals, along with senior citizens and pregnant women, by requiring the installation of auditory traffic signals and Braille-enabled push buttons.

These features will help increase accessibility, safety, and inclusivity in the City of Manila's transportation system. It is the policy of the City Government to promote the self-reliance, rehabilitation, and development of these vulnerable sectors.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy.
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to adopt measures that ensure the independence, recovery, and personal growth of persons with disabilities (PWDs). The city shall uphold the rights of pregnant women, senior citizens, and PWDs to live normal lives through policies that protect their health and safety.

SEC. 2. Objectives.
This Ordinance specifically aims to: a) Further reduce traffic congestion and improve traffic flow;
b) Protect public and driver safety; and
c) Ensure the security of elderly individuals, pregnant women, and pedestrians with disabilities.

SEC. 3. Audible Traffic Signal.
An Audible Traffic Signal provides information on the status and location of pedestrian light signals for the blind and visually impaired. It functions through synchronized sounds (“back and forth call operation”) emitted from two speakers placed at each end of the crosswalk during the walk signal phase.

SEC. 4. Scope.
This Ordinance mandates the installation of audible traffic signals with Braille push buttons for PWDs, senior citizens, and pregnant women at all pedestrian crossings with traffic signals within the jurisdiction of the City of Manila.

SEC. 5. Push Buttons for PWDs, Senior Citizens, and Pregnant Women.
Pressing the push button activates the traffic light’s countdown timer, allowing sufficient time to cross safely. The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) shall conduct time and motion studies to determine appropriate crossing durations for the intended users.

SEC. 6. Penalty.
The push buttons are reserved solely for PWDs, senior citizens, and pregnant women. Any person found guilty of tampering with or misusing the Audible Traffic Signal shall be fined ₱5,000.00 and/or face imprisonment of at least 30 days, subject to the court’s discretion.

SEC. 7. Implementing Agency.
The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) shall be the implementing agency of this Ordinance.

SEC. 8. Separability Clause.
If any part or provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause.
All ordinances, decrees, orders, rules, and regulations inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 10. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in at least two (2) newspapers of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 14, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance requires the City of Manila to install traffic lights that make sound and have Braille push buttons at pedestrian crossings. These special traffic lights will help blind or visually impaired people, senior citizens, and pregnant women cross the street more safely. Pressing the button will give them enough time to cross, and anyone who misuses or damages the device can be fined PhP5,000 or jailed for at least 30 days. The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau will be in charge of implementing this.
fines: PhP5,000 and/or at least 30 days imprisonment for tampering or misuse.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, also known as the Local Government Code of 1991, empowers local government units (LGUs) to exercise the powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental to efficient and effective governance. These powers are also essential for promoting the general welfare, including the right of people to a balanced ecology and the preservation of public comfort and convenience.
Moreover, Section 17 of the same law mandates LGUs to deliver basic services and facilities, such as roads, drainage, and sewerage systems, for the benefit of their constituents.
To address urgent needs and projects, LGUs may enact a supplemental budget when supported by funds either from actual available resources or from newly identified revenue sources, as stated in Section 321 of the Local Government Code.
The City Treasurer and the City Accountant of Manila have certified the availability of funds, supporting the issuance of this supplemental budget. In addition, Resolution No. 4, Series of 2023, of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, was passed to approve the amendment of the Annual Investment Program and to issue a Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2023 to fund various priority projects totaling ₱90,000,000.00.
HON. SALVADOR PHILIP H. LACUNA
Councilor, Sixth District, Manila

SECTION 1. Appropriations.
The FY 2023 Supplemental Budget of the City of Manila, in the total amount of ₱90,000,000.00, is hereby appropriated to fund the following priority projects:
Implementing Office:

•        Capital Outlay (20% Development Fund)

•        Purpose: Additional works for upgrading, concreting, and drainage improvement of Lagusnilad Underpass
•        Amount: PHP 5,000,000.00

2. Object of Expenditure: Road Networks
•        Purpose: Completion of rehabilitation works at Lagusnilad Underpass

3. Object of Expenditure: Other Structures

This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On motion by Hon. Joel, duly seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was approved for third and final reading by the City Council on October 24, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance approves a special additional budget of PhP90 million for important projects in Manila. The funds will be used mainly for three purposes: (1) improving the drainage and concrete works at the Lagusnilad Underpass (PhP5 million), (2) finishing the rehabilitation of the same underpass (PhP10 million), and (3) building the Sacramento Library and a multi-purpose building (PhP75 million). Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation and the sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations subject to the provisions of this Section."

EXPLANATORY NOTE
City Ordinance No. 8919 previously appropriated funds for various items under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the FY 2023 Annual Executive Budget.

However, after further review, certain items require augmentation through savings from other accounts in order to ensure the effective and uninterrupted delivery of priority programs, activities, and basic services in the City of Manila.

The City Treasurer and City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash, validating the existence of savings available for augmentation.

Under Section 336 of the Local Government Code, while appropriated funds must be used for their specific purposes, local chief executives or the presiding officer of the Sangguniang concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item from savings within the same expense class of their appropriations.

The City of Manila has acquired loans from the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) and the Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP) to fund major infrastructure projects, including:

Bagong Ospital ng Maynila

Binondominium and Tondominium residential projects

Construction and improvement of various schools

Improvement of the Manila Zoo

To cover the interest payments for these loans, the City Accountant has requested additional funds based on the projected 4th Quarter loan amortization. As such, the augmentation of funds under Financial Expenses — Interest Expenses, listed under the Special Purpose Appropriations (SPA), is necessary.

The City Council approved Resolution No. 3, Series of 2023, of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled:

“A Resolution Approving the Amendment of the Annual Investment Program and the Issuance of a Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2023 in Relation to the Augmentation of an Item under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses — Special Purpose Appropriations, in the Total Amount of One Hundred Seventy Million Pesos (₱170,000,000.00).”

HON. SALVADOR PHILIP H. LACUNA
Councilor, 6th District, Manila

SECTION 1. Augmentation.

Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses
A. Special Purpose Appropriations (SPAs)

Financial Expenses – Interest Expense: ₱170,000,000.00

TOTAL: ₱170,000,000.00

SECTION 2. Fund Sources.
The fund for the above augmentation shall be sourced from savings under the following appropriation:

Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses
A. Special Purpose Appropriations (SPAs)

Operational Expenses for City General Welfare Development Program: ₱170,000,000.00

TOTAL: ₱170,000,000.00

Attached Documents:

Annex A — Declaration of Savings under MOOE for Augmentation of Funds

Annex B — Augmentation of Accounts under MOOE of the FY 2023 Annual Budget

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on October 24, 2023
short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to reallocate PhP170 million from savings in its 2023 budget to help pay for the interest on loans used to fund major projects. These projects include the Bagong Ospital ng Maynila, Binondominium and Tondominium housing, school improvements, and the renovation of the Manila Zoo. By redirecting the unused budget from a different city program, the city ensures it can meet loan payment deadlines without interrupting services.

ORDINANCE NO. 8997

AN ORDINANCE MANDATING ALL CONSTRUCTION AND CONSTRUCTION SUPPLIERS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA TO PLACE SAND, GRAVEL, AND EXCAVATED DEBRIS IN BAGS OR PROPER CONTAINERS, PREVENTING THE USAGE OF THE CITY STREETS AND SIDEWALKS FOR STORAGE/HOLDING AREAS THAT CAUSE EROSION AND OBSTRUCTION IN PUBLIC UTILITIES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Instead of the customary use of public spaces such as streets and sidewalks as temporary storage areas for sand, gravel, and excavated soil and debris, which become obstructions, proper storage methods are now mandated.

One factor causing silt, sediment, sludge, and residues through erosion in our drainage systems is consistently reducing their efficiency by 30% to 80%, rendering many drainage systems ineffective.

Section 1102, Storage in Public Property, under Chapter 11 of the rules and regulations implementing Presidential Decree No. 1096 or the National Building Code of the Philippines, provides that materials and equipment necessary for work to be done under a permit, when placed or stored on public property, shall not obstruct free and convenient access to and use of any fire hydrant, fire or police alarm box, utility box, catch basin, or manhole, and shall not interfere with drainage in any street or alley gutter.

The Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) and the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA), together with the city, have been tasked to dredge waterways and conduct de-clogging efforts to prevent frequent flooding in the busy streets of Manila.

A report from the DPWH states that the Philippines has suffered several severe floods, causing financial losses to the government. The primary cause of flooding is the filling of inland waterways with sediments and trash due to upstream erosion and waste dumping, which reduces the water-carrying capacity of the drainage system.

The complete solution to flooding involves increasing the holding capacity of floodwater catch basins and widening large pipes/culverts as waterways. However, the most effective maintenance solution is sustaining efficiency by reducing sediments and silt.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. This Ordinance shall be known as “AN ORDINANCE FOR THE PROPER HANDLING OF CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS, SAND, AND GRAVEL IN ALL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA.”

SEC. 2. Basis.
Large construction developments shall provide proper storage areas, such as containers or receptacles, to prevent the erosion of materials. In the absence of such storage, eroding supplies must be placed in nylon or similar bags to be properly contained. As stated in the Implementing Rules and Regulations of the National Building Code (Presidential Decree No. 1096), materials and equipment necessary for work under a permit, when placed or stored on public property, shall not obstruct free and convenient access to or use of any fire hydrant, fire or police alarm box, utility box, catch basin, or manhole, and shall not interfere with the drainage of any street, alley, or gutter, ensuring the smooth flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic.

SEC. 3. Implementing Agencies.
The Building Official/Engineering Department and other law enforcement agencies shall administer the implementation and full compliance with Section 2 by contractors or owners of structures where construction or repairs are taking place.

SEC. 4. Penalties.
It shall be the duty of the implementing departments stated in Section 3 to inspect for immediate compliance with Section 2. If non-compliance is found during inspection, the following penalties will apply:

First Offense: Fine of Two Thousand Pesos (PhP 2,000.00)

Second Offense: Fine of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 3,000.00)

Third Offense: Fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00) and suspension of the permit

SEC. 5. REPEALING CLAUSE.
All laws, issuances, orders, rules, and other regulations or parts thereof that are consistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed and modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect thirty (30) days after its complete publication in a newspaper of general circulation in Metro Manila.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 3, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance requires construction projects in Manila to properly store sand, gravel, and debris by placing them in bags or containers instead of using public streets and sidewalks as storage areas. This is to prevent erosion and obstruction that can block drainage systems and worsen flooding in the city. Violators will face fines, starting at PhP2,000 for the first offense, and up to PhP5,000 and suspension of permits for the third offense.

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR MARIA SHEILAH “HONEY” H. LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, TO ENTER INTO NEGOTIATION, SIGN THE DEED OF SALE, PAY THE PURCHASE PRICE FOR THE ACQUISITION OF THOSE PARCELS OF LAND CONSISTING OF ONE THOUSAND TWENTY-SIX SQUARE METERS AND NINETY SQUARE DECIMETERS (1,026.90 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, SITUATED IN THE CITY OF MANILA, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAMES OF NEONITA D. SALANDANAN, GRACIANO DEL ROSARIO AND RAFAEL DEL ROSARIO, EMBRACED UNDER TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NOS. 154361, 154362, 258178 AND 199733, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA, FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE MEMBERS OF CAMACHILE ALLEY 1 NEIGHBORHOOD ASSOCIATION, INC. OF BRGY. 746, ZONE 81, DISTRICT 5, MANILA, AND APPROPRIATING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR

Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, is hereby authorized to enter into negotiation for the purchase and acquisition of the parcels of land consisting of One Thousand Twenty-Six Square Meters and Ninety Square Decimeters (1,026.90 sq. m.), situated in the City of Manila, registered under the names of Neonita D. Salandanan, Graciano Del Rosario, and Rafael Del Rosario, embraced under Transfer Certificate of Title Nos. 154361, 154362, 258178 and 199733, in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila, under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila. Once the City Mayor and the landowners, or their duly authorized representatives, have finally agreed on the purchase price, the City Mayor shall sign the Deed of Absolute Sale, and thereafter cause the payment of the purchase price.

Purchase Price. — The purchase price of the subject parcel of land shall be based either on the preliminary appraisal report issued by the City Assessor's Office, Manila, dated 7 June 2023, which is pegged at Seventy-Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 75,000.00) per square meter, the assessed value of the property, or the negotiated price agreed upon by the City Mayor and the landowners or their duly authorized representatives.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 3, 2023.

ORDINANCE NO. 8993

AN ORDINANCE STRENGTHENING THE NUTRITION PROGRAM FOR THE FIRST ONE THOUSAND (1000) DAYS OF LIFE THROUGH SUSTAINABLE HEALTH CARE SERVICES FOR MATERNAL, INFANTS, AND YOUNG CHILDREN'S WELL-BEING AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 15, Article II of the 1987 Constitution declares that: “The State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them.”

Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, mandates Local Government Units to exercise their powers and discharge their duties and functions necessary for the efficient and effective provision of basic services and facilities.

Section 2 under Chapter 1 of Republic Act No. 11148 provides that the State shall guarantee the right to adequate food, care, and nutrition for pregnant and lactating mothers, including adolescent females, especially children from zero (0) to two (2) years old.

The First 1000 Days of Life, also known as the "Golden Window of Opportunity," is the critical period for proper nutrition to ensure a child’s growth and development. This period begins with pregnancy and lasts until the child’s second birthday.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Title — This Ordinance shall be known as the "Manila City's First One Thousand (1000) Days of Life Ordinance."

SEC. 2.
Declaration of Policy — The City of Manila prioritizes the nutrition program for adolescent females, pregnant and lactating mothers, and children from zero (0) to two (2) years old. This is achieved through a sustainable program headed by the Manila Health Department (MHD) with other offices concerned, in cooperation with Civil Society Organizations (CSOs).

SEC. 3.
Objectives — This Ordinance aims to:

a. Provide multisectoral strategies to address nutrition issues among adolescent females, pregnant and lactating mothers, infants, and young children to reduce malnutrition.
b. Strengthen the role of the Manila Health Department in sustaining nutrition programs for the first 1000 days of life.
c. Enhance family and community support networks.
d. Ensure comprehensive implementation of health services.

SEC. 4.
Definition of Terms — For purposes of this Ordinance, the following terms are defined as follows:

a. Chronic Energy Deficiency (CED) or Acute Undernutrition - A condition caused by inadequate food and nutrient intake.
b. Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) - Non-state actors, such as NGOs, professional associations, foundations, and community-based organizations.
c. Early Stimulation - A process of providing external stimuli for infants and young children to develop skills and abilities.
d. First One Thousand (1000) Days of Life - The critical period of a child’s life from pregnancy to the child’s second birthday.
e. Low Birth Weight - An infant born with a weight of less than 2,500 grams (5.5 pounds).
f. Malnutrition - Refers to undernutrition (e.g., stunting, wasting, underweight) and overnutrition (e.g., overweight, obesity).
g. Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) - A condition defined by very low weight for length/height, characterized by visible severe wasting or edema.

SEC. 5.
Program Components — The program shall include nutritional services during the first 1000 days. The Manila Health Department (MHD) and CSOs shall collaborate to ensure effective delivery of these services.

A. Prenatal Period (First 270 Days) – Services will include regular prenatal care visits, provision of micronutrient supplements, anti-helminthic treatment, and maternal health monitoring.
B. Postpartum and Lactating Mothers – Services include monitoring health during labor, providing maternal nutrition, lactation support, family planning, and social welfare support.
C. First Six Months of Infancy – Services will include newborn care, exclusive breastfeeding support, immunizations, and growth monitoring.
D. Infants from Six Months to Two Years – Nutritional services will include introducing complementary foods, continued breastfeeding, immunizations, and managing common childhood illnesses.

SEC. 6.
Health and Nutrition of Adolescent Females – Services include nutritional assessments, immunizations, counseling on healthy lifestyle practices, and referral to health facilities when necessary.

SEC. 7.
Capacity-Building of Barangay Health and Nutrition Volunteers – The City will provide training to improve the skills of Barangay Health Workers (BHWs) and other personnel in implementing health and nutrition services.

SEC. 8.
Appropriations – The funds required to implement this Ordinance shall be charged to the Manila Health Department (MHD), subject to the availability of funds.

SEC. 9.
Implementing Authority – The Manila Health Department (MHD) shall implement this Ordinance in coordination with other relevant offices.

SEC. 10.
Separability Clause – If any part of this Ordinance is declared invalid, the other provisions will remain in effect.

SEC. 11.
Repealing Clause – All conflicting laws, decrees, and regulations are hereby repealed.

SEC. 12.
Effectivity Clause — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 3, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance focuses on improving the nutrition and healthcare for mothers, infants, and young children, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from pregnancy to a child's second birthday). The goal is to reduce malnutrition and provide better support for their health and well-being through various health services and community efforts.

ORDINANCE NO. 8988

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 9 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8676, AS AMENDED, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE NO CONTACT APPREHENSION PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE 2020 NO CONTACT APPREHENSION PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES."

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 458 (5) (vi) of Republic Act No. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991, empowers the City, through an ordinance, to regulate traffic on all streets and bridges within the city territory.

Ordinance No. 8676 implemented the No Contact Apprehension Program (NCAP), which enforced traffic rules and regulations by operating a 24-hour NCAP to ensure round-the-clock compliance with traffic ordinances and rules.

Section 4 of the ordinance defined NCAP as a systematic program where the City apprehends traffic violators using state-of-the-art, evidence-based, and comprehensive technology without the need for physical contact with traffic enforcers.

Section 9 of the ordinance created the NCAP Trust Fund, where fines collected from traffic violations under the program would be placed. The Trust Fund is separate from the City’s General Fund and other trust funds for different purposes. The Trust Fund has its own bank account, to which the City has access for implementing NCAP, either on its own or through a Joint Venture or Service Agreement, to be determined by the City.

Furthermore, Section 3(1) of the same ordinance provides that the Trust Fund Review and Approval Committee of NCAP shall be responsible for documentation and liquidation of the Trust Fund proceeds, subject to applicable rules and regulations from the Commission on Audit and other relevant laws.

Currently, the accumulated NCAP Trust Fund has a balance of P152,448,362.50, net of any service fees or charges for NCAP implementation.

Meanwhile, monies from the General Fund have been used to finance the operational requirements of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB). For FY 2023, the Executive Budget appropriated P178,880,905 for MTPB operations.

Given that the NCAP Trust Fund balance has remained unutilized since January 2021, it can be reasonably used to replenish the General Fund, which has been depleted to fund MTPB operations. This will free up funds to finance priority programs, projects, and activities under the FY 2023 Executive Budget, such as the City’s Social Amelioration Program for senior citizens, persons with disabilities, solo parents, Grade 12 public school students, and college students at Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila and Universidad de Manila.

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED:

SECTION 1. Amendments. - Section 9 of Ordinance No. 8676 is hereby amended and shall now be read as follows:

“SEC. 9. No Contact Apprehension Program Trust Fund. — There is hereby created a ‘No Contact Apprehension Program Trust Fund.’ The fines collected by the City for violations of traffic laws under the Program shall be placed in this Trust Fund, which is separate and distinct from the General Fund of the City and all other Trust Funds created for different purposes. This Trust Fund shall have its own bank account, to which the City has access for implementing NCAP, either by the City itself or through a Joint Venture or Service Agreement, as determined by the City.

Any unused balance at the end of each month, in excess of the expenditures for NCAP implementation, shall be automatically transferred to the General Fund to finance the City’s Executive Budget.”

SECTION 2. Separability Clause. — If for any reason, any part of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining parts or provisions thereof, which are not affected, shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SECTION 3. Repealing Clause. — All existing ordinances, executive orders, and administrative regulations or parts thereof, which are inconsistent with any provision of this Ordinance, are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 14, 2023.

CERTIFICATION

This is to certify that Ordinance No. 8988 entitled: “AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 9 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8676 AS AMENDED, ENTITLED: ‘AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE NO CONTACT APPREHENSION PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE 2020 NO CONTACT APPREHENSION PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES’” was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on September 14, 2023. The same was forwarded to the office of the Honorable Mayor on September 15, 2023. Considering that more than ten (10) days have passed without any communication that the ordinance was approved or vetoed by the local Chief Executive, Ordinance No. 8988 shall be deemed approved as if she had signed it, pursuant to Section 54, paragraph (b) of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

Issued this 28th day of September 2023, in the City of Manila.
short_text: This ordinance makes changes to the No Contact Apprehension Program (NCAP) in Manila, particularly in how the fines from traffic violations are handled. It amends the rule that previously set aside the fines in a special fund to now automatically transfer any leftover money to the city’s general budget at the end of each month. This move is intended to help fund other city programs, such as social welfare for vulnerable groups like senior citizens and students.
fines: The ordinance refers to fines collected under the NCAP program but doesn't specify exact amounts or penalties.

ORDINANCE NO. 8987

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING THREE (3) POSITIONS TO GIVE WAY TO THE CREATION OF FIVE (5) ESSENTIAL POSITIONS IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ASSESSMENT

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Effective records management is essential to preserving and utilizing records with long-term value for future generations. It is crucial to manage these records properly from creation to disposal.

The Department of Assessment has recently digitized all tax records, including the Tax Declarations (TDs), FAASes, and supporting documents for approximately 450 real property units in the city. These records cover revision years 1979, 1985, 1996, 2005, and 2014.

The Department has reached its maximum storage capacity for tax records. As a result, there is a pressing need to gradually archive these files to create a more efficient workspace for employees and ensure ease of access for the taxpaying public. The processing of transactions is still done manually before being digitized and added to the in-house system, contributing to the increasing volume of physical files in storage.

To preserve these vital documents and protect them from potential damage caused by natural and man-made disasters, it is necessary to return all scanned files to their respective folders, bind the documents, and archive them properly.

To address this, it is proposed to create lower-grade positions that do not require eligibility for bookbinding, proper inventory, monitoring of record movements, and maintaining the cleanliness of the archives room. These positions will help facilitate the digital transformation and protect records without the need for additional funding.

Therefore, three existing positions in the Department of Assessment will be abolished to create five new essential positions.

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED:

SECTION 1. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby abolished in the Department of Assessment:
Position Titles and Salaries
Item No. (Ord. No. 8919): 174
Title of Position: Assessment Clerk I
Salary Grade: 4-1
Salary: PHP 282,723.64
Item No. (Ord. No. 8919): 107
Title of Position: Local Assessment Operations Officer II
Salary Grade: 15-1
Salary: PHP 613,783.06
Item No. (Ord. No. 8919): 145
Title of Position: Local Assessment Operations Officer II
Salary Grade: 15-1
Salary: PHP 613,783.06
Total Salary Allocation: PHP 1,510,289.76
SEC. 2. New Plantilla Positions. — The following new plantilla positions are hereby created as replacements for the abolished positions:
Position Titles and Salaries
Title of Position: Administrative Aide II (Bookbinder I)
Salary Grade: 2-1
Salary: PHP 254,911.06
Title of Position: Administrative Aide II (Bookbinder I)
Salary Grade: 2-1
Salary: PHP 254,911.06
Title of Position: Administrative Aide III (Reproduction Machine Operator I)
Salary Grade: 2-1
Salary: PHP 254,911.06
Title of Position: Administrative Aide II (Messenger)
Salary Grade: 2-1
Salary: PHP 254,911.06
Title of Position: Administrative Aide II (Messenger)
Salary Grade: 2-1
Salary: PHP 254,911.06
Total Salary Allocation: PHP 1,274,555.30

SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers, and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the positions listed in this Ordinance shall follow the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission, and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 4. Appointment. — Employment and appointment to these positions shall be subject to the qualification standards and guidelines set forth by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 5. Appropriation of Funds. — Funds necessary for the creation of the five (5) new regular plantilla positions shall be sourced from the available funds from the three (3) positions being abolished, as stated in Section 1. These funds are included in the 2023 Executive Budget. The positions will be automatically funded in the succeeding Annual City Budget, as incorporated into the Personnel Schedule of the Department of Assessment.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. — All laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 5, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance eliminates three existing job positions in the Department of Assessment and creates five new positions. The goal is to improve the management and protection of tax records by creating roles that help organize and digitize documents. This change will allow for more efficient archiving and reduce the physical storage space needed, ensuring that important records are preserved and accessible to the public.

ORDINANCE NO. 8986

AN ORDINANCE EXEMPTING FROM THE PAYMENT OF TRANSFER TAXES AND OTHER INCIDENTAL EXPENSES RELATIVE TO THE TRANSFER OF TITLE OF THAT PATRIMONIAL PROPERTY COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 51486, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA, SITUATED AT ARROCEROS COMPOUND, TO BE TRANSFERRED TO RIVERPARK CENTRAL CORPORATION, PURSUANT TO THE AMENDED JOINT VENTURE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF MANILA AND JBROS CONSTRUCTION CORPORATION, DATED 23 MAY 2023
EXPLANATORY NOTE

The City of Manila and JBros Construction Corporation entered into a Joint Venture Agreement (JVA) on 16 June 2017 for the redevelopment of the 10,134-square-meter Arroceros Compound, covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 51486.

On 23 May 2023, the City of Manila and JBros entered into an Amended Joint Venture Agreement (AJVA), superseding the 16 June 2017 JVA.

Under Section 5.1 of the AJVA, the City warrants that it will promptly issue all local licenses, permits, clearances, authorizations, and approvals necessary for the uninterrupted implementation of the project in accordance with Section 6(h) of the JV Ordinance, provided that all requirements under existing laws, ordinances, and regulations are complied with by JBros.

Section 6(h) of the JV Ordinance provides for Direct City Subsidy, which allows for tax exemptions in favor of the city's JV partners.

Through a letter dated 22 August 2023, JBros requested the fulfillment of the City’s obligation under Section 5.1 of the AJVA, specifically for the exemption from the payment of the City's transfer tax relating to the transfer of title to the Arroceros Compound from the City to Riverpark Central Corporation.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The exemption from payment of the City’s transfer tax and other incidental expenses relative to the transfer of title of the patrimonial property covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 51486, in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila, situated at the Arroceros Compound, to be transferred to Riverpark Central Corporation, pursuant to the 23 May 2023 Amended Joint Venture Agreement, as requested by JBros Construction Corporation, is hereby granted and authorized, subject to existing laws, rules, and regulations.

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. -This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 5, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance grants an exemption from the payment of transfer taxes and other incidental expenses for the transfer of the Arroceros Compound (TCT No. 51486) from the City of Manila to Riverpark Central Corporation. The exemption is part of the City’s obligations under the Amended Joint Venture Agreement with JBros Construction Corporation dated May 23, 2023, in accordance with Section 6(h) of the JV Ordinance on Direct City Subsidy.

ORDINANCE NO. 8985

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR MARIA SHEILAH "HONEY" H. LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, TO ENTER INTO NEGOTIATION, SIGN THE DEED OF SALE, PAY THE PURCHASE PRICE FOR THE ACQUISITION OF A PARCEL OF LAND CONSISTING OF THREE THOUSAND THREE HUNDRED TWO SQUARE METERS AND TWENTY SQUARE DECIMETERS (3,302.20 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, SITUATED IN FLORENTINO TORRES STREET, BARANGAY 754, ZONE 81, STA. ANA, DISTRICT V, MANILA, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF ESTHER C. COSIQUIEN, MARRIED TO CHUA PING HIAN, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 002-2019003300, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA, FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE MEMBERS OF SAN ANTONIO COMMUNITY NEIGHBORHOOD ASSOCIATION, INC., AND APPROPRIATING NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFORE

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Requirements before Negotiation. — The following offices must provide favorable recommendations before the start of negotiations for the acquisition of the land for the benefit of the beneficiaries under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila:

a) City Planning and Development Office – To verify if the intended land acquisition aligns with the City's five (5) or ten (10) year development plan.

b) Urban Settlements Office – To conduct a feasibility study on the property as a site for the Land-for-the-Landless Program; to survey the property and any structures; and to profile the actual residents to determine their qualification for the program.

c) City Budget Officer – To determine the availability of appropriations for the acquisition.

d) City Assessor's Office – To determine the fair market value of the property.

e) City Treasurer's Office – To determine the financial capacity of the City to purchase the property.

SEC. 2. Authority to Enter into Negotiation. — The Honorable City Mayor Maria Sheilah “Honey” H. Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, is hereby authorized to enter into negotiations for the purchase and acquisition of a parcel of land consisting of 3,302.20 square meters (more or less), situated in Florentino Torres St., Barangay 754, Zone 81, District V, Sta. Ana, Manila, registered under the name of Esther C. Cosiquien, married to Chua Ping Hian, covered by TCT No. 002-2019003300 in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila. This is in accordance with the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila. Once the City Mayor and the landowner or her duly authorized representative agree on the purchase price, the City Mayor shall sign the Deed of Absolute Sale and subsequently arrange for the payment of the purchase price.

SEC. 3. Purchase Price. — The purchase price of the parcel of land shall be based on either the preliminary appraisal report from the City Assessor's Office, dated May 30, 2023, which is pegged at Fifty-Four Thousand Eight Hundred Ninety-One Pesos and Fifty-Seven Centavos (PHP 54,891.57) per square meter, or the negotiated price agreed upon by the City Mayor and the landowner or her duly authorized representative.

SEC. 4. Appropriation or Funding. — An amount of One Hundred Eighty-One Million Two Hundred Sixty-Two Thousand Nine Hundred Forty-Two Pesos and Forty-Five Centavos (PHP 181,262,942.00) is hereby appropriated from the available funds under the "land account" of the Urban Settlements Office (USO), Manila. If these funds are insufficient, the City of Manila, through USO-Manila, may secure a loan from a reputable government institution, subject to the approval of the City Mayor and prior authorization from the Sangguniang Panlungsod, or through other legal means.

SEC. 5. Beneficiaries. — The final determination of the beneficiaries' qualifications will be made by USO-Manila. The official list of beneficiaries from the San Antonio Community Neighborhood Association, Inc. will be the recipients of the land acquisition.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 3, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the City Mayor to negotiate the purchase of a 3,302.20 square meter land in Sta. Ana, Manila, for the San Antonio Community Neighborhood Association under the Land-for-the-Landless Program. Before the purchase can proceed, various city offices must approve the acquisition, ensuring the land is suitable, affordable, and aligned with the city’s budget. Once the price is settled, the Mayor will finalize the deal and arrange the payment.

ORDINANCE NO. 8984

ORDINANCE EXPRESSLY REPEALING ORDINANCE NO. 7966, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 2-A OF ORDINANCE NOS. 7914, 7928, 7936 AND 7944 BY INCLUDING THEREIN THE TRICYCLE TERMINAL OF THE BASECO-DIVISORIA-INTRAMUROS TRICYCLE OPERATORS ASSOCIATION, INC. (BASECOTODA); AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7871, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NOS. 7914, 7936 AND 7944 BY INCLUDING THEREIN A ROUTE MEASURE CAPACITY FOR BASECOTODA", ENACTED ON APRIL 29, 1999 AND APPROVED BY THE MAYOR ON JUNE 21, 1999.

EXPLANATORY NOTE:

On May 17, 2023, the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) issued a letter addressed to Hon. Jesus "Taga" Fajardo, Jr., Chairman of the Committee on Transportation of the City Council of Manila, regarding the endorsement to the City Council of Manila for the revocation of BASECOTODA (Ordinance No. 7966). The letter outlined violations by BASECOTODA of laws and regulations promulgated by the City of Manila. The MTPB's letter stated:

After a thorough investigation of the complaints against BASECO and the examination of submitted evidence, the undersigned, by virtue of the power granted by Ordinance No. 8291 (otherwise known as the "MANILATRIWHEEL VEHICLE ORDINANCE OF 2012"), which grants this office the power to "receive, process, commence, investigate and submit to the Sangguniang Panlungsod the suspension or revocation of franchises or permits," hereby endorses the revocation of BASECOTODA as a valid TODA existing and operating within the City of Manila and requests the City Council to dissolve it for the benefit of the public.

On August 1, 2023, the City Legal Officer issued a memorandum to Hon. Jesus "Taga" Fajardo, Jr., Chairman of the Committee on Transportation, regarding the revocation of BASECOTODA's franchise. The memorandum emphasized that:

It is clear that the power to grant franchises belongs to the City Council of Manila, and thus, the power to cancel or revoke the same also lies with the City Council. A franchise is a special privilege granted by a governmental authority and is not a common right. If a franchise violates the terms and conditions, it can be revoked by the City Council.

The Committee on Transportation held hearings on June 15, 2023, and August 10, 2023, providing BASECOTODA with due process.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Ordinance No. 7966, entitled: "AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 2-A OF ORDINANCE NOS. 7914, 7928, 7936 AND 7944 BY INCLUDING THEREIN THE TRICYCLE TERMINAL OF THE BASECO-DIVISORIA-INTRAMUROS TRICYCLE OPERATORS ASSOCIATION, INC. (BASECOTODA); AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7871, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NOS. 7914, 7936 AND 7944 BY INCLUDING THEREIN A ROUTE MEASURE CAPACITY FOR BASECOTODA", enacted on April 29, 1999, and approved by the Mayor on June 21, 1999, is hereby expressly repealed.

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 24, 2023.
short_text:
This ordinance repeals Ordinance No. 7966, which was originally enacted on April 29, 1999, and approved by the Mayor on June 21, 1999. Ordinance No. 7966 included amendments to previous ordinances (Nos. 7914, 7928, 7936, and 7944) by adding the BASECO-Divisoria-Intramuros Tricycle Operators Association (BASECOTODA) tricycle terminal and route measure capacity to the list of approved operators and routes.

The repeal of Ordinance No. 7966 comes after the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) investigated BASECOTODA for violations of Manila's traffic and regulatory laws. The MTPB found that BASECOTODA had violated relevant regulations and recommended the revocation of their franchise. The City Legal Officer also confirmed that the power to grant and revoke franchises lies with the City Council of Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 8983

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING A RETURN SERVICE AGREEMENT PROGRAM IN THE CITY OF MANILA FOR GRADUATES OF SUBSIDIZED UNIVERSITIES AND WITH PROFESSIONAL DEGREES IN THE FIELD OF MEDICAL AND HEALTH SERVICES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila, in the course of upholding the General Welfare Clause under Section 16, Chapter I, Title I, Book I, of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the “Local Government Code of 1991,” to create a program wherein graduates with degrees in the field of medicine and allied fields, and as products of funded universities, are called to commit themselves and complement the delivery of appropriate services for a limited time as herein set forth for the benefit of the constituency.

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. — As used in this Ordinance, the terms:

a. Subsidized University — shall mean a college-level university, whether currently existing or hereafter created, either by the Sangguniang Panlungsod or by Congress, funded by the City Government under its Annual Executive Budget, which offers any of the professional degrees as specified in Section 3 hereof.

b. Professional Degree — shall mean a college degree that grants a professional license to practice upon passing the requisite licensure examinations.


SEC. 3. Establishment of Return Service Agreement Program (RSAP) of Manila for Medicine and Health. — A Return Service Agreement Program (RSAP) of the City of Manila for Medicine and Health is hereby established, wherein graduates of any subsidized university with the following professional degrees  as prescribed herein below are required to render service to the City Government under the category of Medical and Health Services:

a. Medicine
b. Nursing
c. Psychology
d. Physical Therapy

SEC. 4. Program Terms and Conditions. — In relation to Section 3 hereof, the RSAP of Manila shall be subject to the following requirements, terms, and conditions:

a. Upon admission to the subsidized university, every student covered by this Ordinance is required to execute with the University President, Dean of the corresponding College, and his parent or other individual in charge of his sustained schooling, a Return Service Contract (RSC) in five (5) copies followed by its notarization and distribution. No student shall be permitted entry for enrollment purposes without the full execution and notarization of such contract.

b. Aside from the RSC, a Surety Agreement in four (4) copies shall be executed by the parent or other individual in charge of the student's sustained schooling, the University President, and the Dean of the corresponding College, in which such parent or individual shall undertake to assure the compliance of the student under his care with the terms and conditions as embodied in the RSC.

c. Within five (5) years from their prescribed date of graduation, the student-graduate shall render service for an uninterrupted period of one (1) year. For this purpose, the City Health Officer, with the assistance of the medical directors, shall determine the assigned workplace of the student-graduates, particularly the district hospitals, primary health care facilities, or other institutions directly involved with medical and health care, with provision for change of assignment as the need therefore arises.

d. During the term of the student-graduate, on or before the 31st day of December of the covered Fiscal Year, he shall submit a written report of his activity signed by him and the head of the district office or institution to which he was designated, the following data:

i. Place of designation
ii. A table of the period of service from the date of commencement, with subsequent tables until the two-year internship period is fully served
iii. A summary of his services rendered

e. If the student-graduate refuses or otherwise fails to comply with the program within the prescriptive period of five (5) years as herein prescribed, he and his parent or individual as party to the Surety Agreement shall be liable to pay for the total cost of the fund allocated to his schooling at the rate prevailing during his academic tenure, including applicable interests if his failure has exceeded the five-year period.

f. During the five-year prescriptive period and prior to his period of internship, the student-graduate shall be required to secure his professional license from the Professional Regulations Commission (PRC).

g. Enrollment for advancement to another degree subsequent to the professional degree as hereby defined such as, but not limited to, Bachelor of Laws, Master’s or Doctorate Degree, shall not be construed as compliance with, or any equivalent thereof to, the RSAP of Manila for Medicine and Health; provided, that if the graduate who obtains the degree of Bachelor of Science in Nursing decides to take up Medicine, his compliance with the program shall commence upon graduating in the latter course and at the same subsidized university where he obtained his first degree.

h. The student-graduate shall be issued his Transcript of Records, provided that the university shall not issue the same to release him from his obligation under the program and shall affix thereon a corresponding annotation for taking the requisite government licensure examinations.

i. Upon full rendition of service and compliance with the RSC, the student-graduate shall be released from his obligation and certified as such, without prejudice to the option on part of the city government to officially employ him. Accordingly, he shall be issued his Transcript of Records with the affixed annotation that he has complied with the terms and conditions of the RSAP of Manila for Medicine and Health.

SEC. 5. Release from the Program. — Notwithstanding the immediately preceding provisions of this Ordinance, any student-graduate may be released from his obligation under the RSAP Manila for Medicine and Health if the City Health Officer has determined, within six (6) months from the end of the school year of the subsidized universities, and based on the report and recommendation of the medical directors of all district hospitals, that the manpower of the said hospitals, primary health care facilities and other institutions directly involved with medical and health care is sufficient so as not to carry out the program.

SEC. 6. Implementing Rules and Regulations. — Within thirty (30) days from the approval of this Ordinance, the City Health Officer, with the collective assistance of the City Legal Officer, medical directors of district hospitals, and heads of the subsidized universities, shall prepare an omnibus rules and regulations implementing the provisions of this Ordinance, which shall include the following:

a. The preparation of the standard Return Service Contract (RSC) bearing the terms and conditions as set forth in Section 3 hereof
b. The preparation of the standard Surety Agreement
c. The monitoring of service progress of the student-graduate
d. A record of every student-graduate with the appropriate degree under this Ordinance, taking into consideration the determination of the five-year period of his compliance with the RSAP of Manila for Medicine and Health
e. In the event of pre-termination under Section 5 (d) of this Ordinance, the appropriate reporting and routine verification to ascertain resumption
f. The determination of the penalty and interests, if any, pursuant to the provisions of Section 4 (e) of this Ordinance
g. The documented release of the student-graduate under Section 4 (i) of this Ordinance

SEC. 7. Funding of the Program. — The funding necessary for the implementation of this Ordinance, especially including the provision of stipend for the student-graduates while rendering service under Sections 3 and 4 hereof, shall be sourced from the Annual Executive Budget of the City of Manila.

SEC. 8. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 22, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance establishes the Return Service Agreement Program (RSAP) in the City of Manila, requiring graduates with professional degrees in Medicine, Nursing, Psychology, and Physical Therapy from city-subsidized universities to render one year of health-related service within five years of graduation. Compliance includes signing a Return Service Contract and Surety Agreement, with penalties for non-compliance. The city may waive the obligation if manpower is sufficient. The program is funded through the city's Annual Executive Budget.
fines: Liability to pay back educational subsidy with interest if service is not rendered

ORDINANCE NO. 8981

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR, MARIA SHEILAH "HONEY" H. LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, TO ENTER INTO A NEGOTIATION, SIGN THE DEED OF SALE, PAY THE PURCHASE PRICE FOR THE ACQUISITION OF A PARCEL OF LAND CONSISTING OF TWO THOUSAND SEVEN HUNDRED SEVENTY-NINE SQUARE METERS AND FIFTY SQUARE DECIMETERS (2,779.50 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, SITUATED IN THE CITY OF MANILA, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF REMEDIOS TUASON-UICHANCO, EMBRACED UNDER TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 31703, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA, FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE MEMBERS OF PINAGPALA NEIGHBORHOOD ASSOCIATION, SAN ANDRES MANILA, INC. OF BARANGAY 739, ZONE 80, DISTRICT 5, MANILA, AND APPROPRIATING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Requirements Before Negotiation
The favorable recommendations of the following offices are required before the start of negotiation for the acquisition of a parcel of land for the benefit of the beneficiaries under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila:

a) City Planning and Development Office – to verify if the intended acquisition of land is in line with the city's five (5) or ten (10) year development plan.

b) Urban Settlements Office – to conduct a feasibility study on the subject property as a site for the city's Land-for-the-Landless Program; to survey the property and the structures built therein; and to profile the actual residents and initially determine their qualification for the Land-for-the-Landless Program.

c) City Budget Officer – to determine the availability of appropriation.

d) City Assessor's Office – to determine the fair market value of the property.

e) City Treasurer's Office – to determine the financial capacity of the city to purchase or acquire the subject property.

SECTION 2. Authority to Enter into Negotiation
The Honorable City Mayor, Maria Sheilah "Honey" H. Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, is hereby authorized to enter into negotiation for the purchase and acquisition of a parcel of land consisting of 2,779.50 square meters, more or less, situated in the City of Manila, registered under the name of Remedios Tuason-Uichanco, embraced under Transfer Certificate of Title No. 31703, in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila, under the Land-for-the-Landless Program.
Once the City Mayor and the landowner or her duly authorized representative have finally agreed on the purchase price, the City Mayor shall sign the Deed of Absolute Sale and thereafter cause the payment of the purchase price.

SECTION 3. Purchase Price
The purchase price of the subject parcel of land shall be based either on:

the preliminary appraisal report issued by the City Assessor's Office, Manila, dated May 30, 2023, pegged at ₱53,000.00 per square meter,

the assessed value of the property, or

the negotiated price agreed by the City Mayor and the landowner or her duly authorized representative.

SECTION 4. Appropriation or Funding
The amount of ₱147,313,500.00 is hereby appropriated from the available funds under the "land account" of the Urban Settlements Office (USO), Manila.
If the amount is not sufficient, the City of Manila, through USO-Manila, may secure a loan from a reputable government institution upon the approval of the City Mayor, subject to prior authority from the Sangguniang Panlungsod or other legal means.

SECTION 5. Beneficiaries
The final determination of the qualifications of the beneficiaries by USO-Manila shall serve as the official list of beneficiaries from the Pinagpala Neighborhood Association, San Andres, Manila, Inc., of Barangay 739, Zone 80, District 5, Manila, to benefit from the acquisition of the subject land.

SECTION 6. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 3, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance allows the Manila City Government to buy a 2,779.50 square meter property owned by Remedios Tuason-Uichanco to give land to the members of the Pinagpala Neighborhood Association in Barangay 739, San Andres, Manila. Before buying, several city offices must review and approve the plan. Once the Mayor and the landowner agree on the price, the city will finalize the sale and pay for the land using available city funds. If needed, the city may also get a loan to complete the purchase.

ORDINANCE NO. 8979

AN ORDINANCE SETTING THE STANDARD FARE MATRIX OF TRI-WHEEL VEHICLES OPERATING WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The Office of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) formally endorsed to the Committee on Transportation an attached Draft Ordinance regarding Fare Matrix of Tri-Wheel Vehicles in the City of Manila.

The undersigned, as Chairman of the Committee on Transportation, took necessary action and filed the same for First Reading and was referred to the said committee for appropriate action, with the Manila City Council.

The Committee, with its Vice Chairman and Members, conducted a series of Committee Hearings for this matter with several resource persons and some other members of the 12th City Council.

A committee report was duly submitted with the polished draft ordinance prior to submission of the measure. The Office of the MTPB issued a letter of no objection.

The committee found out that there was no legislative action yet taken regarding the Fare Matrix of Tri-Wheels in the City of Manila.

Under Sec. 31 of Ordinance No. 8291, entitled: “AN ORDINANCE SETTING GUIDELINES FOR THE REGISTRATION AND OPERATION OF TRICYCLES AND PEDICABS IN THE CITY OF MANILA, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE 'MANILA TRI-WHEEL VEHICLE ORDINANCE OF 2012' AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES,” which reads:

“SEC. 31. FARE STRUCTURE. — The MTRO shall recommend to the City Council the computation of the table of fares for both Tricycle-For-Hire and Pedicab-For-Hire units for appropriate legislative action. In no case will the fare be unreasonable, excessive, and exorbitant. The table of fares to be imposed by the latter shall be posted inside the sidecar or cab facing and in full view of passengers.”

The said Tri-Wheel Ordinance No. 8291 did not include the fare matrix as part of the regulatory power of the MTPB.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Scope. — All tricycle-for-hire, pedicab-for-hire, and e-trike-for-hire operating within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila.

SEC. 2. The Fare Matrix are set as follows:

a. Tricycle-for-hire: First one kilometer (1 km) — Sixteen Pesos (PHP. 16.00) (Per Passenger) and Five Pesos (PHP. 5.00) (Per Passenger) for every Five Hundred Meters (500 m) thereafter.

b. Pedicab-for-hire: First kilometer — Sixteen Pesos (PHP. 16.00) (Per Passenger) and Five Pesos (PHP. 5.00) (Per Passenger) for every Five Hundred Meters (500 m) thereafter.

c. E-trike-for-hire: Flat rate within its approved route — Twenty Pesos (PHP. 20.00).


STANDARD COMPUTATION 15 Km/1 LITER (TRICYCLE)
Distance Traveled(d)         Fare (F) per passenger
0 to 1 Km                 | PHP. 16.00                 |
1 Km + 500m                 | PHP. 21.00                 |
1 Km + 1 Km                 | PHP. 26.00                 |
1 Km + 1 Km & 500 m         | PHP. 31.00                |
1 Km + 2 Km                 | PHP. 36.00                |

SEC. 3. Penalties. — Any violation of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be punished by the following penalties:

1st Offense — A fine of One Thousand Pesos (PHP. 1,000.00) with issuance of Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR) for Code 43 of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) Fines and Penalties, and Section 104-C of Ordinance No. 8092, otherwise known as the “Traffic Management Code of the City of Manila.”

2nd Offense — A fine of One Thousand Pesos (PHP. 1,000.00) with issuance of Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR) for Code 43 of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) Fines and Penalties, and Section 104-C of Ordinance No. 8092, otherwise known as the “Traffic Management Code of the City of Manila,” and three (3) days impoundment of unit.

3rd Offense — A fine of One Thousand Pesos (PHP. 1,000.00) with issuance of Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR) for Code 43 of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) Fines and Penalties, and Section 104-C of Ordinance No. 8092, otherwise known as the “Traffic Management Code of the City of Manila,” and seven (7) days impoundment of unit.

4th Offense — Habitual violators — Cancellation of permit, Accreditation, and Franchise.

SEC. 4. The Office of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau. — Tri-wheel Management Unit (MTPB-TMU) is hereby directed to issue within five (5) days upon approval of this Ordinance the necessary rules and guidelines implementing the same, which shall be immediately applicable.

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances or portions thereof which are contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance or portions hereof are hereby deemed modified or repealed.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 10, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance sets a standardized fare matrix for tricycles, pedicabs, and e-trikes operating within Manila. Tricycles and pedicabs are to charge PhP16.00 for the first kilometer and PhP5.00 for every additional 500 meters, while e-trikes have a flat rate of PhP20.00 within their route. Penalties for overcharging or violating fare rules range from fines to impoundment and cancellation of permits for habitual violators. The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau is tasked with implementing the ordinance within five days of approval.
fines: PhP1,000 per offense, with increasing impound durations and possible cancellation of permits for habitual violators
