ORDINANCE NO. 8977
AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 7885, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA TO ESTABLISH AND OPERATE THE DALUBHASAAN NG MAYNILA (CITY COLLEGE OF MANILA) AND FOR SUCH OTHER PURPOSES", AS AMENDED, IN LINE WITH THE UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA APPLICATION FOR RECOGNITION AS A HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTION WITH THE COMMISSION ON HIGHER EDUCATION

EXPLANATORY NOTE
It is the policy of the City Government of Manila, as vested by the 1987 Philippine Constitution, to protect and promote the right of all citizens to quality education at all levels, and to take necessary steps to make education accessible to all.

In line with the requirements of the Commission on Higher Education (CHED), Universidad de Manila (UdM) is applying for recognition as a Higher Education Institution (HEI). UdM may then become eligible for national government subsidies, thereby making postgraduate studies in the City of Manila of greater quality and more accessible to its citizens.

The City Government of Manila recognizes the financial burden that comes with pursuing career advancement and higher education. This Ordinance aims to support Manileños in enhancing their professional growth and contributing to the city through more equitable access to postgraduate education.

This measure supports the improvement of education in UdM through the formal process of applying for HEI status, which will facilitate access to postgraduate education for bona fide residents of Manila. This Ordinance will have a significant impact on academic and career development in the city and broaden economic opportunities for its people.

Further amendments to Ordinance No. 7885 (as amended by Ordinance Nos. 8120, 8635, and 8750) are necessary to comply with CHED Memorandum Orders No. 32 (Series of 2006), No. 4 (Series of 2007), and No. 42 (Series of 2016).

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Section 3 of Ordinance No. 7885, as amended, is hereby further amended to read as follows:

“SEC. 3. Purposes. — As a public, non-sectarian, non-profit, and non-partisan institution of higher learning, enjoying institutional and individual academic freedom, the purposes of the University shall be:

To advance human knowledge through basic study and research, especially in science and technology;

To serve as a research university across its various fields of specialization;

To develop the Filipino intellect, promote Filipino culture, and encourage international understanding through intercultural and international education;

To promote higher moral and cultural values;

To provide scientific, technological, and professional training responsive to the needs of the city, including but not limited to the arts, humanities, management, accountancy, nursing, education, public administration, criminology, engineering, industrial education, sports, vocational-technical education, and other employment-oriented courses;

To offer graduate/professional programs and juris doctor degrees at an affordable and reasonable cost;

To provide professional studies, special executive programs, and short courses/micro-credentials at an affordable and reasonable cost;

To include in its curriculum programs that are not sufficiently emphasized in existing higher education institutions in the country;

To offer extension and related programs for the general welfare of the public;

To offer Senior High School under DepEd supervision, either through affiliation with existing city-supported institutions or through new institutions as needed;

To offer quality education at reasonable and affordable costs, especially to financially disadvantaged but qualified youth of the city;

To pursue excellence in instruction, research, and service;

To ensure economy, efficiency, and effectiveness in its organization and internal operations.”

SECTION 2.
Section 4 of Ordinance No. 7885, as amended, is hereby further amended to read:

“SEC. 4. Admission. — The University shall implement a system of admission that facilitates the enrollment of students regardless of sex, religious belief, economic status, or political affiliation:

Provided, that enrollment shall be exclusive to bona fide residents of Manila and those whose parents or guardians work and pay taxes to the city, subject to rules set by the Board of Regents.

Provided further, that the residency requirement shall not apply to students enrolling in the Graduate School and College of Law.”

SECTION 3.
Section 5 of Ordinance No. 7885, as amended, is hereby further amended to read:

“SEC. 5. Board of Regents. — The University's overall governance shall be vested in the Board of Regents, the highest governing body composed of individuals of known integrity and commitment to the city's academic development.

The Board shall consist of eleven (11) members as follows:

Chairperson: City Mayor

Vice Chairperson: University President

Nine (9) members, including: a. President of the Faculty Association
b. President of the Supreme Student Government
c. President of the Alumni Association
d. Chairperson of the City Council’s Committee on Education
e. Representative from the DOST or DA (depending on focus)
f. Representative from the recognized business/industry sector (appointed for two years)
g. CHED representative (designated as a permanent resource person)
h. NEDA Regional Office representative (invited resource person)

All members, except the Chairperson and ex-officio City Council representative, shall be appointed by the Mayor with the Council's consent.

The DOST representative must be at least of director rank and confirmed by the DOST Secretary.

All appointed members serve for six (6) years or until successors are appointed. Representatives from the faculty, alumni, and students shall serve co-terminus with their elected term.

The CHED representative shall be designated by the CHED Chairperson and serve as a permanent resource person in board meetings.”

SECTION 4.
Section 15 of Ordinance No. 7885, as amended, is hereby further amended to read:

“SEC. 15. University President. — The University President, as the Chief Academic and Executive Officer, shall serve full-time and be appointed by the Board of Regents upon recommendation of a Search Committee. The term shall be four (4) years, with one reappointment allowed, unless earlier removed for just cause such as incapacity, dishonesty, or a conviction of a crime involving moral turpitude.

The President must hold a doctoral degree (Level 8, Philippine Qualifications Framework) and have at least five (5) years of relevant administrative experience.

Salary and benefits shall be determined by the Board based on qualifications. The President shall perform all duties generally associated with the office.”

SECTION 5. Rules of Construction.
No statute or issuance shall diminish the University’s powers, rights, or benefits under this Ordinance unless explicitly repealed or modified by later legislation. Any ambiguity in interpretation shall be resolved in favor of academic freedom and fiscal autonomy.

SECTION 6. Appropriations.
Implementation costs shall be charged to the lump sum appropriation of the current fiscal year and the University’s internal funds. Future appropriations shall support UdM's growth, operations, and CHED accreditation. The University may use unexpended funds as the Board deems appropriate.

SECTION 7. Transitory Provision.
Current Board of Regents members shall remain in office until removed for cause or incapacitated. Subsequent vacancies shall be filled according to the process in this Ordinance.

SECTION 8. Separability Clause.
If any part of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional, other provisions shall remain valid.

SECTION 9. Repealing Clause.
All laws, decrees, orders, rules, or regulations inconsistent with this Ordinance are repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 10. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 1, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance updates the City College of Manila's governing rules to support Universidad de Manila's (UdM) application for recognition as a Higher Education Institution (HEI) by the Commission on Higher Education (CHED). The updates include changes to the university's purposes, admissions, and governance to align with CHED's requirements. The ordinance aims to make UdM eligible for government funding, improve the quality of postgraduate education, and make it more accessible to Manila residents.

ORDINANCE NO. 8976

AN ORDINANCE MANDATING ALL BARANGAYS WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA TO CREATE THEIR RESPECTIVE TOURISM COMMITTEES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Under Section 2 of Republic Act No. 9593 or The Tourism Act of 2009, the State declares tourism as an indispensable element of the national economy and an industry of national interest and importance, which must be harnessed as an engine of socio-economic growth and cultural affirmation to generate investment, foreign exchange, and employment, and to continue to mold an enhanced sense of national pride for all Filipinos.

Towards this end, the State shall seek to promote a tourism industry that is ecologically sustainable, responsible, participative, culturally sensitive, economically viable, and ethically and socially equitable for local communities, as provided for under the same law.

Pursuant to Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991, “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”

Under Section 17 of the same law, local government units shall likewise exercise such other powers and discharge such other functions and responsibilities as are necessary, appropriate, or incidental to efficient and effective provision of the basic services and facilities.

Manila City Ordinance No. 8588 was enacted on November 14, 2019, which provides for the creation of the Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) that is primarily responsible for the efficient and effective implementation of the city’s approved policies, plans, and programs with respect to tourism, arts, and culture.

With the huge tourism potential of the City of Manila, it is imperative to tap the barangays to ensure its continued development and preservation that would ultimately redound to revenue generation, job creation, and improved basic services to the community.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Creation of Barangay Tourism Committee. — Every barangay within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila shall organize a Tourism Committee to promote tourism primarily and to serve as the implementing arm of the Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) at the Barangay level.

SEC. 2. Composition of the Barangay Tourism Committee. — The Barangay Tourism Committee shall be composed of the following:
Chairperson : Punong Barangay
Members : Sangguniang Barangay Member
	  Representative from the DTCAM
	  Representative from the Civil Society Organization
	  Representative from Private Sector

SEC. 3. Duties and Functions. — The Barangay Tourism Committee shall have the following functions and responsibilities:

3.a. Monitor and coordinate the implementation of tourism programs and projects at their barangay;

3.b. Will act as an information-gather machinery at the barangay level;

3.c. Conduct dialogue with stakeholders on how to contribute to the improvement of tourism in the barangay and the city;

3.d. Formulate plans and recommend such measures necessary for the improvement of tourism at the barangay and city level; and

3.e. Perform such other functions as may be designated to them by the DTCAM from time to time.

SEC. 4. Monitoring and Evaluation. — The city, through the DTCAM in collaboration with the Liga ng mga Barangay, Manila Barangay Bureau, and/or Department of the Interior and Local Government — City of Manila Field Office, as the case may be, shall establish a mechanism to monitor and evaluate the performance of the Barangay Tourism Committee.

SEC. 5. Funding. — The barangays may appropriate funds to effectively perform their duties and functions subject to the availability of funds, and the usual budgeting, accounting, and auditing rules and regulations. The city government may likewise endeavor to provide support to the operations of the Barangay Tourism Committee subject to existing rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. Separability Clause. — In the event any part or provisions of this Ordinance are declared illegal or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. Repealing Clause. — All previous ordinances and rules/regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby deemed modified or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 8. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its publication.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 1, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance mandates all barangays in Manila to establish their own Barangay Tourism Committees, which will serve as local implementers of the city’s tourism initiatives under the Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts of Manila (DTCAM). These committees are tasked with monitoring tourism programs, gathering local tourism data, engaging stakeholders, and recommending development measures. The city government and barangays may allocate funding for these committees, and their performance will be monitored through established city mechanisms.

ORDINANCE NO. 8974

AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING AWARDS TO BE GIVEN BY THE SANGGUNIANG PANLUNGSOD NG MAYNILA TO ITS ERSTWHILE AND CURRENT MEMBERS WHO HAVE RENDERED EXCEPTIONAL AND UNBLEMISHED SERVICE TO THE CITY.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

On September 21, 1972, the entire country was placed under Martial Law by virtue of Presidential Proclamation 1081, resulting in the abolition of all legislative councils, including the then Manila Municipal Board. This hiatus lasted for fourteen years.

With the ratification of the 1987 Constitution, the 1st City Council was elected on January 18, 1988, with its tenure starting on February 2, 1988, and ending on June 30, 1992. This council was composed of six districts, as opposed to the pre-martial law composition of four districts. Each district elects six councilors, making a total of thirty-six elected councilors in the City of Manila. The Local Government Code of 1991 also provides for two additional sectoral representatives, representing the Liga ng mga Barangay and the Sangguniang Kabataan Federation.

On several occasions, aldermen or secretaries of local councils from other parts of the country have visited this Body to seek references on measures that they would pass in their localities.

As the national capital, our city continues to be the primary source of information on local legislation, as this Body has existed since the Spanish Colonial period.

It is sorrowful to note that decades later, many statutes crafted by past members of this Body were lost in the battle for the liberation of Manila in 1945. However, many survived the massive carpet bombing by the Allied Forces and are now preserved in the city’s statute books.

This current membership of this august Chamber recognizes the sacrifices and hard work of its past members. With sincere privilege, a program to give recognition and awards to the distinguished past and current members of the Manila City Council, who have carved a niche in the annals of history of our beloved city, has been crafted.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Awards and Recognition - The following awards and recognitions to be given to the erstwhile and current members of the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila shall hereby be institutionalized, to wit:

DANGAL NG KONSEHO AWARD
The highest recognition given to past and current members of the Manila City Council (Vice-Mayor or Councilor) who have rendered exemplary service to the Council and the City of Manila, adding great honor and prestige to the Council as an institution or contributing to the lasting benefit of the people of Manila.

PERLAS NG KONSEHO AWARD
A recognition given to a City Councilor for political merit, for having dedicated the most number of years in service to the people of Manila as a member of the City Council.

TIMBULAN NG LAYA AWARD
A recognition given to past and current members of the Manila City Council (Vice-Mayor or Councilor) whose life and achievements are worthy of emulation by the people of Manila. This is particularly in recognition of outstanding dedication to the democratic way of life, the rule of law, good governance, defense of truth and freedom, peaceful resolution of conflict, and other meritorious political and civic service.

DIWANG DAKILA AWARD
A posthumous award given in memory of a former member of the Manila City Council, or in exceptional cases, its employees and staff, who had rendered invaluable service and acts worthy of recognition for fostering, developing, and strengthening the honor and prestige of the City Council as an institution.

SEC. 2. Awardees — The list of awardees shall be prepared by a committee created by virtue of this Ordinance, and must pass the unanimous approval of the Sanggunian through a resolution.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 25, 2023.
short_text:
This ordinance creates a system of awards to honor both past and present members of the Manila City Council (which includes the Vice-Mayor and Councilors) who have provided outstanding and unblemished service to the city. The awards are as follows:

Dangal ng Konseho Award: The highest award given to individuals who have made significant contributions to the Council and the city, either by bringing honor to the institution or by improving the lives of the people of Manila.

Perlas ng Konseho Award: Given to a Councilor who has dedicated the most years of service to the City Council, recognizing their long-term commitment.

Timbulan ng Laya Award: This award is for Council members who have shown exceptional dedication to democracy, the rule of law, good governance, and the peaceful resolution of conflicts.

Diwang Dakila Award: A posthumous award, meaning it is given after someone has passed away, to honor a former Council member (or sometimes a staff member) for their exceptional service and contributions to the city.

The awards program aims to recognize and honor those who have made lasting impacts on the city through their public service.

ORDINANCE NO. 8973

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING SECTION 49 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8092, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT CODE OF THE CITY OF MANILA.”

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 49 of Ordinance No. 8092 is hereby furthermore amended to read as follows:

“SEC. 49. Authority to Dispose of Abandoned or Unclaimed Vehicles. – Vehicles impounded six (6) months after the date they were impounded are considered abandoned or unclaimed and shall be in the legal possession of the City of Manila, or specifically, the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau. The head of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau is hereby authorized to recommend to the City Mayor the disposal of a vehicle that has been taken into possession. Such disposal shall be at a public auction under the procedure established by the City Mayor, with the approval of the Sangguniang Panlungsod. Written notice and publications of such auction shall be sent to the last known registered owner or person indicated in the vehicle's papers, and the person indicated in the violation ticket (if available), by private courier and registered mail. These notices will be sent three (3) months after impoundment, five (5) months after impoundment, and at least thirty (30) days prior to the date of the auction. The auction shall be held no earlier than six (6) months after the vehicle was impounded. Any person entitled to reclaim the vehicle may do so at any time prior to the auction, upon payment of all costs and expenses related to the impoundment and storage of the vehicle, as determined by the officers or their authorized subordinates.”

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. – If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause. – All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. – This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 25, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance updates the rules regarding abandoned or unclaimed vehicles in Manila. If a vehicle is impounded and remains unclaimed for six months, it will be considered abandoned. The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau is authorized to recommend the disposal of these vehicles through a public auction, with approval from the City Mayor and the Sangguniang Panlungsod. Notices about the auction will be sent to the vehicle’s last known owner and relevant parties, with the auction happening at least six months after the vehicle is impounded. Owners can reclaim their vehicle before the auction by paying the related impoundment and storage costs.
fines: Costs and expenses related to the impoundment and storage

ORDINANCE NO. 8971

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE REVERSION TO THE GENERAL FUND OF THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF THIRTY-THREE MILLION SIX HUNDRED FORTY THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 33,640,000.00), UNDER THE CAPITAL OUTLAY ACCOUNT OF THE FY 2023 APPROPRIATIONS ORDINANCE, TO FUND THE VARIOUS PRIORITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, categorically provides:

“Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. - Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation, and the sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations, subject to the provisions of this Section.”

Particular amounts were appropriated for certain projects under the Capital Outlay (CO) for the FY 2023 Annual Budget. However, due to changing circumstances, it was determined that said projects are no longer necessary.

The funds under said appropriation are determined to be free from any obligation or encumbrance and still available to be utilized as a source of funds. Furthermore, for FY 2023, there are necessary projects which need urgent funding through a Supplemental Budget.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Reversion. – The following funds under the FY 2023 Capital Outlay Appropriations Ordinance shall be reverted to the General Fund:

Particulars and Amounts:

Reversion of Appropriations:

Fund Source: General Fund

Type: Capital Outlay

Amount: PHP 640,000.00

Reversion of Appropriations:

Type: Hospitals and Health Centers

Particular: Construction of Two (2)-Storey Isidro Mendoza Health Center

Amount: PHP 33,000,000.00

Grand Total: PHP 33,640,000.00

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. – This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 27, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the reversion of PHP 33,640,000.00 from the FY 2023 Capital Outlay budget to the General Fund. The amount includes funds initially intended for projects such as the construction of the Isidro Mendoza Health Center, which are no longer needed. These funds will be used to support other priority improvement projects for the city of Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 8969

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR, MARIA SHEILAH "HONEY" H. LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, TO ENTER INTO A MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM - NATIONAL CAPITAL REGION AND OTHER TOURISM STAKEHOLDERS, PURSUANT TO SECTION 22(C) OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 7160, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT CODE OF 1991

EXPLANATORY NOTE
On May 19, 2023, the Officer-in-Charge of the Department of Tourism, Culture, and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) forwarded to the City Legal Office for review and comment the proposed Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) with the Department of Tourism - National Capital Region (DOT-NCR) for its project entitled "Hop-On Hop-Off (HOHO): Travel By Hub."

Under the proposed MOA, the City of Manila shall be responsible for the following:
1.        Traffic and security augmentation;
2.        Training and accreditation of tour guides;
3.        Identification and assignment of strategic Hop-On Hop-Off Stops;
4.        Oversight of logistics and securing necessary permits for the project;
5.        Participation in sustaining the efforts of the project.

As regards the undertaking to provide traffic and security augmentation, the number of buses, schedules, and frequency of routes must be coordinated with the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB).

The service providers (such as tour operators and guides) operating within the City of Manila must be accredited by the DTCAM.

As regards the identification and assignment of strategic Hop-On Hop-Off stops should likewise be coordinated with the MTPB.

The City Legal Officer observed that the MOA appears to be in order and that the Honorable Mayor may sign and approve the same. However, the passage of an ordinance is required to authorize the Honorable Mayor to enter into a Memorandum of Agreement with the Department of Tourism - National Capital Region (DOT-NCR) and other tourism stakeholders pursuant to Section 22(c) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991. Hence, the necessity for this Ordinance.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. The Honorable City Mayor, Maria Sheilah "Honey" H. Lacuna-Pangan, MD, FPDS, is hereby authorized to enter into a Memorandum of Agreement with the Department of Tourism - National Capital Region (DOT-NCR) and other tourism stakeholders pursuant to Section 22(c) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

SECTION 2. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 6, 2023.
short_text: This ordinance allows Manila Mayor Maria Sheilah “Honey” Lacuna-Pangan to officially sign an agreement with the Department of Tourism - NCR and other tourism groups to launch the "Hop-On Hop-Off: Travel by Hub" project. Manila will help with traffic management, tourist guide training, assigning bus stops, and getting permits to make the project successful. Coordination with the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau is required. The ordinance makes it official under the Local Government Code of 1991.

ORDINANCE NO. 8967

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 3 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8513, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8540, ESSENTIALLY TO AUTHORIZE NEWLY ASSIGNED LAWYERS AT THE PUBLIC ATTORNEY'S OFFICE PROVIDING FREE LEGAL ASSISTANCE TO RESIDENTS OF MANILA TO BE GRANTED MONTHLY INCENTIVE ALLOWANCES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 39, Rule XII of the Implementing Rules and Regulations of Republic Act No. 9406, otherwise known as the “Act Reorganizing and Strengthening the Public Attorney’s Office (PAO), amending for the purpose pertinent provisions of Executive Order No. 292, or the Administrative Code of 1987,” provides that Local Government Units, subject to their capabilities, may extend financial and other support (honoraria, office space, equipment, furniture, stationery, manpower, etc.) to the PAO.

By virtue of this, Ordinance No. 8513, s. 2016 ("An Ordinance Authorizing the Grant of Monthly Incentive Allowance to All Lawyers of the Public Attorney's Office Assigned/Based in the City Providing Free Legal Assistance to the Residents Thereat, Appropriating Annually the Amount of Seven Million Two Hundred Thousand Pesos (Php 7,200,000.00) for the Purpose") was enacted and later amended by Ordinance No. 8540.

The Public Attorney’s Office-Manila District has grown from 54 to 102 lawyers, and more are being assigned to cover the 101 trial courts in Manila. 

Recognizing the PAO's crucial role in providing free legal services to indigent Manileños, this ordinance seeks to further support newly assigned public attorneys.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Amendment to Section 3 of Ordinance No. 8513, as amended by Ordinance No. 8540. Section 3 is hereby further amended to include a second paragraph to read as follows:

“SEC. 3. Pursuant to the stated policy, the following remunerations shall be provided:
XXX
The monthly incentive allowance for Public Attorneys shall also be granted to incoming/newly assigned lawyers in the Public Attorney’s Office – Manila District Office. Provided, that the Public Attorneys concerned shall continue to receive the subject allowance as long as they remain stationed or assigned in the City of Manila, and that it shall automatically be discontinued upon their retirement, death, termination, or transfer to another district or city. Provided further, that the Regional Public Attorney shall annually provide the Office of the Mayor with a report on the number of lawyers stationed or assigned in the Public Attorney’s Office – Manila District Office."

SECTION 2. Source of Fund.
The funds for this purpose shall be sourced from the Special Purpose Appropriation – Statutory and Contractual Obligations under the FY 2023 Appropriations Ordinance (FY 2023 Annual Budget).



SECTION 3. Separability Clause. - Should any provision herein be declared void or unconstitutional, the same shall not affect the validity of the other provisions of this Ordinance.

SECTION 4. Repealing Clause. - All local ordinances, rules, and regulations or parts thereof inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 30, 2023.

CERTIFICATION
This is to certify that Ordinance No. 8967, entitled:
"AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 3 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8513, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8540, ESSENTIALLY TO AUTHORIZE NEWLY ASSIGNED LAWYERS AT THE PUBLIC ATTORNEY'S OFFICE PROVIDING FREE LEGAL ASSISTANCE TO RESIDENTS OF MANILA TO BE GRANTED MONTHLY INCENTIVE ALLOWANCES"
was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on May 30, 2023. It was forwarded to the Office of the Honorable Mayor on June 14, 2023.
Considering that more than ten (10) days have lapsed without any communication regarding approval or veto by the Local Chief Executive, Ordinance No. 8967 shall be DEEMED APPROVED as if signed, pursuant to Section 54(b) of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.
Issued this 6th day of July 2023, in the City of Manila.
short_text: The City of Manila will now give monthly incentive allowances to newly assigned lawyers at the Public Attorney’s Office (PAO) who provide free legal services to Manila residents. These allowances will continue as long as the lawyers remain assigned to Manila and will stop if they retire, leave, or transfer. This move supports the growing number of public lawyers needed to serve the city’s trial courts. Funding will come from the city's 2023 budget under Special Purpose Appropriations.

ORDINANCE NO. 8966

AN ORDINANCE PRESCRIBING A STANDARDIZED ALLOWANCE SCHEDULE TO BE GRANTED FOR THE PERFORMANCE OF ELECTION-RELATED ASSIGNMENTS

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The City Treasurer's Office (CTO) is among the government agencies deputized by the Commission on Elections (COMELEC) to perform election-related duties and responsibilities during the conduct of the National and Local Elections and other similar political exercises.

These election-related duties and responsibilities are distinct from the regular and permanent functions of the CTO, which primarily involve revenue collection, public fund management, and disbursements.

Officials and personnel who perform and carry out election-related assignments render work different from and in addition to their regular workload, and may therefore be entitled to the grant of allowances and other similar forms of honoraria.

Section 458(a)(1)(vii) of the Local Government Code empowers the City Council to determine the positions and the salaries, wages, allowances, and other emoluments and benefits of officials and employees paid wholly or mainly from city funds, and to provide for expenditures necessary for the proper conduct of programs, projects, services, and activities of the city government.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Prescription of Allowances. - There is hereby prescribed a Standardized Allowance Schedule to be granted to officials and personnel performing election-related duties and responsibilities. The amount of hourly allowance shall be based on the organizational designation, the nature of work performed, and the level of responsibility involved in the electoral undertaking.

SECTION 2. Designation of Assignment. - In recognition of the authority as a duly deputized official of the Commission on Elections (COMELEC), the City Treasurer shall designate the officials and employees who will perform a definite election-related assignment. Given the limited number of organic personnel, the Treasurer may augment the manpower complement by drawing from other offices of the city government.

SECTION 3. Emolument Schedule. - The prescribed Hourly Allowance Schedule shall be as follows:

Level        
Level 1 
Level 2 
Level 3 
Level 4

Position/Designation        
1. Central Committee Officers, District Executive Officers        
2. Polling Precinct Supervisors, Senior Technical Staff
3. Administrative Support Personnel
4. Security, and other Manpower

Amount per Hour
1. PHP 925.44
2. PHP 562.61
3. PHP 442.05
4. PHP 227.61

SECTION 4. Implementing Office. - The City Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue the necessary guidelines or Office Orders for the effective implementation of this Ordinance.

SECTION 5. Source of Fund. - Funding for the allowances shall come from a specific expenditure account in the Executive Budget. All payments shall be covered by duly approved disbursement vouchers and shall be subject to usual accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

The amounts of Allowance herein shall prescribed automatically proportionately based on corresponding increases in the prevailing rates under the applicable Salary Tranche of the Salary Standardization Law of 2019 (R.A. No. 11466) and subsequent amendments thereto.

SECTION 6. Separability Clause.  - If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid, the remaining provisions shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 7. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules, regulations, and other issuances, or parts thereof, found inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby revoked, repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SECTION 8. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 30, 2023.
short_text: The City of Manila has set a standardized allowance schedule for city officials and employees who are assigned election-related duties, such as helping during national and local elections. Allowances will vary depending on the role and level of responsibility, with higher allowances for higher-level tasks. The City Treasurer will handle the designation of assignments and implementation. Funds will come from the city’s budget, and allowance rates will automatically adjust with future salary standardization increases.

ORDINANCE NO. 8965

AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND IMPLEMENTING THE INSTITUTIONALIZED NATIONAL FEEDING PROGRAM PURSUANT TO REPUBLIC ACT NO. 11037, ALSO KNOWN AS “MASUSTANSYANG PAGKAIN PARA SA BATANG PILIPINO ACT” IN THE CITY OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Relative to the 1987 Constitution, Article II, Section 15, states that, “The State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them”. Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the “Local Government Code of 1991", Chapter II, Section 17 (b) (4) provides the basic services and facilities which includes program and projects on child and youth welfare, family and community welfare, women’s welfare, welfare of the elderly and disabled persons; community-based rehabilitation programs for vagrants, beggars, street children, scavengers, juvenile delinquents, and victims of drug abuse, livelihood and other pro-poor projects, nutrition services, and family planning services.

Further, Republic Act No. 11037, entitled: “An Act Institutionalizing a National Feeding Program for Undernourished Children in Public Day Care, Kindergarten and Elementary Schools to Combat Hunger and Undernutrition Among Filipino Children and Appropriating Funds Therefor” recognizes the demonstrated relationship between food and nutrition, and the capacity of students to develop and learn. The State commits to establish a comprehensive national feeding program that will address the problem of undernutrition among Filipino children. Studies show that infants and young children are the most susceptible to malnutrition, which has affected thousands of children and, if not prevented, will stunt their growth and weaken their resistance to infections, resulting in needless human deaths due to high infant and child mortality rates.

In order to achieve a nutritionally improved city with inhabitants who are well-nourished, healthy, intelligent, socially, economically, and politically productive, the City of Manila must adopt and implement the provision of R.A. 11037 (Masustansyang Pagkain para sa Batang Pilipino), which is necessary to intensify the City’s campaign against malnutrition.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Title. - This Ordinance shall be known as the “Masustansyang Pagkain para sa Batang Pilipino Ordinance”.

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. - As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall be construed to mean as follows:
a. Cycle Menu — refers to standardized menus prepared by the National Government Agencies (NGAs), in coordination with the National Nutrition Council (NNC) and the Food and Nutrition Research Institute (FNRI), which shall be contextualized and drawn up, among others, according to age range, location and/or type of school, and local cultural and/or religious eating preferences: Provided, That such menu shall have as many varieties and selections as may be necessary taking into account its availability in the place or locality where the daycare center or school is located.



b. Fortified Meal — refers to a meal with deliberately increased content of essential micronutrients so as to improve the nutritional quality of the food and provide the level of calories and protein as prescribed by the NNC which shall consist of at least one-third (1/3) of the daily requirement based on the Philippine Dietary Reference Intake (PDRI).

c. Health Examination — refers to the examination conducted by NGAs, in coordination with the Department of Health (DOH) and Local Government Units (LGUs) concerned on the overall condition of the program beneficiary which shall, among others, include the program beneficiary's height, weight, and other ailments, defects or deformities that may need special care or treatment.

d. National Government Agencies (NGAs) — refers to the Department of Education (DepED) and the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) which shall be the lead agencies in the implementation of the program for public kindergarten and elementary schools and public day care centers, respectively.

e. Undernourished Child — refers to a child who has been supplied with less than the minimum amount of foods essential for sound health and growth. For the purpose of this Ordinance, it shall include children who are suffering from chronic hunger and malnutrition, as well as those who are considered as wasted, severely wasted, or stunted under the World Health Organization Child Growth Standards.
________________________________________
SEC. 3. Manila City Local Feeding Program. - The Manila City Local Feeding Program shall be established in line with the National Feeding Program as provided for in R.A. 11037 to address undernutrition among Filipino children which shall have the following components and coverage:

a. Supplemental Feeding Program for Day Care Children — The Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) shall implement a supplemental feeding program for undernourished children with ages three (3) to five (5) years. The program shall be administered in a day care center or in any other facility which can be used for such purpose: Provided, That the program shall include provision of at least one (1) fortified meal for a period of not less than one hundred twenty (120) days in a year: Provided, further, That in the preparation of fortified meals, the MDSW shall work in collaboration with recognized parents’ organizations.

b. School-Based Feeding Program — The local DepED shall implement a school-based feeding program for undernourished public school children from kindergarten to grade six (6): Provided, That the program shall include the provision of at least one (1) fortified meal to all undernourished public elementary school children for a period of not less than one hundred twenty (120) days in a year.

c. Milk Feeding Program — The city government shall endeavor for the incorporation of fresh milk and fresh milk-based food products in the fortified meals and cycle menu in accordance with Republic Act No. 8976, otherwise known as the “Philippine Food Fortification Act of 2000”.

d. Micronutrient Supplements — The City Health Department shall provide micronutrient supplements to the program beneficiaries including the use of iodized salt in accordance with Republic Act No. 8172, otherwise known as the “An Act for Salt Iodization Nationwide (ASIN)”.
e. Health Examination, Vaccination and Deworming — The Manila Health Department (MHD), in coordination with the local DepED and MDSW, shall conduct simultaneous health examination including, but not limited to, deworming and vaccination, as the case may be, to program beneficiaries.

f. Gulayan sa Paaralan — The city government shall encourage barangays and schools to devote a portion of their land or space for the cultivation of vegetables and other nutrient-rich plants. Parents shall also be encouraged to maintain a similar program in their own backyard.

g. Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) — The city government, particularly the MHD, local DepED and MDSW, shall establish and maintain water and sanitation facilities, promote good hygiene and safe food preparation in all early child care centers and schools located within the City of Manila especially in areas devoted for the preparation of fortified meals under the program.

h. Integrated Nutrition Education, Behavioral Transformation and Social Mobilization — The program shall be complemented by a public health, nutrition and values transformation campaign to promote a holistic and integrated approach to health and nutrition education. Orientation-training on the objectives and mechanics of the program shall be held among the personnel of city government, parent volunteers, and the parent-teachers association (PTAs) to generate support for the program. The city government shall also endeavor to mobilize community organizations to continue nutrition education outside of the school.

SEC. 4. Local Government Assistance to the National Feeding Program. - In accordance with Section 7 of R.A. 11037, the City Government shall assist the NGAs in the efficient and effective implementation of the program and shall be authorized to use a portion of the Special Education Fund (SEF) and/or their twenty percent (20%) development fund as provided for in Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the “Local Government Code of 1991”, as amended, to augment the appropriations available under the General Appropriations Act (GAA).

SEC. 5. Private Sector Participation. - The city government shall encourage the participation of the private sector in the program which shall include, among others, PTAs, private corporations, peoples and non-governmental organizations and such other groups or organizations both foreign and local, that may want to be a partner in whole or in part with the implementation of the program.

SEC. 6. Monitoring and Annual Report. - The Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW), in coordination with the NGAs, the National Nutrition Council and other stakeholders, shall regularly monitor, review, and assess the impact and effectiveness of the program, as well as ensure compliance with standards and guidelines of the program for food safety, quality, accountability, community participation, and the procurement and liquidation processes adopted. The MDSW shall submit an annual report, at the end of every year, to the Sangguniang Panlungsod for this purpose.

SEC. 7. Appropriations. -  The amount necessary to carry out the initial implementation of this Ordinance shall be sourced from the current appropriations of the lead implementing agencies. Thereafter, such sums as may be necessary for the continuous implementation of this Ordinance shall be included in the annual budget under the respective offices.

SEC. 8. Separability Clause. - If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. - All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 10. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in at least two (2) newspapers of local circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 25, 2023.
short_text: The City of Manila has officially adopted the National Feeding Program based on Republic Act No. 11037, also known as the "Masustansyang Pagkain Para sa Batang Pilipino Act." This program aims to give free healthy meals, micronutrient supplements, and health services like deworming and vaccination to undernourished children in public day care centers and elementary schools. It also promotes vegetable gardens in schools and barangays, ensures proper water, sanitation, and hygiene facilities, and encourages private sector participation to help sustain the program. The City will fund this initiative using part of its budget and will submit a yearly report on its progress.

ORDINANCE NO. 8964

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF MAYOR'S PERMIT, AMUSEMENT TAX, AND OTHER INCIDENTAL EXPENSES TO STUDENTS AUTHORIZED BY THEIR RESPECTIVE SCHOOLS FOR FILM SHOOTING FEATURING HISTORICAL SITES AND VENUES WITHIN THE JURISDICTION OF THE CITY, FOR THE PERIOD APRIL 1, 2023 TO JUNE 10, 2023, BEING PARTICIPANTS TO THE MANILA FILM FESTIVAL

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The city-wide film festival was created in the 1960s by former Manila Mayor Antonio Villegas. The event was initiated to showcase and give a platform to the talents of the participants in the film-making industry. However, this film festival was put on hold for 29 years. By the efforts of the City Government of Manila, the film festival returns under the new name called The Manila Film Festival (TMFF), this time inviting students to participate in an endeavor to empower the youth and engage them in activities that will further develop their skills and capabilities as young artists.

This Ordinance seeks to exempt the participating students from the Arellano University, University of the Philippines Diliman, Colegio de San Juan de Letran, and Adamson University, in the upcoming "The Manila Film Festival" for the period April 1, 2023 to June 10, 2023, from payment of Mayor's Permit, amusement tax, and other incidental expenses to sites and venues that they will be featuring within the City of Manila. This will subsidize and promote the participants of the Manila Film Festival to produce a world-class film without hampering their financial capacity to produce one.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. -  Exemption from payment of Mayor's Permit, amusement tax, and other incidental expenses to students authorized by their respective schools for film shooting featuring historical sites and venues within the jurisdiction of the City, for the period April 1, 2023 to June 10, 2023, being participants to The Manila Film Festival, is hereby granted and authorized.

SEC. 2. Participants. - The following schools are the participants to the TMFF which submitted the lists of their authorized students for the specific endeavor:
•        University of the Philippines Diliman
•        Colegio de San Juan de Letran
•        Adamson University
•        Colegio de San Juan de Letran
•        Arellano University

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 23, 2023.
short_text: The City of Manila passed a law allowing students from four schools to film at historical places in the city without paying for Mayor's Permits, amusement taxes, or other fees. This exemption is only for students officially authorized by their schools and participating in The Manila Film Festival from April 1 to June 10, 2023. The goal is to support young filmmakers by reducing their financial burden so they can create high-quality films. The ordinance took effect immediately after it was approved by the City Council on May 23, 2023.

ORDINANCE NO. 8961

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF AMUSEMENT TAX FOR THE STAGING OF SEASON 98 VOLLEYBALL TOURNAMENT BY THE NATIONAL COLLEGIATE ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION AT THE SAN ANDRES SPORTS COMPLEX, MALATE, MANILA FOR THE PERIOD FEBRUARY 21 TO MARCH 23, 2023, AS SOUGHT BY FR. VIRGILIO M. PAREDES, JR., OAR

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) is the oldest athletic association in the country, founded in 1924. The Board and the Committee are composed of representatives of the eight member schools. The NCAA sponsors eleven (11) sports, divided into two categories: the junior division for high school students and the senior division for collegiate students.

With the 98th season of the NCAA being hosted by the Emilio Aguinaldo College, in the City of Manila, comes the responsibility of bearing the fees and taxes required to ensure the successful implementation of the competition and to provide a venue for camaraderie and sportsmanship among Filipino athletes of all ages.

Through a letter dated 21 March 2023, Fr. Virgilio M. Paredes Jr., OAR, Chairman of the 98th Season of the NCAA Volleyball Tournament, requested the exemption from payment of amusement tax for the use of the San Andres Sports Complex, located at Malate, Manila — a tax normally paid to the City Treasurer’s Office — subject to the approval of the City Council of Manila.

The City Legal Office, through a letter dated 11 May 2023, expressed no objection to the tax exemption being applied for by the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) for the period of February 21 to March 23, 2023.

In the spirit of supporting such activities, the City shall continuously seek ways to provide venues for activities that enrich the physical and psychological capacities of the students of the City. Thus, the City Council shall pass an ordinance granting the request.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Exemption from payment of amusement tax for the staging of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Season 98 Volleyball Tournament, as sought by Fr. Virgilio M. Paredes, Jr., OAR, using the San Andres Sports Complex, Malate, Manila for the period February 21 to March 23, 2023, is hereby granted and authorized.

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 16, 2023.
short_text: The City of Manila approved a ordinance allowing the NCAA to hold its Season 98 Volleyball Tournament at San Andres Sports Complex without paying the amusement tax. This exemption covered the event period from February 21 to March 23, 2023, following a request made by Fr. Virgilio M. Paredes, Jr., OAR. The City supports this event to promote sports and unity among students. The ordinance became effective immediately after its approval on May 16, 2023.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8959

AN ORDINANCE IMPOSING A TOURISM CERTIFICATION FEE TO TOURISM
RELATED ESTABLISHMENTS OPERATING WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

CHAPTER I

ARTICLE A - Title

SECTION 1. Title. This Ordinance shall be known as "Tourism Certification Fee of 2023 in the City of Manila" for brevity.   

ARTICLE B- Authority and Scope

SEC. 2. Authority. - This Ordinance is enacted pursuant to Section 17 (a), Chapter 2, Title One, Book I, Section 132, Chapter 1, Title One, Book II and Section 151, Article Three, Chapter 2, Title One, Book II of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, which states that:   

"SEC. 17. Basic Services and Facilities. (a) Local government units shall endeavor to be self-reliant and shall continue exercising the powers and discharging the duties and functions currently vested upon them. They shall also discharge the functions and responsibilities of national agencies and offices devolved to them pursuant to this Code. Local government units shall likewise exercise such other powers and discharge such other functions and responsibilities as are necessary, appropriate or incidental to efficient and effective provision of the basic services and facilities enumerated herein. 

SEC. 132. Local Taxing Authority. The power to impose a tax, fee or charge or to generate revenue under this Code shall be exercised by the sanggunian of the local government unit concerned through an appropriate ordinance.

SEC. 151. Scope of Taxing Powers. Except as otherwise provided in this Code, the city, may levy the taxes, fees and charges which the province or municipality may impose: Provided, however, That the taxes, fees and charges levied and collected by highly urbanized and independent component cities shall accrue to them and distributed in accordance with the provisions of this code. 

The rates of taxes that the city may levy may exceed the maximum rates allowed for the province or municipality by not more than fifty percent (50%) except the rates of professional and amusement taxes."   

SEC. 3. Purpose. This Ordinance shall release a certification issued by the Committee on Tourism under the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) to all tourism enterprises so that it officially distinguishes as having complied with the minimum standards for the operation of tourism facilities and services. All registered and licensed tourism enterprises located within the City of Manila will have to conform to the programs, guidelines, and rules promulgated by the Committee on Tourism in coordination with the DTCAM.   

SEC. 4. Scope. - This Ordinance shall form part of the taxing and other revenue- raising powers under the City of Manila.   

ARTICLE C - Definitions

SEC. 5. Words and Phrases. - When used in this Ordinance:   

a. LICENSE TO OPERATE (DIPLOMA) - refers to the certification of registration issued to all tourism enterprises after such facilities have been certified by the DTCAM as having conformed with the minimum standards/requirements for the operation of tourism facilities and services in accordance with the Committee on Tourism.

b. TOURISM ENTERPRISES - refers to facilities, services and attractions involved in tourism, such as, but not limited to, travel and tour services; tourist transport services, whether for land, sea or air transportation; tour guides; convention organizers; accommodation establishments, including, but not limited to, hotels, resorts, apartelles, tourist inns, motels, pension houses and home stay operators; tourism estate management services, restaurants, shops and department stores, sports and recreational centers, spas, museums and galleries, theme parks, and convention centers.

c. TOURISM-ORIENTED ESTABLISHMENTS - refers to travel and tour services; land, sea and air transport services exclusively for tourist use; accommodation establishments; convention and exhibition organizers; tourism estate management services; and such other enterprises which caters directly to both foreign and local tourists:   

a. APARTMENT HOTEL (APARTEL) - any building or edifice containing several independent and furnished or semi-furnished apartments, regularly leased to tourist and travelers for a period of not less than a day.

b. HOTEL - any building, edifice or premise which offers a venue for receptions, functions, seminar/conventions/forums, accommodations or lodging of travelers or tourists for a fee.

c. MOTORIST HOTEL - a lodging inn for tourists and travelers journeying by automobiles.

d. PENSION HOUSE - a private or family-oriented tourist boarding house or tourist lodging house, employing non-professional domestic helpers, regularly catering to tourist and/or travelers, containing several independent lettable rooms, providing common facilities such as toilets, bathrooms/showers, living and dining rooms and/or kitchen and where a combination of board and lodging may be provided.

e. TOUR GUIDE - an individual who is licensed by the BPLO and registered with the DTCAM to guide tourists, both foreign and domestic for a fee commission or any other form of lawful remuneration.

f. TOUR SERVICES - refers to tourist transport, business operation by air, sea or land either on character or regular run.

g. TOURIST INN - a lodging establishment that caters to local and foreign tourists, but does not meet the minimum requirements of an economy hotel.

h. TOURIST LAND TRANSPORT - any vehicle, carriage or conveyance moving on wheels or tunnels used on public roads and highways and catering to tourists.   

i. TOURIST TRANSPORT OPERATOR - a person or entity which may either be a single proprietorship, partnership or corporation, regularly engaged in providing for a fee or lawful consideration, tourist transport services as hereinafter defined, either on charter or regular run.

j. TRAVEL AGENCY - an entity which may either be a single proprietorship, partnership or corporation regularly engaged in the business of extending to individual or groups, such services pertaining to documentation of travel papers, ticketing, sales and/or accommodation, handling and/or conduct of tours within or outside the Philippines whether or not for a fee, commission or any form of compensation.

k. TRAVEL CONSULTANCY SERVICES - any establishment that act as a consultancy firm, pertaining to immigration and facilitation of travel documents.   

d. TOURISM-RELATED ESTABLISHMENTS - refers to all other tourism enterprises not covered by the preceding subsection and such other enterprises which caters indirectly to both foreign and local tourists:   

a. BAR (KTV/Videoke), COCKTAIL LOUNGE bars are establishments where intoxicating and fermented liquors or malt are sold in addition to cooked food, it may also feature videoke entertainment or live bands.

i. Karaoke Bar is considered a place where guest relations officers are available to entertain customers. Customers may sing rendered by the karaoke machine. Patrons are served with foods and drinks and are allowed to sing with their partners.
ii. Cocktail Lounge or Beer Garden is considered a bar even if there are no hostesses or waitresses to entertain customers.

b. CONVENIENCE STORE - refers to any 24-hour service outlets with a capitalization of above One Million Pesos (PhP. 1,000,000.00).

c. DEPARTMENT STORE a store which sells or carries several lines of merchandises in 
separate sections or departments including one devoted to native/Filipiniana items.

d. GYM-refers to fitness centers with franchise.

e. KIOSK, FASTFOODS - any small businesses that provide the general public with a normal menu, a special menu, catered prepared food, quick orders, wrapped drinks, and beverages.

f. MONEY CHANGER - an establishment that exchanges foreign currencies.

g. NIGHT OR DAY CLUB AND SUPER CLUB - includes any place frequented at night-time or day-time, as the case may be, where patrons are served food and drinks and are allowed to dance with the partners or with professional dance instructors/hostesses furnished by the management and also includes any establishments where food and drinks are served to its patrons to the accompaniment of music furnished by such establishment with musicians under its employ or by jukebox players installed within its premises, and where patrons are allowed to dance only with partners who they bring along.  

h. RESTAURANTS - any establishments offering to the public regular and special meals or menu, catered cooked foods or short orders, wrapped to go, beverages and drinks.

i. SAUNAS, SPA AND HEALTH CLUBS - refers to therapeutic massage and health parlors and establishments which offer complete relaxation to its clients for beauty and wellness.

j. SHOP - a small retail establishment specializing in Filipiniana or other specialized items and souvenir products.

k. SPORTS AND RECREATION FACILITIES - establishments/resorts providing sports and recreational facilities such as swimming pools, bowling lanes, tennis courts, pelota or squash courts, golf course, riding ranges, shooting ranges, archery ranges, aquatic/water sports arrangement, fishing, water skiing, and similar forming part of the resort.

l. THEATERS AND CINEMAS - refers to establishments used as venue for the performing arts or where motion pictures are shown.

m. TOURIST MANPOWER TRAINING CENTER a center conducting training for the manpower requirements of the tourism industry.

n. WINE AND LIQUOR STORE - includes the selling, giving away or dispensing of intoxicating malt, vino, mixed or fermented liquors at any retail outlet.   

ARTICLE D - Classification

SEC. 6. Classifications. -   

6.1 TOURISM-ORIENTED ESTABLISHMENTS. - Refers to travel and tour services; land, sea and air transport services exclusively for tourist use; accommodation establishments; convention and exhibition organizers; tourism estate management services; and such other enterprises which caters directly to both foreign and local tourists. For this purpose, the following are considered tourism- oriented establishments:   

a. Apartment Hotel (Apartel);
b. Hotel;
c. Motorist Hotel;
d. Pension House;
e. Tour Guide;
f. Tour Services;
g. Tourist Inn;
h. Tourist Land Transport;
i. Tourist Transport Operator;
j. Travel Agency; and
k. Travel Consultancy services.   

6.2 TOURISM-RELATED ESTABLISHMENTS. - Refers to all other tourism enterprises not covered by the preceding subsection and such other enterprises which caters indirectly to both foreign and local tourists. For this purpose, the following are considered tourism- oriented establishments 

a. Bar (KTV/Videoke), Cocktail Lounge;
b. Convenience Store;
c. Department Store;
d. Gym;   
e. Kiosk, Fastfoods;
f. Money Changer;
g. Night or Day Club and Super Club;
h. Restaurant;
i. Saunas, Spa and Health Clubs;
j. Shop;
k. Sports and Recreational Facilities;
l. Theaters and Cinemas;
m. Tourist Manpower Training Center; and
n. Wine and Liquor Store.   

ARTICLE E

SEC. 7. The DTCAM shall be responsible in the processing, registration and issuance of the Tourism Certificate for Tourism Enterprises. The rate/amount said is good for one (1) year and shall be renewed on an annual basis.   

ARTICLE F

SEC. 8. The rate of issuance of Tourism Certificate are as follows:   

8.1 TOURISM-ORIENTED ESTABLISHMENTS.
a. Hotel: PHP 1,500.00
b. Apartment Hotel (Apartel): PHP 1,000.00
c. Motorist Hotel: PHP 1,000.00
d. Pension House: PHP 1,000.00
e. Tour Services: PHP 1,000.00
f. Tourist Inn: PHP 1,000.00
g. Tourist Land Transport: PHP 1,000.00
h. Tourist Transport Operator: PHP 1,000.00
i. Travel Agency: PHP 1,000.00
j. Travel Consultancy Services: PHP 1,000.00
k. Tour Guide: PHP 500.00   

8.2 TOURISM-RELATED ESTABLISHMENTS.
a. Bar (KTV/Videoke), Cocktail Lounge: PHP 1,000.00
b. Convenience Store: PHP 500.00
c. Department Store: PHP 1,500.00
d. Gym: PHP 500.00
e. Kiosk, Fastfoods: PHP 500.00
f. Money Changer: PHP 500.00
g. Night or Day Club and Super Club: PHP 1,000.00
h. Restaurant: PHP 1,000.00
i. Saunas, Spa and Health Clubs: PHP 1,000.00
j. Shop: PHP 500.00
k. Sports and Recreational Facilities: PHP 500.00
l. Theaters and Cinemas: PHP 1,000.00
m. Tourist Manpower Training Center: PHP 500.00
n. Wine and Liquor Store: PHP 1,000.00   

ARTICLE G- Miscellaneous Provisions

SEC. 9. Display of License to Operate (Diploma) Certificate. - The License to Operate (Diploma) shall be displayed in a conspicuous area in their place of business for easy identification purposes

SEC. 10. Penal Provisions. - Failure of Tourism Enterprises to file and secure Certification/License to Operate (Diploma) from the DTCAM, the penalty of fine of not less than Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) shall be imposed. Second violation shall merit suspension of License to Operate (Diploma) with warning that repetition of the same for the third time shall mean revocation/cancellation of the License to Operate (Diploma) as may be justified under the circumstances. Said violation shall be reported and approved by the Committee on Tourism and  and Licensing Office.   

SEC. 11. Database. The DTCAM must maintain an updated database of all tourism enterprises, historical and conservatory sites, and accredited tourist guides and tour packages, and tourism centers, to provide the city government a system reference for conservation and monitoring of identified tourism sites and licensed guides and agencies. For transparency and accountability mandates, it will serve as an information hub and tracking system of the improvements needed by the licensed guides and agencies. The current status of the rehabilitation of identified tourist sites shall also be included.   

SEC. 12. Confidential Character of Certain Data. - Information and documents received by or filed with Committee on Tourism in pursuance of the requirements of the ordinance shall be treated as confidential and shall not be divulged to any private party without the consent of the party concerned when public interest so requires. Any official or employee of the DTCAM, including those that are temporarily assigned therewith who shall violate the provision of this section shall be guilty of an offense under this Ordinance and other applicable laws.   

SEC. 13. Enlistment of Aid, Assistance and Support of other Government Agencies. - In the implementation of the provisions of this Ordinance, the City Government of Manila/Committee on Tourism may enlist the aid, assistance and support of any all-government agencies, whether local or national. International assistance in forms of grants and donations are also welcome, subject to existing ordinances, policies and laws.   

SEC. 14. Registration and License Form. - The Committee on Tourism and s and Licensing Office as the case maybe, shall make available all applications for registration and/or license forms which shall be accomplished by applicants and all other forms that may be deemed necessary for the effective implementation of this Ordinance and all government agencies, whether local or national.   

SEC. 15. Implementation of Rules. - The City Mayor may, from time to time, issue rules and regulations, as she may deem fit and necessary for the effective implementation of this Ordinance.   

SEC. 16. Funding. - The funds necessary for the implementation of this Ordinance shall be taken from the Tourism Fund of the City. Succeeding funding requirements for the succeeding years shall be provided for in the Annual Budget of the City Government. Funds may also be sourced from donations, fund raising, grants and special tax revenue measures. A private-public partnership may also be explored for this venture. The Committee on Tourism shall be given additional funds under its Special Project Fund allocation, starting on calendar year 2023. The allocation will be taken from the general funds of the City and funding requirements for the succeeding years shall be provided in the annual or Supplemental Budget of the City.   

SEC. 17. Separability Clause. - The provisions of this Ordinance are separable, and in the event that any or more of such provisions are declared invalid, the validity of all the other provisions is not affected thereby.   

SEC. 18. Repealing Clause. Any ordinance, executive order or rules and regulations of local issuance which are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed and/or modified accordingly.   

SEC. 19. Effectivity. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.   

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 4, 2023.
short_text: This Ordinance imposes a Tourism Certification Fee on tourism-related establishments in Manila, requiring certification from the Committee on Tourism under the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) to ensure compliance with operational standards.  It defines key terms like "Tourism Enterprises" and "Tourism-Oriented Establishments," specifying fees for various establishments and mandates the display of the License to Operate.  The DTCAM is responsible for maintaining a database of tourism-related information.  Non-compliance results in fines, and repeated violations can lead to the suspension or revocation of operating licenses.  The ordinance includes clauses for separability and the repeal of conflicting regulations.

ORDINANCE NO. 8958

AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE JOINT METRO MANILA TRAFFIC CIRCULAR SERIES OF 2023, ESTABLISHING THE METRO MANILA TRAFFIC CODE OF 2023, EXCEPT SECTION 38 THEREOF

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Short Title. - This Ordinance shall be known as the “Metro Manila Traffic Code of 2023 in the City of Manila,” based on the Joint Metro Manila Traffic Circular of 2023 establishing the Metro Manila Traffic Code of 2023, adopted by the Metro Manila Council on February 1, 2023, which shall be made an integral part of this Ordinance as Annex “A”.

SEC. 2. Basis. - This Ordinance is enacted pursuant to Section 458 (5) (v) of Republic Act No. 7160, empowering local legislative bodies to:
•        Regulate the use of streets, avenues, alleys, sidewalks, bridges, parks, and other public places, and approve construction, improvement, repair, and maintenance of the same;
•        Establish bus and vehicle stops and terminals or regulate the use of the same by privately-owned vehicles that serve the public;
•        Regulate garages and the operation of conveyances for hire;
•        Designate stands for public vehicles when not in use;
•        Regulate the putting up of signs, signposts, awnings, and awning posts on the streets; and
•        Provide for the lighting, cleaning, and sprinkling of streets and public places.

SEC. 3. Prescription. - A traffic violation may be contested by filing a verified complaint/contest/protest with the Office of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) within ten (10) working days from:
•        The time of apprehension; or
•        The receipt via courier of the traffic citation.
After the lapse of this period, any complaint/contest/protest shall no longer be entertained, and the traffic citation shall be considered final and unappealable.

SEC. 4. Specific Exclusion. - The Traffic Adjudication Board established under Section 38 of the Metro Manila Traffic Code of 2023 is expressly excluded and shall not form part of this Ordinance.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. - If, for any reason, any part or provision of this Ordinance is held unconstitutional or invalid, the other parts or provisions not affected shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances, rules, and regulations inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby amended and/or revoked accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 2, 2023.
short_text: The City of Manila adopted the Metro Manila Traffic Code of 2023 to create uniform traffic rules across the city, based on a joint circular from Metro Manila authorities. It sets rules for traffic management, public vehicle stands, and regulation of streets and public spaces, but does not include the Traffic Adjudication Board mentioned in Section 38. People who want to contest a traffic violation must file a complaint with the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) within 10 working days, or else the violation becomes final.
fines: Fines for traffic violations as specified under the Metro Manila Traffic Code of 2023.
