ORDINANCE NO. 8948

AN ORDINANCE DECLARING THE MONTH OF JUNE EVERY YEAR AS "BALIK DISIPLINA SA SARILI MONTH" IN THE CITY OF MANILA AND DIRECTING ALL LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO CONDUCT INFORMATION DISSEMINATION DRIVES, PROMOTE, AND CONDUCT MEANINGFUL PROGRAMS FOR THE BETTERMENT OF THE CITIZENS OF THE CITY OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The month of June every year serves as the most auspicious time to celebrate our identity as proud citizens of this country, in connection with the celebration of "Araw ng Kalayaan" on June 12 and the founding anniversary of the City of Manila, more known as "Araw ng Maynila" on June 24. Such celebrations remind us of our proud history as law-abiding citizens in one of the oldest cities in the country.

 The significance of Independence Day and Manila's Foundation Day lies in the struggles and sacrifices of strong Filipinos and martyrs who fought for the country's freedom and independence of this proud country
.
Such heroes and ancestors demonstrated the ability to focus on shared goals, push forward despite hardships, stay motivated, and act with determination.

Today’s fast-paced, social media-driven lifestyles of Millennials (born 1981–1996) and Generation Z (born 1997–2012) have somewhat dulled the sense of compassion for fellow countrymen, love for country, and the value of hard work, sacrifice, and, above all else, self-discipline.
Self-discipline is vital in every sector of society. It is reflected in: (a) Obeying traffic rules, (b) Paying correct taxes, (c) Taking care of the environment and natural resources, (d) Promoting a healthy lifestyle, and (e) Studying diligently.

This Ordinance seeks to remind Manileños of the importance of observing self-discipline to collectively uplift the quality of life in the city and ensure the sacrifices of past generations are not forgotten.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Balik Disiplina sa Sarili Month. —  The month of June every year is hereby declared as "BALIK DISIPLINA SA SARILI MONTH" in the City of Manila.

SECTION 2. Observance. — The City Government of Manila, in coordination with concerned local government agencies, offices, and departments, shall plan and conduct appropriate ceremonies, programs, and activities in observance of Balik Disiplina sa Sarili Month.
The program shall include:
•        (a) Regular weekly clean-up drives in each respective barangay;
•        (b) Random inspection of public utility vehicles (PUVs);
•        (c) Enforcement of city ordinances on basic health and hygiene;
•        (d) School values education seminars;
•        (e) Nutritional feeding programs;
•        (f) Physical fitness and healthy lifestyle programs;
•        (g) Proper pedestrian and PUV passenger etiquette;
•        (h) Other similar activities that are inclusive for women, children, youth, senior citizens, PWDs, heads of families, workers, and entrepreneurs.

SECTION 3. Separability Clause. —  If any provision, section, or part of this Ordinance is suspended, revoked, or declared null and void by a competent authority or the Supreme Court, all other provisions, sections, or parts not affected shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 4. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, rulings, and issuances contrary to or inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 18, 2023.
short_text: Manila has officially declared June of every year as "Balik Disiplina sa Sarili Month," encouraging citizens to practice self-discipline through activities like clean-up drives, health programs, and educational seminars. All local government offices are instructed to organize events that promote good habits and responsible citizenship during this month. The ordinance highlights the importance of remembering our heroes' sacrifices by living disciplined and productive lives today.

short_text:
This ordinance updates and expands Manila’s child welfare code to better respond to modern challenges and uphold children’s rights as guaranteed by the Constitution and various national laws. It affirms children's rights to survival, development, protection, and participation, regardless of their background or legal status. Key updates include:

Mandatory child registration at birth, access to free health services (including maternal and neonatal care), and implementation of child-focused nutrition programs such as iodized salt use and food fortification.

Institutional support for child victims of abuse, requiring all city-owned hospitals to have trained personnel to handle abuse cases.

Adolescent sexual and reproductive health programs to prevent early pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases, aligned with RA 10354 and RA 11166.

Improved sanitation and hygiene facilities (WaSH) in schools and barangays to ensure children's right to a healthy environment.

Strict regulation of food vendors near schools to protect children from unsafe and unhealthy food.

Inclusive city planning, requiring development plans, programs, and monitoring systems that involve children and civil society to ensure community-based solutions.

Establishment of the Child Friendly Movement (CFM) to promote child rights at every level—from family to government.

The ordinance also outlines the responsibilities of children to uphold good values, obey laws, respect elders, and contribute to nation-building.

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 1 FOR THE VARIOUS REQUIREMENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA UNDER PERSONAL SERVICES, MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES AND CAPITAL OUTLAY IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVENTY-FOUR MILLION ONE HUNDRED NINE THOUSAND FIFTY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP 74,109,057.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.) No. 7160 or the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991 provides that every local government unit (LGU) shall exercise the powers that are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other things, promote health and safety, enhancement of economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, and preserve the comfort and convenience of its inhabitants.
Further, Section 17 of the LGC mandates LGUs to exercise such powers and discharge such functions and responsibilities for the efficient and effective provisions of basic services and facilities which includes, among others, roads, buildings and similar facilities to service the needs of its residents.
To fund urgent expenses and projects of the city, a supplemental budget may be enacted when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources (Section 321 of R.A. No. 7160).
The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds as supporting document to the promulgation of a Supplemental Budget.
The City Council likewise approved Resolution No. 1, Series of 2023 of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2023 FOR THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA UNDER PERSONAL SERVICES, MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES AND CAPITAL OUTLAY IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVENTY-FOUR MILLION ONE HUNDRED NINE THOUSAND FIFTY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP. 74,109,057.00).”

ORDINANCE NO. 8935

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE REVERSION TO THE GENERAL FUND OF
THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVENTY-FOUR MILLION ONE HUNDRED NINE
THOUSAND FIFTY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP 74,109,057.00) UNDER PERSONAL
SERVICES, MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES AND CAPITAL
OUTLAY FOR FY 2023 AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160 otherwise known as the Local Government
Code of 1991 categorically provides:

“Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances
of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. —
Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the
annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the
unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the
fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure
except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations
for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully
spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of
continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless
obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be
reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation and the
sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation
of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer
needed in connection with the activities funded by said
continuing appropriations subject to the provisions of this
Section.”

Particular amounts were appropriated for the expenses of the various Offices of
the City of Manila under the Personal Services (PS), Maintenance and Other Operating
Expenses (MOOE) and Capital Outlay (CO) of the FY 2023 Annual Budget. However,
funds under said appropriations are determined to be free from any obligation or
encumbrance and still available to be utilized as source of fund.

For Fiscal Year 2023, there are necessary expenses which need urgent funding
through a Supplemental Budget.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Reversion. — The following funds under the FY 2023 Personal
Services, Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses and Capital Outlay Appropriations
are hereby reverted to the General Fund, to wit:

Other Infrastructure Assets        ₱50,000,000.00

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 21, 2023.
short_text: The City of Manila passed Ordinance No. 8935 to return PhP74,109,057 from unused 2023 funds back to the General Fund. full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8933

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING A WOMEN AND CHILDREN CRISIS CENTER FOR THE VICTIMS/SURVIVORS OF VIOLENCE AND ABUSE IN THE CITY OF MANILA, ADOPTING A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM THEREFOR, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Cases of violence against women and children in the country are increasing every year. Based on the data from the Philippine National Police (PNP), a total of 6,383 violence against women cases were reported to the PNP Women and Children Protection Center, while 9,677 cases of violence against children were tallied in the past seven months of 2022.

In Manila, 585 Anti-Violence Against Women and Children (VAWC) cases were recorded in the years 2020 and 2021 by the Manila Police District (MPD).

All forms of gender-based abuse and violence must be eradicated since they are inconsistent with people's inherent worth and dignity. Gender-based violence is a symptom of sexism that perpetuates human rights abuses, including putting people's lives and health in jeopardy. Women, children, and other genders who are victims of gender-based violence require specific protection and care, including adequate medical, psychological, and legal safeguards against all forms of abuse.

Section 40 of Republic Act No. 9262, or otherwise known as the Anti-Violence Against Women and Children (VAWC) Act, states the government must provide temporary shelters, counseling, psycho-social services and/or recovery, rehabilitation programs, and livelihood assistance.

Section 2 of Republic Act No. 7610, or the Special Protection of Children Against Abuse, Exploitation and Discrimination Act, mandates the rehabilitation of children gravely threatened or endangered by circumstances which affect or will affect their survival and normal development, and over which they have no control. Section 3 of Republic Act No. 8505, or the Rape Victim Assistance and Protection Act, commands the establishment in every province and city of a Rape Crisis Center located in a government hospital, health clinic, or any suitable place that will provide psychological counseling, medical and health services with medico-legal examination, free legal assistance, privacy and safety for victims, and other related laws.

Section 2 of Republic Act No. 8353, or the Anti-Rape Law of 1997, cites the possibility of Human Immuno-Deficiency Virus (HIV)/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) or any other sexually transmissible diseases and viruses being transmitted to the victim, and the need for a medical examination to be carried out in a private examination room.

Section 30 of Republic Act No. 9710, otherwise known as the Magna Carta of Women: Women in Especially Difficult Circumstances – For purposes of this Act, "Women in Especially Difficult Circumstances" (WEDC) shall refer to victims and survivors of sexual and physical abuse, illegal recruitment, prostitution, trafficking, armed conflict, women in detention, victims and survivors of rape and incest, and such other related circumstances which have incapacitated them functionally. Local government units are therefore mandated to deliver the necessary services and interventions to WEDC under their respective jurisdictions.

Section 31 of Republic Act No. 9710, or the Magna Carta of Women: Services and Interventions – WEDC shall be provided with services and interventions as necessary, such as, but not limited to, the following:

(a) Temporary and protective custody;
(b) Medical and dental services;
(c) Psychological evaluation;
(d) Counseling;
(e) Psychiatric evaluation;
(f) Legal services; and
(g) Productivity skills capability building.


Section 9.7 of City Ordinance 8681 or the Manila Gender and Development Code – Creation of Women and Children Crisis Center, the City Government shall create Women and Children Crisis Centers in the key districts of Manila under the supervision of the Manila Department of Social Welfare. This center will provide services to gender-based violence victims, prostituted women, and other genders victim of abuse. A 24-hr hotline for VAWC victims will be created that will be working closely with the Manila Police District Women’s Desk. This will also serve as a temporary shelter for the VAWG victims in their respective districts.

It is in this view that the immediate passage of this draft ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. – This Ordinance shall be known as the “Women and Children Crisis Center for Victims and Survivors of Violence and Abuse in the City of Manila.”

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. – The City is hereby required to protect everyone's dignity, uphold all human rights, and ensure that everyone is treated equally in all material respects. In order to protect victims and survivors of gender-based violence and other types of violence, the Local Government must establish programs and infrastructures. These services must include counseling, medico-legal, legal, psychological, and after-care supports such as livelihood assistance, and they must take a holistic and all-encompassing family approach to case management.

Through community/school advocacy and networking, the Local Government must also lessen and prevent the occurrence of violence against women, children, lesbians, gays, bisexuals, transgender people, intersex people, and queers. The Local Government shall adopt and pursue an integrated system of policy direction, implementation, and enforcement of anti-gender-based violence policies, programs, and activities in order to achieve this purpose.

SEC. 3. Definition of Terms. – As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall be construed to mean as follows:

a. Child – refers to a person below eighteen (18) years of age or over but is unable to fully take care of himself/herself or protect himself/herself from abuse, neglect, cruelty, exploitation or discrimination because of a physical or mental disability or condition.

b. Child Abuse – refers to a child’s abuse, whether it is routine or not, which includes any of the following:

1. Abuse of any kind, whether mental or physical, including neglect, sexual abuse, and emotional maltreatment;

2. Any behavior – words or deeds – that diminishes a child’s inherent value and dignity as a human being;

3. He/she was being deprived of his/her fundamental needs, such as food and shelter, in an unreasonable manner; and

4. Failure to immediately give medical treatment to an injured child resulting in serious impairment of his/her growth and development or in his/her permanent incapacity or death (Section 3, Republic Act No. 7610).

c. Violence Against Women – refers to violence that targets a woman because she is a woman or that disproportionately affects women. It includes acts that cause physical, mental, or sexual harm and suffering, threats of such acts, coercion, and other deprivations of liberty, as well as discrimination and other violations of women's fundamental rights and freedoms protected by general international law or human rights conventions.

d. Prostitution – refers to any act, transaction, scheme, or design involving the use of a person by another for sexual intercourse or lascivious conduct in exchange for money, profit, or any other consideration.

e. Trafficking in Women – refers to a covert or overt recruitment of women into the sex trade industry. It includes new forms of sexual exploitation such as sex tourism, the illegal recruitment for domestic labor to work in developed countries, and organized marriages between women from third world countries and foreign nationals, promoting or initiating a system in which women become movable properties and objects of exchange.

f. Domestic Violence – also called intimate partner violence – occurs between people in an intimate relationship. Domestic violence takes many forms, including emotional, sexual, and physical abuse and threats of abuse. Abuse by a partner can happen to anyone, but domestic violence is most often directed toward women.

g. Physical Abuse and Battering – this includes any form of inflicting wounds, pain, etc. on any part of the woman’s body or the threat of physical violence.

h. Economic Abuse – this includes deprivation of women of economic resources, their generation and mobilization so as to create dependency and submissiveness to men and to any established structures of domination, such as controlling over women’s hard-earned money and using them for his vices, etc.

i. Psychological Abuse – this includes threats of suicide, violence against women or her family, punching, breaking or defacing or otherwise destroying the house or any part thereof, or of personal belongings of a woman; threatening to take the children away; threatening deportation of wives with foreign citizenship; threatening to kidnap children or to take them to a foreign country; and forcing the victim to do degrading things. It includes controlling the victim’s lawful or usual activities, the use of foul and insulting words or statements, and threats of abandonment and expulsion such as forcing the wives to leave the conjugal dwelling. This provision shall apply to any form of intimate relations such as common-law relations, those between and among members of the same household, and include men’s control over women’s resources (e.g., income, property, etc.).

j. Gender – refers to a socially constructed difference between men and women for all sexual orientations and gender identities, created artificially, partly through socialization and partly through positive and negative discrimination in the various institutions and structures of society.

k. Gender-Based Violence – shall be understood to encompass, but not be limited to, the following:

1. Family violence includes physical, sexual, psychological, and financial abuse of women and girls, including dowry-related violence, marital rape, and other detrimental customs. It also includes non-spousal violence associated with exploitation; and

2. Violence against people in the broad public, including rape, sexual assault, harassment, and intimidation at work, in educational settings, and elsewhere, as well as prostitution and human trafficking.

I. Violence Against Children – All sorts of sexual abuse, as well as physical or mental abuse, neglect, as well as mistreatment or negligence. Intentional use of physical force or authority, whether threatened or used, against a child by an individual or group that has a significant likelihood of harming the child's health, welfare, development, or dignity is also included in this definition.

m. Violence Against Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals, Transgenders, Intersexuals, and Queers (LGBTQ) – Violence against LGBTQ people includes acts that cause them physical, mental, or sexual harm and suffering, threats of such acts, coercion, and other restrictions on their freedom. It also includes harassment, exclusion, stigmatization, and violence against them due to their sexual orientation or gender identity.

SEC. 4. Manila Women and Children Crisis Center: Providing Emergency Response and Temporary Shelter for VAWC Victims and Other Gender Victims of Gender-Based Violence. – The center aims to rebuild the lives of women, girls, children, and other genders in crisis. Its mission is to provide temporary shelter and rehabilitation assistance to women and girls in the hope of nurturing and developing them into self-sufficient and self-fulfilled individuals.

I. The Center shall provide the following, as may be appropriate:

a. A temporary halfway house for victims of gender-based violence — women, girls, children, and other genders;
b. An emergency response action unit to immediately rescue and assist victims of gender-based violence;
c. Comprehensive intervention and protection services, including medical and police support, medico-legal, legal, and psychological services to abused victims and their families;
d. Safeguard the victim's and survivor's security and safety;
e. Help victims and survivors with referrals to shelters;
f. Providing case management for offenders' rehabilitation and referral services for those who commit acts of violence, abuse, and exploitation;
g. Act as a clearinghouse for data on gender-based abuse and violence in the City of Manila;
h. Psychological interventions are also provided through regular counseling, music therapy, and sessions on anger management. If necessary, recommendations are given to seek professional help from psychologists/psychiatrists;
i. Health services are provided such as regular medical and dental check-up and laboratory tests, as well as special dietary care when necessary;
j. Training on daily living skills, personality development/self-enhancement skills. Life skills lessons in cooking, washing, and in maintaining the upkeep and cleanliness of the center will be provided; and
k. Livelihood and job training services are also available for them to be productive. Simple food preparation, baking, soap, candles, chocolate/candy making, and rosary making are some of the livelihood training services.

II. The Center shall have the following facilities:

a. Reception area;
b. Counseling/psychotherapy room;
c. Medical/examination room;
d. Interview investigation room (with one-way mirror, audio recorder, etc.);
e. Record/database room;
f. Nursery/infirmary room;
g. Kitchen and dining room;
h. Sleeping quarters;
i. Case management conference room; and
j. Activity corner.

SEC. 5. The Manila Department of Social Welfare. – The center shall be under the management and supervision of the Manila Department of Social Welfare.

SEC. 6. Manila City VAWC and the Gender-Based Violence Referral Pathway. – It is a flexible mechanism that safely links survivors to supportive and competent services in a timely way and includes any or all of the following: Health, psychosocial, security and protection, legal justice, and/or economic reintegration support.

GBV/VAWC Victim Pathway:

Step 1: Report to Barangay VAWC Desk Officer / Police Women’s Desk Officer / Manila Women and Children Crisis Center

a. Rescue operation

b. Interview, incident report, sworn statement

Step 2: Undergo medical check-up for medico-legal case
Step 3: Psychosocial assessment
Step 4: File legal action against the perpetrator
Step 5: Counseling / Continue psychosocial therapy / Rehabilitation

SEC. 7. COUNSELING.

1. Counseling should receive training in identifying the typical mental health problems that victims of violence experience;

2. When providing care for someone healing from an incident of rape or sexual abuse, counselors must have a compassionate attitude and a non-judgmental manner; and

3. Pre- and post-test counseling are provided for medical tests for RTIs, STIs, unintended pregnancy, and HIV/AIDS. Regardless of the outcome, counseling should be provided after an HIV test if one is conducted. Counselors must recommend patients to medical and psychological services if their test results are positive.

SEC. 8. Duty of the Police Officer. – A full-time police officer who is qualified to handle delicate situations will be assigned to the center and will investigate complaints.

When the police receive the complaints, the role of the police officer is to:

1. If the defendant is being held, the matter should be sent to the prosecutor right away for an investigation; otherwise, the court's regulations will be in effect;

2. Make plans for the offended party to receive counseling and medical care; and

3. Report on the action right away.

The police officer's responsibility is to make sure that nobody else enters the room where the investigation is taking place unless they have received the offended party's express permission.

SEC. 9. Protocol on Medical Provision and Standard Medico-Legal Examination and Report. – A plan for medical care, counseling, the prevention and management of RTIs, STIs, unintended pregnancies, HIV/AIDS transmission, including mother-to-child transmission for rape victims will be advised.

SEC. 10. Forensic Medico-Legal Kits. – If the patient agrees, forensic medico-legal kits with the appropriate labels will be made available at the center where blood, urine, nail scrapings, and pubic hair samples will be gathered and sent for the correct DNA analysis.

SEC. 11. Legal Assistance. – The growth and support of a legal network that focuses on cases of gender-based abuse and violence is required.

SEC. 12. Centralized Database on Gender-Based Violence Cases. – The center is responsible for making sure that all cases of gender-based abuse and violence, even those reported to the center solely for monitoring and reporting reasons, are correctly registered and documented in the barangays of the City of Manila.

SEC. 13. Confidentiality. – All documents, including those kept in the barangays, must be kept private, and all public officials, employees, and medical facilities, whether public or private, are required to respect the victim's rights to privacy. Without the victim's or member's consent, anybody who publishes or causes to be published in any format the victim's name, address, phone number, school, business address, employer, or any other identifying information is subject to the court's contempt powers.

SEC. 14. Funding. – Budget allocations must cover the center's expenses for Personal Services (PS), Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE), and Property, Plant, and Equipment (PPE) and shall be charged against the existing accounts under the Manila Department of Social Welfare.

SEC. 15. Separability Clause. – If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 16. Repealing Clause. – All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 17. Effectivity Clause. – This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in at least two newspapers of local circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 7, 2023.
short_text: It establishes the Women and Children Crisis Center in Manila to support victims of violence and abuse, including women, children, and members of the LGBTQ+ community. The center offers temporary shelter, medical and psychological care, legal help, and livelihood training. It also sets up procedures for reporting abuse, receiving medical exams, undergoing counseling, and filing legal cases. Confidentiality is strictly enforced, and a centralized database will track all reported gender-based violence in the city. The Manila Department of Social Welfare will oversee the center’s operations and services.

ORDINANCE NO. 8932

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8331, ALSO
KNOWN AS THE “2013 OMNIBUS REVENUE CODE OF THE CITY OF MANILA”
SPECIFICALLY SECTION 151 (C) OF CHAPTER V CITY CHARGES, ARTICLE G
PUBLIC RECREATION CHARGES BY INCLUDING THEREIN PARKING FEES OF
LARGE VEHICLES AND INCLUDING THEREIN, THE MODIFICATION OF FEES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

This Ordinance seeks to amend Section 151 (C) of Chapter V City Charges,
Article G Public Recreation Charges of the 2013 Omnibus Revenue Code of the City of
Manila by including therein parking fees of large vehicles and including therein the
alteration of fees.

Wherefore, to generate additional funds for the development projects of the city
government since the Public Recreation Bureau is being categorized as an “Income
Generating Office” of the City of Manila.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 151 (C) Chapter V City Charges, Article G Parking fees in
Manila Zoo of Ordinance No. 8331 or the 2013 Omnibus Revenue Code of the City of
Manila, is hereby further amended and shall now read as follows:

“C. PARKING FEES – There shall be charged, assessed, and collected
to owners and drivers of motor vehicles using and utilizing City
pay parking fees at rates provided hereunder:

a. Motorcycles (E-motorcycles):
PhP 30.00 for the first 3 hours
and PhP 15.00 every hour
thereafter

b. Light Vehicles (Pedicabs, tricycles, and three-wheeled vehicles):
PhP 40.00 for the first 3 hours
and PhP 20.00 every hour
thereafter

c. Medium Vehicles (cars, jeepneys, AUVs, SUVs, Mini Vans and E-jeepneys):
PhP 60.00 for the first 3 hours
and PhP 25.00 every hour
thereafter

d. Large Vehicles (e-bus, vans, delivery trucks, co-wheelers and 8-wheeler trucks):
PhP 120.00 for the first 3 hours
and PhP 30.00 every hour
thereafter

e. Heavy Vehicles (Bus):
PhP 180.00 for the first 3 hours
and PhP 35.00 every hour
thereafter”

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain
in full force and effect.

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are
hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
January 12, 2023.
short_text: updates the parking fees at Manila Zoo by adding charges for large and heavy vehicles like delivery trucks and buses. This amendment aims to help the city generate more income from public recreation facilities. New fees are now in place based on the size and type of vehicle, ranging from motorcycles to heavy buses, with rates increasing after the first three hours of parking.

ORDINANCE NO. 8931

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF GRATUITY PAY TO
CONTRACT OF SERVICE AND JOB ORDER WORKERS IN THE CITY
GOVERNMENT OF MANILA PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 3,
SERIES 2022, AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF
FORTY-EIGHT MILLION THREE HUNDRED THIRTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 48,335,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

On December 23, 2022, President Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr. issued Administrative
Order (A.O.) No. 3, Series of 2022, entitled “Authorizing the Grant of Gratuity Pay to
Contract of Service and Job Order Workers in the Government for Fiscal Year 2022."
A.O. No. 3 stated that while Contract of Service (COS) and Job Order (JO) workers
in the government are paid salaries/wages equivalent to those received by personnel
occupying comparable positions in government and a premium of up to 20% of such salary/wage, they do not enjoy benefits accorded to government employees as they have
no employer-employee relationship with the government. 

It further provided that granting a year-end Gratuity Pay to COS and JO workers is a well-deserved recognition of their hard work in implementing programs, projects and activities, and pivotal role in the delivery of government services amidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and present socio-economic challenges.

Section 5 of A.O. No. 3 mandated that local government units (LGUs) are enjoined
to adopt in their respective offices the grant of Gratuity Pay to workers whose services
are engaged through COS and JO, utilizing appropriate and available funding sources
from their respective local government funds. The corresponding supplemental budget
for the purpose shall be enacted by the local sanggunian concerned within FY 2022.

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991
provides that the LGUs shall exercise the powers that are essential to the promotion of
the general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other things, the enhancement of
economic prosperity, full employment, and social justice, and preserve the comfort and
convenience of its inhabitants.

The Local Legislative Body approved Resolution No. 16, adopted by the
Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled “A Resolution
Approving the Amendment of the Annual Investment Program and the Issuance of a
Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2022 for the Grant of Gratuity Pay to Contract
of Service and Job Order Workers in the City Government of Manila for FY 2022
Pursuant to Administrative Order No. 3, Series 2022."

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Gratuity Pay. — The grant of the one-time Gratuity Pay for FY 2022
not exceeding Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 5,000.00) to job order and contract of service
personnel in the City Government of Manila is hereby authorized subject to the conditions
under Administrative Order No. 3, s. 2022.

SEC. 2. Fund Source. — The Gratuity Pay in the total amount of Forty-Eight Million
Three Hundred Thirty-Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 48,335,000.00), shall be funded by
the Special Activities Fund — Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (SAF-MOOE)
from savings from the following Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE)
accounts under the FY 2022 Annual Appropriations Ordinance, to wit:
Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses
A. Office of the Vice-Mayor
- Traveling Expenses-Local: PHP. 345,000.00

B. Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod
- Representation Expenses: PHP. 6,020,000.00

C. Department of Social Welfare
- Donations: PHP. 41,970,000.00

Total PHP.: 48,335,000.00

Attached are the following details:

Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS for Augmentation of Funds; and
Annex B — Budgetary Requirement for Gratuity Pay under the SAF-MOOE.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

On the motion presented by the Honorable Joel “JTV" Villanueva, which was duly
seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final
reading by the City Council of Manila on December 27, 2022.
short_text: It allows the Manila city government to give a one-time gratuity pay of up to PhP5,000 to its contract of service (COS) and job order (JO) workers for their contributions in 2022. This is in line with Administrative Order No. 3 issued by the President, recognizing the role of these workers despite not having regular government employee benefits. The total budget allocated for this is PhP48,335,000, sourced from savings in the city’s 2022 budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 8930

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 6 FOR THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE VARIOUS IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SIXTY-SEVEN MILLION FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 67,500,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.) No. 7160 or the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991 provides that every local government unit shall exercise the powers that are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other things, the health and safety of its constituents, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, and preserve the comfort and convenience of its inhabitants.
Further, Section 17 of the LGC of 1991 mandates local government units to exercise such powers and discharge such functions and responsibilities for the efficient and effective provisions of basic services and facilities, which include, among others, services and facilities related to general hygiene and sanitation, maintenance of roads, drainage and sewerage systems, and other infrastructure facilities to service the needs of the residents.
To fund urgent and priority projects of the City, a supplemental budget may be enacted when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources (Section 321 of R.A. No. 7160).
The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds as supporting document to the promulgation of a Supplemental Budget.
The City Council likewise approved Resolution No. 15, Series of 2022, of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2022 FOR THE VARIOUS IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SIXTY-SEVEN MILLION FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 67,500,000.00).”

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The FY 2022 Supplemental Budget of the City of Manila in the total amount of Sixty-Seven Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP 67,500,000.00) is hereby appropriated to fund the following projects of the City of Manila, to wit:

20% City Development Fund (CDF)        Road Networks        a. Construction of Lined Canal and Upgrading of Various Alleys at Barangay 276, Zone 25 – ₱3,282,000 
b. Upgrading, Concreting and Improvement of Ramirez St. from Barcelona to Madrid Streets – ₱43,350,000        ₱46,632,000.00
        Sewer Systems        Additional works for Waste Water Treatment Plant at Veterinary Inspection        ₱2,270,000.00
        Parks, Plazas, and Monuments        Enhancement of Periphery Parks of Manila City Hall        ₱1,260,000.00 ← (Corrected line item)
        Other Structures        Additional Works for Repair and Rehabilitation of Tondo Sports Complex        ₱1,338,000.00
TOTAL: ₱67,500,000.00

Attached are the following details:
•        LBP Form No. 8 marked as “Annex A” — Statement of Funding Source as Certified by the City Treasurer and City Accountant; and
•        LBP Form No. 9 marked “Annex B” — Statement of Supplemental Appropriation.

SECTION 2. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On the motion presented by the Honorable Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on December 20, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes Supplemental Budget No. 6 amounting to ₱67,500,000.00 to fund various infrastructure improvement projects in Manila. These include upgrades to Manila City Hall offices, construction of lined canals, road and drainage improvements, enhancement of parks, wastewater treatment works, and rehabilitation of the Tondo Sports Complex. The budget is supported by certified available funds and an approved supplemental investment program.

ORDINANCE NO. 8929

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE REVERSION TO THE GENERAL FUND OF
THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SIXTY-SEVEN MILLION FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND
PESOS (PHP 67,500,000.00) UNDER CAPITAL OUTLAY FOR FY 2022 AND FOR
OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160 otherwise known as the Local Government
Code of 1991 categorically provides:

“Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances of
Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. — Unexpended balances of
appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall
revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the
fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except
by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays
shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is
completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed
unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of
the annual budget preparation and the sanggunian concerned may approve,
upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no
longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing
appropriations subject to the provisions of this Section.”

Particular amounts were appropriated for certain projects under the Capital Outlay
(CO) for FY 2022 Annual Budget. However, due to changing circumstances, it was
determined that said projects are no longer necessary.

For Fiscal Year 2022, there are priority projects which need urgent funding through
a Supplemental Budget.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Reversion. — The following funds under the FY 2022 Capital Outlay
Appropriations are hereby reverted to the General Fund, to wit:

Reversion of Appropriations

Other Structures

Grand Total: ₱67,500,000.00

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its
approval.

On the motion presented by the Honorable Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly
seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final
reading by the City Council of Manila on December 20, 2022.
short_text: The City of Manila passed an ordinance authorizing the reversion of PhP67,500,000 from unused Capital Outlay appropriations for fiscal year 2022 back to the General Fund. This reversion follows Section 322 of the Local Government Code, which allows the reallocation of unexpended balances when projects are deemed no longer necessary. The funds will be made available for other urgent priority projects through a Supplemental Budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 8928

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF THE SERVICE RECOGNITION INCENTIVE FOR QUALIFIED GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 2022, PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 1, SERIES 2022, AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE AMOUNT OF NINETY MILLION FOUR HUNDRED FIFTY THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 90,450,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
On December 16, 2022, President Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr., issued Administrative Order (AO) No. 1, authorizing the grant of a one-time Service Recognition Incentive (SRI) for each qualified government employee for FY 2022.

AO No. 1 states that “the administration recognizes all government employees for their collective and invaluable contribution to the government’s continuing efforts to ensure responsive delivery of services to the public, especially in the midst of the continuing public health emergency due to the COVID-19 pandemic and other socio-economic challenges.”

Section 6 of AO No. 1 provides for the grant of SRIs to employees in Local Government Units (LGUs) as follows:

“a. The grant of one-time SRI to employees in LGUs, including those in the barangays, shall be determined by their respective sanggunians depending on the LGU’s financial capability, subject to the PS Limitation in LGU budgets under RA No. 7160 or the “Local Government Code of 1991,” and the conditions set forth in Section 2 hereof, at a uniform rate not exceeding Twenty Thousand Pesos (P20,000.00), chargeable against their respective FY 2022 local government funds. Should the identified funding source prove insufficient to cover the full amount of the SRI, a lower but uniform amount shall be paid to all qualified employees of the LGU; and

b. In determining the amount of SRI, the sanggunians shall exercise prudence and judicious use of government funds, ensuring that the expenditure is reasonable and will not, in any way, prejudice the delivery of services to the public.

The corresponding supplemental budget for the purpose shall be enacted by the local sanggunian concerned within FY 2022.”

On December 20, 2022, the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) issued Budget Circular No. 2022-4 for the guidelines on the grant of SRI to government employees for FY 2022.

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds as a supporting document to support this Ordinance.

Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.) No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991 (LGC), states that: “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local governments shall ensure and support the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”

Section 336 of R.A. No. 7160 or the LGC of 1991 mandates that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing the transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.


Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Service Recognition Incentive. — The grant of one-time Service Recognition Incentive (SRI) for FY 2022 not exceeding Ten Thousand Pesos (PhP 10,000.00) to qualified government employees is hereby authorized subject to the conditions under Administrative Order No. 1, s. 2022 and Budget Circular No. 2022-4 of the Department of Budget and Management.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. — The SRI in the total amount of Ninety Million Four Hundred Fifty Thousand Pesos (PhP 90,450,000.00), shall be funded by augmenting the Special Activities Fund–Personal Services (SAF-PS) Account from savings from the following Personal Services accounts under the FY 2022 Annual Appropriations Ordinance:

Personal Services
A. Office of the Vice-Mayor
Overtime and Night Pay – P 220,000.00

B. Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod
Salaries and Wages–Regular – P 573,536.00
Personnel Economic Relief Allowance (PERA) – P 120,000.00
Retirement and Life Insurance Premiums – P 187,024.00
PAG-IBIG Contributions – P 6,000.00
PHILHEALTH Contributions – P 29,485.00
Employees Compensation Insurance Premiums – P 6,000.00
Year-End Bonus – P 371,822.00

C. Special Purpose Appropriations
Terminal Leave Benefits – 71,596,431.00
Retirement Gratuity – 17,339,702.00

Total: P 90,450,000.00

Attached are the following details:
Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS for Augmentation of Funds;
Annex B — Budgetary Requirement for SRI under the SAF-PS.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On the motion presented by the Honorable Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on December 20, 2022.
short_text: The City of Manila passed an ordinance allowing a one-time Service Recognition Incentive (SRI) of up to PhP10,000 for qualified government employees for fiscal year 2022, in line with Administrative Order No. 1, series of 2022. The city allocated PhP90,450,000 from savings in other budget items to fund this incentive without affecting public service delivery. The ordinance follows the guidelines set by the Department of Budget and Management and the Local Government Code, ensuring funds are used correctly and legally. It was approved by the City Council on December 20, 2022 and takes effect immediately.

ORDINANCE NO. 8927

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF THE PRODUCTIVITY
ENHANCEMENT INCENTIVE OF THE EMPLOYEES OF THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF
MANILA AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE AMOUNT OF FORTY-FIVE
MILLION TWO HUNDRED TWENTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 45,225,000.00)
FROM PERSONAL SERVICES SAVINGS AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Executive Order No. (E.O.) 201, s. 2016, entitled: “Modifying the Salary Schedule
of Civilian Government Personnel and Authorizing the Grant of Additional Benefits for
both Civilian and Military and Uniformed Personnel”, mandates the grant of Productivity
Enhancement Incentive (PEI) to national and local government employees.

As provided by E.O. 201, the PEI is meant to improve the productivity of
government workers. It is granted to government workers, alongside the upward
adjustment of the salary schedule in the bureaucracy.

Budget Circular No. 2017-4 issued by the Department of Budget and Management
(DBM), outlines the guidelines on the grant of PEI to government personnel.

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of
Availability of Funds as supporting document as to the funding of this Ordinance.

Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991
states that: “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted,
those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or
incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and
enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a
balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant
scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic
prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain
peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”

Section 336 of the LGC states that funds shall be available exclusively for the
specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed
authorizing the transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local
chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance,
be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective
offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective
appropriations.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Productivity Enhancement Incentive. — The PEI shall be granted
to the regular, casual, and contractual employees of the City Government of Manila for
the Fiscal Year 2022 pursuant to E.O. 201, s. 2016 and DBM Budget Circular No. 2017-4
dated December 4, 2017.

SEC. 2. Augmentation. — The Special Activities Fund – Personal Services (SAF-
PS) of the FY 2022 Executive Budget shall be augmented for the grant of PEI in the total
amount of Forty-Five Million Two Hundred Twenty-Five Thousand Pesos
(PHP 45,225,000.00).

SEC. 3. Savings. — The funds to augment the SAF-PS for the grant of PEI shall
be sourced from the following savings from the FY 2022 Annual Appropriations, to wit:

Personal Services
A. Office of the Vice-Mayor
- Overtime ang Night Pay: PHP 110,000.00

B. Office of the Sangguiang Panlungsod
- Salaries and Wages-Regular: PHP 985,000.00
- Overtime and Night Pay: PHP 1,000,000.00
- Terminal Leave Benefits: PHP 1,200,000.00

C. Special Purpose Appropriations
- Terminal Leave Benefits: PHP 41,930,000.00

Total: PHP 45,225,000.00

Attached are the following details:

Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS for Augmentation of Funds;
Annex B — Budgetary Requirement for Productivity Enhancement Incentive
Under the SAF-PS.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its
approval.

On the motion presented by the Honorable Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., which was duly
seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final
reading by the City Council of Manila on December 15, 2022.
short_text: This allows the City Government of Manila to give a Productivity Enhancement Incentive (PEI) to its regular, casual, and contractual employees for 2022. This incentive follows national guidelines to boost worker morale and performance. The total amount of  PhP45,225,000 will be sourced from unused funds under the city’s 2022 budget, specifically from salary-related savings.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8926

AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND RECOGNIZING THE 442 CULTURAL
PROPERTIES IN THE CITY OF MANILA PREPARED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF
TOURISM, CULTURE AND ARTS OF MANILA IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE
REQUIREMENT OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR AND LOCAL
GOVERNMENT FOR THE SEAL OF GOOD LOCAL GOVERNANCE

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The State shall foster the preservation, enrichment, and dynamic evolution of a
Filipino culture based on the principle of unity in diversity in a climate of free artistic and intellectual expression. The Constitution likewise mandates the State to conserve, develop, promote, and popularize the nation’s historical and cultural heritage and resources, as well as artistic creations. It further provides that all the country’s artistic and historic wealth constitutes the cultural treasure of the nation and shall be under the protection of the State, which may regulate its disposition. In the pursuit of cultural preservation as a strategy for maintaining Filipino identity, the State shall pursue the objective to protect, preserve, conserve, and promote the nation’s cultural heritage, its property and histories, and the ethnicity of local communities.

The National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), as part of its mandate
is requiring each local government unit, through their cultural offices, to maintain an
inventory of cultural properties under its jurisdiction and shall furnish the NCCA a copy of the same. Cultural agencies and local government units concerned shall continuously
coordinate in making entries and in monitoring the various cultural properties in their
respective inventory.

The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) has been
submitting lists of cultural properties to the NCCA and for this year, has chosen 442
cultural properties which is a requirement for the Seal of Good Local Governance, to be
adopted and recognized as the City of Manila’s inventory of Cultural Properties, hence,
this Ordinance.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The list of local cultural properties prepared by the Department of
Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM), submitted to the National Commission for
Culture and the Arts (NCCA) for inclusion in the Philippine Registry of Cultural Property
(PRECUP), is hereby adopted and recognized as the City of Manila’s official inventory
consisting of 442 cultural properties.

SEC. 2. The list shall be supplemented and updated from time to time and be
submitted to the NCCA for recognition in compliance with the Department of the Interior
and Local Government as a requirement for the Seal of Good Local Governance.

SEC. 3. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
December 6, 2022.
short_text: It officially recognizes and adopts a list of 442 cultural properties in Manila prepared by the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila. This list serves as the city’s official cultural inventory, fulfilling the requirement for the Seal of Good Local Governance and will be submitted to the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). The inventory may be updated over time to include more cultural properties as needed.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8925

AN ORDINANCE DECLARING THE MANILA CLOCK TOWER MUSEUM AS A
TOURIST DESTINATION, PLACING IT UNDER THE CARE AND SUPERVISION OF
THE DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM, CULTURE AND ARTS OF MANILA AND
PROVIDING ADMISSION FEES THEREOF

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The City of Manila has rehabilitated, renovated, and repurposed the entire watch
tower into a museum gallery to be called the Manila Clock Tower Museum (MCTM);

The Manila Clock Tower Museum is envisioned to be a world-class institution,
tourist attraction, and a showcase for the advocacy of Arts and Culture right in the middle of the capital of the Philippines;

The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM), is tasked to
strengthen and boost the tourism of Manila City as an engine of growth and employment,
as well as to ensure and uphold the preservation of the arts, culture, and rich historical heritage of the city;

Recently, the City Government of Manila unveiled the Manila Tourism and Cultural
Development Plan 2020–2025, at the stakeholders’ meeting on the first week of
September, which aims to boost tourism in Manila since the pandemic in 2020.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaring the Manila Clock Tower Museum as a tourist attraction in
the City of Manila.

SEC. 2. The Manila Clock Tower Museum shall be under the care, management,
maintenance, and supervision of the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila.

SEC. 3. The Manila Clock Tower shall have an exhibit about the ‘Battle of Manila’,
Art Gallery Exhibits, Mayor’s Hall, Artisan Center and Workshop, Restoration Room,
Clock Room, and the 360-degree View of Manila.

SEC. 4. The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila shall charge and
collect an admission fee of One Hundred Pesos (PHP. 100.00) for every person entering
the Manila Clock Tower Museum.

Free admission shall be granted to all senior citizens and Persons with Disabilities
(PWD) provided that they present their Senior Citizen Identification Card and PWD
Identification Card.

A discount of 50% shall be given to children of up to 12 years of age, while free
admission shall be granted to public school students of Manila during official field trips and upon presentation of valid school ID. The admission charge shall gradually increase by 10% annually for the next five (5) years, while the rate for the next succeeding years shall be determined by the Office of the Mayor depending on prevailing economic conditions.

SEC. 5. Admission payments shall be made online or directly to the Museum's
Office and remitted to the City Treasurer's Office. It shall accrue to the General Fund to be used for the overall care and maintenance of the Museum.

SEC. 6. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are
hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 8. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
December 6, 2022.
short_text: This declares the Manila Clock Tower Museum as an official tourist destination and places it under the supervision of the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila. The museum features exhibits like the Battle of Manila, an art gallery, and a 360-degree city view. Visitors will be charged an entrance fee of PhP100, with free admission for senior citizens, PWDs, and Manila public school students on official trips. Children up to 12 years old get a 50% discount, and fees will increase by 10% annually for five years.

ORDINANCE NO. 8924

AN ORDINANCE EXPRESSLY REPEALING ORDINANCE NO. 8031, ENTITLED:
“AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF ORDINANCE NO. 7941,
OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE ORDINANCE OF
1998, ENUMERATING COVERED ESTABLISHMENTS, EXEMPTING CERTAIN
ESTABLISHMENTS AND PERSONS THEREFROM AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES”
AND ORDINANCE NO. 7941, ENTITLED:
“AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING OWNERS, OPERATORS, LESSEES, OCCUPANTS AND
CONCESSIONAIRES OF BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS, CONTRACTORS AND
DEVELOPERS AND PERSONS REQUIRED TO SECURE BUSINESS AND/OR BUILDING
PERMIT IN DOING BUSINESS OR UNDERTAKING CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR WORK IN
THE CITY OF MANILA, TO SECURE PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE, PROVIDING PENALTIES
FOR VIOLATIONS THEREOF AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES”

EXPLANATORY NOTE

On December 29, 1997, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 7941,
requiring owners, operators, lessees, occupants and concessionaires of business
establishments, contractors and developers for a Public Liability Insurance as a requisite for securing a business or building permit.

On January 25, 2002, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8301,
amending provisions in Ordinance No. 7941, providing an enumeration of Covered and
Exempted Establishments.

On April 13, 2021, Joint Memorandum Circular (JMC) No. 01, Series of 2021,
entitled: “Guidelines for Processing Business Permits, Related Clearances and Licenses
in All Cities and Municipalities,” was issued by the Anti-Red Tape Authority (ARTA),
Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Trade and Industry
(DTI), and Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT).

Said JMC is in consonance with the mandate of RA 11032, otherwise known as
the “Ease of Doing Business and Efficient Government Service Delivery Act of 2018,”
which aims to streamline government procedures.

Said JMC mandates all Local Government Units (LGUs) to limit the documentary
requirements for business permit applications to be submitted together with the Unified
Application Form (UAF) to those listed below:

New Business Permit Applications

a.) Proof of registration i.e., Certificate of Registration:

    i.) Issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for all
        kinds of corporations;
    ii.) Issued by the Cooperative Development Authority for
        cooperatives;
    iii.) Issued by DTI for sole proprietors.

b.) Proof of right of applicant to use location as business address, which
may include any of the following:

    i.) If owned, proof of ownership – Transfer Certificate of Title or Tax
        Declaration;
    ii.) If not owned by the applicant – Contract of Lease, Memorandum
        of Agreement, or written consent of property owner.

c.) Location plan or sketch of the location, clearly showing where business
premises is located.

d.) Fire Safety Inspection Certificate for Occupancy, valid in the last 9
months (requirement of BFP).

e.) For applicants with valid FSIC for occupancy, Affidavit of Undertaking
that there had been no substantial changes made on the
building/establishment given the FSIC (requirement of BFP).

Business Permit Renewal Applications

a.) Proof on annual gross receipts which may include:

    i.) Audited financial statements (AFS) or unaudited AFS for those
        who are not required to file AFS with the BIR; or
    ii.) Sworn declaration of gross sales or receipts; or
    iii.) Income tax returns.

This Ordinance, once approved, shall promote efficiency in business registration
procedures, thereby improving the business climate in our beloved city.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Ordinance No. 7941 and Ordinance No. 8031 are hereby expressly
repealed.

SEC. 2. All ordinances or portions thereof which are contrary to the provisions of
this Ordinance are hereby deemed repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 3. If any part, section or provision of this Ordinance shall be held invalid or
unconstitutional by a competent court, other parts or portions that are not affected thereby
shall remain valid.

SEC. 4. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 29, 2022.

CERTIFICATION

This is to certify that Ordinance No. 8924, entitled:
AN ORDINANCE EXPRESSLY REPEALING ORDINANCE NO. 8031, ENTITLED:
“AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF ORDINANCE NO. 7941,
OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE ORDINANCE OF 1998,
ENUMERATING COVERED ESTABLISHMENTS, EXEMPTING CERTAIN ESTABLISHMENTS AND PERSONS
THEREFROM AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES” AND ORDINANCE NO. 7941, ENTITLED:
“AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING OWNERS, OPERATORS, LESSEES, OCCUPANTS AND CONCESSIONAIRES
OF BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS, CONTRACTORS AND DEVELOPERS AND PERSONS REQUIRED TO
SECURE BUSINESS AND/OR BUILDING PERMIT IN DOING BUSINESS OR UNDERTAKING CONSTRUCTION
OR REPAIR WORK IN THE CITY OF MANILA, TO SECURE PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE, PROVIDING
PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS THEREOF AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES.”

was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on November 29, 2022.
The same was forwarded to the Office of the Honorable Mayor on December 6, 2022.

Considering that more than ten (10) days lapsed, without any communication that the ordinance was approved or vetoed by the local Chief Executive, Ordinance No. 8924 shall be DEEMED APPROVED as if
he had signed it, pursuant to Section 54 par. (b) of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government
Code of 1991.

Issued this 19th day of December 2022, in the City of Manila.
short_text: This officially repeals two earlier ordinances—Ordinance Nos. 7941 and 8031—which required business owners and developers in Manila to secure Public Liability Insurance before obtaining business or building permits. This repeal is in line with new national guidelines aimed at simplifying business registration under the Ease of Doing Business Act. The goal is to reduce documentary requirements and improve the city's efficiency in processing business permits.

ORDINANCE NO. 8922

AN ORDINANCE PROMOTING PHILIPPINE INDIGENOUS AND TRADITIONAL
WRITING SYSTEMS AND PROVIDING FOR THEIR PROTECTION, PRESERVATION
AND CONSERVATION IN THE CITY OF MANILA

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as
“An Ordinance Promoting Philippine Indigenous and Traditional Writing Systems
and Providing for Their Protection, Preservation and Conservation in the City of Manila.”

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. — As mandated in the 1987 Constitution of the
Philippines, Article XIV, Section 14 to Section 18 (2), the State shall spearhead the
preservation and enrichment of the Filipino national culture based on the principle of unity in diversity. The arts and letters shall be conserved, promoted and popularized by the State as the nation’s historical and cultural heritage and resources. In order to fulfill such mandates, there is a great need to promote, protect, preserve and conserve Philippine indigenous writing systems as tools for cultural development, to instill patriotism and nationalism, as well as to protect the Filipino cultural heritage and identity.

SEC. 3. Promotion of Philippine Indigenous and Traditional Writing
Systems. — Indigenous writings and traditional scripts are a significant part of our cultural treasures and history. To foster awareness and generate appreciation for such treasures, promotion and preservation of these writing systems must be prioritized.

Indigenous and traditional writing systems, as representations of Filipino culture
and history, shall be promoted and preserved through the following means:

(a) Recommending to the Department of Education — Manila and Commission on
Higher Education (CHED) to include these writing systems as a separate
module in existing subjects of basic and higher education curricula of both
public and private educational institutions in the City of Manila, and to create an
elective or specialized course in higher education for the study of the same;

(b) Creating activities that promote awareness during Buwan ng Wika and other
similar occasions and events;

(c) Displaying such writing systems at public spaces and transportation services
in order to promote a culture of awareness within the City of Manila on
Philippine Indigenous and Traditional Writing Systems;

(d) Requiring local offices under the Manila City Hall and encouraging other public
and private establishments in the city to use Baybayin scripts in their logos and
seals;

(e) Providing incentives and recognitions to individuals and groups working for the
production of written materials and record-keeping of oral evidences of
traditional writing systems in Manila;

(f) Supporting the conduct of seminars, conferences, conventions, symposia and
other relevant activities in the City of Manila on the study of Philippine writing systems; and

(g) Other applicable measures as may be adopted by relevant and concerned
agencies.

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby
repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 29, 2022.
short_text: promotes and protects Philippine indigenous and traditional writing systems, such as Baybayin, within the City of Manila. The ordinance calls for including these scripts in school curriculums, showcasing them in public spaces and transport, and encouraging their use in official logos. It also supports activities like seminars, cultural events, and giving recognition to individuals and groups helping preserve these writing systems, all to strengthen Filipino identity and cultural pride.

ORDINANCE NO. 8921

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTIONS 2 AND 3 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8482,
ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE GRANTING BURIAL ASSISTANCE TO THE SURVIVING
HEIRS OF SENIOR CITIZENS WHO HAVE DIED AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS FOR
THE PURPOSE” AND ADDING THERETO THE REQUIREMENTS TO BE PRESENTED
BY THE CLAIMANTS AND APPROPRIATING TWELVE MILLION PESOS (PHP 12,000,000.00)

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 8482 is hereby amended and shall now
read as follows:

“SEC. 2. Burial Financial Assistance. — The surviving heirs of any
senior citizen who has died shall be granted burial financial assistance in
the amount of Two Thousand Pesos (PHP 2,000.00), subject to the
presentation of the following required original documents to the
Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs:

a. Death Certificate of the deceased Senior Citizen with the
official registry number of the Civil Registry Office — Manila;

b. Funeral services contract and receipt indicating the name
of the claimant;

c. Issued Manila City Office of the Senior Citizen Affairs ID; and

d. Any valid government-issued primary ID.

Claimants shall be granted the Burial Financial Assistance
PROVIDED that they submit the abovementioned requirements for
the assistance within thirty (30) days upon the death of the Senior
Citizen. PROVIDED FURTHER, that said deceased senior citizen was
a beneficiary of the Manila City Senior Citizen Allowance and was not
tagged as an inactive beneficiary before his or her death. PROVIDED
FINALLY, that the only claimant of the burial financial assistance is
the person named in the original funeral services contract and
receipt, regardless of relations.”

SEC. 2. Section 3 of Ordinance No. 8482 is hereby amended and shall now read
as follows:

“SEC. 3. Appropriation. — The amount of Twelve Million Pesos
(PHP 12,000,000.00), or so much thereof as may be necessary, is
hereby appropriated out of the funds in the City Treasury not
otherwise appropriated, for the purpose of such financial assistance,
for inclusion in the next year’s budget or from the Special Activities Fund,
Office of the Mayor for CY 2023.”

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are
hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2023
and should be published in two (2) newspapers of local circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 24, 2022.
short_text: amends a previous ordinance to strengthen the burial assistance program for senior citizens in Manila. The heirs of a deceased senior citizen can now receive PhP2,000 in burial assistance, provided they submit required documents like the death certificate, funeral contract, and valid IDs within 30 days of the senior citizen’s death. The deceased must have been an active recipient of the city’s senior citizen allowance, and only the person named on the funeral receipt can claim the benefit. A total of PhP12 million has been allocated for this program.

ORDINANCE NO. 8919

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING THE AMOUNT OF TWENTY TWO BILLION TWO HUNDRED MILLION PESOS (PHP. 22,200,000,000.00), UNDER THE GENERAL FUND EXECUTIVE BUDGET OF THE CITY OF MANILA FOR FY 2023, TO BE TAKEN FROM THE ESTIMATED INCOME CERTIFIED AS REASONABLY COLLECTIBLE BY THE LOCAL FINANCE COMMITTEE FOR FY 2023 AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 16 (The General Welfare Clause) of Republic Act 7160 also known as Local Government Code of 1991 expressly grants and mandates local government units powers and functions which are necessary appropriate or incidental to efficient and effective governance. Pursuant to this the Executive Department has prepared the city's program of expenditures and policies aimed to initiate and maximize the generation of resources and revenues and apply the same to the implementation of Development Plans Program Objectives and other Priority Projects.   

And in compliance with Section 318 of the Code the Chief Executive of our beloved city Hon. Maria Sheilah "Honey" H. Lacuna-Pangan MD FPDS submitted to this august Chamber for consideration the proposed Executive Budget of the City of Manila FY 2023 amounting to Twenty-Two Billion Two Hundred Million Pesos.   

In her prefatory message to this Chamber the Honorable Mayor stated that it is time to balance the scale of health and economy as we recover and mitigate the effect of the pandemic as she defined the priorities of her administration that include strengthening the capacity and quality of healthcare services enhancing the social amelioration program livelihood programs especially for the economically challenged individuals out- of-school youths senior citizens and persons with disabilities accessibility to quality education economic recovery measures maintenance of public order and safety and implementation of infrastructure plans and projects...all for the enrichment of the quality of life of Manilans.   

It is the consensus of this august Chamber to extend its full support to the programs and aspirations of the Chief Executive of the city without compromising its role of check- and-balance and as fiscalizer when it is deemed appropriate.   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila in session assembled THAT:

SECTION 1. There is hereby appropriated the amount of TWENTY TWO BILLION TWO HUNDRED MILLION PESOS (PHP. 22,200,000,000.00) to be made available for appropriations under FY 2023 Executive Budget of the City Government of Manila to be taken from the estimated income certified as reasonably collectible by the Local Finance Committee and which are not otherwise appropriated and which budget documents marked as Annex A for Book I and Annex B for Book II are made integral parts hereof to be made available as appropriation of the City Government of Manila from January 1 2023 to December 31 2023.
