GENERAL PROVISIONS

SEC. 2. Budgetary Requirements. The Budgetary Expenditures herein proposed shall comply with the following requirements:   

(a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions nor create new positions without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.

(b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod the use of which requires a separate ordinance.

(c) The appropriation of the Special Purpose Appropriations being a contingency fund or back up fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed by the different departments to finish certain programs/projects that were not sufficiently funded cannot be utilized without specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Committee on Appropriations for approval.

(d) The payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of the barangay chairman attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted. Garbage hauling services shall be contracted out to one or more companies as recommended by the Department of Public Services to ensure efficient and timely collection of garbage.

(e) As additional funding source any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee on Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee for authority to the Mayor to dispose the same through public bidding.

(f) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solution and detergents) using City Government funds shall conform with Republic Act No. 9003 otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000 Republic Act No. 8749 and Republic Act No. 9275 otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence products to be procured shall be limited to organic biodegradable or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco-Labelling Program of Green Choice Philippines.

(g) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons with Disability under Republic Act No. 7277 otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons before the release of any payment.   

SEC. 3. General Limitations. -

a. The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for FY 2023 shall not exceed Forty-Five Percent (45%) of the Total Annual Income Regular sources realized in the next preceding Fiscal Year;

b. No official or employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher than the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank as determined by applicable laws rules and regulations;

c. No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as maybe expressly authorized by law;

d. In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career services such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Local Government Code and the Civil Service law rules and regulations;

e. Positions in the Official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbents holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations;   

f. No changes in designation or nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed except when the position is actually vacant and filling of such position shall be strictly made in accordance with Civil Service law rules and regulations; and

g. The Annual appropriation for discretionary purpose of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipt delivered from basic real property tax in the next preceding year.   

SEC. 4. Itemization of Personal Services and other Personnel. - The itemization of Personal Services and Other General Services as submitted by the City Budget Office in support of the appropriation herein authorized forms part of this Ordinance and shall be strictly implemented and shall be covered by its provisions. Such appropriations shall be programmed and used for the twelve-month requirement of the city. It may not be disbursed to exponentially increase the number of personnel during the first semester leaving little or no fund for the second semester of the year.   

SEC. 5. Intelligence Expenses. The Intelligence/Confidential expenses provided under this Ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.   

SEC. 6. Changes in the Organizational and Administrative Machinery. - All creations conversions transfers abolitions and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services Positions/Titles and Salary Grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 137 of the Department of Budget and Management.   

a. For a more responsive efficient and effective organization within several departments and offices creation conversion of certain positions performing staff/technical/non-technical functions were made.

b. Modification of Salary Grades in compliance with DBM Local Budget Circular No. 143 implementing the Third Tranche Modified Salary Schedule for Local Government Personnel Pursuant to Republic Act (RA) No.11466.   

SEC. 7. Use of Appropriated Funds. All funds appropriated for functions projects and activities shall be used to finance the full year requirement of the City of Manila and shall be released exclusively for specific purposes and particular period for which they have been authorized. Any amendment and augmentation may be made within the fiscal year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.   

SEC. 8. Authority to Adjust Appropriations. - No Ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.   

SEC. 9. Twenty Percent (20%) Development Fund. The twenty percent (20%) Development Fund shall be strictly utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the Sangguniang Panlungsod in conformity with the Local Government Code.   

SEC. 10. Twenty Percent (20%) Contingency Reserve. - Except for expenses due to public utilities rentals insurance premiums and food supplies expenses a contingency reserve of twenty percent (20%) on the authorized FY 2023 appropriation for Department Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating thereon the 20% contingency reserve.   

SEC. 11. Allotment of Appropriations. For effective budgetary control authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with the DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder:   

a. No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function activity or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor as hereafter provided. The Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted based on the appropriations authorized in the Budget Ordinance. A revised Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted upon approval of the Annual Executive Budget referred herein showing quarterly allotment of the whole authorized appropriations for the department/office.
b. For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided each fiscal year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January April July and October. The appropriations under this Ordinance shall be allocated programmed and used to cover the funding requirement of the city for the whole year. Majority thereof may not be expended in the first semester to ensure availability of funds for the last semester of the year.
c. The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer's notification and certification that the realized income is less than what is estimated in the annual/supplemental budget or that additional income is realized.
d. An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Officer based on recommendation made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least five (5) days before the start of each quarter.   

SEC. 12. Non-Waiver Clause. Notwithstanding the approval of this Appropriation Ordinance by the Sangguniang Panlungsod all contracts disbursements and awards entered into by the City of Manila including but not limited to the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila Universidad De Manila and other government agencies and instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455 paragraph B sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160 otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991 and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.   

SEC. 13. Separability Clause. If for any reason or reasons any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall continue to be in full force and effect.   

SEC. 14. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1 2023.   

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 24 2022.
short_text: This ordinance officially approves a budget of PhP 22.2 billion for the City of Manila's 2023 operations and programs. The money will come from income expected to be collected during the year. The budget prioritizes healthcare improvements, education access, livelihood support for the poor, seniors, PWDs, and out-of-school youth, economic recovery, public safety, and infrastructure projects. Strict rules are set on how funds can be spent, including how jobs are created or modified, how salaries are handled, how special funds are released (like intelligence funds or contingency reserves), and how garbage collection and eco-friendly products are procured. All spending must follow proper planning and approval procedures, and unspent money cannot just be reallocated without City Council approval.

ORDINANCE NO. 8916

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING ONE (1) VACANT PLANTILLA POSITION OF NURSE IV IN THE JUSTICE JOSE ABAD SANTOS GENERAL HOSPITAL BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD AND REPLACING THE SAME PLANTILLA POSITION WITH ONE (1) PHARMACIST III
EXPLANATORY NOTE

By virtue of this Ordinance, different plantilla items at Justice Jose Abad Santos
General Hospital will be eliminated, and a new position will be created for them. According to Chapter III, Budgeting, Article I Local Government Budgets, Section 325 (d) of Republic Act No. 7160 or also known as the Local Government Code of 1991 which states: “In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this code and the civil service law, rules and regulations”.

Also in the same act, the Title III, Human Resources and Development in Section
76 of Republic Act No. 7160 or also known as the Local Government Code of 1991 which
stated: “Organizational Structure and Staffing Pattern. — Every local government unit shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern taking into consideration its service requirements and financial capability, subject to the minimum standards and guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission”.

In times of pandemic, the “Dangal ng Bayan” and Officer in Charge, Hospital Director Merle D. Sacdalan — Faustino, along with the personnel of this hospital, continue to serve and protect for the people of the City of Manila in health, particularly at this time of epidemic.

In view of the foregoing, the approval of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City
Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery
of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability and affordability.

The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting and scaling-down, phasing-out or abolishing non-core tasks.

short_text: This aims to abolish one Nurse IV position and replace it with a Pharmacist III position at the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital. This change is part of a broader effort to optimize the hospital's staffing and resource allocation, as outlined by the Local Government Code of 1991. The Nurse IV position, with a salary of PHP 48,313, will be eliminated, and a new Pharmacist III position, with a salary of PHP 43,681, will be created. This decision is in line with the city’s goal to improve service delivery and manage resources effectively, especially during challenging times such as the pandemic.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

The FY 2022 Annual Budget appropriated funds for various items under the
Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the FY 2022 Annual Budget.

After due consideration, there is a need to augment various items from the FY
2022 Annual Budget through savings from other accounts of the FY 2022 Annual Budget
to ensure the effective and efficient delivery of priority programs and activities of the City of Manila.

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of
Availability of Funds as supporting document to the said savings and augmentation.

Section 336 of Republic Act No. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991,
provides that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of
appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the
presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to
augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings
in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.

The City Council approved Resolution No. 11, Series of 2022, of the Executive
Committee of the City Development Council, entitled “A Resolution approving the
amendment of the Annual Investment Program and Issuance of a Supplemental
Investment Program for FY 2022 in relation to the Augmentation of Various Items under
the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses in the Total Amount of Two Hundred
Sixty-Three Million Nine Hundred Fourteen Thousand Pesos (PHP 263,914,000.00).”

ORDINANCE NO. 8914

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 5 FOR THE
REQUIREMENTS OF THE VARIOUS IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF
MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF ONE HUNDRED FORTY-ONE MILLION THIRTY
THOUSAND NINE HUNDRED NINETY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP. 141,030,997.00) AND
FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Every local government unit shall exercise the powers that are essential to the
promotion of the general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other things, the
health and safety of its constituents, enhance the right of the people to a balanced
ecology, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, and preserve the comfort and
convenience of its inhabitants (Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.) No. 7160 or the Local
Government Code of 1991).   

Local government units shall likewise exercise such powers and discharge such
functions and responsibilities for the efficient and effective provisions of basic services
and facilities which includes, among others, services and facilities related to general
hygiene and sanitation, slaughterhouses, health services which includes health
centers/hospitals and other infrastructure facilities to service the needs of the residents
(Section 17 of R.A. No. 7160).   

A supplemental budget may be enacted when supported by funds actually
available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources
(Section 321 of R.A. No. 7160).   

The City Treasurer and the City Accountant has issued the Certificate of
Availability of Funds as supporting document to the promulgation of a Supplemental
Budget.   

The City Council likewise approved Resolution No. 10, Series of 2022 of the
Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: "A RESOLUTION
APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND
ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2022 FOR THE
VARIOUS IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL
AMOUNT OF ONE HUNDRED FORTY-ONE MILLION THIRTY-ONE THOUSAND
PESOS (PHP 141,031,000.00)".   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Appropriations. - The FY 2022 Supplemental Budget of the City of Manila in the total amount of One Hundred Forty-One Million Thirty Thousand Nine Hundred Ninety-Seven Pesos (PhP. 141,030,997.00) is hereby appropriated to fund the following projects of the City of Manila, to wit:

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE: Department of Engineering and Public Works    

Object of Expenditures: Other Structures 
Particular/Purpose: 1. Construction of Administration Offices including transfer of container vans for the Veterinary Inspection Board

Capital Outlay 
Object of Expenditures: Sewer System
Particular/Purpose: 2. b. Construction of Waste Drainage System Raceway and Water lines at Vitas Slaughterhouse 
AMOUNT: PhP. 16,000,000.00 
Particular/Purpose: 2. a. Upgrading of Sewage Treatment Plant at Sta. Ana Hospital 
AMOUNT: PhP. 7,304,000.00 
(Combined amount for Sewer System: PhP. 23,304,000.00)    

20% City Development Fund (CDF) 
Object of Expenditures: Hospitals and Health Centers 
Particular/Purpose: 3. Additional Works for the Construction of Three (3) Storey Community Hospital at Baseco Compound 
AMOUNT: PhP. 10,985,000.00    

20% City Development Fund (CDF) 
Object of Expenditures: Slaughterhouses 
Particular/Purpose: 4. Construction of Two (2) storey with Mezzanine Animal Pen at Vitas Slaughterhouse 
AMOUNT: PhP. 20,241,997.00    

20% City Development Fund (CDF) 
Object of Expenditures: Other Structures 
Particular/Purpose: 5. a. Disassembly of Manila Covid19 -Field Hospital including the Restoration of Burnham Green 
AMOUNT: PhP. 50,000,000.00 
Particular/Purpose: 5. b. Construction of one (1) Storey Animal Pound Building at VIB

(Combined amount for Other Structures under CDF: PhP. 79,000,000.00)    

TOTAL: PhP. 141,030,997.00    

Attached are the following details:

LBP Form No. 8 marked as "Annex A" - Statement of Funding Source as Certified by the City Treasurer and City Accountant; and    

LBP Form No. 9 marked "Annex B" - Statement of Supplemental Appropriation.   

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.   

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.   

On the motion presented by the Hon. Ernesto C. Isip, Jr., Majority Floor Leader, which was duly seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on November 15, 2022.

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government
Code of 1991, categorically provides:

“Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. — Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for the expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall
continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation and the sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations subject to the provisions of this Section.”

ORDINANCE NO. 8912

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8119, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS
THE “MANILA COMPREHENSIVE LAND USE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE OF
2006”, TO INCLUDE MANILA SOLAR CITY PROJECT

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Manila Solar City (the “Project”) is a 148-hectare high-value and high-density
development that will rise in Manila Bay within the territorial waters of the City of Manila.

Presented before the City Council are Manila Goldcoast Development
Corporation’s (MGDC) Master Development Plan and Zoning and Land Use Plan.

Based on MGDC’s Master Development Plan and Zoning and Land Use Plan, the
Project features a modern urban setting while still recognizing Manila’s glorious heritage and rich culture. It will be comprised of three (3) islands, which will be interconnected by land bridges. Easements will be provided along the perimeter of the islands as buffer zones. Generous open and green spaces are incorporated to promote a natural environment within the city.

The Project area based on the attached Final Land Configuration approved and
issued by the Philippine Reclamation Authority (PRA) shall be: 6.92 hectares for the first island; 69.6 hectares for the second island; and 71.9 hectares for the third island.

The Final Technical Description shall be defined once the final land masses have
been constructed.

There will be a 120-meter-wide channel between each island to provide navigation
for sea vessels and an efficient flushing system; thereby ensuring and maintaining the good quality of water surrounding the whole development.

The average elevation of the Project will be at +4.00 meters above mean lower
low water or MLLW. Pre-engineering studies and activities were conducted to assess possible various impacts and geotechnical risks involved in the Project. Based on these studies, the Project is properly designed and engineered to ensure stability and safety.

The total volume of sandfill materials required is around Twenty-Four Million
(24,000,000) cubic meters, which shall be sourced from the approved seabed quarry area
of PRA. A sand key and containment bund surrounding the perimeter of the islands will
be provided for soil improvement. It will be compacted in order to prevent liquefaction
during utilizing rocks and boulders.

The Project will have a maximum Gross Floor Area Ratio (FAR) of 12.

Each island shall be provided with a central utility area, i.e., each island has its
own power and water supply, as well as telecommunications facilities.

The Project will connect to the proposed Quirino-Macapagal Causeway/Viaduct. Its
proximity to the mainland makes it advantageous to directly connect to the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), providing ease of accessibility. Future connections to existing city light rail systems and electronic monorail/people mover are envisioned. It will also be accessible by ferry and water taxis.

City Ordinance No. 8119 adopts the Comprehensive Land Use Plan/Zoning Ordinance of the City of Manila.

The City Planning and Development Office (CPDO) evaluated the completeness of all the documentary requirements submitted by MGDC and certified that said is in compliance with standards prescribed by applicable laws and rules.

On October 25, 2022, the CPDO rendered a report recommending the approval of the application for Master Development Plan and Zoning and Land Use Plan of MGDC for Manila Solar City.

This Body approves the application pursuant to Section 458, Paragraph 2(x) of Republic Act 7160, which states that the Sanggunian shall "subject to national law, process and approve plans for residential, commercial, or industrial purposes and other development purposes, and to collect processing fees and other charges, the proceeds of which shall accrue entirely to the city xxxxx".

CPDO and City Council approve the Master Development Plan and Zoning and Land Use Plan application of MGDC for Manila Solar City Reclamation Project consisting of approximately one hundred forty-eight square meters (148 sq. m.) along the Manila Bay coastline.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “Manila Solar City
Reclamation Project” for brevity.

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. — It is the policy of the city to pursue development
projects and, towards this end, the reclamation of a specific area based on the
specifications submitted by the proponent MGDC and within the limits and specifications
set forth by competent authorities is hereby authorized.

SEC. 3. Scope of Reclamation. — The Updated and Final Zoning/Land Use Plan,
Land Allocation Plan, and the Master Plan prepared by the international master planning
firm PEN, INK, AND COLOR, in collaboration with the Environmental Planner of Record,
ENVIRONS SYSTEMS GROUP, INC., and submitted by MGDC showing the location of the
required 5% green space, proposed land use and allocation in accordance with the
Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) between the PRA and the City of Manila and MGDC,
as well as its updates, shall define the scope of the reclamation project.

SEC. 4. Amending Ordinance No. 8119. — The Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan and Zoning Ordinance of 2006, as amended, is hereby further amended to include the Manila Solar City Reclamation Project. The City Planning and Development Office is hereby directed to amend the Official Zoning Maps.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 15, 2022.
short_text: It amends Ordinance No. 8119 (Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan and Zoning Ordinance of 2006) to incorporate the Manila Solar City Reclamation Project, a 148-hectare urban development in Manila Bay. The project includes three interconnected islands with designated zoning, green spaces, and modern infrastructure. It was approved after evaluation by the City Planning and Development Office and in compliance with environmental and land use standards. The zoning maps will be updated accordingly.

ORDINANCE NO. 8911

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE PRESIDENT CORAZON C. AQUINO
GENERAL HOSPITAL, LOCATED IN BASECO COMPOUND, BARANGAY 649, PORT
AREA, MANILA, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREOF

EXPLANATORY NOTE

Section 11, Article XIII of the 1987 Constitution of the Philippines provides that the
State shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development
which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health and other social services available
to all the people at affordable cost. There shall be priority for the needs of the underprivileged, sick, elderly, disabled, women, and children. The State shall endeavor to provide free medical care to paupers. The hospital of President Corazon C. Aquino is the 7th government hospital that shall be of help to the citizens of the City of Manila in terms of health.

The Baseco Compound residents would greatly benefit from this institution since
they require medical care and attention. This is equivalent to Gat Andres Bonifacio Medical Center, Ospital ng Tondo, Ospital ng Sampaloc, Ospital ng Maynila, Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital, and Sta. Ana Hospital. These government hospitals will serve as the cornerstone of high-quality treatment, providing care for the underprivileged Manileños who require urgent medical attention without compromising
their financial capacity.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “An Ordinance
establishing the President Corazon C. Aquino General Hospital, located in Baseco
Compound, Barangay 649, Port Area, Manila, appropriating funds thereof”.

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. — The 1987 Constitution mandates that the State shall
provide for equal health opportunities for all and provide for avenues that will cater to the health needs of its constituents. Article II, Section 15, declares that the State shall protect and promote the rights to health of the people.

Pursuant to the above policy, there is hereby established a hospital to be known
as the President Corazon C. Aquino General Hospital, located in Baseco Compound,
Barangay 649, Port Area. This hospital will have a 50-bed capacity with separate male and
female wards. The City of Manila hereby declares that it will provide for and safeguard
the citizen’s public health.

SEC. 3. Services. — The following services shall be provided by the said hospital:

a. Full operational emergency room;
b. Centralized oxygen supply line;
c. Pediatric wards;
d. Isolation wards;
e. Digital X-ray equipment;
f. Radiology;
g. Laboratory;
h. Central diagnostics;
i. Dietary;
j. Surgery;
k. Internal medicine department; and
l. Maternity.

SEC. 4. — The President Corazon C. Aquino General Hospital shall have an
organizational structure and staffing which is made an integral part of this Ordinance.

SEC. 5. — The regular medical and non-medical staff of President Corazon C. Aquino
General Hospital shall be appointed by the Mayor pursuant to the rules and regulations
of the Civil Service Commission.

SEC. 6. — The amount necessary for the implementation of this Ordinance is hereby
appropriated out of funds not otherwise appropriated and existing and available as
certified to by the City Treasurer.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are
hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days
after its publication in at least two (2) newspapers of local circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 8, 2022.
short_text: establishes the President Corazon C. Aquino General Hospital in Baseco Compound, Barangay 649, Port Area, Manila. The hospital will have a 50-bed capacity and offer comprehensive medical services, including emergency care, pediatric and isolation wards, surgery, maternity, and diagnostic facilities. The ordinance appropriates necessary funding for its implementation, with staffing appointments to be handled by the Mayor under Civil Service rules.

ORDINANCE NO. 8909

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8627, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8901, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS “AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING THE MANDATORY USE OF FACE MASKS IN ALL PUBLIC PLACES WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA"

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on October 28, 2022, President Ferdinand “Bong-Bong” R. Marcos,
Jr., issued Executive Order No. 7, Series of 2022, pursuant to IATF Resolution
No. 3, Series of 2022, which recommends the further liberalization of the face mask
mandate;

WHEREAS, Executive Order No. 7, Series of 2022, amended Executive Order
No. 3, Series of 2022, allowing the voluntary or optional wearing of face masks in
indoor and outdoor settings;

WHEREAS, the further liberalization of the face mask mandate was brought as a
result of the increase in the number of individuals vaccinated against COVID-19, as well as individuals administered with COVID-19 vaccines in the Philippines;

WHEREAS, countries around the world, as a result of continued vaccination, have
been instituting measures such as relaxation of health and safety protocols, and
reopening of international borders, resulting in immediate positive impacts to their
economies: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Amendment. — Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8627, as amended by
Ordinance No. 8901, is hereby further amended to read as follows:

“SECTION 1. Voluntary Wearing of Face Masks. — The voluntary wearing of face masks in indoor and outdoor settings is hereby allowed, provided that not fully vaccinated
individuals, senior citizens, and immunocompromised individuals are highly encouraged to wear face masks and physical distancing shall be observed at all times. Provided
further, that the wearing of face masks is still mandatory in heavily crowded spaces and events, such as but not limited to, fiesta celebrations, the Feast of the Black Nazarene,
“tiangge”, Christmas, super spreader events and the like. Provided finally, that face masks shall still be worn in public transportation by land, air, or sea, and in outdoor settings where physical distancing cannot be maintained.”

SEC. 2. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are
hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 3. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 8, 2022.
short_text: amends the face mask policy in Manila, allowing the voluntary wearing of face masks in both indoor and outdoor settings. However, face masks remain mandatory in crowded areas (e.g., fiestas, the Feast of the Black Nazarene, markets, and large events), in public transportation, and in settings where physical distancing is not possible. Vulnerable groups—unvaccinated individuals, senior citizens, and immunocompromised persons—are strongly encouraged to continue wearing masks.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8905

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR A FREE ADMISSION AT THE MANILA ZOO FOR CARD-BEARING SENIOR CITIZENS, WHO ARE ‘BONA FIDE RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA DURING WEDNESDAYS
EXPLANATORY NOTE

This Ordinance seeks to provide for a free admission at the Manila Zoological and Botanical Garden, heretofore be referred to as Manila Zoo, for the card-bearing senior
citizens residing in the City of Manila every Wednesday.

Empowering senior citizens is one of the key missions of the City Government of
Manila, it is important for their health and well-being to be involved in activities that keep them engaged in social activities. Seniors’ quality of life and overall well-being are significantly improved by recreation. Participating in recreational activities can meet a range of requirements for seniors, as well as, for persons of all ages. Increased health and fitness, opportunities for social interaction, the use of skills and talents honed over a lifetime, and the acquisition of new skills are just a few of the significant advantages of recreation for the senior population.

Currently, there are more than 201,000 senior citizen residents in the City of
Manila, all of whom are receiving their monthly allowance from the local government of
Manila. Along with this are arrays of benefits such as that of City Ordinance No. 8142 or
“An Ordinance Providing for Free Cinema/Theaters Admission for Card-Bearing Senior
Citizens, who are residents of Manila during Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays in all
Cinemas operating within the City of Manila, amending for the purpose Ordinance No. 8049”. It is important to implement more recreational activities for the senior citizen residents of Manila City.

With the unveiling of the New Manila Zoo, it is of utmost importance that one of the
most vulnerable sectors are able to experience its beauty in a way that is most  beneficial for their financial and social capacity.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. It is hereby declared the policy of the City of
Manila to care for the health and well-being of its citizens and to provide for certain
privileges that shall be enjoyed by the senior citizens of the city.

SEC. 2. Pursuant to this policy, the duly registered Manila City card-bearing senior
citizens or those who are in possession of the Senior Citizens Identification Cards (I.D.) issued by the local Office for Senior Citizens Affairs, are hereby granted the privilege of being given a non-transferrable, one-person admission ticket, valid on Wednesdays, at the Manila Zoological and Botanical Garden, heretofore referred to as Manila Zoo.

SEC. 3. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional. the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately after
its publication in at least two (2) newspapers of local circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 27, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance grants free admission to the Manila Zoo every Wednesday for senior citizens who are bona fide residents of Manila and holders of official Senior Citizen ID cards issued by the city's Office for Senior Citizens Affairs. This initiative aims to promote senior well-being through recreational access and aligns with the city’s policy of supporting senior citizens via social, cultural, and leisure activities. The benefit is non-transferable and applies to one person per ID.

ORDINANCE NO. 8904

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE TITLE AND SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8402, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE INCREASING BY ONE PESO (PHP. 1.00) THE PRICE OF EACH MOVIE TICKET ISSUED OR SOLD IN CINEMAS IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM AUGUST 15 TO DECEMBER 31, 2015. THE PROCEEDS REALIZED FROM SUCH INCREASE TO BE DONATED TO PSORIASIS PHILIPPINES, SUBJECT
TO ALL APPLICABLE AUDITING RULES AND PROCEDURES” This Ordinance seeks to amend the Title and Section 1 of City Ordinance No. 8402, entitled: “An Ordinance increasing by One Peso (PHP. 1.00) the price of each Movie Ticket issued or sold in the cinemas in the City of Manila from August 15 to December 31, 2015. The proceeds realized from such increase to be donated to Psoriasis Philippines, subject to all applicable auditing rules and procedures"

EXPLANATORY NOTE

This Ordinance seeks to amend the Title and Section 1 of City Ordinance No. 8402, entitled: "An Ordinance increasing by One Peso (PHP 1.00) the price of each Movie Ticket issued or sold in the cinemas in the City of Manila from August 15 to December 31, 2015. The proceeds realized from such increase to be donated to Psoriasis Philippines, subject to all applicable auditing rules and procedures"

Wherefore, the date of effectivity for the increase in tickets issued or sold in the City of Manila shall be from November 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023.

In view of the foregoing, the passage of this Ordinance is earnestly sought.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The Title of Ordinance No. 8402, is hereby amended to read as follows:

“AN ORDINANCE INCREASING BY ONE PESO (PHP.1.00) THE PRICE OF EACH MOVIE TICKET ISSUED OR
SOLD IN CINEMAS IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM NOVEMBER 1, 2022 TO JANUARY 31, 2023, THE PROCEEDS REALIZED FROM SUCH INCREASE TO BE DONATED TO PSORIASIS PHILIPPINES, SUBJECT TO ALL APPLICABLE AUDITING RULES AND PROCEDURES”

SEC. 2. Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8402, is hereby amended to read as follows:

“SECTION 1. The price of each movie ticket issued or sold from November 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023 in all cinemas in the City of Manila shall be increased by One Peso (PhP. 1.00) for the exclusive benefit of Psoriasis Philippines.”

SEC. 3. The cinemas mentioned in Section 1, shall remit their proceeds to the Psoriasis Philippines directly.

The Bureau of Permits shall ensure faithful compliance of the provisions of this
Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances,
rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are
hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 27, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance changes the details of a previous ordinance (No. 8402) that increased movie ticket prices in cinemas in Manila by PhP 1.00. Instead of the original dates (August 15 to December 31, 2015), the new dates for the increase are from November 1, 2022, to January 31, 2023. The extra PhP 1.00 from each movie ticket sold will be donated to Psoriasis Philippines. The cinemas will directly send the proceeds to Psoriasis Philippines, and the Bureau of Permits will ensure the rules are followed.

ORDINANCE NO. 8901

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 1 OF CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8627,
OTHERWISE KNOWN AS “AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING THE MANDATORY USE OF
FACE MASKS IN ALL PUBLIC PLACES WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Rationale. — Pursuant to IATF Resolution No.1, Series of 2022, which
recommends the liberalization of the mask mandate, President Ferdinand "Bong-Bong”
R. Marcos Jr., issued Executive Order No. 03, Series of 2022, allowing the voluntary
wearing of face masks in open spaces and non-crowded outdoor areas with good
ventilation.

SEC. 2. Amendment. - Section 1 of City Ordinance No. 8627, is hereby amended
to read as follows:

“SECTION 1. Voluntary Wearing of Face Masks in Open Spaces. — The voluntary wearing of face masks in open spaces and non-crowded outdoor ideas with good ventilation, is hereby allowed, provided that those not fully vaccinated individuals, senior citizens, and
immunocompromised individuals are highly encouraged to wear face masks and physical distancing shall be observed at all times. Provided further, that the wearing of masks is still mandatory in heavily crowded spaces and events, and where minimum physical distancing cannot be obtained, such as but not limited to, fiesta celebrations, the feast of the Black Nazarene, “tiangge”, Christmas super spreader events and the like. Provided finally, that face masks shall still be wom in indoor private or public establishments, including public transportation by land, air or sea, and in outdoor settings where physical distancing cannot be maintained.”

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4, Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 13, 2022.
short_text: amends the previous mask mandate in Manila (Ordinance No. 8627), aligning with national policy changes. It allows voluntary mask-wearing in open, uncrowded outdoor areas with good ventilation, but maintains mandatory mask use in crowded events, places where distancing isn't possible, and all indoor or public transportation settings. Vulnerable groups—such as the unvaccinated, senior citizens, and immunocompromised individuals—are still strongly encouraged to wear masks.

ORDINANCE NO. 8898

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING SOME POSITIONS TO GIVE WAY TO THE CREATION OF MORE ESSENTIAL POSITIONS IN THE OFFICE OF THE CITY PROSECUTOR,MANILA
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Office of the City Prosecutor (OCP) which is under the umbrella
of the Department of Justice (DOJ), is tasked to investigate the commission of crimes,
violation of laws, statutes, and ordinances, and the prosecution of cases in the seventy-
one (71) Regional Trial Courts and thirty (30) Metropolitan Trial Courts in the City of
Manila, with a personnel complement of one hundred sixty-seven (167) plantilla positions,
however the actual personnel count is only one hundred four (104) local government-paid
employees constituting the administrative support staff, and one hundred fifty (150)
national government-paid prosecutors;

WHEREAS, the present organizational structure for administrative support staff of
the Office of the Prosecutor is no longer suitable to the growing needs of the 150
prosecutors to ensure expeditious investigation and successful prosecution of criminal
cases in courts;

WHEREAS, the support staff are also serving notices of preliminary investigation,
resolutions, release orders and other written communications to the fifteen (15) police
stations in Manila, National Capital Region Police Office (NCRPO), Camp Crame, DOJ-
Main, Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA) and other agencies both in the local
and national government;

WHEREAS, despite submission of the vacant positions and publication thereof by
the Civil Service Commission, the Office of the City Prosecutor is having a hard time in
hiring personnel qualified to the position because only a few or none at all meets the
Qualification Standards required for the position, thus the need for positions with no
required eligibility is preferred for Process Servers to do the messengerial services, and Sub-Professional Eligibility for encoding and monitoring of cases in the database;

WHEREAS, there is a need to abolish some positions from the present plantilla of
personnel of the Office of the City Prosecutor in order to give way to the creation of more essential positions without infusing additional funds for this purpose: NOW,
THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby
abolished under the Office of the City Prosecutor — Manila, to wit:

SEC. 2. New Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby created
under the Office of the City Prosecutor - Manila, to wit:

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING VARIOUS ITEMS UNDER THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2022 ANNUAL BUDGET IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF FIFTY-TWO MILLION THREE HUNDRED FIFTY-EIGHT THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 52,358,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the FY 2022 Annual Executive Budget appropriated funds for various
items under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the said Annual
Budget:

WHEREAS, after due consideration, there is a need to augment various items from
the FY 2022 Annual Budget through savings from other accounts of the FY 2022 Annual
Budget to ensure the effective and efficient delivery of priority programs and activities of the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, the City Treasurer and the City Accountant has issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash as supporting document to the said savings and augmentation;

No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations;

WHEREAS, the social amelioration program for senior citizens is a continuous program of the City of Manila, hence, augmentation is necessary to appropriate enough funds for the full implementation of Ordinance No. 8565, Series of 2019, providing for the Five Hundred Pesos (PHP. 500.00) monthly allowance for senior citizens for them to afford essential goods, health and other basic needs;

WHEREAS, the Department of Labor and Employment-National Wages and Productivity Commission approved Wage Order No. NCR-23 on 13 May 2022, providing for a minimum wage increase in the National Capital Region in the amount of Thirty-Three Pesos (PHP. 33.00). Hence, augmentation of funds for the accounts Janitorial Services and Security Services is necessary to cover the increase in the basic salary of workers contracted by the City Government under the said accounts;

WHEREAS, the legal basis of this Draft Ordinance can be found in Section 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act 7160 (otherwise known as, the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: “In case of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations;
WHEREAS, the City Council has the power to approve ordinances necessary for an efficient and effective city government and to determine the positions, salaries, wages, allowances, and other emoluments and benefits of officials and employees paid wholly or mainly from city funds [Section 458 (1) {viii} Local Government Code of 1991];
WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC in May 12, 2006 came out with Resolution No. 1, which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following: (a) Abolition of positions. (b) Conversion of positions. (c) Reclassification of positions. (d) Re-titling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;

WHEREAS, the modifications in the organizational structure and staffing pattern will ensure that the respective job descriptions suitably correspond to specific and existing functions and guarantee that essential official responsibilities are identified and operational assignments are rationalized; NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

ORDINANCE NO. 8894

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING VARIOUS ITEMS UNDER MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2022 ANNUAL BUDGET TO FUND PRIORITY PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the FY 2022 Annual Budget appropriated funds for various items under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the FY 2022 Annual Budget;
WHEREAS, after due consideration, there is a need to augment various items from the FY 2022 Annual Budget through savings from other accounts of the FY 2022 Annual Budget to ensure the effective and efficient delivery of priority programs and activities of the City of Manila;
WHEREAS, the City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash as supporting document to the said savings and augmentation;
WHEREAS, Section 336 of the Local Government Code, Use of Appropriated Funds and Savings, provides that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations;
WHEREAS, in recent months, the nation has been burdened with the surge in prices of fuel and other petroleum products. However, these supplies are essential for the daily operations of the City Government. Hence, there is a need to augment the funds for fuel, oil, and lubricants for the city to continue its delivery of basic services;
WHEREAS, the general welfare of the residents and the senior citizens of Manila is a primordial program of the City of Manila. Hence, augmentation is necessary to ensure the efficient implementation of these programs, which includes: (i) food boxes for families in the city and (ii) gift packs for the senior citizens;
WHEREAS, the City Council approved Resolution No. 8, Series of 2022, of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, adopted on July 26, 2022, entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2022 IN RELATION TO THE AUGMENTATION OF VARIOUS ITEMS UNDER MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVEN HUNDRED FOUR MILLION FOUR HUNDRED TWENTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 704,425,000.00).”

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Augmentation. — The hereunder items of appropriation under various accounts in the total amount of Seven Hundred Four Million Four Hundred Twenty-Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 704,425,000.00) shall be augmented through savings from the FY 2022 Annual Budget:
A. Department of Social Welfare
•        Welfare Goods Expenses – PhP 654,425,000.00
B. City General Services Office
•        Fuel, Oil, and Lubricants Expenses – PhP 50,000,000.00
GRAND TOTAL: PhP 704,425,000.00

SECTION 2. Fund Sources. — The fund for the aforementioned expenditures shall be sourced from savings from the following appropriation:
Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses:
A. Department of Social Welfare
•        Donations – PhP 704,425,000.00
GRAND TOTAL: PhP 704,425,000.00

Attached are the following details:
•        Annex A — Declaration of Savings under MOOE for Augmentation of Funds
•        Annex B — Augmentation of MOOE Account under the FY 2022 Annual Budget

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 28, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the augmentation of funds under Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) in the total amount of ₱704,425,000.00 for FY 2022. It reallocates savings from the Department of Social Welfare’s “Donations” item to support welfare goods for families and gift packs for senior citizens, as well as fuel and lubricant needs for city operations. This ensures continuity of essential services amid rising fuel costs.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8893

AN ORDINANCE REVERTING THE GENERIC CAREER POSITION TITLES PREVIOUSLY ADOPTED IN ORDINANCE NO. 8653, ENACTED ON JULY 6, 2020, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8712, ENACTED ON DECEMBER 7, 2020, TO LOCAL LEGISLATIVE POSITION TITLES FOR THE COTERMINOUS PRIMARILY CONFIDENTIAL EMPLOYEES OF THE SANGGUNIANG PANLUNGSOD NG MAYNILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, sometime in 2018, the CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION FIELD OFFICE-MANILA (CSFO-MANILA) began invalidating the coterminous primarily confidential appointments in the legislative non-career service positions of the Manila City Council bearing position titles, namely: Local Legislative Staff Employee I, II, III, and V (LLSE I, II, III, and V) and Local Legislative Staff Officer I to VI (LLSO I to VI), due to the alleged non-compliance to the re-titling requirements under the provisions of CSC Memorandum Circular No. 12, Series of 2011 (Revised Guidelines on the Determination of Positions in the Local Government Units as Primarily Confidential);
WHEREAS, the Manila City Council has implemented remedial measures to resolve the alleged violation of CSC MC No. 12 s. 2011 through the passage of City Resolution No. 143, Series of 2018, re-titling the position titles of the invalidated appointments in its non-career legislative offices and adopting the position titles found in CSCMC No. 12, s. 2011 for non-career services positions therein classified as primarily confidential positions such as Executive Assistant, Private Secretaries, Security Agents, Security Officers and Personal Driver/Chauffeur;
WHEREAS, notwithstanding the passage of re-titling City Resolution No. 143, Series of 2018, there remained other invalidated primarily confidential appointments in the personal and confidential staff of the elected members of the Manila City Council bearing the position titles of LLSO II to IV; LLSE I to III; and Administrative I as they were not included in the position titles that were re-titled under Resolution No. 143 for the reason that there were no corresponding salary grades provided for said positions in CSC MC No. 12, s. 2011;
WHEREAS, in order to comply with the requirements of CSC MC 12, s. 2011, the Manila City Council has enacted re-titling City Ordinance No. 8653, entitled: “An Ordinance Adopting Generic Career Position Titles for the Coterminous Employees Assigned to the Offices of the Presiding Officer and Other Members of the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila, Subject for Qualification Standards except for CSC Eligibility, and Coterminous with the Term of Office with the Head of Unit/Office,” which, upon the advice and guidance of CSCFO-Manila, was adopted pursuant to Section 9 (d) (1) and (2), Rule IV of the 2017 Omnibus Rules on Appointments and Other Human Resource Actions (“2017 ORAOHRA”). The ordinance provides for the re-titling of position titles for the remaining invalidated appointments, this time, with the requisite corresponding salary grades;
WHEREAS, after a careful examination, the officers of the Manila City Council have realized that the CSCFO-Manila’s advice to adopt Section 9 (d) (1) and (2), Rule IV, 2017 ORAOHRA as basis in the appointments of the personal and confidential staff in the non-career offices of the members of the City Council, will change the status of the appointments from being originally non-career coterminous primarily confidential to non-career coterminous appointments, which are not primarily confidential in nature;
WHEREAS, if the said re-titling City Ordinance No. 8653 would not be amended by using Section 9, (d) (3), Rule IV, 2017 ORAOHRA as basis, all the elected members of the City Council would be held administratively liable for nepotism as most of their personal and confidential staffs are related to them by affinity or consanguinity;
WHEREAS, as a corrective measure, the Manila City Council enacted City Ordinance No. 8712, basing it this time pursuant to Section 9, (d) (3), Rule IV, 2017 ORAOHRA instead of Section 9 (d) (1) and (2), Rule IV, 2017 ORAOHRA, thereby amending City Ordinance No. 8653;
WHEREAS, a review of the general functions of the foregoing items contained in the position description forms readily shows that the positions are primarily confidential in nature pursuant to the express declaration of law under Section 9 in relation to Section 59 of the 1987 Civil Service Law, to wit:
“SEC. 9. Non-Career Service.
XXX
The Non-Career Service shall include:
(1) Elective officials and their personal or confidential staff:”
(Emphasis and underscoring supplied)
“SEC. 59. Nepotism. — All appointments in the national, provincial, city and municipal governments or in any branch or instrumentality thereof, including government-owned or controlled corporations, made in favor of a relative of the appointing or recommending authority, or of the chief of the bureau or Office, or of the persons exercising immediate supervision over him, are hereby prohibited.
xxx
(2) The following are exempted from the operation of the rules on nepotism:
(a) persons employed in a confidential capacity, (b) teachers,
(c) physicians, and (d) members of the Armed Forces of the Philippines:
Provided, however, that in each particular instance full report of such appointment shall be made to the Commission.”
(Emphasis and underscoring supplied)
WHEREAS, being personal staffs of the Vice-Mayor, City Councilors, and standing committees of the City Council, the duties and responsibilities of the appointees therein imply not only confidence in the aptitude but primarily close intimacy with the elected officials, which ensures freedom from misgivings or betrayals of personal trust. The work involves constant exposure to sensitive policy matters and confidential deliberations that are not always open to the public, as unscrupulous persons may use them to harm the functions of the Sanggunian;
WHEREAS, the Vice-Mayor and City Councilors must have the highest confidence in their staffs and employees to ensure that their honest and legitimate sentiments are always and fully expressed in the interest of the city and general public. Not only do their tasks point to sensitive and confidential acts, they also include such other functions as the Councilors and the Vice-Mayor may direct and/or require, a clear indication of a closely intimate relationship. In such highly acquainted relation, great trust and confidence between the recommending and appointing authorities and the appointee is required;
WHEREAS, the subject items cannot belong to the career service classification, which will bestow upon them regular and permanent status, which will prejudice future councilors and vice-mayors, who will not have coterminous staff;
WHEREAS, the primarily confidential position titles given under CSC Memorandum Circular No. 12 s. 2011 are apparently limited. They pertain to items bearing nomenclatures belonging to the executive branch, but not to personnel performing legislative support work;
WHEREAS, the primarily confidential position titles given under CSC Memorandum Circular No. 12 s. 2011 have different Salary Grades from the items of the Sangguniang Panlungsod under consideration, which will require budgetary adjustments. Unfortunately, the City of Manila could not seek an increase in the appropriations for Salary of city personnel without violating the personal services limitations under the Local Government Code and DBM circulars: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT: 
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability and affordability.
The generic career position titles previously adopted in Ordinance No. 8653, as amended by Ordinance No. 8712 shall be reverted to Local Legislative Positions Titles for the coterminous primarily confidential employees of the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila, effective July 1, 2022.
Moreover, the plantilla position titles of the coterminous primarily confidential staff of the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila, shall now be treated as specified below:
FORMAT: Previous Position Title — Salary Grade — Previous Position Title — Salary Grade         
1.        Executive Assistant V — 24 — Executive Assistant V — 24
2.        Executive Assistant IV — 22 — Executive Assistant IV — 22
3.        Political Affairs Officer III — 19 —        Local Legislative Staff Officer IV — 19
4.        Senior Administrative Assistant IV — 16        — Local Legislative Staff Officer III — 16
5.        Senior Administrative Assistant I — 13 — Local Legislative Staff Officer II — 13
6.        Private Secretary I — 11 — Private Secretary I — 11
7.        Security Agent II — 10 — Security Agent II — 10
8.        Administrative Aide VI (Clerk III) — 6 — Local Legislative Staff Assistant I* — 6
9.        Administrative Aide IV (Clerk II) — 4 — Local Legislative Staff Employee II — 4
10.        Personal Driver/Chauffeur — 3 — Personal Driver/Chauffeur — 3
11.        Administrative Aide II (Messenger) — 2 — Local Legislative Staff Employee I (Messenger) — 2
12.        Administrative Aide I (Utility Worker) — 1 — Administrative Aide I — 1
*Item No. 8 in the Plantilla Position previously titled as Local Legislative Staff Employee III shall now be titled Local Legislative Staff Assistant I. The correction is a mere typographical error as manifested by the Majority Floor Leader during the session of the City Council on August 30, 2022.

SEC. 2. Qualifications, Powers and Duties and Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC) circulars including the Administrative Code of 1987, R.A. No. 6758, entitled: “AN ACT PRESCRIBING A REVISED COMPENSATION AND POSITION CLASSIFICATION SYSTEM IN THE GOVERNMENT AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES” and other relevant laws, rules and regulations.

SEC. 3. Appointments. — The employment and appointment for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed guidelines set forth by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 4. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the reversion to Local Legislative Positions Titles for the coterminous primarily confidential employees shall be sourced from available funds for this purpose as provided for under the 2022 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the complement staffs of the elective officials of the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila.

SEC. 5. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect retroactively on July 1, 2022.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 21, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance changes the job titles of certain Manila City Council employees back to their original legislative titles, reversing previous ordinances (Nos. 8653 and 8712) that gave them generic career position names. It emphasizes that these employees are primarily confidential staff—closely working with the Vice-Mayor and Councilors—and should not have permanent career titles, to avoid issues like nepotism and budget constraints. The ordinance ensures that these roles remain coterminous, meaning they end when the official they work for leaves office, and their functions involve trust, confidentiality, and legislative support. The change is retroactive starting July 1, 2022.

ORDINANCE NO. 8892

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING YUCHENGCO PLAZA ALONG THE EASEMENT OF THE PASIG RIVER PARTICULARLY LOCATED BESIDE MUELLE DEL BANCO NACIONAL IN BINONDO, MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on October 14, 2021, the City Council of Manila passed Resolution No. 222, Series of 2021, entitled: “A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR TO ENTER INTO A MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT WITH YGC CORPORATE SERVICES, INC., FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF A PLAZA ALONG THE WALKWAY OF MUELLE BANCO DEL NACIONAL, BINONDO, MANILA”;

WHEREAS, under the Memorandum of Agreement (MOA), YGC Corporate Services, Inc. (YGC) shall undertake the construction of a plaza along the Pasig River Linear Park beside Muelle Del Banco Nacional in Binondo, Manila, specifically traversing from Yuchengco Street up to Burke Street;

WHEREAS, the plaza shall have a total length of Two Hundred Eighty-Five Meters (285 M.), and shall showcase Philippine native trees. Lamp posts, benches, bollard lights, bike frames, and green spaces will also be installed to provide a scenic view of the Pasig River;

WHEREAS, it was also agreed upon by the parties that the plaza shall be named as “Plaza Yuchengco” subject to the enactment of an ordinance in compliance with the provision of Section 13(b)(5) of the Local Government Code of 1991:
NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Establishing the Plaza. — The portion of the Pasig River Linear Park beside Muelle Del Banco Nacional in Binondo, Manila, specifically Two Hundred Eighty-Five Meters (285 M.) in length and Five Meters (5 M.) in width, traversing from Yuchengco Street up to Burke Street, along the Pasig River, is hereby established and named as “Yuchengco Plaza”.

SEC. 2. Management and Maintenance. — The Parks and Development Office of the City of Manila is hereby mandated to manage the new plaza.

SEC. 3. New Road Signs. — The Department of Engineering and Public Works, and the City Planning and Development Office are hereby tasked to apply the necessary changes on road signs and maps.

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. — Should any provision herein be declared unconstitutional, the same shall not affect the validity of the other provisions of this Act.

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, decrees, orders, rules and regulations or other issuances or parts inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 19, 2022.
short_text: The City of Manila officially created a new public space called "Yuchengco Plaza" along the Pasig River, beside Muelle Del Banco Nacional in Binondo. full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8891

AN ORDINANCE INCENTIVIZING COVID-19 BOOSTER SHOTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, as of July 12, 2022, according to the Manila Public Information Office (MPIO), the City of Manila, through the Manila Health Department (MHD), had a total of 3,483,060 COVID-19 vaccines administered;

WHEREAS, within the said period, the City of Manila, through MHD, had administered a total of 639,508 COVID-19 booster shots and counting;

WHEREAS, an article of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) dated June 24, 2022, stated that COVID-19 vaccine boosters provide further enhancement and protection of the previously administered COVID-19 vaccines, as such, infection decreases over time;

WHEREAS, in an article of the Philippine News Agency dated April 19, 2022, stated that a possible COVID-19 surge may occur, and one of the contributory factors is the low COVID-19 booster shot rate in the Philippines;

WHEREAS, by virtue of Section 16 of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the “Local Government Code of 1991”, the City Government of Manila may exercise its powers, expressly granted, in the promotion of health and safety of its citizens, which further provides:

“Section 16. General Welfare. — Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”

WHEREAS, this would also help encourage the citizens of Manila to stay up-to-date with their COVID-19 vaccines by obtaining booster shots, which would provide the best protection against severe COVID-19 illness: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. An individual who is fully vaccinated against COVID-19, who is of legal age, an actual resident, and a registered voter of the City of Manila, and who shall receive his/her COVID-19 booster shot in the City of Manila shall receive an incentive in cash or any of its equivalent. The City of Manila shall form a partnership with private entities and organizations to provide for these incentives.

SEC. 2. An individual who is fully vaccinated against COVID-19 shall be defined as someone who has more than or equal to two (2) weeks after having received the second dose in a 2-dose vaccine; or more than or equal to two (2) weeks after having received a single-dose vaccine.
The vaccines administered to the individual must be included in any of the following:
1.        Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) List or Compassionate Special Permit (CSP) issued by the Philippine Food and Drug Administration; or
2.        Emergency Use Listing of the World Health Organization (WHO).

SEC. 3. The Committee on Health shall formulate policies and guidelines to fully implement this Ordinance, subject to the City Council's approval.

SEC. 4. If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. All ordinances, rules, and regulations in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed; PROVIDED, that the rights that are vested upon the effectivity of this Ordinance shall not be impaired.

SEC. 6.  This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval and publication.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 19, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance provides a cash or equivalent incentive to fully vaccinated adult residents of Manila who are also registered voters and receive their COVID-19 booster shot within the city. The City Government may partner with private entities to fund these incentives. The Committee on Health will establish the specific implementation guidelines, subject to City Council approval. Only vaccines approved by the Philippine FDA (via EUA or CSP) or the WHO are recognized under this program.
