ORDINANCE NO. 8883

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA, DULY REPRESENTED BY THE HONORABLE CITY MAYOR MARIA SHEILAH “HONEY” LACUNA-PANGAN, MD, FPDS, TO ENTER INTO A NEGOTIATED SALE WITH FELCASTER TORRES FOR A PROPERTY COVERED BY TCT NO. 198223 IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA AND TO EXECUTE AND SIGN THE DEED OF SALE AND OTHER IMPLEMENTING DOCUMENTS, AND TO SUBMIT THE SAME FOR RATIFICATION TO THE CITY COUNCIL UNDER SUCH TERMS AND CONDITIONS MOSTLY ADVANTAGEOUS TO THE CITY

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on 8 May 1998, the Sangguniang Panlungsod enacted Ordinance No. 7959 for the expropriation of several real properties located at Governor Forbes corner Maria Clara Streets, Sta. Cruz, Manila, to be subdivide and resold in installment basis to qualified and bone fide residents. Among those properties is a parcel of land covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 198223 with an area of Four Hundred Seventy-Five Square Meters (475 Sq. M.), more or less.

WHEREAS, on 20 May 2004, the City of Manila filed a complaint for eminent domain before the Regional Trial Court of Manila against the registered owners of TCT No. 198223, namely Anthony Torres, et. al. In a Decision dated 20 April, 2018, the RTC of Manila, Branch 30 dismissed the complaint for failure to comply with Republic Act No. 7279 otherwise known as the Urban Development and Housing Act of 1942. The City filed an appeal before the Court of Appeals but the same was denied. No further appeal was filed.

WHEREAS, in a letter dated 20 October, 2021, Felcaster Torres informed the city of his intention and that of his co-owners to sell the property to the city for Thirty Million Pesos (PhP. 30,000,000.00). The price was later or negotiated to Twenty-Six Million Six Hundred Twenty-Two Thousand One Hundred Twenty Pesos (PhP. 26,622,120.00).

WHEREAS, in an Indorsement dated 8 November 2021, OIC-City Assessor Atty. Marlon Lacson, submitted a Preliminary Appraisal Report which assessed the property to have a current or fair market value of Eighty-Three Thousand Nine Hundred Ninety-Eight Pesos and Forty Centavos (PhP. 83,998.40) per square meter or a total of Thirty-Nine Million Eight Hundred Ninety-Nine Thousand Two Hundred Forty Pesos (PhP. 39,899,240.00).

WHEREAS, in a letter dated 28 February 2022, the erstwhile City Mayor, Honorable Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso formally accepted the offer to sell of the subject property for the price of Twenty-Six Million Six Hundred Twenty-Two Thousand One Hundred Twenty Pesos (PhP. 26,622,120.00) which is less than its fair market value:
NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Authority to Purchase. — The City Government of Manila, duly represented by the City Mayor, is hereby authorized to enter into a negotiated sale with Felcaster Torres for a property covered by TCT No. 198223, with an area of Four Hundred Seventy-Five Square Meters (475 Sq. M.) more or less, located at Gov. Forbes (Lacson Ave.) cor. Maria Clara Street, Sampaloc, Manila.

SEC. 2. Distribution to Residents and Occupants. — The aforementioned parcel of land, when acquired, shall be subdivided and resold by the City Government of Manila to qualified and bona fide residents/occupants thereat, on installment basis for a period not exceeding twenty (20) years.

SEC. 3. Appropriation. — The City Government shall appropriate any available fund from its budget for the implementation of this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, orders, resolutions, rules and regulations or part thereof inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly. Specifically, the provisions pertaining to the expropriation of the subject property provided under Ordinance No. 7959 are hereby repealed.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 7, 2022.
short_text: The City of Manila is authorized to buy a property located at Gov. Forbes (Lacson Ave.) corner Maria Clara Street, Sampaloc, Manila, from Felcaster Torres and co-owners. The land will then be divided and sold on an installment basis (up to 20 years) to the current qualified residents living there. The negotiated purchase price is PhP26,622,120.00 — which is lower than the property’s fair market value — making the deal favorable to the city.

ORDINANCE NO. 8873

AN ORDINANCE IMPLEMENTING THE APPROPRIATE POSITION TITLE AND SALARY GRADE OF THE CITY VICE MAYOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES
PREAMBLE

HEREAS, the current Position title and Salary Grade (SG) of the Vice Mayor is City Vice Mayor at SG-29. This was adopted based on the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) letter dated April 26, 1991 of the Secretary Guillermo N. Carague, approving the request for the upgrading of the SG of the Vice Mayor from SG-28 to SG-29.

WHEREAS, the DBM Circular Letter (CL) No. 2007-6 (DBM’s Manual on Position
Classification and Compensation) dated February 19, 2007 and Local Budget Circular
(LBC) No. 137 (Index of Occupational Services, Position Titles and Salary Grades in the
Local Government - IOS - LGU) dated July 13, 2021, provided that the position title of the City Vice Mayor is City Vice Mayor II with the corresponding salary grade (SG) of SG-28;

WHEREAS, one of the observations of the DBM in its review of the FY 2022 Annual
Budget of the City of Manila, is that: the appropriate position title and SG of an elective official in Special Cities shall be effected upon vacancy in accordance with
CL No. 2007-6 and LBC No. 137, of which position is the following, to wit;

FROM:
Office: Office of the Vice-Mayor
Position Title: City Vice-Mayor
SG: 29

TO:
Position Title: City Vice-Mayor II
SG: 28

WHEREAS, to comply with the DBM review of the FY 2022 Annual Budget of the City of Manila, there is a need to implement the appropriate position title and salary grade
of the position City Vice Mayor: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. implementation of the Appropriate Position Title and Salary Grade of the City Vice Mayor Position. - Pursuant to DBM Circular Letter No. 2007-6 dated February 19, 2007 and Local Budget Circular No. 137 dated July 13, 2021, the appropriate position title and salary grade of the City Vice Mayor under the office of the Vice Mayor is hereby  implemented as follows:

FROM:
Office: Office of the Vice-Mayor
Position Title: City Vice-Mayor
SG: 29

TO:
Position Title: City Vice-Mayor II
SG: 28

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — The herein change in the position title and salary grade of the City Vice Mayor position shall be made effective upon vacancy of the incumbent to the said position.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 16, 2022.
short_text: aligns the position title and salary grade of the City Vice Mayor with the latest Department of Budget and Management (DBM) guidelines. It changes the title from City Vice-Mayor (SG-29) to City Vice-Mayor II (SG-28), as mandated by DBM Circular Letter No. 2007-6 and LBC No. 137. This adjustment will take effect only upon the vacancy of the current officeholder.

ORDINANCE NO. 8872

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8119, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “MANILA COMPREHENSIVE LAND USE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE OF 2006” TO INCLUDE THE MANILA  WATERFRONT CITY PROJECT

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Manila Waterfront City is a 318-hectare high-value and high-density
development that will rise in Manila Bay within the territorial waters of the City of Manila. It has a two (2)-island reclamation development with urban parks and waterways
reminiscent of Manila’s past waterways and riverside development but with a modern and
green touch;

WHEREAS, the Project Area shall be as defined and limited to the metes and bounds as stipulated in the attached technical description submitted to the City Government of Manila for approval:

WHEREAS, the first island is 154.70 hectares and the second island is 163.30 hectares, therefore with total combined area of 318 hectares. Two (2) sixty-meter wide water channels separate the two islands to provide for additional waterfronts accessible
to the public and to flush out stagnant water around the entire development;

WHEREAS, Manila Waterfront City’s ground surface will be at a minimum of four
(4) meters above sea level. It will be higher than most of the coastal areas of the City of Manila. The perimeter of the islands will be protected by revetment or sea wall of rocks and boulders. This will protect the islands from strong waves and storm surges and
ensure that they will not be eroded back to the sea. Also, the perimeter of the development includes landscaping promenades for public use to experience a more beautiful Manila Sunset baywalk experience:

The development will be the new Central Business District for the City of Manila
with a Density Floor Area Ratio (FAR) of 15:

WHEREAS, around sixty (60) million cubic meters of sand filling materials will be
required to reclaim Manila Waterfront City. It will be sourced from sea bed quarries within Manila Bay. This is to prevent the entry of materials from inland quarries that might pollute the Bay. The use of inland sources is not encouraged because it will require thousands of trucks that will further congest the traffic and damage the city roads. The filling materials will be selected and compacted to address the concerns on earthquake and liquefaction;

WHEREAS, Manila Waterfront City will be highly accessible to its residents and the general public. Two main bridges will connect MWC, one bridge at Kalaw Street, and
second bridge at Katigbak/P Burgos Street. A city-wide monorail system is planned to
interconnect with Manila Waterfront City’s own people mover system. It will enhance its
accessibility. Sufficient utility infrastructure will be provided to be responsive to the
requirements of the development. Water, power and telecommunications will be assured
in Manila Waterfront City. Green Technology will be employed where applicable and
practical: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session duly assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “MANILA WATERFRONT CITY RECLAMATION PROJECT” for brevity.

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. - It is the policy of the city to pursue developmental projects and towards this end the reclamation of a specific area based on the specifications submitted by the proponent Waterfront Manila Premier Development, Inc. and within the limits and specifications set forth by competent authorities is hereby  authorized.
SEC. 3. Scope of Reclamation. — Land Allocation Plan and the Master Plan prepared by the international master planning firm AECOM and submitted by the proponent, showing location of the require 5% green space, proposed land use and allocation in accordance with the Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) between the Philippine Reclamation Authority (PRA) and the City of Manila, as well as its updates, shall define the scope of the reclamation project.

SEC. 4. Amending Ordinance No. 8119. - The Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan and Zoning Ordinance of 2006, as amended, is hereby further amended to include the Manila Waterfront City. The City Planning and Development Office is hereby directed to amend the Official Zoning Maps.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 16, 2022
short_text: amends the 2006 Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan and Zoning Ordinance (Ordinance No. 8119) to formally incorporate the Manila Waterfront City Project, a 318-hectare twin-island reclamation development in Manila Bay. The ordinance authorizes the project based on specifications submitted by Waterfront Manila Premier Development, Inc., including the allocation of green space, infrastructure provisions, and the use of green technology. The project aims to establish a new Central Business District with improved accessibility and environmental safeguards.

ORDINANCE NO. 8871

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING VARIOUS ITEMS UNDER THE PERSONAL SERVICES THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2022 ANNUAL BUDGET TO COVER THE REQUIREMENTS FOR TWENTY-EIGHT (28) ADDITIONAL PLANTILLA POSITIONS OF THE OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF TEN MILLION TWO HUNDRED THIRTY-SIX THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED SIXTEEN PESOS (PHP. 10,236,216.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the FY 2022 Annual Budget appropriated funds for various items under the Personal Services (PS);

WHEREAS, after due consideration, there is a need to augment various items under the FY 2022 Annual Budget through savings from other accounts of the FY 2022 Annual Budget to ensure the effective and efficient delivery of priority programs and projects of the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, the City Treasurer and the City Accountant has issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash as supporting document to the herein savings and augmentation.

WHEREAS, Section 336 of the Local Government Code, Use of Appropriated Funds and Savings, provides that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expenses class of their respective appropriations;

WHEREAS, the City Council approved Ordinance No. 8805, entitled: “An Ordinance Expanding the Plantilla Positions of the “Bagong Ospital ng Maynila”. Of the One Hundred Fifty (150) created plantilla positions thereon, One Hundred Twenty-Two (122) plantilla items has been previously subject of augmentation through Ordinance No. 8866, enacted by the City Council on May 16, 2022:

WHEREAS, after evaluation, it was determined that there is a need to also augment the appropriate Personal Services accounts to cover the requirements for the remaining twenty-eight (28) plantilla positions for the efficient operation of the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center,

WHEREAS, the City Council approved Resolution No. 07, Series of 2022, of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: “A Resolution approving the amendment of the Annual Investment Program and Issuance of a Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2022 in relation to the Augmentation of Various Items under the Personal Services (PS) through Savings from the FY 2022 Annual Budget in the total amount of Ten Million Two Hundred Thirty-Six Thousand Two Hundred Sixteen Pesos (PHP 10,236,216.00)": NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Augmentation. — The hereunder items of appropriation under various accounts shall be augmented through savings from the FY 2022 Annual Budget:

Personal Services:

A. Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center

- Salaries and Wages-Regular: PHP 6,917,178.00
- Personnel Economic Relief Allowance (PERA): PHP 324,000.00
- Clothing/Uniform Allowance: PHP 168,000.00
- Subsistence Allowance: PHP 106,920.00
- Laundry Allowance: PHP 20,250.00
- Hazard Pay: PHP 405,000.00
- Year End Bonus: PHP 1,152,863.00
- Cash Gift: PHP 140,000.00
- Retirement and Life Insurance Premiums: PHP 830,061.00
- PAG-IBIG Contributions: PHP 16,800.00
- PHILHEALTH Contributions: PHP 138,344.00
- Employees Compensation Insurance Premiums: PHP 16,800.00

TOTAL: PHP 10,236,216.00

SEC. 2. Fund Sources. — The total funds in the amount of Ten Million Two Hundred Thirty-Six Thousand Two Hundred Sixteen Pesos (PhP. 10,236,216.00) for the abovementioned expenditures shall be sourced from savings from the following appropriations:

Personal Services

A. Special Purpose Appropriations (SPA)
- Special Activities Fund — PS: PHP 10,236,216.00

TOTAL: PHP 10,236,216.00

Attached are the following details:
Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS for Augmentation of Funds; and

Annex B — Augmentation of PS Account under the FY 2022 Annual Budget

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 16, 2022.
short_text: authorizes the augmentation of funds under the FY 2022 Annual Budget using savings from Personal Services to support 28 additional plantilla positions at Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center. The total amount of PhP 10,236,216.00 will cover salaries, allowances, and benefits, ensuring operational efficiency and continuity in healthcare services. This funding follows previous augmentations for 122 positions under Ordinance No. 8866 and aligns with the approved amendments in the city's Supplemental Investment Program.

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 458(3)(v) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local  Government Code of 1991 empowers the City Council to “authorize and license the establishment, operation, and maintenance of cockpits, and regulate cockfighting and commercial breeding of gamecocks: Provided, That existing rights should not be  prejudiced”:

WHEREAS, Bienes De Manila Development Corporation, a corporation duly organized and existing under and by virtue of Philippine laws, with address at 1785 Yangco Street, Tondo, Manila, submitted its application to be granted a franchise to operate a cockpit arena specifically at the VIB Compound, Vitas St., Tondo, Manila.

WHEREAS, upon consideration of the guidelines in the grant of franchise to
operate cockpit as provided for and prescribed under existing laws, it appears that Bienes De Manila Development Corporation had substantially complied with the requirements to operate a cockpit arena: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Nature and Scope of Franchise. — Subject to the provisions of applicable laws, rules and regulations, a franchise to operate and maintain a cockpit within the City of Manila is hereby granted to Bienes De Manila Development Corporation. As such, BDMC is authorized to establish and operate one (1) cockpit arena specifically located at VIB Compound, Vitas Street, Tondo, Manila.

SEC. 2. Period of Validity. - Unless sooner revoked or cancelled, this franchise
Shall be valid for a period of twenty-five (25) years from June 1, 2022 until June 1, 2047, with the option on the part of the Grantee to renew the same for a similar period and subject to the approval of the City Council.

SEC. 3. Authority of the Office of the Mayor. — The Grantee shall apply and
secure the necessary business permit and other relative permits to operate a business
within the City. The Office of the Mayor shall have authority to require compliance of all existing laws, ordinances, rules, and regulations Similarly imposed to all business
establishments, and impose conditions thereto as are expressly or impliedly necessary
for the protection of the welfare and Safety of all persons going or transacting in said
cockpit.

SEC. 4. Prohibition on Sale, Lease, Usufruct and Transfer of Franchise. — The Grantee shall not sell, assign, lease, grant the usufruct of, or transfer this franchise including any rights and privileges acquired thereunder to any person, nor merge with any
corporation or individual without the prior notice and approval of the City Council.

SEC. 5. Mandatory Payment of Taxes and Fees. — The Grantee shall be liable to pay all taxes and other fees prescribed under existing laws. Said assessments shall be without prejudice to the subsequent impositions as may be adopted or hereafter may be required by law or ordinance. Failure on the part of the grantee to promptly and regularly comply with said tax obligations shall be a ground for the revocation or cancellation of this
franchise.

SEC. 6. Prohibition Against Minors. - No person under 18 years of age shall be allowed inside the premises of the cockpits during cockfights. The operator, manager or licensee shall be responsible for strict compliance with these rules and violation thereof is punishable by suspension or cancellation of license to operate cockpits without prejudice to criminal prosecution under existing ordinance or laws.
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Augmentation. — The hereunder items of appropriation under various accounts shall be augmented through savings from the FY 2022 Annual Budget:

Personal Services:

A. Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center

Sub-Total: PHP 32,263,908.00

- Other Maintenance and Operating Expenses: 17,600,000.00
Sub-Total: PHP 66,079,000.00

GRAND TOTAL: PHP 98,342,908.00

SEC. 2. Available Funds. — The total funds in the amount of Ninety-Eight Million Three Hundred Forty-Two Thousand Nine Hundred Eight Pesos (PHP 98,342,908.00) for the foregoing expenditures shall be sourced from savings from the following appropriations:

and

The ordinance serves dual objectives: (1) granting a 25-year franchise to Bienes De Manila Development Corporation (BDMC) to operate a cockpit arena at VIB Compound, Vitas Street, Tondo, Manila; and (2) allocating PHP 98,342,908.00 to support critical operational needs of the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center and select city departments.

ORDINANCE NO. 8865

AN ORDINANCE APPROVING THE FIVE-YEAR INSTITUTIONAL DEVELOPMENT
PLAN OF THE UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA (UDM), AS APPROVED BY ITS BOARD OF
REGENTS, PURSUANT TO SECTION 23 OF MANILA CITY ORDINANCE (MCO)
NO. 8750, THE CHARTER OF UDM, WHICH AMENDED MCO NOS. 7885, 8120 AND
8635, PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Universidad de Manila (UDM) has come a long way as an educational institution since it was established by the City Government of Manila way back in 1995 as the then City College of Manila (CCM);

WHEREAS, the current administration of the City of Manila led by Mayor Francisco "Isko Moreno" Domagoso, who is also the ex-officio Chairman of the Board of Regents of UDM, seeks the Commission on Higher Education's (CHED) recognition of UDM as a HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTION or "HEI";

WHEREAS, should UDM obtain HEI status upon due recognition and conferment by CHED, UDM will then be a rightful recipient of various substantial subsidies and/or funding from the National Government that will surely boost UDM's institutional capabilities to provide accessible, free and quality education to the youth of the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, in order for UDM to successfully obtain CHED's "institutional recognition" as an HEI, UDM needs to comply with CHED's requirements as stated under CHED Memorandum Order (CMO) No. 32, Series of 2006 and CMO No. 42, Series of 2016, both CMOs being the bases of CHED's "Validation Tool", entitled: "Compliance to Requirements for Recognition as Higher Education Institution/Certificate of Authority to establish a Higher Education Institution";

WHEREAS, pursuant to CMO No. 32, Series of 2006, particularly Section 2(d) or Article V thereof, there should be "a five-year institutional development plan duly approved by the Sanggunian which shall include but not limited to the following a) annual budgetary allocation...";

WHEREAS, pursuant to Section 23 of Manila City Ordinance (MCO) No. 8750, the Charter of the Universidad de Manila (UDM), which amended MCO Nos. 7885, 8120 and 8635, the City Council shall approve the Institutional Development Plan (IDP) submitted by UDM, as duly approved by the latter's Board of Regents, to ensure that said IDP of UDM be incorporated and/or integrated into the formulation of the corresponding plans and budget of the City Government of Manila: NOW, THEREFORE,    

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. - It shall hereby be declared the policy of the City of Manila to be genuinely committed, in consonance with the policy of the State, in promoting the right of all citizens to quality education at all levels and to make such education accessible to all.   

SEC. 2. Approval of the Institutional Development Plan (IDP) of the Universidad de Manila (UDM). - Pursuant to Section 23 of Manila City Ordinance (MCO) No. 8750, the Charter of the Universidad de Manila (UDM), which amended MCO Nos. 7885, 8120 and 8635, the City Council shall approve the Institutional Development Plan (IDP) submitted by UDM, as duly approved by the latter's Board of Regents, to ensure that said IDP of UDM be incorporated and/or integrated into the formulation of the corresponding plans and budget of the City Government of Manila.

As such, the IDP of UDM, as cited below, is hereby approved by the City Council through this Ordinance:   

AGENDA/OBJECTIVES & BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS    

1. Achieving Higher Education Institution by Fostering Academic Excellence
1.1. To ensure all program both undergraduate and graduate levels are fully recognized by the Commission on Higher Education
1.2. To uphold and sustain Quality Assurance
1.3. To heighten graduate performance in professional licensure examination
1.4. To deliver support services for the all-inclusive development of students
1.5. Gender Sensitivity and Parity in Education
1.6. Strengthen UDM's unflinching commitment for Teacher Empowerment

2.4. Enhance professional growth opportunities for all members of the university scientific community
2.5. Publish high impact articles to communicate scholarly outcomes relevant to real-world solutions while building reputation and visibility for the university
2.6. Establish a knowledge center, research infrastructure and sound data management to strategically support research initiatives
2.7. Establish an extension service enriched by a synergistic approach of connecting academic curricula to meaningful community services by providing leadership, partnership, and opportunities
2.8. Allocate research budget and actively seek private and public funding to invest multi-disciplinary high impact educational research projects

3.3. To identifies activities and/or strategies used to maintain currency in the faculty member's credential field, developed creative opportunities, and in teaching and learning skills
3.4. To ensure Marketing & Budget Planning success for CMIT Programs
3.5. To determine the physical resources of the institution consisting of the hardware critically determine the success of the major programs includes infrastructure and other facilities which the university/CMIT need in pursuit of its goals
3.6. To ensure a strong partnership with industries

5. Expanding Community Extension Services and Linkages

5.2. To develop a more responsive programs, projects, and activities (PPAs) implemented in the adopted community (Barangay 649)
5.3. To maximize utilization of adopted communities and partner institutions/organizations on various academic and non-academic programs of the university
5.4. To increase the number of adopted Community

AGENDA/OBJECTIVES & BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS (Cont.) 
5.5. To strengthen linkage from government and non-government institutions/organizations
5.6. Strengthen and deepen the social responsibility through volunteerism among faculty, non-teaching personnel and students through involvement in socially relevant, politically active, and environmentally conscious initiatives

SEC. 3. Appropriations. - The amounts needed to carry out the implementation of the above-cited IDP of UDM shall be incorporated into the annual budget allocated to UDM by the City Government of Manila, subject to availability of funds and the needs of the entire City of Manila and the various departments and instrumentalities of the City Government of Manila.   

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. Should any provision herein be declared unconstitutional, the same shall not affect the validity of the other provisions of this Ordinance.   

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. - All previous ordinances, orders, rules, regulations and issuances or parts thereof inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.   

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.   

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 28, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance approves the Five-Year Institutional Development Plan (IDP) of Universidad de Manila (UDM), as endorsed by its Board of Regents, in compliance with CHED requirements to gain official status as a Higher Education Institution (HEI). The IDP outlines goals in academic excellence, research, industry training, administrative services, and community outreach, with a total planned budget exceeding ₱3.3 billion from FY 2021 to FY 2026. The City Government of Manila commits to integrating the IDP into its annual budget, subject to available funds.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8816

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8323, CREATING
THE MANILA DISASTER RISK REDUCTION AND MANAGEMENT OFFICE
(MDRRMO), AS AMENDED, BY MODIFYING ITS COMPOSITION, FUNCTIONS AND
STRUCTURE AND BY REVISING THE PLANTILLA OF POSITIONS THROUGH THE
ABOLITION OF UNNECESSARY POSITIONS AND CREATING NEW ALIGNED ITEMS
UNDER THE SCRAP AND BUILD STRATEGY, REPEALING FOR THIS PURPOSE
CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8518

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on 4 April 2014, the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC), the Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG), the Department of Budget and Management (DBM), and the Civil Service Commission (CSC) issued Joint Memorandum Circular (JMC) No. 2014-1, which provides for the implementing guidelines on the establishment of the Local Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (LDRRMO) for different local government units;

WHEREAS, the LDRRMO shall serve as the Secretariat of the Local Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (LDRRMC) pursuant to Section 12 (c) (18) of Republic Act (RA) 10121;

WHEREAS, the LDRRMC shall be composed of, but not limited, to the agencies and/or offices within the local government unit as stated under Section 11 (a) of RA 10121;

WHEREAS, Executive Order No. 22, Series of 2021, was issued by the Mayor of the City of Manila reconstituting and expanding the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (MDRRMC) pursuant to RA 10121 to ensure the critical and timely response and enhanced monitoring of the city equipped with vigilant personnel in times of adversities;

WHEREAS, the City Government of Manila desires to align itself to the guidelines and policies of the National Government and adopt holistic, comprehensive and proactive approach in delivering unhampered public service to its constituents;

WHEREAS, on the 13th day of August 2013, the City Council enacted City Ordinance No. 8323, entitled: "AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE MANILA DISASTER RISK REDUCTION AND MANAGEMENT OFFICE, DEFINING ITS DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES, PROVIDING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES", which was approved by the City Mayor on September 04, 2013;

WHEREAS, the City Government of Manila amended Ordinance No. 8323 with the passage by the City Council of Manila on October 25, 2016, of City Ordinance No. 8518 which modified, among others, the structure of the MDRRMO by creating five (5) sections, namely; (1) Manila Civil Defense Force, (2) Disaster and Medical Assistance Team, (3) Communications Emergency Readiness Team, (4) Disaster Mortuary, and (5) Climate Change Adaptation Team;

WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 8518 likewise provided for the creation of positions, salary grade and qualifications of a total of eighty-seven (87) varying position titles;

WHEREAS, Number 5.0 of the said Joint Memorandum Circular provides for the proper designation of the Organization and Composition of the LDRRMO;

WHEREAS, Number 6.2 of the said Joint Memorandum prescribes the appropriate salary grades and minimum standard qualifications for each position titles;

WHEREAS, the reorganization and restructuring of positions in the MDRRMO are needed due to the non-compliance of City Ordinance No. 8518 to JMC No. 2014-01, wherein indicated positions and sections are deemed unnecessary and tend to have lower qualifications despite having higher salary grades than prescribed thereto;

WHEREAS, the objectives of this Ordinance are, as follows: (a) create necessary positions found in JMC 2014-01, RA 10121, LBC 137 and other relevant civil service laws, (b) abolish all unnecessary positions while aligning needed items for equitable distribution among the three (3) identified divisions, (c) provide opportunities for the development and promotion of existing and qualified personnel, and (d) fix and prescribe the qualification standards for the new positions to be created: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Purpose. - This Ordinance is promulgated to reorganize and align the positions under the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO) and create necessary positions as prescribed by the Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2014-1, Local Budget Circular No. 137, and other relevant Civil Service Commission Laws and Guidelines to achieve its goals in strengthening the City's capacity for Disaster Risk Reduction and Crisis Management and building resilient communities from disasters including climate change impacts, as mandated by Republic Act No. 10121.

SEC. 2. Repeal of Ordinance No. 8518. - City Ordinance No. 8518, entitled: "AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8323, ENTITLED, "AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE MANILA DISASTER RISK REDUCTION AND MANAGEMENT OFFICE, DEFINING ITS DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES, PROVIDING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES", is hereby repealed in its entirety.

Sections No. 2 (Amendment to the MDRRMC Composition), No. 3 (Amendment to the MDRRMO Functions), and No. 4 (Amendment to the Structure of MDRRMO) of Ordinance No. 8518, amending Ordinance No. 8323, are herewith revoked accordingly.

SEC. 3. Amendment to the MDRRMC Composition. - Pursuant to Executive Order No. 22, Series of 2021, Section 8 of Chapter 3 of Ordinance No. 8323 is hereby further amended to include the Director-Head, Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office as Executive Director of the MDRRMC.

Likewise, the following Heads and Chiefs of Offices, Departments and Groups or their authorized representatives shall be added as members of the MDRRMC, as follows:

"SEC. 8. Composition. The Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (MDRRMC) shall be composed of the following:

(a) Chairman - City Mayor
(b) Vice-Chairman - City Vice Mayor
(c) Executive Director - Head, MDRRMO
(d) Members-City Administrator
City Council Chairperson for Police, Peace and Order, Fire and Public Safety
-City Council Chairperson for Barangay Affairs
-Chief, City Planning and Development Office
-Chief, City Health Office
-Chief, City Engineering Office
-Head, Gender and Development Office
-Head, Social Welfare and Development Office
-Chief, City Veterinary Office
-City Schools Superintendent
-The highest-ranking officer of the Armed Forces of the Philippines assigned in the city
-Chief of Police assigned in the city
-City Fire Marshal assigned in the city
-Head, Philippine Red Cross, Manila
-Director-Head of Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau
-Station Commander - Coast Guard Station Manila, Philippine Coast Guard
-Director, Parks and Development Office
-President of Liga ng mga Barangay
-President of SK Federation
-City General Services Officer
-City Accountant
-City Budget Officer
-City Treasurer
-City Legal Officer
-City Information Officer
-City Personnel Officer
-City Civil Registrar
-City Tourism Officer
-Head of Business Permits and Licensing Office
-Director of Manila Barangay Bureau
-Head of Market Division

-Head of Motorpool Division
-Director of Department of Public Services
-Local Economy and Investment Promotion Officer (LEIPO)
-Representative from the Academe
-Representative from CSO
-Representative from NGO
-Representative from Private Sector"

SEC. 4. Amendment to the MDRRMO Functions. - Section 12, Chapter 4 of Ordinance No. 8323, is hereby further amended by adding items (h) and (i), as follows:

"SEC. 12. FUNCTIONS. - The MDRRMO, in coordination with the concerned national and local agencies and instrumentalities, shall perform the following functions with impartiality given the emerging challenge brought about by the disasters:

(h) Take full control and responsibility of the Manila Disaster Emergency Operations Center (MDEOC) and establish a 24-hour basis which will serve as the data repository and coordinating body of the MDRRMO; and

(i) Perform such other functions as may be assigned by the MDRRMC."

SEC. 5. Amendment to the structure of MDRRMO. - Section 13 of Ordinance No. 8323 shall be modified to simplify and streamline the functions of the MDRRMO in conformity with Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2014-1, and shall read as follows:

"SEC. 13. STRUCTURE OF THE MDRRMO. - The Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO) shall be under the Office of the City Mayor. It shall have three (3) major divisions, namely:

1. Administrative and Training Division (ATD)
2. Operations and Warning Division (OWD)
3. Research and Planning Division (RPD)

SEC. 6. MDRRMO Proposed Organizational Structure. With the repeal of Sec. 13.a (Positions, Salary Grade and Qualifications) under Section 4 of Ordinance No. 8518, the following organizational structure is hereby created under the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO) effective in the 2023 City Executive Budget:

SEC. 10. Appointments. - The employment and appointment for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 11. short_text: Ordinance No. 8816 restructures the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO) by realigning its structure and positions to national standards using a scrap-and-build approach. It repeals Ordinance No. 8518, reorganizes the MDRRMO into three main divisions, and ensures more efficient disaster preparedness and response. The ordinance abolishes redundant plantilla positions and replaces them with more responsive roles in line with disaster risk management needs. Overall, it strengthens the city's capacity to handle emergencies and streamline operations under the MDRRMO.

ORDINANCE NO. 8815

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8119, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “MANILA COMPREHENSIVE LAND USE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE OF 2006” TO INCLUDE IN ITS COVERAGE RECLAMATION PROJECTS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on March 16, 2006, the Sangguniang Panlungsod passed Ordinance No. 8119, otherwise known as the “Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan and Zoning Ordinance of 2006":

WHEREAS, the above-mentioned Ordinance did not include in its coverage
reclamation projects within the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, in view of the numerous approved and proposed reclamation projects to be undertaken in the City of Manila, there is a need to regulate said projects to protect the interest of the City and at the same time, protect the environment and general welfare;

WHEREAS, there is a need to amend Ordinance No. 8119 in order to update the same and include in its coverage reclamation projects within the City of Manila: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. AMENDMENT OF ORDINANCE NO. 8119. — Ordinance No. 8119 is
hereby furthermore amended by adding the following provisions, to wit:

“SEC. 52-A. Reclamation Permit. — No person, corporation or entity shall undertake any reclamation works or projects, regardless of the depth or area to be reclaimed (or shall construct any structure or edifice on reclaimed land) within the city waters of the City of Manila without first securing a Reclamation Permit issued by the Office of the Mayor.

SEC. 52-B. Procedure for the issuance of Reclamation Permit. — The
following procedures shall be followed:

1. Application and Receipt. — The developer of any reclamation development activity/ies to be conducted in the City waters, regardless of depth or area to be reclaimed shall submit the following documents to the Office of the Mayor:

a. Letter of Intent;
b. Company Profile;
c. Notice to Proceed issued by the Philippine Reclamation Authority;
d. Notice to Proceed issued by the City of Manila for reclamation projects under Joint Venture with the City;
e. Environmental Compliance Certificate;
f. Master Development Plan duly approved by the City;
g. Zoning and Land Use Plan duly approved by the City;
h. Affidavit executed by the developer attesting that it has complied with all requirements and conditions prior to actual reclamation works under the Notices to Proceed issued by the Philippine Reclamation Authority and the City and the Environment Compliance Certificate;

i. Proof of compliance with all requirements and conditions prior to actual reclamation works under the Notices to Proceed issued by the Philippine Reclamation Authority and the City and the Environmental Compliance HM Certificate: and
j. Digital PDF copies of all the documents mentioned in the above saved in a Universal Serial Bus (USB);

2. Review and Recommendation.

2.1 Within five (5) working days from receipt of the documents mentioned in the immediately preceding paragraph, the Office of the Mayor shall then FORWARD digital copies of the said documents to the City Planning and Development Office, Department of Engineering and Public Works and Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office.

2.2 Said Offices shall, within thirty (30) working days from receipt thereof, review the documents submitted and make a written recommendation to the Office of the Mayor whether to approve or disapprove the application.

2.3 In case of recommendation of disapproval, the Office of the Mayor shall immediately notify the applicant in writing. The applicant shall be given forty-five (45) working days within which to submit or address the deficiencies noted in the letter disapproving the application. Should the applicant fail to submit or address the deficiencies within the said period, the application shall be deemed denied. However, nothing in this section shall bar the applicant from making a new application which will be subjected to the same process as herein stated.

3. Action of Application for Reclamation Permit. — In case of favorable recommendation for approval by the City Planning and Development Office and Department of Engineering and Public Works, the Office of the Mayor shall review said recommendation and decide whether or not to approve the application for Reclamation Permit.

3.1 Approval of Reclamation Permit. Should the Office of the Mayor approve the application for Reclamation Permit, it shall endorse the application and its supporting documents to the City Planning and Development Office for preparation of Order of Payment.

3.2 Disapproval of Reclamation Permit. Should the Office of the Mayor
disapprove the application for Reclamation Permit, it shall inform the
applicant in writing stating the reason/s for disapproval.

3.2.1 The applicant may move for reconsideration of disapproval within
the ten (10) working days from receipt of the letter from the Office
of the Mayor disapproving its application for Reclamation Permit.

3.2.2 The Office of the Mayor shall act on the request for  reconsideration within ten (10) days from receipt. The decision of the Office of the Mayor shall be final and not be subject to any further appeal of request for reconsideration.

4. Reclamation Permit Fee. — Upon receipt of the endorsement from the Office of the Mayor, the City Planning and Development Office shall prepare the Order of Payment for the Reclamation Permit Fee equivalent to Fifteen Thousand Five Hundred Twenty-Five Pesos (PHP 15,525.00) per hectare of the land to be reclaimed as appearing in the Master Development Plan submitted by the applicant.

4.1 The said fee shall be paid by the applicant within three (3) working days from receipt of Order of Payment.
4.2 Failure to pay by the applicant within the above-mentioned period shall result in the automatic disapproval of the application for Reclamation Permit.

5. Release of Reclamation Permit. — Upon presentment of proof of payment of Reclamation Permit Fee, the Office of the Mayor shall immediately release the Reclamation Permit in favor of the applicant.

SEC. 52-C. — Other permits relative to the actual reclamation works. The Reclamation Permit referred to in this section covers only the permit to commence reclamation works. Other permits such as but not limited to Business Permit, Building Permit, Fencing Permit, and Dredging Permit that may be needed by the applicant to implement the reclamation project/s will have to be applied for with the concerned office/s of the City.

SEC. 2. REPEALING CLAUSE. -— All ordinances, rules or regulations in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed.

SEC. 3. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 7, 2022.
short_text:
This ordinance updates Manila’s 2006 zoning rules (Ordinance No. 8119) by officially including all reclamation projects within its coverage. Anyone planning to reclaim land within Manila’s waters must now secure a Reclamation Permit from the Mayor’s Office. A detailed application, review, and approval process is outlined, including a permit fee of PHP 15,525.00 per hectare. Other necessary city permits must still be secured separately.

Key Provisions:

Reclamation projects must secure a Reclamation Permit before starting.

Permit process includes submission of documents, inter-office review, and payment of fees.

Permit fee: Php15,525 per hectare

Separate permits (e.g., business, building, fencing) are still required.
fines: applications can be denied or canceled for non-compliance

ORDINANCE NO. 8814

AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING THE “BILIS DELIVERY” PROJECT OF THE
CITY’S BUSINESS PERMITS AND LICENSES OFFICE, FIXING THE RATE OF FEES,
AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Republic Act No. 11032, also known as the Ease of Doing Business and Efficient Government Service Delivery Act of 2018 was enacted to mandate all government offices and agencies including local government units (LGUs), Government-Owned and Controlled Corporations (GOCCs) and other government instrumentalities to provide services covering business and non-business related transactions, which adopts
simplified procedures that will reduce red tape and expedite  transactions in government;

WHEREAS, in compliance with the Ease of Doing Business and Efficient
Government Service Delivery Act of 2018 and its Implementing Rules and Regulations, there is a need for the city to adopt a simplified procedure in all its operations, including the release of such as but not limited to documents, licenses, and permits to the applicants through courier and other transport and logistics services by using a
technology company that can provide these services through reliable web and mobile applications and a good management system;

WHEREAS, the city passed City Ordinance Nos. 8754 and 8760 providing for the streamlined procedures for the issuance of local business licenses, clearances, permits, certifications or authorizations in the City of Manila, pursuant to Rule IX of the Implementing Rules and Regulations of Republic Act No. 11032, and for other purposes;

WHEREAS, the city passed Resolution No. 209 authorizing the Local Chief Executive to enter into a contract or agreement with any reputable software development company for web service software development for a smart city local government e-services system integration, including real property tax administration, business permit and licensing system, public rental market information system and other e-service integrations;

WHEREAS, the city has been implementing the smart city local government e-services system integration through the Go Manila Platform;

WHEREAS, in order to fully implement the recitals under Republic Act No. 11032, there is a need to provide courier services for the delivery of documents relevant to applications of Permits and Licenses to the City Government of Manila, release of the same to the applicants, and to fix the rates therefor: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. — This Ordinance shall be known as "AN
ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING THE “BILIS DELIVERY” PROJECT OF THE CITY
PURSUANT TO REPUBLIC ACT NO. 11032".

SEC. 2. TRANSACTIONS GOVERNED. - All transactions involving the issuance of permits and licenses and other documents issued by the City Government of Manila.

SEC. 3. RATES. — The rates for the delivery of documents to and from the City Government of Manila are fixed as follows:

Service: Large Envelope 

Description: Pick-up of documents related to securing business permits/licenses/ certification issued by the City Government of Manila and delivery to the location of the client.

Cost: PHP 180.00 

Service: Large Envelope RUSH

Description: Pick-up of documents related to securing business permits/licenses/ certification issued by the City Government of Manila and delivery to the location of the client, within 1-3 days from release of the document.

Cost: PHP 230.00
SEC. 4. AUTHORITY TO ENTER INTO AGREEMENTS. - For purposes of this
Ordinance, the City Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into agreements with private courier services companies as necessary subject to the strict observance of laws and issuances on the matter

SEC. 5. APPROPRIATION. - There is hereby appropriated for the implementation of the “BILIS DELIVERY” Project of the city in the amount of TWELVE MILLION PESOS (PHP 12,000,000.00), subject to availability of funds.

SEC. 6. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - If, for any reason, any part of this Ordinance is invalidated by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining portion of this Ordinance, not thereby invalidated shall remain in full force and effect

SEC. 7. REPEALING CLAUSE. — All other laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
March 3, 2022.
short_text:
This ordinance formally establishes the “Bilis Delivery” project, a courier service by the Manila Business Permits and Licenses Office for faster delivery of permits, licenses, and official documents to applicants. Citizens can now choose document delivery via standard or rush courier service through the Go Manila Platform. The city sets fixed rates and allocates  PhP12 million for the program.

Delivery Fees:

Standard:  PhP180.00 (Large Envelope)

Rush (1–3 days):  PhP230.00 (Large Envelope)

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, categorically provides:

“Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. — Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation, and the sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations subject to the provisions of this Section.”

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the City Government of Manila, under the able leadership of His Honor, Mayor Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso, has initiated last year the construction of a 10-storey, 384-bed capacity and fully air-conditioned facility known as the “Bagong Ospital ng Maynila” Building;
WHEREAS, the PhP 2.3 Billion health investment of the Local Government is intended to upgrade the facilities of the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center (OMMC) to world-class standards and to provide better tools and equipment for the city’s healthcare workers to meet the present-day challenges of caring for Manila's indigent patients;
WHEREAS, this flagship project under the “Build, Build Manila” Program with a total floor area of Twenty-Nine Thousand Nine Hundred Fifty-One Square Meters (29,951 sq. m.) is scheduled for completion and opening in 2022 and will boast of twelve (12) intensive care units, twenty (20) private rooms, a three-storey parking building, and a helipad;
WHEREAS, the OMMC needs to dramatically expand its personnel complement to adequately service the increase of its hospital capacity from the present three hundred (300) to the target three hundred eighty-four (384) total beds: NOW, THEREFORE,

SECTION 1. New Plantilla Positions. — The following new Plantilla items are hereby created under the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center (OMMC), with particulars as follows:

Funding will come from the FY 2022 Executive Budget's Special Activities Fund and be included in future city budgets.

This ordinance formally establishes the KASAMA Program, a community-based emergency employment initiative in Manila. It provides temporary work lasting 10 to 40 days for displaced, underemployed, or seasonal workers who are at least 18 years old, unemployed, and bona fide residents of Manila. Eligible projects include community improvement tasks such as public facility repairs, canal cleaning, tree planting, and infrastructure maintenance. The Public Employment Service Office (PESO) oversees implementation. Beneficiaries are paid for their work and must submit basic documents like a barangay certificate, affidavit of no income, application form, and ID.

ORDINANCE NO. 8802

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF GRATUITY PAY TO CONTRACT
OF SERVICE AND JOB ORDER WORKERS IN THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA
PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 46 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2021 AND
PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF FIFTY-ONE MILLION
ONE HUNDRED FIFTY THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 51,150,000.00) AND FOR OTHER
PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on 29 December 2021, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte issued Administrative Order (A.O.) No. 46, Series of 2021, entitled “Authorizing the Grant of
Gratuity Pay to Contract of Service and Job Order Workers in the Government for Fiscal Year 2021”;

WHEREAS, as mentioned in A.O. No. 46, while Contract of Service (COS) and
Job Order (JO) workers in the government are paid salaries/wages equivalent to those
received by personnel occupying comparable positions in government and a premium of
up to 20% of such salary/wage, they do not enjoy benefits accorded to government
employees such as the Personnel Economic Relief Allowance, Mid-Year and Year-End
Bonus and Performance Based Bonus, among others, considering that they have no
employer-employee relationship with the government;

WHEREAS, it also stated that “granting a year-end Gratuity Pay to COS and JO
workers is a well-deserved recognition of their hard work in implementing programs,
Projects and activities, including those which are part of the emergency COVID-19
response efforts of the government”;

WHEREAS, Section 5 of A.O. No. 46 provides that “LGUs are enjoined to adopt in
their respective offices the grant of Gratuity Pay to workers whose services are engaged
through COS and JO, utilizing appropriate and available funding sources from their
respective local government funds”;

WHEREAS, on December 31, 2021, the Department of Budget and Management
issued Budget Circular No. 2021-5 relative to the “Guidelines on the Grant of Gratuity Pay
to Contract of Service and Job Order Workers in Government for FY 2021”;

WHEREAS, every local government unit shall exercise the powers that are
essential to the promotion of the general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other
things, the enhancement of economic prosperity, full employment, and social justice, and
preserve the comfort and convenience of its inhabitants [Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.)
No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991];

WHEREAS, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 01, adopted by
the Executive Committee on the City Development Council on January 10, 2022,
entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL
INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL
INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2022 FOR THE GRANT OF GRATUITY PAY TO
CONTRACT OF SERVICE AND JOB ORDER WORKERS IN THE CITY
GOVERNMENT OF MANILA FOR FISCAL YEAR 2021 PURSUANT TO
ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 46 S. 2021":
NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Gratuity Pay. — The grant of the one-time Gratuity Pay for FY 2021
not exceeding Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00) to job order and contract of service
personnel in the City Government of Manila is hereby authorized subject to the conditions
under Administrative Order No. 46, s. 2021.

SEC. 2. Fund Source. — The Gratuity Pay in the total amount of Fifty-One Million
One Hundred Fifty Thousand Pesos (PhP 51,150,000.00) shall be funded by the Special
Activities Fund — Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses under the FY 2022 Annual
Appropriations Ordinance.

Attached are the following details:
•        LBP Form No. 8 marked as Annex A — Statement of Funding Source as Certified
by the City Treasurer and City Accountant; and
•        LBP Form No. 9 marked Annex B — Statement of Budgetary Requirements.

SEC. 3. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared
invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
its approval.

On the motion presented by the Hon. Joel R. Chua, which was duly seconded by
all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the
City Council of Manila on January 13, 2022.
short_text: The City Council of Manila approved Ordinance No. 8802, allowing a one-time gratuity pay of up to PhP5,000 for Contract of Service (COS) and Job Order (JO) workers in the City Government of Manila as recognition of their service in 2021, especially during COVID-19 response efforts. The funding of PhP51,150,000 for this benefit will come from the Special Activities Fund under the FY 2022 budget. This ordinance follows Administrative Order No. 46.

ORDINANCE NO. 8800 

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE ENHANCED VACCINATION MANDATE TO
REGULATE THE MOBILITY OF THE UNVACCINATED INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE
TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND PROVIDING
PENALTIES FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Article II, Section 15 of the 1987 Philippine Constitution provides that the State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them;

WHEREAS, Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that “every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare”;

WHEREAS, Article 99 of the Administrative Order No. 270 or the Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that “the Sangguniang Panglungsod, as the legislative body of the city, shall enact ordinances, approve resolutions and appropriate funds for the general welfare of the city and its inhabitants pursuant to Sec. 16 of the Code”;

WHEREAS, on September 10, 2021, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte issued Proclamation No. 1218, Series of 2021, further extending the period of State of Calamity throughout the country for a period of one (1) year or unless earlier lifted or extended as circumstances may warrant;

WHEREAS, the National Capital Region (NCR) has been placed under Alert Level 3 from January 3 to 15, 2022, in view of the rising active cases of COVID-19 in the Philippines;

WHEREAS, the Department of Health (DOH), the University of the Philippines–Philippine Genome Center (UP-PGC), and the University of the Philippines–National Institute of Health (UP-NIH) bio-surveillance have detected the new SARS-CoV-2 variant in the Philippines designated as Variant of Concern and named Omicron, which calls for proactive measures and restrictions;

WHEREAS, according to the Manila Public Information Office, as of January 7, 2022, the City of Manila has fully vaccinated 1,505,400 individuals, which is more than 111% of its target population;

WHEREAS, the City Government of Manila, under the leadership of Mayor Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso, continues to offer COVID-19 vaccinations to the general public through various vaccination sites;

WHEREAS, despite the government's efforts to encourage vaccination, a number of individuals remain unvaccinated, making them more susceptible to the virus and may further spread the infection in their communities;

WHEREAS, as of January 6, 2022, the DOH has observed that 85% of those hospitalized in the National Capital Region due to the COVID-19 virus are unvaccinated, thereby burdening the healthcare system;

WHEREAS, Republic Act No. 11332 or the “Mandatory Reporting of Notifiable Diseases and Health Events of Public Health Concern Act” declares that it is the policy of the State “to protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them” and that the State “recognizes epidemics and other public health emergencies as threats to public health and national security, which can undermine the social, economic, and political functions of the State”; NOW THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. TITLE. — This Ordinance shall be called “AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE ENHANCED VACCINATION MANDATE TO REGULATE THE MOBILITY OF UNVACCINATED INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF."

SEC. 2. RESTRICTION FOR UNVACCINATED INDIVIDUALS. — Unvaccinated individuals shall:
1.        Remain in their residences at all times except for the procurement of essential goods and services such as, but not limited to, food, water, medicine, medical devices, public utilities, and energy, work, and medical and dental necessities; Provided, however, that individual outdoor exercise shall be allowed within the general area of their residence, e.g., within the barangay, purok, subdivision, or village;
2.        Be prohibited in indoor and outdoor/al fresco dining in restaurants and other food establishments and shall likewise be prohibited from leisure or social trips to malls, hotels, event venues, sports and country clubs, and similar facilities;
3.        Be prohibited in domestic travel via public transportation by land, sea, and air except for the procurement of essential goods and services such as, but not limited to, food, water, medicine, medical devices, public utilities, and energy, work, and medical and dental necessities subject to the production of proof to support and justify such travel; and,
4.        Be prohibited from entering government offices, recreational parks, religious establishments, and other similar public areas.
5.        Unvaccinated individuals employed in the City of Manila, public or private, shall be required to undergo a Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) test every two (2) weeks, at their own personal expense or through any of the free RT-PCR testing sites in the City of Manila and present a negative COVID-19 result prior to being admitted to work onsite, consistent with the guidelines, rules, and regulations issued by the IATF and the Department of Labor and Employment; Provided, however, that in the event that the RT-PCR test and/or result is/are not immediately available, a Rapid Antigen Test, from a DOH-accredited lab or the Manila City Health Department, may be utilized in lieu thereof. PROVIDED FURTHER, unvaccinated personnel employed by the City of Manila must undergo Rapid Antigen Test every three (3) days and must present a negative antigen test prior to being admitted to work onsite.

The foregoing rules shall also cover individuals who reside outside the City of Manila but who work and/or travel to the same.

Likewise, the foregoing rules shall be implemented in the event of Alert Level 3 or above or its equivalent.

SEC. 3. RESPONSIBILITY OF BARANGAY OFFICIALS AND ESTABLISHMENTS. — It will be the responsibility of every barangay official to ensure the implementation of this Ordinance.

Likewise, it shall be the responsibility of every establishment mentioned in Sec. 1 hereof to require the presentation of the vaccination ID before allowing entry thereof.

SEC. 4. EXEMPTIONS. — Public markets, groceries, convenience stores, pharmacies selling essential goods and medicines, and are located outside the mall, shall be exempted from this Ordinance, subject to the observance of social distancing and other health protocols.

Persons who are not qualified to get vaccinated shall be exempted from the provisions of this Ordinance provided that they have a duly certified medical certificate issued by a medical doctor proving the same.

SEC. 5. PENALTIES. —  Violations of this Ordinance shall meet the following penalties:
•        FIRST OFFENSE - One Thousand Pesos (PhP 1,000.00)
•        SECOND OFFENSE - Two Thousand Pesos (PhP 2,000.00)
•        THIRD AND SUBSEQUENT OFFENSES - Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00) or one (1) month imprisonment or both, at the discretion of the court.

Any person violating the provisions of this Ordinance shall likewise be in violation of Republic Act No. 11332, particularly Sections 9(d) and (e) on Prohibited Acts in relation to Section 10 on Penalties.
In addition, any establishments, as mentioned under Section 1, allowing unvaccinated individuals to enter the premises shall be met with a revocation of its business permits.
Further, any barangay official and its agents allowing movement of unvaccinated people outside of their residence for non-essential purposes shall likewise be liable under applicable laws.

Furthermore, any individual or establishment who or which will falsify the COVID-19 vaccine card shall be prosecuted under R.A. No. 3815 or the Revised Penal Code, as amended, pursuant to Section 12 of Republic Act No. 11525 or the COVID-19 Vaccination Program Act of 2021.

SEC. 6. REPEALING CLAUSE. — All other ordinances, resolutions, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 7. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 10, 2022.
short_text: This ordinance limits the movement of people in Manila who have not been vaccinated against COVID-19. Unvaccinated individuals can only leave their homes for essentials like food, medicine, work, or medical needs and must show proof when traveling. They are also banned from dining in restaurants, entering malls, government offices, and traveling domestically unless for essential reasons. Unvaccinated workers must regularly undergo COVID-19 tests at their own expense to be allowed to work onsite. Barangay officials and establishments must enforce these rules by checking vaccination IDs.
fines:
First offense: Php1,000 fine

Second offense: Php2,000 fine

Third and subsequent offenses: Php5,000 fine or 1 month imprisonment or both (court's decision)

Businesses that allow unvaccinated individuals inside may have their business permits revoked.

Barangay officials who allow violations can also be held liable.

Falsifying vaccination cards will lead to charges under the Revised Penal Code and COVID-19 Vaccination Program Act of 2021.

ORDINANCE NO. 8799

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF THE FISCAL YEAR 2021
SERVICE RECOGNITION INCENTIVE FOR GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES PURSUANT
TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 45, S. 2021, AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR
IN THE AMOUNT OF NINETY-ONE MILLION FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS
(PHP. 91,500,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on December 24, 2021, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte issued Administrative Order (AO) No. 45, Series of 2021, authorizing the grant of Service Recognition Incentive to Government Employees for Fiscal Year (FY) 2021;

WHEREAS, as mentioned in AO No. 45, “it is imperative to provide reasonable incentives and assistance to our public servants, who are impacted not only by the pandemic, but also by various natural calamities”;

WHEREAS, Section 6 of AO No. 45 provides the guidelines for the grant of SRIs to Local Government Employees as follows:
“a. The grant of one-time SRI to employees in LGUs, including those in the barangays, shall be determined by their respective sanggunians depending on the LGU's financial capability, subject to the PS Limitation in LGU budgets under RA No. 7160 or the “Local Government Code of 1991“ and the conditions set forth in Section 2 hereof, at a uniform rate not exceeding Ten Thousand Pesos (P10,000.00), chargeable against their respective FY 2021 local government funds. Should the identified funding source prove insufficient to cover the maximum allowable rate of the SRI, a lower but uniform amount shall be paid to all qualified employees of the LGU; and

b. In determining the amount of SRI, the sanggunians shall exercise prudence and judicious use of government funds, ensuring that the expenditure is reasonable and will not, in any way, adversely affect the delivery of services to the public.”;

WHEREAS, Section 336 of the Local Government Code states that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing the transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sangguniang concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations;

WHEREAS, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 25, adopted by the Executive Committee on the City Development Council on 28 December 2021, entitled “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2021 FOR THE GRANT OF THE FY 2021 SERVICE RECOGNITION INCENTIVE (SRI) FOR GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 45 S. 2021”: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Service Recognition Incentive. — The grant of one-time Service Recognition Incentive for FY 2021 not exceeding Ten Thousand Pesos (PhP. 10,000.00) to government employees is hereby authorized subject to the conditions under Administrative Order No. 45, s. 2021.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. — The Service Recognition Incentive in the total amount of Ninety-One Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 91,500,000.00) shall be paid by augmenting the Special Activities Fund–Personal Services (SAF-PS) Account from Personal Service savings under the FY 2021 Annual Appropriations Ordinance.

Attached and made an integral part hereof are the following details:
•        Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS for Augmentation of Funds;
•        Annex B — Budgetary Requirement for the Service Recognition Incentive for FY 2021 under the SAF-PS.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

On the motion presented by the Honorable Macario M. Lacson, which was duly seconded by all those present, this Ordinance was finally approved for third and final reading by the City Council of Manila on December 29, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance allows the Manila City government to give a one-time cash incentive of up to PhP10,000 to eligible government employees for their service in 2021, following the national order issued by the President. The total budget allocated for this is PhP91.5 million, and it will come from savings in the city’s 2021 funds. This financial reward is meant to recognize public servants' work during tough times like the pandemic and natural disasters.

PREAMBLE
