ORDINANCE NO. 8794

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY MAYOR HONORABLE FRANCISCO “ISKO MORENO” DOMAGOSO TO NEGOTIATE THE PROPOSED BORROWING OF THE CITY OF MANILA, IN THE AMOUNT OF TWO BILLION EIGHT HUNDRED MILLION PESOS (PHP. 2,800,000,000.00), TO FUND THE ACQUISITION OF HOSPITAL EQUIPMENT, FURNITURE AND FIXTURES FOR THE OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER AND ACQUISITION/EXPROPRIATION OF LOTS UNDER THE LAND-FOR-THE-LANDLESS PROGRAM OF THE CITY INCLUDED IN THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT UNIT'S APPROVED LOCAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN (LDP) OR ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (AIP)

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. The City Mayor, in representation of the City Government of Manila, hereinafter referred to as the “City”, is hereby authorized to enter into a loan under TERM LOAN Nos. 2 and 3 with the LAND BANK OF THE PHILIPPINES (LBP) in accordance with Section 297 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code, in the aggregate amount of Two Billion Eight Hundred Million Pesos (PhP. 2,800,000,000.00) under the terms and conditions herein set forth and such other terms and conditions as may be agreed upon with any person, corporation, or entity for the purpose of funding priority project/s, and subject to the requirements under Section 123 of Republic Act No. 7653 as implemented by the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Circular No. 402. In this connection, the City Mayor shall have full power and authority to represent the City in negotiating the terms and conditions for the said borrowing and in signing, executing, and delivering such agreements, contracts, deeds, papers, and documents as may be necessary and proper for the full and total implementation of the authority herein granted.
SEC. 2. The said priority project/s herein specified are hereby certified to be a local infrastructure and/or other socio-economic development projects in accordance with the approved local development plan and public investment program of the City of Manila for the Current Year of 2021 of the City of Manila.
SEC. 3. Consistent with the covering Term Loan Agreement/Contracts, deeds and assignments, mortgage contracts, and such other agreements as may be entered into by the City in connection with the borrowing, the features, terms, and conditions shall be as follows and are hereby approved:
3.1 TERM LOAN Nos. 2 and 3
Borrower: City Government of Manila
a. Term Loan 2 — Up to PhP. 1.60 Billion or Contract Amount or Purchase Order Price, whichever is lower.
b. Term Loan 3 — Up to PhP. 1.200 Billion or Deed of Sale/Contract Amount Price or based on Court Decision, whichever is lower.
Or a total of PhP. 2,800,000,000.00.
a. TERM LOAN 2:
To finance the acquisition of various hospital equipment, furniture, and fixtures for the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center, included in the LGU's approved Local Development Plan (LDP) or Annual Investment Program (AIP).
b. TERM LOAN 3:
To finance the cost of acquisition/expropriation of land including related charges as stated in the Court Decision under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City, or Annual Investment Program (AIP).
Purposes
Any change and/or addition in the projects, including a) type of equipment, furniture, and fixtures, specifications, and number of units, and b) lots to be purchased, may be allowed provided it will not exceed the total approved amount and that said change and/or addition in the projects is included in the City's approved LDP or AIP.
Term Loan Nos. 2 and 3
•        a. TERM LOAN 2: Up to ten (10) years, with up to one (1) year grace period on principal, on a per lot/release basis.
•        b. TERM LOAN 3: Up to fifteen (15) years with up to two (2) years grace period on principal, on a per lot/release basis.
Manner of Payment:
•        a. TERM LOAN 2 and 3:
Interest: Payable quarterly in arrears to start at the end of the first (1st) quarter from date of initial release on a per lot/release basis.
•        a. TERM LOAN 2: Payable in thirty-six (36) equal quarterly payments to start at the end of the fifth (5th) quarter from date of initial release on a per lot/release basis.
•        b. TERM LOAN 3: Payable in fifty-two (52) equal quarterly payments to start at the end of the ninth (9th) quarter from date of initial release on a per lot/release basis.
Interest Rate:
•        Variable — at LANDBANK prevailing rate at the time of availment, subject to quarterly repricing, with a floor rate of 3.50% per annum.
•        Fixed for five (5) years — at LANDBANK prevailing rate at the time of availment, subject to repricing at the end of the 5th year, with a floor rate of 3.50% per annum.
The Borrower has a one-time option to convert its preferred interest rate (i.e., from variable to fixed or vice versa) on any repricing date during the term of the loan.
Collateral: Assignment of 20% of Internal Revenue Allotment (IRA) and other recurring revenues of the City.
Commitment and Handling Fees: Waived.
SEC. 4. The City of Manila hereby appropriates the entire proceeds of the borrowing exclusively to finance the acquisition of hospital equipment, furniture and fixtures for the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center, and acquisition/expropriation of lots under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City and other financial services relative thereto.
SEC. 5. Terms and conditions shall be subject to ratification by the City Council through resolution/ordinance.
SEC. 6. Any ordinance or parts thereof, inconsistent with this enactment, is hereby repealed or amended accordingly.
SEC. 7. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its publication and compliance with all procedures required under Republic Act No. 7160 of an ordinance for its validity, including the affixation of signatures of the Sangguniang Panlungsod members, in concurrence thereto, composing at least a majority thereof, on all the pages of this Ordinance.
This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila through the motion of the Majority Floor Leader, Honorable Joel R. Chua and seconded by all members present in this august Chamber in session duly assembled on December 13, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes Manila’s City Mayor, Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso, to negotiate and secure a loan of PHP 2.8 billion from the Land Bank of the Philippines. The loan will finance the acquisition of medical equipment, furniture, and fixtures for Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center and fund the Land-for-the-Landless Program to acquire land. The loan terms, including interest and repayment conditions, are outlined, and the loan's proceeds are to be used exclusively for these purposes.

short_text:
This ordinance establishes comprehensive rules for sanitation, disinfection, and hygiene in all public-serving establishments in Manila. All businesses must secure a Sanitary Permit from the Business Permits and Licensing Office (BPLO) before starting operations, and renew it annually as a condition for getting or renewing a business permit. All employees, especially food and non-food handlers, must obtain a Health Certificate through an online application and undergo medical tests. These certificates are valid for one year and must be worn during work.

Food handlers are required to follow strict hygiene practices, including wearing clean uniforms, using mouth shields or head coverings, and frequent handwashing. Water used in businesses—especially food establishments—must pass regular physical, chemical, and microbiological tests, with certificates of potability displayed in visible areas. Ice and bottled water also fall under strict monitoring and registration. The ordinance further bans smoking and e-cigarette use inside air-conditioned or enclosed food businesses, except in sealed, ventilated smoking areas.

Penalties: Businesses and individuals who violate any provision (such as operating without sanitary permits, not securing health certificates, or failing to meet hygiene standards) are subject to fines, suspension of permits, or closure, as determined by the Manila Health Department and BPLO.

ORDINANCE NO. 8792

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING FIVE (5) VACANT POSITIONS OF FOUR (4) MEDICAL LABORATORY TECHNICIAN II AND ONE (1) DENTIST IN THE JUSTICE JOSE ABAD SANTOS GENERAL HOSPITAL BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM AND REPLACING THE SAME ABOLISHED POSITIONS WITH FOUR (4) NEW PLANTILLA ITEMS CONSISTING OF TWO (2) MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIST I, ONE (1) RESPIRATORY THERAPIST III, ONE (1) RESPIRATORY THERAPIST I

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this Ordinance can be found in Sec. 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: “In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations”;
WHEREAS, on May 12, 2006, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program, composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC, came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following: (a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Retitling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions, whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;
WHEREAS, the proponent, the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital (JJASGH), has certified that the collapsed items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary while the positions being created will immediately address its most urgent need to fill up several medical personnel positions;
WHEREAS, the generated savings from the scrapped positions will be more than enough to cover the computed amount needed to fund the created positions, and that the total amount for Personnel Services, including the new positions, will not exceed the forty-five percent (45%) statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability. 
The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling down, phasing out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby abolished under the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital (JJASGH):
FORMAT: TITLE OF POSITION - NUMBER - ITEM# - SALARY GRADE- AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM)
1.        Medical Laboratory Technician II - 4 - 113, 114, 115, 116 – 8-1 -  Php 1,451,982.72
2.        Dentist - 1 - 136 – 14-1 - Php 559,740.32
TOTAL NUMBER: 5
TOTAL AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM): Php 2,011,731.04

SEC. 3. New Plantilla Positions. — The following new Plantilla Items are hereby created under the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital (JJASGH):
FORMAT: TITLE OF POSITION - NUMBER - SALARY GRADE - AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM)
1.        Medical Technologist I - 2 - 11-1 - Php 902,422.72
2.        Respiratory Therapist III - 1 - 17-1 - Php 703,800.48
3.        Respiratory Therapist I - 1 - 10-1 - Php 409,314.40
TOTAL NUMBER: 4 
TOTAL AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM): Php 2,015,537.60



SEC. 4. Qualifications, Powers, Duties, and Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. Appointments. — The employment and appointment for those who will occupy the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 6. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the creation of the four (4) new regular positions shall be sourced from available funds of the existing five (5) positions to be abolished for this purpose, as provided for under the 2022 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the plantilla of personnel of the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital (JJASGH).

SEC. 7. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 29, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance abolishes five vacant positions at the Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital and replaces them with four new positions through a scrap-and-build strategy under the government's rationalization program. The abolished roles include four Medical Laboratory Technician II and one Dentist. In their place, the hospital will create two Medical Technologist I, one Respiratory Therapist III, and one Respiratory Therapist I. The savings from the abolished positions will cover the cost of the new positions, staying within the budget limits.

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160 otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991 categorically provides: “Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. — Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for the expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.
The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation and the Sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations subject to the provisions of this Section.”

GENERAL PROVISIONS

SEC. 2. Budgetary Requirements. - The Budgetary Expenditures herein proposed shall comply with the following requirements:

(a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions, nor create new positions, without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.
(b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, the use of which requires a separate Ordinance.

(c) The appropriation of the Special Purpose Appropriations, being a contingency fund or back up fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed by the different departments to finish certain programs/projects that were not sufficiently funded, cannot be utilized without specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Committee on Appropriations for approval.
(d) The payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of the barangay chairman attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted. Garbage hauling services shall be contracted out to one or more companies as recommended by the Department of Public Services to ensure efficient and timely collection of garbage.
(e) As additional funding source, any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee on Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee for authority to the Mayor to dispose the same through public bidding.
(f) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solution and detergents) using City Government funds shall conform with Republic Act No. 9003, otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000, Republic Act No. 8749 and Republic Act No. 9275, otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence, products to be procured shall be limited to organic, biodegradable or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco-Labelling Program of Green Choice Philippines.
(g) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons with Disability under Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons, before the release of any payment.

SEC. 3. General Limitations. -

a. The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for FY 2022 shall not exceed Forty-Five Percent (45%) of the Total Annual Income Regular sources realized in the next preceding Fiscal Year;
b. No official or employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher than the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank as determined by applicable laws, rules and regulations;
c. No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as maybe expressly authorized by law;
d. In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career services, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Local Government Code and the Civil Service law, rules and regulations;
e. Positions in the Official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbents holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations;

f. No changes in designation or nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed except when the position is actually vacant and filling of such position shall be strictly made in accordance with Civil Service law, rules and regulations; and
g. The Annual appropriation for discretionary purpose of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipt delivered from basic real property tax in the next preceding year.

SEC. 4. Itemization of Personal Services and other Personnel. The itemization of Personal Services and Other General Services as submitted by the City Budget Office in support of the appropriation herein authorized forms part of this Ordinance and shall be strictly implemented and shall be covered by its provisions. Such appropriations shall be programmed and used for the twelve-month requirement of the city. It may not be disbursed to exponentially increase the number of personnel during the first semester leaving little or no fund for the second semester of the year.

SEC. 5. Intelligence Expenses. The Intelligence/Confidential expenses provided under this Ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. Changes in the Organizational and Administrative Machinery. - All creations, conversions, transfers, abolitions and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services, Positions/Titles and Salary Grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 137 of the Department of Budget and Management.

a. For a more responsive, efficient and effective organization within several departments and offices, creation, conversion of certain positions, performing staff/technical/non-technical functions were made.
b. Modification of Salary Grades in compliance with DBM Local Budget Circular No. 132 implementing the Second Tranche of the Modified Salary Schedule for Local Government Personnel Pursuant to Republic Act (RA) No.11466.

SEC. 7. Use of Appropriated Funds. All funds appropriated for functions, projects and activities shall be used to finance the full year requirement of the City of Manila and shall be released exclusively for specific purposes and particular period for which they have been authorized. Any amendment and augmentation may be made within the fiscal year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.

SEC. 8. Authority to Adjust Appropriations. - No Ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.

SEC. 9. Twenty Percent (20%) Community Development Fund. The twenty percent (20%) Development Fund shall be strictly utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the Sangguniang Panlungsod in conformity with the Local Government Code.

SEC. 10. Twenty Percent (20%) Contingency Reserve. - Except for expenses due to public utilities, rentals, insurance premiums and food supplies expenses, a contingency reserve of twenty percent (20%) on the authorized FY 2022 appropriation for Department Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating thereon the 20% contingency reserve.

SEC. 11. Allotment of Appropriations. For effective budgetary control, authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with the DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder:

a. No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila, shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function, activity or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor, as hereafter provided. The Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted based on the appropriations authorized in the Budget Ordinance. A revised Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted upon approval of the Annual Executive Budget referred herein showing quarterly allotment of the whole authorized appropriations for the department/office.
b. For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided, each fiscal year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January, April, July and October. The appropriations under this Ordinance shall be allocated, programmed and used to cover the funding requirement of the city for the whole year. Majority thereof may not be expended in the first semester to ensure availability of funds for the last semester of the year.
c. The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer's notification and certification that the realized income is less than what is estimated in the annual/supplemental budget or that additional income is realized.
d. An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Officer based on recommendation made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official, the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least five (5) days before the start of each quarter.

SEC. 12. Non-Waiver Clause. Notwithstanding the approval of this Appropriation Ordinance by the Sangguniang Panlungsod, all contracts, disbursements and awards entered into by the City of Manila including, but not limited to, the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, Universidad De Manila and other government agencies and instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455, paragraph B, sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.

SEC. 13. Separability Clause. - If for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 14. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2022.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 18, 2021.
short_text: Ordinance No. 8789 authorizes the appropriation of PHP22.2 billion from the City of Manila's estimated income for Fiscal Year 2022 to fund government operations, services, and development projects as outlined in the Executive Budget, including provisions for personal services, intelligence expenses, community development, contingency reserves, and administrative changes, with strict guidelines on fund usage, budgetary limits, inter-office augmentations, and compliance with national laws and auditing rules, while ensuring transparency, proper documentation, and Council ratification of key contracts; this ordinance does not impose any fines or penalties.

ORDINANCE NO. 8788

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE LOCAL COUNCIL ON ANTI-TRAFFICKING AND
VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND THEIR CHILDREN (LCAT-VAWC), PRESCRIBING
ITS COMPOSITION, POWERS AND FUNCTIONS, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

EXPLANATORY NOTE
Section 14, Article II of the 1987 Constitution recognizes the role of women in nation-building and ensures the fundamental equality before the law of women and men. Pursuant to this mandate, several legislations for women empowerment, as well as for the protection of the welfare of women and children, were enacted by Congress. Among these laws were Republic Act (R.A.) No. 9208, or the Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act of 2003; R.A. No. 9262, or the Anti-Violence Against Women and Their Children Act of 2004; and R.A. No. 9710, or the Magna Carta of Women.

In consonance with these laws, the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD), and Department of Justice (DOJ) have issued Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2010-01, dated October 18, 2010, directing local government executives and other entities concerned to create a Local Council on Anti-Trafficking and Violence Against Women and Their Children (LCAT-VAWC).

Pursuant to the mandate of these laws and the Circular, this Ordinance is being proposed to create the Manila LCAT-VAWC.

The Manila LCAT-VAWC shall be chaired by the City Mayor. The Vice Mayor shall be Vice Chair, with fifteen (15) members. The City Department of Social Welfare and Development shall act as its secretariat.

The Council shall be tasked to institute policies and programs to protect women and children who are victims of trafficking and violence. It shall create and establish systems of surveillance, investigation, and rescue. It will also undertake information, education, and advocacy campaigns against trafficking in persons and violence against women and children. It shall monitor and oversee the strict compliance with RA 9208, RA 9262, and other related laws for the protection of women and children.

The creation of the Council will ensure that Manila rules and regulations are consistent with national policies against trafficking in persons, violence against women and their children, and other women/children-related laws.

It is in this view that the immediate passage of this draft ordinance is earnestly sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Creation of the Council on Anti-Trafficking and Violence Against Women and Their Children and Gender-Based Violence. — The Manila Council on Anti-Trafficking and Violence Against Women and Their Children, and Gender-Based Violence, hereinafter referred to as the Council, is hereby created.

SEC. 2. Composition of the Council. — The Council shall be composed of the following:
Chairman: City Mayor
Vice Chairman: City Vice Mayor
Members:
1.        Chairperson, Sangguniang Panlungsod (SP) Committee on Women and Family Relations
2.        Chairperson, SP Committee on Children’s Affairs
3.        Chairperson, SP Committee on Laws
4.        Head, Manila Department of Social Welfare
5.        President, Liga ng mga Barangay – Manila Chapter
6.        Head, City Planning and Development Office
7.        Head, Manila Health Department
8.        Head, DILG Manila Office
9.        Chief of Police, PNP Manila Police District
10.        PNP MPD Women and Children Protection Desk Officer
11.        Head, Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila
12.        Head, Gender and Development Office
13.        Manila City Prosecutor
14.        Head, Public Employment Service Office – City of Manila
15.        Head, Manila Barangay Bureau
16.        Non-Governmental Organization Representative
17.        Women’s Organization Representative
Secretariat: City Department of Social Welfare and Development
The Chairperson of the SP Committee on Women and Family Relations shall preside over the Council in the absence of the Chair and Vice Chair.

SEC. 3. Powers and Responsibilities of the Council. — The Council shall have the following powers and responsibilities:
•        Institute policies and programs to protect women and children who are victims of trafficking and gender-based violence;
•        Formulate local ordinances and resolutions;
•        Create and establish systems of surveillance, investigation, and rescue to ensure effective and efficient coordination;
•        Undertake information, education, and advocacy campaigns against trafficking in persons and VAWC and gender-based violence;
•        Monitor and oversee the strict compliance with RA 9208, RA 9262, and other related laws for the protection of women and children and for the implementation of the local council on Anti-Trafficking and Violence Against Women and Children, and national plans of action;
•        Perform such other functions as it may deem necessary, consistent with national policies against trafficking in persons, violence against women and their children, and other women/children-related laws.

SEC. 4. Meetings. — The Council shall conduct regular meetings on a quarterly basis. Special meetings may be conducted when necessary. The policies, programs, projects, and activities relative to the promotion, protection, and fulfillment of women's and children’s rights shall be the agenda for such meetings.

SEC. 5. Appropriations. — The appropriation needed for this Ordinance shall be sourced out of unused appropriations for the present fiscal year. Thereafter, its funding requirement shall be included in the annual appropriations ordinance under the City’s GAD Fund.

SEC. 6. Formulation of Implementing Rules and Regulations. — The Council shall formulate such Implementing Rules and Regulations as it may deem necessary.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. — If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts which are not affected thereby shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — Any Ordinance, Executive Order, Local Issuances, or Rules and Regulations, or parts thereof, which are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed and/or modified accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately and shall remain in force unless otherwise superseded or amended by competent authority.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 15, 2021.
short_text: The City of Manila established created the Local Council on Anti-Trafficking and Violence Against Women and Their Children (LCAT-VAWC) to help prevent abuse and trafficking. The council, Led by the Mayor and Vice Mayor, the council is composed of city officials and representatives from relevant organizations, enforces laws like RA 9208 and RA 9262, runs awareness campaigns, and coordinates rescue efforts.
fines: None stated in the ordinance; enforcement aligns with national laws (RA 9208, RA 9262, etc.)

ORDINANCE NO. 8785

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING ELEVEN (11) VARIOUS VACANT POSITIONS IN THE OFFICE OF THE CITY ACCOUNTANT (OCAT) BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM AND REPLACING THE SAME ABOLISHED POSITIONS WITH ELEVEN (11) NEW PLANTILLA ITEMS CONSISTING OF ONE (1) ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER IV, SIX (6) ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT IV, ONE (1) ADMINISTRATIVE AIDE III AND THREE (3) ADMINISTRATIVE AIDE I.

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this Draft Ordinance can be found in Section 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states:
“In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules and regulations”;
WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC on May 12, 2006, came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid as part of the allowable staffing actions the following:
(a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Retitling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions, whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;
WHEREAS, the proponent, the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT), has certified that the collapsed items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary, while the positions being created will immediately address its most urgent need to fill up several administrative positions;
WHEREAS, the generated savings from the scrapped positions will be more than enough to cover the computed amount needed to fund the created positions and that the total amount for Personnel Services, including the new positions, will not exceed the forty-five percent (45%) statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability.
The City and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling-down, phasing-out or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby abolished under the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT):
FORMAT: TITLE OF POSITION - NUMBER - ITEM NO. - SALARY GRADE -AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM)
•        Administrative Assistant III – 3 – 36, 43, 110 – SG 9-7 – Php 1,081,082.88
•        Administrative Assistant III – 2 – 37, 111 – SG 9-4 – Php 704,791.04
•        Administrative Assistant III – 1 – 139 – SG 9-2 – Php 347,189.76
•        Administrative Assistant II – 1 – 102 – SG 8-6 – Php 336,746.88
•        Administrative Assistant II – 1 – 125 – SG 8-3 – Php 328,781.44
•        Administrative Aide VI – 2 – 118, 119 – SG 6-1 – Php 582,832.00
•        Computer Operator II – 1 – 137 – SG 9-1 – Php 344,618.24

TOTAL: 11 positions — Php 3,726,042.24

SEC. 3. New Plantilla Positions. — The following new Plantilla Items are hereby created under the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT):
FORMAT: TITLE OF POSITION – NUMBER – SALARY GRADE – AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2021 (PER ANNUM)
•        Administrative Officer IV – 1 – SG 15-1 – Php 563,856.00
•        Administrative Assistant IV – 6 – SG 10-1 – Php 2,219,366.40
•        Administrative Aide III – 1 – SG 3-1 – Php 250,208.96
•        Administrative Aide I – 3 – SG 1-1 – Php 678,279.36

TOTAL: 11 positions — Php 3,711,710.72

SEC. 4. Qualifications, Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. Appointments. — The employment and appointment for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 6. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the creation of the eleven (11) new regular positions shall be sourced from available funds of the existing eleven (11) positions to be abolished for this purpose as provided for under the 2022 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla of Personnel of the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT).

SEC. 7. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 8, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance approves the abolition of eleven vacant positions in the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT) and replaces them with eleven new positions. The new positions consist of one Administrative Officer IV, six Administrative Assistant IV, one Administrative Aide III, and three Administrative Aide I. The funds for these new positions come from the savings generated by abolishing the vacant roles. This restructuring aims to improve service delivery while adhering to budget limitations.

AN ORDINANCE CONVERTING THE VACANT ITEMS OF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER V, ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER IV, AND DRIVER IV TO NEW POSITIONS OF ACCOUNTANT III, ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER III, AND ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT III IN THE OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM

ORDINANCE NO. 8782

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING RELIEF FOR THE ASSESSMENT OF
CONTRACTOR'S TAX AMOUNTING TO ONE MILLION FOUR HUNDRED SIXTY-FOUR
THOUSAND SIX HUNDRED THIRTY-TWO PESOS AND TWENTY-SEVEN CENTAVOS
(PHP 1,464,632.27) FOR THE RECONSTRUCTION AND REBUILDING OF THE
STO. NIÑO DE PANDACAN PARISH CHURCH

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, under Article 458, paragraph 2(ii) of the 1991 Local Government Code, the Sanggunian Panlungsod is authorized to “enact ordinances levying taxes, fees and charges, prescribing the rates thereof for general and specific purposes and granting tax exemptions, incentives or reliefs” pursuant to its powers expressly granted, implied, and necessary, appropriate, or incidental in the promotion of the general welfare under Section 16 thereof;

WHEREAS, under Section 131, paragraph 13 thereof, and Section 105 of City Ordinance No. 8331, or the 2013 Omnibus Revenue Code of the City of Manila, contractor's tax is one of the taxes that the City may levy against natural or juridical persons whose activity consists essentially of the sale of services for a fee, regardless of whether or not the performance of the service calls for the exercise or use of the physical or mental faculties of such contractor or their employees;

WHEREAS, on July 10, 2020, a massive fire occurred in the Sto. Niño de Pandacan Parish Church, which razed the church to ashes, including the 400-year-old image of Sto. Niño, the Child Jesus, resulting in liturgical services being held in a temporary assembly area;

WHEREAS, the proposed rebuilding of the Sto. Niño de Pandacan Parish Church is now nearing its implementation stage due to the collaborative efforts of the faithful and various generous contributors, with all the required documents and clearances fully complied with. However, said project is assessed for a contractor's tax amounting to One Million Four Hundred Sixty-Four Thousand Six Hundred Thirty-Two Pesos and Twenty-Seven Centavos (PHP 1,464,632.27), in accordance with the schedule of fees provided under Section 105 of City Ordinance No. 8331 or the  “2013 Omnibus Revenue Code of the City of Manila”;

WHEREAS, due to financial hardships, the Sto. Niño de Pandacan Parish Church, represented by its parish priest, Rev. Fr. Sanny C. De Claro, is appealing for the said contractor's tax assessment to be waived by the City Council of Manila, in order to facilitate the rebuilding of the parish which serves not only as the center of faith in Pandacan, Manila, but also bears significant historical and cultural value: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Grant of Tax Relief. — The City Council of Manila hereby grants relief for the assessed contractor's tax amounting to One Million Four Hundred Sixty-Four Thousand Six Hundred Thirty-Two Pesos and Twenty-Seven Centavos (PHP 1,464,632.27) for the proposed reconstruction project of the Sto. Niño de Pandacan Parish Church in Pandacan, Manila, pursuant to the power granted by Local Government Code of 1991 under Article 458, paragraph 2(ii).

SEC. 2. Implementation. — The Department of Assessment of the City of Manila is also hereby directed to take appropriate action pursuant to the relief granted herein.

SEC. 3. Separability Clause. — If, for any reason, any part of this Ordinance is declared illegal or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 18, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance waives a contractor’s tax of ₱1,464,632.27 for the reconstruction of the Sto. Niño de Pandacan Parish Church, which was destroyed by fire in July 2020. The waiver was granted in recognition of the church's religious, historical, and cultural significance, as well as in response to financial hardship. The Department of Assessment of Manila is tasked with ensuring the implementation of this tax relief.

ORDINANCE NO. 8781

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING SOME POSITIONS TO GIVE WAY TO THE CREATION OF MORE ESSENTIAL POSITIONS IN THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) is undoubtedly a department that provides frontline services to the residents of Manila;
WHEREAS, change being inevitable, the Department needs to rise up to the growing challenges of delivering basic social services;
WHEREAS, in order to give way to the creation of new positions which are very essential during this public health emergency, seventeen (17) regular plantilla items which are hardly being filled up due to existing Civil Service Commission (CSC) requirements shall be abolished to give way to the hiring of necessary frontline workers: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following seventeen (17) positions are hereby abolished under the Manila Department of Social Welfare:
FORMAT: TITLE OF POSITION – NUMBER – ITEM NO. – SALARY GRADE/STEP – RATE (PER ANNUM)
Recreation and Welfare Officer III – 1 – 310 – 24-1 – Php 1,020,888.00
Recreation and Welfare Aide – 6 – 163, 176, 265, 318, 319, 322 – 7-4 – Php 1,184,976.00
Administrative Aide VI (Clerk III) – 4 – 14, 18, 24 – 6-1 – Php 745,152.00
Administrative Aide IV (Clerk II) – 6 – 118, 142, 164, 178, 196 – 4-1 – Php 994,104.00

TOTAL: 17 positions — Php 3,945,120.00

SEC. 2. New Plantilla Positions. — The following new plantilla items are hereby created under the Manila Department of Social Welfare, with particulars as follows:
FORMAT: TITLE OF POSITION – NUMBER – SALARY GRADE/STEP – SALARY RATE (PER ANNUM)

Social Welfare Aide – 23 – 4-1 – Php 165,684.00
TOTAL: Php 3,810,732.00

SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties and responsibilities of the Social Welfare Aide position shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 4. Appointments. — The employment and appointment of the individuals for the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 5. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the creation of the twenty-three (23) new regular positions shall be sourced from available funds of the existing seventeen (17) regular plantilla items to be abolished for this purpose as provided for under the 2022 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla of Personnel of the Manila Department of Social Welfare.

SEC. 6. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 11, 2021.
short_text: The Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) has abolished 17 existing positions and created 23 new ones to address the growing need for frontline workers during the public health emergency. This move aims to improve the delivery of essential social services by focusing on more urgent roles like Social Welfare Aides. The changes will be funded through the existing department budget and will be reflected in the following year’s budget. The new positions are a response to challenges in fulfilling basic services to residents.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8780

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING THE MEDICAL, DENTAL AND LABORATORY SUPPLIES EXPENSES ACCOUNT UNDER THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES OF THE SIX (6) HOSPITALS AND THE MANILA HEALTH DEPARTMENT THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2021 ANNUAL BUDGET AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the FY 2021 Annual Budget appropriated funds for the Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses of the Six (6) Manila Hospitals and the Manila Health Department under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the FY 2021 Annual Budget;

WHEREAS, after due consideration, there is a need to augment the Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses from the FY 2021 Annual Budget through savings from other accounts of the said budget to ensure the effective and efficient delivery of priority programs and projects of the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, the City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash as supporting document to the said savings and augmentation;

WHEREAS, Section 336 of the Local Government Code, Use of Appropriated Funds and Savings, provides that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment an item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations;

WHEREAS, the City Council approved Resolution No. 19, Series of 2021 passed by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on September 30, 2021, entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2021 IN RELATION TO THE AUGMENTATION OF THE MEDICAL, DENTAL AND LABORATORY SUPPLIES EXPENSES ACCOUNT UNDER THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES OF THE SIX (6) HOSPITALS AND THE MANILA HEATH DEPARTMENT THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2021 ANNUAL BUDGET”: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Augmentation. — The hereunder items of appropriations under Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses of the Six (6) Manila Hospitals and the Manila Health Department shall be augmented through savings from the FY 2021 Annual Budget:

Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses:
A. Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses - PhP. 38,700,000.00

B. Justice Jose Abad Santos General Hospital
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses - PhP. 9,426,063.00
            
C. Manila Health Department
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses - PhP. 7,934,630.00
           
D. Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses - PhP.  26 ,532,029.00             

E. Ospital ng Sampaloc
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses - PhP.  15,000,000.00
          
F. Ospital ng Tondo
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses - PhP.  3,000,000.00
           
G. Sta. Ano Hospital
  - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses – PhP. 28,248,570.00           

TOTAL: PhP.. 128. 841, 292.00

SEC. 2. Fund Sources. — The total funds in the amount of One Hundred Twenty-Eight Million Eight Hundred Forty-One Thousand Two Hundred Ninety-Two Pesos (PhP. 128,841,292.00) for the aforementioned expenditures shall be sourced from savings from the following appropriations:

Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses:

A. Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center
  - Various MOOE Accounts - PhP. 53,210,002.00

Attached are the following details:
Annex A — Declaration of Savings under MOOE for Augmentation of Funds
Annex B — Augmentation of MOOE under the FY 2021 Annual Budget

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 4, 2021.

ORDINANCE NO. 8779

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE PAYMENT OF COVID-19 HAZARD PAY IN
THE AMOUNT OF FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP 500.00) PER DAY FOR THE MANILA
CITY GOVERNMENT PERSONNEL WHO PHYSICALLY REPORTED FOR WORK
DURING THE PERIOD OF IMPLEMENTATION OF AN ENHANCED COMMUNITY
QUARANTINE AND MODIFIED ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE RELATIVE
TO THE COVID-19 OUTBREAK PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 43,
SERIES OF 2021, TO BE FUNDED BY AUGMENTATION OF THE SPECIAL
ACTIVITIES FUND – PERSONAL SERVICES AND THE SPECIAL ACTIVITIES FUND –
MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES IN THE FY 2021 BUDGET
THROUGH AVAILABLE SAVINGS IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF ONE HUNDRED
NINETY-FIVE MILLION NINE HUNDRED TEN THOUSAND FIVE HUNDRED FORTY-
EIGHT PESOS (PHP 195,910,548.00), AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Administrative Order (A.O.) No. 43, s. 2021, authorized the grant of COVID-19 Hazard Pay to government personnel who physically reported for work during the period of implementation of an Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) and a Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ), amending AO No. 26, s. 2020;

WHEREAS, Budget Circular No. 2020-1 dated March 24, 2020, provided the guidelines on the grant of COVID-19 Hazard Pay;

WHEREAS, the foregoing issuances provided that the grant of COVID-19 Hazard Pay for employees in Local Government Units shall be determined by their respective Sanggunians, subject to prescribed conditions and chargeable against FY 2021 local government funds;

WHEREAS, upon the recommendation of the Inter-Agency Task Force (IATF) through Resolution No. 106-A, s. 2021, the President imposed an Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) in the National Capital Region and other provinces beginning March 27, 2021, until April 4, 2021, which was subsequently extended until April 11, 2021;

WHEREAS, the NCR shifted from ECQ to Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ) beginning April 12, 2021, until May 14, 2021, pursuant to IATF Resolutions Nos. 109-A dated April 10, 2021, and 113-A dated April 29, 2021;

WHEREAS, Section 336 of Republic Act No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that "...the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations";

WHEREAS, the City Council approved Resolution No. 18, Series of 2021, of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2021 FOR THE PAYMENT OF COVID-19 HAZARD PAY IN THE AMOUNT OF FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP 500.00) PER DAY FOR THE MANILA CITY GOVERNMENT PERSONNEL WHO PHYSICALLY REPORTED FOR WORK DURING THE PERIOD OF IMPLEMENTATION OF AN ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE AND MODIFIED ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE RELATIVE TO THE COVID-19 OUTBREAK PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 43, S. 2021, TO BE FUNDED BY AUGMENTATION OF THE SPECIAL ACTIVITIES FUND – PERSONAL SERVICES AND THE SPECIAL ACTIVITIES FUND – MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES IN THE FY 2021 BUDGET THROUGH AVAILABLE SAVINGS IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF ONE HUNDRED NINETY-FIVE MILLION NINE HUNDRED TEN THOUSAND FIVE HUNDRED FORTY-EIGHT PESOS (PHP 195,910,548.00)": NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. COVID-19 Hazard Pay. — The payment of COVID-19 Hazard Pay is hereby authorized to city government employees and personnel who physically reported for work in their respective workstations during the implementation of an ECQ and MECQ, at Five Hundred Pesos (PHP 500.00) per day per person, based on the following computation:
PHP 500.00 x number of days physically reporting for work from March 27, 2021 to May 14, 2021.

SEC. 2. Conditions on the Grant of COVID-19 Hazard Pay. — The COVID-19 Hazard Pay may be granted provided that the following requirements are met:
a. The personnel are occupying regular, contractual, or casual positions, or are engaged through Contract of Service (COS), Job Order (JO), or other similar schemes;
b. The personnel shall have been authorized to physically report for work at their respective offices or workstations on the prescribed official working hours by the head of the department, bureau, or office during the ECQ and MECQ periods in the area of such office or workstation; and
c. The personnel entitled to Hazard Pay, Hazardous Duty Pay, Hazard Allowance, and other similar benefits under existing laws, issuances, rules, and regulations (e.g., public health workers, public social workers, science and technology personnel, military and uniformed personnel, etc.) shall continue to be entitled to such benefits or the COVID-19 Hazard Pay, whichever is higher.

SEC. 3. Augmentation and Fund Sources. — The total funds in the amount of One Hundred Ninety-Five Million Nine Hundred Ten Thousand Five Hundred Forty-Eight Pesos (PHP 195,910,548.00) for the grant of the COVID-19 Hazard Pay shall be charged against the following sources:
a. Personal Services (PS). — For personnel occupying regular, contractual, or casual positions, the total amount of Ninety-Three Million Six Hundred Forty Thousand Forty-Eight Pesos (PHP 93,640,048.00) shall be funded by augmentation of the Non-Office Account, Special Activities Fund (SAF) – PS, from savings from the Terminal Leave Benefits Account and Salaries from January 1, 2021 to July 31, 2021 of different Departments/Offices/Bureaus.
b. Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE). — The total amount of One Hundred Two Million Two Hundred Seventy Thousand Five Hundred Pesos (PHP 102,270,500.00) for COS and JO workers, other professionals, and consultants shall be funded by augmentation of the Non-Office Account, SAF – MOOE, from savings from the MOOE accounts of various Departments/Offices/Bureaus.

Attached are the following details:
•        Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS for Augmentation of Funds
•        Annex B — Declaration of Savings under MOOE for Augmentation of Funds
•        Annex C — Budgetary Requirement for COVID-19 Hazard Pay under the SAF – PS; and
•        Annex D — Budgetary Requirement for COVID-19 Hazard Pay under the SAF – MOOE

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 4, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes hazard pay of PhP500 per day for Manila City government employees who physically reported for work during the Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) and Modified ECQ from March 27 to May 14, 2021, amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The benefit applies to all personnel, including regular, contractual, casual, job order, and contract-of-service workers, provided they were authorized to work on-site. A total of PhP195.9 million will be allocated from savings in the 2021 city budget to cover the cost.

ORDINANCE NO. 8774

AN ORDINANCE CONVERTING THE VACANT POSITIONS OF ENGINEER V TO ARCHITECT V AND LABORATORY INSPECTOR II AND III TO ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER II AND III IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING AND PUBLIC WORKS BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this draft Ordinance can be found in Sec. 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: “In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations”;
WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program, composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC, on May 12, 2006, came out with Resolution No. 1, which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following: (a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Retitling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions, whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions may be created, as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;
WHEREAS, the proponent, the Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW), has certified that the collapsed items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary while the positions being created will immediately address its most urgent need to fill up several administrative and technical service positions;
WHEREAS, the generated savings from the scrapped positions will be more than enough to cover the computed amount needed to fund the created positions and that the total amount for Personal Services, including the new positions, will not exceed the 45% statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation;
NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability.
The City and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling down, phasing out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SECTION 2. Abolition of Section. — The Gas Laboratory Section is hereby abolished since the scrapped positions of Laboratory Inspector III and II (Item Nos. 477 and 478) are deemed no longer functional.

SECTION 3. Conversion of Plantilla Positions. — The following vacant positions in the Department of Engineering and Public Works are hereby converted to new plantilla items, as follows:
FROM        TO        ITEM NO.        POSITION        SALARY GRADE        ANNUAL RATE (2021)        POSITION        SALARY GRADE        ANNUAL RATE (2021)
Engineer V        Architect V        5        24-2        PhP 1,037,544.00        Architect V        24-1        PhP 1,020,888.00        
Laboratory Inspector III        Administrative Officer II        477        14-1        PhP 351,324.00        Administrative Officer II        14-1        PhP 351,324.00        
Laboratory Inspector II        Administrative Officer III        478        10-1        PhP 242,628.00        Administrative Officer III        10-1        PhP 242,628.00        

SECTION 4. Qualifications, Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SECTION 5. Appointments. — The employment and appointment for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SECTION 6. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the creation of the three (3) new regular positions shall be sourced from the existing three (3) positions to be abolished for this purpose, as provided for under the 2022 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the plantilla of personnel of the Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW).

SECTION 7. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 23, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance converts certain vacant positions in the Department of Engineering and Public Works. Specifically, Engineer V positions are reclassified as Architect V, and Laboratory Inspector II and III positions are converted into Administrative Officer II and III positions. The changes follow the government's scrap-and-build policy, ensuring that no additional funding is needed as the cost of the new positions is covered by the savings from abolishing the old ones.

This ordinance granted a general amnesty from October 1 to December 29, 2021, waiving surcharges, penalties, and interest on overdue business taxes, real property taxes, regulatory fees, and service charges in Manila. Taxpayers only needed to pay the original tax amount within the given period, and all penalties would be forgiven. It also allowed those with pending local tax cases or traffic violations to benefit from reduced or waived penalties under certain conditions. The goal was to help individuals and businesses financially affected by the pandemic recover and catch up on their obligations.

ORDINANCE NO. 8772

AN ORDINANCE REGULATING THE USE OF MODIFIED MUFFLER/EXHAUST PIPE AND SIMILAR DEVICES ON ALL TYPES OF MOTOR VEHICLES RESULTING IN THE EMISSION OF EXCESSIVE, LOUD, AND UNREASONABLE NOISE IN THE CITY OF MANILA AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Sections 15 and 16, Article II of the 1987 Philippine Constitution declare it a policy of the State to protect and promote the right to health of the people, as well as to a balanced and healthful ecology in accord with the rhythm and harmony of nature;

WHEREAS, motor vehicles offered for sale to the public are originally equipped with factory-installed mufflers or exhaust pipes primarily designed to minimize and eradicate noise pollution;

WHEREAS, it is of judicial notice that there are owners who remove and detach the factory-installed muffler or exhaust pipe of their motor vehicles and modify or replace them with mufflers or pipes that increase the emitted sound to a level that causes annoyance, disturbance, displeasure, and irritation to the public;

WHEREAS, this rampant but obnoxious practice has resulted in serious disagreements, including bodily injuries and death, between owners of motor vehicles with modified mufflers or pipes and the public;

WHEREAS, these motor vehicles with modified mufflers or exhaust pipes that emit loud and roaring noise cause serious discomfort, particularly during nighttime, and have created numerous complaints and condemnation from the general public;

WHEREAS, other than the abatement of public nuisance and prohibition against public disorder as provided and defined in the Civil Code of the Philippines and the Revised Penal Code of the Philippines, respectively, there is a need for a local statute that specifically addresses this type of noise pollution that has become a perennial source of annoyance with deleterious effects on the public welfare;

WHEREAS, Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, emphatically declares that “every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, incidental for the efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare”: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. TITLE. — This Ordinance shall be known and cited as the “Motor Vehicle Modified Muffler Noise Regulation Ordinance of the City of Manila.”

SEC. 2. DECLARATION OF POLICY. — It is the policy of the City of Manila to promote, uphold, and maintain peace and preserve a peaceful environment within its territorial jurisdiction for the general welfare of its inhabitants, particularly the young and elderly. The purpose of this Ordinance is to regulate and penalize all types of motor vehicles with modified mufflers or exhaust pipes that emit excessive, loud, and unreasonable noise.

SEC. 3. SCOPE. — This Ordinance shall cover all motor vehicles, whether public or private, with modified mufflers or exhaust pipes, including those already existing, in the City of Manila, with the exemption of those motor vehicles designed for use in sports competitions, motor shows, and those with a displacement of 400cc and above.

SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF TERMS. — As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall mean:
a) Muffler — A device consisting of a series of chambers or other mechanical designs for the purpose of receiving exhaust gas from an internal combustion engine and effective in reducing noise.

b) Motor Vehicle — A self-propelled road and off-road vehicle, commonly wheeled, that does not operate on rails such as trains or trams and is used for commercial and private purposes in the transportation of passengers and property.

c) Modified Muffler — The aftermarket change/replacement of a muffler from its original form that emits excessive and unreasonable noise.

d) Excessive Noise — Any sound that disturbs or annoys, or which causes or tends to cause disturbance and annoyance to humans.

e) Unreasonable Loud Noise — A noise that is incompatible with the time and location to the extent that it creates an actual or imminent interference with peace and tranquility.

f) Decibel — A unit for measuring the loudness or intensity of sound.

SEC. 5. PROHIBITED ACTS. — It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate a motor vehicle with a modified muffler that emits and produces noise levels beyond the national standard of 99 decibels (dB) taken at an engine speed of 2,000 to 2,500 rpm.

SEC. 6. IMPLEMENTATION AND ENFORCEMENT. — In line with their mandates, the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) and Philippine National Police (PNP) shall serve as the lead agencies in the enforcement of this ordinance. They shall fulfill the following responsibilities:
a. Report, apprehend, and maintain the records of all violators of this Ordinance and ascertain how many times an offender has violated the ordinance.
b. Collect and safeguard all copies of Ordinance Violation Receipts being issued by duly authorized enforcement officers.
c. Collect and safeguard all confiscated driver's licenses and return the same to their owners once the pertinent conditions of this ordinance have been met.
d. Accredit official motor vehicle repair shops that may undertake the repairs of the vehicles of offenders of this ordinance on behalf of the city.
e. Coordinate with the Land Transportation Office (LTO) for the proper implementation of this Ordinance.

SEC. 7. ROLE OF BARANGAY. — The Sangguniang Barangay and its officials shall serve as a complementary force in the effective implementation of this Ordinance within their territorial jurisdiction by reporting the offender to the agencies mentioned above.

SEC. 8. AUTHORITY OF THE ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS. — Officers that will enforce this Ordinance must be duly deputized by the City Mayor.

The duly deputized enforcement officer(s) shall confiscate the driver's license of the violator and shall issue an Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR) in lieu thereof that will serve as the latter's temporary driver's license for a period of five (5) days from the date of its issuance.

The confiscated driver's license will be returned to the violator once his/her vehicle passes a second noise level testing and proof of payment of the corresponding penalties has been presented.

All fees and penalties as provided for in this Ordinance shall be paid to the City Treasurer and will accrue to the general fund of the city government.

SEC. 9. PENALTY. — Any person who violates this Ordinance shall be punished as follows:
a) Failure to install an adequate muffler system or having a muffler system that does not suppress the noise emanating from the vehicle but rather increases the noise shall be penalized as follows:
1st offense — Penalty of One Thousand Pesos (PhP 1,000.00), and removal of modified muffler or exhaust pipe;
2nd offense — Penalty of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 3,000.00), and removal of modified muffler or exhaust pipe;
3rd offense and subsequent offenses — Penalty of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00), and removal of modified muffler or exhaust pipe.

In case the motor vehicle of the offender fails to pass the noise level testing for a second time, the city government will undertake the necessary repair of the vehicle, with the offender shouldering the cost of repairs to be charged by the duly accredited vehicle repair shop in addition to the penalties already due.

In case the offender refuses to submit his/her vehicle for noise level testing, or if an offender refuses to surrender his/her driver's license, or in any way resists the impounding of his/her vehicle, such acts will be presumed to be willful violations of this Ordinance.

SEC. 10. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. — If for any reason, a part of this Ordinance is declared illegal or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SEC. 11. REPEALING CLAUSE. — All previous ordinances and rules/regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby deemed modified or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 12. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. — This Ordinance shall take effect after all requirements for official posting prescribed in Section 511 of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as “The Local Government Code of 1991,” have been met.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 16, 2021.
short_text: The City of Manila prohibits the use of modified mufflers or exhaust pipes on any motor vehicle that emit excessive, loud, or disturbing noise beyond 99 decibels. Only vehicles used in sports competitions, motor shows, or those with 400cc engine displacement and above are exempt. The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau, PNP, and barangays will enforce this rule, with enforcement officers authorized to confiscate licenses and require noise testing. Repeated violations result in increasing fines and mandatory removal of the modified parts.
fines:
1st offense: Php1,000 and removal of the modified muffler/exhaust

2nd offense: Php3,000 and removal of the modified muffler/exhaust

3rd and succeeding offenses: Php5,000 and removal of the modified muffler/exhaust

Additional penalties: Vehicle repair costs if noise levels remain excessive after retesting; refusal to comply may be considered a willful violation.

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

Interest Expenses: PhP 60,342,916.00

Attached are the following details:
Annex A — Declaration of Savings under MOOE for Augmentation of Funds by the City Treasurer and City Accountant
Annex B — Augmentation of Account under MOOE

SEC. 2. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 13, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to reallocate PHP 119,434,886.00 in savings from its 2021 budget to increase funding for specific operating expenses. These funds will be used for welfare goods under the Office of the Mayor, taxes and licenses under the City General Services Office, and interest payments for statutory and contractual obligations. PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the COVID-19 global pandemic has, among other things, drastically altered numerous workplace processes and extensively placed a tremendous pressure on time-sensitive adaptability and response of fiscal management in order to successfully address the unprecedented challenges brought about by the prevailing plague;
WHEREAS, the City Council has the power to approve ordinances necessary for an efficient and effective city government and to determine the positions, salaries, wages, allowances, and other emoluments and benefits of officials and employees paid wholly or mainly from city funds [Sec. 458 (1) (viii), Local Government Code];
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this draft Ordinance can be found in Sec. 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: “In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules and regulations”;
WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC in May 12, 2006 came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following: (a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Re-titling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;
WHEREAS, the contemplated revision in the Personnel Schedule of the City Treasurer's Office is compelled by the unquestionable necessity to streamline treasury operations in order to quickly adapt and effectively respond to different exigencies and best serve the critical funding requirements of the City Government of Manila;
WHEREAS, the proposed adjustments consist of minor but crucial changes in the current personnel contingent as there would be no significant increase in the present allotment for personnel services;
WHEREAS, the re-titling will simply remove the eligibility requirement and will thus allow lower-level personnel who have been competently performing comparable tasks for many years to be promoted to these higher positions;
WHEREAS, the modifications in the organizational structure and staffing pattern will ensure that the respective job descriptions suitably correspond to specific and existing functions and guarantee that essential official responsibilities are identified and operational assignments are rationalized: NOW, THEREFORE,

 Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability.
The city and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling-down, phasing-out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to reallocate over PHP 10.7 million in unused funds (savings) within its 2021 budget to support key projects and services. These include allowances for newly created positions in the Manila Urban Settlements Office, employment programs for students and interns, security for city parks, and improvements to public parks and monuments.
