ORDINANCE NO. 8764

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING VARIOUS PLANTILLA ITEMS IN MANILA URBAN SETTLEMENTS OFFICE AND REPLACING THE SAME WITH THE NEW POSITIONS THROUGH SCRAP-AND-BUILD POLICY AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
Supplementing Ordinance No. 8730, also known as the Manila Urban Housing Ordinance, which in addition initiated the Organization of the Manila Urban Settlements Office or MUSO, pursuant to the functions ascribed by Executive Order No. 81-03, and other subsequent issuances, shall act as the primary local government entity responsible for the management of housing and urban development within the territorial jurisdiction of the city as specified in Section 5 of the said Ordinance;
WHEREAS, to meet the needs of the present demand of a very functional and responsive office, the Manila Urban Settlements Office deemed it imperative to amend the organizational structure and staffing pattern;
WHEREAS, the existing complement fails to provide the plantilla position with the appropriate manpower to carry out the additional functions mandated under the above-mentioned Ordinance, thus, preventing the smooth flow and direction of the said office;
WHEREAS, the Manila Urban Settlements Office has certified that the collapsed items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary while the positions being created will immediately address its most urgent need to fill up several positions;
WHEREAS, the generated savings from the abolished positions and available Personnel Services appropriations may cover the funding for the created positions: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Abolished Plantilla Position. — The following positions are hereby abolished under the Manila Urban Settlements Office:

Planning Officer II        15-1        PhP 384,636.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer II        13-1        PhP 321,048.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer II        13-6        $40,272.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer II        —        PhP 321,048.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer II        13-1        PhP 321,048.00
Administrative Aide VI        6-1        PhP 186,288.00
Administrative Aide V        5-6        PhP 182,544.00
Administrative Aide IV        4-1        PhP 165,684.00
Administrative Aide I        1-1        PhP 138,612.00
TOTAL: 9 positions — PhP 2,361,180.00

SECTION 2. New Plantilla Positions. — The following are the new Plantilla Positions as replacement to the abolished Plantilla Positions under the Urban Settlements Office as mentioned in Section 1 hereof, to wit:
TITLE        DIVISION        NUMBER        SALARY RATE (PER ANNUM)
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer VI        Project Management        1        PhP 1,020,888.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer VI        Special Projects and Community Affairs        1        PhP 1,020,888.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer I        Project Management        1        PhP 267,792.00
Housing and Homesite Regulation Officer I        Special Projects and Community Affairs        1        PhP 267,792.00

SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code and Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant laws.

SEC. 4. Appointments. — The appointments for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 5. Appropriation. — The amount for the creation of the six (6) new plantilla positions shall be sourced from funds which shall be derived from the existing nine (9) positions to be abolished for this purpose and available Personnel Services appropriations as provided for under the 2021 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the plantilla of personnel of the Manila Urban Settlements Office.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 22, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance removes nine outdated or vacant job positions in the Manila Urban Settlements Office (MUSO) and replaces them with six more relevant positions to better address the office's current responsibilities. The changes aim to improve MUSO's efficiency and ensure that it has the right staff to fulfill its expanded duties under the city's housing ordinance. The funds saved from the old positions will be used to cover the new ones.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8763

AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING STRICT AND FULL COMPLIANCE WITH SECTION 28(8) OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 7279, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “URBAN DEVELOPMENT AND HOUSING ACT OF 1992,” ON ALL EVICTION ACTIVITIES INVOLVING UNDERPRIVILEGED AND HOMELESS CITIZENS IN THE CITY OF MANILA, WHETHER JUDICIAL OR EXTRAJUDICIAL, AND PROVIDING PENALTIES IN VIOLATION THEREOF

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 9, Article XIII of the 1987 Constitution provides that:
“The State shall, by law, and for the common good, undertake, in cooperation with the public sector, a continuing program of urban land reform and housing which will make available at affordable cost decent housing and basic services to underprivileged and homeless citizens in urban centers and resettlement areas. It shall also promote adequate employment opportunities to such citizens. In the implementation of such program, the State shall respect the rights of small property owners.”
WHEREAS, the same provision likewise provides that: “Urban or rural poor dwellers shall not be evicted nor their dwellings demolished, except in accordance with law and in a just and humane manner.” (Section 10, Article XIII of the 1987 Constitution)
WHEREAS, Republic Act No. 7279, otherwise known as the “Urban Development and Housing Act of 1992,” was enacted to undertake, in cooperation with the private sector, a comprehensive and continuing Urban Development and Housing Program;
WHEREAS, among the objectives of R.A. No. 7279 is to: “Uplift the conditions of the underprivileged and homeless citizens in urban areas and in resettlement areas by making available to them decent housing at affordable cost, basic services, and employment opportunities.” (Section 2(a), R.A. No. 7279)
WHEREAS, the City of Manila, the capital city of the Philippines, partakes in the implementation of the Urban Development and Housing Act of 1992, and in ensuring the rights of the urban poor to humane housing: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of State Policy. — Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the enhancement of economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.

SEC. 2. Strict Compliance with Section 28(8) of Republic Act No. 7279. — All persons within the City of Manila shall strictly and fully comply with Section 28(8) of Republic Act No. 7279 on all eviction activities involving underprivileged and homeless citizens in the City of Manila, whether judicial or extrajudicial.

SEC. 3. Penalties. —  Any person found liable for violating this Ordinance shall be penalized with a fine not exceeding Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00) and imprisonment for a period not exceeding one (1) year.

In addition to the penalties provided in the preceding paragraph, any public official found violating the provisions of this Ordinance shall be subject to administrative sanctions under the Civil Service Laws, Rules, and Regulations.

SEC. 4. The City Legal Office shall assist any and all complaints of non-compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance and initiate the necessary legal proceedings. The Urban Settlements Office of Manila shall identify all lands and properties which are covered within the provisions of this Ordinance.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 5, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance mandates that all eviction activities involving underprivileged and homeless citizens in Manila must fully follow Section 28(8) of the Urban Development and Housing Act of 1992 (R.A. No. 7279). This means evictions—whether through court orders or not—must be lawful, just, and humane. The City Legal Office and Urban Settlements Office are tasked with enforcing and assisting in its implementation.
fines: Up to ₱5,000 fine and/or 1 year imprisonment; public officials may face administrative sanctions

ORDINANCE NO. 8762

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE TITLE AND SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8594, BY CHANGING THE NAME OF THE FRANCHISEE FROM UNITED ASSOCIATION OF COCKPIT OWNERS AND OPERATORS OF THE PHILIPPINES, INCORPORATED TO LUCKY 8 STAR QUEST INC., THE FORMER HAVING AN EXISTING FRANCHISE IN THE CITY OF MANILA BUT TRANSFERRED ITS ENTIRE BUSINESS OPERATION TO LUCKY 8 STAR QUEST INC., WHICH HAS VAST MANPOWER RESOURCES TO ACCOMMODATE THE LEGAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE PHILIPPINE AMUSEMENT AND GAMING CORPORATION

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on 14 November 2019, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8594, granting a franchise to the United Association of Cockpit Owners and Operators of the Philippines, Incorporated, to broadcast live and data-streamed cockfighting activities and derbies at commercial establishments, and to establish, operate, and maintain off-site cockpit betting stations within the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, on 1 July 2021, Mr. Manuel M. Zarcal, Assistant Secretary to the Mayor, submitted a letter to the City Council of Manila, forwarding the request of United Association of Cockpit Owners and Operators of the Philippines, Incorporated to amend Ordinance No. 8594 to reflect their change of name to Lucky 8 Star Quest Inc.; NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. The Title of Ordinance No. 8594 is hereby amended and shall now read as follows:
"AN ORDINANCE GRANTING FRANCHISE TO LUCKY 8 STAR QUEST INC., TO BROADCAST LIVE AND DATA-STREAMED COCKFIGHTING ACTIVITIES AND DERBIES AT COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS AND TO ESTABLISH, OPERATE AND MAINTAIN OFF-SITE COCKPIT BETTING STATION WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA"

SEC. 2.  Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8594 is hereby amended, and shall now read as follows:
"SECTION 1. Nature, Scope, Grant of Franchise. — Subject to the provisions of applicable laws, rules, and regulations, a franchise to broadcast live and data-stream cockfighting activities and derbies at commercial establishments such as bars, clubs, restaurants, and the like within the City of Manila is hereby granted to Lucky 8 Star Quest Inc., provided that the cockfighting subject to broadcast shall only be done in a licensed cockpit, unless otherwise allowed in some other area, pursuant to Presidential Decree No. 449."

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. —  This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 5, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance changes the franchise holder named in a previous law (Ordinance No. 8594) from the United Association of Cockpit Owners and Operators of the Philippines, Inc. to Lucky 8 Star Quest Inc. The change reflects a full transfer of business operations to the new company, which meets the regulatory requirements of the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation (PAGCOR). The new franchisee is authorized to broadcast cockfights and set up off-site betting stations in Manila.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8761

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE CITY EPIDEMIOLOGY AND SURVEILLANCE UNIT (CESU) UNDER THE MANILA HEALTH DEPARTMENT, DEFINING ITS FUNCTIONS IN COMPLIANCE WITH REPUBLIC ACT NO. 11332 (OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “MANDATORY REPORTING OF NOTIFIABLE DISEASES AND HEALTH EVENTS OF PUBLIC CONCERN ACT”), ESTABLISHING ITS MANPOWER COMPLEMENT THROUGH THE FILLING UP OF VACANT POSITIONS ALREADY EXISTING IN THE DEPARTMENT AND CONVERTING VARIOUS ABOLISHED ITEMS FOR NEW PLANTILLA POSITIONS OF ONE (1) MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIST IV, FOUR (4) DISEASE SURVEILLANCE OFFICER III AND SIX (6) DISEASE SURVEILLANCE OFFICER II, AND PROVIDING FUNDS NECESSARY THEREFOR

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, at the end of 2019, the World Health Organization (WHO) had identified the Philippines as the country with the 5ᵗʰ highest number of reported measles cases after the Department of Health (DOH), on January 2019, declared a measles outbreak in the National Capital Region (NCR) reporting a total of eight hundred fifty-five (855) cases of measles and thirty-seven (37) deaths;
WHEREAS, in September 2019, the DOH declared a polio outbreak in the Philippines after it re-emerged in the country 19 years since the last known case and in which the City of Manila reported a total of seventy-seven (77) suspected cases by January 2020;
WHEREAS, on January 30, 2020, the WHO declared the outbreak of the Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in Wuhan, China as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern and subsequently, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte issued Proclamation No. 922 declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines amid the COVID-19 outbreak which today has since afflicted more than 1.2 Million Filipinos and claimed the lives of more than 20,000;
WHEREAS, Section 15, Article II of the 1987 Philippine Constitution provides that the State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them;
WHEREAS, under Section 2 on the Declaration of Policy of Republic Act No. 11332, otherwise known as the “Mandatory Reporting of Notifiable Diseases and Health Events of Public Concern Act,” the State shall endeavor to protect the people from public health threats through the efficient and effective disease surveillance of notifiable diseases including emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, diseases for elimination and eradication, epidemics and health events including chemical, radio-nuclear and environmental agents of public health concern, and provide an effective response system in compliance with the 2005 International Health Regulations (IHR) of the World Health Organization (WHO);
WHEREAS, Section 8 of RA 11332 provides the mandate of the Epidemiology and Surveillance Units (ESUs) to include the following:
(a) Capturing and verifying all reported notifiable diseases and health events of public health concern,
(b) Providing timely, accurate and reliable epidemiologic information to appropriate agencies,
(c) Conducting disease surveillance and response activities,
(d) Coordinating needed response, and
(e) Facilitating capacity building in the field of epidemiology, disease surveillance and response at the Epidemiology Bureau:
NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Creation of CESU. — The City Epidemiology and Disease Surveillance Unit (CESU) is hereby created under the Manila Health Department (MHD) under the direct supervision of the City Health Officer in order to streamline and strengthen the implementation of a robust public health surveillance and response system in the City of Manila.

SECTION 2. Functions. — The CESU shall have the following duties and functions:
a. Manage an early warning public health surveillance and response system within the geographic jurisdiction of the City Government of Manila, using the Philippine Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response System (PIDSR) and the Event-Based Surveillance (ESR), and involving mandatory reporting of notifiable diseases by all health centers, local and private hospitals, clinics and laboratories within the City of Manila;
b. Provide epidemiological reports on notifiable diseases including vaccine-preventable diseases and health events to the Office of the Mayor, policy makers, program managers and other key stakeholders;
c. Maintain special surveillance operations (HIV Surveillance, STI Laboratory Surveillance, Non-Communicable Surveillance);
d. Conduct field epidemiologic investigation, including the following —
  1. Outbreak investigation
  2. Event-based investigation
e. Conduct special surveys (e.g., Integrated HIV Behavioral and Serologic Survey) and scientific research;
f. Provide technical assistance and capacity building activities related to epidemiology and disease surveillance;
g. Conduct rapid health assessments during calamities, disasters and/or emergencies;
h. Establish disease surveillance in evacuation centers during disasters or calamities; and
i. Establish networks with other government and non-government agencies such as the Department of Health Regional Epidemiology and Surveillance Units, Department of Science and Technology, Local Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council and World Health Organization.

SECTION 3. Composition. — The City of Manila Epidemiology and Surveillance Unit shall have the following manpower complement, to be filled up from vacant plantilla items existing in the MHD and from newly created positions not available in the department's current Personal Schedule:
POSITION        NUMBER        SALARY GRADE
Medical Officer V        1        25-1
Medical Officer IV        1        23-1
Nurse V        1        22-4
Nurse IV        1        20-1
Medical Technologist IV*        1        20-1
Statistician IV        7        18-4
Disease Surveillance Officer III*        4        18-1
Disease Surveillance Officer II*        6        15-1
Computer Programmer I        2        10-1
Administrative Aide IV        1        4-1
Administrative Aide III        1        3-1
Administrative Aide I        2        1-1
TOTAL        34        
*New Positions for Creation
Medical doctors and any allied Medical Health Workers (i.e., Nurse or Medical Technologist) assigned to this Unit shall have commensurate training on Applied or Field Epidemiology and Disease/Event-based Surveillance by the DOH or any equivalent training from recognized educational institutions.

SECTION 4. Conversion of Abolished to New Positions. — The following positions are hereby abolished under the Manila Health Department:
TITLE OF POSITION        NUMBER        ITEM #        SALARY GRADE        AUTHORIZED RATE (PER ANNUM)
Medical Officer IV        1        279        23-1        PhP 1,382,558.00
Medical Officer III        5        341–345        21-1        PhP 5,158,738.40
Nurse IV        1        1036        20-1        PhP 981,132.64
Medical Equipment Technician II        1        774        8-1        PhP 362,995.68
TOTAL        8                        PhP 7,885,424.72
The following new Plantilla Items are hereby created under the Manila Health Department and assigned to the CESU:
TITLE OF POSITION        NUMBER        SALARY GRADE        ANNUAL RATE
Medical Technologist IV        1        20-1        PhP 927,475.68
Disease Surveillance Officer III        4        18-1        PhP 3,046,952.32
Disease Surveillance Officer II        6        15-1        PhP 3,619,656.00
TOTAL        11                PhP 7,594,084.00

SECTION 5. Qualifications, Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SECTION 6. Appointments. — The employment and appointment for those who will be occupying the herein subject positions shall be within the prescribed qualification standards and guidelines set by the CSC, Department of Health (DOH) and other relevant agencies.

SECTION 7. Appropriations. — The amount necessary thereof is hereby appropriated out of the available funds of the Department or the City Government, as the case may be, to be taken for the purpose of funding the Operating Expenditures and Initial Capital Outlay of the CESU. Thereafter, the herein budgetary requirement shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget of the MHD.

SECTION 8. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SECTION 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 28, 2021.
short_text: The City of Manila has established the City Epidemiology and Surveillance Unit (CESU) within the Manila Health Department to manage public health surveillance and response, including mandatory disease reporting. CESU will monitor and respond to outbreaks, conduct investigations, and offer technical support during emergencies. It will also focus on specific health concerns like HIV, STIs, and vaccine-preventable diseases. New positions will be added to the unit, and the department will repurpose some existing vacant positions to strengthen the city's health response system. The budget for CESU will be funded through the City Health Department's annual budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 8760 

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CHAPTER 7, SECTION 37 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8754, ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE STREAMLINED PROCEDURES FOR THE ISSUANCE OF LOCAL BUSINESS LICENSES, CLEARANCES, PERMITS, CERTIFICATIONS OR AUTHORIZATIONS IN THE CITY OF MANILA PURSUANT TO RULE IX OF THE IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 11032, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE ‘EASE OF DOING BUSINESS AND EFFICIENT GOVERNMENT SERVICE DELIVERY ACT OF 2018’ AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES" 

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT: 
SECTION 1. Chapter 7, Section 37 of Ordinance No. 8754 is hereby amended and shall now read as follows:
 “SEC. 37. Rate of Fees to be Collected. — The rate of fees to be collected by the City Treasurer’s Office for the issuance of Barangay Clearance for Business Permit and Barangay Clearance for Locational Clearance (as a requirement for Building Permit), shall be in accordance with the rates fixed by the enacted Barangay Ordinance of the concerned barangay. Nevertheless, each barangay is reminded to adopt, update, or adjust its own Barangay Revenue Ordinance whenever necessary, and to comply with the guidelines set forth in R.A. 11032 and by the DILG and DOF through DILG-DOF Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2019-01, dated 17 May 2019, and subsequent related issuances. 

In conformity with the guiding principles laid down in R.A. 11032 and the said Joint Memorandum Circular, it is hereby recommended that the Barangay Clearance Fee to be imposed by each barangay shall not exceed Five Hundred Pesos (PhP 500.00). 

Should there be a barangay that fails to adopt, update, or adjust its own Barangay Revenue Ordinance in compliance with R.A. 11032 and the aforementioned circular, the City shall, in the interim period, collect a Barangay Clearance Fee of Five Hundred Pesos (PhP 500.00) for clearances issued on behalf of the said barangay, pending its eventual compliance. All Barangay Ordinances issued by barangays in relation to the imposition of Barangay Clearance Fees shall be subject to the City’s power of review under Section 57 of the Local Government Code of 1991. Rates for barangay clearances and permits for specific documents, other activities not related to doing business, or the use of barangay facilities shall be left to the sound discretion of each barangay.” 

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

 This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 17, 2021.
short_text: The City of Manila amended a previous ordinance to regulate the fees barangays can charge for business and locational clearances, recommending a cap of PHP 500 per clearance as aligned with national policies. If a barangay fails to update its revenue ordinance, the city will temporarily impose this fee on its behalf until the barangay complies. This amendment aims to streamline government processes and make transactions more efficient under the Ease of Doing Business law.

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING VARIOUS ITEMS UNDER THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATING EXPENSES THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE FY 2021 ANNUAL BUDGET AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the FY 2021 Annual Budget appropriated funds for various items under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the FY 2021 Annual Budget;

WHEREAS, the City Treasurer and the City Accountant have issued the Certificate of Availability of Funds/Cash as a supporting document to the augmentation through savings;

However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations;

short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to reallocate ₱142,890,000.00 in savings from its 2021 budget to increase funding for important services like food supplies, janitorial and security services, drugs and medicines, and donations. These savings come from unused funds within the same budget category (Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses), in compliance with the Local Government Code.

ORDINANCE NO. 8757

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE REVERSION TO THE GENERAL FUND OF THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF TWO HUNDRED SIXTY-FOUR MILLION EIGHTEEN THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED FIVE PESOS (PHP 264,018,405.00), UNDER THE CAPITAL OUTLAY APPROPRIATIONS OF FY 2015 AND FY 2017, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, categorically provides:
“Section 322. Reversion of Unexpended Balances of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. — Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled. 

The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation and the sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations, subject to the provisions of this Section.”

WHEREAS, amounts were appropriated for certain projects under the Capital Outlay account of the FY 2015 and FY 2017 Annual Budgets. However, due to changing circumstances, it was determined that said projects are no longer necessary;

WHEREAS, for Fiscal Year 2021, there are priority programs and projects which need urgent funding through a Supplemental Budget: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Reversion. — The following funds under the FY 2015 and FY 2017 Continuing Capital Outlay Appropriations are hereby reverted to the General Fund, to wit:
Particulars        Amount
1. FY 2015 Continuing Appropriations – Ord. No. 8381        
Non-Office (Major Projects of the City):
Modernization, Rehabilitation and Redevelopment of Markets - PhP 240,000,000.00

2. FY 2017 Continuing Appropriations – Ord. No. 8515        
Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau:
Other Structures        PhP 24,018,405.00

TOTAL: PhP 264,018,405.00

Attached as Annex A — Statement of Availability of Funds/Cash.

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 17, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the City of Manila to return a total of ₱264,018,405.00 from unspent capital outlay funds from 2015 and 2017 back to the city's General Fund. These funds were originally set aside for projects such as the modernization of markets and traffic infrastructure, but are no longer needed. The reversion allows the city to reallocate the funds for urgent 2021 programs through a supplemental budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 8756

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF ORDINANCE NO. 8565, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8632, ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP 500.00) MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE TO ALL BONA FIDE SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED OR PERSONS WITH DISABILITY AND SOLO PARENT RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES”

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. The following provisions of Ordinance No. 8565 are hereby further amended and shall now read as follows, with the succeeding section numbers adjusted accordingly:
“SEC. 5. REQUIREMENTS FOR THE AVAILMENT OF THE BENEFITS.
I. For Senior Citizens:
a. Must be sixty (60) years old or above;
b. Must be a Filipino citizen or a dual citizen of the Philippines and another country, provided that they fulfill the residency requirement;
c. Must be a registered voter of the City of Manila with the exemption of the following:
1.        Bedridden senior citizens as proven by an updated medical certificate; and
2.        Senior citizens aged 85 years old and above and are incapable of going to voting precincts.
d. Must be a bona fide resident of the City of Manila for the last six (6) months;
e. Must be included in the master list (database) of the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs of the City of Manila; and
f. For Muslim Senior Citizens without birth certificates, must provide a Certification from the Muslim Affairs Coordinator providing that they are already 60 years of age and are entitled to register at the OSCA Manila before availing monetary allowance.
II. For Persons with Disability:
a.        Must be at least eighteen (18) years of age;
b.        Must be a registered voter of the City of Manila; provided, however, if the PWD does not qualify as a registered voter, his or her parents or legal guardian must be a registered voter(s) in the City of Manila;
c.        Must be a bona fide resident of the City of Manila for the last six (6) months; and
d.        Must be included in the master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare Office.
III. For Solo Parents:
a. Must be a registered voter of the City of Manila; provided, however, if the solo parent is a minor, his or her parents or legal guardian must be a registered voter(s) in the City of Manila;
b. Must be a bona fide resident of the City of Manila for the last six (6) months; and
c. Must be included in the master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare Office.

SEC. 6. VERIFICATION. — The Office for Senior Citizen Affairs of the City of Manila and the Manila Department of Social Welfare Office shall verify the authenticity of the requirements submitted by the applicants.

SEC. 7. LIABILITY OF BARANGAY OFFICIALS. — Barangay Officials who submit false documents may be held administratively and criminally liable as may be prescribed by law.”

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. — If any part of this Act is declared unconstitutional or invalid, such parts or provisions thereof not so declared shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 14, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance updates the rules for giving ₱500 monthly financial aid to qualified senior citizens, persons with disabilities (PWDs), and solo parents living in Manila. It sets clearer requirements for eligibility, including age, residency, and voter registration status. Special rules apply to bedridden seniors, elderly individuals aged 85 and above, and Muslim seniors without birth certificates. Barangay officials who submit fake documents may face legal penalties. The ordinance ensures only legitimate residents receive the allowance through proper verification.
fines: Administrative and criminal liability for submitting false documents (Barangay officials)

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8755

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE AUTOMATION OF TRANSACTIONS
THROUGH THE INTERNET AND THE DIGITIZATION OF TRANSACTIONAL
DOCUMENTS IN ALL DEPARTMENTS, OFFICES, BUREAUS AND AGENCIES
UNDER THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE

RE: AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE AUTOMATION OF TRANSACTIONS
THROUGH THE INTERNET AND THE DIGITIZATION OF TRANSACTIONAL
DOCUMENTS IN ALL DEPARTMENTS, OFFICES, BUREAUS AND AGENCIES
UNDER THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA

The proposed measure has for its purpose the establishment of an alternative towards a more significant and effective approach towards the transaction of business with the City Government in terms of inter-office interactions as well as interactions of the City Government with its constituency and the public at large. 

For so long, it has been noted that the City Government remains largely engaged in conventional means to fulfill its vast number of duties and functions. Computerization has already dominated the way official and employees go about their business, but much remains to be addressed. One line of action that is viewed as most appropriate is the conversion of orthodox means to automation with the end view of dispensing with physical contact with individuals and the need to utilize documents in paper from, which is alternatively achievable through digitization.

As of the time of submission of this proposed measure, the entire planet remains locked with the pandemic caused by the spread of COVID-19 since it was discovered in the first quarter of 2020. The City of Manila continues to wage war with the viral contagion that has both afflicted lives and ruined businesses, which are attributable to normal human interaction and the lack extreme caution in the handling of documents that are at the disposal of the City Government. Such predicament can nonetheless be remedied. With the full use of automation and digitization and the support of the internet, both the General Welfare and the constitutional right to health are served essentially, hence this proposed measure.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. - The City Government recognizes the value of automation and digitization in order to promote a contactless interaction between and among offices, as well as the transacting public, as well as a paperless office environment the benefits of which would lead to a smoother course of business transactions within, between and among agencies, institutions and offices under its jurisdiction, including a more efficient service and interaction with other offices and the public in general. Thus, it is hereby declared the policy to adopt technologies in order to reduce document management in physical paper form, dispense with the burden of processing and safekeeping of physical documents, mitigate the need for personal presence and interaction, address the objective of avoiding health risks due to direct or indirect physical contact, and consider other relevant duties and functions or otherwise enhance existing ones, thereby improving work productivity.

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. - As used in this Act, the terms:

1. Transaction - shall refer to any established, routine or institutionalized action or activity involving any department, agency, bureau, division or office of the City Government physically interacting with another or with the public at large, and shall include, but not limited to, the following activities: 
a. Initiative on the part of the head of a department, agency, bureau, division or office to issue any memorandum, notice or similar communication in order to either disseminate information, or to elicit appropriate action, or both;
b. Official meetings, conferences and other similar assemblies requiring personal attendance and participation; 
c. Application or request for transactional document or modifications therein; 
d. Application for service or supportive action; 
e. Payment of taxes or fees, including payment of arrears, fines and/or surcharges; 
f. The procurement or redemption of identification cards and licenses;
g. Application, hiring, promotion, resignation and retirement of personnel; 
h. Issuance of summons and notices; and 
i. Verification of status of action.

2. Transactional Documents - shall refer to any public document in physical paper form and bearing among others a name and signature, whether introduced individually or as a file with accessory documents, that is used to create or carry out, or otherwise accomplish, a valid transaction sought in the ordinary course of business and therefore undergo the acceptable document management process of submission, evaluation, filing, reassessment, approval, retrieval, reproduction or issuance, and which shall include, but it not limited to, the following items:
a. Memoranda
b. Executive Orders
c. Copies of enacted ordinances and adopted resolutions
d. Permits, whether for the purpose of managing a business enterprise, the rental of a public market stall, the zoning classification, construction, demolition renovation of real property, the excavation of land, the interment or transfer of the remains of a deceased person, or use of a city-owned facility or similar property;
e. Health permits and burial permits
f. Permits for recreation
g. Designs of buildings regardless of classification
h. Official receipts
i. Statement of account
j. Local tax declarations and clearances
k. Employee payroll
l. Summons and notices except notices of closure of business
m. Certificates, whether applied for as health, birth, marriage or death

3. Digitized Transactional Document - shall refer to that certain document which is the exact processed version of the original transactional document as defined in the immediately preceding item that underwent exact digitization.

4. Digitization - shall refer to the computerized conversion of the contents of a document or a set of documents into an acceptable and permanent, unalterable digital form.

5. Digitization Device - shall refer to any stationary device that is used to capture paper documents and convert the same into electronic documents of any acceptable format that currently exists or may thereafter be created and adopted as a more appropriate format, and which includes, but is not limited to, scanners whether standalone or part of multipurpose devices. It shall not include any device with the same digitization function which is movable and, therefore, can be carried personally.

6. Cloud Computing - shall refer to the practice of storing regularly used computer data on multiple servers that can be accessed through the Internet.

SEC. 3. Coverage of the Act and Exemptions Therefrom. - This Ordinance shall cover all departments, bureaus, divisions, and offices of the City Government, whether already existing or may hereafter be created, as well as district and satellite offices, including agencies and offices that are financed or subsidized by way of the Annual Local Executive Budget. 

Exempted from the coverage of this Ordinance are such departments, agencies, bureaus, divisions, and offices that are currently implementing a standard and acceptable system of automated transaction of business without prejudice to integration to a unified and updated digital infrastructure as adopted by the City Government, and which includes, but is not limited to, online call or messaging application, confirmation and payment when applicable; provided, however, that such system shall involve the digitization of any document produced in the course of accomplishing a transaction subject thereof.

SEC. 4. Duty to Establish Automated Transactions and Digitize Transactional Documents. - Every unit covered by Section 3 of this Ordinance shall establish an automated or online process of conducting official transactions with other units and the public at large commensurate to its official duties and functions. For this purpose, the director, administrator or chief of office shall undertake the following steps:

a. Secure an appropriate online application link or webpage for inter-office and applicant transactions in relation to the availment of the services of the City Government of Manila, including therein a digital application form that contains the requisite of filling the applicant's basic information before such application is confirmed and accepted;

b. Adopt an appropriate software to enable inter-office videoconferencing between and among heads of offices or authorized representatives if official meetings and other forms of official interaction would not be possible based on justifiable grounds;

c. For departments, bureaus and offices that engage interaction with the public as a routine function, provide for videoconferencing as an alternative mode of interaction;
d. Adopt an appropriate email address for transaction purposes;

e. If the transaction or service applied for requires the submission of any documentary prerequisite, provide for the online submission thereof;

f. If the transaction applied for involves the payment of any sum of money, provide for the inclusion of any of the following options wherever appropriate:
i) Personal payment at the counter of the Office of the City Treasurer following the issuance of a physical Order of Payment

ii) Bank payment using the account number of the Office of the City Treasurer

iii) Bank payment using the separate account number of the department, bureau or office to which the unit belongs

g. Adopt a system-generated response for every completed application with a prescribed deadline for its full accomplishment; and

h. Adopt the incorporation of an electronic identification code in the issuance of documents to confirm authenticity thereof.

Likewise, every such unit shall digitize all transactional documents based on its filing system already in place. For this purpose, the director, administrator or chief of office of the unit shall undertake the following steps commensurate to the volume of documents being handled and processed:

a. Secure an electronic signature for the appointed head and assistant head of every such unit;

b. Acquire and maintain at least one digitization device of a superior and dependable quality and a computer dedicated for digitization purposes;

c. Acquire large-capacity computer hard disks as well as cloud-based computing to store all digitized transactional documents in such quantity as may be necessary in proportion to the bulk of transactional documents produced by such given unit; and

d. Authorize at least one qualified member of its personnel, whose name and position shall be duly recorded and, in whose name, and position a computer shall be provided solely for digitization purposes, and who, under the close supervision of his immediate superior, shall be tasked with the following responsibilities:

i) Digitize all transactional documents on an on-spot basis, including the duty of storing such entries in hard disks and through such computer folders and files with application of backup storage through cloud computing;

ii) Ensure that digitized documents and data stored are locked with a personal password whenever it is not in use;

iii) Ensure the said computer is installed and updated with any reliable anti- virus software, including the periodic scanning of files to detect and remove viruses;

iv) Ensure that that every document digitized is not altered in any way and secured with a digital code, and that the said computer does contain any other software that may alter any digitized transactional document or transmit the same without proper authorization;

v) Ensure that no unauthorized person or personnel shall use his computer, digitize transactional documents, or manage the storage of digitized documents in disks;

vi) At the end of every business day, store hard disks actually used in a locked confidential compartment;

vii) Surrender hard disks that are already full in storage to his immediate superior who shall supply him with new hard disks without delay;

viii) Prevent any digitized transactional document from being transmitted or otherwise shared with any unauthorized person;

ix) Prevent any digitized transactional document from being printed or otherwise reproduced without any authorization or instruction from his immediate superior;

x) Ensure that, in the case of personal data from any individual and confidential papers, digitized transactional documents are not shared with any unauthorized personnel; and

xi) At the end of every workweek, advise his immediate superior of the weekly progress of his digitization process.

In the light of the foregoing provisions, the City Government shall secure the services of an Internet Service Provider (ISP) with an established proven track record for network coverage.

SEC. 5. Digitization Based on Reglementary Periods. - Notwithstanding the date of effectivity of this Ordinance, all transactional documents undergoing reglementary periods that previously took effect shall be digitized ahead of other documents not bearing any such period. In case there is no such period but the transaction sought therein requires immediate action, transactional documents already submitted shall nevertheless be given priority digitization and at the soonest time possible.

SEC. 6. Integrity and Legal Binding Effect of Digitized Transactional Documents. - Digitized transactional documents pursuant to this Ordinance shall be deemed to possess and retain the exact integrity of original transactional documents in physical paper form and shall possess the same value and binding effect derived from the latter before their spot-on digitization and in their complete and unaltered state.

SEC. 7. Utilization of Digitized Transactional Documents. Upon proper authorization, digitized transactional documents shall be used for retrieval, reevaluation, reproduction as the need therefor arises, and other appropriate action without the need for original paper copies and as basis for the fulfillment of the transaction sought therein.

SEC. 8. Protection of Confidential and Personal Data. - Digitized transactional documents containing confidential material or data of any individual shall at all times be protected against any form of unauthorized use that include disclosures of any data obtaining any copy whether by way of computerized transfer or by direct copy using any device.

SEC. 9. Disposal of Original Transactional Documents after Digitization. - Each transactional document in its physical paper form shall be disposed of after digitization and storage both in hard disks and cloud computing; provided, however, that whenever a specific copy or copies of such documents are required by law or rules to be retained, such copy or copies shall be retained without prejudice to the disposal of any excess copy.

SEC. 10. Training of Personnel and Public Information Dissemination. - Within thirty (30) days after the effectivity of this Ordinance, all heads of departments, bureaus and offices, including their immediate assistants, shall be provided with hands-on training incorporating the pertinent provisions of this Ordinance and corresponding to their respective duties and functions. In conjunction hereto, the Office of the Mayor shall disseminate appropriate information to the public through print, radio, television and online media.

SEC. 11. Implementing Rules and Guidelines. - Within thirty (30) days after the effectivity of this Ordinance, the Office of the Mayor, supported by the heads of departments, bureaus and offices with the cooperation of the Electronic Data Processing (EDP) Section and the Office of the City Legal Officer, shall promulgate rules and guidelines implementing the provisions of this Ordinance.

SEC. 12. Penalties. The violation of this Ordinance shall be penalized, as follows:

a. The deliberate omission to comply with the provisions of Section 4 of this Ordinance, which shall be punished by a fine of Two Thousand Pesos (PhP. 2,000.00);
b. The deliberate omission to digitize any particular document or set of documents, which shall be punished by a fine of Two Thousand Pesos (PhP. 2,000.00);
c. The theft, deletion, substitution or alteration of any digitized transactional document, which shall be punished by a fine of Two Thousand Pesos (PhP. 2,000.00) or an imprisonment of one (1) year, or such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court;
d. The unauthorized transmission or sharing of digitized transactional documents, which shall be punished by a fine of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) or an imprisonment of one (1) year, or such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court.

SEC. 13. Appropriation. - The amount necessary to carry out the provisions of this Ordinance shall be charged against funding sources as determined by the City Budget Officer. Appropriations for the succeeding years shall be incorporated in the Annual Executive Budget.

SEC. 14. Separability Clause. The provisions of this Ordinance are hereby declared separable, and in any event that any provision is declared unconstitutional, the other provisions, which are not affected, shall remain in force and effect.

SEC. 15. Repealing Clause. All ordinances or parts thereof which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 16. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 14, 2021.
short_text:
Ordinance No. 8755 establishes a citywide system for the automation of transactions and digitization of documents in all departments, offices, bureaus, and agencies under the City Government of Manila. The goal is to improve efficiency, reduce reliance on paper, and promote contactless interactions, especially in light of the ongoing challenges brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic. By adopting digital processes, the City aims to protect public health, enhance productivity, and modernize how it delivers services to both internal offices and the public.

This ordinance requires all city government entities—including those created in the future and those funded by the Annual Local Executive Budget—to transition to digital systems, unless they already use standard and acceptable automated systems, in which case integration into a unified digital infrastructure will still be encouraged. It also mandates that documents subject to legal deadlines or urgent needs be prioritized for digitization.
fines:
PhP 2,000 fine for omission to comply with the provisions of Section 4 of this Ordinance

PhP 2,000 fine for omission to of requirements or failure to digitize any particular document or set of documents

PhP 2,000 fine and/or 1 year imprisonment at the discretion of the court for tampering with digital records

PhP 3,000 fine and/or 1 year imprisonment at the discretion of the court for unauthorized sharing of digital documents

short_text:
This ordinance mandates the streamlining of procedures for issuing business and non-business permits, licenses, and clearances in the City of Manila, in compliance with the Ease of Doing Business and Efficient Government Service Delivery Act of 2018 (RA 11032). It applies to various city departments and covers documents such as business permits, building permits, occupancy certificates, medical certificates, and more. Key reforms include limiting the number of required signatures to three, simplifying documentary requirements, integrating the Community Tax Certificate (cedula) with the business permit, and reducing processing time and costs through digitalization.

Barangay clearances related to business are now processed at the city level, with corresponding fees remitted to barangays. Some permits like locational clearances are no longer required for businesses in malls or central business districts during initial registration or renewal, provided zoning compliance is met. Sanitary permits are only needed for businesses explicitly covered by the Sanitation Code of the Philippines. Permits are valid for 1 year and must be renewed within the first 20 days of January.
fines:
Validity Period of Business Permits. —  The Mayor's/Business Permit shall be granted for a period of not more than one (1) year and shall expire on the thirty-first (31st) of December following the date of issuance unless revoked or surrendered earlier. Sanction. —  (A) Any violations by the Chief of Office/Head of the Department or Office, or their employee(s) of the provisions of this Ordinance shall subject them to administrative sanctions in accordance with the relevant administrative and civil service rules and regulations, where applicable. 
(B) Failure by the heads of offices/departments to comply with the provisions of this Ordinance shall render them liable to being charged in accordance with existing laws or rules before the appropriate forum.

ORDINANCE NO. 8753

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 07, SERIES OF FY 2021 FOR THE MAJOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF TEN BILLION PESOS (PHP. 10,000,000,000.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, every local government unit shall exercise the powers that are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. It shall ensure and support, among other things, the enhancement of economic prosperity and social justice, and preserve the comfort and convenience of its inhabitants [Section 16 of Republic Act (R.A.) No. 7160 or the Local Government Code of 1991];
WHEREAS, local government units shall likewise exercise such powers and discharge such functions and responsibilities for the efficient and effective provision of basic services and facilities, which include, among others, school buildings and low-cost housing and other mass dwellings (Section 17 of R.A. No. 7160);
WHEREAS, a supplemental budget may be enacted when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources (Section 321 of Republic Act No. 7160);
WHEREAS, the City Council approved Resolution No. 08, Series of 2021, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2021 FOR THE MAJOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF TEN BILLION PESOS (PHP. 10,000,000,000.00)”; NOW, THEREFORE,

Appropriations. — The FY 2021 Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila in the total amount of Ten Billion Pesos (PhP. 10,000,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated for the Major Development Projects of the City of Manila under the Department of Engineering and Public Works, as follows:

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 10, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance approves Supplemental Budget No. 07 for Fiscal Year 2021, allocating ₱10 billion for major infrastructure projects in Manila. Albert Elementary, Rosauro Almario Elementary, and Manila Science High School—as well as mass housing projects—San Sebastian, Pedro Gil, and San Lazaro Residences. ORDINANCE NO. 8751

AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE GUIDELINES SET FORTH BY THE COMMISSION ON HIGHER EDUCATION (CHED) FOR THE UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA (UDM) TO BE CONFERRED THE STATUS OF HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTION (HEI), CHANGING THE TITLE POSITIONS OF ITS TOP EXECUTIVES, CREATING THIRTEEN (13) ADDITIONAL PLANTILLA POSITIONS FOR GUIDANCE OFFICERS, NURSES AND LIBRARIANS, PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, in its quest to be conferred a “Higher Education Institution” recognition by the Commission on Higher Education (CHED), UdM was informed by CHED that it should have a plantilla of positions that is compliant with the Manual of Regulations for Private Higher Education (MORPHE) of 2008, pursuant to CHED Memorandum Order (CMO) No. 30, Series of 2009, which applied said MORPHE to State Universities and Colleges (SUCs) and Local Universities and Colleges (LUCs);
WHEREAS, a plantilla of positions compliant with the above-mentioned MORPHE is one of the requirements before UdM could be granted recognition by CHED as an HEI;
WHEREAS, the MORPHE mandates that an HEI should have a President/Administrator, Registrar, proper number of Librarians, Nurses, Instructors and Guidance Counsellors, depending on student population, among others;
WHEREAS, UdM shall likewise have a plantilla of positions with position titles and plantilla titles that are befitting a University, considering that the existing plantilla positions of UdM are those for the defunct “City College of Manila”;
WHEREAS, the creation of the CHED-required plantilla positions of UdM shall greatly impact the provision of accessible and free quality education for the youth of the City of Manila as it will move UdM closer towards HEI recognition by CHED, which will make UdM eligible for numerous subsidies/funding/grants/scholarships from the National Government: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Change of Title Positions. — The following existing Position Titles under UdM shall be changed:
a. “City Government Department Head III (President)” shall be changed into “LUC President I”;
b. “City Government Assistant Department Head III (Executive Vice-President)” shall be changed into “LUC Vice-President I”; and
c. “City Government Assistant Department Head III (VP for Academic Affairs)” shall be changed into “LUC Vice-President I”.

SEC. 2. New Plantilla Positions. — The following new plantilla positions are hereby created exclusively for and under the Universidad de Manila (UdM):
Title of Position        No. of Staff        Grade/Step        Rate/Annum        Total Amount
Guidance Services Associate II        2        14-1        PhP 351,324        PhP 702,648
Guidance Coordinator II        3        15-1        PhP 384,636        PhP 1,153,908
Guidance Services Specialist I        1        16-1        PhP 421,272        PhP 421,272
Guidance Services Specialist II        1        18-1        PhP 505,908        PhP 505,908
Nurse I        2        15-1        PhP 384,636        PhP 769,272
Nurse II        1        16-1        PhP 421,272        PhP 421,272
College Librarian I        1        13-1        PhP 321,048        PhP 321,048
College Librarian II        1        15-1        PhP 384,636        PhP 384,636
College Librarian III        1        18-1        PhP 505,908        PhP 505,908
TOTAL: 13 positions — PhP 5,185,872
The employment status of the plantilla positions created under this Section shall be PERMANENT.

SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, the Civil Service Commission (CSC), and the Commission on Higher Education’s (CHED) rules, regulations, and issuances governing a Higher Education Institution (HEI).

SEC. 4. Appointment. — The employment and appointment of the individuals for the herein subject positions shall be within the qualification standards and guidelines set by CSC, CHED, and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause. — All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 31, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance supports the recognition of Universidad de Manila (UdM) as a Higher Education Institution (HEI) by CHED by updating the job titles of its top officials and creating 13 new permanent plantilla positions, including guidance officers, nurses, and librarians. These changes are in line with CHED regulations and aim to qualify UdM for national government funding and grants for higher education institutions.

Ordinance No. 8750 amends the provisions of Ordinance No. 7885, which authorized the City Government of Manila to operate the City College of Manila (now known as Universidad de Manila or UDM). The amendment aligns the university with the requirements set by the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) for recognition as a Higher Education Institution (HEI). This recognition would allow UDM to receive subsidies and funding from the national government, enabling it to offer accessible, free, and quality education to the youth of Manila.

The ordinance also includes various changes, such as establishing a policy to promote quality education for all citizens and particularly for talented and gifted students from public schools. It outlines the procedures for filling vacancies in the Board of Regents, the governing body of UDM, and establishes a policy to avoid conflicts of interest among board members. Additionally, the ordinance grants the Board of Regents general powers as outlined in the Revised Corporation Code of the Philippines, which enables the Board to manage and oversee the operations of the university.

ORDINANCE NO. 8745

AN ORDINANCE WAIVING THE MARKET RENTAL FEES FOR STALLHOLDERS ENGAGED IN THE BUSINESS OF SELLING PORK AND/OR CHICKEN MEAT IN THE PUBLIC MARKETS OF THE CITY OF MANILA FOR THE DURATION OF THE MANDATED PRICE CEILING UNDER PRESIDENT RODRIGO DUTERTE'S EXECUTIVE ORDER NO. 124, SERIES OF 2021

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, in order to manage the high rate of increase or inflation of the prices of basic necessities and prime commodities, particularly pork and chicken, the President issued Executive Order No. 124, Series of 2021. The EO 124 imposed a price ceiling on pork and chicken in the NCR with a duration of 60 days from effectivity;
WHEREAS, Republic Act No. 7581, or the Price Act, penalizes the selling of covered goods above the mandated price ceiling;
WHEREAS, compliance with the mandatory price ceiling is difficult for the majority of the meat vendors;
WHEREAS, meat vendors in Manila's public markets collectively appeal for rent relief to help them mitigate the impact of the mandated price ceiling;
WHEREAS, the City Council of Manila, in its effort to help mitigate the impact of the mandatory price ceiling and heeding the call of our meat vendors in Manila’s public markets during the imposition of the mandated price ceiling under Executive Order No. 124, Series of 2021, or from 08 February 2021 to 09 April 2021: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as the “RENTAL FEE WAIVER ORDINANCE FOR MEAT VENDORS IN MANILA’S PUBLIC MARKET FOR THE DURATION OF THE MANDATED PRICE CEILING.”

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. — For purposes of this Ordinance, the following definitions shall apply:
a. Public Market — refers to any structure, building, or place of any kind dedicated to the service of the general public, where wet and dry products may be bought and sold, which is owned, operated, or managed by the City Government of Manila.
b. Meat Vendors — refer to stallholders engaged in the business of selling pork and/or chicken meat, who have been granted the privilege to use the stall, and pay the rental thereon, for the purpose of selling pork and/or chicken meat.

SEC. 3. Waiver of Rental Fees. — The rental fees of stallholders engaged in the business of selling pork and/or chicken in the public markets of the City of Manila, whether collected by the city or those under joint venture agreement during the imposition of the mandated price ceiling under President Rodrigo R. Duterte’s Executive Order No. 124, Series of 2021, or from 08 February to 09 April 2021, are hereby waived. Rental fees already paid or collected during such period shall be considered as advanced payment and shall be used as rental credit for the succeeding period.

SEC. 4. Non-Eviction. — No meat vendor shall be evicted for failure to pay any of his rental fee during the period of the mandatory price ceiling under the preceding section.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. — Any provision of this Ordinance that may be declared unconstitutional or illegal shall not have the effect of nullifying other portions or provisions hereof, as long as such remaining portions or provisions can still subsist and be given effect in their entirety.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances or resolutions, or parts thereof, which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 29, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance waives the rental fees for stallholders in Manila public markets who sell pork and/or chicken during the mandated price ceiling period under Executive Order No. 124 (from February 8 to April 9, 2021). Any rental fees already paid for that period will be treated as advance payment for future rentals. It also ensures that meat vendors cannot be evicted for failing to pay rent during this specific time.

ORDINANCE NO. 8744

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING TWO HUNDRED EIGHTY MILLION PESOS (PHP 280,000,000.00) AS SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 6 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2021 TO COVER EXPENSES FOR COVID-19 VACCINES IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on 8 March 2020, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte issued Presidential Proclamation No. 922, s. 2020, declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). As of 2 January 2021, the Department of Health has already recorded 476,916 COVID-positive cases with almost 10,000 deaths; 26,842 of those positive cases were recorded in the City of Manila;
WHEREAS, in December 2020, several pharmaceutical companies successfully produced vaccines against COVID-19 which were then rolled out and used by various countries;
WHEREAS, in January 2021, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8719, entitled:
“AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING TWO HUNDRED MILLION PESOS (PHP 200,000,000.00) AS SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 1 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2021 TO COVER EXPENSES FOR COVID-19 VACCINES IN THE CITY OF MANILA”;
WHEREAS, in March 2021, the City Government of Manila together with the Department of Health began its vaccination program. As of 22 April 2021, a total of 114,124 vaccines have already been deployed in the City of Manila;
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991 states that:
“Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”
(Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160)
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code provides that:
“All budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources.
A supplemental budget may also be enacted in times of public calamity by way of budgetary realignment to set aside appropriations for the purchase of supplies and materials or the payment of services which are exceptionally urgent or absolutely indispensable to prevent imminent danger to, or loss of, life or property, in the jurisdiction of the local government unit or in other areas declared by the President in a state of calamity. Such ordinance shall clearly indicate the sources of funds available for appropriations, as certified under oath by the local treasurer and local accountant and attested by the local chief executive, and the various items of appropriations affected and the reasons for the change.”
(Section 321 of Republic Act No. 7160) NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2021 in the amount of Two Hundred Eighty Million Pesos (PhP 280,000,000.00) is hereby approved to cover the expenses for COVID-19 vaccines.

SEC. 2. Source of the Fund. — The funds for the Supplemental Budget shall be sourced from funds actually available in the total amount of Two Hundred Eighty Million Pesos (PhP 280,000,000.00).

SEC. 3. Use of Funds. — The amount of Two Hundred Eighty Million Pesos (PhP 280,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated under the Manila Health Department (Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses - Drugs and Medicines Expenses) for the procurement of vaccines against COVID-19.
Annex A — Statement of Funding Source
Annex B — Statement of Supplemental Appropriations

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 29, 2021.
short_text: TThis ordinance allocates PHP 280 million as Supplemental Budget No. 6 for 2021 to purchase additional COVID-19 vaccines for Manila residents.  The entire amount will be managed by the Manila Health Department and allocated under maintenance and operating expenses specifically for drug and medicine purchases. The funds were certified as available and sourced from the city's actual available resources.

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 322 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code, categorically provides:
“Section 322. Reversion of the Unexpended Balances of Appropriations, Continuing Appropriations. — Unexpended balances of appropriations authorized in the annual appropriations ordinance shall revert to the unappropriated surplus of the general fund at the end of the fiscal year and shall not thereafter be available for expenditure except by subsequent enactment. However, appropriations for capital outlays shall continue and remain valid until fully spent, reverted, or the project is completed. Reversions of continuing appropriations shall not be allowed unless obligations therefor have been fully paid or otherwise settled.
The balances of continuing appropriations shall be reviewed as part of the annual budget preparation and the sanggunian concerned may approve, upon recommendation of the local chief executive, the reversion of funds no longer needed in connection with the activities funded by said continuing appropriations.”

WHEREAS, as the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in the Philippines has totaled more than 1 million cases, with more than 8,000 new cases/day and 70 deaths/day last April 26, 2021;

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

E-Permits (Management Information System for Processing of Permits and License Application) - PhP. 80,000,000.00

Continuing Appropriation - Ord. 8515 FY 2017        
1. Non-Office (Major Projects of the City)        
E-Vehicles - PhP. 200,000,000.00

TOTAL: PhP. 280,000,000.00

Attached as Annex A — Statement of Availability of Funds/Cash.

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 29, 2021.
short_text: The City of Manila approved the reversion of ₱280 million worth of unused capital outlay funds from the 2016 and 2017 budgets back to the General Fund. This was done to help finance the city's COVID-19 vaccination efforts. The funds originally allocated for projects like the E-Permits system and E-Vehicles were deemed no longer necessary, enabling the city to reallocate them for pandemic response.
