“Presidential Proclamation No. 922, s. 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sublevel Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases. Further, Presidential Proclamation No. 929, s. 2020, was issued declaring a State of Calamity throughout the Philippines and imposed an Enhanced Community Quarantine throughout Luzon.
In view of the continuing rise of confirmed cases of COVID-19, the serious threat to the health, safety, security, and lives of our countrymen, the long-term adverse effects on their means of livelihood, and the severe disruption of economic activities, a state of national emergency is hereby declared over the entire country.”;
WHEREAS, both Proclamations enjoined all government agencies and Local Government Units (LGUs) to render full assistance to and cooperation with each other and mobilize the necessary resources to undertake critical, urgent, and appropriate disaster response aid and measures in a timely manner to curtail and eliminate the threat of COVID-19;
WHEREAS, in the same law, the President is empowered to:
“ensure that all Local Government Units (LGUs) are acting within the letter and spirit of all the rules, regulations and directives issued by the National Government pursuant to the said law, and are implementing standards of Community Quarantine consistent with what the National Government has laid down for the subject area, while allowing the LGUs to continue exercising their autonomy on matters undefined by the National Government or are within the parameters it has set, and are fully cooperating towards a unified, cohesive and orderly implementation of the national policy to address COVID-19.” (Section 4 (g) of RA No. 11469);
WHEREAS, Proclamation No. 1021 dated September 16, 2020, extended the period of the State of Calamity throughout the Philippines until September 12, 2021, due to COVID-19 declared under Proclamation No. 929, s. 2020;
WHEREAS, the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) and the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) had issued Joint Memorandum Circular (JMC) No. 01, dated March 27, 2020, providing additional guidelines on the utilization of the Twenty Percent (20%) of the Annual Internal Revenue Allotment for Development Projects in view of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) situation, which authorized the use of the said fund for “food assistance and other relief goods for affected households” (Par. 2.1.7), as well as “other necessary COVID-19 related PPAs and expenses” (Par. 2.1.12). Further, DBM, DILG and the Department of Finance issued JMC No. 1 dated November 4, 2020, revising the guidelines on the appropriation and utilization of the 20% of the Annual Internal Revenue Allotment for Development Projects, which clarified that:
“the development projects that may be included under the 20% DF (Development Fund) shall be those that are necessary, appropriate, or incidental to efficient and effective local governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare of the people.”
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code states that:
“All budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources.
A supplemental budget may also be enacted in times of public calamity by way of budgetary realignment to set aside appropriations for the purchase of supplies and materials or the payment of services which are exceptionally urgent or absolutely indispensable to prevent imminent danger to, or loss of, life or property, in the jurisdiction of the local government unit or in other areas declared by the President in a state of calamity. Such ordinances shall clearly indicate the sources of funds available for appropriations, as certified under oath by the local treasurer and local accountant and attested by the local chief executive, and the various items of appropriations affected and the reasons for the change.” (Section 321 of Republic Act No. 7160);
WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 05, Series of 2021, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on March 22, 2021, entitled:
“A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2021 TO AUGMENT THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES (MOOE) — WELFARE GOODS EXPENSES OF THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE IN THE AMOUNT OF ONE BILLION FOUR HUNDRED TWENTY-SEVEN MILLION PESOS (PHP 1,427,000,000.00) FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CITY OF MANILA’S FOOD SECURITY PROGRAM.” NOW, THEREFORE, 

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2021 in the amount of One Billion Four Hundred Twenty-Seven Million Pesos (PhP 1,427,000,000.00) is hereby approved.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. — The funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of One Billion Four Hundred Twenty-Seven Million Pesos (PhP 1,427,000,000.00) shall be derived from funds actually available as certified by the City Treasurer and City Accountant.

SEC. 3. Use of Funds. — The amount of One Billion Four Hundred Twenty-Seven Million Pesos (PhP 1,427,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated under the Manila Department of Social Welfare: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses — Welfare Goods Expenses for the City’s Food Security Program.
Attached are the following details:
Annex A — Statement of Funding Source
Annex B — Statement of Supplemental Appropriations

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 25, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes a supplemental budget of ₱1,427,000,000 for the City of Manila in 2021. The funds will be used to support the Food Security Program managed by the Manila Department of Social Welfare. These funds are sourced from available revenues, and the ordinance ensures the allocation of these resources for providing welfare goods as part of the city’s response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

ORDINANCE NO. 8737

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING ORDINANCES NOS. 8616, 8647, 8658, 8665, AND 8692 BY IMPOSING THE CURFEW IN THE CITY OF MANILA ACCORDING TO THE QUARANTINE CLASSIFICATIONS.

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on March 8, 2020, the President issued Presidential Proclamation No. 922, declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to COVID-19. This declaration enjoins all government agencies and Local Government Units (LGUs) to undertake critical and appropriate responses to curtail the spread of COVID-19;
WHEREAS, on March 14, 2020, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8616, imposing a curfew from 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM during the imposition of community quarantine, pursuant to the resolution of the Metro Manila Council in response to the community quarantine declared by His Excellency, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte;
WHEREAS, on June 15, 2020, President Duterte approved the Inter-Agency Task Force (IATF) Resolution No. 46-A which placed the City of Manila under General Community Quarantine (GCQ);
WHEREAS, with reference to the declaration of the IATF, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8647, amending Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8616, by imposing curfew from 10:00 PM to 5:00 AM;
WHEREAS, on September 16, 2020, the President issued Proclamation No. 1021 (S. 2020) extending the period of the State of Calamity throughout the Philippines due to COVID-19, declared under Proclamation No. 929;
WHEREAS, on October 15, 2020, the President approved IATF Resolution No. 79, recommending, among others, the relaxation of curfew hours imposed by LGUs, based on the COVID-19 situation in their respective jurisdictions;
WHEREAS, despite the gradual relaxation of curfew hours, quarantine and social distancing protocols within the City of Manila will remain enforced in accordance with IATF guidelines;
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991 (Republic Act No. 7160) provides that LGUs shall exercise powers necessary for their efficient and effective governance, which includes ensuring public health, safety, and the welfare of their constituents; NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1.  Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8616, as amended by Ordinance No. 8647, is hereby further amended to read as follows:
Section 1. Imposition of Curfew Hours; Covered Persons. — Unless otherwise provided by the IATF or the City Mayor, the following curfew hours shall be imposed for all persons in the City of Manila, depending on the quarantine classification of the National Capital Region (NCR):
•        Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ): between 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM
•        Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ): between 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM
•        General Community Quarantine (GCQ):
a. For persons 18 years old and above, curfew shall be from 10:00 PM to 5:00 AM.
b. For persons below 18 years old, curfew shall be from 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM.
Provided further that any person below 15 years old, 65 years old and above, persons with immunodeficiency, comorbidity, or other health risks, and pregnant women, as well as those who reside with them, shall remain at their residences at all times, except when obtaining essential goods or services or for work in permitted industries or offices (as amended by Paragraph A of IATF Resolution No. 79, October 15, 2020).

SECTION 2. Power of the Mayor to Amend Curfew Hours. — The City Mayor may, through Executive Order, amend the curfew hours specified above when the COVID-19 situation in the City of Manila warrants.

SECTION 3. Exceptions. —  During curfew hours, no person shall be allowed outside their residence, except for the following:
a. Authorized Persons Outside of Residence (APOR): Persons allowed by the IATF to be outside their residence.
b. Medical and Humanitarian Emergencies.
c. Fast Food Restaurants and Food Chains that are allowed to operate beyond curfew hours or 24/7.
d. Employees and Delivery Personnel for restaurants or food chains allowed to operate beyond curfew hours or 24/7.
e. Work-Related Travels.
f. Travel to the Airport for international travel.

SECTION 4. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 12, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance updates previous curfew rules in Manila based on the current quarantine classification (e.g., ECQ, MECQ, GCQ). Under ECQ and MECQ, curfew runs from 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM. Under GCQ, adults must follow a 10:00 PM to 5:00 AM curfew, while minors must follow an earlier 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM curfew. Certain people, such as seniors, pregnant women, and those with health risks, must stay home unless doing essential tasks. The Mayor is allowed to adjust curfew hours as needed based on COVID-19 developments. Exceptions apply to emergencies, authorized workers, and essential services like food delivery.

ORDINANCE NO. 8735

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING RACIAL, ETHNIC AND RELIGIOUS DISCRIMINATION

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as the “Equality and Non-Discrimination on Race, Ethnicity, and Religion Act.”

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. — As enshrined in the Constitution, it is the policy of the City to:
a. Maintain peace and order, protect life, liberty, and property, and promote the general welfare for the enjoyment of the blessings of democracy by all people;
b. Promote a just and dynamic social order that ensures the prosperity and independence of the nation, and free the people from poverty through policies that provide adequate social services, promote employment, a rising standard of living, and an improved quality of life;
c. Recognize and promote the rights of indigenous cultural communities within the framework of national unity and development;
d. Give the highest priority to the enactment of measures that shall protect and enhance the right of all people to human dignity; reduce social, economic, and political inequalities; and remove cultural inequities by equitably diffusing wealth and political power for the common good;
e. Ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.

SEC. 3. Definition of Terms. — As used in this Ordinance:
a. Discrimination — refers to any distinction, exclusion, restriction, or preference made on the basis of race, color, descent, national or ethnic origin, religion, or religious affiliation or beliefs, which has the effect or purpose of impairing or nullifying the recognition, enjoyment, or exercise on an equal footing of the human rights and fundamental freedoms in any field of public life.
b. Education and Training — refers to all types and levels of education and training, including access, standard and quality, and the conditions under which these are given.
c. Employment — refers to the condition where an employer-employee relationship exists, as determined by existing laws and jurisprudence, including terms, conditions, and privileges related to work in public and private institutions.
d. Ethnic Origin — refers to the classification of people based on common color, racial, national, tribal, religious, ethno-linguistic, or cultural origin.
e. Ethno-linguistic Group — refers to a group of people that shares a distinct language, cultural inheritance, and history that give them a unique identity, with racial, ethnic, and religious bases.
f. Goods and Services — refers to material and non-material products or services offered for sale, such as those provided by restaurants, resorts, hotels, stores, and various public service establishments.
g. Housing and Other Accommodations — refers to various forms of residential or accommodation arrangements, such as houses, apartments, motels, boarding houses, shelters, health facilities, and similar establishments.
h. Indigenous Cultural Communities and Indigenous Peoples — refers to groups of people who self-identify as indigenous, living as an organized community in specific territories, with distinct cultural traits and resistance to political, social, and cultural pressures.
i. Religious Affiliation or Belief — refers to the profession or non-profession of religion or beliefs, which may be publicly manifested in worship, practice, and teaching.
j. Stereotype — refers to oversimplified, often negative opinions or attitudes about specific ethnicities, religions, or cultures that do not accurately reflect reality.
k. Vehicle — refers to public conveyances, such as trains, ships, buses, taxis, cars, and aircraft.

SEC. 4. Acts of Discrimination. — It is unlawful for any person, natural or juridical, to perform any act involving a distinction, exclusion, restriction, or preference based on race, color, descent, national or ethnic origin, religion, or religious affiliation or beliefs, which has the effect of nullifying or impairing the recognition, enjoyment, or exercise on an equal footing of any human right or fundamental freedom in the political, economic, social, cultural, civil or any other field of public life.
An act is deemed discriminatory when a person requires another to comply with a term condition or requirement which are not reasonable having regard to the circumstances of the case; or the other person does not or cannot has the purpose or effect of nullifying or impairing the recognition, enjoyment, or exercise on an equal footing by persons of the same race, color, descent, or national or ethnic origin, religion or religious affiliation beliefs

SEC. 5. Prohibited Acts. — The following acts of discrimination are prohibited when committed on the basis of race, color, descent, national or ethnic origin, religion, or religious affiliation or beliefs:

a. Discrimination in Political Participation — This includes acts that prevent, impede, or obstruct another person’s right to vote, be voted upon, or participate in a plebiscite, as well as imposing unreasonable terms or discriminating against those exercising political rights.

b. Discrimination in Employment — Employers or agents are prohibited from discriminating against individuals based on race or religion in hiring, promotion, training, compensation, benefits, and termination.

c. Discrimination in Education and Training — Educational or training institutions must not refuse to admit students or expel them based on their race, religion, or beliefs, nor should they deny students access to benefits or privileges provided to others.

d. Discrimination in the Delivery of Goods and Services — Suppliers of goods and services must not refuse, fail, or discriminate in the provision of goods or services based on race, ethnicity, religion, or beliefs.

e. Discrimination in the Acquisition, Possession, Utilization, Lease, or Disposal of Lands, including Housing and Other Accommodations — Discrimination in acquiring or leasing land or housing is prohibited, including rejecting applications or imposing less favorable conditions based on race, ethnicity, or religion.

f. Discrimination in Access to Public Places, Facilities, and Public Meetings. — A person acting as principal or agent shall be liable for any of the following discriminatory acts:
1.        Refusing to allow another person access to or use of any place, vehicle, or facilities that the general public, or a section thereof, is entitled or allowed to enter or use;
2.        Refusing to allow another person access to or use of any such place, vehicle, or facilities by providing onerous terms or conditions not similar to others who are allowed access to or use of the place, vehicle, or facilities;
3.        Refusing to allow another person access to a meeting or assembly open to the general public, or to a section thereof, or refusing to allow another person access to a meeting or assembly by providing onerous terms or conditions not similar to others to which they would otherwise allow access;
4.        Requiring another person to leave or to stop the use of any public place, vehicle, or any such facilities;
5.        Subjecting a person to a denial of access to public places, facilities, or public meetings; or
6.        Failing to make reasonable efforts to make facilities accessible to people whose disabilities reduce their range of mobility.

g. Discrimination by Wrongful Portrayal. — A person acting as principal or agent shall be held liable for portraying, imitating, depicting, or describing in learning institutions, instructional materials, teaching devices, books, and reference materials—especially in Civics and History—certain individuals and/or groups as inferior religiously, racially, or ethnically.

h. Discrimination through Speech, Utterances, Acts of Hatred, and Similar Acts. — Any person shall be held liable for delivering speeches, making utterances, performing acts of hatred or violence against another person, or mocking or ridiculing another person on account of one's ethnicity, race, or religious affiliation or belief.

i. Discrimination through Analogous Acts that Result in Impairment of the Enjoyment of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. — A person acting as principal or agent shall be liable for analogous acts that impair the exercise of a person’s human rights and fundamental freedoms in the political, economic, social, cultural, or civil spheres, or any other field of public life. These rights and freedoms are guaranteed and consistent with relevant international human rights instruments to which the Philippines is a State Party. Such analogous acts must be committed on the basis of race, color, descent, national or ethnic origin, religion, or religious affiliation or beliefs.

j. Discrimination by Engaging in Profiling. — A person acting as principal or agent, including any member of the military or law enforcement agencies, shall be held liable for subjecting a person or a group of persons to investigatory activities, such as unnecessary, unjustified, illegal, and degrading searches and similar acts, which are unlawful, immoral, or socially unacceptable.

k. Discrimination through Abuses of State and Non-State Actors. — A government official or employee of any government agency or corporation, local government unit, police, military, or any law enforcement agency, including non-state actors, shall be liable if that official or employee commits acts of harassment, either verbal or physical, to curtail the freedom of movement of any person or to extort a favor from the latter, whether financial or not. This includes legitimate orders issued by persons in authority or courts of justice.

SEC. 6. Persons Liable. — Any person who performs any of the discriminatory acts enumerated in the preceding section shall be liable under this Ordinance. If the discriminatory acts are committed by a judicial person, the President, Manager, Director, and/or responsible officers shall be held liable.
Any person who requests, instructs, induces, encourages, authorizes, or assists another to commit acts of discrimination shall be the ones liable under this Ordinance. Any person who is duty-bound to act on complaints of discrimination under this Ordinance but fails or refuses to do so shall be deemed to have sanctioned the discriminatory act and shall consequently be held equally liable for discrimination.

SEC. 7. Creation of a Non-Discrimination and Equal Opportunity Committee. —  In order to  ensure compliance with this Ordinance, all agencies, corporations, companies, organizations, and educational and/or training institutions, whether public or private, as well as any person providing employment, housing, education, or the delivery of basic goods and services, shall create a Non-Discrimination and Equal Opportunity Committee (hereinafter referred to as the Non-Discrimination Committee).
The Non-Discrimination Committee shall:
1.        Exercise administrative jurisdiction to investigate acts and practices of discrimination under this Ordinance.
2.        Conduct the initial investigation of cases involving discrimination based on race, ethnic background, religion, religious affiliation, or beliefs.
3.        Refer the result and findings of such investigations to the appropriate government agencies for resolution, settlement, or prosecution.
Any administrative sanction imposed on the perpetrator of discrimination shall not preclude prosecution in the proper courts for acts of discrimination, nor shall it preclude any civil claims for damages suffered by the victim.
Failure by any juridical entity, whether public or private, to effectively implement this provision shall be deemed as refusal to address discrimination and will be considered an act of discrimination, subject to the penalty provided in Section 10.

SEC. 8. Responsibility to Promote a Non-Discrimination and Equal Opportunity Environment. —  It shall be the duty of every person, whether natural or juridical, public or private, to ensure non-discrimination and equal opportunity to all individuals in relation to actual or prospective employees, students, tenants, customers, or clients. They must ensure that no discriminatory acts, as defined herein, are committed by them or their agents.
All City government officers and workers are also required to promote and observe equality and non-discrimination in the discharge of their duties and responsibilities.

SEC. 9. Penalty Clause. — Any person found liable for violating any provision of this Ordinance shall be penalized with a fine not exceeding Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 5,000.00) or imprisonment for a period not exceeding one (1) year, or both, at the discretion of the court.

SEC. 10. Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR). —  Upon the effectivity of this Ordinance, a Drafting Committee composed of representatives from the Manila Department of Social Welfare, City Legal Office, City Planning and Development Office, Division of City Schools, and the Manila Barangay Bureau shall be convened to formulate the Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR) for this Ordinance.

SEC. 11. Repealing Clause. —  All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules, regulations, and other issuances, or parts thereof, found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SEC. 12. Separability Clause. — If any portion of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining portions not affected thereby shall continue to have force and effect.

SEC. 13. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in a newspaper of general circulation.
short_text: This ordinance prohibits any form of discrimination in the City of Manila based on race, ethnicity, or religion. It covers areas such as employment, education, public services, housing, political participation, and access to public spaces. Individuals, businesses, and even government officials can be penalized if they commit or fail to prevent discriminatory acts. The ordinance also requires institutions to form Non-Discrimination Committees to investigate and respond to such violations.
fines: Up to ₱5,000 fine, up to 1 year imprisonment, or both

ORDINANCE NO. 8734

AN ORDINANCE CONVERTING THROUGH ABOLITION OF THE FOUR (4) ADMINISTRATIVE AIDE POSITIONS IN THE CITY LEGAL OFFICE OF MANILA BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM AND THEREBY CREATING ONE (1) NEW POSITION OF ATTORNEY III

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this draft Ordinance can be found in Sec. 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: “In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules and regulations”;
WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC, on May 12, 2006, came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following: (a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Re-titling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;
WHEREAS, the proponent, the City Legal Office, has certified that the collapsed items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary, while the position being created will help augment its legal/technical plantilla of items in furtherance of its mandate to defend the legal interests of the City and provide services to its officials and constituents;
WHEREAS, the generated savings from the scrapped positions will help cover the computed amount needed to fund the position of Attorney III and that the total amount for Personal Services, including the created position, will not exceed the 45% statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability. The City and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling-down, phasing-out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions. — The following positions are hereby abolished under the City Legal Office of Manila:
TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide VI
Number: 3
Salary Grade: 6-1
ITEM NO.: 44, 46, and 47
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 (PER ANNUM): PhP 178,164.00

TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide IV
Number: 1
Salary Grade: 
ITEM NO.: 51
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 (PER ANNUM): PhP 158,568.00


Total Number: 4
Total Authorized Rate FY 2020: PhP 693,660.00



SEC. 3. New Plantilla Position. — The following new Plantilla Item is hereby created under the City Legal Office of Manila:
TITLE OF POSITION: Attorney III
Number: 1
Salary Grade: 21-4
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 (PER ANNUM): PhP 693,660.00

Total Number: 1
Total Authorized Rate FY 2020: PhP 693,660.00

SEC. 4. Classification on Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The classification and powers/duties/responsibilities of the herein enumerated position shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. Appointment. — The employment and appointment of the individual for the subject position shall be within the qualification standard and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 6. Appropriation. — The amount necessary for the creation of one (1) Attorney III position shall be sourced from available funds of the existing four (4) positions to be abolished for this purpose as provided for under the 2020 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject position shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the plantilla of personnel of the City Legal Office.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 8, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance removes four vacant administrative aide positions from the City Legal Office of Manila and replaces them with one new position of Attorney III. This change follows the government's “scrap-and-build” policy, aiming to improve efficiency by using resources for more essential roles. The new attorney position is intended to strengthen the legal support provided by the City Legal Office while staying within the allowed budget limits. The funding comes from the savings generated by removing the obsolete positions.

This ordinance confirms and officially approves the sale of certain city-owned properties at 599 P. Ocampo Street, Malate, Manila, to Vancouver Lands, Inc. The sale was conducted through a public bidding process, with Vancouver Lands, Inc. submitting the highest and most favorable bid of ₱1,382,472,000.00. The sale was finalized on an “as-is-where-is” basis, and the ordinance ratifies the signed Deed of Absolute Sale between both parties.

This ordinance exempts all COVID-19 vaccines procured by the Manila City Government from paying any local taxes, fees, or charges imposed by the City. The exemption was in effect for one year, from February 22, 2021, to February 22, 2022, to support the City’s vaccination efforts during the public health emergency.

ORDINANCE NO. 8728

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING THIRTY MILLION PESOS (PHP 30,000,000.00) AS SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 3 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2021 FOR THE GRANT OF INCENTIVES TO ALL BARANGAYS WHICH HAVE REMAINED COVID-19 FREE FROM DECEMBER 1, 2020 TO JANUARY 31, 2021

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on February 3, 2021, the City Budget Officer Grace Chua forwarded to the City Council of Manila the list from the City Health Officer, Dr. Arnold M. Pangan, MD, RSW, certifying two hundred fifty-nine (259) barangays which successfully remained Covid-19 free from December 1, 2020 to January 31, 2021. There are two hundred twenty-eight (228) barangays which became Covid-19 free for the first time, while thirty-one (31) barangays are Covid-19 free for the second time during said period;
WHEREAS, the grant of incentives is another step taken by the City in ensuring the health and safety of its citizenry by encouraging and upholding the exemplary performance of barangays during the Covid-19 Pandemic;
WHEREAS, the City Government recognizes the vital role of Barangay Officials in implementing national and local COVID-19 and quarantine protocols and in ensuring the health and safety of their constituents;
WHEREAS, Section 321 of the Local Government Code states that “all budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the sanggunian, no ordinance providing for supplemental budget shall be enacted except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources”;
WHEREAS, the allocation and use of the said amount shall be subject to existing laws, rules, and budgeting regulations: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2021 in the amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) is hereby approved.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. — The funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) shall be derived from funds actually available as certified by the City Treasurer.

SEC. 3. Use of Funds. — The amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated under the Office of the Mayor: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses — Awards and Rewards Expenses as incentives, in the amount of One Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP 100,000.00) for barangays which became Covid-19 free for the first time, and Two Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP 200,000.00) for barangays which have remained Covid-19 free for the second time, for the period December 1, 2020 until January 31, 2021.
Attached are the following details:
•        Annex A — Statement of Funding Source
•        Annex B — Statement of Supplemental Appropriations

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 4, 2021.

ORDINANCE NO. 8726

AN ORDINANCE DECLARING A CERTAIN PORTION IN BARANGAY 699 AND BARANGAY 702 OF MALATE AS MANILA KOREA TOWN FOR BUSINESS AND TOURIST HUB IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, City of Manila envisions becoming a premiere urban destination within Metro Manila and a showcase of sustainable urban tourism development in the country. With proper planning and implementation, the City aims to obtain social and economic benefits from tourism, currently the largest and fastest growing industry in the world that has been utilized by both countries and local governments as one of the foundations of their economies;
WHEREAS, South Koreans are currently the top tourism market for the Philippines and the Korean government promises to bring even more in the coming years;
WHEREAS, data shows that around 1.6M Korean tourists visited Manila last year, and the Korean government is committing to bring up to two million Korean tourists in the coming year;
WHEREAS, establishing a Korea Town in Malate, Manila would entail promising business opportunities not only for Koreans but for the Manila constituents as well;
WHEREAS, the recent pronouncement of the Korean government emphasizing that the Philippines has a strong leadership under the Duterte government resonates with Manila as a safe and robust business center;
WHEREAS, establishing a Korea Town in Malate, Manila will strengthen diplomatic ties between Manila City and South Korea, particularly with Korea's Retailing Association, and eventually enhance and improve tourist visitations, creating a strong business activity;
WHEREAS, DTCAM provides that the tourism districts were chosen based on their inherent advantages, unique character, and tourism potential compared to other areas in the City. Development of these areas will include programs and projects with regard to accessibility, mobility, security, incentives to attract specific businesses, and structural and aesthetic enhancements to transform these places into attractive and viable tourist attractions;
WHEREAS, the Manila City Council recognized the economic and tourism potential of Barangay 699 & Barangay 702, Malate area, based on the feasibility study conducted by the Korean-Filipino community, which sought to improve the physical environment of the area for tourism and strengthen its economic base through a strong partnership between the City and the community;
WHEREAS, aside from being widely known as the "Korean Restaurant" area because of the concentration of Korean restaurants in the locale, Barangay 699 & Barangay 702 have also been identified by the Korean-Filipino community as an area of prosperity based on feng shui, making it a viable place for community resettlement and home to authentic Korean dining;
WHEREAS, considering the invaluable contribution of the Korean-Filipino community in Malate to revenue and employment generation, the City government deems it proper to support the community in terms of site development, security, and other improvements to foster growth and progress in the area as one of the City of Manila's tourism districts; NOW, THEREFORE, 

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled:
SECTION 1. Declaration. —  “AN ORDINANCE DECLARING A CERTAIN PORTION IN BARANGAY 699 & BARANGAY 702 OF MALATE IS HEREBY DECLARED AS THE MANILA KOREA TOWN FOR BUSINESS AND TOURIST ACTIVITIES IN THE CITY OF MANILA.”

SECTION 2. Objective. — The City of Manila, in partnership with stakeholders and barangay officials in the area, shall develop Manila Korea Town through programs and policies consistent with the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) and shall undertake efforts to promote and popularize the same as a tourist destination within the City.

SECTION 3. Boundaries. — Manila Korea Town is bounded by the following streets in Malate, Manila: M. H. Del Pilar St. to Gen. Malvar St., to Adriatico St. cor. Remedios St., to Guerrero St., to San Andres St., and back to Adriatico St. and Remedios St.

The location map of the Manila Korea Town shall be attached as Annex "A" to this Ordinance and made an integral part hereof.

SECTION 4. Manila Korea Town Tourism Council. — The Manila Korea Town Tourism Council is hereby created composed of authorized representatives from the following:
1.        Office of the City Mayor
2.        Office of the City Vice Mayor
3.        Chairman, Committee on International Relations
4.        Chairman, Committee on Tourism
5.        Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts, Manila (DTCAM)
6.        Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW)
7.        City Planning and Development Office (CPDO)
8.        National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP)
9.        Malate Police Station Representative
10.        Korean Organization Representative of the Korean Business District
11.        Punong Barangays of the Barangays covered by Manila Korea Town

The City Mayor may invite provisional non-voting representatives from national government agencies, regulatory bodies, private sector entities, and others as deemed necessary.

SECTION 5. Secretariat. — The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) shall serve as the secretariat to facilitate and ensure the performance of the Manila Korea Town Tourism Council’s duties, including providing technical support, documentation, report preparation, and other necessary assistance, to introduce, suggestions and recommendations in furtherance of this goal.
SECTION 6. Meetings. — The Manila Korea Town Tourism Council shall conduct regular meetings as scheduled by the City Mayor or as required by DTCAM.

SECTION 7. Development Plan. — The Manila Korea Town Council shall prepare and adopt a development plan consistent with DTCAM. This plan, subject to confirmation by the City Council, shall include architectural, landscape, and engineering designs, as well as guidelines for implementation and monitoring of the development plan, within six (6) months from the approval of this Ordinance. 
The development plan shall improve accessibility and mobility, ensure environmental sustainability, as well as enhance infrastructure and amenities within the tourism district. The improvements within the area may include, but are not limited to, the following:
I. Information Dissemination and Promotion
a. Signages, Markers and Information Boards — Korean translation and/or symbols shall complement signages in Filipino or English, including business signages. Korean art may be incorporated in the area, either engraved or painted. Locational maps to guide visitors shall be included in the information boards, written in the Filipino, English, and Korean language.
b. Information Center — These shall be established in strategic locations to meet the needs of the visitors. The City’s collaterals, such as pamphlets, fliers, maps, and other communication materials shall be distributed to visitors, and should be written in Filipino, English, and Korean languages.
c. Digital Billboards — These include LED displays, which shall flash advertisements and announcements with allotted screen time for City informational/promotional matters.
d. Souvenir Shops — The souvenir items shall primarily promote the tourism district and/or the City and may include, among others, products made by the stakeholders within the area or City micro-entrepreneurs, livelihood communities, and cooperatives.

II. Traffic Improvement
a. Parking Area — A parking space/facility within the vicinity of the tourism district shall be provided to decongest the area and encourage visitor traffic.
b. Shuttle Service — Preferably environmentally sound, electronic-powered and equipped with Global Positioning System (GPS) and Wi-Fi connectivity, this shall be provided to facilitate the visitors and locals of the area and ease the traffic flow therein, with designated stops at fixed time intervals.
c. Traffic Regulation — Traffic rules and regulations shall be developed and strictly implemented in the area.
d. Traffic Lights and Signals — These will include countdown timers and pedestrian signals, which may include sensors to aid PWDs.
e. Illegal transportation terminals shall be removed.
f. Ambulant vendors and/or privilege-stores or tiangges shall be regulated.
III. Peace and Order Measures/Security Facilities
a. Emergency Calling Stations and Helpdesks/Hotlines — These shall be established in accessible areas with helpdesk operators who are well-versed in the Filipino, English, and Korean languages.
b. Closed-Circuit Television (CCTV) Cameras — High-definition closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras shall be installed in traffic lights posts, street lamps or other key points in the area. These shall be connected to a command center manned by technical personnel who shall provide real-time updates for rapid response/assistance to ensure peace and security within the tourism district.
IV. Road Facilities Improvement
a. Lamp Post — These shall be environmentally-sound and shall complement the design of the tourism district. Korean lanterns or any other Korean ornaments shall also be installed in the area during special occasions.
b. Sidewalks — These shall be widened and/or cleared of obstructions to give due consideration for pedestrians and persons with disabilities (PWDs). Walkways may likewise be landscaped for aesthetics purposes.
c. Waiting Sheds — These shall be designed according to theme.
d. Drainage System — As may be deemed necessary for the tourism district.
e. Public Restrooms — Shall have appropriate signage or markers and strategically placed in areas with high foot traffic. These shall be properly sanitized and maintained by assigned personnel.
f. Sanitation — Sanitary bins shall be strategically placed in areas with high foot traffic. The cleanliness of streets, walkways, and other public spaces shall be maintained at all times by assigned personnel.
V. Miscellaneous Improvement
•        Wi-Fi Connection — Accessible to visitors and locals within the tourism district.
VI. Such other improvements as may be provided in the development plan.

SEC. 8. Solid Waste Management — The City government, through the Department of Public Safety (DPS), shall provide guidelines for an efficient and effective waste management system applicable to the tourism district, including the strict implementation of programs, and promotion of waste segregation, recycling, re-use, and zero-waste initiatives.
SEC. 9. Food Sanitation — The City government, through the Manila Health Department (MHD), shall strictly monitor food service establishments and enforce sanitation rules within the area.

SEC. 10. Implementation. — The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) is primarily mandated to monitor the implementation of this Ordinance. It shall maintain close coordination with the stakeholders within the community, which shall be made part of the conceptualization, planning, and promotion of all projects and activities within the area. Further, it shall coordinate with the barangays covered by the Manila Korea Town to ensure the accessibility, sanitation, and smooth traffic flow within the area.

SEC. 11. Site Branding and Promotion — The City government, through the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM), shall reinforce the identity of the tourism district and promote the same through appropriate branding mechanisms, as provided in the Manila Tourism Development Plan.
The official logos of the City government shall be adopted by all City departments and offices in promoting the tourism district. The said logos shall be prominently displayed in strategic areas within the area, and the same shall be incorporated in all collaterals or promotional materials of the area.
The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) shall collaborate with the Manila Public Information Office (MPIO) in adopting ways to popularize and promote the tourism district through various media platforms, including the internet. It shall disseminate feature articles, press releases, and audio-video presentations; upload locational maps, brochures, and lists of business establishments on the City government website; facilitate the creation of a tourism website, and undertake such other tasks to promote the tourism district.
SEC. 12. Guided Tours — The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) shall include the subject tourism district in educational guided tours for visitors and guests.
Tour guides within the tourism district must be accredited by the Department of Tourism (DOT) and registered with the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM), who must undergo regular training and attend seminars conducted by DOT, the City government, or any other agency or institution duly authorized by the DOT to conduct said trainings and seminars.
SEC. 13. Festivities — The Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM), in consultation with the stakeholders of the area, shall organize, implement and promote events and activities to popularize the Manila Korea Town.

SEC. 14. Appropriations — Necessary funds are hereby appropriated based on the availability of funds of the City government for the implementation of this Ordinance.

SEC. 15. Repealing Clause — All other ordinances, resolutions, orders, circulars, and regulations or parts thereof, which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 16. Separability Clause — If, for any reason, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 17. Effectivity Clause —  This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 28, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance designates a portion of Barangay 699 and Barangay 702 in Malate as the "Manila Korea Town" to develop it into a business and tourist hub. The area will feature programs to enhance tourism, including cultural displays, improved infrastructure, and security. The plan involves promoting the area through signage, events, and a development plan aimed at improving accessibility, sanitation, and local business opportunities. It will also support the Korean-Filipino community, encourage Korean tourism, and boost the local economy.

ORDINANCE NO. 8725

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING NINE HUNDRED THIRTY MILLION PESOS (PHP 930,000,000.00) AS SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 2 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2021 FOR THE HAULING AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE WITH EXCAVATION, BACKFILLING AND COMPACTING OF GROUND IN SMOKEY MOUNTAIN, TONDO, MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, no less than the 1987 Philippine Constitution provides for the duty of the State to protect and advance the right of the people to a balanced and healthful ecology in accord with the rhythm and harmony of nature (Section 16, Article II);
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that:
“Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare... promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology... and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.” (Section 16, Republic Act No. 7160)
WHEREAS, since the 1970s, Smokey Mountain, located in Tondo, has been a major repository of waste for the City of Manila, resulting in decades of solid waste accumulation;
WHEREAS, in 1995, then President Fidel V. Ramos ordered the closure of the Smokey Mountain dumpsite due to its deteriorating condition and the approval of a redevelopment plan under the National Housing Authority;
WHEREAS, the Manila Health Department conducted a health survey in the area and recommended:
•        Immediate clean-up and end to waste dumping in Smokey Mountain
•        Rehabilitation of the area to mitigate environmental and health risks
•        Continued health surveillance and stakeholder consultation
•        Environmental and sanitation strategies to protect residents
WHEREAS, on October 30, 2019, the Regional Trial Court of Quezon City, Branch 97, ruled that the Quezon City Government was liable for a fatal 2000 landslide at a dumpsite that killed 232 people. The court awarded damages to victims’ families, citing government negligence as the proximate cause;
WHEREAS, this decision serves as a reminder to local governments to proactively prevent such tragedies in compliance with environmental laws like the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act;
WHEREAS, during a Joint Committee Hearing on October 14, 2020, the Department of Environment and Natural Resources confirmed the high risk of a similar landslide at Smokey Mountain, citing its 90-degree slope and low waste density. The area is home to over 800 families;
WHEREAS, the Committees on Health and Environmental Protection recommended the immediate clearing and removal of the Smokey Mountain dumpsite to protect lives and improve the environment;
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code allows for the enactment of a supplemental budget supported by available funds or new revenue sources, especially in times of public calamity (Section 321, R.A. No. 7160), and prohibits transferring funds between items unless properly authorized (Section 336, R.A. No. 7160);
WHEREAS, on January 25, 2021, the City Council adopted Resolution No. 01, Series of 2021, issued by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, approving the amendment of the Annual Investment Program and issuing a Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2021 in the amount of PHP 930,000,000.00 for the clearing, grubbing, hauling, and disposal of solid waste in Smokey Mountain, Tondo, Manila;
WHEREAS, the funds released through this ordinance shall be aligned with national and local policies and will promote the health and safety of Manileños by removing the Smokey Mountain dumpsite and improving the area;

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Appropriations. — The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2021 in the amount of Nine Hundred Thirty Million Pesos (PHP 930,000,000.00) is hereby approved.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. — The funds shall be sourced from actual available funds and new revenue sources as certified by the City Treasurer.
Attached:
•        Annex A — Statement of Funding Source
•        Annex B — Statement of Supplemental Appropriation No. 2

SEC. 3. Use of Funds. — The amount of PHP 930,000,000.00 shall be appropriated under the Department of Public Services (DPS) — Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses - Environmental/Sanitation Services, specifically for the hauling and disposal of solid waste, including:
•        Mobilization and demobilization
•        Site preparation, clearing, construction of temporary storage area, safety enclosure
•        Hauling of debris, removal of water and electrical utilities
•        Demolition/hauling of 361.85 linear meters of existing CHB wall
•        Clearing and grubbing of 1,323,934.86 cubic meters (compacted)
•        Hauling and disposal of 2,647,862.72 loose volume of solid waste
•        Excavation of unsuitable materials
•        Backfilling, compaction, and ground preparation
•        Gravel bedding
•        Other necessary works

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 28, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance approves a supplemental budget of PHP 930 million for 2021 to clean up the Smokey Mountain dumpsite in Tondo, Manila. The budget will be used for clearing, hauling, and safely disposing of solid waste, along with necessary groundwork like excavation, backfilling, and compaction. The cleanup aims to protect residents from health and environmental hazards and prevent possible landslides, following recommendations from health and environmental authorities. The funds will come from available and new revenue sources certified by the City Treasurer.

ORDINANCE NO. 8723

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING SECTION 2A OF ORDINANCE NO. 7755 (UNDER TRICYCLE TERMINALS), AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THEREIN THE LOADING AND UNLOADING AREAS OF PARAISO TRICYCLE OPERATORS AND DRIVER'S ASSOCIATION, BRGY. 177, AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7871, AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THEREIN ITS ROUTE MEASURE CAPACITY

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Section 2A (Tricycle Terminals) of Ordinance No. 7755 is hereby furthermore amended by including therein the loading and unloading areas of Paraiso Tricycle Operators and Driver’s Association, Brgy. 177, to read as follows:
“PARAISO TRICYCLE OPERATORS AND DRIVER’S ASSOCIATION, BRGY. 177
Loading and Unloading Areas:
1.        Loading
 a. Clemente St. – Hermosa St. (vice versa)
2.        Unloading
 a. Flora
 b.  Juan Luna

SECTION 2. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 7871 is hereby furthermore amended by including therein the Route Measure Capacity and authorized route line of Paraiso Tricycle Operators and Driver’s Association, Brgy. 177, to read as follows:
“ASSOCIATION                     
Paraiso Tricycle Operators and Driver’s Association, Brgy. 177

R.M.C.
40 Units

ROUTE:
The authorized route line of operation shall be via Clemente Street – Flora Street – Juan Luna Street – Hermosa Street and vice versa.”

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 25, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance updates existing laws by officially designating the loading and unloading zones for the Paraiso Tricycle Operators and Driver’s Association in Barangay 177. It also sets their approved route and allows them to operate with a maximum of 40 tricycles. Their authorized route covers Clemente, Flora, Juan Luna, and Hermosa Streets, going back and forth.

ORDINANCE NO. 8722

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING AUTHORITY TO THE CITY MAYOR, HONORABLE FRANCISCO “ISKO MORENO” DOMAGOSO, TO DISPOSE THE CITY-OWNED PATRIMONIAL PROPERTIES SPECIFICALLY A PORTION OF TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 002-6571 (LOT 6 OF PCS-00-015367 ISSUED ON NOVEMBER 9, 2016) AND A PORTION OF LOT 5-B UNDER TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 002-2012004038, BOTH LOCATED AT VITO CRUZ STREET, MALATE, MANILA, THROUGH PUBLIC BIDDING AND TO, SUBSEQUENTLY, SIGN ALL PERTINENT DOCUMENTS RELATIVE TO THE SAID DISPOSAL, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE CONTRACT OF SALE, SUBJECT TO ALL EXISTING LAWS, RULES AND REGULATIONS

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, on March 14, 2016, the City Government of Manila entered into a Joint Venture Agreement (JVA) with Maranaw Hotels & Resort Corporation for the financing, design, construction and development of a commercial and office tower in Vito Cruz Street, Malate, Manita:

WHEREAS, on November 20. 2020 and upon the recommendation of the Sangguniang Panlungsod based on Resolution No. 274, Series of 2020, the City of Manila entered into a mutual termination of the above-cited Joint Venture Agreement due to non-compliance to certain provisions thereof which effectively reverted the property to the City of Manila thereby placing it at the City’s disposal;

WHEREAS, the Asset Management Committee (AMC) made it a point to hire the services of a private independent appraiser to determine the value of the above- mentioned patrimonial properties, subject to applicable procurement rules and regulations;

WHEREAS, the Asset Management Committee (AMC) likewise recommended to the Mayor the disposition of the subject patrimonial property to augment the budget of the  City for the utilization of the same in the delivery of basic services, and for the purchase of medical equipment, vaccines and medicines in its fight against the COVID-19 Virus: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Authority. — The City Council of Manila hereby authorizes the City Mayor, Hon. Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso, to dispose the City-Owned Patrimonial  Property in a manner mostly advantageous to the City and to, subsequently, sign all  pertinent documents relative to the said disposal, including, but not limited to, the Contract of Sale.

SEC. 2. Coverage. Location. — The Patrimonial Property subject of this Ordinance are a Portion of Transfer Certificate of Title No. 002-6571 (Lot 6 of Pcs-00-015367 issued on November 9, 2016), and a portion of Lot 5-B under Transfer Certificate No. 002-2012004038, both located at Vito Cruz Street, Malate, Manila.

SEC. 3. Mode of Disposal. Proviso. — The disposition of the property covered by this Ordinance as described under Section 2 hereof is through public bidding, subject to all pertinent laws, rules and regulations existing under the Republic of the Philippines.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 18, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance gives the Manila City Mayor, Francisco "Isko Moreno" Domagoso, the authority to sell two specific city-owned properties located on Vito Cruz Street, Malate, Manila. These properties, which were returned to the city after a cancelled joint venture, will be sold through public bidding. The goal of the sale is to raise funds to support basic public services, including the purchase of medical supplies and COVID-19 response needs. The mayor is also authorized to sign all necessary documents related to the sale.

ORDINANCE NO. 8721 

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING THE SNEAKING-IN AND SMUGGLING OF CONTRABAND INSIDE THE BUREAU OF JAIL MANAGEMENT AND PENOLOGY (BJMP) MANILA CITY JAIL AND IMPOSING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila is given the power to exercise local legislative powers under Section 48 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991;
WHEREAS, in particular, the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila is authorized by Section 458 (a)(5)(xv) of the same Code to institute a sound Jail Management Program;
WHEREAS, the aforesaid problem poses a continuous threat to the overall security of the facility and fully impedes the realization of the program thrusts of the government towards the total reformation of the Persons Deprived of Liberty (PDL) under our custody;
WHEREAS, as part of instituting sound jail management programs, there is a need to restrain and prevent these frenzied activities from happening inside the BJMP Manila City Jail through the enactment of a local ordinance prohibiting the sneaking-in and smuggling of contraband within its confines and prescribing penalties for violation thereof: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “THE ANTI-SNEAKING-IN AND SMUGGLING OF CONTRABAND INSIDE THE BUREAU OF JAIL MANAGEMENT AND PENOLOGY (BJMP) MANILA CITY JAIL AND IMPOSING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF.”

SEC. 2. Purpose and Coverage. — This Ordinance seeks to penalize persons who sneak in or surreptitiously bring in contraband as defined under Section 12 of the BJMP Comprehensive Operations Manual Revised 2015. The Ordinance shall cover the BJMP Manila City Jail and/or other detention facilities within the jurisdiction.

SEC. 3. Definition of Terms. — As used in this Ordinance.
A. Person – Shall refer to natural persons, including:
A.1 Visitor – A person who enters a jail facility for a definite period of time to meet an inmate or personnel of the Bureau, or conduct official business or activities inside the jail. A visitor includes relatives, friends, lawyers, doctors, spiritual advisers, service providers, or any person who enters the jail for the purpose of seeing or conferring with an inmate.
A.2 Jail Officers – In general, refers to all uniformed personnel of the BJMP. When referring to rank, the term “officer” shall refer to those holding the rank of Jail Inspector and above. They are responsible for the humane safekeeping and development of inmates.
A.3 General Services – All persons involved in services applicable to the entire facility and not confined to a specific function (e.g., garbage collectors, delivery staff, and the like).
A.4 Outsiders – All those persons who do not belong to a particular jail unit but may transact or enter the jail facility for a certain purpose, including Law Enforcement Agencies and BJMP Officers, and other outsiders not specifically defined but who may commit the same acts.
B. Contrabands – Refers to prohibited items, including any article, item, or thing forbidden by law and jail rules that may pose a security hazard or endanger the lives of inmates. Contraband is further divided into:
B.1 Illegal Contraband – Items unlawful in themselves and not due to external circumstances (e.g., dangerous drugs, weapons, explosives).
Dangerous Drugs – As defined in Article I, Sec. 3(j) of R.A. 9165, includes but is not limited to heroin, morphine, opium, marijuana, cocaine or its derivatives, methamphetamine hydrochloride ("shabu"), MDMA ("ecstasy"), PMA, TMA, LSD, and GHB.
B.2 Merely Prohibited and Nuisance Contraband – Items not illegal by law but forbidden by jail rules (e.g., cellphones, excessive money or commodities like jewelry, gadgets, excessive clothing or bedding, intoxicants, cigarettes, pornographic materials, gambling items, and other vices).
C. Persons Deprived of Liberty (PDL) – A person accused before a court or competent authority and temporarily confined in jail while awaiting investigation, trial, or final judgment.
D. Jail/Detention Facility – Any location used for detention, including jails or prisons where inmates are confined and deprived of liberty under state authority following conviction.

SEC. 4. Prohibition. — Without prejudice to prosecution under other applicable laws, it shall be unlawful for any person to commit the following acts:
1.        For any person visiting a PDL in Manila City Jail to sneak in or smuggle any form of contraband as defined in Section 3(B).
2.        For any person (including general services staff, outsiders, or others not specified) who enters Manila City Jail for specific purposes and sneaks in or smuggles any contraband.
3.        The same prohibitions and penalties shall apply to BJMP officers or personnel proven to have sneaked in or smuggled contraband as defined herein or who have aided in such acts.

SEC. 5. Penalties. — Penal Provisions:
1.        All persons defined under Section 3(A) who sneak in, smuggle, or possess dangerous drugs or paraphernalia upon entering or while inside the jail shall be prosecuted under R.A. 9165 (Comprehensive Dangerous Drugs Act of 2002). Confiscated drugs shall be disposed of in accordance with said law.
2.        All such persons found possessing deadly weapons (e.g., blades, firearms) shall be prosecuted under P.D. 1866 as amended by R.A. 8294, or B.P. 6. Confiscated weapons shall be disposed of according to applicable law.
3.        All persons found to sneak in, smuggle, or possess merely prohibited and nuisance contraband, or who aided in such acts, shall face the following:
First Offense – ₱2,000 fine, forfeiture of contraband, and community service
Second Offense – ₱3,000 fine, forfeiture of contraband, and/or imprisonment of up to 6 months (at the Court’s discretion)
Third Offense – ₱5,000 fine, forfeiture of contraband, and/or imprisonment of up to 1 year (at the Court’s discretion)
Penalties may be modified at the discretion of the court.
4.        Fines upon conviction shall be paid directly to the City Treasurer. Proceeds shall be held in trust and used as supplemental funds for managing jails and detention facilities.
5.        In addition to the above, any BJMP personnel found in violation shall face administrative charges under BJMP disciplinary procedures when evidence of guilt is strong.

SEC. 6. Implementing Rules and Regulations.  — The BJMP, in coordination with the Philippine National Police (PNP), shall be responsible for apprehending violators and filing appropriate charges.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. —  If any section or provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the remainder shall not be affected and shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause.  —  All ordinances inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or amended accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 14, 2021.
short_text: This ordinance makes it illegal to bring in or sneak prohibited items (like drugs, weapons, cellphones, or even cigarettes) into the BJMP Manila City Jail. It applies to visitors, jail staff, outsiders, and even jail officers themselves. Anyone caught smuggling dangerous drugs or weapons will be charged under national laws, while those caught with less dangerous contraband may be fined, required to do community service, or even jailed depending on how many times they’ve offended. The BJMP and police are tasked to catch and charge violators.
fines:
For merely prohibited items:

1st Offense: PhP2,000 fine + community service

2nd Offense: PhP3,000 fine + up to 6 months' imprisonment (Court’s discretion)

3rd Offense: PhP5,000 fine + up to 1 year imprisonment (Court’s discretion)

For drugs/weapons: Prosecution under national laws (R.A. 9165, P.D. 1866, etc.)

BJMP personnel: Administrative penalties if found guilty

ORDINANCE NO. 8720

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING SECTION 2.a OF ORDINANCE
NO. 7755 (UNDER TRICYCLE TERMINALS), AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING
THEREIN THE LOADING AND UNLOADING AREAS OF BALUT-TODA DISTRICT 1-
INC. (BALTODA-1) AND SECTION 2 OF ORDINANCE NO.7871, AS AMENDED, BY
INCLUDING THEREIN ITS ROUTE MEASURE CAPACITY

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 2.a (Tricycle Terminals) of Ordinance No. 7755, is hereby
furthermore amended, by including therein the loading and unloading areas of BALUT-
TODA DISTRICT 1 — INC. (BALTODA-1), to read as follows:

“BALUT-TODA DISTRICT 1 — INC. (BALTODA-1)

Loading and Unloading Areas

a. Nepa-Malaya-Rodriguez-Guidote Balut”

SEC. 2. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 7871, is hereby furthermore amended, by
Including therein the Route Measure Capacity and authorized route line of BALUT-
TODA DISTRICT 1 —INC. (BALTODA), to read as follows:

“ASSOCIATION:
BALUTTODA, DISTRICT 14, INC
(BALTODA)
 RMC:
300 Units
ROUTE

Balut, Tondo, Manila.”

Sec. 3. Separability Clause — If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or

short_text: This ordinance updates the regulations for tricycle terminals and routes in the Balut-TODA District 1. It adds new loading and unloading areas along the Nepa-Malaya-Rodriguez-Guidote Balut route. The ordinance also sets the capacity for Balut-TODA District 1 to operate with 300 tricycles along this route, ensuring proper organization of the transportation system for better efficiency and safety.

This ordinance is about reusing PhP 200,000,000 from last year’s budget that wasn’t fully spent on COVID-19 vaccine purchases. The money will be transferred to the current year’s budget (Fiscal Year 2021) so that the City of Manila can buy vaccines for its residents. This is an important step in continuing the city’s efforts to protect its people from the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The funds will be specifically used for the purchase of vaccines, and they will come from money the city has available from new revenue sources, as confirmed by the city’s financial officers.

This ordinance authorizes the grant of one-time gratuity pay for 2020 to job order and contract of service employees of the Manila City Government. The workers will receive up to PhP 3,000 as a token of appreciation for their hard work during the pandemic. The total amount for the gratuity pay is PhP 29,883,000, which will be sourced from available savings in the city's budget.

This ordinance authorizes a one-time Service Recognition Incentive for job order and contract of service employees of the Manila City Government for the year 2020. These workers will receive up to PhP 3,000 as a form of gratitude for their hard work during the pandemic. The total amount for the incentive is PhP 92,820,000, which will be sourced from available savings in the city’s budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 8716

AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES — DONATION ACCOUNT OF THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE AND THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES — SPECIAL ACTIVITIES FUND UNDER THE FY 2020 ANNUAL BUDGET IN THE AMOUNT OF SIXTY-FIVE MILLION PESOS (PhP 65,000,000.00) AND TEN MILLION PESOS (PhP 10,000,000.00), RESPECTIVELY, IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVENTY-FIVE MILLION PESOS (PhP 75,000,000.00), AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 8565, entitled “An Ordinance Providing Five Hundred Pesos (PhP 500.00) Monthly Monetary Allowance to All Bonafide Senior Citizens, Differently-Abled or Persons With Disability and Solo Parent Residents of the City of Manila, as Part of the Social Amelioration Program of the City, Appropriating Funds Therefor and for Other Purposes,” mandated that a Five Hundred Pesos (PhP 500.00) monthly allowance shall be given to qualified Persons with Disability and Solo Parents;

WHEREAS, the FY 2020 Annual Budget appropriated funds under the Donations Account of the Manila Department of Social Welfare and the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses — Special Activities Fund (SAF), which, upon implementation of necessary programs/activities, are determined to be deficient. Hence, the need for augmentation of funds through available savings from other accounts under the FY 2020 Annual Budget;

WHEREAS, Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991, states that:

“Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”

WHEREAS, Section 321 of RA No. 7160 provides that:

“All budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources.”

WHEREAS, Section 336 of RA No. 7160 states that:

“Funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.”

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 29, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on December 14, 2020, entitled:

“A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 TO AUGMENT THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES (MOOE) — DONATION ACCOUNT OF THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE AND THE MOOE — SPECIAL ACTIVITIES FUND UNDER THE FY 2020 ANNUAL BUDGET IN THE AMOUNT OF SIXTY-FIVE MILLION PESOS (PhP 65,000,000.00) AND TEN MILLION PESOS (PhP 10,000,000.00), RESPECTIVELY, IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVENTY-FIVE MILLION PESOS (PhP 75,000,000.00) FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ORDINANCE NO. 8565 AND VARIOUS ACTIVITIES AND PROGRAMS OF THE CITY.”

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in special session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Augmentation.
The following accounts under the FY 2020 Annual Budget shall be augmented:

a. Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) — Donation Account under the Manila Department of Social Welfare in the amount of Sixty-Five Million Pesos (PhP 65,000,000.00) to provide additional funds for the Five Hundred Pesos (PhP 500.00) monthly allowance of qualified Persons with Disability and Solo Parents pursuant to Ordinance No. 8565; and

b. Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) — Special Activities Fund in the amount of Ten Million Pesos (PhP 10,000,000.00) for necessary programs and activities, subject to the issuance of a City Council Resolution authorizing the use of the fund.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds.
Such augmentation shall be sourced from available savings from various accounts of the FY 2020 Annual Budget in the total amount of Seventy-Five Million Pesos (PhP 75,000,000.00).

SEC. 3. Separability Clause.
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on December 17, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance provides an additional PhP 75 million to the 2020 city budget to support social programs under the Manila Department of Social Welfare. PhP 65 million is allocated to continue the monthly PhP 500 allowance for Persons with Disability and Solo Parents, as mandated by Ordinance No. 8565. The remaining PhP 10 million will fund special city programs and activities, pending further approval. The funding comes from savings within the city’s 2020 budget.
