ORDINANCE NO. 8715

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING FORTY-FIVE MILLION PESOS (PhP. 45,000,000.00) AS SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 21 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2020 FOR THE MANILA E-CITIZENS IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM OR THE MANILA RESIDENCE IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM (MRIS) PURSUANT TO ORDINANCE NO. 8619 UNDER THE CAPITAL OUTLAY — COMPUTER SOFTWARE ACCOUNT OF THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR (ELECTRONIC DATA PROCESSING SERVICE) TO COVER THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE PORTAL (CORE) PHASE OF THE SYSTEM AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 8619, entitled: “AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING THE CITY IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM TO ALL RESIDENTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA AND BE KNOWN AS MANILA RESIDENT IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM (MRIS)”, mandates that all residents are required to secure the MRIS. It covers permanent residents of the City of Manila who are actual inhabitants in the barangay and who have resided in the City for a minimum of six (6) months prior to their application;

WHEREAS, Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991, states that:
"Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.”

WHEREAS, Section 321 of RA No. 7160 provides that:
"All budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the Sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources;"

WHEREAS, Section 336 of RA No. 7160 states that:
"Funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated. No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations.”

WHEREAS, the Local Legislative Body approved Resolution Nos. 30, 31, and 32, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on 14 December 2020, entitled:
"A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 BY WAY OF A SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET IN THE AMOUNT OF FORTY-FIVE MILLION PESOS (PhP. 45,000,000.00) FOR THE MANILA E-CITIZENS IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM OR THE MANILA RESIDENCE IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM (MRIS) PURSUANT TO ORDINANCE NO. 8619":

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Appropriations.
The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2020 in the amount of Forty-Five Million Pesos (PhP. 45,000,000.00) is hereby approved under the Capital Outlay — Computer Software Account of the Office of the Mayor (Electronic Data Processing Service) for the Manila E-Citizens Identification System or the Manila Residence Identification System (MRIS) to cover the Establishment of the Administrator Portal (Core) Phase of the System.

Inclusive in this phase are the following deliverables:

Dashboard

User Management

Policy Creation

Content Management

Web Portal with Mobile Application

Centralized and Real-Time Administrator Portal

Establishment and Workplace Protection

Geo-Mapping / Location

Biometric Core Engine

SEC. 2. Source of Funds.
The source of funds for this Supplemental Budget shall be derived from available savings from the FY 2020 Annual Appropriations Ordinance, herein reverted to the General Fund in the amount of Forty-Five Million Pesos (PhP. 45,000,000.00).

SEC. 3. Separability Clause.
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 17, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance sets aside PhP 45 million as a supplemental budget for 2020 to develop the Manila E-Citizens Identification System (MRIS). This system, created under Ordinance No. 8619, requires all Manila residents who’ve lived in the city for at least six months to register for an official city ID. The budget will fund the creation of the Administrator Portal, which includes features like a dashboard, user and content management tools, mobile and web apps, biometric engine, and geo-mapping. These tools aim to improve the city’s digital governance and public service delivery.

ORDINANCE NO. 8714

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING SIX MILLION FIVE HUNDRED TEN
THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED THIRTY-FOUR PESOS (PHP. 6,510,234.00) AS
SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 22 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2020 UNDER THE MANILA
HEALTH DEPARTMENT - MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES
MEDICAL, DENTAL AND LABORATORY SUPPLIES EXPENSES AND FOR OTHER
PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on 8 March 2020, Presidential Proclamation No. 922, s. 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sublevel Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force (IATF) for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases;

WHEREAS, said Presidential Proclamation enjoined all government agencies and Local Government Units (LGUs) to render full assistance to and cooperation with each other and mobilize the necessary resources to undertake critical, urgent, and appropriate disaster response aid and measures in a timely manner to curtail and eliminate the threat of COVID-19;

WHEREAS, no less than the 1987 Constitution provides that the state shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health and other social services available to all the people at affordable cost and prioritizing, among others, the underprivileged, women and children (Section 11, Article XIII, 1987 Philippine Constitution);

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991, states that: "Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants" (Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, the same Code provides that a supplemental budget may also be enacted in times of public calamity by way of budgetary realignment to set aside appropriations for the purchase of supplies and materials or the payment of services which are exceptionally urgent or absolutely indispensable to prevent imminent danger to, or loss of, life or property, in the jurisdiction of the local government unit or in other areas declared by the President in a state of calamity. Such ordinance shall clearly indicate the sources of funds available for appropriations, as certified under oath by the local treasurer and local accountant and attested by the local chief executive, and the various items of appropriations affected and the reasons for the change. (Section 321 par. 2 of Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, Section 336 of the Local Government Code provide that "funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations"

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 28, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on 11 December 2020, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 BY WAY OF A SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET IN THE AMOUNT OF SIX MILLION FIVE HUNDRED TEN THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED THIRTY-FOUR PESOS (PHP. 6,510,234.00) UNDER THE MANILA HEALTH DEPARTMENT FOR THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES MEDICAL, DENTAL AND LABORATORY SUPPLIES EXPENSES AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES" NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in special session assembled, THAT;

SECTION 1. Appropriations. - The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2020 in the amount of Six Million Five Hundred Ten Thousand Two Hundred Thirty-Four Pesos (PhP. 6,510,234.00) is hereby approved to augment the Manila Health Department: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses - Medical, Dental and Laboratory Supplies Expenses (Special Purpose Appropriations - Bayanihan Grant).

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. - The source of funds for this Supplemental Budget shall be derived from available MOOE appropriations and savings from the Special Purpose Appropriations - Bayanihan Grant under various departments/offices.

SEC. 3. Separability Clause. If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 14, 2020.

NATIONAL CAPITAL REGION
GENERAL SOLANO STREET, SAN MIGUEL, MANILA

January 8, 2021

No. 7160 (Local Government Code of 1991), our review of the FY 2020 Supplemental Budget No. 22 of the City of Manila, involving an appropriation of SIX MILLION FIVE HUNDRED TEN THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED THIRTY FOUR PESOS (P6,510,234.00) under Ordinance No. 8714, submitted to this Office for review on 4 January 2021 reveals substantial compliance with the same law and its Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR). Accordingly, the said Ordinance is declared operative in its entirety effective on the date of its approval, subject to the posting requirements under Section 59 of R. A. No. 7160.

Please be advised of compliance with the following guidelines:

1. 2. All procurement of goods, supplies and materials, equipment, infrastructure/civil works and consulting services shall be subject to the pertinent provisions of R.A. No. 9184 (Government Procurement Reform Act) and its Revised IRR, and prior clearances from pertinent agencies as may be appropriate/needed. In addition, all procurement shall be included in the duly approved Annual Procurement Plan.

It is understood that this review action does not authorize any item of appropriation that is specifically prohibited by or inconsistent with the provisions of law.

It is further understood that the FY 2020 Supplemental Budget No. 22 of the City of Manila shall operationalize approved local development plans.

Compliance with all existing laws, rules and regulations shall be the responsibility of the City of Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 8713

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF COVID-19 SPECIAL RISK ALLOWANCE TO FRONTLINE PUBLIC HEALTH WORKERS DURING THE PERIOD OF ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE RELATIVE TO THE COVID-19 OUTBREAK PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 28, S. 2020 AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Administrative Order No. 28, s. 2020 authorized the grant of COVID-19 Special Risk Allowance (SRA) to frontline Public Health Workers (PHWs) during the period of Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) relative to the COVID-19 outbreak;

WHEREAS, Budget Circular No. 2020-2 dated April 7, 2020 provided the guidelines on the grant of the COVID-19 SRA;

WHEREAS, the aforesaid issuances provided that the grant of COVID-19 SRA to PHWs in Local Government Units (LGUs) shall be determined by their respective Sangguniang depending on the LGUs’ financial capability, subject to prescribed conditions and chargeable against the FY 2020 local government funds;

WHEREAS, Section 336 of Republic Act No. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that “...the Local Chief Executive or the Presiding Officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by Ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations”;

WHEREAS, the Local Legislative Body approved Resolution No. 27, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on December 11, 2020, entitled:

“A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 IN CONNECTION WITH THE GRANT OF COVID-19 SPECIAL RISK ALLOWANCE TO FRONTLINE PUBLIC HEALTH WORKERS DURING THE PERIOD OF ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE RELATIVE TO THE COVID-19 OUTBREAK PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 28, S. 2020.”

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. SPECIAL RISK ALLOWANCE.
The grant of the one-time COVID-19 Special Risk Allowance (SRA) to Public Health Workers (PHWs) is hereby authorized, equivalent to a maximum of 25% of monthly basic salary, to be pro-rated based on the number of days PHWs physically reported for work during the ECQ from March 17 to May 15, 2020, as follows:


No. of Days Physically Reporting for Work: 3 to 7
Percentage of Incentive: 25%

No. of Days Physically Reporting for Work: 8 to 12
Percentage of Incentive: 50%

No. of Days Physically Reporting for Work: 13 to 17
Percentage of Incentive: 75%

No. of Days Physically Reporting for Work: 18 or more
Percentage of Incentive: 100%

SEC. 2. PUBLIC HEALTH WORKERS.
PHWs include medical, allied-medical, and other necessary personnel assigned to hospitals and healthcare facilities who are directly attending to or in contact with COVID-19 patients, persons under investigation (PUIs), or persons under monitoring (PUMs). These workers are exposed to health risks and physical hardships and provide essential services during the ECQ.

They physically report for work at their respective offices or workstations during official working hours, as authorized by their agency heads, during the ECQ period.

They may be:

(a) Civilian employees occupying regular, contractual, or casual positions, on a full-time or part-time basis; or

(b) Workers engaged through Contract of Service (COS) or Job Order (JO), including Barangay Health Workers (BHWs), regardless of employment nature, provided they meet the required conditions.

SEC. 3. EXCLUSIONS FROM THE GRANT OF COVID-19 SRA.
The following are excluded from receiving the COVID-19 SRA (except those authorized under Section 2):

a. Consultants and experts hired for a limited time to perform specific tasks with deliverables;

b. Laborers engaged through pakyaw contracts or paid on a piecework basis;

c. Student workers and apprentices;

d. All individuals hired through COS or JO (including BHWs) not assigned to hospitals and healthcare facilities.

SEC. 4. AUGMENTATION AND FUND SOURCES.
A total of PhP 30,755,099.00 shall be allocated for the grant of the COVID-19 SRA, sourced from:

a. Personal Services (PS) — PhP 25,383,343.00
Funded through augmentation of the Non-Office Account, Special Activities Fund (SAF) - PS, from PS savings.

b. Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) — PhP 5,371,756.00
Funded through augmentation of the Non-Office Account, SAF - MOOE, from MOOE savings, for COS, JO workers, other professionals, and consultants.

Attachments:

Annex A — Declaration of Savings under PS and MOOE

Annex B — Budgetary Requirements under SAF - PS and SAF - MOOE

SEC. 5. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE.
If any part of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, all unaffected provisions shall remain in effect.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 14, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance grants a COVID-19 Special Risk Allowance (SRA) to frontline public health workers in Manila who physically reported for work during the Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) from March 17 to May 15, 2020. The allowance is based on how many days they worked during the ECQ and can be up to 100% of 25% of their monthly basic pay. The SRA covers regular, casual, contractual, and job order health workers (including Barangay Health Workers) assigned to hospitals and healthcare facilities. However, consultants, student workers, and non-healthcare-based job order workers are excluded. The city allocated a total of PhP 30,755,099.00 from savings in Personnel Services and Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses to fund the allowance.

short_text: This ordinance changes the title and descriptions of several positions within the Manila City Council. It updates the job titles for the personal staff of the Council members, aligning them with the term of the appointing authority. These changes apply to both existing staff and newly assigned employees. For example, "Local Legislative Staff Officer IV" is now called "Political Affairs Officer III," and other similar changes have been made for various positions. Additionally, the plantilla or official list of positions has also been revised to reflect these updates, and the new titles apply retroactively starting January 1, 2020.

This ordinance authorizes the City Government of Manila to give a special bonus called the Productivity Enhancement Incentive (PEI) to its employees for the year 2020. This incentive is meant to reward employees for their hard work and improve government productivity. The total amount for the PEI is PhP 46,240,000, which will be sourced from savings within the city's budget. All regular, casual, and contractual employees of the city government are eligible for this bonus.

ORDINANCE NO. 8710

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING THE AMOUNT OF THIRTY MILLION PESOS (PhP 30,000,000.00) FOR FOOD ASSISTANCE TO COVID-19 AFFECTED HOUSEHOLDS IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, under Section 4(q) of the "Bayanihan to Recover As One Act", Republic Act No. 11494, One Billion Five Hundred Million Pesos (PhP 1,500,000,000.00) was appropriated to the Local Government Support Fund (LGSF) to provide financial assistance to Local Government Units (LGUs) in their local anti-COVID efforts;

WHEREAS, the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) issued Local Budget Circular No. 128, S. 2020, to prescribe the guidelines and procedures on the release and utilization of the LGSF-COVID-19 Financial Assistance to LGUs (LGSF-COVID-19 FA to LGUs) consistent with the "Bayanihan to Recover As One Act, RA No. 11494";

WHEREAS, the amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) has been released to the City of Manila for food assistance to COVID-19 affected households from the LGSF-COVID-19 FA to LGUs as per DBM letter dated November 27, 2020;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991, states that: "Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants" (Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, the same Code provides that all budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the Sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources (Section 321 of Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 25, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on December 4, 2020, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND THE ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR THE FOOD ASSISTANCE TO COVID-19 AFFECTED HOUSEHOLD IN THE CITY OF MANILA:"

NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. APPROPRIATIONS
The amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated for food assistance to COVID-19 affected households under the Welfare Goods Expenses of the Manila Department of Social Welfare pursuant to Local Budget Circular No. 128, S. 2020, regarding the LGSF-COVID-19 Financial Assistance to LGUs consistent with the "Bayanihan to Recover As One Act", RA No. 11494.

SEC. 2. SOURCE OF FUNDS
The source of funds for the food assistance in the total amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) shall be derived from funds released by the National Government to the City of Manila, which are actually available.

SEC. 3. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE
This ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 7, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance allocates PhP 30,000,000 for food assistance to households affected by COVID-19 in Manila. The funding comes from a national government program under the "Bayanihan to Recover As One Act," which supports local governments in their COVID-19 response efforts. This funding will be used to provide food aid to help families facing difficulties during the pandemic, ensuring the welfare of the city's residents.

ORDINANCE NO. 8709

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING VARIOUS ADMINISTRATIVE POSITIONS IN THE STA. ANA HOSPITAL BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM AND REPLACING THE SAME ABOLISHED POSITIONS WITH NEW PLANTILLA ITEMS OF ONE (1) MEDICAL SPECIALIST I, FOUR (4) MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIST I, AND TWO (2) RESPIRATORY THERAPIST I UNDER THE APPROVED FY 2021 PERSONNEL SCHEDULE, TO HELP AUGMENT ITS MANPOWER SHORTAGE DUE TO THE OPENING OF THE MANILA MOLECULAR TESTING LABORATORY IN RESPONSE TO THE CONTAIN AND DELAY PROGRAM OF THE CITY AGAINST THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

PRINCIPAL AUTHORS:
HON. LUCIANO M. VELOSO, HON. LOUISITO N. CHUA, HON. SCIENCE A. REYES, HON. LEILANI MARIE H. LACUNA, HON. NUMERO G. LIM, HON. PAMELA "FA" G. FUGOSO-PASCUAL, HON. TIMOTHY OLIVER I. ZARCAL, HON. SALVADOR PHILIP H. LACUNA, HON. JOEL "JTV" VILLANUEVA, HON. TERRENCE F. ALIBARBAR, HON. ERNESTO G. DIONISIO, HON. JOEL R. CHUA (Majority Floor Leader), and HON. ERNESTO C. ISIP, JR. (President Pro-Tempore and Acting Presiding Officer)

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this Draft Ordinance can be found in Section 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: "In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of the Code and the Civil Service Law, rules and regulations";

WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program, composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC, in May 12, 2006, came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following:
(a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Retitling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions, whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions are created, provided there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;

WHEREAS, Sta. Ana Hospital has certified that the abolished positions are vacant and unnecessary, while the positions being created will help in the operation and accreditation of the Manila Molecular Testing Laboratory (MMTL) by the City of Manila in partnership with the Ayala Group of Companies;

WHEREAS, this new service offered by Sta. Ana Hospital will significantly boost Manila's efforts to contain and delay the spread of the COVID-19 virus by increasing the City's mass testing capacity using the gold standard RT-PCR testing tool;

WHEREAS, the generative savings from the abolished positions will help cover the cost of funding the seven (7) new plantilla items under the MTTL, and the total amount for Personal Services, including the created positions, will not exceed the 45% statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation;

NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, that:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability. The City and its instrumentalities must promote the focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling down, phasing out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions
The following positions are hereby abolished under Sta. Ana Hospital:


Table :

NUMBER: 1

TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide VI

SALARY GRADE:11-1
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2021 (PER ANNUM): PhP186,288.00 , PhP372,576.00


Total Number: 10
Total Authorized Rate : PhP 2,359,500.00


SEC. 3. New Plantilla Positions
The following new plantilla positions are hereby created under Sta. Ana Hospital:


TITLE OF POSITION: Medical Specialist I
NUMBER:1

AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2021 (PER ANNUM):PhP. 802,404.00

Total Number: 7
Total Authorized Rate: PhP 2,358,828.00

SEC. 4. Qualifications, Powers, and Duties/Responsibilities
The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. Appointment
The employment and appointment of individuals for the aforementioned positions shall be in accordance with the qualification standards and guidelines set by the CSC and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 6. Appropriation
The amount necessary for the creation of the seven (7) new positions shall be sourced from available funds of the abolished ten (10) positions and incorporated into the FY 2021 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the plantilla of personnel of Sta. Ana Hospital.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 3, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance eliminates ten administrative positions at Sta. Ana Hospital and replaces them with seven new positions (one Medical Specialist I, four Medical Technologist I, and two Respiratory Therapist I). The decision is made to address the hospital’s manpower shortage due to the opening of the Manila Molecular Testing Laboratory (MMTL) in support of the city's COVID-19 containment efforts. The savings from the abolished positions will fund the creation of these critical new roles. The new positions aim to enhance the city’s capacity for mass testing and improve public health services during the pandemic.

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING VARIOUS ADMINISTRATIVE POSITIONS IN THE OFFICE OF THE CITY ACCOUNTANT (OCAT) BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM AND REPLACING THE SAME ABOLISHED POSITIONS WITH NEW PLANTILLA ITEMS OF FIVE (5) ACCOUNTANT II AND FIVE (5) ACCOUNTANT III POSITIONS UNDER THE APPROVED FY 2020 PERSONNEL SCHEDULE

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the legal basis of this draft Ordinance can be found in Section 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states:

"In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations";

WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program, composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC, in May 12, 2006, issued Resolution No. 1, which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions the following:
(a) Abolition of positions,
(b) Conversion of positions,
(c) Reclassification of positions,
(d) Re-titling of positions, and
(e) Creation of positions, whereby the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions are created, as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions that can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;

WHEREAS, the proponent, the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT), has certified that the collapsed items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary, while the positions being created will help augment its accounting and auditing services in furtherance of its mandate;

WHEREAS, the generated savings from the scrapped positions will help cover the computed amount needed to fund the ten (10) Accountant positions, and that the total amount for Personal Services, including the created positions, will not exceed the 45% statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation:

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability, and affordability. The City and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling down, phasing out, or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Abolished Plantilla Positions
The following positions are hereby abolished under the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT):

The following table:    
TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Assistant II
NUMBER: 4
ITEM #: 60,64,109 and 128
SALARY GRADE: 8-1
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 PER ANNUM: PhP. 201,096.00, PhP. 804,384.00


TITLE OF POSITION:Administrative Aide VI
NUMBER: 14
ITEM #:14,23,114-117,131,134-136 and 147-150
SALARY GRADE:6-1
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 PER ANNUM: PhP. 178,164.00 , PhP. 2,494,296.00

TITLE OF POSITION: Administrative Aide IV
NUMBER: 9
ITEM #: 26, 67,68,91,118,137,151,152 and 160
SALARY GRADE: 4-1
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 PER ANNUM: PhP. 158,568.00 , PhP. 1,427,112.00

TOTAL NUMBER : 27
TOTAL AUTHORIZED RATE: 4,725,792.00


SEC. 3. New Plantilla Positions
The following new Plantilla Items are hereby created under the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT):


TITLE OF POSITION: Accountant III
NUMBER:5
ITEM#: 4,36,88,112 and 126
SALARY GRADE:19-1
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 PER ANNUM:

TITLE OF POSITION: Accountant II
NUMBER:5
ITEM#:90,91,114,127 and 139
SALARY GRADE:16-1
AUTHORIZED RATE FY 2020 PER ANNUM:

TOTAL NUMBER: 10
TOTAL AUTHORIZED RATE : PhP 4,731,180.00



SEC. 4. Qualifications, Powers, and Duties/Responsibilities
The qualifications, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant laws.

SEC. 5. Appointment
The employment and appointment of the individuals for the herein subject positions shall be within the qualification standards and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 6. Appropriation
The amount necessary for the creation of five (5) Accountant III and five (5) Accountant II positions shall be sourced from available funds of the existing twenty-seven (27) administrative positions to be abolished for this purpose, as provided for under the 2020 Executive Budget. Thereafter, the herein subject positions shall be automatically funded through the succeeding Annual City Budget as part of the Plantilla of personnel of the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT).

SEC. 7. Effectivity
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 3, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance removes outdated administrative positions from the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT) and replaces them with ten new accounting positions (five Accountant II and five Accountant III). This shift follows the government’s scrap-and-build policy, where unused or unnecessary positions are abolished to fund the creation of more relevant roles. By doing so, OCAT aims to improve its accounting and auditing services. The funds saved from the abolished roles will cover the salaries of the newly created positions, ensuring a more efficient use of the city’s resources without exceeding the budget limits.

ORDINANCE NO. 8707
AN ORDINANCE CONVERTING ITEM NO. 192, WITH POSITION TITLE CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER V IN THE CITY GENERAL SERVICES OFFICE (CGSO) THROUGH THE SCRAP-AND-BUILD PROGRAM UNDER THE GOVERNMENT'S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM AND CREATING ITEM NO. 3, WITH POSITION TITLE ATTORNEY IV UNDER THE SAME OFFICE

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 325(d) of the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that:

"In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules, and regulations" (Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, on 12 May 2006, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program, composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and the Civil Service Commission (CSC), issued Resolution No. 1, providing that the scrap-and-build policy must be observed when new positions are to be created, as long as there are corresponding obsolete or unnecessary but funded positions which can be abolished to support the creation of new ones;

WHEREAS, the generated savings from the abolished positions shall not be less than the computed amount needed to fund the created positions and that the total amount for Personal Services, including the new positions, will not exceed the 45% statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation:

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in special session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Conversion of the Abolished Position.
Item No. 192, with position title Chief Administrative Officer V in the City General Services Office (CGSO), is hereby scrapped and converted to Item No. 3, with position title Attorney IV, through the Scrap-and-Build Program under the same office:

short_text: This ordinance removes a high-level administrative position (Chief Administrative Officer V) from the City General Services Office and replaces it with a new legal position—Attorney IV—under the same office. The move ensures compliance with budget limits and civil service rules, and reflects the city's need for more legal expertise in managing its operations.

ORDINANCE NO. 8706
AN ORDINANCE AUGMENTING THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES (MOOE) OF THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR – PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT SERVICE OFFICE IN THE AMOUNT OF FOURTEEN MILLION TWO HUNDRED FIFTY-ONE THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED FORTY PESOS (PhP 14,251,440.00) TO FUND THE FACE MASK PRODUCTION PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA THROUGH SAVINGS FROM THE MOOE ACCOUNTS OF VARIOUS DEPARTMENTS/OFFICES UNDER THE FY 2020 ANNUAL BUDGET

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the 1987 Constitution provides that the State shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health, and other social services available to all the people at affordable cost, prioritizing among others the underprivileged, women, and children (Section 11, Article XIII, 1987 Philippine Constitution);

WHEREAS, consistent with the Constitution, the City Government of Manila has espoused programs and projects for the benefit and welfare of the underprivileged, women, and children of Manila. It has likewise initiated programs to promote the safety of its citizenry and the general public;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991 states that:

"Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants."
(Section 16, Republic Act No. 7160)

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that all budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive shall have submitted the executive budget to the Sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources (Section 321, R.A. No. 7160);

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code also provides that:

"The local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations."
(Section 321, Republic Act No. 7160)

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 24, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on 20 November 2020, entitled:

“A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 BY AUGMENTING THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES (MOOE) OF THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR – PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT SERVICE OFFICE IN THE AMOUNT OF FOURTEEN MILLION TWO HUNDRED FIFTY-ONE THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED FORTY PESOS (PhP 14,251,440.00) TO FUND THE FACE MASK PRODUCTION PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA.”

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Augmentation
The amount of Fourteen Million Two Hundred Fifty-One Thousand Four Hundred Forty Pesos (PhP 14,251,440.00) shall be used to augment the MOOE account of the Office of the Mayor – Public Employment Service Office to implement the Face Mask Production Program of the City of Manila, as follows:


Office of the Mayor - MOOE : Other Supplies and Materials Expenses
AMOUNT: 11,751,000.00
Office of the Mayor - MOOE : Other General Services
AMOUNT: 2,500,440.00
TOTAL : PhP 14,251,440.00

SEC. 2. Source of Funds
The source of funds for this augmentation shall be derived from savings from the various MOOE accounts of the following departments/offices, in the total amount of PhP 14,251,440.00, as detailed below:


Department/Office: Office of the Mayor
MOOE: Various accounts
Amount: PhP 7,198,090.00

Department/Office: Department of Public Services
MOOE: Rent Expenses
Amount: 7,053,350.00

Total:PhP 14,251,440.00


SEC. 3. Separability Clause
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions not affected shall remain valid and in force.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 26, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to reallocate PhP 14,251,440.00 from the existing budgets of the Office of the Mayor and the Department of Public Services to fund a Face Mask Production Program during the COVID-19 pandemic. The funds will be used for materials and general services needed to manufacture face masks, which are essential for public health and safety. The program will be handled by the Public Employment Service Office (PESO) under the Mayor's Office, aligning with national health mandates to make protective goods accessible and affordable, especially for underprivileged residents. This also creates employment opportunities while helping prevent the spread of disease.

ORDINANCE NO. 8705

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8667 ON THE GRANT OF COVID-19 HAZARD PAY IN THE AMOUNT OF FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PhP 500.00) PER DAY FOR THE MANILA CITY GOVERNMENT PERSONNEL WHO PHYSICALLY REPORTED FOR WORK DURING THE PERIOD OF IMPLEMENTATION OF AN ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE RELATIVE TO THE COVID-19 OUTBREAK PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER NO. 26, S. 2020, AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES



PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Administrative Order (A.O.) No. 26, s. 2020 authorized the grant of COVID-19 Hazard Pay to government personnel who physically reported for work during the implementation of an Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) in their respective workstations in an amount not exceeding Five Hundred Pesos (PhP 500.00) per day per person;

WHEREAS, Budget Circular No. 2020-1 dated March 24, 2020 provided the guidelines on the grant of the COVID-19 Hazard Pay;

WHEREAS, the aforesaid issuances provided that the grant of COVID-19 Hazard Pay for employees in Local Government Units shall be determined by their respective Sanggunians subject to prescribed conditions, chargeable against the FY 2020 local government funds;

WHEREAS, the City of Manila promulgated Ordinance No. 8667, which authorized the payment of COVID-19 Hazard Pay at PhP 500/day for Manila City Government personnel who physically reported for work during the ECQ in the total amount of One Hundred Fifty-One Million Pesos (PhP 151,000,000.00);

WHEREAS, during the payout of the COVID-19 Hazard Pay, it was determined that some qualified Manila City Government personnel were inadvertently not included or there were errors in the report for funding of the Hazard Pay. Examples of these are: detailed employees who were not reported by their mother units nor by the offices where they were assigned due to lack of or miscommunication, or when personnel were reported under MOOE but should be under PS;

WHEREAS, the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) posted on its website (https://www.dbm.gov.ph) the Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) on the Grant of the COVID-19 Hazard Pay and COVID-19 Special Risk Allowance, which clarified that:

"For purposes of granting the COVID-19 Hazard Pay and/or COVID-19 SRA, one (1) working day may be considered equivalent to up to eight (8) working hours, depending on the prescribed official working hours of an agency. For agencies/hospitals adopting a 12-hour or 24-hour shift as their prescribed official working hours on a regular basis during the ECQ, the rate will be adjusted proportionately."

WHEREAS, in view of the foregoing, there is a need for additional funds for the payment of COVID-19 Hazard Pay for qualified personnel who were not included in the initial report for funding, as well as for the proportionate rate adjustment for personnel under the Manila Health Department and the six city hospitals which adopted a 12-hour or 24-hour shift as official working hours pursuant to the aforementioned clarification under the DBM FAQs;

WHEREAS, Section 336 of Republic Act No. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that the local chief executive or the presiding officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their respective appropriations;

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 23, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on 23 November 2020, entitled:

"A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM AND ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 IN CONNECTION WITH THE GRANT OF FIVE HUNDRED PESOS COVID-19 HAZARD PAY UNDER CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8667 TO QUALIFIED PERSONNEL OF THE CITY GOVERNMENT WHO WERE UNABLE TO RECEIVE THEIR COVID-19 HAZARD PAY AND DUE TO THE PROPORTIONATE RATE ADJUSTMENT FOR PERSONNEL UNDER THE HEALTH SECTOR WHICH ADOPTED A 12 OR 24-HOUR SHIFT AS OFFICIAL WORKING HOUR."

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. COVID-19 Hazard Pay.
In addition to the provisions of Ordinance No. 8667, the rate for the COVID-19 Hazard Pay under the Manila Health Department and the six City Hospitals which adopted a 12-hour or 24-hour shift as their prescribed official working hours on a regular basis during the ECQ shall be proportionately adjusted as follows:


"Hours Per Shift: 8
Rate Equivalent: 1

"Hours Per Shift: 12
Rate Equivalent: 1.5


"Hours Per Shift: 16
Rate Equivalent: 2


"Hours Per Shift: 24
Rate Equivalent: 3

In case the previously paid-out amount is higher than the herein prescribed rate equivalent, no cash refund shall be made by the personnel concerned and such excess amount shall be considered as payment of unpaid hazard pay, other benefits, or compensation of said personnel.

SEC. 2. Augmentation and Fund Sources.
The total additional funds in the amount of Eight Million Six Hundred Fifty-Two Thousand Nine Hundred Twenty-Three Pesos (PhP 8,652,923.00) for the grant of the COVID-19 Hazard Pay shall be charged against the following sources:

a. Personal Services (PS)
For personnel occupying regular, contractual, or casual positions, the total amount of Six Million Five Hundred Eighteen Thousand Six Hundred Seventy-Three Pesos (PhP 6,518,673.00) shall be funded by way of augmentation of the Non-Office Account, Special Activities Fund (SAF) - PS from PS savings of various departments/offices/bureaus;

b. Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE)
The total amount of Two Million One Hundred Thirty-Four Thousand Two Hundred Fifty Pesos (PhP 2,134,250.00) for contract of service and job order workers, other professionals, and consultants shall be funded by way of augmentation of the Non-Office Account, SAF - MOOE from MOOE savings of various departments/offices/bureaus.

Attached are the following details:

Annex A – Declaration of Savings under PS and MOOE for Augmentation of Funds

Annex B – Budgetary Requirement for COVID-19 Hazard Pay under the SAF - PS and SAF - MOOE

SEC. 3. Separability Clause.
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 26, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance updates the previous rule (Ordinance No. 8667) about giving COVID-19 Hazard Pay to city government workers in Manila who physically went to work during the Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ). Originally, each eligible employee received PhP 500 per workday. However, some qualified workers were accidentally left out, and adjustments were needed for employees—especially healthcare workers—who worked longer shifts (12 to 24 hours). This amended ordinance provides additional funding and allows proportional hazard pay based on actual hours worked. For example, those who worked 12-hour shifts will receive 1.5 times the daily rate. The city will use savings from its 2020 budget to pay the additional PhP 8.6 million needed for this. No one will be required to return any extra amount they previously received. This aims to ensure fair and complete compensation for the risks city employees took during the COVID-19 outbreak.

short_text: This ordinance approves the allocation of PhP 134,190,900.00 to fund several important infrastructure projects in Manila. The funds will be used for improvements such as land development, building new public facilities, and enhancing existing health centers. Specifically, the money will go toward land improvements (like parks or plazas), infrastructure upgrades, new buildings, hospitals, and other vital equipment for public use. The money for these projects will come from the sale of government-owned property. This effort is part of Manila's ongoing initiative to improve public services and make the city a better place to live.

GENERAL PROVISION
SEC. 2. Budgetary Requirements. – The budgetary expenditures imposed shall comply with the following requirements:
(a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions, nor create new positions, without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.
(b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, the use of which requires a separate Ordinance.
(c) The appropriation of the Non-Office Account, being a contingency fund or back-up fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed by the different departments to finish certain programs/projects that were not sufficiently funded, cannot be utilized without a specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Committee on Appropriations for approval.
(d) The payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of the barangay chairman attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted. Garbage hauling services shall be contracted out to one or more companies as recommended by the Department of Public Services to ensure efficient and timely collection of garbage.
(e) As an additional funding source, any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee on Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee for authority to the Mayor to dispose of the same through public bidding.
(f) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solution and detergents) using City Government funds shall conform with Republic Act No. 9003, otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000, Republic Act No. 8749, and Republic Act No. 9275, otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence, products to be procured shall be limited to organic, biodegradable or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco-Labelling Program of Green Choice Philippines.
(g) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons with Disability under Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons, before the release of any payment.

SEC. 3. General Limitations.
(a) The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for FY 2021 shall not exceed forty-five percent (45%) of the total annual income sources realized in the next preceding fiscal year;
(b) No official or employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher than the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank as determined by applicable laws, rules and regulations;
(c) No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as may be expressly authorized by law;
(d) In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Local Government Code and the Civil Service Law, rules and regulations;
(e) Positions in the official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbents holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations;
(f) No changes in designation or nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed except when the position is actually vacant and filling of such position shall be strictly made in accordance with Civil Service Law, rules and regulations; and
(g) The annual appropriation for discretionary purposes of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipts derived from basic real property tax in the next preceding year.

SEC. 4. Itemization of Personal Services and Other Personnel. – The itemization of Personal Services and Other General Services as submitted by the City Budget Office in support of the appropriation herein authorized forms part of this Ordinance and shall be strictly implemented and shall be covered by its provisions. Such appropriations shall be programmed and used for the twelve-month requirement of the city. It may not be disbursed to exponentially increase the number of personnel during the first semester leaving little or no fund for the second semester of the year.

SEC. 5. Intelligence Expenses. – The Intelligence/Confidential expenses provided under this Ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. Changes in the Organizational and Administrative Machinery. – All creations, conversions, transfers, abolitions and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services, Positions/Titles and Salary Grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 61 of the Department of Budget and Management.
(a) For a more responsive, efficient and effective organization within several departments and offices, creation and conversion of certain positions performing staff/technical/non-technical functions were made.
(b) Modification of Salary Grades in compliance with DBM Local Budget Circular No. 121 implementing the First Tranche of the Modified Salary Schedule for Local Government Personnel pursuant to Republic Act No. 11466.

SEC. 7. Use of Appropriated Funds. – All funds appropriated for functions, projects and activities shall be used to finance the full-year requirement of the City of Manila and shall be released exclusively for specific purposes and particular periods for which they have been authorized. Any amendment and augmentation may be made within the fiscal year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.

SEC. 8. Authority to Adjust Appropriations. – No Ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.

SEC. 9. Twenty Percent (20%) Community Development Fund. – The 20% Community Development Fund shall be strictly utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the Sangguniang Panlungsod in conformity with the Local Government Code.

SEC. 10. Twenty Percent (20%) Contingency Reserve. – Except for expenses due to public utilities, rentals, insurance premiums and food supplies expenses, a contingency reserve of 20% on the authorized 2021 appropriation for Department Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating thereon the 20% contingency reserve.

SEC. 11. Allotment of Appropriations. – For effective budgetary control, authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with the DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder:
(a) No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function, activity or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor. The Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted based on the appropriations authorized in the Budget Ordinance.
(b) A revised Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted upon approval of the Annual Executive Budget referred herein showing quarterly allotment of the whole authorized appropriations for the department/office.
(c) For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided, each fiscal year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January, April, July and October. The appropriations under this Ordinance shall be allocated, programmed and used to cover the funding requirement of the city for the whole year. Majority thereof may not be expended in the first semester to ensure availability of funds for the last semester of the year.
(d) The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer's notification and certification that the realized income is less than what is estimated in the annual/supplemental budget or that additional income is realized.
(e) An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Officer based on the recommendation made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official, the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least one week before the start of each quarter.

SEC. 12. Non-Waiver Clause. – Notwithstanding the approval of this Appropriation Ordinance by the Sangguniang Panlungsod, all contracts, disbursements and awards entered into by the City of Manila including, but not limited to, the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, Universidad de Manila and other government agencies and instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455, paragraph B, sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.

SEC. 13. Separability Clause. – If for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 14. Effectivity Clause. – This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2021.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 23, 2020.
short_text:
Ordinance No. 8702 is legislation by the City of Manila that appropriates a substantial amount of money (Php. 20,000,000,000.00) for the city's operations in the 2021 fiscal year. The funding for this appropriation comes from the city's General Fund Executive Budget and is based on the estimated revenues that the city's Local Finance Committee projects it will collect.

Essentially, this ordinance is the city's way of authorizing how it will spend its money for the year, allocating funds to various departments and offices to provide services and carry out its functions. It's important for the city's financial management and governance.

The total amount allocated for this financial aid is PhP49,805,000, which will be sourced from savings in various city department funds. This aid is intended to help workers cope with the financial strain caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

ORDINANCE NO. 8700

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE UPGRADING OF THE SALARY GRADE OF THE NURSE 1 ENTRY LEVEL POSITION IN THE MANILA HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND THE SIX (6) CITY HOSPITALS FROM SG 11 TO SG 15 AND MODIFYING THE POSITION ATTRIBUTES OF THE NEXT HIGHER NURSING POSITION TITLES PURSUANT TO REPUBLIC ACT NO. 9173 (PHILIPPINE NURSING ACT OF 2002) AND ITS IMPLEMENTING GUIDELINES UNDER DBM BUDGET CIRCULAR NO. 2020-04

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the Supreme Court of the Philippines has upheld with finality on 13 December 2019 the validity of Section 32 of Republic Act No. 9173, (otherwise known as the Philippine Nursing Act of 2002) which provides a minimum base pay of not lower than Salary Grade (SG)-15 for Nurses working in the public sector;
WHEREAS, the President, Rodrigo Roa Duterte, subjected the implementation of the salary adjustment of Nurses to the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) after the promulgation of the Supreme Court decision, which led to the issuance of DBM Budget Circular No. 2020-04 on 17 July 2020;
WHEREAS, the said Circular prescribed the Rules and Regulations on the upgrading of the entry-level Nurse I position from SG-11 to SG-15, while at the same time utilizing administrative procedures for the consequential modification of the position attributes of the next higher Nurse positions from Nurse II to Nurse VII;
WHEREAS, these necessary actions were taken by DBM in order to prevent the possibility of an unforeseen across-the-board adjustment of the SG level of all Nursing Positions, which would wreak havoc on the budgetary outlay of national and local government agencies for Personal Services in 2020 and beyond; NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in special session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to comply with the prescribed rules and regulations contained under DBM Circular No. 2020-04 regarding the upgrading of the entry-level Nurse position and modifying the position attributes of Nurse Positions.

SEC. 2. Upgrading of Entry Level Position of Nurse. — The Salary Grade of the following classes of Nurse Positions are hereby upgraded in the Manila Health Department and the six (6) City Government Hospitals, as follows:
FORMAT: POSITION — SALARY GRADE(FROM) – SALARY (TO)
POSITION TITLES — SALARY GRADE(FROM) – SALARY (TO)
1.        (Nurse I) — (11) —  (15)
2.        (Nurse II) — (15) —  (17)
3.        (Nurse III) — (17) — (19)
4.        (Nurse IV) — (19) — (20)
5.        (Nurse V) —  (20) — (22)
6.        (Nurse VI) — (22) — (24)

SEC. 3. Modifying the Position Attributes of Nurse Positions. — The position attributes of the following classes of Nurse Positions in the Manila Health Department and the six (6) City Government Hospitals are hereby modified, accordingly:
FORMAT: SALARY GRADE(FROM) – SALARY GRADE(TO)
1.        (Nurse II , 15) – (Nurse I , 15)
2.        (Nurse III , 17) – (Nurse II , 17)
3.        (Nurse IV, 19) – (Nurse III , 19)
4.        (Nurse V, 20) – (Nurse IV , 20)
5.        (Nurse VI, 22) – (Nurse V , 22)
6.        (Nurse VII, 24) – (Nurse VI , 24)
SEC. 4. Appropriation. — The amount necessary to implement this Ordinance shall be taken from existing and available funds appropriated for such purpose under the FY 2021 Executive Budget. Thereafter, all subsequent appropriations shall be integrated into the annual budget of the City of Manila.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 23, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance upgrades the entry-level salary grade of Nurse I positions in the Manila Health Department and city hospitals from Salary Grade 11 to 15, in compliance with the Philippine Nursing Act of 2002 and DBM Budget Circular No. 2020-04. It also adjusts the salary grades and position titles of higher-level nurse positions (Nurse II to Nurse VII) accordingly. Funding comes from the 2021 Executive Budget and will be included in future annual budgets.

ORDINANCE NO. 8699

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING AMNESTY FOR PAYMENTS OF ACCUMULATED
PENALTIES, INTERESTS AND SURCHARGES PERTAINING TO TRAFFIC
VIOLATIONS

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the 1987 Constitution provides that the state shall ensure the local autonomy of Local Government Units and create its own sources of revenues;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code provides that Local Government Units shall have the power to generate income and apply said resources for its sustenance and for the attainment of national development;

WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 8092, otherwise known as the Traffic Code of the City of Manila provides that the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) has the power to collect regulatory fees, fines, penalties and charges coming from traffic rule and regulation violations;

WHEREAS, the same ordinance provides that the violator shall have five days from date of violation to redeem his license which shall only be released upon presentation of Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR), and proof of payment of appropriated fines. An additional surcharge of five percent (5%) for each delay or failure to pay the appropriated fine is hereby imposed until the full amount of fine and surcharge is paid;

WHEREAS, due to the current pandemic crisis and economic challenges faced by all, the Sangguniang Panlungsod of Manila seeks to provide humanitarian consideration for the regulatory fees and compassion amongst holders of OVR Tickets with accumulated penalties;

WHEREAS, by virtue of the power of the Sangguniang Panlungsod of Manila to enact laws that will serve the best interests of the people especially in this time of crisis, the same hereby enacts this Ordinance granting amnesty for the accumulated penalties
and interests for traffic violations: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as: "AN ORDINANCE
GRANTING AMNESTY FOR PAYMENTS OF ACCUMULATED PENALTIES,
INTERESTS AND SURCHARGES PERTAINING TO TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS",

SEC. 2. Coverage. — This amnesty is applicable to all constituents of Manila and all others whose licenses are confiscated by the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) or any commissioned officer authorized by the City of Manila.

SEC. 3. Amnesty Grant. — An amnesty is hereby granted to all delinquent holders of Ordinance Violation Receipts (OVRs) or those with accumulated penalties, interests and surcharges.

SEC. 4. Payment Scheme. — The accumulated penalties, interests and
surcharges of the violation ticket shall be waived. Hence, the holders of OVRs shall pay only the original amount of violation. Payments made under the amnesty shall be unconditional. Thus, payments under protest shall not be allowed.

SEC. 5. Duration. — The amnesty granted herein may be availed of within ninety (90) days from the effectivity of this Ordinance. Holders of OVRs shall avail the amnesty within the abovementioned period. Thereafter, no further amnesty shall be granted and the accumulated penalties will be paid in accordance with the original computation of the penalties, interests and surcharges.
SEC. 6. Pending Cases - Holders of OVRs with a complaint pending before the Office of the City Prosecutor or any other court shall be eligible to avail the amnesty. Those who avail the amnesty under this Section shall be exempt from criminal, civil and administrative liability arising from violation of traffic rules and regulations under Ordinance No. 8092 or the Manila Traffic Code, without prejudice to the prosecution of other violations under existing laws and ordinances, rules and regulations.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. — If, for any reason, any provisions of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — Any previously issued ordinance, or provision thereof which is inconsistent herewith is hereby repealed, revised or amended accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 23, 2020.
short_text: The City of Manila is granting a limited-time amnesty for people with unpaid traffic violation tickets. If you have an overdue Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR), you can pay only the original fine without any added penalties, interest, or surcharges. This applies even if your case is already filed in court. The amnesty period lasts for 90 days from when the ordinance took effect.
fines: Original fine must be paid; additional penalties waived during the amnesty period.

short_text: The City Council approved the transfer of PhP3,103,000 originally meant for training, building and furniture repairs, and rent into the consultancy services budget of the Mayor's Office. This fund will be used to pay the salaries of 36 additional consultants until December 31, 2020.
