ORDINANCE NO. 8697

AN ORDINANCE REGULATING THE USE AND SALE OF VAPORIZED AND
HEATED TOBACCO PRODUCTS (VHTPs) IN PUBLIC PLACES AND PUBLIC
CONVEYANCES, ADVERTISEMENTS AND PROMOTIONS, AND PROVIDING
PENALTIES THEREFORE

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the 1987 Constitution declares it the policy of the state to protect and promote the right to health consciousness among them;

WHEREAS, a wide range of vapor and heated tobacco products (VHTPs) also known as e-cigarettes, have been introduced in the Philippines and globally. They are handled products that generate a nicotine - containing aerosol without combustion;

WHEREAS, Congress enacted Senate Bill No. 2233 with differentiated excise tax roles in recognition of the clear distinction between VHTPs-consisting of vapor products and heated tobacco products - which release an aerosol that can be inhaled without burning;

WHEREAS, last July 25, 2019, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte signed into law a bill raising the excise tax on tobacco products to support the governments universal health care program. Republic Act No. 11346 will hike tobacco excise tax rates on cigarettes and impose new taxes on heated tobacco and vapor products;

WHEREAS, an emerging body of scientific evidence shows that while not risk-free, VHTPs are far less harmful due to the lack of combustion. Public Health in England stated that carcinogenic constituents of cigarette smoke that harm health are either absent in e-cigarette vapor or if present, they are mostly at levels much below five percent (5%) of smoking doses a reduced risk potential based on the reduced level of air pollution where VHTPs are used compared to conventional cigarettes;

WHEREAS, regulating VHTPs in the exact same way as cigarettes, however, would fail to acknowledge the fundamental difference between combustible and non- combustible products and their respective risk profiles. Groups such as Public Health England and the British Lung Foundation have underscored the importance of regulating VHTPs or e-cigarette products differently from cigarettes;

WHEREAS, the proliferation of illicit or non-compliant of VHTPs is a serious problem that could deprive the government of potential revenue form excise tax collections and has the effect of flooding the market with cheaper VHTPs, thereby making them more accessible to the public, especially the youth;

WHEREAS, these non-compliant VHTPs, if not eradicated may pose a threat to the health of consumers because of their substandard quality;

WHEREAS, in order to fully protect the health and welfare of the citizens of Manila and further safeguard the interests of all stakeholders, including smokers who have the right to choose less harmful alternatives to cigarettes, there is a need to pass an ordinance regulating the use of vapor and heated tobacco products in public places and conveyances, including its advertising and promotion, in line with the latest scientific studies on thus class of products: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Definitions of terms. - As used in this Ordinance:

A. Vapor and Heated Tobacco Products (VHTPs) also known as "e-cigarette" - refers to a category of products that include vapor products. Vapor products shall mean any liquid solution or gel which contains nicotine that transforms into an aerosol without combustion through the employment of a mechanical heating element, battery or circuit that can be used to heat such solution or gel, and include but is not limited to a cartridge, a tank and the device without cartridge or tank. It is commonly known as e-liquid for e-cigarette. The electronic device are used to produce an aerosol, mist or vapor that user inhale by mimicking the act of smoking. Heated tobacco products refer to tobacco products that may be consumed through heating tobacco, either electrically or through other means sufficiently to release an aerosol that can be inhaled, without burning or any combustion of the tobacco. Heated tobacco products include liquid solutions and gels that are part of the product and are heated to generate an aerosol. For purposes of this Ordinance, "VHTPs" is used interchangeably with "electronic cigarette or "e-cigarette".

B. Nicotine receptacle - shall refer to bottles, boxes, cartons, or containers of any kind in which a nicotine-containing solution or non-burning tobacco or product that can be used for the consumption of nicotine-containing vapors or Nicotine Mixtures or any related products is offered for sale to consumers for use with VHTP system.

C. Advertise - refers to any visual and/or audible message disseminated to the public about a particular product that promotes and gives publicity by words, design, images or any other means through broadcast, electronic, print or whatever forms of mass media, including outdoor advertisement, such as, but not limited to, signs and billboards. For the purpose of this Ordinance, advertisements shall be understood as VHTP or e-cigarette advertisement.

D. Advertising - refers to the business of conceptualizing, presenting, making available and communicating to the public through any form of mass media, quality or availability of consumer product, services or credit. For purposes of this Ordinance, advertising shall be understood as e-cigarette advertising. This shall specifically refer to message and images promoting VHTPs; the purchase or use of VHTPs; and VHTP or e-cigarette trademarks, brand names, design and manufacturer's names.

E. Celebrity - refers to any natural person who, by his accomplishments or fame, or by reason of his profession or calling, gives the public a legitimate interest in his doings, affairs and character. The term includes anyone who has arrived at a position where public attention is focused upon him as a person, such as, but not limited to, actors, athletes and other sports personalities, war heroes, famous investors and explorers among other.

F. Distributor refers to any person to whom VHTP product is delivered or sold for purposes of distribution in commerce, except that such term does not include a manufacturer or retailer or common carrier of such product.

G. Enclosed Area - refers to an area that is physically separated from adjacent areas by walls or partitions and a roof or ceiling. The walls or partitions must be continuous, interrupted only by doors and windows. The mere presence of a roof or ceiling over the structure, but without walls or partitions surrounding said structure, does not constitute an enclosed area.

H. Mass Media - refers to any medium of communication which reaches a mass of people. For the purpose of this Ordinance, communication designed to reach persons by private, postal or regular mail, electronic mail (e-mail), and similar means shall not be considered as mass media.

I. Minor - refers to any person below eighteen (18) years old.

J. Non-compliant VHTPs - refers to those VHTPs being sold in the domestic market but fail to comply with national laws or regulations; these may be any of the following:
a. j.1) Non-tax paid VHTPs (Products with no affixed tax stamp or without fake stamp); and
b. j.2) VHTPs without the health warnings on its labels and packages as required under national laws and/or regulations.

K. Perimeter - when used in this Ordinance in relation to sale of, and outdoor advertisements for, VHTPs, the term shall refer to any point in the boundaries as indicated in the Original Certificate of Title of Transfer Certificate of Title of the tract of land that is actually used or occupied by a public school, public playground owned by government or other facility frequented particularly by persons below eighteen (18) years old age who are or intended to be principal users or patrons of such facility, whether or not said tract of land is separated by adjacent tracks by a wall or fence.

L. Point-of-sale- refers to any location at which an individual can purchased or otherwise obtain VHTPs.

M. Premises - refers to a tract of land and the building or buildings thereon, including the open space between the buildings located on the same tract of land and within the perimeter of said tract of land.

N. Promotion - refers to an event or activity organized by or on behalf of a VHTP or e-cigarette manufacturer, distributors or retailer with the aim of promoting a brand of e-cigarette, which event or activity would not occur but for now the support given to it by or on behalf of the VHTP manufacturer, distributor or retailer. It may also refer to the display of a VHTP or manufacturer's name, trademark, logo, and the like on non-VHTP goods.

O. Public Conveyances - refers to the modes of transportation servicing the general population, such as but not limited to, elevators, airplanes, buses, taxicabs, ships, jeepneys, light rail transits, tricycles, e-trikes, pedicabs, and similar vehicles.

P. Public places - refers to enclosed or confined areas of all places of worship, hospitals, or other healthcare centers, public conveyances, government offices, and educational or recreational facilities primarily intended to minors.

Q. Vaping - refers to the act of using a VHTP where a user inhales from the device and exhales the vapor.

SEC. 2. Public Place Use. - Use of VHTPs indoor is prohibited in places of worships, hospitals, or other healthcare centers, public conveyances, and educational or recreational facilities primarily intended for minors.

SEC. 3. Designation of vaping areas. - In all enclosed places that are open to the general public, and private workplaces, and other places not covered by Section 2 of this ordinance, the owner, proprietor, operator, possessor, manager or administrator of such places shall establish vaping areas in accordance with the following standards:

3.1. Designated Vaping Areas (DVA) within the building may be in an open space or separate area with proper ventilation, but shall not be located within the same room that has been designated as a smoking area.
3.2. The owner, proprietor, operator, possessor, manager or administration shall determine the size and specifications of the vaping area and non-vaping area.
3.3 Unless the whole establishment has been designated as a vaping area, the VNA shall not be located within two (2) meters from the entrances and exits, and physically delineated from non-vaping areas.
3.4 DVAs shall have at least one (1) legible and visible sign posted, namely "VAPING AREA" for the information and guidance of all concerned. In addition, the sign or notice posted shall include a warning about the health effects of vaping in accordance with national laws and regulations. Lastly, DVAs should have a sign that states: "Minors are not allowed to use VHTPs".

Vaping shall be allowed in outdoor areas without any need for designation as vaping area.

Notwithstanding the restrictions provided in this Section 3, temporary use of VHTPs shall be allowed within the immediate vicinity of point-of-sale establishments solely for the limited purpose of testing and demonstrating the proper use of VHTPs.

SEC. 4. VHTP/electronic cigarette ban in public conveyances: exception. Notwithstanding the absolute ban on vaping in public conveyances mentioned in Section 2, the prohibition does not apply to inter-island vessels where vaping areas have been designated.

SEC. 5. Minimum Age Sales. - Under this Ordinance, it shall be unlawful:

a. For any retailer to sell or distribute VHTPs to minor.
b. To purchase VHTPs from a minor.
c. For minors to sell VHTPs.
d. For minors to purchase VHTPs.

SEC. 6. Sale of VHTPs within School Perimeters. - The sale or distribution of VHTPs is prohibited within one hundred (100) meters from any point of the perimeter of a school, public playground or other facility frequented particularly by minors who are intended to be the principal users of such facility.

SEC. 7. Point of Sale Display and Signage. - No point-of-Sale establishment shall display VHTPs without ensuring that the unit pockets and outside wrapping of Heated Tobacco Products, Vapor Products and other similar products are compliant with the health warnings required under national laws and regulation.

SEC. 8. Proof of Age Verification. - In case of doubt as to the age of the buyer, retailers shall verify by means of any valid form of photographic identification containing the date of birth of the bearer that the individual purchasing a VHTP is not below eighteen (18) years of age.

It shall not be a defense or distributing that he/she did not know nor had any reason to believe that the VHTP was for the consumption of the minor to whom it was sold.

SEC. 9. Advertisement Restrictions. - Printed and outdoor advertisements shall be allowed only within the premises of point-of-sale establishments regardless of whether it is visible from the outside or not. Advertisements shall likewise be allowed through direct marketing and on the internet. The following restrictions shall apply to all VHTP advertisements:

a. Advertisements shall not be aimed at or particularly appeal to persons under eighteen (18) years of age;
b. Advertisements shall not contain cartoon characters or subjects that depict humans or animals with comically exaggerated features or that attribute human or unnatural characteristics to animals, plants or other objects;
c. Advertisements shall only depict persons who are or who appear to be above twenty-five (25) years of age;
d. Advertisements shall not show, portray or depict scenes where the actual use of, act of using, or puffing of VHTPs is displayed;
e. Advertisements should not undermine quit-smoking message and encourage non-tobacco or non- nicotine users to use the product.
f. Advertisements shall not contain any information or element that is untrue or not scientifically substantiated, in particularly with regard to product characteristics, health effects, risks or emissions;
g. Promotional communications shall allow for adult consumers to learn about the availability of VHTPs, receive information about how to use them, try before purchasing, subject to proof of age and certification of smoker status, and receive pre-sale and after-sales support;
h. Advertisements shall not appear on mass media television, radio, or cinema; and
i. All allowable advertisements and promotional materials for VHTPs shall carry health warnings as required by existing laws and regulation.

SEC. 10. Punishable Acts. The following acts are punishable under this Ordinance:

a. Vaping in public places where vaping is expressly prohibited under Section 2 of this Ordinance;
b. Non-compliance with Section 3 of this Ordinance when an establishment owner requires users of VHTPs to use the same designated smoking areas, unless smoking is allowed in the entire establishment;
c. Sale of VHTP products to or by a minor;
d. Purchase of VHTP from a minor;
e. Minors to purchase VHTPs;
f. Distribution of samples of VHTP to minors;
g. Non-compliance with Section 6 of this Ordinance on selling restrictions;
h. Non-compliance with the restrictions on VHTP promotions, advertisements, and required signages at point-of-sale establishments;
i. Sale and distribution of non-compliant VHTP with fake tax stamp, or proof of payment of excise tax, as required by law or regulations; and
j. Sale and distribution of non-compliant VHTPs without health warnings, as required by law or regulations.

SEC. 11. Penalties for Violation of this Ordinance -

a. On the FIRST OFFENSE, a fine of not less than One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) but not more than One Thousand Five Hundred Pesos (PhP. 1,500.00) or one (1) day of community service shall be imposed.
b. On the SECOND OFFENSE, a fine of more than Two Thousand Five Hundred Pesos (PhP. 2,500.00) but not more than Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) or up to three (3) days of community service shall be imposed.
c. On the THIRD OFFENSE, in addition to a fine of not less than Four Thousand Pesos (PhP. 4,000.00) but not more than Six Thousand Pesos (PhP. 6,000.00) or up to Five (5) days of community service, the business permits and license to operate of the offender may be cancelled or revoked.
d. One (1) day community service shall equivalent to eight (8) hours.

SEC. 12. Community Service. - The apprehended violator who opts to render community service shall report to the City Health Officer and shall attend a seminar or training with topics relating to healthy living and activities such as clean up drives or other community development programs being implemented by the City Governance.

SEC. 13. Minor Offender. - A minor offender of this Ordinance shall be dealt with accordance with the provisions of the Republic Act No. 9344 or with the Juvenile Justice and Welfare Act of 2006.

SEC. 14. Confiscation. - VHTPs for sale and distribution association with any violation of the prohibited acts in SECTION 1 and 5 of this Ordinance shall, upon apprehension of the appropriate law enforcement agency, be subject to confiscation, removal, preservation and presentation as evidence before the appropriate court of competent jurisdiction. 

The operatives of the Manila Police District or the Special Mayor's Reaction Team, or any of their duly authorized representatives, shall issue a corresponding confiscation receipt to the owner or retailer of items confiscated. All confiscated VHTPs shall be retained in their respective custody for evidentiary purposes. After presentation in court, the confiscated items shall be subject to disposal as directed by court order or in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations, whichever applicable.

SEC. 15. Enforcement on Point-of-Sale Establishments. - Within thirty (30) calendar days after the effecting of this Ordinance, the business permits and licensing office shall conduct inspections of point-of-sale establishments to determine their compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance.

Regular inspections shall thereafter be conducted at least once a month, or at such frequency that is practicable, during normal hours of operation of the point-of-sale establishments.

SEC. 16. Civilian Participation in Enforcement. - Any person may file with the Manila task force a report or complaint for any violation of this Ordinance which report or complaint for any violation of this Ordinance which report or complaint will be promptly acted upon within five (5) working days from receipt of such report or complaint.

SEC. 17. Repealing Clause. All existing ordinances inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 18. Interpretation. - Any request for interpretation of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be referred to the City Legal Office. Any doubt in the interpretation of this Ordinance shall be construed in favor of the promotion of harm reduction.

SEC. 19. Separability Clause. Should any provision of this Ordinance be subsequently declared unconstitutional or invalid, the other provisions not affected by such declaration shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 20. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days from its Publication in at least two (2) newspapers of general or local circulation within the City of Manila, consistent with the provisions of the Local Government code.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 5, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance regulates the use, sale, and promotion of e-cigarettes and heated tobacco products (VHTPs) in Manila. It bans vaping indoors in public places like hospitals, schools, and public transportation (with some exceptions), restricts sales to minors, and prohibits selling within 100 meters of schools or playgrounds. Businesses must set up designated vaping areas and ensure proper signage and health warnings. Violations may lead to fines ranging from PhP1,000 to PhP6,000, community service, and even cancellation of business permits. Confiscated products will be used as evidence in court and disposed of accordingly.

ORDINANCE NO. 8696

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE TITLE AND CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF
ORDINANCE NO. 8676, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE IMPLEMENTING THE NO
CONTACT APPREHENSION PROGRAM (NCAP) OF THE CITY AMENDING FOR THE
PURPOSE CERTAIN SECTIONS OF CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8092 AND ORDINANCE
NO. 8327, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES"

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, City Ordinance No. 8676, entitled: "An Ordinance Implementing the No Contact Apprehension Program (NCAP) of the City Amending for the Purpose Certain Sections of City Ordinance No. 8092 and Ordinance No. 8327, and for other Purposes" took effect on October 12, 2020;

WHEREAS, Section 16 of Republic Act 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that. "Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants.";   

WHEREAS, in order to enhance the culture of traffic discipline among motorists, the City of Manila implemented a "No Contact Apprehension Program" which will provide another way of enforcing traffic rules and regulations by operating a 24-hour no contact apprehension program which is intended to instill a round-the-clock obedience to the said rules;

WHEREAS, the said Ordinance for No Contact Apprehension of traffic violators, despite having ordained and approved, demand modifications that will justify the imposition of penalties by the No Contact Apprehension Program, hence, the need to update the same becomes imperative in order to attain the objectives of the law;

WHEREAS, in order to effectively implement the City's No Contact Apprehension Program and to discourage disobedience of the law, there is a need to intensify the same;

WHEREAS, the amendment of the title, and the amendment and inclusion of some provisions that will justify the penalties to be imposed is necessary due to numerous cases of traffic violations of motorists in the city: NOW, THEREFORE,   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. - This Ordinance shall be known as the "An Ordinance Amending the Title and Certain Provisions of Ordinance No. 8676, entitled: "An Ordinance Implementing the No Contact Apprehension Program (NCAP) of the City Amending for the purpose Certain Sections of City Ordinance No. 8092 and Ordinance No. 8327, and for other Purposes".   

SEC. 2. The following provisions of Ordinance No. 8676, are hereby amended and shall now be read as follows:   

"TITLE OF ORDINANCE NO. 8676: "An Ordinance Creating the No Contact Apprehension Program of the City of Manila, otherwise known as "2020 No Contact Apprehension Program Ordinance of The City of Manila", and for other purposes."

Section 5. Traffic Rules and Regulations covered by NCAP - xxx

12. Disregarding Lane Markings
A driver should observe compliance with lane markings as may be deemed applicable to him. The said markings may be installed on the side, median, overhead, or may be painted on the road.   

Section 7. Penalty for Violation of "No Contact Apprehension Program (NCAP)"

Registered owners of vehicles found violating the provisions under this Ordinance shall be liable in accordance with the fines enumerated below:   

CODE: Section 5 (1)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Counter Flow Driving
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 3,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 4,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 5,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (2)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Disobedience to Traffic Control Signals and Signs
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 2,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 3,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 4,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (3)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Obstruction of the Pedestrian Lane
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 2,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 3,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 4,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (4)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Driving over a Yellow Box
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 2,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 3,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 4,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (5)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Over Speeding
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 2,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 3,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 4,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (6)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Reckless Driving
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 3,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 4,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 5,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (7)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Failure to Wear the Prescribed Seat Belt Device
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 3,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 4,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 5,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (8)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Failure to Use Motorcycle Helmets
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 2,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 3,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 4,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (9)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Anti-Distracted Driving
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 3,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 4,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 5,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (10)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Driving an Unregistered Vehicle
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 3,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 4,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 5,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (11)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Failure to attach or improper attachment/tampering of authorized vehicle license plate and/or third plate sticker
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 3,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 4,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 5,000.00

CODE: Section 5 (12)
TYPE OF OFFENSE/VIOLATION: Disregarding Lane Markings
FINES & PENALTIES:
1st offense: PhP 2,000.00
2nd offense: PhP 3,000.00
3rd offense: PhP 4,000.00

A Notice of Violation (NOV) shall be issued to registered owners of vehicles violating the Traffic Rules and Regulations stated in Section 5 of this Ordinance. Attached is the template of the Notice of Violation marked as "ANNEX A" to be issued to a traffic violator and shall form an integral part hereof. The Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) may change the design of the Notice of Violation from time to time as needed.   

Section 12. Repealing Clause. - Provisions of the City Ordinance No. 8092 and Ordinance No. 8327, insofar as inconsistent herewith and all other existing ordinances, executive orders and administrative regulations or part of parts thereof which are inconsistent with any provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly."    

SEC. 3. Separability Clause. If for any reason, a part of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. All existing ordinances, executive orders and administrative regulations or part of parts thereof which are inconsistent with any provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.   

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 5, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance amends Ordinance No. 8676 to strengthen and clarify the implementation of Manila’s No Contact Apprehension Program (NCAP), which enforces traffic laws using 24/7 surveillance without direct police interaction. It renames the ordinance as the “2020 No Contact Apprehension Program Ordinance of the City of Manila” and adds more explicit provisions for traffic violations, including failure to follow lane markings and use of helmets or seat belts. Registered vehicle owners are held liable for offenses. A schedule of escalating fines (from PHP 2,000 to PHP 5,000) is introduced for 12 specific violations such as counterflow driving, over speeding, and distracted driving. The ordinance also updates the format and function of the Notice of Violation (NOV).

Covered Violations & Fines:

Counterflow Driving – PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000 / PHP 5,000
Disobedience to Traffic Signals – PHP 2,000 / PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000
Blocking Pedestrian Lane – PHP 2,000 / PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000
Driving Over Yellow Box – PHP 2,000 / PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000
Over Speeding – PHP 2,000 / PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000
Reckless Driving – PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000 / PHP 5,000
Not Wearing Seat Belt – PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000 / PHP 5,000
No Motorcycle Helmet – PHP 2,000 / PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000
Distracted Driving – PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000 / PHP 5,000
Unregistered Vehicle – PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000 / PHP 5,000
Tampered/No License Plate or Sticker – PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000 / PHP 5,000
Disregarding Lane Markings – PHP 2,000 / PHP 3,000 / PHP 4,000

ORDINANCE NO. 8694

AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE MEASURE APPROVING THE UPDATED AND FINAL ZONING/LAND USE PLAN, LAND ALLOCATION PLAN AND THE FINAL MASTER DEVELOPMENT PLAN OF HORIZON MANILA RECLAMATION PROJECT 

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, HORIZON MANILA is a 406-hectare high-value and high-density
development that will rise in Manila Bay within the territorial waters of the City of Manila. Its 3-island landform will be the platform interlinked with urban parks and waterways reminiscent of Manila’s past waterways and riverside development but with a modern and green touch;

WHEREAS, the Project Area shall be as defined and limited to the metes and bounds as stipulated in the attached technical description submitted to the City Government of Manila for approval;

WHEREAS, the first three (3) islands is about three and a half kilometers west of the Manila Yacht Club, followed by the next two islands. Two-sixty meter wide water channels separate the three islands to provide for additional waterfronts accessible to the
public and to flush out stagnant water around the entire development;

WHEREAS, HORIZON MANILA's ground surface will be at a minimum of four (4) meters above sea level. It will be higher than most of the coastal areas of the City of Manila. The perimeter of the islands will be protected by revetment or sea wall of rocks and boulders. This will protect the islands from strong waves and storm surges and ensure that they will not be eroded back to the sea;

WHEREAS, around ninety (90) million cubic meters of filling materials will be required to reclaim HORIZON MANILA. It will be sourced from sea bed quarries within Manila Bay. This is to prevent the entry of materials from inland quarries that might pollute the Bay. The use of inland sources is not encouraged because it will require thousands
of trucks that will further congest the traffic and damage the city roads. The filling materials will be selected and compacted to address the concerns on earthquake and liquefaction;

WHEREAS, HORIZON MANILA will be highly accessible to its residents and the general public. A dedicated iconic skyway from Quirino Avenue will provide fast and direct access to HORIZON MANILA. There will be bridge interconnections with the neighboring developments as mandated by the government. A city-wide monorail system is planned to interconnect with HORIZON MANILA’s own people mover system. It will enhance its
accessibility. Sufficient utility infrastructure will be provided to be responsive to the requirements of the development. Water, power and telecommunications will be assured in HORIZON MANILA. Green Technology will be employed where applicable and practical: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session duly assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “HORIZON MANILA RECLAMATION PROJECT” for brevity.

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. — It is the policy of the city to pursue developmental projects and towards this end the reclamation of a specific area based on the specifications submitted by the proponent JBROS Construction Corporation and within the limits and  specifications set forth by competent authorities is hereby authorized.

SEC. 3. Scope of Reclamation. — The Updated and Final Zoning/Land Use Plan, Land Allocation Plan and the Master Plan submitted by the proponent shall define the scope of the reclamation project.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.
This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
October 26, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance approves the updated zoning, land use, and master development plans for the Horizon Manila reclamation project—a 406-hectare development composed of three artificial islands in Manila Bay. The project will feature parks, waterways, green technology, and modern infrastructure including a skyway, monorail, and utility systems. The city supports this large-scale project led by JBROS Construction Corporation as part of Manila’s urban development goals.

ORDINANCE NO. 8692

AN ORDINANCE FURTHERMORE AMENDING SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO.
8616, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8647, BY IMPOSING THE CURFEW FOR
ALL PERSONS EXCEPT MINORS IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM TWELVE MIDNIGHT (12:00 AM) TO FOUR O'CLOCK IN THE MORNING (4:00 AM) UNTIL 30 NOVEMBER 2020, AND FROM TWELVE MIDNIGHT (12:00 AM) TO THREE O'CLOCK IN THE  MORNING (3:00 AM) STARTING 1 DECEMBER 2020
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on 08 March 2020, the President issued Presidential Proclamation No. 922, declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to Covid-19. The declaration of a State of Public Health Emergency enjoins all government agencies and LGUs to undertake critical, urgent and appropriate responses and measures in a timely manner to curtail the spread of the Covid-19;

WHEREAS, on 14 March 2020, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8616 imposing curfew from Eight O'clock in the evening (8:00 pm) to Five O'clock in the morning (5:00 am) during the imposition of community quarantine pursuant to the resolution of the Metro Manila Council in response to the community quarantine declared
by his Excellency, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte;

WHEREAS, on 15 June 2020, President Duterte approved the Inter Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Disease (IATF) Resolution No. 46-A which placed the City of Manila under a General Community Quarantine;

WHEREAS, with reference to the declaration of the IATF, the City Council of Manila enacted Ordinance No. 8647, amending Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8616, by imposing curfew from Ten O'clock in the evening (10:00 pm) to Five O'clock in the morning (5:00 am);

WHEREAS, on September 16, 2020, the President issued Proclamation No. 1021, (S. 2020) extending the period of the State of Calamity throughout the Philippines due to COVID-19 declared under Proclamation No. 929;

WHEREAS, on 15 October 2020, the President approved IATF Resolution No. 79 recommending, among others, the relaxation curfew hours imposed by local government units (LGUs) in connection with the pandemic unless called for by the COVID-19 situation in their respective jurisdictions;

WHEREAS, such recommendation is based on the approved proposals of the
Economic Development Cluster on the gradual expansion of business operations to stimulate and sustain economic gains;

WHEREAS, despite the gradual relaxation of curfew hours, quarantine and social distancing protocols within the City of Manila will remain to be enforced in accordance with the IATF Guidelines;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that, “Every local
government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied, therefrom as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general
welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to balanced ecology, encourage and
support the development of appropriate and self-reliant, scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morale, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants” (Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160):
NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT

SECTION 1. Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8616 as amended by Ordinance
No 8647, is hereby furthermore amended and shall now be read as follows:

“SECTION. 1. Imposition of Curfew Hours; Covered Persons. —

1. The curfew hours is hereby imposed for all persons except minors in the City of Manila from Twelve Midnight (12:00 am) to Four O'clock in the morning (4:00 am) until November 30,2020.

2. The curfew hours is hereby imposed for all persons except
minors in the City of Manila from Twelve Midnight (12:00 am)
to Three O’clock in the morning (3:00 am) starting December
1, 2020.”

SEC. 2. Ordinance No. 8547, imposing curfew for all minors in the City of Manila from Ten O'clock in the evening (10:00 pm) until Four in the morning (4:00 am) and Ordinance No. 8243, imposing penalties therefor shall still be strictly enforced

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
October 19, 2020
short_text: This ordinance adjusts the curfew hours for all persons except minors in the City of Manila. From October 19 to November 30, 2020, curfew is from 12:00 AM to 4:00 AM. Starting December 1, 2020, the curfew is shortened to 12:00 AM to 3:00 AM. It does not affect curfew regulations for minors, which remain at 10:00 PM to 4:00 AM under Ordinance Nos. 8547 and 8243.
fines: curfew enforcement only; penalties governed by other ordinances

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the legal basis of this draft Ordinance can be found in Sec. 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states: “In cases of abolition of the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules and regulations;”

WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC in May 12, 2006 came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions among the following, (a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Retitling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions where the scrap-and-build policy needs to be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;

WHEREAS, the generated savings from the scrapped positions will be more than enough to cover the computed amount needed to fund the created positions and the amount for Personal Services, including new positions, will not exceed the 45% statutory limitation on the total approved annual appropriation. NOW, THEREFORE:

ORDINANCE NO. 8690

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING SEVEN HUNDRED SIXTY-FOUR MILLION
NINE HUNDRED TWENTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 764,925,000.00) AS
SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 18 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2020 FOR THE VARIOUS
SOCIO-ECONOMIC PROGRAMS AND INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS OF THE CITY
OF MANILA AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on 8 March 2020 Presidential Proclamation No. 922, s. 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sublevel Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases. 

In view of the continuing rise of confirmed cases of COVID-19, the serious threat to the health, safety, security, and lives of our countrymen, the long-term adverse effects on their means of livelihood, and the severe disruption of economic activities, a state of national emergency is hereby declared over the entire country;

WHEREAS, said Presidential Proclamations enjoined all government agencies and Local Government Units (LGUs) to render full assistance to and cooperation with each other and mobilize the necessary resources to undertake critical, urgent, and appropriate disaster response aid and measures in a timely manner to curtail and eliminate the threat of COVID-19;

WHEREAS, no less than the 1987 Constitution provides that the state shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health and other social services available to all the people at affordable cost and prioritizing, among others, the underprivileged, women and children (Section 11, Article XIII, 1987 Philippine Constitution);

WHEREAS, likewise, the Constitution upholds the conservation, promotion and popularization of the nation's historical and cultural heritage and resources, as well as the right of the people to a balanced and healthful ecology in accord with the rhythm and harmony of nature (Section 15, Article XIV and Section 16, Article II, 1987 Philippine Constitution);

WHEREAS, consistent with the Constitution, the City Government of Manila has espoused programs and projects for the benefit and welfare of the underprivileged, the women and the children of Manila. It has likewise initiated programs to conserve and promote Manila's cultural heritage, and promoted safety by improving public infrastructures;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991, states that: "Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants" (Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160).

WHEREAS, the same Code provides that all budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources. (Section 321 par 1 of Republic Act No 7160),

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 19, Series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on October 9, 2020, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020, TO COVER THE VARIOUS SOCIO- ECONOMIC PROGRAMS AND INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEVEN HUNDRED SIXTY-FOUR MILLION NINE HUNDRED TWENTY-FIVE THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 764,925,000.00)": NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8689

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF ORDINANCE NO. 8619,
ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE INSTITUTIONALIZING THE CITY IDENTIFICATION
SYSTEM TO ALL RESIDENTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA AND BE KNOWN AS MANILA
RESIDENT IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM (MRIS), AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES"
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, City Ordinance No. 8619, entitled: “AN ORDINANCE
INSTITUTIONALIZING THE CITY IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM TO ALL RESIDENTS IN
THE CITY OF MANILA AND BE KNOWN AS MANILA RESIDENT IDENTIFICATION
SYSTEM (MRIS), AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES’ was passed into law on March 14,2020;

WHEREAS, the aforementioned identification system aims to speed up and
simplify processing of documents such as clearances, certifications, permits, licenses, tax payments and others as the information of the constituents in the city are readily available in the data information system;

WHEREAS, in order to properly implement the said Ordinance, certain provisions shall be amended to specify its primary implementing body, and the material to be used for the identification cards: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 6 of Ordinance No. 8619 is hereby amended and shall now read as follows:

“Sec. 6. One City ID Card Policy. — Every resident shall possess only
one Manila Resident information System card which may be a physical
card or virtual card.

SEC. 2. Section 7 of Ordinance no. 8619 is hereby amended and shall now read as follows:

“Sec. 7. Issuance of a Manila Resident Identification System Card.
— All residents of the city, as certified by the validating office designated, shall be issued, upon clearance, an MRIS card bearing the name of the City Mayor as its authority and shall be the sole signatory of the ID card.

All MRIS cards shall be issued by the Electronic Data Processing
(EDP) Services which shall be the primary implementing body of this
Ordinance.”

SEC. 3. Section 11 of Ordinance No. 8619 is hereby amended and shall now read as follows:

“Sec. 11. — Information to be contained in the Manila resident
Information System Card. — The MRIS card shall contain the following
information:

1. Manila City Name, Seal and Logo
2. Name of the Bearer
3. Photo of the Bearer
4. Citizenship
5. Sex
6. Blood Type
7. Address of the Bearer
8. Date of Birth of the Bearer
9. Contact person in case of emergency
10. Name of Mother
11. Name of Father
12. Name of Wife/Husband
13. Name of Children (if any)14. Voter's ID reference
15. Date of MRIS Issuance and Validity
16. Unique Identification Number
17. Signature of the Bearer
18. Signature of the Authority (Mayor of the City)
19. Quick Response (QR) Code”

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 8,2020
short_text: This ordinance amends specific provisions of Ordinance No. 8619, which created the Manila Resident Identification System (MRIS). It designates the Electronic Data Processing (EDP) Services as the primary implementing body, allows for either physical or virtual ID cards, and clarifies the data to be included in the ID, such as emergency contacts and QR code. These amendments aim to streamline implementation and improve the city's identification system.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8688

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING THE USE OF KARAOKES, VIDEOKES AND
OTHER SOUND-PRODUCING DEVICES WHICH TEND TO DISTURB THE COMMUNITY DURING MONDAY TO SATURDAY WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM SEVEN IN THE MORNING UNTIL FIVE IN THE AFTERNOON (7:00 AM - 5:00 PM) AND PROVIDING PENALTIES THEREOF
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the City Mayor, Honorable Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso, has expressed his concern after receiving multiple complaints from parents of students whose Online classes were disturbed by neighbors using Karaoke machines since the opening
of School Year 2020-2021 last 5 October, 2020,

WHEREAS, on 8 March, 2020 Presidential Proclamation No 922, S 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sublevel Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases,

In view of the continuing rise of confirmed cases of COVID-19, the serious threat to the health, safety, security, and lives of our countrymen, the long-term adverse effects on their means of livelihood, and the severe disruption of economic activities, a state of national emergency is hereby declared over the entire country,

WHEREAS, in view of the COVID-19 Pandemic, face-to-face classes in both private and public schools in the country have been suspended and were shifted to a “Distance Learning” method;

WHEREAS, on 19 June, 2020, the Department of Education issued Department Order No. 12, Series of 2020, entitled: “Adoption of the Basic Education Learning Continuity Plan for School Year 2020-2021 in Light of the Covid-19 Public Health Emergency”, providing among others the use of e-learning or online platforms as alternative to face-to-face classes;

WHEREAS, the City Government of Manila, consistent with Article II of the 1987 Constitution upholds the welfare of the youth and the value of their education,

WHEREAS, Section 16 of the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for
its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units
shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self reliant scientific and
technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants” NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in special session assembled, THAT,

SECTION 1. It is hereby prohibited to use karaokes, videokes: and other sound producing devices which tend to disturb the community during Monday to Saturday within the City of Manila from seven in the morning until five in the afternoon (7:00 am - 5:00 pm). Devices used for online of e-learning by students or teachers are
hereby exempted from this Ordinance
SEC. 2. Penalties. — Violators of this Ordinance shall be fined as follows, upon the discretion of the court:

a. For the First Offense, a fine of One Thousand Pesos
(PHP. 1,000.00) shall be imposed;

b. For the Second Offense, a fine of Two Thousand Pesos
(PHP 2,000.00) shall be imposed;

c. For the Third and Succeeding Offense, a fine of Three Thousand
Pesos (PHP 3,000.00) shall be imposed;

SEC. 3. All Barangay Officials and Police Officers are hereby tasked to implement this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 8, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance prohibits the use of karaokes, videokes, and other noise-producing devices from 7:00 AM to 5:00 PM, Monday to Saturday, within the City of Manila to avoid disrupting online classes. Exemptions are given to devices used specifically for e-learning. Fines range from Php1,000 for the first offense, Php2,000 for the second, and Php3,000 for the third and succeeding violations. Barangay officials and police are tasked with enforcement.
fines: Php1,000 for the first offense, Php2,000 for the second, and Php3,000

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8687

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING ONE HUNDRED THIRTY-THREE MILLION
EIGHT HUNDRED FIFTY-SEVEN THOUSAND SIX HUNDRED SEVENTY-SIX
PESOS AND SIXTY-EIGHT CENTAVOS (PHP. 133,857,676.68) AS SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 17 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2020 TO COVER THE WELFARE GOODS EXPENSES FOR THE "PAMASKONG HANDOG PARA SA SENIOR CITIZENS NG MAYNILA", AND FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF A MOLECULAR LABORATORY AT THE OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER AND OTHER PURPOSES
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on 8 March 2020 Presidential Proclamation No. 922, S. 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sublevel Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases. In view of the continuing rise of confirmed cases of COVID-19, the serious threat to the health, safety, security, and lives of our  countrymen, the long-term adverse effects on their means of livelihood, and the severe disruption of economic activities, a state of national emergency is hereby declared over the entire country;

WHEREAS, said Presidential Proclamations enjoined all government agencies and Local Government Units (LGUs) to render full assistance to and cooperation with each other and mobilize the necessary resources to undertake critical, urgent, and appropriate disaster response aid and measures in a timely manner to curtail and eliminate the threat of COVID-19:

WHEREAS, further, no less than the 1987 Constitution under Article XIII, Section 11 thereof, specifically provides that the state shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health and other social services available to all the people at affordable cost and prioritizing, among others, the elderly;

WHEREAS, consistent with the Constitution, the City Government of Manila has continuously produced programs and projects for the benefit and welfare of the elderly;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code of 1991, states that “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and
effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure
and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve
the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants” (Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, the same Code provides that all budgetary proposals shall be included and considered in the budget preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the executive budget to the Sanggunian, no Ordinance
providing for a supplemental budget shall be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources. A supplemental budget may also be enacted in times of public calamity by way of budgetary
realignment to set aside appropriations for the purchase of supplies and materials or the payment of services which are exceptionally urgent or absolutely indispensable to prevent
imminent danger to, or loss of, life or property, in the jurisdiction of the local government unit or in other areas declared by the President in a state of calamity. Such ordinance
Shall clearly indicate the sources of funds available for appropriations, as certified under oath by the local treasurer and local accountant and attested by the local chief executive,
and the various items of appropriations affected and the reasons for the change (Section 321 par. 1 of Republic Act No. 7160);
WHEREAS, the Code further provides that funds shall be available exclusively for the specific purpose for which they have been appropriated No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the
local chief executive or the Presiding Officer of the Sanggunian concerned may, by ordinance, be authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budget for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense class of their
respective appropriations (Section 336 of Republic Act No. 7160):

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 18, series of 2020, adopted by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council on October 5, 2020, entitled: “A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF THE
ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL
INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 TO COVER THE WELFARE GOODS
EXPENSES INTENDED FOR THE SENIOR CITIZENS OF MANILA, AND FOR THE
CONSTRUCTION OF A MOLECULAR LABORATORY IN THE TOTAL AMOUNTS OF
ONE HUNDRED NINETEEN MILLION FIVE HUNDRED NINETY THOUSAND PESOS
(PHP. 119,590,000.00) AND FOURTEEN MILLION TWO HUNDRED SIXTY SEVEN THOUSAND SIX HUNDRED SEVENTY SIX PESOS AND SIXTY EIGHT CENTAVOS (PHP. 14,267,676.68) RESPECTIVELY’: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Appropriations. - The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2020 in the amount of One Hundred Thirty-Three Million Eight Hundred Fifty-Seven Thousand Six Hundred Seventy-Six Pesos and Sixty-Eight Centavos (PHP 133,857,676.68) is hereby approved.

SEC. 2. Source of Funds. - The source of funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of One Hundred Thirty-Three Million Eight Hundred Fifty-Seven Thousand Six Hundred Seventy Six Pesos and Sixty-Eight Centavos (PHP 133,857,676.68) shall be derived from the following sources from savings hereby
reverted to the general fund:

a. Office of the Mayor: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses - Other Maintenance and Operating Expenses amounting to Sixty Nine Million Five Hundred Ninety Thousand Pesos (PHP 69,590,000.00).

b. Urban Settlements Office: Capital Outlay - Other Infrastructure Assets amounting to Fifty Million Pesos (PHP 50,000,000.00).

c. Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center: Capital Outlay - Medical Equipment amounting to Fourteen Million Two Hundred Sixty-Seven Thousand Six Hundred Seventy-Six Pesos and Sixty-Eight Centavos (PHP 14,267,676.68).

TOTAL: One Hundred Thirty-Three Million Eight Hundred Fifty Seven Thousand Six Hundred Seventy Six Pesos and Sixty Eight Centavos (PHP 133,857,676.68).

SEC. 3. Use of Funds. - The amount of One Hundred Thirty-Three Million Eight Hundred Fifty-Seven Thousand Six Hundred Seventy-Six Pesos and Sixty-Eight Centavos (PHP 133,857,676.68) is hereby appropriated with the following appropriations:

1. Office of the Mayor: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses - Welfare Goods Expenses for the "PAMASKONG HANDOG PARA
SA SENIOR CITIZENS NG MAYNILA" in the total amount of One
Hundred Nineteen Million Five Hundred Ninety Thousand Pesos
(PHP 119,590,000.00)
2. Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center Capital Outlay - Hospitals and Health Centers for the construction of a Molecular Laboratory at the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center in the amount of Fourteen Million Two Hundred Sixty-Seven Thousand Six Hundred Seventy-Six Pesos and Sixty-Eight Centavos (PHP 14,267,676.68)

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 8, 2020
short_text:
This ordinance approves a supplemental budget of  PhP133,857,676.68 for fiscal year 2020, allocating funds for two major purposes:

1. PhP119.59 million for the Pamaskong Handog para sa Senior Citizens ng Maynila, a welfare program for the elderly; and

2. PhP14.27 million for the construction of a molecular laboratory at the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center.
The funds are sourced from savings within various offices, including the Office of the Mayor and the Urban Settlements Office.

ORDINANCE NO. 8686

AN ORDINANCE ABOLISHING SEVERAL VACANT ADMINISTRATIVE POSITIONS
IN THE OFFICE OF THE CITY ACCOUNTANT (OCAT) BY WAY OF SCRAP-AND-
BUILD STRATEGY UNDER THE GOVERNMENT’S RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM
AND REPLACING THE SAME ABOLISHED POSITIONS WITH NEW PLANTILLA ITEMS OF ONE (1) COMPUTER OPERATOR II, ONE (1) COMPUTER OPERATOR III, ONE (1) DATA ENTRY MACHINE OPERATOR Ili AND ONE (1) ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER III
 
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the legal basis of this draft Ordinance can be found in Sec. 325 (General Limitations) of Republic Act No. 7160 (otherwise Known as the Local Government Code of 1991) and Section 2.5 of the Civil Service Commission (CSC) Memorandum Circular No. 19, Series of 1992, which states; "In cases of abolition of positions and the creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition shall be made in accordance with pertinent provisions of this Code and the civil service law, rules and regulations";

WHEREAS, the Executive Committee on the Rationalization Program composed of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and CSC in May 12, 2006 came out with Resolution No. 1 which laid down as part of the Allowable Staffing Actions are the following: (a) Abolition of positions, (b) Conversion of positions, (c) Reclassification of positions, (d) Retitling of positions, and (e) Creation of positions whereby the scrap and build policy must be observed when new positions may be created as long as there are corresponding obsolete/unnecessary but funded positions can be abolished to support the creation of these new positions;

WHEREAS, the proponent, Office of the City Accountant (OCAT), has certified that the administrative items being abolished remain vacant and unnecessary while the positions being created will immediately address its most urgent need to fill up information
Technology-related positions;

WHEREAS, the generated savings from the collapsed positions shall be less than the computed amount needed to fund the created positions and that the total amount for Personal Services, including the new positions, will not exceed the 45% statutory
limitation on the total approved annual appropriation: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. — It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to faithfully observe the overriding goal of improving the delivery of vital services in terms of quality, scope, speed, accountability and affordability.

The City and its instrumentalities must promote focused use of limited resources on core functions and programs, while simultaneously cutting down waste and overlaps by scaling-down, phasing-out or abolishing non-core tasks.

SEC. 2. Replacing of the following Abolished Positions. — The following unfilled and unnecessary positions in the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT) are hereby scrapped and converted to the following new positions, to wit:

FROM:
ITEM NO.: 54
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Assistant III
SG: 9

ITEM NO.: 106
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Assistant II
SG: 8

ITEM NO.: 14
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Aide VI
SG: 6

ITEM NO.: 109
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Aide VI
SG: 6

ITEM NO.: 62
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Aide 
SG: 4

ITEM NO.: 63
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Aide 
SG: 4

TO:

ITEM NO.: 137
POSITION TITLE: Computer Operator II
SG: 9

ITEM NO.: 135
POSITION TITLE: Computer Operator II
SG: 12

ITEM NO.: 136
POSITION TITLE: Data Entry Machine Operator III
SG: 11

ITEM NO.: 71
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Officer III
SG: 13

SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The qualification, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant laws.

SEC. 4. Appointment. — The employment and appointment of the individuals forherein subject positions shall be within the qualification standard and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 5. Appropriation. — The amount necessary to implement this Ordinance shall be taken from existing and available funds sourced from the savings generated by the abolition of the aforementioned positions in the approved Executive Budget for 2020. Thereafter, all subsequent appropriations shall be integrated in the annual budget of the City of Manila.

SEC. 6. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 8, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance abolishes seven vacant and unnecessary administrative positions in the Office of the City Accountant (OCAT) through a "scrap-and-build" strategy aligned with the government's Rationalization Program. The abolished posts are replaced with four new plantilla positions: Computer Operator II, Computer Operator III, Data Entry Machine Operator III, and Administrative Officer III. This restructuring aims to prioritize information technology-related roles and improve public service delivery without breaching budgetary limits.

SEC. 2. Replacement of the following Abolished Positions. — The following unfilled and unnecessary positions in the Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center are hereby scrapped and converted to the following new positions, to wit:

FROM:
ITEM NO.: 278
POSITION TITLE: Psychologist I
SG: 11

ITEM NO.: 270
POSITION TITLE: Medical Laboratory Technician II
SG: 8

ITEM NO.: 271
POSITION TITLE: Medical Laboratory Technician II
SG: 8

TO:
ITEM NO.: 36
POSITION TITLE: Administrative Assistant I (Computer Operator I)
SG: 7

ITEM NO.: 272
POSITION TITLE: Medical Technologist II
SG: 15
SEC. 3. Qualifications, Powers and Duties/Responsibilities. — The
qualification, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant laws.

SEC. 4. Appointment. — The employment and appointment of the individuals for herein subject positions shall be within the qualification standard and guidelines set by the Civil Service Commission (CSC) and other relevant agencies.

SEC. 5. Appropriation. — The amount necessary to implement this Ordinance shall be taken from existing and available funds sourced from the savings generated by the abolition of the aforementioned positions in the approved Executive Budget for 2020. Thereafter, all subsequent appropriations shall be integrated in the annual budget of the City of Manila.

SEC. 6. Effectivity. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 8, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance abolishes three vacant positions—one Psychologist I and two Medical Laboratory Technician II—at the Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center. In their place, the ordinance creates one Administrative Assistant I (Computer Operator I) and one Medical Technologist II position. The changes follow the government’s scrap-and-build strategy under the Rationalization Program, aiming to better align staffing with the hospital’s current operational needs while remaining within budgetary limits.

ORDINANCE NO. 8680

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING THE IMPROPER DISPOSAL OF ALL TYPES OF

PANDEMIC RELATED WASTES, INCLUDING SPECIAL HOUSEHOLD INFECTIOUS
WASTE AND PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT LIKE FACE MASKS AND
PROTECTING GEAR, MATERIALS AND PRODUCTS, BANNING THE DELIBERATE
OR UNINTENTIONAL DISCARDING OF SUCH IN ALL PUBLIC PLACES OR SIMILAR
AREAS AND IMPOSING THE APPROPRIATE PENALTIES THEREIN, OTHERWISE
KNOWN AS “THE MANILA PANDEMIC WASTE DISPOSAL ACT OF 2020"
PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines affirms the state policy to "protect and promote the right to health" and to "protect and advance the right of the people to a balanced and healthful ecology";

WHEREAS, Manila City Ordinance No. 7866, Metro Manila Development Authority (MMDA) Regulation No. 96-009 as amended by Regulation No. 99-006 and R.A. 9003 or the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act prohibit littering and other acts detrimental to public health and the environment:

WHEREAS, the current COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in ultra massive consumption, as well as disposal of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), same with hygiene and disinfectant products constantly used to contain contamination and prevent the spread of the deadly Coronavirus;

WHEREAS, amid the continuously disconcerting daily uptick of new Covid cases in the country, a very recent finding of a major environmental advocacy coalition has sounded the alarm over photo documentation of wanton discarding and rampant littering
of used worn-out face masks and gloves, both of the disposable kind, mixed with empty bottle containers of alcohol spray cleanser, blatantly scattered, many in mounds, along sides metro avenues, some in heaps on the pavement or thickly clogged around fringes of gutters and drain-ways of a number of local government units in the capital region;

WHEREAS, causing further concern and consternation for the ecological watchdog advocates was seeing additional images identical to the aforementioned infectious PPEs, but this time sprawling lengthy the shores of Baseco white beach,
possibly polluting the bayside, poisoning aquatic life and putting the locals there at risk of contagion, which clearly goes against the commitment, effort to fight this dreaded disease, clean up tour city and save Manila Bay;

WHEREAS, the reckless disposal of such Covid protecting gear and products, probably highly contagious, does indeed pose a threat very harmful to the human health, as well as the surrounding ecology, and this ought to be stopped at once, for such
recklessness, as with Covid viruses, simply has no place right now in the City of Manila: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. TITLE. - This legislative measure shall be known as the “MANILA PANDEMIC WASTE DISPOSAL ACT OF 2020”.

SEC. 2. - It is imperative that this measure recognizes and adopts the General Guidelines of the Management of COVID-19 Related Healthcare Waste of the National Solid Waste Commission under the Department of Environment and Natural Resources
(DENR).

As this Ordinance seeks to mandate for as separate (yellow) bin, special for the disposing of pandemic related waste only in each Barangay of the City of Manila, (to be provided by the City or the Barangay depending on the availability of funds), as well as,
for any individual discarding such waste to be specially placed and sealed in a separate plastic bag, not to be mixed with the regular house rubbish or home trash (before being properly disposed in the aforementioned yellow bin).
SEC. 3. SCOPE & PROHIBITIVE ACTS. - It shall be unlawful to improperly dispose of, throw away, dispense with, discard or dump, deliberately or unintentionally, any type of Pandemic (COVID-19) related wastes, which includes Special Household
Infectious Waste and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) such as face masks, face-covers, face-shields, eye-shields, head/hair caps, hand gloves, and other protecting materials, items or gear, also disinfectant or hygiene products like hand sanitizer or
alcohol containers, as well as, every form of wipes, tissues, towels, handkerchief or similar cloths and discarded test kits used to counter Coronavirus, among others.

Thus, this Ordinance shall prohibit strictly the improper disposal of such types of Pandemic (COVID-19) related wastes in all public places/open spaces, streets, roads, alleys, sidewalks, center-islands, overpasses, bridges, parks, malls, markets, squares, halls, transport, terminals, buildings, establishments, schools, churches, hospitals, banks, commercial business centers and similar areas, as well as, coastlines, shorelines,
harbors, docks, rivers, waterways, esteros, canals, streams, gutters, drains, pipelines, restrooms, toilets, or water bodies.

SEC. 4. PENALTIES. - Any person or Barangay in violation of this Ordinance shall be fined with One Thousand Pesos (PHP 1,000.00) for the first offense and Three Thousand Pesos (PHP 3,000.00) for the second offense. Any subsequent offense shall be further fined with Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 5,000.00) and/or face subsidiary
imprisonment not exceeding one (1) month or both at the discretion of the court, and in case of a Corporation or corporate entity, the revocation of business permit and/or closure of business establishment.

SEC. 5. - The City shall establish an Inter-Agency Task-force for the Management of Pandemic Wastes with the Manila Department of Public Services as lead enforcement and implementing authority, which also shall include the local Liga ng mga Barangay and
Sangguniang Kabataan Federation, the Manila Barangay Bureau, Manila Public Information Office, and the Chairperson of the Manila City Council, Committee on Environmental Protection, Ecological Preservation and Sanitation, Manila City Council to
come up with the Implementing Rules and Regulations with a positive approach to coordinate and conduct a comprehensive city-wide, community-level and social media based information and educational campaign to promote awareness and compliance to
this Ordinance.

SEC. 6. REPEALING CLAUSE. - All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules, and regulations, which are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 7. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval and publication.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 28,2020.
short_text: This ordinance prohibits the improper disposal of pandemic-related wastes, such as used face masks, gloves, PPE, test kits, and containers of sanitizers, especially in public places like streets, parks, waterways, and beaches. It mandates the use of yellow bins for these wastes, to be provided by either the city or barangays, and requires individuals to seal such waste in separate bags. Violators will be fined Php1,000 (1st offense), Php3,000 (2nd offense), and Php5,000 or 1-month imprisonment (3rd/subsequent offenses); corporations may also face business permit revocation.
