ORDINANCE NO. 8636

AN ORDINANCE EXTENDING THE DEADLINE FOR THE PAYMENT OF UNPAID MONTHLY AMORTIZATION OF ALL LANDED ESTATES IN THE CITY OF MANILA DUE TO THE DECLARATION OF THE ENHANCED COMMUNITY QUARANTINE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2020 WITH WAIVER OF INTERESTS, SURCHARGES AND PENALTIES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, since 15 March 2020, the whole of Luzon has been under an Enhanced Community Quarantine which primarily prohibits anyone from leaving his or her residence in order to contain, delay and mitigate the effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic;

WHEREAS, on 23 March 2020, Congress enacted Republic Act No. 11469 authorizing the President, among others, to move statutory deadlines and timelines for the payment of taxes, fees and other charges required by law in order to ease the burden on individuals under Community Quarantine;

WHEREAS, Section 167 of the Local Government Code provides that unless otherwise provided, all local taxes, fees and charges shall be paid within a prescribed period. The Sanggunian concerned may, for a justifiable reason or cause, extend the time for payment of such taxes, fees, or charges without surcharges or penalties, but only for a period not exceeding six (6) months;

WHEREAS, considering that everyone within National Capital Region is required to stay inside their residences, with exemptions to health workers and those delivering basic goods and services to ensure public health and safety, there is an imperative need to extend the deadline of payment of amortization until 30 June 2020: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. COVERAGE. - All unpaid monthly amortization during the Enhanced Community Quarantine of all landed estates in the City of Manila is hereby extended until June 30, 2020, without penalties, surcharges and interests.

SEC. 2. REPEALING CLAUSE. - Any provisions of ordinances, executive orders, issuances or rules and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 3. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 27, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance extends the deadline for payment of unpaid monthly amortizations on all landed estates in the City of Manila until June 30, 2020, due to the Enhanced Community Quarantine. The extension includes a waiver of interests, surcharges, and penalties. It aims to ease the financial burden on residents during the COVID-19 pandemic in line with national emergency measures.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8635

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING PROVISIONS OF ORDINANCE NO. 7885, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8120, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA TO OPERATE THE
DALUBHASAAN NG MAYNILA (CITY COLLEGE OF MANILA) AND FOR SUCH OTHER PURPOSES", ENACTED ON APRIL 17, 1995

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. DECLARATION OF POLICY. - It shall hereby be declared the policy of the City of Manila to be genuinely committed, inconsonance with the policy of the State, in promoting the right of all citizens to quality education at all levels and to make such education accessible to all. Moreover, the City of Manila, aware of its obligations to give the poor but talented and gifted students of the City of Manila the opportunity to develop their potentials, is committed to establish another tertiary school to accommodate the graduates of secondary public schools to pursue college education.

SEC. 2. NAME OF INSTITUTION. - The DALUBHASAAN NG MAYNILA or CITY COLLEGE OF MANILA, is hereby renamed, UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA, and as such shall continue to operate in accordance with law and within the powers and limitations hereinafter specified, and the same shall be organized as a corporation under the same name.

The Universidad de Manila, hereinafter referred to as "the University", shall be treated as an independent and institutional department of the City of Manila wherein the management of fiscal, human resources, and all other assets shall be within its control.

SEC. 3. PURPOSE. As a public, non-sectarian, non-profit and non-partisan institution of higher learning, enjoying institutional and individual academic freedom, the purposes of the University, shall be:

1. To advance human knowledge through basic study and research, specifically
in, but not limited to, science and technology:

2. To serve as a research university in its various fields of expertise and
specialization;

3. To develop more fully the Filipino intellect, propagate Filipino culture and
promote international understanding through intercultural and international
education;

4. To promote an increasingly higher order of moral and cultural values;

5. To provide scientific, technological and professional training responsive to the
needs of the City and relevant to an achieving society, such training to include,
but not limited to, the arts and humanities, management, accountancy, nursing, education, public administration, criminology, engineering, industrial education, sports, vocational-technical education and other applied livelihood-oriented and employment guaranteed courses;

6. To introduce in its curricula studies which do not at present receive sufficient
emphasis in existing institutions of higher learning in the country;

7. To offer extension and other related programs and services for the general
welfare of the people;

8. To offer quality education at a reasonable and affordable cost for all who
qualify for admission, particularly the financially disadvantaged but talented
and deserving youth of the City;

9. To pursue excellence in academic instruction, research and extension of
services; and

10. To strive for economy, efficiency and effectiveness in its organization and
internal operations.

The University shall establish/organize a laboratory school (technical high school,
science high school, arts school, sports high school) for its education programs through
affiliation with existing institutions supported by the City Government or by creating new
ones as it may deem necessary.

SEC. 4. ADMISSION. - The University shall have a system of admission which shall facilitate the enrollment of students regardless of sex, religious beliefs, economic status, or political affiliation: Provided, that the enrollment shall be exclusively for the bona fide residents of Manila and to those whose parents and/or guardians work and pay their taxes to the City subject to the rules and regulations of admission and retention prescribed by the Board of Regents. Provided further, that the residential requirement shall not apply to the admission of students to the Graduate School.

SEC. 5. BOARD OF REGENTS. - The overall governance of the University shall be vested in a governing board to be known as the Board of Regents of the University, whose members are of known probity and integrity, and have great interest in the continuing development of the City of Manila.

The Board shall be composed of eleven (11) members as follows: Chairman, the Mayor; Vice Chairman, the President of the University; nine (9) members, of which the Chairman of the Committee on Education of the City Council and the Superintendent of City Schools shall be ex-officio members.

All members of the Board, with the exception of the Chairman and two (2) ex-officio
members, shall be appointed by the Mayor of the City of Manila with the consent of the
City Council.

The seven (7) appointive members of the Board shall be appointed from, but not limited to, the following: representative from business and industry; the Commission of Higher Education (CHED); the Association of Local Colleges and Universities (ACLU); the Department of Science and Technology (DOST); and representatives from the faculty. alumni, and the student body: PROVIDED, that the representatives from CHED, ACLU, and DOST shall hold the rank not lower than Director.

All appointive members of the Board shall serve for a term of six (6) years, or until
their successors shall have been appointed and qualified; PROVIDED, however, that the
representatives from CHED, ACLU, DOST, the faculty, alumni, and the student body be
co-terminus with their respective tenure of office.

SEC. 6. REQUIREMENTS AND ALLOWANCE OF MEMBERS IN THE BOARD. All members of the Board shall be citizens of the Philippines. They shall serve without compensation other than the reasonable allowance for attendance in Board meetings and for official business duly authorized by the Board.

SEC. 7. VACANCY. - In case of vacancy in the Board by reason of resignation, death, or other forms of incapacity of any member of the Board, such vacancy shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor: PROVIDED, that, the appointee shall serve only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.

SEC. 8. CONFLICT OF INTEREST. - Members of the Board shall not have any business interest, directly or indirectly, in any aspect of University operations.

SEC. 9. GENERAL POWERS OF THE BOARD OF REGENTS. - The University shall have the general powers set out in Section thirteen of Act Numbered Fourteen hundred and fifty-nine and such other functions as are necessary to carry out the purposes of the corporation and administration of the said university, and the exercise of its corporate powers are hereby vested exclusively in the Board of Regents and the President of the University insofar as authorized by the Board.

SEC. 10. POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE. BOARD OF REGENTS. - The Board of Regents shall have the following powers and duties, in consonance with existing laws and in addition to its general powers under Section 16 hereof:

1. To receive and appropriate such sums of money, properties, or materials as may be provided by Ordinance of the City of Manila for the support of the University;

2. To provide for the establishment of undergraduate and graduate schools, specifically in, but not limited to, Science and Technology, considering the priorities of the City and national needs;

3. To approve the courses of study and rules of discipline recommended by the University Council as hereinafter provided for, and to fix tuition and other fees;

4. To confer degrees for which graduating students are qualified, and honorary
degrees and titles upon persons in recognition of their wisdom, statesmanship,
or service in the government and to society as well as in due regard to eminence in philosophy, science, technology, literature and community service;

5. To provide fellowships and scholarships for students, faculty and staff on the
basis of merit;

6. To establish professional chairs in the University's colleges and to provide or
arrange for the maintenance or endowment of such chairs;

7. To provide for academic ranks and approve the appointment of the teaching
personnel and to fix the compensation commensurate with such ranks;

8. To receive from the City of Manila assistance to augment the internal sources of funds, as may be provided, for the support of the University in the manner it may determine, and its discretion, to carry out the purposes and functions of the University.
Such fees and charges, including government subsidies and other income
generated by the University, shall constitute its regular fund and shall be
deposited in any authorized government depository bank, and all interests that
shall accrue therefore shall form part of the same fund for the use of the
University.
If, for reason of control, the University shall be able to pursue any project for
which funds have been appropriated and allocated under its approved program
of expenditures, the Board may authorize the use of said funds for any
reasonable purpose which, in its discretion, may be necessary and urgent for
the attainment of objectives and goals of the University;

9. To provide a reasonable system of compensation and fringe benefits such as housing, medical, and health insurances, scholarships for direct descendants of University personnel, legal support in case of litigation and other benefits provided by existing laws. Such compensation benefits shall be for all University officials, faculty and staff, full time or part time, as applicable. Non-pecuniary benefits shall be in accordance with rules and regulations on hours of service, and such other conditions as the Board may deem proper;

10. To receive in trust, tax free, all legacies, gifts, donations, and grants of real and
personal properties, and any other form of donation, and to administer the same for the benefit of the University or any part thereof in accordance with the instructions of the donor, or in default thereof, in such manner as it may determine;

11. To disburse the appropriated funds in accordance with the line-item expenditure of the University as determined by the Board, subject to limitations imposed by law: PROVIDED, that any or all funds allocated and accruing to the University shall be put and kept under its name and account, and PROVIDED FURTHER, that any surplus for unappropriated amount at the end of each year shall remain with the coffers and considered as savings of the University. There shall be a provision for the regular annual appropriation from the City of Manila to support and sustain the operation of the University. Likewise, there shall be
a budget allocation for the accreditation of programs to be provided by the City of Manila;

12. To prescribe rules of its own governance, to establish the governance structure of the University, and to enact for the governance of the University such general policies and regulations as are consistent with the purposes of the University as defined in Section 3 of this Ordinance;

13. To promulgate rules and regulations of discipline governing University officials,
faculty, and staff members, including removal from the service for cause, after
due process;

14. To exercise such other powers and duties not inconsistent with laws as may be
necessary or essential to carry out its purposes;

15. To elect the President of the University; and

16. To appoint, on the recommendation of the President of the University, the officials of the University, the members of the faculty, the support personnel and other University personnel.

SEC. 11. PROCESSES. - Actions and processes against the Board of Regents shall be served on the University President or the Board Secretary thereof.

SEC. 12. MEETINGS OF THE BOARD OF REGENTS. - The Board of Regents shall hold its regular meetings at least once a month, or in special meetings as may be deemed necessary by the Chairman and the University President. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum to transact business. The University President shall determine and prepare the agenda of all meetings of the Board. All acts of the Board shall be collegial, and no member may take action on any matter on his own. At the end of each fiscal year, the Board shall submit an annual report to the Mayor and the City Council.

SEC. 13. ADMINISTRATION OF THE UNIVERSITY. The responsibility of University administration shall devolve upon the University President and its officials.

SEC. 14. UNIVERSITY COUNCIL. There shall be a University Council, consisting of the President of the University and all of the members of the faculty of the University holding the rank of professor, associate professor, and assistant professor. Subject to existing laws, the Council shall have the power to prescribe the course of study and rules of discipline, provided those matters are first approved by the Board of Regents. Subject to the same limitations, it shall fix the requirements for admission to any college of the university, as well as for graduation and the conferment of degrees. The Council alone shall have the power to recommend students or others to be recipients of degrees. Through its president or committees, it shall have disciplinary powers over the students within the limits prescribed by the rules of discipline approved by the Board of Regents.

SEC. 15. UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT. - The President of the University, who is the Chief Academic and Executive Officer of the University, shall be elected by the Board of Regents for a term of six (6) years, subject to reappointment, unless sooner removed for cause such as incapacity, incompetence, dishonesty, and/or final conviction of a crime involving moral turpitude and other grave offenses as decided upon by a competent court of law. He shall receive salary, emoluments and fringe benefits commensurate with his position and qualifications as determined by the Board. The powers and duties of the President of the University, in addition to this specifically provided for in this Ordinance, shall be those usually pertaining to the Office of the President of the University.

SEC. 16. STRUCTURE AND ORGANIZATION. - The President shall recommend to the Board for approval, the structure and organization of the University which shall define efficiently and effectively its operations for the achievement of its goals and objectives.

SEC. 17. FACULTY AND DEANS. The body of professors and instructors of each college shall constitute its faculty, and as Presiding Officer of each faculty there shall be a dean elected by the Board of Regents on nomination by the President of the University.

In the appointment of professors, instructors, and other personnel of the University.
no religious tests shall be required, nor shall their religious opinions or affiliations be made a matter of examination or inquiry.

SEC. 18. EXEMPTION FROM CIVIL SERVICE. Professors, instructors, and members of the academic teaching and research staff shall be exempt from Civil Service Examinations, regulations and other requirements as requisite for appointment; Provided, That all appointments are submitted to the Civil Service Commission and the Government Service Insurance System for record purposes only.

SEC. 19. SECRETARY OF THE UNIVERSITY. There shall be a Secretary of the University, appointed by the Board of Regents, on the recommendation of the University President. He/she shall serve as secretary of such Board and Legal Officer of the University, responsible for all documentation, records, and information dissemination of all decisions of the President and the Board to insure proper implementation, monitoring and evaluation.

SEC. 20. BOARD OF VISITORS. - The Mayor, the Vice Mayor, and the Members of the City Council shall constitute the Board of Visitors of the University. As Chairman of the Board of Visitors, the Mayor shall convene the Board in order to discharge its duties, such as attendance in graduation ceremonies, making visits at the University as it may deem necessary, and other visitorial duties and privileges as may be provided by law.

SEC. 21. GENERAL PROVISIONS. - The City Council shall appropriate funds for the operations of the University, the regular Annual appropriation of which shall be included in the Executive Budget of the Office of the City Mayor as lump sum appropriation or such amount thereof to support and sustain the full operation and maintenance of the University; PROVIDED, That the City Council may appropriate additional funds for special programs and/or projects which may be deemed necessary to be undertaken by the University, outside of its regular annual appropriation.

SEC. 22. EMBLEM, COLOR, AND SEAL. - The University shall adopt its emblem, color, seal, and other appurtenances consistent with the reflective of the Philippine culture and values that shall enhance the uniqueness and dignity of the Filipino identity.

SEC. 23. PROGRESS REPORT. - The Board of Regents shall file with the CHED, the Mayor, and the City Council an annual detailed report, setting forth the progress, condition, and needs of the University.

SEC. 24. REPORTORIAL REQUIREMENTS AND AUDITING OF ACCOUNTS. - The University shall submit an annual report to the City Council containing the financial statements, statements of assets and liabilities, actual projected income from tuition fees, and other revenue sources, contracts and investments entered into, including programs of expenditures. All accounts and disbursements of the University shall be audited by the Commission on Audit.

SEC. 25. OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE AND SUNSET REVIEW. An Oversight Committee composed of the Mayor, Vice Mayor, the President of the University and their designated representatives shall constitute the oversight committee to oversee the transition in terms of setting up the University's procurement, payroll, and revenue collection systems and such other systems and processes that are critical for the University's operation.

It shall likewise conduct a review on the grant of fiscal autonomy to the University
upon lapse of five (5) years from the approval hereof.

SEC. 26. TRANSITORY PROVISIONS. - Upon signing of this Ordinance by the Mayor, the University shall submit, in thirty (30) days, its enhanced organizational chart
and operations manual to the Mayor. Within ninety (90) days thereafter, the Local Finance
Committee shall transfer any and all appropriations of the University for the current fiscal year such funds from previous years that were not released for personnel services,
maintenance and operating expense and capital outlay.

SEC. 27. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. - No statutory or other issuances shall diminish the powers, right, privileges, and benefits accorded to the University under this Ordinance or enjoyed at present by it under other issuances not otherwise modified or repealed under this Ordinance, unless subsequent legislation expressly provides for their repeal, amendment or modification. Any case of doubt in the interpretation of any of the provisions of this Charter shall be resolved in favor of the academic freedom and fiscal autonomy of the University.

SEC. 28. APPROPRIATIONS. The amount needed to carry out the implementation of this Ordinance shall be charged against the lump sum appropriation of the current fiscal year and other internal funds of the University. Thereafter, such lump sum representing the responsibility of the City of Manila for the continued growth, operation, maintenance, and requirements for Commission on Higher Education (CHED) Accreditation.

The University may use unexpended balances in any appropriation for purposes that the Board determines.

SEC. 29. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - Should any provision herein be declared unconstitutional, the same shall not affect the validity of the other provisions of this Act.

SEC. 30. REPEALING CLAUSE. Ordinance No. 7885, as amended, and all laws, decrees, orders, rules, and regulations or other issuances or parts inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

This Ordinance can only be repealed by a UNANIMOUS vote of all members of the City Council.

SEC. 31. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 27, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance officially renames the City College of Manila (Dalubhasaan ng Maynila) to Universidad de Manila (UdM) and restructures it as a corporate, independent, and institutionally autonomous department of the City Government of Manila. The University is designed to provide accessible and quality tertiary education, especially to academically qualified but financially disadvantaged Manila residents. UdM will have its own Board of Regents, composed of 11 members, including city officials and representatives from various sectors.

The ordinance lays down the university’s policy direction, including institutional independence, fiscal autonomy, academic freedom, and curriculum development focused on local and national development. It defines admission policies prioritizing Manila residents, outlines powers and responsibilities of the Board of Regents, establishes the role and selection of the University President, and exempts academic staff from Civil Service examinations.

The ordinance also requires the City Council to provide annual funding and grants fiscal autonomy to the university, subject to periodic reviews. Provisions include audit requirements, administrative structures, and allowances for a Board of Visitors composed of city officials.

ORDINANCE NO. 8634

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 2 EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE OF ORDINANCE NO. 8632 AMENDING SECTION 5 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8565
PROVIDING FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP. 500.00) MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE TO ALL BONA FIDE SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED OR PERSONS WITH DISABILITY AND SOLO PARENT RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, City Ordinance No. 8632, entitled: "AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP. 500.00) MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE TO ALL BONA FIDE SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED OR PERSONS WITH DISABILITY AND SOLO PARENT RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES" was passed into law on April 23,2020;

WHEREAS, Section 2 of the above-cited Ordinance provides that the Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval which was supposed to be April 23, 2020;
 
WHEREAS, there is a need to amend the period of effectivity of Ordinance No. 8632 in order to maximize the benefits afforded to the beneficiaries under the Social Amelioration Program: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 8632 is hereby amended and shall now read as follows:

"Sec. 2. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall be effective retroactive to January 1, 2020."

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 27, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance amends the effectivity date of Ordinance No. 8632, which grants a monthly PHP 500 monetary allowance to all bona fide senior citizens, persons with disabilities (PWDs), and solo parents residing in the City of Manila as part of the city's Social Amelioration Program. Previously, Ordinance No. 8632 stated the benefits would begin upon its approval on April 23, 2020. Ordinance No. 8634 retroactively adjusts the date of effectivity to January 1, 2020, allowing qualified residents to receive benefits for the earlier months of that year. This change ensures that beneficiaries maximize the financial support provided under the program.

ORDINANCE NO. 8633

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 05, SERIES OF 2020, THROUGH BUDGETARY REALIGNMENT, INVOLVING AN AMOUNT OF SIX HUNDRED TWENTY-ONE MILLION EIGHT HUNDRED TEN THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 621,810,000.00), FOR THE CITY AMELIORATION CRISIS ASSISTANCE FUND (CACAF) FY 2020 - 2ND TRANCHE

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on April 24, 2020, the President adopted the recommendation of the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF) to extend the Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) in high-risk areas, including the National Capital Region (NCR) until May 15, 2020 due to Covid-19;

WHEREAS, in view of the ECQ extension, there is a need to augment the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) that was previously allocated to support the assistance intended by the City Government for the 896 barangays in the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 5, Series of 2020, adopted on April 24, 2020 by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF
THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 IN RELATION TO THE ADDITIONAL OF SIX HUNDRED TWENTY-ONE MILLION EIGHT HUNDRED TEN THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 621,810,000.00) AS THE CITY AMELIORATION CRISIS ASSISTANCE FUND SECOND TRANCHE (CACAF 2ND TRANCHE) AS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA";

WHEREAS, the intention of the CACAF is to immediately attend to the needs of the Manileño because the supply of basic commodities has been scarce due to the high demand and production challenges causing difficulties in the immediate distribution of the relief goods to the entire population of the city: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. This Ordinance shall be known as City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) FY 2020 - 2nd tranche.

SEC. 2. The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2020 in the amount of Six Hundred Twenty-One Million Eight Hundred Ten Thousand Pesos (PhP. 621,810,000.00), through budgetary realignment, for the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) is hereby approved.

SEC. 3. Sources of Funds. - The source of funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of Six Hundred Twenty-One Million Eight Hundred Ten Thousand Pesos (PhP. 621,810,000.000) shall be derived from the following sources:

a. City Planning and Development Office
Capital Outlay – Buildings (City Hall Clock Tower)
PHP 30,000,000.00

b. Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila
Subsidies – Others (Manila Robotic)
PHP 20,000,000.00

c. Manila Department of Social Welfare Donation
₱70,000,000.00
Other Supplies and Materials Expenses
PHP 62,440,000.00

d. Manila Health Department
Food Supplies Expenses (Nutribun)
PHP 173,000,000.00

e. Urban Settlements Office
Capital Outlay
Other Infrastructure Assets (Vertical Housing Program)
PHP 100,000,000.00

f. Department of Engineering and Public Works
Capital Outlay
Parks, Plaza and Monuments
PHP 105,000,000.00

1. Plaza Miranda – In front of Quiapo Church
PHP 39,000,000.00

2. Carriedo to Fountain Park – In front of Sta. Cruz Church
PHP 6,000,000.00

3. Remedios Circle – Remedios St. Ermita
₱5,000,000.00

4. Plaza Guanzon – Quirino Ave., Paco
₱30,000,000.00

5. Plaza Guerrero/Plaza Senora De Guia
₱9,000,000.00

6. Plaza Jacinto Zamora – San Luis St.
₱2,000,000.00

7. Plaza Isabel (Anda Circle) – Aduana St., Intramuros
₱14,000,000.00

g. Markets (BASECO)
₱15,000,000.00

h. Other Structures
Repair/Rehabilitation of Sen. Arturo Tolentino Sports Complex
₱46,370,000.00

Total: ₱621,810,000.00

SEC. 4. Use of Funds. -The amount of Six Hundred Twenty-One Million Eight Hundred Ten Thousand Pesos (PhP. 621,810,000.00) is hereby appropriated for the Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila as City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) - 2nd tranche under the MOOE-Donation Account of the Manila
Department of Social Welfare.

SEC. 5. Beneficiaries. - The amount of One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) per beneficiary shall be given to the barangay-identified beneficiaries as financial assistance to be distributed in the 896 Barangays in the City of Manila to cushion the economic effect of COVID-19 crisis and to enable the people of Manila to purchase much
needed food and supplies for their survival.

SEC. 6. Accountability. The amount appropriated in this Ordinance shall be coursed through the barangays concerned, who shall be in-charge of the proper liquidation of the said fund, subject to existing laws, rules and regulation.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 27, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance authorizes a Php621,810,000 supplemental budget (called CACAF – 2nd Tranche) to provide Php1,000 in cash assistance to each qualified beneficiary in the 896 barangays of Manila. This financial aid is meant to help residents affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and the extended Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ).

The money comes from realigning unused funds originally meant for projects like:

Clock Tower improvements

Manila Robotics program

Nutribun food supply

Housing projects

Park and plaza beautification (e.g., Plaza Miranda, Anda Circle)

Sports complex repairs

BASECO market development

The assistance will be distributed by barangay officials, who are also responsible for reporting how the funds are used, following proper rules.

ORDINANCE NO. 8632

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 5 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8565, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP. 500.00) MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE TO ALL BONA FIDE SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED OR PERSONS WITH DISABILITY AND SOLO PARENT RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES"

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 5 of Ordinance No. 8565 is hereby amended as follows:

Sec. 5. REQUIREMENTS FOR THE AVAILMENT OF THE BENEFITS.- 

for Senior Citizens:

a.  Must be at least 60 years of age;
b.  Must be a registered voter of the City of Manila; provided, however, if the senior citizen is not a
registered voter, he or she must be an actual resident and actually living in the City of Manila, as certified by
the Barangay Chairman thereat, and
c.  Must be included in the master list of the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs of the City of Manila.

for Person with Disability:

a.  Must be at least 18 years of age;
b.  Must be a registered voter of the City of Manila; provided, however, if the PWD does not qualify as a
registered voter, his or her parents or legal guardian must be a registered voter(s) in the City of Manila; and
c.  Must be included in the master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare Office.

for Solo Parent:

a.  Must be a registered voter of the City of Manila; provided, however, if the solo parent is a minor, his or
her parents or legal guardian must be a registered voter(s) in the City of Manila, and must be included in the
master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare Office.

SEC. 2. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its
approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 23, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance updates the eligibility rules for receiving the PhP500 monthly financial aid provided by the City of Manila to senior citizens, persons with disability (PWDs), and solo parents under the city's Social Amelioration Program. The changes clarify the requirements for each group:

For Senior Citizens:

Must be at least 60 years old

Must be a registered voter in Manila, or if not, must be certified by the Barangay Chairman as an actual resident of Manila

Must be listed in the master list of the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs (OSCA)

For Persons with Disability (PWDs):

Must be at least 18 years old

Must be a registered voter in Manila, or if not, the parent or legal guardian must be a registered voter in the city

Must be included in the master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW)

For Solo Parents:

Must be a registered voter in Manila, or if a minor, their parent or guardian must be a registered voter

Must be listed in the master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare

ORDINANCE NO. 8631

AN ORDINANCE CREATING SEVENTY-FIVE (75) REGULAR PLANTILLA ITEMS FOR OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFORE

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the present COVID-19 Pandemic has greatly burdened local hospitals with the increasing number of its victims,

WHEREAS, to sustain the services provided by public hospitals, there is an urgent need to increase the number of medical personnel being employed;

WHEREAS, this increase of available regular plantilla positions, particularly in its Nursing, Medical and Administrative divisions, is in accordance with the guidelines issued by the Department of Health for Tertiary Hospitals;

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. NEW PLANTILLA POSITIONS. The following new positions are hereby created under the different offices and departments of Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center.

TITLE OF POSITION: Computer Maintenance Technologist I

SALARY GRADE: 11

NO. OF ITEMS: 1
SALARY GRADE: 11

SALARY GRADE: 8

NO. OF ITEMS: 20
SALARY GRADE: 15

SALARY GRADE: 15

TITLE OF POSITION: Physical Therapist I

SEC. 2. QUALIFICATIONS, POWERS AND DUTIES/RESPONSIBILITIES. - The qualifications, powers, duties and responsibilities of the herein enumerated positions shall be based on the provisions of the Local Government Code, Civil Service Commission (CSC), the Medical Act and other relevant laws.

SEC. 3. APPOINTMENTS. The employment and appointment of individuals for the herein subject positions shall be within the qualification, standard and guidelines set by the Department of Health, Civil Service Commission (CSC), and other relevant agencies

under the 2020 Executive Budget. Further, herein subject positions shall be automatically
funded through the succeeding annual city budget as part of Ospital ng Maynila Medical
Center plantilla.

SEC. 5. REPEALING CLAUSE. - Any provisions of ordinances, executive orders, issuances or rules and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 23, 2020

ORDINANCE NO. 8630

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8625 BY HEREIN SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 04, SERIES OF 2020, AUGMENTING THE AMOUNT ALLOCATED FOR THE CITY AMELIORATION CRISIS ASSISTANCE FUND (CACAF) IN THE AMOUNT OF TWENTY MILLION PESOS (PHP. 20,000,000.00)

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code states that "a supplemental budget may also be enacted in times of public calamity by way of budgetary realignment to set aside appropriations for the purchase of supplies and materials or the payment of services which are exceptionally urgent or absolutely indispensable to prevent imminent danger
to, or loss of, life or property, in the jurisdiction of the local government unit or in other areas declared by the President in a state of calamity. Such ordinances shall clearly indicate the sources of funds available for appropriations, as certified under oath by the local treasurer and local accountant and attested by the local chief executive, and the various items of appropriations affected and the reasons for the change." [Section 321
of Republic Act No. 7160];

WHEREAS, on April 5th, 2020, the City Council of Manila passed Ordinance No. 8625 entitled: "An Ordinance authorizing the Supplemental Budget No. 02, Series of 2020, through Budgetary Realignment, involving an amount of Five Hundred Ninety-One Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 591,000,000.00), for the City Amelioration
Crisis Assistance Fund" in accordance with Section 321 of R.A. No. 7160;

WHEREAS, the intention of the said Ordinance is to provide immediate assistance to all the families residing, whether temporary or permanently, in the City of Manila while the entire City is under the Enhance Community Quarantine (ECQ), as ordered by the President;

WHEREAS, the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) was provided by the City of Manila because the supply of basic commodities has been scarce due to its high demand and production challenges causing difficulties in the immediate distribution of the relief goods to the entire population of the city;

WHEREAS, after the implementation of the CACAF in the eight hundred ninety-six (896) Barangays, a number of barangays appealed for additional funding to accommodate those families who have not benefited from the said fund;

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 4, Series of 2020, adopted on April 16, 2020 by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF
THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 IN RELATION TO THE ADDITIONAL TWENTY MILLION PESOS (PHP. 20,000,000.00) CITY AMELIORATION CRISIS ASSISTANCE FUND AS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA": NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. APPROPRIATIONS. Ordinance No. 8625 is hereby amended by herein Supplemental Budget augmenting the amount of the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) by Twenty Million Pesos (PhP. 20,000,000.00).

SEC. 2. SOURCES OF FUND. - The source of funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of Twenty Million Pesos (PhP. 20,000,000.00), shall be derived from the Office of the Mayor [Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) - Donation Account].

SEC. 3. USE OF FUNDS. The amount of Twenty Million Pesos (PhP. 20,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated for the Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila as City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund under the
Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) - Donation Account of the Manila Department of Social Welfare.

SEC. 4. BENEFICIARIES. - The amount of One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) per beneficiary shall be given to the barangay-identified beneficiaries, who were not able to avail of the funding from Ordinance No. 8625, as financial assistance to be distributed to various Barangays in the City of Manila to cushion the economic effect of COVID-19
crisis and to enable the people of Manila to purchase much needed food and supplies for their survival.

SEC. 5. ACCOUNTABILITY. The amount appropriated in this Ordinance shall be coursed through the barangays concerned, who shall be in-charge of the proper liquidation of the said fund, subject to existing laws, rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 17, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance adds Php20 million to the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) to help more Manila residents during the COVID-19 pandemic. It supplements Ordinance No. 8625, which originally set aside Php591 million for financial aid to families in all 896 barangays of Manila.

Due to high demand and gaps in the original distribution, some families didn’t receive assistance. This ordinance addresses that gap by giving Php1,000 per eligible beneficiary (as identified by barangay officials) who missed the previous aid.

The fund comes from the Mayor’s Office – Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (Donation Account) and will be managed by the Manila Department of Social Welfare, with barangays in charge of distribution and liquidation, following standard government accounting rules.

ORDINANCE NO. 8629

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 03, SERIES OF 2020, TO APPROPRIATE THE BAYANIHAN GRANT TO THE CITY OF MANILA IN THE AMOUNT OF TWO HUNDRED NINETY-TWO MILLION SIX HUNDRED THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED EIGHTY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP. 292,600,487.00) AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) issued Local Budget Circular No. 125, dated April 7, 2020, to all local chief executives, members of the local sanggunian, local budget officers, local treasurers, local planning and development coordinators, local accountants and all other concerned to serve as guidelines on the
release and utilization of the Bayanihan Grant to Cities and Municipalities;

WHEREAS, the said Circular was in line with Republic Act (RA) No. 11469 (the Bayanihan to Heal as One Act) which granted the President the power to adopt various temporary emergency measure to respond to crisis brought about by the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic;

WHEREAS, in the same law, the President is empowered to "ensure that all Local Government Units (LGUs) are acting within the letter and spirit of all the rules, regulations and directives issued by the National Government pursuant to the said law, and are implementing standards of Community Quarantine consistent with what the National
Government has laid down for the subject area, while allowing the LGUs to continue exercising their autonomy on matters undefined by the National Government or are within the parameters it has set, and are fully cooperating towards a unified, cohesive and orderly implementation of the national policy to address COVID-19" (Section 4 (g) of RA No. 11469);

WHEREAS, the utilization of this funding shall be subject to the usual local budgeting process pursuant to the pertinent provisions of the Local Government Code of 1991 (RA No. 7160);

WHEREAS, earlier today, the local legislative body approved Resolution No. 3, Series of 2020, adopted on April 16, 2020 by the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled: "A RESOLUTION APPROVING THE AMENDMENT OF
THE ANNUAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM OR ISSUANCE OF A SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM FOR FY 2020 IN RELATION TO THE ALLOCATION OF TWO HUNDRED NINETY-TWO MILLION, SIX HUNDRED THOUSAND, FOUR HUNDRED EIGHTY-SEVEN PESOS (PHP. 292,600,487.00) FROM THE BAYANIHAN GRANT TO CITIES AND MUNICIPALITIES FOR THE CITY OF MANILA";

WHEREAS, the passage of this Supplemental Budget is in accordance with Section 321 of Republic Act No. 7160 which provides that "all budgetary proposal shall be included and considered in the budgetary preparation process. After the local chief executive concerned shall have submitted the Executive Budget to the sanggunian, no ordinance providing for a supplemental budget be enacted, except when supported by funds actually available as certified by the local treasurer or by new revenue sources.': NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Appropriation of Funds. - The Supplemental Budget, appropriating the BAYANIHAN GRANT TO THE CITY OF MANILA, in the amount of Two Hundred Ninety-Two Million Six Hundred Thousand Four Hundred Eighty-Seven Pesos
(PhP. 292,600,487.00), is hereby approved.

SEC. 2. Sources of Funds. - The source of Funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of Two Hundred Ninety-Two Million Six Hundred Thousand Four Hundred Eighty-Seven Pesos (PhP. 292,600,487.00), shall be derived from the Bayanihan Grant to the City of Manila under the Republic Act (RA) No. 11469.

SEC. 3. Use of Fund. The amount of Two Hundred Ninety-Two Million Six Hundred Thousand Four Hundred Eighty-Seven Pesos (PhP. 292,600,487.00), is hereby appropriated for the programs, activities and projects of the City Government of Manila, as follows:

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE: Office of the Mayor
MAINTENANCE and OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES(MOOE): Welfare Goods Expenses
AMOUNT: PHP 45,000,000.00

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE: Department of Social Welfare
MAINTENANCE and OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES(MOOE): Welfare Goods Expenses
AMOUNT: PHP 95,000,000.00

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE: Manila Health Department
MAINTENANCE and OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES(MOOE): Medical, Dental and Laboratory Expenses
AMOUNT: PHP 69,700,000.00

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE: Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office
MAINTENANCE and OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES(MOOE): Other Supplies and Materials Expenses
AMOUNT: PHP 10,900,487.00

MOOE SUBTOTAL: PHP 220,600,487.00

IMPLEMENTING OFFICE: Manila Health Department
MAINTENANCE and OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES(MOOE): Medical Equipment
AMOUNT: PHP 72,000,000.00

CO Subtotal: PHP 72,000,000.00

GRAND TOTAL: PHP 292,600,487.00

SEC. 4. Accountability. - A Special Account in the General Fund shall be created covering the Bayanihan Grant to the City of Manila for easy monitoring/tracking of the utilization of the fund in accordance with Section 313 of the Local Government Code. Disbursement of funds shall be subject to existing laws, rules and regulations.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 17, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance approves Supplemental Budget No. 03, Series of 2020, allocating Php292,600,487.00 to the City of Manila from the Bayanihan Grant under the Bayanihan to Heal as One Act (RA 11469). The funds are intended to support emergency COVID-19 response programs and will be used as follows:

Php45 million – Office of the Mayor: Welfare goods

Php95 million – Department of Social Welfare: Welfare goods

Php69.7 million – Manila Health Department: Medical, dental, and lab expenses

Php10.9 million – Disaster Risk Reduction Office: Supplies and materials

Php72 million – Manila Health Department: Medical equipment

The ordinance also mandates the creation of a special account in the city's general fund to track and ensure accountability of the grant's utilization.

ORDINANCE NO. 8627

AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING THE MANDATORY USE OF FACE MASKS IN ALLPUBLIC PLACES WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 15, Article II of the 1987 Philippine Constitution, provides that it is the State's policy to protect and promote the right to health of the people;

WHEREAS, Presidential Proclamation No. 922, Series of 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines in view of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and raised the Code Alert System of COVID-19 to Code Red Sublevel 2;

WHEREAS, Presidential Proclamation 929, Series 2020, further declared a State of Calamity throughout the Philippines and imposed an Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) throughout Luzon from 17 March 2020 to 12 April 2020 but was extended by the President on April 8, 2020 until 11:59 PM of April 30, 2020;

WHEREAS, the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases, through its Spokesman, Cabinet Secretary Karlo Nograles, announced in a virtual presser held on 2 April 2020, that wearing of face masks, or other similar protective equipment, is now mandatory for people who will be going out of their
homes in areas under ECQ, to further minimize the spread of the COVID-19 virus: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Mandatory use of Face Mask in Public. - All persons who are within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila are hereby MANDATED to use face masks while outside of their respective residences, offices, and all other public places. The face mask must sufficiently cover one's nose and mouth and must be worn at all times.

SEC. 2. Face Masks Allowed. Face masks, including ear loop masks, indigenous, reusable, do-it-yourself masks, handkerchiefs, or such other protective equipment that can effectively lessen the transmission of COVID-19.

SEC. 3. Penalties. There shall be imposed penalties for persons found in violation of this Ordinance, to wit:

First Offense: One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00)

Second Offense: Two Thousand Pesos (PhP. 2,000.00)

Third and Subsequent Offense: Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) or one (1) Month imprisonment or both, at the discretion of the court.

Penalties under this Ordinance is without prejudice to any charges and/or penalties that may be imposed under other existing laws.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. - All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. - If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. Effectivity. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 13, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance requires all individuals in Manila to wear face masks in public places, including streets, offices, and other areas outside their homes, to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Accepted masks include surgical masks, cloth masks, DIY masks, and similar protective gear that covers the nose and mouth.

Penalties for violations are:

1st offense: PhP1,000

2nd offense: PhP2,000

3rd and subsequent offenses: PhP5,000 or 1 month imprisonment, or both, at the court’s discretion.
fines: PHP 1,000 to PHP 5,000 and/or 1 month imprisonment
