ORDINANCE NO. 8625

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 02, SERIES OF 2020, THROUGH BUDGETARY REALIGNMENT, INVOLVING AN AMOUNT OF FIVE HUNDRED NINETY-ONE MILLION FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 591,500,000.00), FOR THE CITY AMELIORATION CRISIS ASSISTANCE FUND

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 2 of Republic Act No. 11469, provides that "Presidential Proclamation No. 922, Series of 2020, was issued declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sublevel Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases. Further, Presidential Proclamation No. 929, Series of 2020, was issued declaring a State of
Calamity throughout the Philippines and imposed an Enhanced Community Quarantine throughout Luzon.

In view of the continuing rise of confirmed cases of COVID-19, the serious threat to the health, safety, security and lives of our countrymen, the long-term adverse effects on their means of livelihood, and the severe disruption of economic activities, a state of national emergency is hereby declared over the entire country.";

WHEREAS, both Proclamations enjoined all government agencies and Local Government Units (LGUs) to render full assistance to and cooperation with each other and mobilize the necessary resources to undertake critical, urgent and appropriate disaster response aid and measures in a timely manner to curtail and eliminate the threat
of COVID-19;

WHEREAS, in the same law, the President is empowered to "ensure that all Local Government Units (LGUs) are acting within the letter and spirit of all the rules, regulations and directives issued by the National Government pursuant to the said law, and are implementing standards of Community Quarantine consistent with what the National
Government has laid down for the subject area, while allowing the LGUs to continue exercising their autonomy on matters undefined by the National Government or are within the parameters it has set, and are fully cooperating towards a unified, cohesive and orderly implementation of the national policy to address COVID-19." (Section 4 (g) of Republic Act No. 11469);

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code states that "a supplemental budget may also be enacted in times of public calamity by way of budgetary realignment to set aside appropriations for the purchase of supplies and materials or the payment of services which are exceptionally urgent or absolutely indispensable to prevent imminent danger
to, or loss of, life or property, in the jurisdiction of the Local Government Unit or in other
areas declared by the President in a state of calamity. Such ordinances shall clearly indicate the source of funds available for appropriations, as certified under oath by the local treasurer and local accountant and attested by the Local Chief Executive, and the various items of appropriations affected and the reasons for the change." (Section 321 of Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) and the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) had issued a Joint Memorandum Circular (JMC) No. 01, dated 27 March 2020, providing additional guidelines on the utilization of the Twenty Percent (20%) of the Annual Internal Revenue Allotment for Development
Projects in view of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) situation;

WHEREAS, consequently, the following policy guidelines were provided for the Local Government Unit to comply; to wit:

"2.3. All COVID-19 related expenses to be funded by the LGUs should be part of their respective approved AIPs.

In case the COVID-19 related expenses are not among those included in the approved AIP, the local development council shall prepare a supplemental investment program for the purpose, to be approved by the local sanggunian.

2.4. In case the LGUs opt to realign their existing PPAs under the 20% DF, including the continuing appropriations from previous years' 20% DF, for Covid-19 related expenses as authorized under this JMC, the LGUs concerned shall effect changes in their respective annual budgets through the following:

a. Changes in annual budgets through the supplemental budgets in accordance with Section 321 of the Code
and Article 417 of its IRR, as amended by the Administrative Order No. 47, Series of 1993;":

WHEREAS, today, the City Council was called to a special session, 12(S) for the purpose of approving Resolution No. 2, Series of 2020 of the Executive Committee of the City Development Council, entitled "A Resolution approving the amendment of the Annual Investment Program Issuance of a Supplemental Investment Program for FY 2020 in
relation to the creation of the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund in support of the Financial Assistance to residents of the City of Manila in the amount of One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) per beneficiary for the total amount of Five Hundred Ninety-One Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 591,500,000.00);

WHEREAS, the supply of basic commodities has been scarce due to the high demand and production challenges causing the difficulties in the immediate distribution of the relief goods to the entire population of the city: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT

SECTION 1. This Ordinance shall be known as "City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) 2020".

SEC. 2. The Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila for Fiscal Year 2020 in the amount of Five Hundred Ninety-One Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 591,500,000.00), through budgetary realignment, for the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund (CACAF) is hereby approved.

SEC. 3. Sources of Funds. - The sources of Funds for the Supplemental Budget in the total amount of Five Hundred Ninety-One Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 591,500,000.00), shall be derived from the following sources:

a. Office of the Mayor
[Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses(MOOE)-Expenses]
PHP 200,000,000.00

b. Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW)
(MOOE- Donation)
PHP 124,000,000.00

c. 20% City Development Fund
PHP 267,500,000.00

Total: PHP 591,500,000.00

SEC. 4. Use of Funds. The amount of Five Hundred Ninety-One Million Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 591,500,000.00) is hereby appropriated for the Supplemental Budget of the City Government of Manila as City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund under the MOOE-Donation Account of the Manila Department of Social
Welfare.

SEC. 5. Beneficiaries. - The amount of One thousand Pesos (PhP 1,000.00) per beneficiary shall be given to the barangay identified beneficiaries as financial assistance to be distributed in the 896 Barangays in the City of Manila to cushion the effect of COVID-19 crisis and to enable the people of Manila to purchase much needed food and supplies for their survival.

SEC. 6. Accountability. The amount appropriated in this Ordinance shall be coursed through the barangays concerned, who shall be in-charge of the proper liquidation of the said fund, subject to existing laws, rules and regulation.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 5, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes a supplemental budget of PhP591.5 million to establish the City Amelioration Crisis Assistance Fund. Each beneficiary in Manila's 896 barangays will receive PhP1,000 as financial aid to help cope with the COVID-19 crisis. The fund will be distributed through barangays and must be properly liquidated in accordance with laws and regulations.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8624

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING ANY PERSON FROM COMMITTING ANY ACT WHICH CAUSES STIGMA, DISGRACE, SHAME, HUMILIATION, HARASSMENT OR OTHERWISE DISCRIMINATING AGAINST A PERSON INFECTED, UNDER
MONITORING OR INVESTIGATION DUE TO THE COVID-19 VIRUS INCLUDING PUBLIC AND PRIVATE DOCTORS, NURSES, HEALTH WORKERS, EMERGENCY PERSONNEL AND VOLUNTEERS, SERVICE WORKERS WHO ARE ASSIGNED TO HOSPITALS OR OTHER CENTERS WHERE THESE PERSONS ARE BEING TREATED, AND IMPOSING THE APPROPRIATE PENALTIES THEREIN, HEREIN OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE "ANTI COVID-19 DISCRIMINATION ORDINANCE OF 2020"

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on March 9, 2020, President Rodrigo Duterte issued Proclamation No. 922, declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines, due to the Corona Virus Disease 2019 (Covid-19) and the Code Alert System for COVID-19 was raised to Code Red Sub-Level Two (2) in accordance with the recommendation of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Inter-Agency Task Force for Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF). Further, Presidential Proclamation No. 929, Series of 2020 was issued declaring a State of Calamity throughout the Philippines due to Covid-19;

WHEREAS, as of April 1, 2020, there have been two thousand three hundred eleven (2,311) confirmed cases of the COVID-19 in the Philippines, nine hundred twenty (920) cases of Patients under Investigation (PUIs) and six thousand three hundred twenty-one (6,321) Persons under Monitoring (PUMs); Out of the two thousand three hundred eleven (2,311) confirmed cases, ninety-six (96) deaths were recorded;

WHEREAS, since the emergence of COVID-19 we have seen instances of public stigmatization among persons who have contracted the disease including PUIs and PUMs, and the rise of harmful stereotypes. This means that people are being labelled, stereotyped, separated and/or experience loss of status and discrimination because of a potential negative affiliation with the disease. Stigmatization could drive people to hide the illness to avoid discrimination or prevent people from seeking health care immediately and discourage them from adopting healthy behaviors;

WHEREAS, the Department of Health (DOH) recently warned the public against discrimination against persons reported to have contracted COVID-19 as well as PUIs, PUMs including health workers and emergency workers who are among those in the front lines of the battle against the rapidly spreading COVID-19; The DOH stated "that with the world confronted with a virus with little information known, it is human to be afraid. But we must not allow hysteria and paranoia to result in irrational treatment of people";

WHEREAS, there have been several reported incidents of people being evicted out of their residences or after having recovered from the illness were prevented from returning back to their residences, while some were even doused with water and were refused services in eateries or transportations over fears of infection; Some were shunned by local stores, boarding houses, and even their own barangays and homes. Several false and inaccurate social media posts even circulated online spreading names of people alleged to have been infected with COVID-19 and urging the recipients to check if they had contact with those listed;

WHEREAS, considering the gravity of the situation, there is an urgent need to combat this pervasive stigmatization on the basis of one's medical condition; There is a need for the City to bring normalcy and order amidst the crisis, and protect its constituency from unjust discrimination brought on by fear and panic by public;

WHEREAS, it is at this trying times, families who are affected by this pandemic suffer severe anxiety and social humiliation. Hence, it is the policy of the City Government of Manila to act as parens patria during this trying times by showing compassion, empathy
and tolerance towards its affected constituents as this virus can inflict any person
regardless of race, age, sex or social standing; Only through a united front, strengthened
by our religious conviction can we fight and end this pandemic;

WHEREAS, the 1987 Philippine Constitution under Article III, Section 1 provides that every person has the right to life, liberty, security of person and privacy and the right to be free from discrimination. Furthermore, under Section 11 thereof, the State values the dignity of every person and guarantees full respect for human rights: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE - This Ordinance shall be known as "Anti Covid-19 Discrimination Ordinance of 2020".

SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. - Persons infected, Patients Under Investigation (PUIs) and Persons Under Monitoring (PUMs) are those defined by the protocols and guidelines of the Department of Health.

Health workers are those who deliver care and services to the sick and ailing, either directly or indirectly. Health workers include, among others, doctors, nurses, hospital and clinic aides, and laboratory technicians.

Frontliners include officers and members of the PNP, AFP, PCG and instrumentalities of the government rendering emergency frontline services, border control and other critical services. Frontliners also include service workers who are working in private establishments providing basic necessities and such activities related to food and medicine, production, i.e. public markets, supermarkets, groceries, convenience stores, hospitals, medical clinics, pharmacies and drug stores, food preparation and delivery services, water-refilling stations, manufacturing and processing plants of basic food products and medicines, banks, money transfer services, power, energy, telecommunications and water supplies and other related facilities.

SEC. 3. UNLAWFUL ACTS. It shall be unlawful for any person, whether natural or juridical, to commit any act or make utterances which cause or tend to cause stigma, disgrace, shame, humiliation, harassment on otherwise discriminating against a person infected, under investigation or monitoring due to Covid-19, health worker or frontliner as defined under this Ordinance.

If any public officer refuses or fails to give assistance to a person infected, under investigation or monitoring due to Covid-19, health worker or frontliner who intends to return to his place of residence or domicile, after obtaining clearance of the Covid-19 infection from the proper health officials, he/she shall be equally liable under this section.

Any person who shall publicly claim, post on social media, spread or announce that a person is infected, is under investigation or monitoring due to Covid-19 whether or not the same has been confirmed or validated from the list given by authorized proper health officials, agency or department, shall also be liable under this section. If the person violating is a public officer, the penalty imposed shall be in its maximum and can also be a ground for filing of an administrative case against said official. EXCEPT when the patient concerned waived his/her right to privacy and for purposes of contact tracing and other medical purposes.

SEC. 4. PENALTIES. - Any person caught in violation of Section 3 hereof shall be fined with Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) or imprisonment not exceeding six (6) months or both at the discretion of the court. If the offender is a public officer, the maximum penalty herein shall be imposed.

Juridical Person - If committed by a juridical person, the President, General Manager, Corporate Secretary or person with related interest in the Corporation or Partnership or Association shall be held liable or penalized accordingly.

SEC. 5. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances, rules or regulations in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed; PROVIDED, That the rights already vested under those Ordinances, rules or regulations shall not be impaired.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 2, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance makes it illegal to discriminate against people who have COVID-19, are being monitored or investigated for it (like PUIs and PUMs), or those working on the frontlines—including doctors, nurses, health workers, emergency responders, and service workers in hospitals, stores, pharmacies, and other essential services.

Acts like harassment, public shaming, online posts revealing someone’s health status, or refusing service or housing to these individuals are banned. Public officials who refuse to help these people, even after they recover, can also be punished.
fines:
₱5,000 fine, up to 6 months in jail, or both.

If the violator is a public official, the maximum penalty applies and may lead to administrative cases.

If a company violates the law, top executives like the President or General Manager will be held responsible.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8623

AN ORDINANCE TEMPORARILY SUSPENDING SURCHARGES OF ORDINANCE VIOLATION RECEIPTS ISSUED IN MARCH 2020 UNTIL THE LIFTING OF THE STATE OF PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY BY THE PRESIDENT

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, pursuant to Proclamation Numbers 922 and 929 issued by the Office of the President, an Enhanced Community Quarantine has been imposed throughout Luzon thereby cancelling classes, mass gatherings and implementing strict home quarantine protocols to mitigate the effects and slow down the further spread of the COVID-19 Pandemic;

WHEREAS, Section 16 of the Local Government Code provides that "Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants";

WHEREAS, in fulfillment of its duty to ensure public order, safety and security, the
City of Manila enforces Ordinances imposing penalties to violators within its jurisdiction,
and such penalties when left unpaid will incur surcharges;

WHEREAS, on 23 March 2020, the Congress also enacted Republic Act No. 11469 authorizing the President, among others, to move statutory deadlines and timelines for the payment of fees and other charges required by law in order to ease the burden on individuals under the Enhanced Community Quarantine;

WHEREAS, in view of the Enhanced Community Quarantine, everyone is required to stay inside his or her own residence which has critically affected workers and their livelihood rendering them unable to immediately pay their dues to the local government:
NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. COVERAGE. All surcharges of Ordinance Violation Receipts issued in March 2020 are hereby suspended until the lifting of the State of Public Health Emergency by the President.

SEC. 2. REPEALING CLAUSE. - Any provisions of ordinances, executive orders, issuances or rules and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 3. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 26, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance temporarily suspends the added surcharges or penalties for Ordinance Violation Receipts (OVRs) that were issued during March 2020, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The suspension will last until the President lifts the State of Public Health Emergency.

The goal is to help residents who were financially affected during the lockdown, especially those who lost work or income due to the Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ). People will still need to pay for their original fines, but no extra fees will be added while this ordinance is in effect.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8622

AN ORDINANCE EXTENDING THE DEADLINE FOR THE PAYMENT OF THE FIRST AND SECOND QUARTERLY INSTALLMENT OF REAL PROPERTY TAXES AND THE TAX ON THE TRANSFER OF REAL PROPERTY OWNERSHIP AS WELL AS BUSINESS TAXES UNTIL JUNE 30, 2020 WITH WAIVER OF INTEREST PENALTIES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, since 15 March 2020, the whole of Luzon has been under an Enhanced Community Quarantine which primarily prohibits anyone from leaving his or her residence in order to mitigate the effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic;

WHEREAS, on 23 March 2020, the Congress enacted Republic Act No. 11469 authorizing the President, among others, to move statutory deadlines and timelines for the payment of taxes, fees and other charges required by law in order to ease the burden on individuals under Community Quarantine;

WHEREAS, Section 167 of the Local Government Code provides that unless otherwise provided, all local taxes, fees and charges shall be paid within the first twenty (20) days of January or of each subsequent quarter, as the case may be. The Sanggunian concerned may, for a justifiable reason or cause, extend the time for payment of such taxes, fees, or charges without surcharges or penalties, but only for a period not exceeding six (6) months;

WHEREAS, considering that everyone within Luzon is required to stay inside their residences, with exemptions to health workers and those delivering basic goods and
services, to ensure public health and safety, there is an imperative need to extend the
deadline of payment until 30 June 2020: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. COVERAGE. - All Quarterly Real Property Taxes and Taxes imposed on the Transfer of Real Property (Transfer Taxes) as well as Business Taxes for the current year is hereby extended to June 30, 2020, without penalties, surcharge and interests.

SEC. 2. REPEALING CLAUSE. - Any provisions of ordinances, executive orders, issuances or rules and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 3. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 26, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance extends the deadline for paying Real Property Taxes, Transfer Taxes (for real estate ownership transfers), and Business Taxes in the City of Manila until June 30, 2020. The extension is given without any added interest, penalties, or surcharges.

This action was taken to help residents and business owners affected by the COVID-19 lockdown, especially during the Enhanced Community Quarantine when most people were not allowed to leave their homes or conduct regular business.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8621

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING ANY PERSON FROM CARELESSLY OR INTENTIONALLY SPITTING OR EXPELLING SALIVA, PHLEGM, MUCUS OR OTHER SUBSTANCES FROM THE MOUTH AND/OR NOSE IN PUBLIC PLACES SUCH AS STREETS, ALLEYS, SIDEWALKS, PARKS, MALLS, MARKETS, PUBLIC CARRIERS, PUBLIC HALLS, BUILDINGS, BANKS, PUBLIC SQUARES, TERMINALS, SHOPPING AND BUSINESS CENTERS, SCHOOLS, CHURCHES, HOSPITALS AND OTHER SIMILAR AREAS AND IMPOSING THE APPROPRIATE PENALTIES THEREIN,
OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE "ANTI-SPITTING ORDINANCE OF 2020"

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on March 9, 2020, President Rodrigo Duterte issued Proclamation No. 922, declaring the country under a State of Public Health Emergency. To prevent the spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), on March 12, 2020, during his public address on the emergency, President Duterte declared "Code Red Sub-Level 2", issuing a partial lockdown on Metro Manila;

WHEREAS, as of March 16, 2020, there have been one hundred forty (140) confirmed cases of the COVID-19 in the Philippines; Out of the one hundred forty (140) cases, twelve (12) deaths were recorded;

WHEREAS, scientific findings earlier showed that the strand of the COVID-19 can be transmitted among humans through the transfer of body fluid from one person to another;

WHEREAS, considering the gravity of the situation, there is an urgent need to institute a concrete preventive measure to stop the spread of the disease that has become a global health emergency and pandemic. These measures will not only prevent the spread of the deadly COVID-19 but also other contagious and airborne diseases; 

WHEREAS, this would also help spread environmental and health consciousness among the citizens apart from changing societal habits and unhygienic lifestyles: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. It shall be unlawful for any person to carelessly or intentionally spit or
expel saliva, phlegm, mucus or other substances from the mouth and/or nose in public
places such as streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks, malls, markets, public carriers, public
halls, buildings, banks, public squares, terminals, shopping and business centers,
schools, churches, hospitals and other similar areas.

SEC. 2. Any person caught in violation of Section 1 shall be fined with One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) for the first offense and Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) for the second offense. Any subsequent offense shall be fined with Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) and attend a health seminar conducted by the Manila Health Department or face a subsidiary imprisonment not exceeding one (1) month or both at the discretion of the court.

SEC. 3. If, for any reason or reasons, any part of provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected
thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. All ordinances, rules and regulations in conflict with the provisions of this
Ordinance are hereby repealed; PROVIDED, That the rights that are vested upon the effectivity of this Ordinance shall not be impaired.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval and publication.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 16, 2020.
short_text: Ordinance No. 8621, known as the "Anti-Spitting Ordinance of 2020," prohibits any person from spitting or expelling saliva, phlegm, mucus, or similar substances from the mouth or nose in public places such as streets, sidewalks, malls, terminals, schools, churches, hospitals, and other similar areas in Manila. This measure was enacted to help prevent the spread of COVID-19 and other airborne diseases during the declared State of Public Health Emergency.
fines: PHP 1,000 (1st offense), PHP 3,000 (2nd), PHP 5,000 + seminar or jail (subsequent offense)

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8618

AN ORDINANCE REGULATING ALL BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS AND PRESCRIBING SAFETY MEASURES FOR THE PROTECTION OF CONSUMERS IN THE CITY OF MANILA AGAINST HOARDING, PROFITEERING AND CARTELS WITH RESPECT TO SUPPLY, DISTRIBUTION, MARKETING AND PRICING OF GOODS AND MEDICINES DURING CALAMITY AND EMERGENCY SITUATIONS AND SIMILAR OCCASIONS AND PROVIDING PENALTY FOR VIOLATION THEREOF

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the 1987 Constitution provides that; the "maintenance of peace and order, the protection of life, liberty, and property, and the promotion of general welfare are essential for the enjoyment by all the people of the blessings of democracy (Section 5,
Article II, Declaration of Principles and State Policies), Also, "The State shall protect and promote the right of health of the people and instill health consciousness among them"
(Sections 15, Article II, Declaration of Principles and State Policies);

WHEREAS, the Price Act clearly articulated the following: "It is the policy of the State to ensure the availability of basic necessities and prime commodities at reasonable prices at all times without denying legitimate business a fair return on investment. It is also a declared policy of the State to provide effective and sufficient protection to consumers against hoarding, profiteering and cartels with respect to the supply. distribution, marketing and pricing of said goods especially during periods of calamity, emergency, widespread illegal price manipulation and other similar situations." (Section 2, Republic Act No. 7581, May 27, 1992);

WHEREAS, the General Welfare Clause under the Local Government Code likewise stated that: "Every local government shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotions of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdiction, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants." (Section 16, Republic Act No. 7160);

WHEREAS, on March 8, 2020, President Rodrigo Roa Duterte issued Proclamation No. 922 Declaring the Philippines Under the State of Public Health Emergency In View of the Novel Coronavirus Disease or COVID-19 outbreak;

WHEREAS, consequently, an Executive Order No. 14, Series of 2020, was issued by His Honor, Mayor Francisco "Isko Moreno" Domagoso, providing for precautionary measures to contain the spread of Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19), including suspension of all public events and mass gatherings organized by or to be conducted in collaboration with the City Government of Manila;

WHEREAS, the Department of Health has confirmed a growing number of cases infected by the virus in our country particularly in the National Capital Region (NCR). In fact, this virus has affected more than a hundred countries worldwide and a significant number of people were reported to have been inflicted with several fatalities prompting the World Health Organization (WHO) to declare the outbreak as a pandemic;

WHEREAS, despite this catastrophic incident, unscrupulous businessmen are taking advantage of this appalling situation to earn more profit by hoarding, profiteering and cartels on basic necessities and prime commodities: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. - This Ordinance shall be known as "Anti-Hoarding, Profiteering and Cartel Ordinance of the City of Manila".

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms. - For purposes of this Ordinance, the terms:

(1) "Basic necessities" are goods vital to the needs of consumers for their sustenance
and existence in times of any of the cases provided under the Sections 6 and 7 of the
Price Act, such as, but not limited to, rice, corn, bread, fresh, dried and canned fish
and other marine products, fresh pork, beef and poultry meal, fresh eggs, potable
water in bottles and containers, fresh and processed milk, fresh vegetables, locally
manufactured instant noodles, root crops, coffee, sugar, cooking oil, salt, laundry
soap, detergents, firewood, charcoal, household liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and
kerosene, candles, and drugs classified as essential by the Department of Health and
such other goods as may be included under Section 4 of the Price Act, unless
otherwise excluded;

(2) "Cartel" is committed when any combination of or agreement between two (2) or more
persons engaged in the production, manufacture, processing, storage, supply, distribution, marketing, sale or disposition of any basic necessity or prime commodity designed to artificially and unreasonably increase or manipulate its price;

(3) "Hoarding" is the undue accumulation by a person or combination of persons of any
basic commodity beyond his or their normal inventory levels or the unreasonable
limitation or refusal to dispose of, sell or distribute the stocks of any basic necessity of prime commodity to the general public or the unjustified taking out of any basic
necessity or prime commodity from the channels of reproduction, trade, commerce
and industry;

(4) "Panic-buying" is the abnormal phenomenon where consumers buy basic necessities
and prime commodities grossly in excess of their normal requirement resulting in
undue shortages of such goods to the prejudice of less privileged consumers;

(5) "Person" means a natural person or juridical person;

(6) "Prevailing price" means the average price at which any basic necessity has been
sold in a given time within a month from the occurrence of any of the conditions
enumerated under Section 6 of the Price Act

(7) "Price ceiling" means the maximum price at which any basic necessity or prime
commodity may be sold to the general public;

(8) "Prime commodities" include fresh fruits; flours; dried processed and canned pork;
beef and poultry meat; dairy products not falling under basic necessities; noodles;
onions; garlic; vinegar, patis; soy sauce; toilet soap; fertilizer; pesticides; herbicides;
poultry; swine; and cattle feeds; veterinary products for poultry, swine and cattle;
paper; school supplies; nipa shingles; sawali; cement; clinker, Gl sheets; hollow
blocks; plywood; plyboard; construction nails; flashlight, batteries; electrical supplies:
light bulbs; steel wire; and all drugs not classified as essential drugs by the Department
of Health; and

(9) "Profiteering" is the sale or offering for sale of any basic necessity or prime commodity at a price grossly in excess of its true worth.

SEC. 3. Coverage. - Unless otherwise provided by any law or ordinance, all business establishments within the City of Manila are covered by this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Illegal Acts. - It shall be unlawful for any business establishment operating within the City of Manila to commit an act of hoarding, profiteering and/or cartel.
The prima facie evidence of hoarding, profiteering and/or cartel are those defined under
Section 5 of Republic Act No. 7581.

SEC. 5. Mandatory Requirements for all Business Establishments in the City of Manila during the period of calamity or emergency situation and similar occasions. - During the effectivity of this Ordinance, all business establishments within the City of Manila are mandated to comply the following:

(1) Posting in a conspicuous place the following list of the items together with the
prevailing price and limitations regulated by this Ordinance;

(2) All basic necessity or prime commodity being sold should have its corresponding price
tag:

(3) Subject to reasonable changes as may be duly determined by the implementing
offices, there shall be limitations of items to be sold per person per day. The list of the
Kind of Goods with its corresponding Limit for individual consumers and for registered
retailers, sari-sari store customers, restaurants, hotels, and the likes is attached and
marked herewith as ANNEX "A" and intended to be made part and parcel of this
Ordinance.

SEC. 6. Powers and Responsibility of the City Mayor. - The City Mayor or his duly authorized representative shall have the following additional powers and responsibilities to carry out the intents and purposes of this Ordinance.

(1) The City Mayor is authorized to create a special task force for the proper
implementation and monitoring of this Ordinance and to issue, if necessary, additional
implementing rules and regulation covering additional items and goods that need
regulation or deregulation;

(2) The City Mayor is also authorized, upon recommendation of the task force, to add
items to the list of basic necessities and prime commodities enumerated in Section 5
(3) of this Ordinance.

(3) Institute and establish temporary measures to ensure orderly and equitable distribution
of sale to consumers so as to avoid hoarding, profiteering and cartel of basic necessities and prime commodities during the time of emergency.

SEC. 7. Appropriations. - To carry out the provisions of this Ordinance, such amount as hereby necessary is hereby authorized to be appropriated from the calamity fund or discretionary fund under the Office of the Mayor.

SEC. 8. Penalty. - Any establishment found violating this Ordinance shall suffer the penalty of closure and/or revocation of their Mayor's and/or Business Permits and
shall be prohibited from doing business in the City of Manila for a period not to exceed
Five (5) years to be reckoned from the time of closure and/or revocation of permits. This
does not preclude the City Government from filing appropriate charges of violating the
Price Act law, among others.

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. - Any City Ordinance contrary to or inconsistent with any provisions of this Ordinance is hereby repealed and/or modified accordingly.

SEC. 10. Separability Clause. If, for any reason, a part of this Ordinance is declared illegal or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof which are not affected thereby
shall remain valid and in full force and effect.

SEC. 11. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon
approval due to the urgency of the concern caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Should
the declared state of emergency be lifted, the regulations imposed in this Ordinance shall
accordingly be suspended. This Ordinance shall be effective during the time that the
President of the Philippines shall declare the entire country, or part thereof which includes the City of Manila, under the state of emergency or calamity or any similar situation and/or the City Mayor shall declare the entire City under the state of emergency or calamity or any similar situation. Should the City Mayor declare only part or portion of the City under the state of emergency or calamity or any similar situation, only in that part or portion of the City that this Ordinance shall apply.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 14, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance regulates business practices during calamities and emergencies (e.g., the COVID-19 pandemic) to protect consumers from hoarding, profiteering, and cartels related to essential goods and medicines. All businesses in Manila must comply with strict rules, such as displaying price lists and limiting quantities of key goods sold per customer.

Violators face business permit revocation, closure, and up to 5 years of prohibition from operating in Manila. The Mayor may also form a task force and expand the list of regulated goods as needed. The ordinance remains in effect during declared states of emergency or calamity affecting the city.
fines: Business closure, permit revocation, up to 5 years ban from operating, plus possible legal charges under the Price Act.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8617

AN ORDINANCE IMPOSING A TEMPORARY CLOSURE OF ALL MALLS AND SIMILAR ESTABLISHMENTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA DURING THE IMPOSITION OF THE COMMUNITY QUARANTINE PURSUANT TO THE RESOLUTION OF THE METRO MANILA COUNCIL IN RESPONSE TO THE COMMUNITY QUARANTINE DECLARED BY HIS EXCELLENCY, PRESIDENT RODRIGO ROA DUTERTE

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on March 12, 2020, the Inter Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Disease, with the approval of President Rodrigo Roa Duterte, raised the Code Alert Level to Code Red Sublevel Two and the imposition of stringent Social Distancing Measure in the National Capital Region (NCR) for thirty (30) days, effective March 15, 2020;

WHEREAS, the Metro Manila Council, during the meeting held on March 14, 2020, agreed to pass a resolution for all Local Government Units in the NCR to pass an Ordinance implementing the temporary closure of malls and similar establishments in the City of Manila to further implement the SOCIAL DISTANCING measures to CONTAIN and DELAY the further spread of COVID-19 in the Metropolitan Area, and to the whole country;

WHEREAS, this measure is necessary for the duration of the imposition of the Community Quarantine ordered by the President: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Imposition of Temporary Closure. - There is hereby imposed a temporary closure of the malls and similar establishments in the City of Manila for the duration of the community quarantine as ordered by the Inter Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Disease with the approval of the President, starting March 15, 2020 to April 14, 2020.

SEC. 2. Exceptions. - For the duration of the temporary closure, those offering essential services such as, but not limited to, groceries, supermarkets, pharmacies, restaurants with home deliveries, bank services, and establishments offering medical services shall be exempted from this Ordinance.

SEC. 3. Role of the City Department. - The City Department with the responsibility to implement this Ordinance is ordered to monitor and supervise the implementation of this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Penalties. - Any offender of this Ordinance shall be penalized as follows:

1. First Offense - Warning will be issued;

2. Second Offense - Suspension of Business Permit;

3. Third Offense and Subsequent Offense-cancellation of Business Permit;

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. - If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or
declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. - SEC. 11. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon approval due to the urgency of the concern caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Should the declared state of emergency be lifted, the regulations imposed in this Ordinance shall accordingly be suspended. This Ordinance shall be effective during the time that the President of the Philippines shall declare the entire country, or part thereof which includes the City of Manila, under the state of emergency or calamity or any similar situation and/or the City Mayor shall declare the entire City under the state of emergency or calamity or any similar situation. Should the City Mayor declare only part or portion of the City under the state of emergency or calamity or any similar situation, only in that part or portion of the City that this Ordinance shall apply.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 14, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance mandates the temporary closure of all malls and similar establishments in Manila from March 15 to April 14, 2020, in line with the national community quarantine to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Establishments offering essential services—such as groceries, pharmacies, banks, medical facilities, and restaurants with delivery—are exempt.

Violations lead to escalating penalties: first offense (warning), second offense (business permit suspension), and third/subsequent offenses (permit cancellation). The ordinance remains effective during any declared state of emergency or calamity involving the City of Manila.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8616

AN ORDINANCE IMPOSING CURFEW IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM EIGHT O'CLOCK IN THE EVENING (8:00 PM) TO FIVE O'CLOCK IN THE MORNING (5:00 AM) DURING THE IMPOSITION OF COMMUNITY QUARANTINE PURSUANT TO THE RESOLUTION OF THE METRO MANILA COUNCIL IN RESPONSE TO THE COMMUNITY QUARANTINE DECLARED BY HIS EXCELLENCY, PRESIDENT RODRIGO ROA DUTERTE

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, on March 12, 2020, the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management
of Emerging Infectious Disease, with the approval of President Rodrigo Roa Duterte,
raised the Code Alert Level to Code Red Sublevel Two and the imposition of stringent
Social Distancing Measures in the National Capital Region (NCR) for thirty (30) days,
effective March 15, 2020;

WHEREAS, the Metro Manila Council, during the meeting held on March 14, 2020, agreed to pass a resolution for all Local Government Unit in the NCR to pass an Ordinance implementing a curfew for all residents and persons in the jurisdiction of the LGUs between 8:00 pm to 5:00 am to further implement the SOCIAL DISTANCING measures to CONTAIN and DELAY the further spread of the Covid-19 in the Metropolitan Area, and to the whole country;

WHEREAS, this measure is necessary during the duration of the imposition of the
Community Quarantine ordered by the President: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Imposition of Curfew Hours; Covered Persons. - There is hereby imposed curfew hours for all persons in the City of Manila between Eight O'clock in the Evening (8:00 PM) to Five O'clock in the morning (5:00 AM) during the duration of the community quarantine imposed by the National Government.

SEC. 2. Exceptions. - During curfew hours, no persons shall be allowed in the streets, commercial establishments, recreation centers, malls or any other areas outside the immediate vicinity of their residence, except in cases of emergency or for the purpose
of purchase of food and essential basic necessities and prime commodities and work
related travels.

The movement of cargoes within the City of Manila shall be unhampered.

SEC. 3. Role of the Barangays. The Punong Barangay, members of the Barangay Council and the duly designated Barangay Tanods are hereby authorized to implement the provision of this Ordinance

SEC. 4. Guidelines in Apprehension. Offenders of this Ordinance shall be
apprehended in accordance with the guidelines to implement the provisions of this
Ordinance:

1. The apprehending official or officer shall, without necessary delay, accompany the offender immediately to his/her residence. In case the offender is a minor, notify the family member/s of the offender and release the offender in recognizance to said family member/s with the understanding that the offender shall be submitted to the Punong
Barangay for the corresponding penalty under Section 5 of this Ordinance;

2. In case the offender refuses to be accompanied to his/her residence, the apprehending official shall seek the support of the Philippine National Police (PNP) for proper arrest and detention; and

3. For an offender who is homeless, abandoned, neglected, or have no known family member, the apprehending official or officer shall refer the offender to the custody of the Manila Department of Social Welfare concerned within twenty-four (24) hours of apprehension.

SEC. 5. Penalties. - Any person found violating the provisions of this Ordinance
shall be fined of not more than Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00), at the discretion
of the Court and/or imprisonment of not more one (1) month;

SEC. 6. Role of the Philippine National Police (PNP). - the Philippine National
Police shall provide police support to the Punong Barangays whenever needed for the
enforcement of this Act.

SEC. 7. Separability Clause. If any provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or inoperative, the other provisions not so declared shall remain in force
and effect.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. All laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations or parts thereof inconsistent with the Act or the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto are hereby repealed and amended accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 14, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance enforces a city-wide curfew in Manila from 8:00 PM to 5:00 AM during the period of community quarantine beginning March 15, 2020. People are prohibited from being outside their residences during curfew hours except for emergencies, buying essential goods, or work-related travel. Cargo transport remains unhampered.

Barangays and the PNP are authorized to enforce the ordinance. Offenders may be accompanied home or turned over to authorities if needed. Penalties include a fine up to PHP 5,000 or imprisonment of up to one month, at the court's discretion.
fines: Up to PHP 5,000 fine and/or imprisonment up to 1 month

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8615

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING MONETARY REWARD TO QUALIFIED MANILA DAY CARE TEACHERS UNDER THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE IN THE CITY OF MANILA, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the National Government, through the Department of Social Welfare and Development, in prioritizing its commitment to human development concerns of children, as a response to the country's ratification of the Convention of the Rights of Children on July 26, 1990, recognizes the role of Day Care Service and other Early Childhood Care and Development programs for their well-being;

WHEREAS, Day Care Teachers are tasked to take care of children of the City of Manila under the Early Childhood Care and Development program;

WHEREAS, despite the delicate and important role of Day Care Teachers, they do not have plantilla items in government;

WHEREAS, despite their predicament, they continue to nurture and educate children like their own: an invaluable role in rearing of the next generation of Manileños that needs to be rewarded;

WHEREAS, in recognition of the Day Care Teachers' tireless commitment to their students, the City of Manila intends to reward them as they end their service absent the benefits given to regular government employees: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. TITLE. This Ordinance shall be known as "THE DAY CARE TEACHERS WELFARE ORDINANCE OF 2020" for brevity.

SEC. 2. BENEFICIARY OF THIS ORDINANCE. - Day Care Teachers under the MDSW shall qualify to benefit from this Ordinance under the following conditions:

1. rendered at least fifteen (15) years of service as Day Care Teachers in the City of Manila; or

2. have reached sixty (60) years old and provided that the Day Care Teacher has rendered at least ten (10) years of service as Day Care Teacher in the City of Manila under the MDSW.

SEC. 3. MONETARY REWARD. - Monetary Reward, which shall be availed of only once, shall be given to the following:

a.  THIRTY THOUSAND PESOS (PhP. 30,000.00) to the Day Care Teacher who has reached sixty (60) years old, PROVIDED, that the said beneficiary has rendered at least ten (10) years of service as Day Care Teacher in the City of Manila under the MDSW; and

b.  FIFTY THOUSAND PESOS (PhP. 50,000.00) to the Day Care Teacher who has rendered at least fifteen (15) years of service as Day Care Teacher in the City of Manila under the MDSW.

Further, a plaque of appreciation recognizing their years of service will be given together with the monetary reward.

SEC. 4. APPROPRIATION. - The City Government shall appropriate funds which shall be used for purposes mandated by this Ordinance in the city's Annual Executive Budget and in every succeeding budget year thereafter.

SEC. 5. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions thereof not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with
the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified or amended accordingly.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 2, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance grants a monetary reward to qualified Day Care Teachers under the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW). Eligible teachers are those who:

Have rendered at least 15 years of service, or

Have reached 60 years old with at least 10 years of service.

Qualified teachers will receive a PHP 30,000 reward (for those aged 60+ with 10 years of service) or a PHP 50,000 reward (for those with 15 years of service), along with a plaque of appreciation. Funds will be included in the city's annual budget.

ORDINANCE NO. 8609

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING CITY ORDINANCE NO. 6511, AS AMENDED BY CITY ORDINANCE NO. 7971, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING THE DEFACING, BY PAINTING, WRITING, SCRIBBLING,
SCRAWLING, DRAWING, SMEARING, COLORING, STAMPING OR INSCRIBING OF WALLS, SIDINGS, PARTITIONS, FENCES, GATES, DOORS OR WINDOW PANES OF BUILDING, EDIFICES, HOUSES OR STRUCTURES, WHETHER PUBLIC OR PRIVATE, OF LAMPPOSTS, STREET SIGNS, STREETS, SIDEWALKS OR OTHER PUBLIC PROPERTY, WITH CERTAIN EXCEPTIONS AND PROVIDING PENALTY FOR VIOLATION THEREOF AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES"

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, property owners of both public and private property spent time, money, efforts and other resources to clean and/or paint walls and fences, as well as maintain the same free from any and all forms of graffiti;

WHEREAS, the City Government and Barangays often embarked on a cleanliness campaign including the cleaning and/or painting of walls, fences and other surface within
their respective jurisdiction;

WHEREAS, despite serious campaign and effort on the part of the City Government, the Barangays, as well as private owners to eradicate, if not discourage, any form of vandalism and acts of defacement destructive of the aesthetic appearance of walls, fences and other surfaces, the same remain unabated;

WHEREAS, under the guise of expressing one's opinion, belief and principle, political or otherwise, there are individual or group of persons that use, utilize and convert
walls, fences and other surfaces as platform without regards to the costs of removing the
same;

WHEREAS, there is a need to increase the severity of any and all forms of vandalism and acts of destructive defacement to discourage any individual or group of persons from vandalizing walls, fences and other surfaces, as well as encourage property owners to maintain the cleanliness of these structures: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Ordinance No. 6511, as amended by Ordinance No. 7971 is hereby further amended, to read as follows:

"SECTION 1. This Ordinance shall be called "THE ANTI-VANDALISM ORDINANCE OF 2019".

SEC. 2. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface or cause to be defaced, by painting, writing, scribbling, scrawling, drawing, smearing coloring, stamping or inscribing the walls, sidings, partitions, fences, gates, doors or window panes of buildings, edifices, houses or structures, whether public or private, lampposts, street signs, streets, sidewalks or other public property, except when done with the consent and authority of the owner, with respect to privately-owned property, or when duly authorized by the Mayor, with respect to the public property.

SEC. 3. Any person caught in flagrante delicto by any public officer or private citizen committing the act/s enumerated in the preceding section under the principle of warrantless arrest shall be brought immediately to the nearest police station for proper disposition.

In addition, but without prejudice to further prosecution for the violation of this Ordinance, he may, at his option, be required to clean, wash, erase and perform any and all acts necessary to restore the structures vandalized to its original condition and/or reimburse the expenses thereof incurred by the City of Manila or the private owner with undertaking that a repetition of the same with be dealt with more severely.

SEC. 4. Any person found violating or infringing this Ordinance shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) but not more than Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) or imprisonment of not less than six (6) months nor more than one (1) year or both such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court.

In addition to the penalty herein imposed, the offender shall also be liable for the expenses incurred to restore the defaced and/or vandalized structures.

SEC. 5. All Punong Barangays, Kagawads and their respective Barangay Tanods are likewise mandated to monitor, investigate and coordinate with the proper authorities for proper implementation of this Ordinance; PROVIDED, That every Barangay shall, through a duly approved resolution, submit to the City Council a monthly report of their performance in monitoring the afore-stated prohibited acts.

SEC. 6. Copies of this Ordinance shall always be posted in all barangay outposts."

SEC. 2. Separability Clause. - If any provision of the ordinance or the application
of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions
thereof not affected hereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules
and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the
provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified, or amended accordingly.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 23, 2020.ORDINANCE NO. 8609

short_text: This ordinance strengthens the city's anti-vandalism laws by prohibiting the defacement of public and private property (e.g., walls, fences, street signs, lampposts) without proper authorization. Offenders caught in the act may be arrested, fined PHP 1,000 to PHP 5,000, jailed for 6 months to 1 year, or both. They must also restore or reimburse the damage. Barangays are required to monitor and report such violations monthly to the City Council.
fines: PHP 1,000 to PHP 5,000 fine and/or 6 months to 1 year imprisonment; reimbursement of damage repair costs

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8608

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE MANILA MUSLIM CEMETERY AND CULTURAL HALL AT THE MANILA SOUTH CEMETERY, CREATING THE MANILA MUSLIM CEMETERY DIVISION, APPROPRIATING THE AMOUNT NECESSARY
FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CEMETERY, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. - Declaration of Policy. It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to confer recognition to the Muslim community in Manila with their inherent cultural attributes and customary traditions, especially in terms of caring for the remains of their departed, by defining a burial ground in the South Cemetery and a special body intended to manage the same.

SEC. 2. Establishment of a Manila Muslim Cemetery in the South Cemetery. - A Manila Muslim Cemetery is hereby established at Manila South Cemetery, especially a portion situated at Section N thereof, measuring Thirty Meters (30 M.) in length and Eighty Meters (80 M.) in width, or with an area of Two Thousand Four Hundred Square Meters (2,400 Sq. M.) as an exclusive ground for the interment and transfer of the remains of deceased Muslim residents of the City of Manila.

SEC. 3. Establishment of a Manila Muslim Cemetery Cultural Hall. - Inside the premises of the Manila Muslim Cemetery, a Manila Muslim Cemetery Cultural Hall, otherwise known as the Cultural Hall, is likewise hereby established measuring Five Meters (5 M.) in length and Ten Meters (10 M.) in width or with an area of Fifty Square Meters (50 Sq. M.).

SEC. 4. Control and Supervision of the Manila Muslim Cemetery and Cultural Hall. - The control and supervision of the operations of the Manila Muslim Cemetery and Cultural Hall, including the requirement of a burial permit, the standard requirements for gravesites, and the procedure for the interment and transfer of remains, shall be under the Manila Health Department (MHD) through the Manila South Cemetery, provided that, observation of certain practices and traditions indigenous to the Muslim Culture may be allowed.

SEC. 5. Creation of the Manila Muslim Cemetery Division. - A Manila Muslim Cemetery Division is hereby created, composed of the following personnel who shall hold office in the Manila South Cemetery:

a.  Administrative Officer III as Division Chief
b.  Administrative Officer II as Assistant Division Chief
c.  Administrative Officer I
d.  Security Guard
e.  Administrative Aide I
f.  Administrative Aide I
g.  Administrative Aide I

The composition of the Manila Muslim Cemetery Division shall be taken from available position existing in the Manila South Cemetery, as well as the Manila North Cemetery, provided that the exigency of the operations of the said cemeteries is not compromised.

SEC. 6. Functions of the Manila Muslin Cemetery Division. The Manila Muslim Cemetery Division shall have the following duties and functions:

a.  Oversee the implementation of this Ordinance in coordination with the Manila
Health Department (MHD);
b.  Supervise the construction of the Manila Muslim Cemetery and the Cultural
Hall, as well as the development of the individual graves therein pursuant to
the Sanitation Code;
c.  Require the submission of a burial permit and barangay certification of ante-mortem residence for every deceased Muslim to be buried in the cemetery; and
d.  Create and maintain a database of qualified deceased Muslim interred in the
cemetery and transferred thereto with copies thereof furnished the Manila
South Cemetery at the start of every fiscal year.

SEC. 7. Appropriations. The amount of Forty-Nine Million Three Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 49,300,000.00), or so much thereof, is hereby appropriated out of the unappropriated funds of the City Government, to be taken for the purpose of financing the construction of the Manila Muslim Cemetery and the Cultural Hall, and additional appropriations including those relating to the Operating Expenditures and Capital Outlay of the Manila Muslim Cemetery Division shall be provided in the appropriate Annual Executive Budget of the City Government.

SEC. 8. Implementing Rules and Regulations. - Within the period of thirty (30) days from the effectivity of this Ordinance, the MHD, in coordination of the City Personnel Office (CPO) and the Department of Engineering and Public Works (DEPW), shall formulate rules and regulations implementing the provisions hereof, which shall include the following:

a. The acquisition of qualified technical specifications of the structure of the
Manila Muslim Cemetery and the Cultural Hall, without prejudice to consultations with organized Muslim groups in Manila in terms of aesthetic designs based on indigenous cultural practices;
b.  The qualifications of the personnel of the Manila Muslim Cemetery Division,
with preference to qualified Muslim residents; and
c.  The availability of the Manila Muslim Cemetery and Cultural Hall in relation to
the traditional requirement of the interment within twenty-four (24) hours from
the point of death of any qualified Muslim resident.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect after its publication in any newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 17, 2020.
short_text: This ordinance establishes a dedicated Muslim cemetery and cultural hall within the Manila South Cemetery to honor Islamic burial customs. It creates the Manila Muslim Cemetery Division to oversee operations, burial permits, and compliance with cultural practices. A PHP 49.3 million budget is allocated for construction and operations. The cemetery will serve as an exclusive burial ground for Muslim residents of Manila, respecting the traditional requirement of burial within 24 hours of death.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8607

AN ORDINANCE DECLARING A PARCEL OF LAND, KNOWN THEN AS DECS PROPERTY, LOCATED AT ARROCEROS STREET, MANILA, ACROSS THE STREET FROM THE METROPOLITAN THEATER AND THE MEHAN GARDEN AND BESIDE THE PASIG RIVER, AS A PERMANENT FOREST PARK PURSUANT TO REPUBLIC ACT NO. 5752, ΤΟ ΒΕ KNOWN AS THE "ARROCEROS FOREST PARK" AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 3-A of Republic Act No. 5752, as amended, provides that every municipality or city shall exert efforts to establish, develop and maintain a permanent forest, tree parks or watershed within public land owned by such municipality or city with an aggregate size equivalent to at least two (2) percent of its entire area within two (2) years from the approval of this Act; Provided, that the forest, park or watershed may be located in one or more places within the municipality or city;

WHEREAS, in 1993, the City of Manila, represented by then Mayor Alfredo S. Lim, entered into a Memorandum of Agreement with the Winner Foundation, Inc., to create and develop a forest park in the city for the purpose of beautifying and enhancing the ecological environment within the city;

WHEREAS, the City of Manila designated the former DECS property owned by the City of Manila and located at Arroceros Street, Manila, across the street from the Metropolitan Theater and the Mehan Garden, and beside the Pasig River, to be developed as a forest park in accordance with the Memorandum of Agreement: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. - This Ordinance shall be known and referred to as the "Arroceros Forest Park Ordinance".

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy. It shall be the policy of the City of Manila, hereinafter referred to as the City, to protect and conserve the integrity of the last environmental frontier of the City - a two-hectare parcel of land with thousands of trees, otherwise known as the Arroceros Forest Park, which possesses significance for scientific, educational and recreational use and may be effectively managed and administered through cooperation among the City residents, national government, civil society and business sector. It is further recognized that the use and enjoyment of the Arroceros Forest Park must be consistent with the principles of sustainable development, and the right of the people to a balanced and healthful ecology.

It shall further be the policy of the City to establish and develop permanent forests,
tree parks and watersheds within the City with an aggregate size equivalent to at least
two (2) percent of its entire area, pursuant to Republic Act No. 5752.

SEC. 3. Declaration as a Permanent Forest Park. - Pursuant to the duty of the City to establish, develop and maintain permanent forests, tree parks and watersheds as instructed in Letter of Instruction No. 1312 (1983) and provided in Republic Act No. 5752, the Arroceros Forest Park is hereby withdrawn from sale and declared a permanent Forest Park and shall be known henceforth as the "Arroceros Forest Park".

Moreover, the "Arroceros Forest Park" is hereby declared open to the public, subject to the payment of appropriate Environmental User Fees, in recognition of its significance for scientific, educational and recreational use.

SEC. 4. Scope. - The Arroceros Forest Park, shall have the following technical description:

A parcel of land (Lot 2-B of the subdivision plan (LRC) Psd-31622), approved
as a non-subdivision project, being a portion of Lot 2, Block 304, Manila
Cadastre (Ap-25497); L.R.C Record No. N44385), situated in the District of
Ermita, City of Manila, Island of Luzon. Bounded on the NE., points 7 to 17 &
17 to 1, by Pasig River; on the SE., points 1 to 3, by Lot 1, Block 304, Manila
Cadastre; on the SW., points 3 to 4, by Arroceros Street; and points 5 to 7, by
Calle Colgante (Quezon Bridge).

SEC. 4-A. Ordinance No. 8593, as approved last November 25, 2019, shall form part of this Ordinance, providing for the permanent closure and withdrawal from public use of a portion of Arroceros Street, Manila, bounded in the East by LRT Central Station, in the West by the Metropolitan Theater, in the North by the Riverside Drive and in the South by Dr. Basa Street, with an aggregate area of 1,144.34 square meters, more or less, to be converted and developed as part of the Arroceros Forest Park for the purpose of enhancing the ecological environment within the city pursuant to Section 16 of the Local Government Code of 1991, with the following technical description:

Bounded on the NE, points 1-2, by Riverside Drive, on the SW., points 9-
10, by Dr. Basa Street, on the SE., points 2-9, by LRT Central Station and
on the NW., points 10-15 and 15-1, by the Metropolitan Theater.

SEC. 5. Management Plan. - After consultation with the residents of the City, civil
society and stakeholders, the City, together with the existing partner/s in the management
of the Arroceros Forest Park, shall formulate a management plan, incorporating the
proposals raised in the consultations. The Management Plan shall, at the minimum,
promote the adoption and implementation of innovative management techniques
including, if necessary, community organizing, socio-economic and scientific researches,
among others. The Management Plan shall be subject to review every five years, or as
often as may be necessary.

The City of Manila, which has the sole control and supervision over the subject
Forest Park, shall create an Arroceros Forest Park Governing Committee, as part of the
Management Plan and thereafter, corresponding Executive Order shall be issued by the
Office of the Mayor constituting the powers, functions and composition of the said
Governing Committee.

SEC. 6. Arroceros Forest Park Fund. The City shall initially appropriate One
Million Pesos (PhP. 1,000,000.00) for the operation of Arroceros Forest Park, which funds
shall go to the Arroceros Forest Park Fund, hereinafter referred to as the Fund. In
addition, Environmental User Fees collected pursuant to Section 7 hereof, and the fines
collected pursuant to Section 9 hereof, shall form part of the Fund. The Fund shall be
used solely for the conservation, protection and management of the Arroceros Forest
Park.

SEC. 7. Environmental User Fees. - Environmental User Fees shall be collected, which are prescribed as follows:

Residents of the City of Manila: PhP. 5.00
Visitors from outside of the City of Manila: PhP. 15.00
Visitors under humanitarian programs: Exempted

SEC. 8. Prohibited Acts. Except as may be allowed under the Management
Plan, the following acts are prohibited within the Arroceros Forest Park:

a.  Hunting, destroying, disturbing or mere possession of any plants or animals or
products derived from them;
b.  Archaeological digging, and other forms of excavations;
c.  Dumping of any waste products detrimental to the Arroceros Forest Park, or to
the plants and animals or inhabitants therein;
d.  Mutilating, defacing or destroying objects of natural beauty, or objects of
interest to cultural communities (of scenic value);
e.  Damaging and leaving roads and trails in a damaged condition;
f.  Squatting, mineral locating, or otherwise occupying any part of the land;
g.  Constructing or maintaining any kind of structure, fence or enclosures,
conducting any business enterprise without permit;
h.  Leaving in exposed or unsanitary conditions refuse or debris, or depositing in
ground or in bodies of water;
i.  Altering, removing, destroying or defacing boundary marks or signs; and
j.  Any other acts inimical to the declared policy of protection and conservation
stated in Section 2 hereof.

SEC. 9. Penalties. The following penalties shall be imposed upon violators of this Ordinance:

a. First Offense: A fine of Two Thousand Five Hundred Pesos (PhP. 2,500.00)

b. Second Offense: A fine of Three Thousand Five Hundred Pesos (PhP. 3,500.00)

c. Third Offense: A fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) and/or imprisonment of not exceeding one (1) year, depending upon the discretion of the court.

SEC. 10. Peace Officers. The City shall deputize individuals who will act as Peace Officers and who may issue citations for violations against individuals who commit any of the prohibited acts enumerated under Section 8.

SEC. 11. Separability Clause. Should any provision of this Ordinance be declared invalid or unconstitutional, any provision not affected thereby shall remain valid and enforceable.

SEC. 12. Repealing Clause. Any ordinance whose provisions are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed.

SEC. 13. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance, upon approval, shall take effect after fifteen (15) days from publication in a newspaper of general circulation pursuant to Section 59 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 20, 2020.
short_text:
The City of Manila has officially designated a two-hectare area located in Arroceros Street (across from the Metropolitan Theater, near the Mehan Garden, and beside the Pasig River) as the Arroceros Forest Park. This green space is meant to be a permanent park for everyone to enjoy, providing a clean, beautiful, and environmentally healthy area in the city.

The City aims to protect this area from being sold or used for other purposes, keeping it as a public forest park for future generations. The park is open to the public, and there will be a small entrance fee:

PHP 5 for Manila residents

PHP 15 for non-residents
(Those visiting under humanitarian programs are exempt from the fee.)

The ordinance ensures that the Arroceros Forest Park is not only a place for recreation but also for scientific and educational purposes. This will be done while ensuring that the park’s natural beauty and wildlife are preserved.

2nd offense: PHP 3,500

ORDINANCE NO. 8606

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORK FOR THE PURPOSE OF REVIVING ESCOLTA, KNOWN AS MANILA'S QUEEN OF THE STREETS, TO ITS ERSTWHILE REPUTATION AS ECONOMIC CENTER OF MANILA

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the street of Escolta looms large in the economic and cultural history
of the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, the street of Escolta was the Philippines's first business district, being
in proximity to the government center of Intramuros, and suburbs of Quiapo, Sta. Cruz
and Binondo;

WHEREAS, in its heyday, Escolta was the home of the Philippine Stock Exchange
and other important commerce building;

WHEREAS, the street of Escolta enjoys strategic location as it is accessible both
from the land and from the Pasig River;

WHEREAS, the rapid overcrowding of the City of Manila, along with the rise of other commercial districts elsewhere in the metropolis has led to Escolta's decline, as
well as the dilapidation of its once-grand structures;

WHEREAS, for the City of Manila to reclaim its former glory as the Philippine's foremost economic and historical center, there is a need for its supervised comprehensive
development: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short Title. - This Ordinance shall be known as the "Escolta Development Ordinance of Manila".

SEC. 2. Declared Policy. It is the policy of the city to pursue a development framework in Escolta aimed to use its cultural heritage value as a driver of urban economic development.

SEC. 3. Establishment of the Escolta Development Area (EDA). - There is hereby established the Escolta Development Area ("EDA") covering the following area: Escolta St., Binondo, City of Manila, in particular, the zone bound by Muelle Del Banco National (along Pasig River) a portion of Quintin Paredes St., San Vicente St., a portion Tomas Pinpin St., Martires St., a portion of Burke St., a portion of Banquero St., (Estero Dela Reina), a portion of Dasmariñas St., a portion of Tetuan St., and a portion of Plaza Sta. Cruz St., closing off at Muelle del Banco National.

SEC. 4. Creation of the Escolta Development Council (EDC). - There is hereby created the Escolta Development Council (EDC) which will oversee any and all construction in the EDA. The EDC shall be composed of the City Mayor as the Chairman, the City Assessor as the Vice Chairman, and the following as members: the City Engineer, the City Planning and the Urban Development Officer, and the Majority Floor Leader of the Sangguniang Panlungsod ng Maynila.

SEC. 5. Any and all construction, development, renovation, and improvements made to properties or lots located in the EDA shall require the approval of the Majority of the members of the EDC. The EDC shall have the power to approve or reject any application for any and all construction, development, renovation, and improvements made to properties or lots located in the EDA on the basis of its general benefit to the residents of the City of Manila vis-a-vis the pursuit of the city's herein declared policy.

SEC. 6. The owners/developers covered by the EDA shall employ as its administration and maintenance only those who are residents of the City of Manila.

SEC. 7. Newly constructed buildings with twenty (20) stories and above located
along the EDA, shall be taxed at zero percent (0%) of the prevailing real property tax rate
for a period of fifteen (15) years from the issuance of the certificate of occupancy.

SEC. 8. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days
after its publication in the Official Gazette or a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 16, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance aims to bring Escolta Street back to life by restoring it as a historic and economic center of Manila, like it once was. Escolta, located in Binondo, used to be known as the “Queen of the Streets” and was the country’s first business district, home to the Philippine Stock Exchange and other iconic buildings. However, over time, it lost its glory due to urban congestion and the rise of other commercial areas.

To address this, the City of Manila will:

Develop and protect Escolta as a heritage and economic zone.

Promote its cultural value as a way to spark business and tourism.

Create a special council to guide and approve all construction, renovation, and development in Escolta.
