ORDINANCE NO. 8600

AN ORDINANCE RETITLING THE POSITION TITLES IN THE ASSESSMENT RECORDS MANAGEMENT DIVISION AND ASSESSMENT STANDARDS AND EXAMINATION DIVISION OF THE DEPARTMENT OF ASSESSMENT IN
ACCORDANCE WITH SECTION 5, CHAPTER 1 OF THE MANUAL ON REAL PROPERTY APPRAISAL AND ASSESSMENT OPERATIONS OF THE BUREAU OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT FINANCE, DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE PRESCRIBING THE MINIMUM AND MAXIMUM ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE AND STAFFING PATTERN FOR PROVINCIAL/CITY/MUNICIPAL ASSESSOR'S OFFICE IN THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT UNITS

EXPLANATORY NOTE

As per Memorandum Circular No. 20, Series of 2012, of the Civil Service Commission, the existing qualification standards of assessors and appraiser positions was amended. In the local level, only the City Assessor III and Assistant City Assessor III was required to have an eligibility under R.A. 1080 (Real Estate Services). On the other hand, all positions for Local Assessment Operations Officer I to Local Assessment Operations Officer V in the national level is required to have the same eligibility. Since the City of Manila is a special city and the salary grade of positions is at par with the national level, the Civil Service Commission, through the City Personnel Office is also requiring the same eligibility in the City of Manila for all positions from Local Assessment Operations Officer I to Local Assessment Operations Officer V.

Under the approved Personnel Schedule of the Department of Assessment as incorporated in the Executive Budget of the City of Manila for the current and incoming year, all positions in the Assessment Records Management Division and Assessment Standards and Examination Division were reclassified as Local Assessment Operations Officer I, II, III, IV and V, despite the fact that they are not doing appraisal and assessment function but merely recording of transactions and safekeeping of records. As a consequence thereof, all personnel holding these positions are being deprived of any promotion since they are required to have this eligibility similar to their counterparts in the national level unless they take up a refresher course on Bachelor of Science in Real Estate Management (BSREM) for two (2) years and pass the board exam.

Henceforth, there is a need to retitle the positions in the Assessment Records Management Division and in the Assessment Standards and Examination Division of the Department of Assessment to conform with the position titles as provided for under Section 5, Chapter I, of the Manual on Real Property Appraisal and Assessment Operations (MRPAAO) prescribing the minimum and maximum organizational structure and staffing pattern for Provincial/City/Municipal Assessor's Office in the Local Government Units, thus giving the chance to holders of these position titles to be promoted after having served the city for more than two (2) decades, some of which are about to retire soon.

In view of the foregoing circumstances, approval of this Ordinance is hereby sought.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Pursuant to Section 2, Chapter I, of the Manual on Real Property Appraisal and Assessment Operations, the BLGF shall exercise technical supervision and coordination over the treasury and assessment operations of local governments; provide consultative service and technical assistance on real property assessments, local taxation and other related matters; and exercise line supervision over its Regional Offices and the Local Treasury and Assessment Services nationwide.

SEC. 2. Prescribed likewise under Section 5, Chapter I, of the said Manual is the minimum and maximum organizational structure and staffing pattern for the Provincial/City/Municipal Assessor's Offices in the local government with the following divisions:

A. Assessment Operations Evaluation Unit
B. Administrative Division

C. Assessment Records Management Division
Assessment Records Officer V, SG-24
Assessment Records Officer IV, SG-22
Assessment Records Officer III, SG-18
Assessment Records Officer II, SG-15
Assessment Records Officer I, SG-11

D. Tax Mapping Operations Division
E. Property Appraisal Division

F. Assessment Standards and Examination Division
Assessment Examiner V, SG-24
Assessment Examiner IV, SG-22
Assessment Examiner III, SG-18
Assessment Examiner II, SG-15
Assessment Examiner I, SG-11

SEC. 3. Memorandum Circular No. 20, Series of 2012, amended the qualification standards of assessor and appraiser positions in the government and shall be filled only by registered and licensed practitioners, thus possess the required eligibility under R.A. 1080 (Real Estate Service). However, in the City of Manila, the Civil Service Commission through the City Personnel Office extended this eligibility requirements to all positions for Local Assessment Operations Officer I to Local Assessment Operations Officer V.

SEC. 4. Under the said Memorandum Circular No. 20, all position titles of Local Assessment Operations Officer I to Local Assessment Operations Officer V in the national level is also being required the same eligibility under R.A. 1080 (RESA). However, this is being applied to similar positions in the City of Manila being a special class city where the salary grade is at par with the national government, though excluded under the said circular.

SEC. 5. Under the approved Personnel Schedule of the Department of Assessment, as incorporated in the Executive Budget of the City of Manila for the current year, there are positions in the two (2) divisions of the department, namely the Assessment Records Management Division and the Assessment Standards and Examination Division, which were reclassified before as Local Assessment Operations Officer I to Local Assessment Operations Officer V despite the fact that they are not doing appraisal and assessment work but merely recording of transactions and safekeeping of records. Since these position titles are requiring the eligibility under R.A. 1080 (RESA), the holders of these positions are being deprived of any promotion unless they take up a two (2) year course of Bachelor of Science in Real Estate Management (BSREM) after which they have yet to pass the required board exam.

SEC. 6. The following position titles in the Assessment Records Management Division and Assessment Standards and Examination Division are hereby amended to conform with Section 5, Chapter I, of the Manual on Real Property Appraisal and Assessment Operations and to give the holders of these position titles to be promoted after having served the City of Manila for a number of years considering that they are not performing appraisal and assessment function:

short_text:
This ordinance retitles several positions in the Assessment Records Management Division and the Assessment Standards and Examination Division of the Manila Department of Assessment. The goal is to align job titles with actual functions and avoid unnecessary eligibility requirements under R.A. 1080 (Real Estate Service Act), which hinder promotion for long-serving employees not engaged in real property appraisal.

By adopting the correct titles (e.g., from “Local Assessment Operations Officer” to “Assessment Records Officer” or “Assessment Examiner”), the ordinance removes the need for affected staff to obtain real estate licensure, as they only handle documentation and records, not appraisal.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8599

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF MANILA'S VENTURE FINANCING PROGRAM FOR THE STUDENTS AND FRESH GRADUATES OF PAMANTASAN NG LUNGSOD NG MAYNILA AND UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFORE AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. It is hereby declared the policy of the City
Government of Manila to accelerate the development of innovative and emerging
technologies by its academic institutions by providing the necessary funding support to
proposed business ideas and plans of deserving and eligible students.

SEC. 2. Establishment of Venture Financing Program. - The City Government shall establish a Venture Financing Program, based on the City's Innovation Agenda and Strategy, which shall provide financial support to deserving and eligible students and fresh graduates of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) and Universidad de Manila (UDM) who have feasible business ideas and a workable business plan leading up to incubation and start-ups.

SEC. 3. Qualification for the Venture Financing Program. -

a.  A student or a group of students or fresh graduates of PLM and UDM
who are bonafide residents of the City of Manila;

b.  Must have feasible business ideas and workable business plan
approved by the concerned Board of Regents, as endorsed by the
respective University President.

SEC. 4. Duties of the President and Board of Regents of PLM and UDM. - The Presidents of PLM and UDM shall respectively assess the feasible business ideas and workable business plans submitted by their respective students and new graduates. If the same merit funding, the President shall recommend its approval to the respective Board of Regents. The Board of Regents shall issue a resolution endorsing its funding to the City Mayor thru the City Council of Manila.

The concerned Board of Regents shall monitor and submit a detailed progress report on the beneficiaries usage of fund provided under Section 5 herein and development of startups at least once every semester to the City Mayor and the City Council based on agreed upon startup metrics.

SEC. 5. Incubator Fund. - A trust fund known as an Incubator Fund is hereby created for feasible business ideas and workable business plans as seed money. The revenue realized from the seed money shall be shared according to the following percentages:

a.  Seventy percent (70%) shall accrue to the student/group of students who
pioneered the business ideas and plans;

b.  Fifteen percent (15%) to the University where the student/group of students
are registered or have graduated from; and

c.  Fifteen percent (15%) to the City of Manila which shall in turn be part of the
Fund.

SEC. 6. Formulation of Internal Rules and Regulations of Venture Financing Program. - The Presidents of PLM and UDM and their concerned Board of Regents shall formulate within thirty (30) days upon the effectivity of this Ordinance the corresponding Internal Rules and Regulations for the proper implementation of this Ordinance and submit the same to the City Council of Manila for ratification.

SEC. 7. Appropriation. - The City Government shall appropriate One Hundred Million Pesos (PhP. 100,000,000.00) which shall be used for the above purposes mandated by this Ordinance in the City's Annual Budget, and every year thereafter.

SEC. 8. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 16, 2019.
short_text:
The City Government of Manila establishes a Venture Financing Program to support eligible students and fresh graduates from Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) and Universidad de Manila (UDM) who have feasible business ideas and plans. A PHP 100 million annual budget is allocated for this initiative. Selected proposals will receive seed funding from an Incubator Fund, with revenue shares of 70% to the student(s), and 15% each to the university and the city. The program aims to promote innovation and entrepreneurship, guided by internal rules formulated by university officials and subject to City Council ratification.

Key Features:
Eligibility:

Must be bona fide residents of Manila.

Must be students or fresh graduates of PLM or UDM.

Must have a viable business plan endorsed by the university president and approved by the Board of Regents.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8598

AN ORDINANCE MANDATING FAST FOOD CORPORATIONS TO PROVIDE TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT TO QUALIFIED SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITY RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the 1987 Philippine Constitution under Article XIII, Section 11, thereof,
provides that the State shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health
development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health and other social
services available to all the people at affordable costs and prioritizing the elderly,
disabled, women and children;

WHEREAS, the aforesaid provision of the Constitution treats the elderly and disabled as similarly situated in terms of being afforded essential goods, health and other social services in accordance with their needs;

WHEREAS, the City of Manila, likewise, recognizes the invaluable role of the senior citizens, differently abled and persons with disability in the development of the City
given the opportunity to be productive members of the society;

WHEREAS, there is a need to provide equal job opportunities to our senior citizens, differently abled and persons with disability to be able to be a productive members of the society;

WHEREAS, in Section 458(a) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, the Sangguniang Panlungsod is empowered to approve legislation that shall provide for general care of its inhabitants, particularly the senior citizens, the differently abled and persons with disability;

WHEREAS, the same Code empowers the City Government to adopt measures that will ensure the protection of the social, moral, intellectual welfare of its inhabitants: 
NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. TITLE OF THE ORDINANCE. - This Ordinance shall be known as "AN ORDINANCE MANDATING FAST FOOD CORPORATIONS TO PROVIDE TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT TO QUALIFIED SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITY (PWD) RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AS PART OF THE AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY".

SEC. 2. DEFINITION. - As used in this Ordinance, the following words, terms and phrases shall be defined as follows:

a.  FAST FOOD - refers to types of food that can be prepared and served very quickly. They are characterized as easy to prepare, accessible and cheap alternatives to home-cooked meals. 

b.  FAST FOOD CORPORATIONS - also known as Quick Service Restaurants, serve fast food as defined above to customers packaged for immediate consumption, either on or off the eating premises. Fast food customers normally order at the counter and pay before eating. For
purposes of this Ordinance, Food Corporations included in this Ordinance are those Fast Food Corporation operating within the City of Manila that has at least ten (10) branches.

c.  SENIOR CITIZEN OR ELDERLY - refers to any resident of the City of Manila who are at least sixty (60) years of age who are still able to perform tasks without harm to others or themselves.

d.  DIFFERENTLY ABLED PERSON - proposed as a substitute for "disabled" or "handicapped" and it emphasizes the fact that many people with disabilities are quite capable of accomplishing or performing a particular task and function only in a different manner or taking more time and effort than people without the disability in question.

e.  PERSONS WITH DISABILITY (PWD) - are those suffering from restriction or different abilities as a result of a mental, physical or sensory impairment, to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for human being.

f.  CSWDO - refers to the City Social Welfare and Development Office and headed by the City Social Welfare Officer.

SEC. 3. BENEFICIARY OF THIS ORDINANCE. The following persons are entitled to be considered for temporary employment under this Ordinances, to wit:

a.  Senior Citizens
b.  Differently abled persons
c.  Persons with Disability

SEC. 4. EMPLOYMENT. - The Fast Food Corporations included in this Ordinance shall be mandated to provide for temporary employment of not more than six (6) months to qualified senior citizens, differently abled persons and persons with disability (PWD). Each branch of the Fast Food Corporations under this Ordinance shall give temporary employment to at least two (2) Senior Citizens and one (1) PWD with a salary of at least the minimum wage provided under the Labor Code and with a minimum four (4) hours work for at least four (4) days each working week.

PROVIDED, that the senior citizens, differently abled persons and persons with disability will not be assigned to perform tasks that are hazardous to their health or beyond their physical limitations or capabilities.

PROVIDED FURTHER, that their employment will not be covered by the provisions and benefits provided by the Labor Code.

SEC. 5. OTHER PROVISIONS. - Upon approval of this Ordinance, a Technical Working Group shall be formed to come up with the Implementing Rules and Regulations for the implementation of this Ordinance.

SEC. 6. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions thereof not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified or amended accordingly.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 3, 2020.
short_text:
This ordinance requires fast food corporations with at least 10 branches operating within the City of Manila to provide temporary employment to qualified senior citizens, differently abled persons, and persons with disability (PWDs). Each branch must employ at least 2 senior citizens and 1 PWD for a period not exceeding six (6) months, working minimum 4 hours per day, at least four days a week, with a salary not less than the minimum wage. The work assigned must not be hazardous or beyond the beneficiaries' capabilities. A Technical Working Group shall create the IRR for implementation. Employment under this ordinance is not covered by regular Labor Code benefits.

Key Features:
Eligibility:

Senior citizens aged 60+ who can perform tasks safely.

Differently abled individuals and persons with disabilities residing in Manila.

The renewal follows a previously vetoed attempt under Ordinance No. 8557 that was not overridden by the previous council. The renewed franchise retains the same terms and conditions as originally stipulated.

ORDINANCE NO. 8596

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE POSITION OF DRIVER IV WITH SALARY GRADE 10, THROUGH THE ABOLITION OF THE POSITION OF ENGINEER II WITH SALARY GRADE 16, TO LEAD THE MOTORPOOL UNIT OF OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Engineer II position of Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center has been vacant for the past several years, and the hospital management has deemed it economical to abolish the said position to give for the creation of Driver IV to lead its Motorpool Unit and, at the same time, maximize its own plantilla to give chance to deserving employee qualified for the position: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. CREATION OF DRIVER IV. The existing position of Engineer II bearing Salary Grade 16 (Item No. 129), in the Old Personnel Schedule FY 2020 of the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center, is hereby abolished to be replaced by the position of Driver IV bearing Salary Grade 10 (Item No. 132), in the New Personnel Schedule FY 2020.

SEC. 2. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance, upon approval, shall take effect after ten (10) days from publication in a newspaper of general circulation pursuant to Section 59 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 5, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance abolishes the vacant Engineer II position (SG-16) at the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center and creates a new position of Driver IV (SG-10) in its place. The Driver IV will lead the hospital's Motorpool Unit, aiming to better utilize the hospital's plantilla and provide opportunities for qualified personnel.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8595

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 130 (CREATION OF TRAFFIC DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND) OF ORDINANCE NO. 8092, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8327, ALSO KNOWN AS "THE TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT CODE OF THE CITY OF MANILA"

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. TRAFFIC DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND. - In order to maximize the utilization of the Traffic Development Trust Fund to support the operations of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB), among others, Section 130 of Ordinance No. 8092, as amended by Ordinance No. 8327, or the Traffic Management Code of the City of Manila is hereby amended, to read as follows:

"Sec. 130. Creation of Traffic Development Trust Fund - There is hereby created a Traffic Development Trust Fund generated from all receipts from franchising, supervisory, regulatory fees, fines and surcharges as set forth in this Ordinance.

All collections for violations of any section or provision of this Ordinance shall accrue to the Trust Fund of the City of Manila. The City Accountant shall keep and maintain a special account and all records related thereto.

For the collected fines, incentives shall be given the following:

- Twenty percent (20%) to the Traffic Enforcers concerned to be distributed through Automated Teller Machine (ATM).

- Five percent (5%) to Traffic Enforcement Units.

- The Officers-in-Charge in different levels of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB), tasked to implement the provisions of this Ordinance, shall have a hand in the formulation of policies for the disbursement of the two percent (2%) share which accrued to the Trust Fund specifically created by operation of this Ordinance.

The Fund shall be used for the operational requirements of the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) and Capital Outlay of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau, traffic improvement and other activities, maintenance of facilities and traffic control
devices, and requirements of the Traffic Management Committee, excluding Personnel Services. Any unused balance at the end of the fiscal year in excess of twenty-five percent (25%) of the previous year's expenditures shall accrue to the General Fund."

SEC. 2. REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified and amended accordingly.

SEC. 3. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, such provision is hereby repealed, modified or amended accordingly. The valid provisions shall be in full force and effect.

SEC. 4. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 5, 2019.
short_text:
This ordinance amends Section 130 of Ordinance No. 8092, as amended by Ordinance No. 8327, to maximize the use of the Traffic Development Trust Fund in support of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB). It specifies how traffic violation fines are allocated, including incentives for traffic enforcers and units, and outlines that the fund will be used exclusively for operational and capital expenses—excluding Personnel Services. Any fund balance exceeding 25% of the previous year's expenditures shall revert to the General Fund.

Key Features:
Fund Source: Franchising, regulatory fees, fines, and surcharges

Incentive Allocation:

20% to traffic enforcers (via ATM)

5% to Traffic Enforcement Units

2% managed by MTPB Officers-in-Charge for policy formulation

full_text:
MISSINGORDINANCE NO.  8594 


AN ORDINANCE GRANTING FRANCHISE TO UNITED ASSOCIATION OF 
COCKPIT OWNERS AND OPERATORS OF THE PHILIPPINES, INCORPORATED, TO 
BROADCAST LIVE AND DATA STREAMED COCKFIGHTING ACTIVITIES AND 
DERBIES AT COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS AND TO ESTABLISH, OPERATE 
AND MAINTAIN OFF-SITE COCKPIT BETTING STATION WITHIN THE CITY OF 
MANILA

PREAMBLE 

WHEREAS, the Sangguniang Panlungsod as a legislative body, by express 
provision of law, is empowered and authorized to license and grant franchise for the 
establishment, operation and maintenance of cockpits, regulate cockfighting activities 
and breeding of fighting cocks within its territorial jurisdiction, provided that existing rights 
should not be prejudiced; 

WHEREAS, the UNITED ASSOCIATION OF COCKPIT OWNERS AND 
OPERATORS OF THE PHILIPPINES, INC. (UACOOP) is a duly registered association 
here in the Philippines, which caters to the needs of owners, operators and promoters of 
cockfighting aficionados; 

WHEREAS, pursuant to the Games and Amusement Board (GAB) continuing 
regulatory powers over all aspects of cockfighting as provided in P.D.  No. 1802 (Creating 
the Philippine Gamefowl Commission), in relation to E.O. No. 149 (Streamlining the Office 
of the President).  That were devolved to the LGU's through Sec. 447 (a) (3) (v) of 
R.A.  No. 7160 (Local Government Code of 1991), it granted UACOOP authority to take 
video live coverage of cockfights and live stream the same, subject to the terms and 
conditions stated therein; 

WHEREAS, in view of today's modern technology, the City of Manila recognizes 
that a cockpit may be viewed in different social media platforms for a fee, through the 
internet or live-streaming wherein the end-user is situated in another location; 

WHEREAS, upon consideration of the application of UACOOP, the City of Manila 
hereby grants franchise for the live streaming, broadcasting or other forms of transmission 
of cockpits, and any and all betting on cockfighting through the telephone, internet and 
other electronic machines/means such as short messaging, mobile and desktop 
applications and similar platforms and collect fees for such purpose in commercial 
establishments within the City of Manila: NOW, THEREFORE, 


Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT: 

SECTION 1. Nature, Scope, Grant of Franchise.  - Subject to the provisions of 
applicable laws, rules and regulations, a franchise to broadcast live and data stream 
cockfighting activities and derbies at commercial establishment such as bars, club, 
restaurant and the likes, within the City of Manila is hereby granted to United Association 
of Cockpit Owners and Operators of the Philippines, Incorporated, provided that the 
cockfighting subject to broadcast shall only be done in a licensed cockpit, unless 
otherwise allowed in some other area, pursuant to Presidential Decree No. 449. 


The Commercial establishments where the grantee intends to broadcast and live 
stream cockfighting activities and to establish, operate and  maintain off-site cockpit 
betting stations, shall be located and operated only within appropriated areas as 
prescribed by zoning laws and applicable ordinances.  No establishment shall be operated 
and maintained within the radius of two hundred (200) lineal meters from any existing 
school buildings, churches and public buildings. 

SEC. 2. Declaration of Franchise. - Unless sooner revoked or cancelled, this 
franchise shall be valid for a period of fifteen (15) years commencing from the effectivity 
of this Ordinance with the option on the part of the Grantee to renew the same for a similar 
period and subject to the approval of the Sangguniang Panlungsod. 

SEC. 3. Authority of the Office of the Mayor. - The Grantee shall apply and 
secure the required business permit to operate from the Office of the Mayor and the latter 
shall have authority to require compliance of all existing laws, ordinances, rules and 
regulations similarly imposed to all business establishments and impose conditions 
thereto as are expressly or impliedly necessary for the protection of the welfare and safety 
of all persons going or transacting in said commercial establishments. 

SEC. 4. Prohibition of Sale, Lease, Usufruct and Transfer of Franchise. - This 
franchise is non-transferable in character.  As such, the Grantee shall not sell, assign, 
lease, grant the usufruct of or transfer this franchise, including rights and privileges 
acquired thereunder to any person, natural or juridical, firm or other entities, nor merge 
with any corporation or individual without prior notice and approval of the Sangguniang 
Panlungsod. 

SEC. 5. Mandatory Payment of Taxes and Fees Provisions. - The Grantee 
shall be liable to pay all taxes and other fees prescribed by the City of Manila.  The 
assessment shall be without prejudice to the subsequent impositions as may be adopted 
or hereafter may be required by law or ordinance.  Failure on the part of the grantee to 
promptly and regularly comply with said tax obligations shall be a ground for the automatic 
revocation or cancellation of this franchise. 

SEC. 6. Other Gambling Activities. - All gambling games of any kind shall at any 
time be hereby prohibited at the premises of the off-site business operation.  The 
managers or lessee/s of such off-site business and the violators of this provision shall be 
prosecuted and held criminally liable under the provisions of existing laws. 

SEC. 7. Prohibition against Minors. No person less than twenty-one (21) years 
of age shall be allowed inside the premises of offsite cockpit betting stations at any time. 
The operator, manager or licensee shall be responsible for strict compliance with these 
rules and any violation thereof is punishable by suspension or cancellation of this 
franchise without prejudice to criminal prosecution under existing ordinance or laws. 

SEC. 8. Anti-Fraud Measures. The Office of the City Mayor shall adopt such 
measure as to obviate the use of fraudulent means or manipulation in all aspects of 
cockfighting.  Persons employing means or manipulation shall be prosecuted against in 
accordance with our penal laws as may be warranted by the prevailing circumstances. 

Any breach and/or circumvention of any of the conditions set in this Ordinance, shall be cause for the suspension or revocation of the issued eSabong Gaming License. 

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances not consistent with the provisions of 
this Ordinance are hereby repealed.

SEC.  10. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance, upon approval, shall take effect 
after ten (10) days from publication in a newspaper of general circulation pursuant to 
Section 59 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 
1991. 


This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on 
December 12, 2019.
short_text:
This ordinance grants a 15-year franchise (renewable) to the United Association of Cockpit Owners and Operators of the Philippines, Inc. (UACOOP) to broadcast live and data-stream cockfighting activities in commercial establishments (such as bars, clubs, and restaurants) and to establish and operate off-site cockpit betting stations within the City of Manila. The operations must strictly comply with existing zoning laws, maintaining a minimum distance of 200 meters from schools, churches, and public buildings.

The franchise prohibits transfer, sale, lease, or merger of the granted rights without the prior approval of the City Council. UACOOP is required to secure a business permit from the Office of the Mayor and comply with all tax obligations to the city; failure to do so may lead to automatic franchise cancellation.

Minors (below 21 years old) are strictly prohibited from entering betting station premises, and other forms of gambling are not allowed within these premises. The ordinance also mandates anti-fraud measures to prevent manipulation or deceit in cockfighting activities. Violations can result in the suspension or revocation of the eSabong Gaming License and may subject violators to criminal prosecution under existing laws.
fines:
Failure to pay taxes and fees: Grounds for automatic revocation or cancellation of the franchise.
 Operating in violation of the 200-meter radius rule or without proper zoning compliance: Implicit grounds for cancellation.
Allowing minors (below 21 years old) or other forms of gambling in the off-site betting station: Punishable by suspension or cancellation of the franchise, plus criminal prosecution under existing ordinances or laws.
Fraud or manipulation in cockfighting activities: Grounds for suspension or revocation of the eSabong Gaming License and criminal prosecution

ORDINANCE NO. 8593

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE PERMANENT CLOSURE AND WITHDRAWAL FROM PUBLIC USE OF A PORTION OF ARROCEROS STREET, ERMITA, MANILA, BOUNDED IN THE EAST BY LRT CENTRAL STATION, IN THE WEST BY THE METROPOLITAN THEATER, IN THE NORTH BY THE RIVERSIDE DRIVE AND IN THE SOUTH BY DOCTOR BASA STREET, WITH AN AGGREGATE AREA OF ONE THOUSAND ONE HUNDRED FORTY-FOUR SQUARE METERS AND THIRTY-FOUR SQUARE DECIMETERS (1,144.34 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, TO BE CONVERTED AND DEVELOPED AS PART OF THE ARROCEROS TREE PARK FOR THE PURPOSE OF ENHANCING THE ECOLOGICAL ENVIRONMENT WITHIN THE CITY PURSUANT TO SECTION 16 OF THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT CODE OF 1991

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, in 1993, the City of Manila designated and developed the property located at Arroceros Street, Ermita, Manila, across the street from the Metropolitan Theater and the Mehan Garden, and beside the Pasig River, as a forest park in accordance with the Memorandum of Agreement entered into by then Mayor Alfredo S. Lim and the Winner Foundation, Inc., for the purpose of beautifying and enhancing the ecological environment within the city;

WHEREAS, as a matter of policy of the City Government of Manila, to protect and
conserve the integrity of the last environmental frontier of the city, and to establish and
develop permanent forests, tree parks or watersheds within the City, Draft Ordinance
No. 7981, principally authored by Hon. Joel M. Par, Hon. Salvador Philip H. Lacuna,
Hon. Priscilla Marie T. Abante-Barquia, Hon. Leilani Marie H. Lacuna, Hon. Ernesto C.
Isip, Jr., Hon. Wardee P. Quintos XIV, Hon. Manuel M. Zarcal, Hon. Joel R. Chua, Majority
Floor Leader, and all the members of the Majority Bloc, was filed last August 23, 2019:
"Declaring a parcel of land, commonly known as the Arroceros Forest Park, as a
permanent Tree Park pursuant to Republic Act No. 5752, to be known as the Arroceros
Tree Park, and appropriating funds thereof";

WHEREAS, Section 16, General Welfare of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991 provides, that: "Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure and support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants" NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration as Part of Arroceros Tree Park. - A portion of Arroceros Street, Ermita, Manila, bounded in the East by LRT Central Station, in the West by the Metropolitan Theater, in the North by the Riverside Drive and in South by Dr. Basa Street, with an aggregate area of One Thousand One Hundred Forty-Four Square Meters and Thirty-Four Square Decimeters (1,144.34 Sq. M.), more or less, is hereby permanently closed and withdrawn from public use to be converted and developed as part of the Arroceros Tree Park for the purpose of enhancing the ecological environment within the city pursuant to Section 16 of the Local Government Code of 1991.

SEC. 2. Scope. - The subject portion of Arroceros Street shall have the following
technical description:

Bounded on the NE., points 1-2, by Riverside Drive, on the SW., points 9-10 by
Dr. Basa Street, on the SE., points 2-9, by LRT Central Station and on the NW., points
10-15 and 15-1, by the Metropolitan Theater.

SEC. 3. Attachment. - With the exception of the portion of Arroceros Street occupied by LRT Central Station, as evidenced by attached copy of Transfer Certificate of Title No. 167114, the technical description attached hereto of the subject portion of the same to be withdrawn from public use, as submitted by the Department of Engineering and Public Works of the City of Manila, is hereby made an integral part of this Ordinance. 

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. Should any provision of this Ordinance be declared invalid or unconstitutional, any provision not affected thereby shall remain valid and enforceable.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance, upon approval, shall take effect after fifteen (15) days from publication in a newspaper of general circulation pursuant to Section 59 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 25, 2019.
short_text:
This ordinance permanently closes and withdraws from public use a 1,144.34 sq. m. portion of Arroceros Street, located in Ermita, Manila, bounded by the LRT Central Station, Metropolitan Theater, Riverside Drive, and Dr. Basa Street. The area will be converted and developed as part of the Arroceros Tree Park, enhancing the ecological environment in accordance with Section 16 of the Local Government Code of 1991. The ordinance supports the city’s policy of environmental preservation by expanding green space in the urban core.

Key Features:
Location: Arroceros Street, Ermita, Manila

Size: 1,144.34 square meters

Boundaries:

East: LRT Central Station

West: Metropolitan Theater

North: Riverside Drive

South: Dr. Basa Street

This ordinance is about strengthening the Tuberculosis Control Program in Manila to eliminate TB by creating policies for detection, care, and treatment, involving various groups like the government and community organizations. The City of Manila will follow the National Tuberculosis Control Program, establish a TB Council to coordinate efforts, ensure proper implementation, and secure funding for TB control. full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8591

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE MANILA TOURISM, CULTURE AND ARTS COUNCIL AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREOF

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. -

a.  Pursuant to Section 17 of R.A. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991, grants to local government units, such other powers and discharge, such other functions and responsibilities, as are necessary, appropriate or incidental to efficient and effective provision of tourism facilities and other tourist attractions, including the acquisition of equipment, regulation and supervision of business concessions and security services for such facilities;

b.  Pursuant to Section 2 of Republic Act No. 9593, otherwise known as the
Tourism Act of 2009, provides that: "The State declares tourism as an
indispensable element of the national economy and an industry of national
interest and importance, which must be harnessed as an engine of
socioeconomic growth and cultural affirmation to generate investment,
foreign exchange and employment and to continue to mold an enhanced
sense of national pride for all Filipinos";

c.  Pursuant to the pertinent provisions of Republic Act No. 7356, otherwise
known as the Law Creating the National Commission for Culture and the
Arts (NCCA), provides that the NCCA in cooperation with various agencies
such as the Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG), is
mandated to undertake a systematic collection of statistical and other data
which reflects the state of cultural conditions in the country, to serve as
essential quantitative and qualitative basis for formulating cultural policies;

d.  Pursuant to Section 458 (a)(5)(xvi) of R.A. 7160 or the Local Government
Code of 1991, and DILG Memorandum Circular No. 2002-81, mandate the
establishment of a council whose purpose is the promotion of culture and
arts, coordinate with government agencies and Non-Governmental
Organizations and subject to availability of funds, appropriate necessary
fund for its support and promotion;

e.  To preserve, promote and propagate culture and arts in the City of Manila,
reflective of the positive values among Manileños thereby contributing to
the constructive well-being of Filipino people as a nation;

f.  To promote, develop, provide support and recognize talents and skills of
gifted Manileños in the Arts.

SEC. 2. Composition. -

Chairman:
City Mayor of Manila

Vice Chairperson/s:
Chairperson of the Committee on Arts and Culture - City Council
Chairperson of the Committee on Tourism - City Council

Members:

Head of Local Tourism, Culture and Arts

Local Planning and Development Officer

Local Information Officer

Local Budget Officer

Representative of the Department of Education (DEPED) - Manila

Representative of the Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG) - Manila

Representative of the Department of Tourism (DOT) - Regional Office

Representative of Manila Police District (MPD)

Representative of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR)

Representative of the Business Sector

Representative of the Local Artists Group

Representative of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA)

Representative of the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction Office (MDRRO)

The abovementioned representatives shall be registered voters of Manila.

SEC. 3. Duties and Functions. -

a.  Adopt its own internal rules and policies governing its meetings and
decisions;
b.  Formulate programs and recommendations to develop local tourism
facilities and attractions tapping local resources and funds;
c.  To enable the different groups in the government and the tourism related
enterprises to collaborate and fuse their strength in the promotion of tourist
destinations;
d.  To encourage local action and leadership in planning, coordinating and
raising the standards of tourism industry;
e.  Strictly enforce sanitary standards in public restrooms frequented by public
utility vehicles and tourist transport services, i.e. gasoline stations,
restaurants along main highways and bus stops;
f.  Formulate programs for the development of the local artists talents;
g.  Ensure the protection, preservation and conservation of local artistic,
cultural and historical heritage;
h.  In coordination with the private sectors, conduct cultural and artistic events
such as competitions, lectures, seminars, workshops, symposia, guilds, and
set up exhibits during said activities;
i.  Conduct regular consultations with stakeholders in order to identify the
grassroots based on cultural artistic concerns, welfare, issues and agenda;
j.  Encourage development of local cultural and artistic industries;
k.  Adopt programs that shall encourage, support, search, and promote local
cultural and artistic talents among the constituents of the City of Manila
including but not limited to students and out of school youths;
l.  Provide recognition program, incentives and awards to deserving bonafide
Manileños that brings pride and honor to the City of Manila;
m.  Recommend establishment of Culture and Arts facilities for the exhibits and
shows of art works and collections of Manileños; and
n.  Establish and maintain the local cultural inventory with the head of local
tourism, culture and arts department as the focal person and custodian of
local inventory.

SEC. 4. Funding. - An amount of Two Million Pesos (PhP. 2,000,000.00) from the
budget of the local tourism, culture and arts department will be initially appropriated in
order to carry out the purposes of this Ordinance without prejudice to any augmentation
as the needs arise.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. - If any part, section or provision of this Ordinance
shall be held invalid, illegal or unconstitutional, such part, section or provision not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances or portions thereof which are contrary
to the provisions of this Ordinance or portions hereof are hereby deemed modified or
repealed.

SEC. 7. Effectivity. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 21, 2019.
short_text:
This ordinance establishes the Manila Tourism, Culture and Arts Council to promote tourism, support cultural heritage, and foster artistic development in Manila. It outlines the council’s composition, powers, and responsibilities, including creating programs for local tourism, preserving cultural sites, and supporting local artists. The ordinance initially allocates PhP2,000,000.00 from the local tourism, culture and arts department's budget to fund the council's operations.

Key Features:
Council Chairperson: City Mayor of Manila

Vice Chairpersons: Chairpersons of the City Council Committees on Arts & Culture and on Tourism

Members Include:
Representatives from DepEd, DILG, DOT, MPD, DENR, local artists, business sector, NCCA, and others

Duties Include:

Promoting tourism and local attractions

Preserving historical and cultural sites

Supporting artists and cultural events

Enforcing sanitary standards in tourist areas

Maintaining a local cultural inventory

Recommending facilities for culture and arts

Giving recognition and awards to outstanding Manileños

Funding: PhP2,000,000.00 initial allocation, subject to augmentation

ORDINANCE NO. 8590

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF PERMIT
FEES/TAXES IN DIFFERENT VENUES WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA FOR HOLDING
IN THE COUNTRY, THE 30TH SOUTH EAST ASIAN GAMES TO BE HELD PARTLY AT
THE RIZAL MEMORIAL SPORTS COMPLEX AND MANILA HOTEL TENTS ON
NOVEMBER 25 TO DECEMBER 10, 2019

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Exemption from payment of Permit Fees/Taxes for games to be held
partly at the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex and the Manila Hotel Tents for the duration
of the 30th Southeast Asian Games is hereby authorized from November 25 to
December 10, 2019.

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.
This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on
November 18, 2019.

MEMORANDUM

FOR : MR. BERNARDITO C. ANG
Secretary to the City Mayor

FROM : CITY LEGAL OFFICE

RE : Ordinance No. 8590 for approval of the City Mayor

DATE : 28 June 2022

I. BACKGROUND

1. 2nd Indorsement dated 20 June 2022 forwarded to this office, for our comment and recommendation, a copy of City Ordinance No. 8590 enacted by the Sangguniang Panlungsod of the City of Manila entitled, "AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF PERMIT FEES/TAXES IN DIFFERENT VENUES WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA FOR HOLDING IN THE COUNTRY, THE 30TH SOUTH EAST ASIAN GAMES TO BE HELD PARTLY AT THE RIZAL MEMORIAL SPORTS COMPLEX AND MANILA HOTEL TENTS ON NOVEMBER 25 TO DECEMBER 10, 2019," intended for approval of the City Mayor.

2. While we were advised that the said ordinance would lapse into law on 30 June 2022, we took notice that the same was enacted as early as 18 November 2019. In other words, after the enactment of the ordinance, it took a period of almost three (3) years before the same was transmitted on 20 June 2022 to the Office of the Mayor for his approval.

II. COMMENT/RECOMMENDATION

In reviewing the subject ordinance, this office is of the opinion that the subject matter therein is covered by Section 458 (a)(2)(ii) of the Local Government Code of 1991 which provides for the power of the Sangguniang Panlungsod to grant exemptions in the following manner:

(ii) Subject to the provisions of Book II of this Code and applicable laws and upon the majority vote of all the members of the sangguniang panlungsod, enact ordinances levying taxes, fees and charges, prescribing the rates thereof for general and specific purposes, and granting tax exemptions, incentives or reliefs; (emphasis supplied)

A perusal of the ordinance under review shows no indication that the same had been voted upon by at least a majority of all members of the Sangguniang Panlungsod or the City Council of Manila.

Furthermore, it must be pointed out that the activity sought to be benefitted by the grant of exemption under the ordinance had already been allowed to proceed and concluded even before the ordinance had taken effect. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 8590 expressly provides that, "[t]his Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval," which we took to mean the approval of the Honorable City Mayor. The activity sought to be benefitted had already been accomplished even before the ordinance took effect. Neither does the ordinance provide any indication of any future application since it was meant to apply specifically to the already concluded30th SEA Games to be held of 25 November 2019 to 10 December 2019. In other words, the approval of the ordinance under review no longer possesses any legal significance.

In view of the foregoing observations, this office recommends that City Ordinance No. 8590 be returned to the Sangguniang Panlungsod (City Council) for the City of Manila for purposes of clarifying the above-mentioned matters.

Respectfully submitted for your information and guidance.

EMETERIO S. MORENO, JR.
City Legal Officer

Republic of the Philippines
CITY COUNCIL
Manila

1ST. Endorsement
June 20, 2022

Respectfully presented to Honorable Francisco "Isko Moreno" Domagoso, City Mayor, Manila, for your Honor's consideration and action the attached Ordinance No. 8590, Entitled: "AN ORDINANCE GRANTING EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF PERMIT FEES/TAXES IN DIFRENT VENUES WITHIN THE CITY OF THE MANILA FOR HOLDING IN THE COUNTRY, THE 30TH SOUTH EAST ASIAN GAMES TO BE HELD PARTLY AT THE RIZAL MEMORIAL SPORTS COMPLEX AND MANILA HOTEL TENTS ON NOVEMBER 25 TO DECEMBER 10, 2019.", which was enacted by the City Council of Manila at its regular session held on November 18, 2019.

LUCHER. GEMPIS, JR.
City Gov't. Dept. Head I
(Secretary to the City Council)


Republic of the Philippines
OFFICE OF THE MAYOR

OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY TO THE MAYOR

3rd Indorsement
29 June 2022

Respectfully returned to Atty. LUCH R. GEMPIS, JR., City Government Department Head III, City Council, Manila, inviting attention to the attached comment and recommendation of the City Legal Officer regarding Ordinance No. 8590, entitled An Ordinance granting exemption from payment of permit/fees/taxes in different venues within the City of Manila for holding in the Country, the 30th South East Asian Games to be held partly at the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex and Manila Hotel tents on November 25 to December 10, 2019, contents of which are self-explanatory.

For your information and guidance.

BERNARDITO C. ANG
Secretary to the Mayor
short_text: This ordinance grants tax and permit fee exemptions for venues used during the 30th Southeast Asian Games held from November 25 to December 10, 2019, specifically at the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex and the Manila Hotel Tents. However, the ordinance faced legal issues: it was only forwarded to the Mayor's Office in June 2022—nearly three years after the event—rendering it moot. The City Legal Office recommended its return to the City Council for clarification due to the delay and lack of immediate effectivity.

ORDINANCE NO. 8588

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM, CULTURE AND
ARTS OF MANILA

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 2 of Republic Act No. 9593, otherwise known as The
Tourism Act of 2009, provides, that: "The State declares tourism as an indispensable
element of the national economy and an industry of national interest and importance,
which must be harnessed as an engine of socio-economic growth and cultural
affirmation to generate investment, foreign exchange and employment, and to continue
to mold an enhanced sense of national pride for all Filipinos",

WHEREAS, Section 16 of R.A. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991,
provides, that: General Welfare "Every local government unit shall exercise the
powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers
necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those
which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective
territorial jurisdiction, local government units shall ensure and support, among other
things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance
the right of the people to a balance ecology, encourage and support the development of
appropriate and self-reliant, scientific and technological capabilities, improve public
morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment
among their residents, maintain peace and order and preserve the comfort and
convenience of their inhabitants";

WHEREAS, Section 17 of R.A. 7160, or the Local Government Code of 1991,
grants to local government units, such other powers and discharge such other functions
and responsibilities, as are necessary, appropriate or incidental to efficient and effective provision of tourism facilities and other tourist attractions, including the acquisition of equipment, regulation and supervision of business concessions and security services for such facilities;

WHEREAS, there is now a need to expand the present Manila Tourism and
Cultural Affairs Bureau into a Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila with
the corresponding powers, duties and responsibilities;

WHEREAS, the Museo ng Maynila is hereby merged with the newly created
Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. CREATION OF DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM CULTURE AND
ARTS OF MANILA. -

a.  The City of Manila hereby creates the present Manila and Tourism and
Cultural Affairs Bureau into a department which shall be called Department of
Tourism Culture and Arts of Manila. It is task to strengthen and boost the
tourism of Manila as an engine of growth and employment; and to ensure and
support the preservation of arts and culture;

b.  The Museo ng Maynila which is presently under the Office of the Mayor is now
separated there from and instead merged with the newly created Department
of Tourism Culture and Arts of Manila.

SEC. 2. POWERS AND FUNCTIONS. - As one of the primary operating
agencies of the City of Manila, the Department of Tourism Culture and Arts of Manila
(DTCAM) shall be responsible in the efficient and effective implementation of its
approved policies, plans and programs with respect to tourism, arts and culture.
Towards this end, the DTCAM shall:

a.  Formulate, monitor, implement and/or coordinate tourisms plans and
programs;
b.  Monitor and conduct accreditation of tourism-oriented and related facilities
and service providers;
c.  Conduct capability building trainings for tourism's front liners;
d.  Establish and maintain tourism information management system and web
portal for the city;
e.  Forms and establishes linkage and networking with national government
agencies, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and People's
Organizations (POs) in planning and implementing tourism activities;
f.  Conducts inventory of existing cultural and heritage properties in conjunction
with other department.
g.  Advocate responsible culture of tourism among the students and all tourism
stakeholders;
h.  Perform such other functions related to sustainable tourism development;
i.  Prepares an annual plan on culture and arts, and make programs so as
recommendations to develop local cultural and artistic talents;
j.  Ensures the protection, preservation and conservation of the local, cultural
and historical heritage;
k.  In coordination with the private sector, conducts cultural events such as,
cultural festivals, competitions, lectures, seminars, tours and symposia and
sets up exhibits during fiesta and other related activities;
l.  Produce promotional and marketing collaterals; and
m.  Represents the City of Manila in tourism-related activity.

SEC. 3. COMPOSITION. - The following list of existing positions under the
Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila as indicated in the herein personnel
schedule shall continue the personnel compliment of the department with the following
positions:

SEC. 4. FUNDING. - Existing funds of Manila Tourism and Cultural Affairs
Bureau shall be transferred to the account of the newly created Department of Tourism,
Culture and Arts of Manila to form part of the latter's budget.

All funds due to Museo ng Maynila shall be separated from that of the Office of
the Mayor and shall be deposited under the account of Department of Tourism, Culture
and Arts of Manila.

Such funds shall form part of the annual appropriations for the Department of
Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila.

SEC. 5. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. If any part, section or provision of this
Ordinance shall be held invalid, illegal or unconstitutional, such part, section or provision not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. REPEALING CLAUSE. All ordinances or portions thereof which are
contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance or portions hereof are hereby deemed
modifies or repealed.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its
approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 14, 2019.
short_text:
This ordinance formally creates the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (DTCAM) by upgrading the existing Manila Tourism and Cultural Affairs Bureau. It also merges the Museo ng Maynila into this new department. DTCAM is tasked with formulating and implementing tourism, arts, and cultural programs for the city, accrediting tourism-related establishments, conducting training, organizing events, and preserving Manila’s heritage. The ordinance outlines the department’s structure, staffing, and budget transition, and establishes it as a primary city agency for cultural and tourism development.

Key Features:
Creation of DTCAM

Elevates the Manila Tourism and Cultural Affairs Bureau to a full department.

Merges Museo ng Maynila under DTCAM.

Mandates and Functions:

Tourism planning, coordination, accreditation, and promotion.

Preservation and conservation of cultural and historical assets.

Cultural events organization, education, and community outreach.

Collaboration with NGOs, POs, national agencies, and the private sector

ORDINANCE NO. 8587

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE RE-ALLOCATION OF THE SALARY
GRADE OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGIST OF THE OSPITAL NG MAYNILA
MEDICAL CENTER, PURSUANT TO DBM CIRCULAR NO. 2018-2

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the field of Radiology has evolved to become a vital component
of health care by being a key diagnostic tool for diseases and as an instrument for
monitoring treatments. Moreover, Radiologic Technologists who have become key
members of the health care team in health establishments, have to keep pace with
technological developments and be knowledgeable in all modalities of radiologic
examination and monitoring;

WHEREAS, the DBM Circular No. 2018-2, provides for the re-allocation of
the Radiologic Technologist II up to Radiologic Technologist V classes of positions
with corresponding salary adjustments: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. - It is hereby declared the policy of the
City Government to comply with the prescribed rules and regulation on the re-
allocation of the Radiologic Technologist II up to Radiologic Technologist V classes
of positions as embodied in the DBM Circular No. 2018-2.

SEC. 2. Re-allocation of Radiologic Technologist Classes of Positions. - The salary grade of the following classes of Radiologic Technologist positions are hereby re-allocated, to wit:

POSITION TITLE: RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGIS II
SALARY GRADE FROM: 13
SALARY GRADE TO: 15

POSITION TITLE: RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGIS III
SALARY GRADE FROM: 15
SALARY GRADE TO: 18

POSITION TITLE: RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGIS IV
SALARY GRADE FROM: 18
SALARY GRADE TO: 20

The Radiologic Technologist I position will continue to be allocated to Salary Grade 11.

SEC. 3. Appropriation. The amount necessary to implement this
Ordinance is hereby appropriated out of any fund not otherwise appropriated as
existing in the City Budget Treasury. Thereafter, subsequent appropriations shall
be integrated in the Annual Budget of the City of Manila.

SEC. 4. Effectivity. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 7, 2019.
short_text:
Ordinance No. 8587 provides for the re-allocation of salary grades for various Radiologic Technologist positions at the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center based on the DBM Circular No. 2018-2. This adjustment aims to recognize the evolving role of radiologic technologists in health care, especially with advancements in technology and diagnostic tools.

Re-allocated Salary Grades:

Radiologic Technologist II: Increased from Salary Grade 13 to Salary Grade 15

Radiologic Technologist III: Increased from Salary Grade 15 to Salary Grade 18

Radiologic Technologist IV: Increased from Salary Grade 18 to Salary Grade 20

The Radiologic Technologist I position remains at Salary Grade 11.

Funding:
The necessary amount to implement this ordinance will be allocated from the existing City Budget Treasury, with future appropriations to be included in the Annual Budget of the City of Manila.

ORDINANCE NO. 8585 

AN ORDINANCE APPROPRIATING THE AMOUNT OF SEVENTEEN BILLION EIGHT HUNDRED FIFTY-SEVEN MILLION EIGHTY-SIX THOUSAND ONE HUNDRED FORTY-SIX PESOS (PHP. 17,857,086,146.00), UNDER THE GENERAL FUND EXECUTIVE BUDGET OF THE CITY OF MANILA FOR FY 2020, TO BE TAKEN FROM THE ESTIMATED INCOME CERTIFIED AS REASONABLY COLLECTIBLE BY THE LOCAL FINANCE COMMITTEE FOR FY 2020 AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

GENERAL PROVISIONS
SEC. 2. BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS. – The Budgetary Expenditures herein proposed shall comply with the following requirements:
(a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions, nor create new positions, without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.
(b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, the use of which requires a separate Ordinance.
(c) The appropriation of the Non-Office Account, being a contingency fund or backup fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed by the different departments to finish certain programs/projects that were not sufficiently funded, cannot be utilized without a specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Committee on Appropriations for approval.
(d) The payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of the barangay chairman attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted. Garbage hauling services shall be contracted out to one or more companies as recommended by the Department of Public Services to ensure efficient and timely collection of garbage.
(e) As an additional funding source, any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee on Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee for authority to the Mayor to dispose the same through public bidding.
(f) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solution and detergents) using City Government funds shall conform with Republic Act No. 9003, otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000, Republic Act No. 8749, and Republic Act No. 9275, otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence, products to be procured shall be limited to organic, biodegradable, or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco-Labelling Program of Green Choice Philippines.
(g) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons with Disability under Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons, before the release of any payment.
SEC. 3. GENERAL LIMITATIONS. –
(a) The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for FY 2020 shall not exceed Forty-Five Percent (45%) of the Total Annual Income sources realized in the next preceding Fiscal Year;
(b) No official or employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher than the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank as determined by applicable laws, rules, and regulations;
(c) No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as may be expressly authorized by law;
(d) In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career services, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Local Government Code and the Civil Service law, rules, and regulations;
(e) Positions in the Official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbents holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations;
(f) No changes in designation or nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed except when the position is actually vacant, and filling of such position shall be strictly made in accordance with Civil Service law, rules, and regulations;
(g) The annual appropriation for discretionary purposes of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipt derived from basic real property tax in the next preceding year.
SEC. 4. ITEMIZATION OF PERSONAL SERVICES AND OTHER PERSONNEL. – The itemization of Personal Services and Other General Services as submitted by the City Budget Office in support of the appropriation herein authorized forms part of this Ordinance and shall be strictly implemented and shall be covered by its provisions. Such appropriations shall be programmed and used for the twelve-month requirement of the City. It may not be disbursed to exponentially increase the number of personnel during the first semester leaving little or no fund for the second semester of the year.
SEC. 5. INTELLIGENCE EXPENSES. – The Intelligence/Confidential expenses provided under this Ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities, and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.
SEC. 6. CHANGES IN THE ORGANIZATIONAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE MACHINERY. – All creations, conversions, transfers, abolitions, and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services, Positions/Titles and Salary Grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 61 of the Department of Budget and Management.
(a) For a more responsive, efficient, and effective organization within several departments and offices, creation and conversion of certain positions performing staff/technical/non-technical functions were made.
(b) Likewise, effected and adopted are the: (i) transfer of Museo ng Maynila to the Department of Tourism, Culture and Arts of Manila (formerly Manila Tourism and Cultural Affairs Bureau);    (ii) transfer/merging of Manila Tricycle Regulatory Office with the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau, which resulted in the abolition of certain vacant positions to trim down the City bureaucracy to a leaner but more effective and economical organization.
(c) Re-allocation of the Radiologic Technologist positions in the six (6) hospitals including Manila Health Department pursuant to DBM Budget Circular No. 2018-02 dated March 15, 2018.
SEC. 7. USE OF APPROPRIATED FUNDS. – All funds appropriated for functions, projects, and activities shall be used to finance the full-year requirement of the City of Manila and shall be released exclusively for specific purposes and particular periods for which they have been authorized. Any amendment and augmentation may be made within the fiscal year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.
SEC. 8. AUTHORITY TO ADJUST APPROPRIATIONS. – No Ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.
SEC. 9. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND. – The 20% Community Development Fund shall be strictly utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the Sangguniang Panlungsod in conformity with the Local Government Code.
SEC. 10. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) CONTINGENCY RESERVE. – Except for expenses due to public utilities, rentals, insurance premiums, and food supplies expenses, a contingency reserve of 20% on the authorized 2020 appropriation for Department Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating thereon the 20% contingency reserve.
SEC. 11. ALLOTMENT OF APPROPRIATIONS. – For effective budgetary control, authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder:
(a) No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function, activity, or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period, and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor. The Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted based on the appropriations authorized in the Budget Ordinance. A revised Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted upon approval of the Annual Executive Budget referred herein showing quarterly allotment of the whole authorized appropriations for the department/office.
(b) For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided, each fiscal year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January, April, July, and October. The appropriations under this Ordinance shall be allocated, programmed, and used to cover the funding requirement of the City for the whole year. The majority thereof may not be expended in the first semester to ensure availability of funds for the last semester of the year.
(c) The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer's notification and certification that the realized income is less than what is estimated in the annual/supplemental budget or that additional income is realized.
(d) An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Officer based on recommendations made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official, the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least five (5) days before the start of each quarter.
SEC. 12. NON-WAIVER CLAUSE. – Notwithstanding the approval of this Appropriation Ordinance by the Sangguniang Panlungsod, all contracts, disbursements, and awards entered into by the City of Manila including, but not limited to, the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, Universidad de Manila, and other government agencies and instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455, paragraph B, sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.
SEC. 13. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. – If for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.
SEC. 14. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. – This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2020.
This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 4, 2019.

The allocation, derived from the estimated income certified by the Local Finance Committee, supports the city's operational expenses and obligations from January 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8584    

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING A SUSTAINED MILK AND NUTRIBUN FEEDING PROGRAM FOR ALL PRESCHOOL STUDENTS ENROLLED IN PUBLIC KINDERGARTEN AND ALL GRADE 1 STUDENTS ENROLLED IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN THE CITY OF MANILA, AMENDING FOR THE PURPOSE ORDINANCE NO. 8380, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES 

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:    

SECTION 1. It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila, consistent with Section 15, Article II, of the Constitution, to effectively address the nutritional needs of students in the primary academic level in order to aid in their full learning potential and thus supplement their efforts to reach their higher academic levels. 

SEC. 2. A sustained Milk and Nutribun Feeding Program for one hundred twenty (120) school days is hereby established for all preschool students enrolled in kindergarten and all Grade 1 students enrolled in public schools in the City of Manila, in which milk and nutribun meals shall be served individually on such students, both for the morning and afternoon batches. 

If there is a need to continue the Milk and Nutribun Feeding Program in cases where there still malnutrition in kindergarten and Grade 1 students in the City of Manila, said program shall be extended under the provisions of this Ordinance. 

SEC. 3. Within thirty (30) days from the approval of this Ordinance, the Manila Health Department (MHD) and the Division of City Schools of Manila under the Department of Education (DepEd) shall formulate rules and guidelines implementing the provisions hereof, which shall include, but not limited to, the following:    

a. The mandatory examination of students covered by program based on the age-to-weight ratio and the documentation thereof;    

b. The integration of the nutritional formula prepared by the Manila Health Department for the nutribun mass-production;    

c. The outsourcing of qualified bakeries for the mass-production of nutribun according to the total number of students in all public preschool and primary level schools; 

d. The procurement of safe local milk or milk products from qualified suppliers;    

e. The procurement of basic hygiene items, such as disposable cups for milk and proper packing for individual nutribun items for individual serving per student; 

f. The creation of a monitoring group for the random inspection of schools covered by this Ordinance for the purpose of ensuring compliance hereof;  and   

g. The periodic inspection of individual students to determine their health status based on their age-to-weight ratio.    

SEC. 4. The amount of One Hundred Seventy-Three Million Pesos (PhP. 173,000,000.00) or so much thereof as they may be necessary is hereby appropriated out of any available and existing funds in the City Treasury of Manila. 

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval. 

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 28, 2019.
short_text:
This ordinance creates a sustained 120-day Milk and Nutribun Feeding Program for all public kindergarten and Grade 1 students in Manila. It aims to improve children's nutritional health to support better academic performance. The program may be extended in areas with persistent malnutrition. The Manila Health Department (MHD) and the Division of City Schools (DepEd) are tasked with implementing the program, including health checks, food production standards, and supplier procurement. A monitoring group will ensure compliance, and student health will be periodically assessed.

Program Details:
Coverage: Public kindergarten and Grade 1 students

Duration: 120 school days, with morning and afternoon feeding
