AN ORDINANCE CREATING TEN (10) NURSE I POSITIONS (SG-11) ΤΟ FACILITATE THE TRANSFER OF NURSE I EMPLOYEES OF OSPITAL NG MAYNILA MEDICAL CENTER, CURRENTLY OCCUPYING THE NURSE I POSITION UNDER THE CLINICAL NURSING DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM, AND TO INCLUDE THE TEN (10) NURSE I POSITIONS IN THE REGULAR PLANTILLA ITEMS   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:    

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. - It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government to provide equal opportunity to regular employees and those employees classified under the Lump-Sum Appropriations-CNRPD under the Personal Services, through integration with the Regular Plantilla Items as far as status of employment are concerned, and entitlement to other benefits given to regular employees. 

SEC. 2. Creation of ten (10) Nurse I positions and corresponding Salary Grades. The positions of ten (10) Nurse I bearing Salary Grade 11 for Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center are hereby created and the existing Nurse I positions under the Clinical Nursing Development Program (CNRDP), are hereby converted into Regular Plantilla Items (RPI) for legitimacy of their current status of employment. 

SEC. 3. Appropriation. - The amount necessary to implement this Ordinance is hereby appropriated out of any fund not otherwise appropriated as existing in the City Treasury.  Thereafter, subsequent appropriations for the positions created shall be integrated in the Annual Budget of the City of Manila.    

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval. 

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 24, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance creates ten (10) Nurse I positions (Salary Grade 11) at the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center, intended to facilitate the transfer of current Nurse I employees under the Clinical Nursing Development Program (CNRDP) into the Regular Plantilla Items (RPI). The measure ensures these employees attain the benefits and employment status of regular personnel. Funding will come from unappropriated city funds and will be included in subsequent annual budgets.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8572
AN ORDINANCE STRICTLY REQUIRING ALL RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA TO MAINTAIN THE CLEANLINESS AND ORDERLINESS OF THEIR IMMEDIATE SURROUNDING AND FRONTAGE, AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF OR OTHERWISE KNOWN AS “TAPAT KO-LINIS KO ORDINANCE”


PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the advocacy of the City of Manila for cleanliness and orderliness being the premier city and capital of the country must be fully implemented and enforced;

WHEREAS, the efforts of the local government alone is not sufficient in providing and maintaining cleanliness and orderliness in the city;

WHEREAS, the collaboration of the dwellers and residents of the city is needed to discourage and prevent the proliferation of continued practice of indiscriminate display of visual clutters in the frontage of their residences and commercial establishments, as well as in any open or public places that affect the cleanliness of their surroundings;

WHEREAS, the City Government is empowered to adopt measures to ensure cleanliness and sanitation within its territorial jurisdiction and protect the health, social and moral welfare of its inhabitants;

WHEREAS, the cleanliness of the city shall not only encourage and attract local and foreign businesses and investors but will also provide health and environmental benefits:

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title of the Ordinance
This Ordinance shall be known as “AN ORDINANCE STRICTLY REQUIRING ALL RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA TO MAINTAIN THE CLEANLINESS AND ORDERLINESS OF THEIR IMMEDIATE SURROUNDING AND FRONTAGE, AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF OR OTHERWISE KNOWN AS ‘TAPAT KO-LINIS KO ORDINANCE’.”

SECTION 2. Definition
For the purpose of this Ordinance, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meaning given herein:

[1] Waste – garbage, refuse and other rubbish which is not disposed of properly, tends to create a danger to public safety, diminished cleanliness and sanitation.

[2] Hanging and Drying – colloquially known as “pagsasampay” of clothing, apparels and other materials which if not properly made, which result to visual clutters.

[3] Immediate Surroundings – refers to the frontage including up to the mid-span of the road, street alley or avenue [excluding highways and major thoroughfares] from the edge of the street gutter, sidewalks of residential houses, dwelling units, business/commercial establishments or offices whether public or private.

SECTION 3. Coverage
It shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or dweller, lessee, occupant of a residential or commercial establishment to maintain the cleanliness of the frontage or immediate surroundings of their residence or establishment.

SECTION 4. Prohibitions
The following are hereby prohibited:

[a] Hanging of clothes and other effects in electrical wires, windows, posts and other places not intended for the purpose;

[b] Washing and drying of clothes in the gutter, sidewalks, streets, alleyway and roads;

[c] Leaving trash and other refuse in the gutter, sidewalks, streets, alleyway and roads and allowing or leaving pet animals to defecate or urinate outside their property line;

[d] Storing, dumping or placing wastes, debris, junked or under repair vehicles, dilapidated appliances and other objects in any part of the road, street or avenue or in any sidewalk which may impede or obstruct the vehicular and pedestrian traffic;

[e] Construction of pens or cages of animals or animal on leash;

[f] Construction of house or business extension, including installation of roofs and canopies, awnings and the like;

[g] Installation of permanent fences or gates; and

[h] Use of sidewalks for plants, trees and platters.

SECTION 5. Temporary use when allowed
The use of any roads, streets, avenues, alleys, sidewalks, bridges, parks or other places on a temporary basis and for public purpose or use for a definite period only shall require a special permit from the City Government.

SECTION 6. Implementation and Enforcement
A technical working group shall be created to be composed of the following committees of the Sanguiniang Panlungsod, namely:

a) Committee on Barangay Affairs;
b) Committee on Engineering and Public Works;
c) Committee on Environmental Protection, Ecological Preservation and Sanitation;
d) Committee on Laws; and
e) Committee on Health which shall formulate and promulgate the implementing rules and regulations for the effective enforcement within thirty (30) days upon approval of this Ordinance.

SECTION 7. Penalties
Any person, corporation, trust, firm or entity found violating this Ordinance or its implementing rules shall be punished in the following manner:

1st Offense: Warning/Reprimand
2nd Offense: Fine not more than PhP. 500.00
3rd Offense: Fine not more than PhP. 1,000.00
4th Offense: Fine not more than PhP. 3,000.00
5th Offense/Succeeding Offense: Fine not more than PhP. 5,000.00 or Imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days or both at the discretion of the court

The penalty of imprisonment shall not be applicable to Section 4.a and 4.b hereof.

It is understood that the fines shall accrue to the City Treasury to form part of the general fund of the City.

SECTION 8. Separability Clause
If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions thereof not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SECTION 9. Repealing Clause
All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuance or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified or amended accordingly.

SECTION 10. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 26, 2019.
short_text: The "Tapat Ko, Linis Ko Ordinance" requires all Manila residents and businesses to keep the area in front of their homes or establishments clean and orderly. This includes keeping sidewalks, gutters, and roads free of trash, clutter, hanging laundry, parked junk vehicles, or business/home extensions that block pathways. Special permits are needed for temporary public use. Violators will face warnings, fines, or even jail time after repeated offenses.
fines:
1st Offense: Warning/Reprimand

2nd Offense: Fine up to PhP 500

3rd Offense: Fine up to PhP 1,000

4th Offense: Fine up to PhP 3,000

5th and succeeding offenses: Fine up to PhP 5,000 or imprisonment up to 30 days, or both (court’s discretion)
(Note: Jail time does not apply for violations related to hanging or drying clothes)

g. Majority Floor Leader of the City Council    

h. City Councilor, Chairman of the Committee on Laws    

i. City Councilor, Liga ng mga Barangay President    

j. One Representative from Non-Governmental Organizations (NGO) or

One representative from private sector duly appointed by the City Mayor    

SEC. 3. All ordinances, rules or regulations in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed;  PROVIDED, That the rights that are vested upon the effectivity of this Ordinance shall not be impaired.    

SEC. 4. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 22, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance repeals Ordinance No. 8502, which had previously given the Mayor the sole authority to approve exceptions or variances to the Manila Zoning Ordinance (Ordinance No. 8119). With this repeal, that authority is returned to a restructured Manila Zoning Board of Adjustment and Appeals (MZBAA), now composed of city officials, councilors, and a representative from an NGO or the private sector.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8570

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 3 OF CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8362, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8457, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE GRANTING BIRTHDAY GIFTS TO ALL SENIOR CITIZENS OF MANILA, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES"

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.   Section 3 of Ordinance No. 8362, as amended by Ordinance No. 8457, is hereby amended to increase the value of the Birthday Gift entitlement of senior citizens of the City of Manila, to read as follows:

"SEC. 3.   BIRTHDAY GIFT. - All Senior Citizens or elderly shall be granted a yearly Birthday Gift, in the amount of Eight Hundred Pesos (PhP. 800.00), to be given in cash or in kind or a combination thereof."    

SEC. 2.   Appropriation. - The City Government shall appropriate funds therefor which shall be used for the above purposes mandated by this Ordinance in the City's Annual Budget, and every year thereafter.    

SEC. 3.   Separability Clause. - If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held or declared invalid or unconstitutional, the other provisions not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.    

SEC. 4.   Repealing Clause. - All other local laws, decrees, orders, issuances, rules and regulations which are inconsistent with the provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.    

SEC. 5.   Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation which appropriation shall be included in the Calendar Year 2020 Executive Budget and thereafter.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 15, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance increases the birthday gift for senior citizens in Manila to PhP 800.00 per year. The gift can be given in cash, in kind, or a combination of both. This amends the earlier ordinances (Nos. 8362 and 8457) to provide more support to the elderly residents of the city.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8569

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CERTAIN ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS OF ARTICLE XI OF ORDINANCE NO. 8119, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE MANILA COMPREHENSIVE LAND USE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE OF 2006, BY REQUIRING THE NOTICE OF COMPLIANCE PROVIDED UNDER REPUBLIC ACT NO. 7279, AS AMENDED BY REPUBLIC ACT NO. 10884 PRIOR TO THE APPLICATION OF ISSUANCE OF THE ZONING PERMIT, BUILDING PERMIT, DEVELOPMENT PERMIT AND OCCUPANCY PERMIT

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.   Section 63, Article XI of Ordinance No. 8119, otherwise known as the Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan and Zoning Ordinance of 2006 is hereby amended as follows to include:

"ISSUANCE OF NOTICE OF COMPLIANCE OF R.A. NO. 7279, AS AMENDED BY R.A. NO. 10884 PRIOR TO THE APPLICATION FOR ISSUANCE OF THE ZONING PERMIT, BUILDING PERMIT, DEVELOPMENT PERMIT AND OCCUPANCY PERMIT.

All subdivision and condominium developers shall secure a Notice of Compliance of the socialized housing provisions of Republic Act No. 7279 as amended by Republic Act No. 10884 prior to the application for issuance of the zoning permit, building permit, development permit and occupancy permit.    

The Notice of Compliance shall specify the location of the area or the monetary amount that will be utilized for socialized housing equivalent to at least fifteen percent (15%) of the total subdivision area or total subdivision cost, or at least five percent (5%) of the condominium area or project cost, at the option of the developer, as provided by law.    

The Notice of Compliance shall indicate the beneficiaries of the socialized housing, who shall be underprivileged and homeless, as determined by the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) in coordination with the Urban Settlements Office, and are bona fide residents of the City of Manila.    

The CPDO shall issue the necessary implementing rules and regulations concerning the issuance of the Notice of Compliance contemplated herein within fifteen (15) days from the effectivity of this Ordinance.    

The amount representing the same in compliance with this Ordinance shall be paid and remitted to the City Treasurer's Office of Manila and shall be held in a Trust Account exclusively for socialized housing development."    

SEC. 2.   If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.    

SEC. 3.   All ordinances, rules or regulations in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed; PROVIDED, That the rights that are vested upon the effectivity of this Ordinance shall not be impaired.    

SEC. 4.   This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 1, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance updates Manila’s zoning rules to require all subdivision and condominium developers to first secure a Notice of Compliance under the Socialized Housing Law (RA 7279, as amended by RA 10884) before applying for zoning, building, development, or occupancy permits. The notice must state the location or monetary equivalent of the required socialized housing contribution (15% for subdivisions, 5% for condominiums). These contributions will help provide housing for underprivileged and homeless residents of Manila, identified by the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) and Urban Settlements Office. All collected funds will go into a trust fund for socialized housing projects.
fines: Not explicitly stated, but permits will not be processed without the required Notice of Compliance.

short_text: This ordinance provides a PhP 1,000 monthly allowance to qualified undergraduate students of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) and Universidad de Manila (UDM). To qualify, students must be in good standing and either be a registered voter and resident of Manila or have a parent/legal guardian who is. Students who are dismissed must return the ATM card used for receiving the allowance; failure to do so may lead to legal consequences. The City Government of Manila will fund this allowance through its annual budget.
fines: Not specified, but failure to surrender ATM card upon disqualification may result in legal charges.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8567

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A TWENTY PERCENT (20%) REDUCTION ON THE INCREMENTAL REAL PROPERTY TAXES DUE ON ALL CLASSES OF REAL PROPERTIES


PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, City Ordinance No. 8330, the 2014 General Revision of Real Property Assessments, became effective on January 1, 2014;    

WHEREAS, City Ordinance No. 8516 was enacted on January 2017 which repealed the 2nd phase increase of forty percent (40%) in the real property taxes;    

WHEREAS, Sec. 192 of the Local Government Code (RA No. 7160) authorizes the City Government of Manila, through ordinances duly approved, to grant tax exemptions, incentives or reliefs under such terms and conditions as concerned authorities may deem necessary;    

WHEREAS, there is need to adopt a more progressive and equitable revenue system to help our taxpayers from the detrimental effects of economic downturn.  This may be achieved through a further reduction in the ceiling on the corresponding increase in the tax levy from sixty percent (60%) by twenty percent (20%) based on the incremental values of real properties provided under Ordinance No. 8330: NOW, THEREFORE,   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.   City Ordinance No. 8516 is hereby amended, to read as follows:

"SEC. 3: The Department of Assessment shall adopt the newly approved schedules specified in Section 1 hereof PROVIDED, that:

d)   The amount of tax to be paid by virtue hereof shall, in no case, be lower than the tax imposed thereon in 2013.  PROVIDED, that any tax increase, as a consequence of this Ordinance, shall be at the rate of FORTY-EIGHT PERCENT (48%) PROVIDED, Further, that said rates are based on the incremental values of real properties prescribed under Ordinance No. 8330, PROVIDED, Finally, that the total amount of tax to be paid on Land, Buildings, and other Structures and Machineries used for Residential, Commercial, Industrial and Special Classes shall, in no case, be more than double the tax imposed in 2013 over the same real property;"    

SEC. 2.   The City Treasurer's Office and the Department of Assessment are directed to issue within five (5) days from approval hereof, the necessary rules and guidelines implementing this Ordinance.    

SEC. 3.   All other ordinances, acts, administrative orders, rules and regulations inconsistent with or contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or otherwise modified accordingly.    

SEC. 4.   This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2020.  All advance payments of real property taxes made before the effectivity of this Ordinance shall be deemed entitled to an automatic tax credit applicable on the same real property.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 25, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance gives a 20% reduction on the increase in real property taxes for all types of properties in Manila (residential, commercial, industrial, and special classes). This discount applies to the additional tax amount calculated based on new property values under the 2014 assessment (Ordinance No. 8330). It amends a previous law (Ordinance No. 8516) and limits tax increases so that the new amount will not be more than 48% higher than the 2013 rate, and in no case should total taxes double the 2013 level. Those who paid in advance before January 1, 2020, will receive a tax credit for the excess amount they paid.
fines: No fines; offers tax reduction and automatic tax credit for advance payers.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8566

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A GENERAL AMNESTY ON ALL DELINQUENT BUSINESS TAXES, REAL PROPERTY TAXES, REGULATORY FEES AND OTHER SERVICE CHARGES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code (Sections 168, 169 and 255, R.A. No. 7160) authorizes the City Government of Manila to impose surcharge and penalty interests on certain unpaid taxes, fees and charges;    

WHEREAS, a rising number of taxpayers affected by economic misfortune have experienced hardships in paying their basic taxes, fees and charges.  As a consequence, these unpaid impositions have incurred surcharge and interests making it even more difficult for taxpayers to settle their obligations;    

WHEREAS, Section 192 of the said law authorizes the City Government of Manila, through ordinance duly approved, to grant tax exemptions, incentives or reliefs under such terms and conditions as it may deem necessary;    

WHEREAS, an effective response to the clamor of our constituencies for an immediate relief is in order to give stakeholders a fresh clean start with the assumption of the new Administration: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.   SCOPE. The General Amnesty shall apply on all appropriate surcharge and penalty interests incurred on unpaid local business taxes, regulatory fees and service charges;  interest penalties on all Classes of delinquent real properties (Residential, Commercial, Industrial and Special) within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila;  and penalties on all other overdue accounts.  The Amnesty may be availed of for a period from August 1, 2019 to December 20, 2019.    

SEC. 2.   WHO MAY AVAIL. - The Tax Amnesty shall be granted to taxpayers or individuals who:

a.  Own, operate or are engaged in any business enterprise within the City of Manila which has a delinquent account or unpaid business tax, regulatory fee or any charge or obligation to the City Government;    

b.  Own or administer real property declared for the first time subject to back taxes.  The property shall be assessed based on the prevailing Fair Market Values and Assessment Levels under Ordinance No. 8330;    

c.  Own or administer any delinquent real property [Land, Building or Machinery] with or without Notices of Collection; and    

d.  Has any transaction to secure a license, permit or any and all other services with the City Government of Manila.    

SEC. 3.   WAIVER OF SURCHARGE AND INTEREST PENALTIES. - All corresponding accrued surcharge and interest penalties that any delinquent tax, regulatory fee or service charges may have incurred shall be deemed waived upon full payment of the principal amount of the basic tax, fee or charge.    

SEC. 4.   APPLICATION OF PAYMENTS. - All taxes paid under this Ordinance shall first be applied to prior years' tax delinquencies until all the tax deficiencies shall have been paid in full.  In the event that a taxpayer shall be unable to fully pay and settle the subsisting business or real property tax delinquencies, the payments made pursuant to and by virtue hereof shall be deducted from the principal amount of delinquent tax and the outstanding surcharge and interest penalties, when applicable, shall again be imposed thereon and be due and demandable.    

SÉC. 5.   IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS. - The Office of the City Treasurer is hereby directed to issue within five (5) days upon the approval of this Ordinance the necessary rules and regulations including other administrative guidelines for the implementation of the same.    

SEC. 6.   REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances or portions thereof which are contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby deemed repealed or modified accordingly.    

SEC. 7.   SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. If any part, section or provision of this Ordinance shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by a competent court, other parts or portions that are not affected thereby shall remain valid.    

SEC. 8.   EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 25, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance gives a general amnesty to taxpayers in Manila by waiving all penalties, surcharges, and interest on unpaid business taxes, real property taxes, regulatory fees, and other service charges. Taxpayers only need to pay the basic amount due, and the extra charges will be removed. This amnesty was available from August 1, 2019 to December 20, 2019, and covered delinquent accounts for businesses, real properties (even first-time declarations), and any overdue payments tied to city services or permits. However, if a taxpayer fails to pay the full amount, the waived charges can be reimposed.
fines: Waives surcharges and interest penalties on unpaid taxes, fees, and charges—if the basic tax is fully paid during the amnesty period. Failure to fully settle means the waived penalties can be re-applied.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8565

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP. 500.00) MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE TO ALL BONA FIDE SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED OR PERSONS WITH DISABILITY AND SOLO PARENT RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES


PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, no less than the paramount law of the land, the 1987 Constitution under Article XIII, Section 11 thereof, specifically provides that the state shall adopt an integrated and comprehensive approach to health development which shall endeavor to make essential goods, health and other social services available to all the people at affordable cost and prioritizing the elderly, disabled, women and children;    

WHEREAS, the aforesaid provision of the Constitution treats the elderly and disabled as similarly situated in terms of being afforded essential goods, health and other social services in accordance with their needs;    

WHEREAS, similar to elderly citizens, it is the valued policy of the State to protect the disabled by rehabilitating them so they can be productive citizens upon their integration to the mainstream society;    

WHEREAS, the rights of senior citizens and disabled persons should be recognized and must be the primordial concern of the City Government;    

WHEREAS, there is an imperative need to provide the senior citizens and disabled persons with a comprehensive health care and financial assistance to foster their capacity to attain a more meaningful and productive lifestyle;    

WHEREAS, in Section 458 (a) of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, the Sangguniang Panlungsod is empowered to approve legislation that shall provide for the care of its inhabitants particularly the elderly and the disabled;    

WHEREAS, the same Code empowers the City Government to adopt measures that will ensure the protection of the health, social and moral welfare of its inhabitants especially the needy ones: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. TITLE.
 This Ordinance shall be known as "AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (PHP. 500.00) MONTHLY MONETARY ALLOWANCE TO ALL BONA FIDE SENIOR CITIZENS, DIFFERENTLY ABLED OR PERSONS WITH DISABILITY AND SOLO PARENT RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AS PART OF THE SOCIAL AMELIORATION PROGRAM OF THE CITY, APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES".    

SEC. 2. DEFINITION OF TERMS.
 As used in this Ordinance, the following words, terms and phrases shall be defined as follows:   

1.)  Senior Citizens or Elderly - Refers to any resident of the City of Manila who are at least sixty (60) years of age;    

2.)  Differently Abled Person - Proposed as a substitute for "disabled" or "handicapped" and it emphasizes the fact that many people with disabilities are quite capable of accomplishing or performing a particular task and function only in a different manner or taking more time and effort than people without the disability in question;    

3.)  Persons With Disability (PWD) - Are those suffering from restriction or different abilities as a result of an impairment, to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for human being as determined by the Manila Social Welfare and Development Office (MSWDO);    

4.)  Solo Parent - According to Section 3 (a) of R.A. 8972, a "solo parent" is a person who has been left with the child's responsibility or care under any of the following categories:    

i)  A woman who gives birth as a result of rape, and other crimes against chastity even without a final conviction of the offender, provided that mother keeps and raises the child;    

ii)  Parent left solo or alone with the responsibility of parenthood due to the following circumstances:    

a)  Due to death of spouse;    

b)  Spouse is detained or is serving sentence for a criminal conviction for at least one (1) year;    

c)  Physical and/or mental incapacity of spouse as certified by a public medical practitioner;    

d)  Legal separation or de facto separation from spouse for at least one (1) year, as long as he/she is entrusted with the custody of the children;  and   

e)  Declaration of nullity or annulment of marriage as decreed by a court or by a church as long as he/she is entrusted with the custody of the children.    

iii)  Unmarried mother/father who has preferred to keep and rear her/his child/children instead of having others care for them or give them up to a welfare institution;    

iv)  Any other person who solely provides parental care and support to a child or children;  and   

v)  Any family member who assumes the responsibility as head of the family as a result of the death, abandonment, disappearance or prolonged absence of the parents or solo parent.    

5.)  CSWDO - Refers to the City Social Welfare and Development Office and headed by the City Social Welfare Officer.    

SEC.
 3.  BENEFICIARIES OF THIS ORDINANCE. The following persons are entitled to receive the allowance covered by this Ordinance, to wit:   

a.  Senior Citizens;    

b.  Persons With Disability; and

c.  Solo Parents.

PROVIDED, However, that in case the beneficiary falls on two (2) or more of the above-mentioned classification of beneficiaries, he/she can only avail of one (1) allowance covered by Section 4 hereof from the City Government of Manila.    

SEC. 4.
 MONTHLY ALLOWANCE. The Five Hundred Pesos (PhP. 500.00) monthly allowance shall be given to the beneficiaries as defined by Section 3 hereof, provided that the requirements under Section 5 of this Ordinance shall be complied with.    

SEC 5.
 REQUIREMENTS FOR THE AVAILMENT OF THE BENEFITS. - for Senior Citizens:   

a.  must be at least, 60 years of age;    

b.  must be a bona fide resident and registered voter of the City of Manila; and    

c.  must be included in the master list of the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs of the City of Manila.    

for Persons with Disability and Solo Parent:

a.  must be a bona fide resident and registered voter of the City of Manila;  and   

b.  must be included in the master list of the Manila Department of Social Welfare Office.    

SEC. 6.
 NON-DISCLOSURE CLAUSE. PENALTY. In case of death of the beneficiaries covered by this Ordinance, the nearest of kin should immediately report to the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs the death of the beneficiary and surrender immediately the corresponding Automated Teller Machine (ATM) card to the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs (OSCA) for Senior Citizen beneficiaries, and to the Manila Social Welfare and Development Office (MSWDO) for Persons With Disabilities and Solo Parent Beneficiaries.  Failure to comply with this provision shall cause the filing of the appropriate charges to the relative concerned.    

SEC. 7.
 APPROPRIATION. The City Government shall appropriate funds therefor which shall be used for the above purposes mandated by this Ordinance in the City's Annual Budget and in every succeeding budget year thereafter.    

SEC. 8.
 SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. If any provision of this Ordinance or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances is declared invalid, the provisions thereof not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.    

SEC. 9.
 REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, rules and regulations, and other issuances or parts thereof found to be inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed, modified or amended accordingly.    

SEC. 10.
 EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval and after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.  The Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs (OSCA) and the Manila Social Welfare and Development Office (MSWDO) are hereby directed to immediately draft the Implementing Guidelines/Rules and Regulations upon the approval of this Ordinance, PROVIDED, that the failure of the concerned agencies to promulgate the said Guidelines/Rules and Regulations shall not prevent the implementation of this Ordinance upon its effectivity.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on July 22, 2019.
short_text: Senior citizens, persons with disabilities (PWDs), and solo parents who live and vote in Manila will receive PhP 500 monthly cash aid from the city government. This is part of the city’s social assistance program to help support their daily needs. However, even if a person qualifies under more than one category (like being both a senior and a solo parent), they can only receive one allowance. To qualify, they must be listed in the official records of either the Office of Senior Citizens Affairs (OSCA) or the Manila Social Welfare and Development Office (MSWDO). If a beneficiary dies, their family must return the ATM card and report the death immediately, or they could face legal consequences.
fines: Relatives who fail to report the death of a beneficiary and return the ATM card may face charges.

short_text: This ordinance gives a monthly allowance of PhP 500 to qualified Grade 12 students in all public schools in Manila. To qualify, a student must be a Filipino citizen, a resident of Manila, and enrolled in Grade 12 in any public school run by the city government. The allowance is given for 10 months each school year to help students continue their education despite financial challenges. The City Government will include the needed funds in its yearly budget, and the Division of City Schools will handle implementation.

This ordinance creates a new system to avoid overcrowding in Manila’s police detention centers, especially for common minor offenses like public drinking of alcohol or liquor, noise violations, smoking in public, or being shirtless in public. Instead of automatically jailing offenders, violators will now receive an Ordinance Violation Receipt (OVR) and can choose to pay a fine within five (5) working days under a "No Contest Provision"—which allows them to settle the issue without going to court. If they don’t pay or contest it, a case will be filed. Offenders may also opt to do community service instead of paying. Children below 18 are exempt from punishment but their guardians may be held accountable. The ordinance also sets up a centralized database to track violators and encourages fair enforcement by rewarding Barangays and officers with a share of collected fines.
fines:
Voluntary payment under No Contest Provision (amount based on offense)

Community service for those who cannot pay:

PhP 500 or less: 8 hours

PhP 501–1,000: 16 hours

PhP 1,001–2,000: 24 hours

No fines for minors; parents/guardians may be charged under City Ordinance No. 8243

Repeat offenders will be fined based on the number of violations

ORDINANCE NO. 8562
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING THE RIGHTFUL SHARE OF THE BARANGAYS OF ZONE 47, DISTRICT IV, MANILA, WITH RESPECT TO ITS NEWLY ADJUSTED TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION, CORRESPONDING TO THE ALLOCATION OF ITS BASIC REAL PROPERTY TAXES, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 271 of the Local Government Code of 1991 provides that the proceeds of the basic real property tax, including interest thereon, shall be distributed as follows: 70% for the general fund of the city and 30% among the component barangays. The latter allocation for the barangay shall be further divided: 50% to the barangay where the property is located and 50% equally among all component barangays;

WHEREAS, there are barangays in the City of Manila whose real property taxes and other revenue-generating measures are credited to adjacent barangays instead of to the barangay exercising jurisdiction over the properties;

WHEREAS, this issue is prevalent in Zone 47, District IV, Manila, particularly in Barangays 472, 473, 474, 475, 476, 477, 478, 479, 480, and 481. To resolve this, the newly adjusted territorial boundaries are defined and established for real property taxes and other revenue-generating measures, as guided by the Detailed Plan of the Drafting and Surveys Division of the Office of the City Engineer of Manila and the Zone Ordinance Concurring the Set Boundaries of Barangays within Zone 47, District IV, Manila:

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:
SECTION 1. ALLOCATION OF THE AREA.
The barangays within Zone 47, District IV, Manila shall now have their newly adjusted territorial boundaries for purposes of real property taxes and other revenue-generating measures, based on the Detailed Plan of the Drafting and Surveys Division of the Office of the City Engineer and the Concurring Set Boundaries of the barangays in Zone 47.

SEC. 2. REAL PROPERTY TAX (RPT) SHARES.
Upon the effectivity of this Ordinance, the City Assessor's Office and the Real Property Tax Division are hereby directed to make the necessary adjustments based on the newly defined and established territorial boundaries of the barangays in Zone 47 for purposes of real property taxes and revenue-generating measures, consistent with the provisions of Section 271 of Republic Act No. 7160.

SEC. 3. REPEALING CLAUSE.
All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, and other issuances that are inconsistent with or contrary to any of the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed and/or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE.
If any part or provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining parts or provisions which are not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 29, 2019.

CERTIFICATION
This is to certify that City Ordinance No. 8562, "AN ORDINANCE GRANTING THE RIGHTFUL SHARE OF THE BARANGAYS OF ZONE 47, DISTRICT IV, MANILA, WITH RESPECT TO ITS NEWLY ADJUSTED TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION CORRESPONDING TO THE ALLOCATION OF ITS BASIC REAL PROPERTY TAXES AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES," was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on April 29, 2019. The same was forwarded to the office of the Honorable Mayor on May 21, 2019.

Considering that more than ten (10) days had lapsed without any communication from the Local Chief Executive regarding the approval or veto of the ordinance, Ordinance No. 8562 shall be deemed approved as if signed, pursuant to Section 54, paragraph (b) of R.A. 7160 (The Local Government Code of 1991).

Issued this 6th day of August 2019, in the City of Manila.
short_text: The ordinance updates the territorial boundaries of barangays in Zone 47, District IV, Manila, so that the real property taxes and other revenues are properly assigned to the correct barangay. This ensures that each barangay gets its fair share based on the new borders.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8561
AN ORDINANCE MANDATING THE MANILA BUREAU OF PERMITS TO REQUIRE APPLICANTS FOR BUSINESS PERMITS, WHETHER NEW OR FOR RENEWAL, TO SECURE A CERTIFICATE OF EMPLOYER'S REGISTRATION FROM THE LOCAL BRANCH OF THE PAG-IBIG FUND AS A REQUIREMENT FOR THE ISSUANCE OF A BUSINESS PERMIT

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, while there is an abundance of available housing units for the middle and upper classes, there remains a significant shortage of low-cost housing for the marginalized sector. Demand for socialized housing has increased this year, with recent reports estimating a backlog of 5.07 million units;

WHEREAS, one of the contributing factors to this increasing demand is the annual series of typhoons that often cause death and destruction, highlighting the urgent need to expand socialized housing initiatives to address both natural calamities and the growing number of informal settlers;

WHEREAS, efforts have been made to address the housing shortage through the Home Development Mutual Fund Law of 2009 (Pag-IBIG Fund), which mandates the registration of employers and their employees under Republic Act No. 9679 and its Implementing Rules and Regulations;

WHEREAS, the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) Memorandum Circular No. 01, Series of 2014, dated May 9, 2014, directs all city mayors, presiding officers, and members of local councils to require new employers to register with the Pag-IBIG Fund prior to the start of their operations, as provided under Section 5 of R.A. 9679:

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:
SECTION 1. DECLARATION OF POLICY.
Pursuant to R.A. 9679, it is the policy of the City Government of Manila to support less-privileged Manileños in acquiring decent housing and to promote financial assistance through Pag-IBIG Fund loan programs as part of its basic social responsibility.

SEC. 2. REQUIREMENT FOR BUSINESS PERMIT APPLICATION.
To fulfill the mandate of this policy, the Manila Bureau of Permits is hereby directed to require all applicants for new and renewal of business permits to present a Certificate of Employer's Registration issued by the local branch of the Pag-IBIG Fund as one of the official requirements for permit issuance.

SEC. 3. COMPLIANCE PROCEDURE.
To implement this directive and comply with the provisions of R.A. 9679, the requirement stated in Section 2 of this Ordinance shall be formally included in the checklist of documentary requirements for obtaining a business permit from the City of Manila.

SEC. 4. PENALTY CLAUSE.
Any violation of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be penalized with a fine of not less than One Thousand Pesos (₱1,000.00) and not more than Five Thousand Pesos (₱5,000.00), or imprisonment of not less than one (1) month and not more than six (6) months, or both, at the discretion of the court.

SEC. 5. REPEALING CLAUSE.
All ordinances, resolutions, or parts thereof inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby deemed repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 15, 2019.
short_text:

ORDINANCE NO. 8560
AN ORDINANCE DECLARING CONCORDIA COLLEGE, LOCATED AT PEDRO GIL STREET, PACO, MANILA, A HISTORICAL SITE IN THE CITY

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 16, Article XIV of the 1987 Philippine Constitution provides that:

“All the country’s artistic and historic wealth constitutes the cultural treasure of the nation and shall be under the protection of the State which shall regulate its disposition”;

WHEREAS, historical and cultural sites are significant landmarks and memorials of momentous events that shaped the course of the nation’s history, and as such, deserve special protection and conservation as they foster national identity and cultural heritage;

WHEREAS, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP) officially recognized the historical importance of Concordia College in our nation’s history and installed historical markers at the site in 1934 and 1998;

WHEREAS, the NHCP has also suggested that the City of Manila may recognize Concordia College’s invaluable historical contribution to local history;

WHEREAS, it is the declared policy of the City Government of Manila to preserve and protect the city’s historical and cultural heritage, and to promote education, patriotic heritage, and nationalism as embodied in historic sites, areas, and structures through proper recognition and regulation, in accordance with City Ordinance No. 8310:

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:
SECTION 1. TITLE.
This Ordinance shall be known as the “Ordinance Declaring Concordia College a Historical Site in the City of Manila.”

SEC. 2. STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.
In pursuit of cultural preservation, this Ordinance aims to protect, preserve, conserve, and promote the City’s history and cultural identity by declaring Concordia College, located at Pedro Gil Street, Paco, Manila, as one of the Historical Sites of Manila.

Concordia College shall henceforth be protected under City Ordinance No. 8310, subject to any amendments thereto.

SEC. 3. REPEALING CLAUSE.
All ordinances, resolutions, or any parts thereof inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 18, 2019.
short_text: Concordia College, located along Pedro Gil Street in Paco, Manila, is now officially recognized as a historical site by the City Government. This means the school will be protected, preserved, and promoted as part of Manila’s cultural and historical heritage. This recognition aligns with existing laws and the City’s policy to protect places of historical value.
fines: Not specified in this ordinance, but protection and regulation will follow the provisions of City Ordinance No. 8310.

ORDINANCE NO. 8559

AN ORDINANCE EXEMPTING ALL SENIOR CITIZENS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITY (PWDs) WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM THE PAYMENT OF INITIAL PARKING FEES IN ALL ESTABLISHMENTS, MALLS, HOSPITALS, PARKING AREAS, OR ANY OTHER SIMILAR PLACES CHARGING THE SAME WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF MANILA, AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, under Republic Act No. 9994, also known as the “Expanded Senior Citizens Act of 2010,” the City Government is mandated to adopt measures recognizing the rights of senior citizens to take their proper place in society, and to support their improvement, well-being, and contributions to nation-building;

WHEREAS, the City Government is likewise mandated to establish mechanisms whereby senior citizens are properly assisted, appreciated, and accommodated by the community as a whole;

WHEREAS, pursuant to Section 2 of Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the “Magna Carta for Disabled Persons,” persons with disabilities (PWDs) have the same rights as others to fully participate in society, and this should be supported by the family, community, and all governmental and non-governmental organizations. These rights should not be viewed as welfare services;

WHEREAS, the City Government of Manila, through the City Council, recognizes the needs and concerns of senior citizens and PWDs, and sees the necessity of extending privileges that assist and uplift them:

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA, IN SESSION ASSEMBLED, THAT:
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.
This Ordinance shall be known as the “Manila City Senior Citizens and PWDs Free Initial Rate in Parking Fees Ordinance of 2019.”

SEC. 2. DECLARATION OF POLICY.
The City Government of Manila reaffirms its commitment to give priority and access to national and local services to the elderly and differently-abled.

In line with RA 9994 and RA 7277 (as amended), the City Government shall adopt measures to ensure that Senior Citizens and PWDs are assisted, accommodated, appreciated, and empowered to be self-reliant and fully integrated in society.

SEC. 3. PURPOSE.
This Ordinance provides exemption from paying the initial rate of parking fees for all Senior Citizens and PWDs in establishments, malls, hospitals, parking areas, and other similar places within the City of Manila.

Note: This privilege does not apply to overnight parking.

SEC. 4. PROCEDURE.
To avail of the exemption, the following must be presented upon entry:

For Senior Citizens:
A valid Senior Citizen ID issued by the Office of the Senior Citizen Affairs (OSCA), or any government-issued ID proving Senior Citizen status.

For PWDs:
A valid PWD ID issued by the National Council on Disability Affairs (NCDA).

The ID holder must be either the driver or a passenger of the vehicle.

SEC. 5. PENALTIES.
For cashiers or booth attendants:

Imprisonment: 1 to 30 days

Fine: ₱500.00

Or both, at the discretion of the court

For managers, operators, or owners of the establishments:

Imprisonment: 1 to 30 days

Fine: ₱2,000.00

Or both, at the discretion of the court

Repeat violations by the manager, operator, or owner shall result in the revocation of the business permit of the concerned parking area.

SEC. 6. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE.
If any part of this Ordinance is declared invalid, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVITY.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 18, 2019.
short_text: Senior citizens and persons with disabilities (PWDs) in Manila are now exempted from paying the initial parking fee in all malls, hospitals, parking areas, and similar places in the city. To enjoy the exemption, they must present a valid Senior Citizen ID (OSCA or government-issued) or PWD ID (NCDA), and they must be either the driver or a passenger of the vehicle. This does not apply to overnight parking. Violators, including cashiers or parking lot operators, may face fines, jail time, or business permit revocation for repeated offenses.

ORDINANCE NO. 8553

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8531, BY PROVIDING FOR THE ENTITLEMENT OF ALL REGIONAL TRIAL COURT (RTC) JUDGES TO THE MONTHLY ALLOWANCE GIVEN BY THE CITY OF MANILA AND FURTHER PROVIDING FOR THE INCREASE OF SAID MONTHLY ALLOWANCE AND ALLOCATING THE FUNDS NECESSARY THEREFOR

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the Regional Trial Court (RTC) Judges of Manila play an indispensable role in the administration of justice, the preservation of the rule of law, and the maintenance of peace and order in the City of Manila, thereby deserving the full support of the City Government;

WHEREAS, pursuant to Ordinance No. 8531 dated January 22, 2018, only fifty-six (56) RTC Judges in Manila were entitled to a monthly allowance of Twenty-Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 25,000.00);

WHEREAS, since then, seven (7) additional RTC branches have been added, and eight (8) more are currently being organized by the Supreme Court, necessitating an amendment to Ordinance No. 8531 to include all incumbent and future RTC Judges in the entitlement, for a total of seventy-one (71) RTC Judges;

WHEREAS, due to the increasing caseload and the rising cost of living brought about by inflation, there is also a need to increase the monthly allowance of RTC Judges to Thirty-Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 35,000.00) to preserve the dignity of their judicial offices and enable them to attain a reasonable standard of living:

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8531 is hereby amended to read as follows:

“SECTION 1. The monthly allowance of all judges of the Regional Trial Courts in the City of Manila shall be Thirty-Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 35,000.00) upon approval of this Ordinance.”

SECTION 2.
Section 2 of Ordinance No. 8531 is hereby amended to read as follows:

“SECTION 2. The amount of Twenty-Nine Million Eight Hundred Twenty Thousand Pesos (PHP 29,820,000.00), exclusive of training expenses, is hereby authorized to be appropriated from funds available and not otherwise appropriated, for the implementation of Section 1 of this Ordinance.”

SECTION 3. Repealing Clause.
All ordinances or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SECTION 4. Effectivity.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 17, 2019.
short_text: This ordinance updates a previous law (Ordinance No. 8531) to include all current and future Regional Trial Court (RTC) Judges in Manila as recipients of the city-provided monthly allowance, which is now increased from PhP25,000 to PhP35,000 per judge. The adjustment accounts for the addition of more RTC branches and the rising cost of living. A total of PhP29.82 million is allocated to support this increase.

ORDINANCE NO. 8550

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE INCREASE IN THE MONTHLY ALLOWANCES OF THE THIRTY (30) JUDGES AND THE CLERK OF COURT, AND PROVIDING A MONTHLY ALLOWANCE FOR THE ASSISTANT CLERK OF COURT OF THE METROPOLITAN TRIAL COURTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AND PROVIDING FUNDS NECESSARY THEREFOR

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the Metropolitan Trial Court (MeTC) Judges of Manila play an indispensable role in the administration of justice and the preservation of law and order in the City;

WHEREAS, these judges have proven themselves to be competent and dedicated public servants. Despite the continuous influx of cases and hearings, there remains an undeniable need to incentivize and appreciate their efforts by heeding their recommendations for an increase in their allowances;

WHEREAS, there is a pressing need to preserve the dignity of these officers of justice amid the strenuous demands of their work, the rising cost of living, and the risks and sacrifices they endure as administrators of the law;

WHEREAS, the preservation of the respect due to the MeTC Judges of Manila—by increasing their monthly allowances—is crucial to maintaining their effectiveness and enthusiasm in performing their judicial duties;

WHEREAS, the Local Government of Manila is legally empowered to provide additional allowances or grant increases thereof:

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The monthly allowance of the Judges of the Metropolitan Trial Courts in the City of Manila shall be increased to Twenty-Five Thousand Pesos (PHP 25,000.00). The monthly allowance of the Clerk of Court shall be Fifteen Thousand Pesos (PHP 15,000.00), and the Assistant Clerk of Court shall receive a monthly allowance of Thirteen Thousand Pesos (PHP 13,000.00), effective upon approval of this Ordinance.

SEC. 2. The amount of Nine Million Three Hundred Thirty-Six Thousand Pesos (PHP 9,336,000.00) is hereby authorized to be appropriated from available and unappropriated funds for the implementation of Section 1 of this Ordinance.

SEC. 3. The amount stated in Section 2 shall be included and appropriated in the succeeding Annual Executive Budget following the enactment of this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. All ordinances or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on July 23, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance increases the monthly allowances of 30 judges and the Clerk of Court of the Metropolitan Trial Courts in Manila. Judges will now receive PhP25,000 per month, the Clerk of Court will receive PhP15,000, and for the first time, the Assistant Clerk of Court will receive PhP13,000 monthly. A total of PhP9,336,000 is allocated to fund this adjustment

ORDINANCE NO. 8549

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY OF MANILA, THROUGH HONORABLE MAYOR JOSEPH EJERCITO ESTRADA, TO NEGOTIATE AND ENTER INTO AN AGREEMENT—EITHER THROUGH SALE, PURCHASE, AND OTHER LEGAL MODES OF ACQUISITION, AND IN CASE OF DEFAULT, BY EXPROPRIATION—OF THAT PARCEL OF LAND COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 254983, WITH AN AREA OF NINE HUNDRED FIFTEEN SQUARE METERS AND TEN SQUARE DECIMETERS (915.10 SQ.M.), FOR THE PURPOSE OF PREVENTING THE BLOCKAGE OF INGRESS/EGRESS OF ALMOST ONE THOUSAND (1,000) FAMILIES RESIDING IN BARANGAYS 829 AND 832, ZONE 90, DISTRICT VI, MANILA.

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 19 of the Local Government Code of the Philippines provides that a local government unit may, through its local chief executive and acting pursuant to an ordinance, exercise the power of eminent domain for public use, purpose, or welfare—for the benefit of the poor and landless—upon payment of just compensation, pursuant to the provisions of the Constitution and pertinent laws;

WHEREAS, social justice necessitates the intervention of the Local Government of Manila to prevent the blockage of ingress and egress for nearly one thousand (1,000) residents in Barangays 829 and 832, Zone 90, District VI, Manila;

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The Honorable Mayor of the City of Manila is hereby authorized to negotiate and enter into an agreement, either through sale, purchase, or other legal modes of acquisition. In case of default, the City may proceed with the expropriation of the parcel of land covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 254983, with a total area of Nine Hundred Fifteen Square Meters and Ten Square Decimeters (915.10 sq.m.).

SEC. 2. Upon acquisition, the land shall be utilized to provide access (ingress and egress) for nearly one thousand (1,000) families residing in Barangays 829 and 832, Zone 90, District VI, Manila.

SEC. 3. The amount of Twelve Million Pesos (PHP 12,000,000.00) needed for the acquisition is hereby appropriated from the unappropriated funds available and existing in the City Treasury to ensure the implementation of this Ordinance in accordance with its objectives.

SEC. 4. If any provision or portion of this Ordinance is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions shall not be affected and shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on July 23, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to buy or legally acquire a piece of land (915.10 sq.m.) to prevent the blocking of entrance and exit routes for nearly 1,000 families living in Barangays 829 and 832. If needed, the city may use expropriation (forced purchase with compensation) to secure the land.

ORDINANCE NO. 8548

AN ORDINANCE PENALIZING CATCALLING AND OTHER FORMS OF PUBLIC SEXUAL HARASSMENT, PRESCRIBING PENALTIES THEREFOR, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Short title. — This Ordinance shall be known as “Sexual Harassment in Public Spaces”.

SEC. 2. Definition of terms. — As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall have the following meanings:

(a) Catcalling - A loud or raucous cry, especially to express disapproval, and a derisive remark.

(b) Cursing - The use of words intended to ridicule on the basis of actual or perceived sex, gender expression, or sexual orientation and identity, including sexist, homophobic, and transphobic slurs.

(c) Leering - The act of casting lascivious, knowing, or wanton looks or sidelong glances directed at a person because of their actual or perceived sex, gender, gender expression, or sexual orientation or identity.

(d) Public Spaces - Include, but are not limited to, streets, alleys, public parks, schools, government buildings, malls, bars, restaurants, transportation terminals, public markets, and public utility vehicles.

(e) Sexual Harassment in Public Spaces (SHiPS) - Constitutes unwarranted comments, gestures, and actions forced on a person in a public space without their consent and directed at them because of their actual or perceived sex, gender, gender expression, or sexual orientation and identity. This includes but is not limited to unwanted cursing, wolf-whistling, catcalling, leering, sexist, homophobic, or transphobic slurs, persistent requests for someone's name, number, or destination after clear refusal, persistent telling of sexual jokes, use of sexual names, comments and demands, following, flashing, public masturbation, groping, stalking, and all analogous cases of sexual harassment and/or sexual assault.

(f) Stalking - An intentional act committed by a person who, knowingly and without any lawful jurisdiction, follows a person or places them under surveillance.

(g) Wolf-whistling - “Paninipol” in Filipino, is the making of a distinctive 2-toned whistle sounded to express approval or disapproval of another person's appearance, directed at the person because of their actual or perceived sex, gender, gender expression, or sexual orientation and identity.

SEC. 3. Specific prohibited acts and penalties. — The following are Sexual Harassment in Public Spaces or SHiPS, and are hereby declared as infractions, penalized as follows:

(a) Light violations are punishable with imprisonment of between one (1) day to fifteen (15) days, and/or a fine ranging from Two Hundred Pesos (PhP. 200.00) to One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00), or both, at the discretion of the Court, inclusive of a Gender Sensitivity Seminar to be conducted by the Philippine National Police (PNP) in coordination with the local government unit or the Philippine Commission on Women (PCW). Those who are found guilty of the same offense more than once and considered recidivists will face imprisonment of between fifteen (15) to thirty (30) days, and/or a fine ranging from One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) to Two Thousand Pesos (PhP. 2,000.00), or both, at the discretion of the Court.

Light violations include the following:

Wolf-whistling;

Catcalling;

Leering;

Persistent requests for name and contact details after a person has conveyed refusal to share this information;

Cursing; or

Persistent telling of sexual jokes.

(b) Medium violations are punishable with imprisonment of between one (1) month to three (3) months, and/or a fine ranging from One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) to Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00), or both, at the discretion of the Court, inclusive of a Gender Sensitivity Seminar to be conducted by the Philippine National Police (PNP) in coordination with the local government unit and the Philippine Commission on Women (PCW). Those who are found guilty of the same offense more than once and considered recidivists will face imprisonment of between three (3) to six (6) months, and/or a fine ranging from Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) to Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00), or both, at the discretion of the Court.

Medium violations include the following:

Making offensive body gestures that demean, harass, threaten, or intimidate the offended party; or

Exposing private parts for the sexual gratification of the perpetrator.

(c) Severe violations are punishable with imprisonment of between three (3) months to six (6) months, and/or a fine ranging from Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) to Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00), or both, at the discretion of the Court, inclusive of a Gender Sensitivity Seminar to be conducted by the Philippine National Police (PNP) in coordination with the local government unit and the Philippine Commission on Women (PCW). Those who are found guilty of the same offense more than once and considered recidivists will face imprisonment of between six (6) months to one (1) year, and/or a fine ranging from Four Thousand Pesos (PhP. 4,000.00) to Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00), or both, at the discretion of the Court.

Severe violations include the following acts:

All the acts mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b), when accompanied by touching, pinching, or brushing against the body of a person; or

Stalking.

The penalties imposed under this Ordinance shall be separate and distinct from any other penalty that the guilty party may suffer as a consequence of performing an act punishable under the Revised Penal Code or any other law. It shall also be without prejudice to administrative sanctions that may be imposed if the perpetrator is a government employee.

SEC. 4. Implementation. — The Office of the City Mayor, or any other office as may be designated by the City Mayor, shall implement this Ordinance.

SEC. 5. Separability Clause. — If any provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, the other provisions not otherwise affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 6. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, executive orders, and issuances, or any part thereof, which are inconsistent herewith, are hereby repealed or amended accordingly.

SEC. 7. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 28.

CERTIFICATION

This is to certify that CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8548 ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE PENALIZING CATCALLING AND OTHER FORMS OF PUBLIC SEXUAL HARASSMENT, PRESCRIBING PENALTIES THEREFOR, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES,” was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on June 28, 2018. The same was forwarded to the Office of the Honorable Mayor on July 2, 2018.

On 13 July 2018, this office received the 3rd Indorsement from the Office of the Secretary to the Mayor returning the subject Ordinance without action. Considering that more than ten (10) days had lapsed, without any communication that the Ordinance was approved or vetoed by the Local Chief Executive, Ordinance No. 8548 shall be DEEMED APPROVED as if he had signed it, pursuant to Section 54 par. (b) of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

Issued this 18th day of September 2018, in the City of Manila.
short_text: This ordinance prohibits catcalling and other forms of sexual harassment in public places in Manila. It defines and penalizes actions like wolf-whistling (paninipol), catcalling, leering, cursing with sexist or homophobic slurs, persistent sexual jokes, stalking, and public exposure. Offenses are grouped into light, medium, and severe violations, each with corresponding jail time, fines, and mandatory gender sensitivity training. For example, first-time catcalling may lead to up to 15 days in jail or a fine of PhP 200–1,000. Repeat offenders and those who commit more aggressive acts like stalking or groping face higher penalties. This law aims to make public spaces safer and more respectful, especially for women and the LGBTQ+ community.
fines:
Light violations (e.g., wolf-whistling, catcalling, cursing) are punishable by a fine of PhP 200 - PhP 2,000 or imprisonment for 1-30 days, plus a required Gender Sensitivity Seminar.

Medium violations (e.g., exposing private parts) have a fine of PhP 1,000 - PhP 5,000 or imprisonment of 1-6 months.

Severe violations (e.g., touching, pinching, stalking) can result in fines of PhP 3,000 - PhP 5,000 or imprisonment for 3 months - 1 year.

ORDINANCE NO. 8547
AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING PROTECTION AND DISCIPLINE HOURS FOR MINOR CHILDREN AND WARDS IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM TEN O’CLOCK IN THE EVENING (10:00 P.M.) TO FOUR O’CLOCK IN THE MORNING (4:00 A.M.), PROVIDING GUIDELINES THEREON AND CONSOLIDATING HEREIN CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8243

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, it is the policy of the City of Manila to promote the physical and moral well-being of children, who must be protected from harm, danger, threats, or situations that are detrimental to their health, safety, welfare, and development;
WHEREAS, children shall likewise be restricted to such a level allowed by law, as they are neither capable enough to protect themselves from external aggressions nor have sufficient prudence not to commit infractions of the law;
WHEREAS, the Local Government of the City of Manila plays a vital role in protecting the welfare of our children by creating laws aimed at addressing situations endangering the lives and limbs of children, as well as laws intended to protect children from the call of criminality in their actions;
WHEREAS, the purpose and intention of our statesmen in creating these laws are not achieved, or worse, frustrated by consenting parents and/or guardians of the minor. Non-cooperation and non-liability of the parents and/or guardian over the minor’s actions often frustrate the purpose;
WHEREAS, the City of Manila takes steps to achieve the purpose under the doctrine of Parens Patriae: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
This City Ordinance hereby establishes protection and discipline hours for minor children and wards in the City of Manila from ten o’clock in the evening (10:00 p.m.) to four o’clock in the morning (4:00 a.m.), providing guidelines thereon and consolidating herein City Ordinance No. 8243.

SECTION 2. Definition of Terms:
a. MINOR — An individual who is below eighteen (18) years old.
b. WARD — An individual who is below eighteen (18) years old and under the parental authority of another individual who is not their parent. The person having parental authority over the ward may or may not be related to the ward, as appointed by the court or by long practice, observance, and/or representation.
c. PARENT — Mother or father of the child by blood or by decree of adoption.
d. GUARDIAN — An individual exercising parental authority over the ward other than the parent, whether by court decree or by practice, representation, and long observance.
e. OFFENDER/S — Individual/s who violate/s this City Ordinance:
e.1 Adult Offender — Parent or guardian having parental authority over the minor who violated the provisions of this City Ordinance and/or City Ordinance No. 8243.
e.2 Youth Offender — An individual less than eighteen (18) years old who violates the provisions of this Ordinance.
f. PUBLIC PLACES — A place located within the juridical boundaries of the City of Manila, where the general public or a substantial group of people have access, including but not limited to streets, sidewalks, parking lots, vacant lots, and the common areas in and about churches, apartment buildings, office buildings, hospitals, schools, cemeteries, and places of entertainment such as movie theaters and the like.
g. LOITERING, WANDERING, OR STANDING-BY — Means to linger or stay, as well as to refuse to leave when requested by a police officer, a barangay officer, or the owner or other person in control of a public place. The term also encompasses activities which may be mobile, such as walking, driving, and riding in public places.
h. HABITUAL VIOLATOR — Refers to a minor or ward who frequently or repeatedly violates this Ordinance (violating the ordinance twice or more).
i. EMERGENCY SITUATION — Means any unforeseen circumstances or a combination thereof that results in a state calling for immediate action. This term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, a vehicular accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life.
j. CHILD/REN AT RISK — Child/ren who are vulnerable to and at risk of committing criminal offenses because of personal, family, and social circumstances such as abuse, exploitation, abandonment, out-of-school or street children, among others.

SECTION 3. Restricted Time
It shall not be allowed for a child or ward to loiter, wander, or stand by in public areas during and/or between ten o’clock in the evening (10:00 p.m.) and four o’clock (4:00 a.m.) the following morning, unless the attendance of any child/ward in public places during the prohibited time falls under the enumerated exemptions.

SECTION 4. Exemptions
No penalty provided in this Ordinance shall be imposed on a person found to be under any of the following conditions:
(a) Child/ren found in public places during the protection and discipline hours herein prescribed, is/are accompanied by a parent, guardian, or adult who has moral ascendancy over the child/ren.
(b) Child/ren is/are engaged in lawful employment where their shift is within the protection and discipline hours herein prescribed, or when such lawful employment causes the child/ren to be at the public place for travel coming home or going to their place of work.
(c) Child/ren is/are attending or would be going to or attending, or has attended and is coming from an official school, religious, recreational, educational, social, community, private civic, and religious group activity recognized by the barangay which supervises the activity, provided that the child/ren going home will do so without detours or stops.
(d) When the minor is involved in emergency situations and seeks immediate medical, police, or other needed assistance. Furthermore, child/ren found in public places during protection and discipline hours on occasions of nearby accidents, conflagrations, fires, inundations, and the like.
(e) Child/ren who is/are on the way to or from a social gathering such as a get-together, ceremonial rites in school, religious mass, or other extracurricular activities of the school organization where attendance is required or otherwise indispensable.
(f) Child/ren found during discipline hours in public places but who are verified to be unable to go home due to circumstances beyond their control and capability.

SECTION 5. Imposable Measures on Youth Offender and Penalties for Adult Offenders
Violators of this Ordinance shall be meted out with the following measures and/or penalties:
a. Youth Offender — Admonition shall be given to the minor who violates the protection and discipline hours for the first and second time. However, when the minor habitually violates the discipline hours ordinance, the minor shall be subjected to intervention programs enacted by the barangay or by the Manila Department of Social Welfare, such as community service programs in the barangays and charitable non-government offices.
b. Adult Offender — Admonition and orientation about the ordinance shall be given to the adult offender whose child or ward violates the protection and discipline hours for the first and second time. Intervention programs enacted by the barangay or by the Manila Department of Social Welfare, such as community service programs, shall be given to the adult offender whose child or ward violates the protection and discipline hours for the third time.
The penalties stated under City Ordinance No. 8243, entitled "An Ordinance Penalizing Any Person Who Abandons or Exposes Minors or Allows Said Minor to Be Abandoned or Exposed to a Perilous Situation That Endangers Human Life, Health, or Well-Being," are hereby adopted and shall be imposed on any adult offender whose child or ward violates the discipline hours for the fourth succeeding time. The following graduated penalties apply:

A fine of Two Thousand Pesos (PhP 2,000) or imprisonment for one (1) month, if the minor is 15 to 17 years old;

A fine of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 3,000) or imprisonment for three (3) months, if the minor is 13 to 14 years old;

A fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000) or imprisonment for six (6) months, or both fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court, if the minor is 12 years old or younger.

SECTION 6. Enforcement Procedure
The provisions of Republic Act No. 9344, as amended, or the Juvenile Justice and Welfare Act of 2006, shall be suppletory in dealing with a youth offender under this Ordinance.

SECTION 7. Separability Clause
If any part or provision of this Ordinance is held invalid, illegal, or unconstitutional, such part, section, or provision not affected thereby shall remain in full force and effect.

SECTION 8. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 28, 2018.
short_text:
This ordinance aims to protect the physical and moral well-being of children by restricting minors from loitering in public places between 10:00 p.m. and 4:00 a.m. The ordinance outlines when and how minors can be outside during these prohibited hours and the penalties for violations.

Key Provisions:

Policy: The City of Manila is committed to protecting the safety, welfare, and development of children, ensuring that they are not exposed to dangerous or harmful situations.

Restricted Time:
Children and wards are prohibited from being in public places from 10:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m., except under specific exemptions.

Exemptions: Children can be outside during restricted hours if:

They are accompanied by a parent or guardian.

They are engaged in lawful employment that requires them to be out.

They are attending or coming from school or official activities.

They are involved in emergencies, such as needing medical or police assistance.

They are going to or coming from social gatherings, school events, or extracurricular activities.

They are unable to go home due to circumstances beyond their control.
fines:
Youth Offender: Community service programs or interventions for repeated violations.

Adult Offender: If a child or ward violates curfew for the third time, the adult may face community service or interventions.
Graduated penalties (fines or imprisonment) apply for adults whose children repeatedly violate the curfew:

PhP 2,000 or 1-month imprisonment for minors aged 15-17.

PhP 3,000 or 3-month imprisonment for minors aged 13-14.

PhP 5,000 or 6-month imprisonment for minors aged 12 or younger.
