ORDINANCE NO. 8546
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY OF MANILA TO ISSUE PERMIT OR LICENSE TO OPERATORS OF COCKPITS, TO ESTABLISH, OPERATE, AND MAINTAIN OFF-COCKPIT BETTING STATIONS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA, SUBJECT TO EXISTING LAWS, RULES, AND REGULATIONS

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the General Welfare Clause under Section 16, Chapter II, Title I, Book I of Republic Act 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, authorizes local government units (LGUs) to grant licenses and regulate businesses and commercial activities within their jurisdiction;
WHEREAS, paragraph (a)(3)(v) of Section 458 of the Local Government Code vests the power in the Sangguniang Panlungsod to regulate the establishment, operation, and maintenance of cockpits, cockfighting, and the commercial breeding of gamecocks;
WHEREAS, the Local Government Code empowers the LGU, through its chief executive, to issue licenses and permits to businesses and other commercial activities within their jurisdiction;
NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. ISSUANCE OF PERMIT OR LICENSE.
The City of Manila is hereby authorized to issue a permit or license to operators of cockpits, authorizing them to establish, operate, and maintain off-cockpit betting stations within the City of Manila, subject to existing laws, rules, and regulations.

SECTION 2. CONDITIONS OF THE PERMIT OR LICENSE.
The permit or license shall be subject to the following conditions:
(a) The permit or license shall be valid for a period of five (5) years and is renewable for an additional five (5) years;
(b) Off-cockpit betting stations shall not be established within a 200-meter radius of any public or private educational institution, place of worship, public park, plaza, hospital, health center, market, barangay hall, or public building, and must comply with the city's zoning ordinance;
(c) Persons below eighteen (18) years old shall not be allowed to play or place bets at off-cockpit betting stations;
(d) The operator or owner of the off-cockpit betting stations shall provide ample space within its premises to accommodate bettors and ensure adequate parking so as not to obstruct traffic on adjacent roads and streets;
(e) The operator or owner must comply with national laws, city ordinances, the provisions of the National Building Code, and any other lawful orders and conditions imposed by the City Government of Manila or other government agencies.

SECTION 3. REPEALING CLAUSE.
All ordinances and other city issuances, or any parts thereof, that are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 4. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE.
If any provision of this Ordinance is held unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining provisions not affected shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 5. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 25, 2018.
short_text:
This ordinance allows the City of Manila to issue permits for operating off-cockpit betting stations, which are places where people can bet on cockfights, subject to certain rules and regulations.

Key Provisions:

Issuance of Permits:
The City of Manila can grant permits or licenses to operators, allowing them to set up and run off-cockpit betting stations within the city.

Conditions of the Permit/License:
The permit/license comes with certain conditions:

Validity Period: The permit is valid for 5 years, with the possibility of renewal for another 5 years.

Location Restrictions: Off-cockpit betting stations cannot be within a 200-meter radius of places such as:

Schools, places of worship, parks, hospitals, markets, and public buildings.

Age Restriction: Only those 18 years old and above can bet at these stations.

Facilities and Parking: Operators must ensure the premises have enough space for bettors and sufficient parking to avoid traffic issues.

Compliance with Laws: Operators must follow the National Building Code, city ordinances, and any relevant government rules.
fines: ordinance does not explicitly mention fines or penalties, but violations of the conditions for the permit or license would likely result in penalties as per applicable laws and regulations

ORDINANCE NO. 8545
AN ORDINANCE WITHDRAWING FROM PUBLIC USE THAT CERTAIN PARCEL OF LAND WITH AN AREA OF ONE HUNDRED FORTY-TWO SQUARE METERS (142 SQ.M.), MORE OR LESS, LOCATED AT AN ALLEY CALLED CALLE TRONQUED BETWEEN CALLE AGUILAR AND ESTERO DE MAGDALENA, BINONDO, MANILA, AND CONVERTING THE SAME AS PATRIMONIAL PROPERTY FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, public roads and streets are government properties purposed to serve and give benefit to the public;

WHEREAS, these government properties are designated for “public use.” However, if they no longer fulfill this purpose and instead become dumping grounds or breeding grounds for criminal activities, this becomes detrimental to public health, peace, and order;

WHEREAS, areas no longer serving public use are at risk of abandonment and illegal occupation;

WHEREAS, the parcel of land located at Calle Tronqued, Binondo, Manila, with an area of One Hundred Forty-Two Square Meters (142 sq.m.), ending at Estero de Magdalena, has been identified as an illegal dumping site:

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
The parcel of land with an area of 142 square meters, located at Calle Tronqued between Calle Aguilar and Estero de Magdalena, Binondo, Manila, is hereby withdrawn from public use as a road lot and converted into patrimonial property for the benefit of the City of Manila.

SEC. 2.
The said land, now reclassified under this Ordinance, shall be used in a way that is beneficial to the residents of the City of Manila, PROVIDED that a six-meter easement shall be maintained and excluded from any development, beginning from the point along Estero de Magdalena.

SEC. 3. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 28, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance removes a 142-square-meter piece of land at Calle Tronqued, Binondo, Manila, from being used as a public road. The land is being repurposed for the benefit of the city, as it has become a dumping site and a place for illegal activities. However, a 6-meter section along Estero de Magdalena must remain clear and not be developed.

ORDINANCE NO. 8544
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY OF MANILA TO ISSUE PERMIT OR LICENSE TO THE MANILA COCKERS CLUB, INC. (MCCI) TO ESTABLISH, OPERATE AND MAINTAIN OFF-COCKPIT BETTING STATIONS WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA TO SERVICE MCCI'S COCKFIGHTING OPERATIONS CONDUCTED IN CARMONA, CAVITE, SUBJECT TO EXISTING LAWS, RULES AND REGULATIONS

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the General Welfare Clause under Section 16, Chapter II, Title I, Book I of Republic Act 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, authorizes LGUs to grant licenses and regulate businesses and commercial activities within their jurisdiction;

WHEREAS, paragraph (a)(3)(v), Section 458 of the Local Government Code vests the power in the Sangguniang Panlungsod to regulate the establishment, operation and maintenance of cockpits, cockfighting, and commercial breeding of gamecocks;

WHEREAS, the Local Government Code empowers the LGU, through its chief executive, to issue licenses and permits to businesses and other commercial activities within their jurisdiction:

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. ISSUANCE OF PERMIT OR LICENSE.
The City of Manila is hereby authorized to issue a permit or license to the Manila Cockers Club, Inc. (MCCI) to establish, operate, and maintain off-cockpit betting stations within the City of Manila to service MCCI’s cockfighting operations conducted in Carmona, Cavite, subject to existing laws, rules, and regulations.

SEC. 2. CONDITIONS OF THE PERMIT OR LICENSE.
The permit or license to be issued to the MCCI shall be subject to the following conditions:

(a) The grant shall be valid for five (5) years and renewable for another five (5) years.
(b) Off-cockpit betting stations shall not be established within 200 meters of schools, places of worship, parks, plazas, hospitals, health centers, markets, barangay halls, and public buildings, and must comply with the city’s zoning ordinance.
(c) Persons below eighteen (18) years old are prohibited from betting or playing at the stations.
(d) Operators shall provide ample space for bettors and parking, ensuring no obstruction of traffic.
(e) Operators shall comply with national laws, city ordinances, the National Building Code, and other lawful regulations imposed by the City of Manila and relevant agencies.

SEC. 3. REPEALING CLAUSE.
All ordinances and issuances inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE.
If any provision of this Ordinance is held unconstitutional or invalid, the rest shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE.
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on May 7, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance allows the City of Manila to grant a business permit to Manila Cockers Club, Inc. (MCCI) so they can open and run off-cockpit betting stations in the city, even though the actual cockfights happen in Carmona, Cavite. These stations must follow strict rules—like not being near schools, churches, or public buildings, and ensuring bettors are at least 18 years old. The license lasts for 5 years and can be renewed for another 5 years.
fines: No specific fines mentioned, but operations must follow zoning laws and national/local regulations.

ORDINANCE NO. 8543
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE OBJECT OF EXPENDITURES SPECIFIED IN PARAGRAPH (B) UNDER THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES IN THE PROGRAMMED APPROPRIATION AND OBLIGATION OF THE OFFICE OF THE SANGGUNIANG PANLUNGSOD, UNDER ACCOUNT CODE NOS. 5-02-11-030 AND 5-02-11-990, AUTHORIZED THROUGH ORDINANCE NO. 8530, ALSO KNOWN AS THE EXECUTIVE BUDGET FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2018

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Paragraph (b) under Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses of Ordinance No. 8530, under Account Code Nos. 5-02-11-030 and 5-02-11-990 in the Programmed Appropriation and Obligation by Object of Expenditures of the Office of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, shall now be amended to be covered and lumped exclusively under Account Code No. 5-02-11-030, for consultancy services in the amount of Ten Million Pesos (PhP 10,000,000.00).

The said object of expenditures shall be expended to hire consultants for advice and/or research necessary for the adoption and enactment of legislative measures, and for other legislative affairs/concerns of the City Council covering the period June 1 to December 31, 2018.

SECTION 2. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 23, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance changes how a PhP10 million budget from the 2018 Executive Budget is categorized. The funds, originally split across two expense codes for the City Council, are now fully assigned under one code for hiring consultants. These consultants will assist the City Council with research and advice on legislation from June to December 2018.

ORDINANCE NO. 8542
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET NO. 1, CALENDAR YEAR 2018, IN THE AMOUNT OF TWO HUNDRED FIFTY MILLION PESOS (PHP 250,000,000.00)

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Authorization.
Supplemental Budget No. 1, Calendar Year 2018, in the amount of Two Hundred Fifty Million Pesos (PhP 250,000,000.00) to cover expenses for unforeseen expenditures, is hereby authorized, to wit:

Appropriations Breakdown

Implementing Office: Special Non-Office Expenditures (Statutory and Contractual Obligations)

Particulars / Purpose: To cover expenses for the provision for unforeseen expenditures

ALP Code: 9000-23

Object of Expenditures: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses

Account Code: 5-01-99-080

Amount: PHP 250,000,000.00

Total Appropriations: PHP 250,000,000.00

This is in accordance with the accompanying/attached investment program for S.B. No. 1, C.Y. 2018.

SECTION 2. Source of Funds.
The funds necessary to execute this Ordinance as specified in Section 1 hereof, in the amount of PHP 250,000,000.00, are hereby appropriated and sourced from funds actually available, as duly certified by the City Treasurer.

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 23, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance allows the Manila city government to use an additional budget of PhP 250 million for the year 2018. This extra budget, known as Supplemental Budget No. 1, will be used to cover unexpected expenses and obligations that were not originally planned for. The funds will go toward maintenance and operating expenses under the city's special non-office expenditures.

ORDINANCE NO. 8541
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY OF MANILA, THROUGH HONORABLE MAYOR JOSEPH EJERCITO ESTRADA, TO NEGOTIATE AND ENTER INTO AN AGREEMENT—EITHER THROUGH SALE, PURCHASE, OR OTHER LEGAL MODES OF ACQUISITION, AND IN CASE OF DEFAULT, BY EXPROPRIATION—OF A PARCEL OF LAND SITUATED AT BARANGAY 590, ZONE 58, DISTRICT VI, STA. MESA, MANILA, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 249208, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA, MEASURING THREE HUNDRED FIFTY-NINE SQUARE METERS AND THIRTY SQUARE DECIMETERS (359.30 SQ. M.), TO BE USED AS THE SITE OF A MULTI-PURPOSE HALL FOR THE COMMUNITY.

WHEREAS, Section 19 of the Local Government Code of the Philippines provides that a local government unit may, through its local chief executive and acting pursuant to an ordinance, exercise the power of eminent domain for public use, purpose, or welfare, for the benefit of the poor and landless, upon payment of just compensation, in accordance with the Constitution and relevant laws;
WHEREAS, general welfare necessitates the Local Government of Manila to provide venues for members of the community to congregate and conduct productive activities;
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Authority to Acquire Land
The Honorable Mayor of the City of Manila is hereby authorized to negotiate and enter into an agreement—either through sale, purchase, or other legal modes of acquisition, and in case of default, through expropriation—for the acquisition of a parcel of land situated at Barangay 590, Zone 58, District VI, Sta. Mesa, Manila, covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 249208 in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila, with a total land area of Three Hundred Fifty-Nine Square Meters and Thirty Square Decimeters (359.30 sq. m.).

SECTION 2. Purpose of Acquisition
The acquired land shall serve as the site for a multi-purpose hall to be used by the community.

SECTION 3. Appropriation of Funds
The amount necessary for the implementation of this Ordinance is hereby appropriated from the unappropriated funds available and existing in the City Treasury to ensure the objectives of this Ordinance are achieved.

SECTION 4. Separability Clause
If any provision or part of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions or parts not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 2, 2018.
short_text: This ordinance allows the City Government of Manila, through Mayor Joseph Estrada, to acquire a piece of land in Barangay 590, Sta. Mesa, either by buying it, using other legal means, or through expropriation if necessary. The land will be used to build a multi-purpose hall for community activities.

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTIONS 3 AND 4 OF CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8513, ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF MONTHLY INCENTIVE ALLOWANCE TO ALL LAWYERS OF THE PUBLIC ATTORNEY'S OFFICE ASSIGNED/BASED IN THE CITY PROVIDING FREE LEGAL ASSISTANCE TO THE RESIDENTS THEREAT, APPROPRIATING ANNUALLY THE AMOUNT OF SEVEN MILLION TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 7,200,000.00) FOR THE PURPOSE.”

ORDINANCE NO. 8538
AN ORDINANCE AFFIRMING THE EXISTING TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF BARANGAY 666, ZONE 72, DISTRICT V, MANILA, AND DEFINING ITS BOUNDARIES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Affirmation of Territorial Jurisdiction
This Ordinance affirms and defines the existing territorial jurisdiction of Barangay 666, Zone 72, District V, Manila. The boundaries are as follows:

North: From P. Burgos Street, National Museum (formerly the Legislative Building), Planetarium, and the northern part of the National Parks Development Committee Area.

East: Including Taft Avenue and the eastern part of the National Parks Development Committee Area, Tourism Building, Rizal Park, etc.

South: United Nations Avenue.

West: Manila Bay, Manila Ocean Park, and the western part of the National Parks Development Committee Area, including Quirino Grandstand, Army Navy Club, Museo Pambata, Seafood Wharf, etc.
This delineation is based on information from the maps of COMELEC — National Capital Region, which have served as the basis for election-related activities in the past and present.

SECTION 2. Affirmation of City Council Resolution
City Council Resolution No. 309, Series of 2017, is hereby affirmed.

SECTION 3. Transitory Provision
All income, real property taxes, business taxes, and governmental and corporate services within the area described above, which are incidental to the passing of this Ordinance, shall be collected, delivered, and performed by Barangay 666, Zone 72, District V, Manila.

SECTION 4. Amendment of Existing Ordinances
This Ordinance amends Ordinance No. 8368 and other existing Ordinances/Resolutions that are inconsistent with the intent of this Ordinance.

SECTION 5. Separability Clause
If any provision of this Ordinance is held unconstitutional or invalid, the other parts of the Ordinance not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SECTION 6. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 22, 2018.
short_text:
This ordinance confirms and defines the territorial boundaries of Barangay 666, Zone 72, District V, Manila.

Key Provisions:

Territorial Jurisdiction of Barangay 666:
The ordinance affirms the current boundaries of Barangay 666, which are outlined as follows:

North: From P. Burgos Street, National Museum, Planetarium, and the northern part of the National Parks Development Committee Area.

East: Includes Taft Avenue, eastern parts of the National Parks Development Committee Area, Tourism Building, and Rizal Park.

South: United Nations Avenue.

West: Manila Bay, Manila Ocean Park, Quirino Grandstand, Army Navy Club, Museo Pambata, Seafood Wharf, etc.

These boundaries are based on maps provided by the COMELEC for election-related activities.

ORDINANCE NO. 8537
AN ORDINANCE WITHDRAWING FROM PUBLIC USE PORTIONS OF THOSE PARCELS OF LAND OWNED BY THE CITY OF MANILA, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 15312 AND TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 19821, AND RECLASSIFYING THE SAME FROM ROAD LOT TO RESIDENTIAL LOT TO FORM PART OF THE PATRIMONIAL PROPERTY OF THE CITY, PROVIDING FOR ITS USE AS A SUITABLE SITE FOR THE LAND-FOR-THE-LANDLESS PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Withdrawal and Reclassification of Land
Portions of the parcels of land owned by the City of Manila, covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. 15312 (measuring approximately 1,698.80 square meters) and Transfer Certificate of Title No. 19821 (measuring approximately 526.70 square meters), located along Solis Street corner New Antipolo Street, within the jurisdiction of Barangay 214 and Barangay 217, Zone 20, District II, Manila, shall be withdrawn from public use and reclassified from road lot to residential lot.

SECTION 2. Use for the Land-for-the-Landless Program
The subject land parcels shall be used as residential lots and will form part of the City's Land-for-the-Landless Program. These lots will be awarded to actual and bona fide tenants through a sale on an installment basis.

SECTION 3. Oversight and Implementation
The City Urban Settlements Office (USO) shall oversee the effective implementation of this Ordinance.

SECTION 4. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 11, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance withdraws certain city-owned land from public use and reclassifies it from a road lot to a residential lot. The land will be used for the Land-for-the-Landless Program, where eligible tenants will have the opportunity to purchase the land on an installment basis.

ORDINANCE NO. 8536
AN ORDINANCE REPROGRAMMING THE AMOUNT OF ONE MILLION EIGHT HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 1,800,000.00) OF THE PROJECT PROCUREMENT MANAGEMENT PLAN OF THE CITY AUDITOR’S OFFICE FOR FISCAL YEAR 2017, APPROPRIATED IN THE ANNUAL EXECUTIVE BUDGET, CALENDAR YEAR 2017

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Reprogramming Authorization
This Ordinance authorizes the reprogramming of One Million Eight Hundred Thousand Pesos (PHP 1,800,000.00) from the 2017 Budget of the Office of the City Auditor of Manila, as approved in the Annual Executive Budget for CY 2017.

The reprogramming involves:

Reducing the amount appropriated for Machinery and Equipment from PHP 620,000.00 to PHP 320,000.00, which will now be allocated for Information and Communication Technology Equipment.

Increasing the amount appropriated for Transportation Equipment, Motor Vehicle from PHP 1,000,000.00 to PHP 1,300,000.00.

The amount appropriated for Other Property, Plant, and Equipment will remain at PHP 180,000.00.

These adjustments are all within the Capital Outlay of the City Auditor's Office, as originally authorized by the Annual Executive Budget for CY 2017.

SECTION 2. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 11, 2017.

Reprogramming of Funds:

PHP 620,000 allocated for Machinery and Equipment is reduced to PHP 320,000 and reallocated for Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Equipment.

PHP 1,000,000 initially allocated for Transportation Equipment (Motor Vehicle) is increased to PHP 1,300,000.

The allocation for Other Property, Plant, and Equipment remains at PHP 180,000.

ORDINANCE NO. 8535
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING AMNESTY OR CONDONATION TO DELINQUENT AWARDEES OF THE "LAND-FOR-THE-LANDLESS PROGRAM" OF THE CITY OF MANILA

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Grant of Amnesty and/or Condonation
All awardees of the "Land-for-the-Landless Program" of the City of Manila who are either currently paying the value of the land purchase or the tentative price and have been delinquent for at least three (3) months shall be granted amnesty or condonation for the payment of penalties or charges. These awardees shall be required to pay the full value of the purchase price within four (4) years, starting from January 1, 2018, to December 31, 2022.

SECTION 2. Acceptance and Undertaking
Awardees who avail themselves of the amnesty or condonation shall freely and voluntarily accept the terms. They must execute an undertaking to pay the total outstanding principal within the specified period. If they fail to do so, the Urban Settlements Office (USO) shall demand payment, and the City Treasurer's Office (CTO) will impose and collect the applicable penalties and charges in accordance with existing ordinances, rules, and regulations.

SECTION 3. Implementing Rules and Regulations
The Urban Settlements Office (USO), in coordination with the City Treasurer's Office (CTO) and the City Legal Office (CLO), shall draft and formulate the Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR) for the orderly enforcement of this Ordinance.

SECTION 4. Repealing Clause
All ordinances, city issuances, or parts thereof that are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SECTION 5. Separability Clause
If any provision of this Ordinance is found to be unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining provisions not affected shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 6. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 11, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance grants amnesty or condonation to people who have not been able to pay their debts under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of Manila for at least three months. They can now avoid penalties if they pay the full land price within four years, from January 1, 2018, to December 31, 2022. If they don’t pay in full by the end of this period, penalties will apply.
fines: Penalties will apply if full payment is not made within the given period.

ORDINANCE NO. 8534
AN ORDINANCE DECLARING THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF BARANGAY 666, ZONE 72, DISTRICT V, MANILA, AS DEFINED BY SPECIFIC LANDMARKS AND BOUNDARIES BASED ON MAPS FROM COMELEC — NATIONAL CAPITAL REGION

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Delineation of Boundaries
This Ordinance officially defines the territorial jurisdiction of Barangay 666, Zone 72, District V, Manila, with the following boundaries:

North: Padre Burgos Street, National Museum (former Legislative Building), Planetarium, and the northern portion of the National Parks Development Committee;

East: Taft Avenue, the eastern part of the National Parks Development Committee, the Tourism Building, Rizal Park, and adjacent landmarks;

South: United Nations Avenue;

West: Manila Bay, Manila Ocean Park, and the western section of the National Parks Development Committee including the Quirino Grandstand, Army Navy Club, Museo Pambata, Seafood Wharf, and similar sites.

This boundary delineation is in accordance with the official maps from COMELEC — National Capital Region, thereby affirming the intent of City Council Resolution No. 309, Series of 2017.

SECTION 2. Transitory Provision
All incomes derived from real property taxes, business taxes, and governmental or corporate services within the specified area shall henceforth be collected, managed, and rendered by Barangay 666, Zone 72, District V, Manila.

SECTION 3. Amendment Clause
This Ordinance amends Ordinance No. 8368 and all other existing ordinances or resolutions inconsistent with its provisions.

SECTION 4. Separability Clause
If any part or provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining provisions shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 4, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance officially sets the boundaries of Barangay 666, Zone 72, District V in Manila, based on landmarks and maps from COMELEC–NCR. It clearly defines its area—stretching from Padre Burgos Street and Rizal Park to Manila Bay and the Quirino Grandstand—and confirms that taxes and services from this zone will now be under Barangay 666’s control.

ORDINANCE NO. 8532
AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR A MONTHLY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO ALL MANILA FIRE DISTRICT PERSONNEL IN THE AMOUNT OF TWO THOUSAND FIVE HUNDRED PESOS (₱2,500.00) AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, it is high time to recognize the invaluable contributions of the men and women of the Manila Fire District in providing fire suppression and fire prevention services in the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, they have consistently demonstrated gallantry and dedication in their sworn duties, while also taking on vital roles in community safety by providing emergency medical and rescue services;

WHEREAS, their efforts extend to basic socio-civic activities such as water rationing, flushing operations, Ugnayan sa Barangay programs, civil disturbance management, and clean-up drives;

WHEREAS, the grant of financial assistance to personnel of the Manila Fire District will uplift the morale of the fire service and encourage them to work even harder in protecting the residents of Manila from the destructive effects of fires;

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
All 473 personnel of the Manila Fire Department shall be granted a monthly financial assistance of Two Thousand Five Hundred Pesos (₱2,500.00) starting Fiscal Year 2018.

SECTION 2.
The amount of Fourteen Million One Hundred Ninety Thousand Pesos (₱14,190,000.00) is hereby authorized to be appropriated from available funds not otherwise appropriated in the current appropriation ordinance.

SECTION 3.
The same financial assistance shall be included and appropriated in the Annual Executive Budget for the year following the enactment of this Ordinance.

SECTION 4. Repealing Clause.
All ordinances or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 23, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance grants a monthly financial assistance of PhP2,500 to each of the 473 personnel of the Manila Fire District. The purpose is to recognize their bravery and dedication in protecting the city through firefighting, rescue, and community services. A total of PhP14,190,000 was allocated from available funds, and the same support will continue in future city budgets.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8531
AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE INCREASE IN THE MONTHLY ALLOWANCES OF THE FIFTY-SIX (56) JUDGES OF THE REGIONAL TRIAL COURTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AND PROVIDING FUNDS NECESSARY THEREFOR

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the Regional Trial Court (RTC) Judges of Manila play a major role in the administration of justice and in preserving the rule of law in society;

WHEREAS, they have consistently proven themselves to be competent and dedicated public servants, despite being challenged by the unrelenting volume of cases for disposal and trials for hearing. There remains an undeniable need to incentivize the RTC Judges of Manila and recognize their efforts by heeding their recommendation for an increase in allowances;

WHEREAS, there is a pressing urgency to preserve the dignity of these officers of justice amid the strenuous demands of their work, the rising cost of living, and the sacrifices and risks they endure in the performance of their duties;

WHEREAS, maintaining the respect due to RTC Judges of Manila through the increase of their monthly allowances is essential to ensuring their continued effectiveness and enthusiasm in fulfilling their judicial functions;

WHEREAS, the Local Government of Manila is legally empowered to provide additional allowances or grant increases to the same:

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
The monthly allowance of the judges of the Regional Trial Courts in the City of Manila shall be increased to Twenty-Five Thousand Pesos (₱25,000.00), effective upon approval of this Ordinance.

SECTION 2.
The amount of Sixteen Million Eight Hundred Thousand Pesos (₱16,800,000.00) is hereby authorized to be appropriated from available funds not otherwise appropriated, for the implementation of Section 1 of this Ordinance.

SECTION 3.
The amount stated in Section 2 shall also be appropriated in the succeeding Annual Executive Budget following the enactment of this Ordinance.

SECTION 4. Repealing Clause.
All ordinances or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 2, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance increases the monthly allowance of the 56 Regional Trial Court (RTC) judges in Manila to PhP25,000. It recognizes their dedication and the challenges they face in handling a large number of cases. A total of PhP16.8 million is set aside from available funds to support this increase, and this amount will be included in the city's future annual budgets.

GENERAL PROVISION

SEC. 2. BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS. - The Budgetary Expenditures herein proposed shall comply with the following requirements:

(a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions, nor create new positions, without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.
(b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, the use of which requires a separate appropriation.
(c) The appropriation of the Non-Office Account, being a contingency fund or backup fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed to the different departments to finish certain programs/projects that were not sufficiently funded, cannot be utilized without specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Committee of Appropriations for approval.
(d) That Payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of barangay officials attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted.
(e) As additional funding source, any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee of Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee for authority to the Mayor to dispose the same thru public bidding.
(f) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solution and detergents) using the City Government funds should conform with Republic Act No. 9003, otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000, Republic Act No. 8749, and Republic Act No. 9275, otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence, products to be procured shall be limited to organic, biodegradable or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco-Labeling Program of Green Choice Philippines.
(g) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons With Disability under Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons, before the release of any payment.
(h) The Department of Engineering and Public Works shall be authorized to allot Four Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 400,000.00) for the utilities expenditures of the Sta. Ana Theater at Plaza Hugo in the 6th District of Manila.

SEC. 3. GENERAL LIMITATIONS. -

a. The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for Calendar Year 2018 shall not exceed Forty-Five Percent (45%) of the Total Annual Income sources realized in the next preceding Calendar Year;
b. No Official or Employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher than the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank, as determined by applicable laws, rules and regulations issued thereunder;
c. No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as maybe expressly authorized by law;
d. In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career services, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Rules and Regulations implementing R.A. 7160 and the Civil Service law, Rules and Regulations;
e. Positions in the Official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbent holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations;
f. No changes in designation nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed, except when the position is actually vacant and filling of such position shall be strictly made in accordance with Civil Service Law, Rules and Regulations;
g. The creation of new position and salary increase or adjustment shall in no case be made retroactive; and
h. The Annual appropriation for discretionary purpose of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipt delivered from basic real property tax in the next preceding fiscal year.

SEC. 4. ITEMIZATION OF PERSONAL SERVICES. - The itemization of Personal Services in support of the appropriation herein authorized for personal services shall form part of this Ordinance and shall be covered by its provisions.

SEC. 5. INTELLIGENCE EXPENSES. - The intelligence expenses provided under the ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. CHANGES IN THE ORGANIZATIONAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE MACHINERY. - All creation conversion, transfer, abolition and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services, Positions/Titles and Salary Grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 61 of the Department of Budget and Management.

a. For a more responsive efficient and effective organization within several departments and offices, conversion of certain positions, performing staff/non- technical functions were made as mandated by DBM Circular No. 2004-3.
b. Likewise, effected and adopted, is the abolition of certain vacant position in order to trim down the City bureaucracy to a leaner but more effective and economical organization.

SEC. 7. USE OF APPROPRIATED FUNDS. - All funds appropriated for functions, projects and activities shall be released and used exclusively for the specific purposes for which they have been authorized. Any amendment and augmentation may be made within the calendar year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.

SEC. 8. AUTHORITY TO ADJUST APPROPRIATIONS. - No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.

SEC. 9. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND. - The 20% Community Development Fund shall strictly be utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the Sangguniang Panlungsod in conformity with the Local Government Code.

SEC. 10. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) CONTINGENCY RESERVE. - Except for expenses due to public utilities, rentals, insurance premiums and food supplies expenses, a contingency reserve of 20% on the authorized 2017 appropriation for Departmental Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating therein the 20% contingency reserve.

SEC. 11. ALLOTMENT OF APPROPRIATIONS. - For effective budgetary control, authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with the DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder.

a. No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila, shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function, activity or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor, as hereafter provided. The Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted to the City Budget Officer not less than twenty-five (25) days prior to the beginning of the ensuing calendar year: PROVIDED, That in case the annual budget is approved after December 6 of each calendar year, the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted based on the appropriations authorized in the Budget Ordinance. A revised Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted upon approval of the Annual Executive Budget referred to herein showing quarterly allotment of the whole authorized appropriations for the department/office.
b. For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided, each calendar year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January, April, July and October.
c. The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer's notification and certification that the realized income is less than what is estimated in the annual/supplemental budget or that additional income is realized.
d. An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Office based on recommendation made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official, the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least five (5) days before the start of each quarter.

SEC. 12. NON-WAIVER CLAUSE. Notwithstanding the approval of this appropriation Ordinance by the Sangguniang Panlungsod, all contracts, disbursement, and awards entered into by the City of Manila including but not limited to the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, the Universidad de Manila and other government agencies and its instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455, Paragraph B, sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.

SEC. 13. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - If for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 14. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2018.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 2, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance sets aside PHP 14.88 billion for Manila’s 2018 city budget. The money will be used to fund city departments, services, and development projects from January to December 2018. It includes rules to make sure the budget is used properly — like requiring spending plans, following environmental laws when buying cleaning products, and ensuring public buildings are accessible to persons with disabilities. It also limits how much can be spent on salaries, discretionary funds, and intelligence operations. The Mayor needs City Council approval before selling any city-owned property. Special funds are also set aside for community development and emergency needs.

ORDINANCE NO. 8529

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE HONORABLE JOSEPH EJERCITO ESTRADA, MAYOR OF THE CITY OF MANILA, TO NEGOTIATE AND ENTER INTO AN AGREEMENT, EITHER THROUGH SALE, PURCHASE, AND OTHER LEGAL MODES OF ACQUISITION, AND IN CASE OF DEFAULT, THROUGH EXPROPRIATION, FOR THE ACQUISITION OF PARCELS OF LAND SITUATED AT AND ENCLOSED BY JUAN LUNA AND NICOLAS ZAMORA STREETS, CORNER CORAL STREET, TONDO, MANILA, TECHNICALLY DESCRIBED IN TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NOS. 157370, 157371, AND 157372, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF J.S.P. DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION, TO BE RESOLD ON AN INSTALLMENT BASIS TO THE MEMBERS OF THE TONDO CORAL NEIGHBORHOOD ASSOCIATION, INC., BARANGAY 59, ZONE 5, DISTRICT I, TONDO, MANILA; APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Authorization.
The Honorable Mayor of the City of Manila is hereby authorized to negotiate and enter into an agreement, either through sale, purchase, and other legal modes of acquisition, and in case of default, through expropriation, for the acquisition of parcels of land located at and enclosed by Juan Luna and Nicolas Zamora Streets, corner Coral Street, Barangay 59, Zone 5, District I, Tondo, Manila. These parcels are technically described in Transfer Certificate of Title Nos. 157370, 157371, and 157372, issued by the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila, and registered under the name of J.S.P. Development Corporation or its successors-in-interest, with a total area of Five Thousand Three Hundred Twenty-Seven Square Meters and Eighty Square Decimeters (5,327.80 sq. m.), more or less.

SEC. 2. Resale to Beneficiaries.
The acquired parcels of land shall be resold at cost, on an installment basis, to the members of the Tondo Coral Neighborhood Association, Inc., consisting of one hundred twenty (120) bona fide residential members and actual tenants, for a period not exceeding fifty (50) years, pursuant to the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City Government.

SEC. 3. Appropriation.
The amount of Fifty-Three Million Two Hundred Seventy-Eight Thousand Pesos (₱53,278,000.00), or so much thereof as may be necessary, is hereby appropriated out of the unappropriated funds available and existing in the City Treasury to implement the provisions and objectives of this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on October 19, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance allows the Mayor of Manila to acquire a large parcel of land in Tondo (located near Juan Luna, Nicolas Zamora, and Coral Streets) through sale, purchase, or expropriation if needed. The land will then be resold on an installment basis to 120 legitimate members and tenants of the Tondo Coral Neighborhood Association, Inc., as part of the city’s Land-for-the-Landless program to help residents own land where they already live.

short_text: This ordinance updates a previous law (Ordinance No. 8473) to clearly state that PhP11,387,340.00 from the Manila City Treasury will be used to acquire a piece of land in Barangay 88, Tondo. This land is intended for actual residents living there under the city's Land-for-the-Landless program, which helps provide land ownership to qualified urban poor families.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8527

AN ORDINANCE MANDATING THE MANILA DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING AND PUBLIC WORKS TO UNDERTAKE A CITYWIDE SURVEY AND EXAMINATION OF EXISTING OLD GOVERNMENT AND PRIVATELY-OWNED BUILDINGS, STUDENT DORMITORIES, SCHOOLS AND HOSPITALS, LANDMARKS AND CULTURAL HERITAGE BUILDINGS TO EVALUATE THEIR STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY, TO DETERMINE HOW TO CORRECT DEFICIENCIES AND IDENTIFY THOSE TO BE CONDEMNED, IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE DAMAGE TO PROPERTIES AND PREVENT LOSS OF LIFE IN THE EVENT OF STRONG EARTHQUAKES AND NATURAL DISASTERS, AND TO PROVIDE FUNDS THEREFOR

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the 6.7 magnitude earthquake that struck Surigao City on February 10, 2017, killed 8 people, injured 200, disrupted power and water supplies, damaged homes, buildings, roads, and bridges, and affected a total of 29,190 persons or 5,838 families across 54 barangays in Surigao del Norte, with property and infrastructure damage reaching ₱716 million as of the latest report;

WHEREAS, over 100 aftershocks, including a magnitude 4.9 tremor, further rocked Surigao City, which, according to state seismologists, was the strongest to hit the city since 1879, prompting the local government to declare a state of emergency the following day;

WHEREAS, this disastrous quake serves as a stark reminder of the need to prepare for “The Big One,” which the country's foremost earthquake experts warn could strike anytime and may be stronger than the Surigao earthquake or even more powerful than those that hit Bohol and Cebu in 2013;

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy.
Pursuant to Section 4 of Republic Act No. 10121, also known as the Philippine Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Act of 2010 (PDRRM–2010), which provides for the development of policies, plans, and implementation of actions and measures covering all aspects of disaster risk reduction and management—including good governance, risk assessment and early warning, knowledge building and awareness raising, reduction of underlying risk factors, and preparedness for effective response and recovery—it is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to ensure a constant state of readiness against strong earthquakes and to strengthen its disaster risk reduction capabilities.

SEC. 2. Mandate for Structural Survey.
In preparation for potential disaster caused by a powerful earthquake, the Department of Engineering and Public Works is hereby mandated to conduct a citywide survey and examination of the structural integrity and disaster-resistance of all existing old government and privately-owned buildings, including student dormitories, schools, hospitals, landmarks, and cultural heritage structures.

SEC. 3. Evaluation and Recommendations.
All structures mentioned above shall be assessed for their structural soundness and fitness for purpose. The survey shall identify buildings at risk of collapse, recommend appropriate structural improvements such as reinforcement or retrofitting, and determine which structures should be condemned as unfit for occupancy. This aims to minimize property damage and prevent loss of life in the event of strong earthquakes and other natural disasters.

SEC. 4. Funding.
The Department of Engineering and Public Works shall allocate the necessary funds for the execution of the citywide survey and structural assessments, including any other incidental expenses.

SEC. 5. Repealing Clause.
All ordinances, resolutions, or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, amended, or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on October 12, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance orders the Manila Department of Engineering and Public Works to conduct a citywide inspection of old buildings—both government- and privately-owned—including dormitories, schools, hospitals, landmarks, and heritage structures. The goal is to check if these buildings can withstand strong earthquakes. The department must identify unsafe buildings, recommend improvements, or declare them unfit for use to prevent property damage and save lives in case of natural disasters. Funds will be allocated to carry out this structural assessment.

This ordinance repeals Ordinance No. 8493 and restores the rightful share of real property tax (RPT) to Barangays 48, 49, 51 (Zone 4, District I) and 245, 247 (Zone 22, District II), which was previously removed. These barangays, along with Barangay 248, all have jurisdiction over parts of the Tutuban Commercial Complex. The city acknowledges the overlapping claims and reaffirms each barangay’s right to its proper share of the taxes collected from the area. The ordinance applies retroactively to cover any past periods where the shares were withheld.
status: Repealed (Ordinance No. 8493 and reinstated entitlements from Ordinance No. 8439)

ORDINANCE NO. 8525

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY MAYOR TO INITIATE THE EXPROPRIATION PROCEEDINGS OVER THE PROPERTY LOCATED AT 673 TO 687 BARCELONA STREET, BINONDO, MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the event that transpired from the ambiguity of the legal ownership of the property located at 673 to 687 Barcelona Street, Binondo, Manila, and the unlawful attempt to demolish the structures in the said property have led to the jeopardization of the lives and households of the twenty-six (26) underprivileged families that have been living there;

WHEREAS, in pursuance of the mandate to provide the best possible quality of life to our constituents, it is in the best interest of the City of Manila to take responsibility for the legal facets of the aforesaid property;

WHEREAS, in doing so, the twenty-six (26) underprivileged families will be assured of their rightful access to a better life;

WHEREAS, through the exercise of the power of eminent domain, the affected private property shall be acquired by the local government unit through expropriation proceedings;

WHEREFORE, on motion of Kagawad Geofrey Angelo F. Trinidad, duly seconded by Kagawads Rebecca dela Cruz, Eduardo Herrera, Joenel Hung, and Rolando Dollosa of Barangay 273, Zone 25, Chairwoman Mary Ann L. Arboleda endorsed to the City Council of Manila their Barangay Resolution No. 08-2017 with a prayer for expropriation of the property located at 673 to 687 Barcelona Street, Binondo, Manila, containing an area of Five Hundred Seventy-Three Square Meters and Five Square Decimeters (573.5 Sq.M.), more or less, with a market value of Nine Million Three Hundred Seventy-One Thousand Three Hundred Sixty Pesos (PhP 9,371,360.00), as reflected in the tax declaration of Real Property for the current year: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Expropriation Proceedings
The power of Eminent Domain is exercised, thus, Expropriation Proceedings are authorized in the acquisition of the lot located at 673 to 687 Barcelona Street, Binondo, Manila, to protect the interest of twenty-six (26) families and households living there, as the owner, Isabel Bibby Vda. De Padilla, refused to negotiate with the association involved.

SECTION 2. Authority to Initiate Proceedings
Authority is hereby granted to the City Mayor to initiate the expropriation proceedings over the property located at 673 to 687 Barcelona Street, Binondo, Manila, containing an area of Five Hundred Seventy-Three Square Meters and Five Square Decimeters (573.5 Sq.M.).

SECTION 3. Funding Allocation
The amount of Nine Million Three Hundred Seventy-One Thousand Three Hundred Sixty Pesos (PhP 9,371,360.00) is hereby authorized to be charged against the yearly program budget of the Urban Settlements Office, specifically, vis-a-vis the Fifty Million Pesos (PhP 50,000,000.00) yearly appropriation provided to the Urban Settlements Office for the said purpose.

SECTION 4. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 26, 2017.

CERTIFICATION
This is to certify that CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8525, "AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY MAYOR TO INITIATE THE EXPROPRIATION PROCEEDINGS OVER THE PROPERTY LOCATED AT 673 TO 687 BARCELONA STREET, BINONDO, MANILA" was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on September 26, 2017. The same was forwarded to and received by the Office of the Honorable Mayor on October 4, 2017.

The said Ordinance was returned to this office without action on February 28, 2018 by the Local Chief Executive, thus Ordinance No. 8525 should have been DEEMED APPROVED as if the Local Chief Executive had signed it, pursuant to Section 54, paragraph (b) of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

Issued this 3rd day of September 2019, in the City of Manila.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the City Mayor to initiate expropriation proceedings to acquire a property located at 673 to 687 Barcelona Street, Binondo, Manila. This action is taken to protect the twenty-six (26) underprivileged families living there, as the property owner refused to negotiate for their relocation. The land, valued at PhP9,371,360.00, will be acquired using the City’s Urban Settlements Office budget, with the goal of securing a better living situation for these families.

ORDINANCE NO. 8523

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR A GRANT OF SEVEN HUNDRED SIXTY PESOS (PhP 760.00) MONTHLY ALLOWANCE TO TWO HUNDRED THIRTY-SIX (236) BUREAU OF JAIL MANAGEMENT AND PENALOGY PERSONNEL COVERING THE PERIOD OF JANUARY TO DECEMBER 2017, FOR A TOTAL AMOUNT OF TWO MILLION ONE HUNDRED FIFTY-THREE THOUSAND PESOS (PhP 2,153,000.00) PER ANNUM

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. POLICY STATEMENT
It is the declared policy of the City Government of Manila, subject to its financial capacity, to provide allowances and benefits to government officials and personnel stationed or assigned to the city, with the aim of strengthening their capacity to deliver effective and necessary services to the people of Manila.

SEC. 2. ALLOWANCE GRANT
Pursuant to the policy above, the following allowances shall be provided to the two hundred thirty-six (236) Bureau of Jail Management and Penology personnel assigned to the City of Manila:

a) A monthly allowance in the amount of Seven Hundred Sixty Pesos (PhP 760.00) per person.

b) The total yearly allowance for all personnel amounts to Two Million One Hundred Fifty-Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 2,153,000.00).

SEC. 3. FUNDING AND ALLOCATION
The total amount of Two Million One Hundred Fifty-Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 2,153,000.00) is hereby authorized and allocated. This amount shall be sourced from the Manila Peace and Order Council (MPOC) Intervention Programs under the General Fund for FY 2017. These funds shall be used for the payment of the monthly allowances for the two hundred thirty-six (236) Bureau of Jail Management and Penology personnel covering the period from January to December 2017, in accordance with accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

SEC. 4. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on May 2, 2017.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8522

AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE CHINATOWN DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL, DEFINING ITS JURISDICTION, FUNCTIONS, DUTIES, AND PURPOSE FOR THE PROMOTION OF CHINESE-FILIPINO CULTURE AND TOURISM IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Manila includes a territory within its jurisdiction officially designated as Chinatown, located in the Binondo District on the northern bank of the Pasig River, where a significant portion of the City’s Filipino-Chinese community resides;

WHEREAS, Chinatown is widely recognized as the premier commercial and financial district of the City of Manila, with Filipino-Chinese business enterprises firmly established and commerce and trade historically active in the area;

WHEREAS, in recent years, the Chinatown area has experienced deterioration due to the lack of development, maintenance, and promotion of its unique character and reputation. Consequently, many Filipino-Chinese businesses have relocated to more favorable areas with better accessibility and security;

WHEREAS, despite these challenges, many Filipino-Chinese entrepreneurs remain optimistic and continue to affirm that Chinatown remains a vital center of financial activity and cultural heritage combining Filipino and Chinese traditions;

WHEREAS, the City of Manila commits to supporting the revitalization and development of Chinatown through policies and plans that ensure sustainable, effective, and equitable progress, including the promotion of Chinese-Filipino culture and tourism;

WHEREAS, under Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, the City of Manila, led by Honorable City Mayor Joseph Ejercito Estrada, is empowered to establish multi-sectoral Local Development Councils (LDCs) within its jurisdiction;

NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. CREATION OF THE CHINATOWN DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL (CDC)
There is hereby created the Chinatown Development Council (CDC), a local development council tasked with revitalizing and enhancing Chinatown’s economic activities while promoting Chinese-Filipino culture and heritage.

SEC. 2. POWERS AND FUNCTIONS OF THE CDC
The CDC shall exercise the following powers and perform the following functions:

a. Promote and develop Chinese-Filipino culture and historical awareness;
b. Formulate short- and long-term development plans incorporating Chinese-Filipino cultural elements appropriate to contemporary times, and recommend the same to the City Mayor for approval;
c. Regulate, monitor, and supervise festivals, pageants, commemorations, conventions, and other events that promote Chinese-Filipino culture and history;
d. Serve as the official depository of all historical, cultural, and artistic items of value belonging to the City Government of Manila that pertain to Chinese-Filipino culture and history. The CDC shall maintain, preserve, and compile such items in a secure area designated by the City Government for this purpose;
e. Perform other related functions necessary to achieve the objectives outlined above.

SEC. 3. COMPOSITION OF THE CHINATOWN DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL (CDC)
The CDC shall be composed of fourteen (14) members and a Secretariat.

The Secretariat shall be appointed by the City Mayor and shall be responsible for implementing the resolutions and decisions of the CDC.

The fourteen (14) members include:

Nine (9) Government Officials:
a. City Engineer, Office of the Mayor
b. City Planning Officer, Office of the Mayor
c. Local Tourism Officer, Office of the Mayor
d. Director, Manila Barangay Bureau
e. Chairman, Committee on Laws, City Council of Manila
f. Chairman, Committee on Housing, Land, Urban Planning Development, and Resettlement, City Council of Manila
g. Chairman, Committee on Tourism, City Council of Manila
h. Councilor from District III
i. Barangay Chairman from District III

Five (5) Ex-Officio Members Appointed by the City Mayor from the Non-Governmental Sector:
j. Representative from the Chinatown Business Association
k. Representative from the Real Property Owners Association within Chinatown
l. Representative from Chinese Educational Institutions within the Chinatown area
m. Representative from Property Developers and Investors
n. Academic consultant on Chinese-Filipino culture and history

SEC. 4. REPEALING CLAUSE
All ordinances, orders, issuances, memoranda, or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed, superseded, canceled, and/or revoked accordingly.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and enactment, in accordance with the law.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on April 4, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance establishes the Chinatown Development Council (CDC) to revitalize and enhance Chinatown in Manila. The CDC will focus on promoting Chinese-Filipino culture, regulating events, and preserving historical and cultural items related to the Filipino-Chinese heritage. The council will also help develop plans to improve Chinatown's economy and attract tourism.

This ordinance bans the use of cigarettes, vapes, and other tobacco products inside and around all buildings owned, controlled, or used by the Manila City Government, including places like Manila City Hall, public schools, and hospitals. Smoking is not allowed indoors, within the building compounds, or within 100 meters of these buildings. A single outdoor smoking area may be designated per building, provided it follows strict conditions like being far from entrances and not accessible to minors. Violators will face fines and possible jail time depending on how many times they’ve offended.
fines:
1st Offense: Up to PhP2,000 fine and/or 1 day imprisonment

2nd Offense: Up to PhP3,000 fine and/or 2 days imprisonment

3rd and succeeding offenses: Up to PhP5,000 fine and/or 3 days imprisonment

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8520

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING THE SELLING TO, ORDERING/REQUESTING TO SELL TO, AND SENDING A MINOR ON AN ERRAND TO BUY WINE, LIQUOR, OR ANY ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES FROM ANY STORE, MALL, BAR, RESTAURANT, EATERY, OR ANY COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT IN THE CITY OF MANILA, AND PRESCRIBING PENALTIES THEREFOR

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. DECLARATION OF POLICY
It is hereby declared the policy of the City of Manila to promote and protect the physical and moral well-being of the youth from any form of vice that is detrimental to their health, safety, and intellectual growth and development, and to pursue at all times the general welfare of the residents.

SEC. 2. DEFINITION OF TERMS
a. Minor – refers to any individual below eighteen (18) years of age.
b. Liquor – any liquid substance that contains intoxicating alcoholic properties and effects when consumed. This includes, but is not limited to, wine, whisky, brandy, rum, gin, vodka, and local alcoholic beverages such as tuba, bahalina, lambanog, beer, and/or any form of mixture or concoction thereof.
c. Commercial Establishment – includes stores, malls, bars, restaurants, eateries, and any business entity owned by a proprietor or corporation doing business in the City of Manila, whether or not duly permitted.
d. Offenders – includes store owners, managers, employees, or crew members of any commercial establishment who sell liquor to minors, who are considered children at risk. It also includes any person who sends a minor on an errand to buy/purchase liquor and/or alcoholic beverages from a store.

SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES
It shall be unlawful for:

Store owners, managers, employees, or crew of commercial establishments to sell liquor or alcoholic beverages to minors.

Any person to send a minor on an errand to buy or purchase liquor or alcoholic beverages.

Treatment of Minors Caught Possessing Alcoholic Substances:
If apprehended by Barangay authorities: The minor shall be processed and released to their parents or guardian upon signing of an undertaking that the child will not repeat the offense.

If apprehended by Police authorities: The minor shall be processed and released by the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW) officer to the parents or guardian upon signing of an undertaking with the same condition.

Penalties for Selling Liquor to Minors:
First Offense: PHP 200.00 fine

Second Offense: PHP 500.00 fine

Third Offense: PHP 1,000.00 fine or six (6) months imprisonment, or both, at the discretion of the court; plus revocation of business permit

Penalties for Sending a Minor to Buy Liquor:
First Offense: PHP 200.00 fine

Second Offense: PHP 500.00 fine

Third Offense: PHP 1,000.00 fine or six (6) months imprisonment, or both, at the discretion of the court

SEC. 4. DISPOSAL OF CONFISCATED ALCOHOL
Any alcoholic substance seized from a minor shall be publicly disposed of by law enforcement authorities.

SEC. 5. IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS (IRR)
The drafting of the Implementing Rules and Regulations of this Ordinance shall be led by the Manila Department of Social Welfare (MDSW), in coordination with the City Legal Department and other concerned agencies as necessary.

SEC. 6. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE
If any part, section, or provision of this Ordinance is held invalid, illegal, or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. REPEALING CLAUSE
All ordinances, rules, and regulations or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE
This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after posting on bulletin boards in public places or publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

ENACTED by the City Council of Manila on February 9, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance makes it illegal in Manila for anyone to sell, request, or send a minor (anyone under 18) to buy wine, liquor, or any kind of alcoholic drink from any store, mall, bar, restaurant, or business. Even sending a minor to buy alcohol for someone else is not allowed. If caught, the alcohol will be publicly destroyed. Penalties increase for repeat offenders and may include business permit revocation or jail time. Minors caught with alcohol will be released to their guardians after a commitment that it won't happen again.
fines:
Selling to minors:
 • 1st Offense: PHP 200
 • 2nd Offense: PHP 500
 • 3rd Offense: PhP1,000 or 6 months imprisonment (or both) + business permit revocation

 • 1st Offense: PHP 200
 • 2nd Offense: PHP 500
 • 3rd Offense: PHP 1,000 or 6 months imprisonment (or both)

ORDINANCE NO. 8519

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING SMOKEY MOUNTAIN COMMUNITY ASSOCIATION, INCORPORATED, A FRANCHISE TO OPERATE A PRIVATELY OWNED PUBLIC MARKET LOCATED AT SMOKEY MOUNTAIN, BALUT, TONDO, MANILA, UNDER CERTAIN TERMS AND CONDITIONS

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Smokey Mountain Community Association, Inc. is hereby granted a franchise to operate a privately-owned public market located at Smokey Mountain, Balut, Tondo, Manila, subject to the following terms and conditions:

a) The franchisee shall pay the franchise fee prescribed under Ordinance No. 7988 (Revenue Code of Manila, as amended). For this purpose, the books of accounts of the franchisee reflecting its gross receipts shall be made available to the City Treasurer or his duly authorized representative/s for inspection.

b) The City shall continue to have and exercise the power to impose all applicable permit and license fees and other service charges upon the franchisee and the stallholders, in accordance with existing ordinances, rules, and regulations.

c) The City shall likewise exercise the power granted by law to regulate, inspect, and supervise the operation of the market to ensure compliance with pertinent rules and regulations.

d) The franchisee, in order to ensure the collection of revenues due to the City, shall have the authority to adopt such measures, impose charges and penalties, and effect collection from stallholders.

e) The franchisee shall ensure that the administration of the market is conducted in the most efficient manner, in faithful compliance with the terms and conditions of this grant.

f) In the award of stalls, preferential rights shall be accorded to qualified residents of the City of Manila.

g) The franchisee shall post a continuing bond of ONE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 100,000.00) in favor of the City, which shall be forfeited as liquidated damages in case of failure of the franchisee to do, perform, and comply with any of the terms and conditions set forth herein.

h) The operating expenses for the said privately-owned public market, including maintenance, cleanliness, and sanitation, shall be borne by the franchisee.

i) Installation of four (4) digital “Timbangan ng Bayan” in conspicuous and easily accessible places within the area of operation shall be required.

j) The chapel or place of worship shall be transferred to the second floor, and the ironworks shop (welding shop) shall be relocated.

SECTION 2.
The authority granted herein shall be for a period of ten (10) years from the date of approval, subject to renewal in accordance with the provisions of this grant.

SECTION 3.
Any violation or breach on the part of the franchisee to comply with any of the terms and conditions set forth above shall be a ground for the outright cancellation of the franchise, revocation of the permit issued, and closure of the market premises.

SECTION 4.
Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 12, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance gives Smokey Mountain Community Association, Inc. a 10-year franchise to operate a privately owned public market at Smokey Mountain, Balut, Tondo, Manila. The market must follow city rules on fees, inspections, and operations. The franchisee must maintain the market, install weighing scales, relocate certain facilities, and prioritize stall awards to qualified Manila residents. A 100,000 Pesos bond is required as a guarantee. The City retains regulatory authority and may cancel the franchise for violations.
fines: PHP 100,000 bond forfeiture for non-compliance; cancellation of franchise and market closure for violations

ORDINANCE NO. 8518

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8323, ENTITLED: “AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE MANILA DISASTER RISK REDUCTION AND MANAGEMENT OFFICE, DEFINING ITS DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES, PROVIDING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES”

WHEREAS, on August 13, 2013, the City Council enacted Ordinance No. 8323, entitled: “An Ordinance Creating the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO), Defining its Duties and Responsibilities, Providing the Necessary Funds Therefor and for Other Purposes,” which was approved by the City Mayor on September 4, 2013;

WHEREAS, on April 4, 2014, the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC), the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), the Department of Budget and Management (DBM), and the Civil Service Commission (CSC) issued Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2014-1, providing guidelines on the establishment of Local Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Offices (LDRRMOs) for various LGUs, classifying the City of Manila as a Special City;

WHEREAS, Item 5.0 of the said Joint Memorandum Circular prescribes the proper organization and composition of the LDRRMO;

WHEREAS, Item 6.2 prescribes the appropriate salary grades corresponding to new position titles and minimum qualification standards;

WHEREAS, Section 76 of the Local Government Code provides that every LGU shall design and implement its own organizational structure and staffing pattern, subject to service requirements, financial capability, and the minimum standards and guidelines set by the CSC;

NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, that:

SECTION 1. PURPOSE
This Ordinance is enacted to strengthen the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO) by correcting position titles, qualification standards, and salary grades of its personnel in accordance with Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2014-1 and pertinent CSC rules.

SEC. 2. AMENDMENT TO THE MDRRMC COMPOSITION
Section 8, Chapter 3 of Ordinance No. 8323 is hereby amended to include the Head of the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) as a member of the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (MDRRMC). The amended section shall read:

“SEC. 8. Composition
The MDRRMC shall be composed of:

(a) Chairman – City Mayor
(b) Vice-Chairman – City Vice-Mayor
(c) Members:
– City Administrator
– City Council Chairperson for Police, Peace and Order, Fire, and Public Safety
– City Council Chairperson for Barangay Affairs
– Chief, City Planning and Development Office
– Chief, City Health Office
– Chief, City Engineering Office
– Chief, City Budget Office
– Head, Gender and Development Office
– Head, Social Welfare and Development Office
– Chief, City Veterinary Office
– City Schools Superintendent
– Highest-ranking AFP Officer assigned in the City (if any)
– Chief of Police assigned in the City
– City Fire Marshal assigned in the City
– Head, Philippine Red Cross – Manila Chapter
– Director-Head, Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB)

The MDRRMC shall determine the criteria for selecting additional members including:
– Four (4) representatives from accredited civil society organizations
– One (1) representative from the private sector.”

SEC. 3. AMENDMENT TO MDRRMO FUNCTIONS
Section 12, Chapter 4 of Ordinance No. 8323 is amended to include full control over the Emergency Response Action Program–Centralized Command and Control Center (ERAP-C4). The section shall read:

“SEC. 12. Functions.
The MDRRMO shall coordinate with concerned agencies and perform the following functions:

(a) Design and formulate disaster risk reduction and management plans consistent with national standards and guidelines for MDRRMC approval.
(b) Identify and assess hazards, vulnerabilities, and risks in the city; consolidate local disaster risk data and maintain a City Risk Map.
(c) Facilitate and coordinate risk assessments, contingency planning, and disaster responses at city and barangay levels.
(d) Operate a multi-hazard early warning system using mass media, radio, and communications technology.
(e) Maintain a database of human resources, equipment, directories, and the location/capacity of critical infrastructure such as hospitals and evacuation centers.
(f) Identify high-risk disaster areas and execute effective rescue and evacuation plans.
(g) Take full control of the ERAP-C4 from the MTPB, ensuring disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation integration.
(h) Respond to and manage emergencies and recovery activities, including networking with other entities.
(i) Perform such other functions as assigned by the MDRRMC.”

SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO MDRRMO STRUCTURE
Section 13, Chapter 4 of Ordinance No. 8323 is hereby amended to restructure the MDRRMO and establish new positions in accordance with Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2014-1.

“SEC. 13. Structure of the MDRRMO.
The MDRRMO shall operate under the Office of the City Mayor and consist of the following divisions:

Administrative and Training Division

Operations and Warning Division

Research and Planning Division

The Operations and Warning Division will have the following five (5) sections:

Manila Civil Defense Force (MCDF) Section

Disaster and Medical Assistance Team (DMAT) Section

Communications Emergency Readiness Team (COMERT) Section

Disaster Mortuary (DMORT) Section

Climate Change Adaptation Team (CMAT) Section

SEC. 13.a POSITIONS, SALARY GRADES, AND QUALIFICATIONS
Personnel shall be appointed or designated by the City Mayor, subject to civil service laws and rules. The following mandatory positions are created:

I. MDRRMO Director – Dept. Head III, SG-27
– Bachelor’s Degree
– Career Service Professional Eligibility
– 5 years supervisory/management experience, with 1 year in DRRM
– 32 hours of management training

II. Admin & Training Division Chief – Admin Officer II, SG-25
III. Operations & Warning Division Chief – Civil Defense Officer II, SG-25
IV. Research & Planning Division Chief – Planning Officer II, SG-25
(Same qualifications as Director above)

SEC. 13.a. POSITIONS, SALARY GRADES, AND QUALIFICATIONS
Personnel shall be appointed or designated by the City Mayor, subject to civil service laws and rules.

Mandatory Positions:

III. Operations and Warning Division – Sectional Units
1. Manila Civil Defense Force (MCDF)
