SEC. 5. FUNDING
Funding for the organizational changes and new positions shall be sourced from the City Government's budget, subject to accounting and auditing rules. Additional budget requirements may be included in the annual executive budget proposal.

SEC. 6. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 7. REPEALING CLAUSE
All ordinances, rules, and regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVITY
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 12, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance updates the structure and staffing of the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO), originally created in 2013. It aligns the office with national standards based on Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2014-1. Key changes include adding the Manila Traffic and Parking Bureau (MTPB) head as a council member, giving MDRRMO full control over the city’s emergency command center (ERAP-C4), and restructuring the office into specialized divisions and teams (e.g., Civil Defense, Medical Assistance, Emergency Communications, Mortuary Services, and Climate Adaptation). New mandatory positions were also created with detailed qualifications and salary grades.

ORDINANCE NO. 8516

AN ORDINANCE REPEALING THE SECOND PERIOD INCREASE OF REAL PROPERTY TAX SCHEDULED TO TAKE EFFECT IN FISCAL YEAR 2017, AS STATED UNDER SECTION 3(d) OF ORDINANCE NO. 8330, ENTITLED: “THE 2014 GENERAL REVISION OF REAL PROPERTY ASSESSMENTS AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8375”

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, City Ordinance No. 8330 was passed into law on December 3, 2013, and took effect on January 1, 2014;

WHEREAS, the passage of City Ordinance No. 8330 was done as per the order of the Department of Finance through the Bureau of Local Government and the Commission on Audit;

WHEREAS, Section 3(d) of Ordinance No. 8330 was amended by Ordinance No. 8375 on December 4, 2014, to wit:

“SEC. 3. The Department of Assessment shall adopt the newly approved schedules specified in Section 1 hereof: PROVIDED, that:

d. The amount of tax to be paid by virtue hereof shall in no case be lower than the tax imposed thereon in 2013. Any tax increase, as a consequence of this Ordinance, shall be staggered into two (2) periods of payments at the rate of 60% for the first period (2014 to 2016) and 40% for the second period (2017), provided that the said rates are based on the incremental values of real properties. However:

i. For the first payment period (2014 to 2016), the total amount of tax to be paid on land, buildings, and other structures and machineries used for residential, commercial, and industrial purposes shall in no case be more than double the tax imposed for 2013 on the same real property;

ii. For the second payment period (2017) and succeeding years, the total amount of tax to be paid shall not exceed 150% of the tax imposed for 2013;

iii. It is understood, therefore, that the herein staggered relief pursuant to Section 192 of R.A. 7169 shall be applied only for a period of two (2) payment periods from the effectivity hereof.”

WHEREAS, in the implementation of said ordinance, the Real Property Tax collection considerably increased, resulting in additional revenues for the city, which boosted the funds in the City’s Coffers and Treasury;

WHEREAS, in the implementation of the first period increase in real property tax (60%), the considerable increase in tax collection enabled the City Government of Manila to pay and settle its debt obligations. The previous debt servicing payments made by the city throughout the years have been eradicated;

WHEREAS, the implementation of said increase had consequential results for the people. It is a fact that additional taxes place an additional burden on the paying public. As the saying goes, “Too much of the taxes may kill the horse that delivers the hay.” Thus, with the year 2017 fast approaching, the start of the second period stated in City Ordinance No. 8375 would be implemented soon unless legislative action is taken. Another tax increase, the 40% increase stated in City Ordinance No. 8330, would burden the public;

WHEREAS, there is a need to reconsider the impending implementation of the second period increase (40%) in Real Property Tax in 2017. NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. It is a principle of law that taxes are each and everyone's obligation to the government. It is every individual’s participation in sustaining and maintaining our government’s costs. Tax is the lifeblood of our government. Without it, there can be no funding for the public services our government provides. It is an inherent power of the government to create its own sources of revenue by law.

The power of taxation by our government is exercised not as an exercise of police power, but rather as a necessary means to settle the City Government's debts and obligations, which must be addressed to maintain public services.

As the increase stated in City Ordinance No. 8330 was divided into two periods (60% and 40%), with the first period implemented in January 2014, the propriety and necessity of implementing the second period (40% increase) are hereby re-evaluated.

As stated in the preceding paragraphs, the implementation of the first period increase led to a significant boost in the city’s funds, which allowed the City Government to settle its debts and remove most of its debt servicing obligations.

Maintaining the current tax rate without implementing the second period increase in 2017 would not be detrimental to the City Government of Manila. Since there is no more debt servicing to be accounted for, the City Government can now allocate its funds for further improvements to projects and programs without imposing additional burden on the public.

Thus, the portion of City Ordinance No. 8330, as amended by City Ordinance No. 8375, that provides for a second period increase of 40% in the real property tax rates is hereby REPEALED. Section 3(d) of said ordinance is hereby amended to read as follows:

“SEC. 3:

d. The amount of tax to be paid by virtue hereof shall in no case be lower than the tax imposed thereon in 2013. Any tax increase, as a consequence of this Ordinance, shall be at the rate of 60%, provided that the said rates are based on the incremental values of real properties. However:

i. The total amount of tax to be paid on land, buildings, and other structures and machineries used for residential, commercial, and industrial purposes shall in no case be more than double the tax imposed for 2013 on the same real property.”

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause – This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 10, 2017.
short_text: This ordinance cancels the second period (40%) increase in real property taxes that was supposed to take effect in 2017, as part of the city's plan to gradually increase taxes over two periods. The first increase (60%) was implemented in 2014 and helped the city pay off its debts. Since the city has already settled most of its debts, this ordinance removes the planned 40% tax increase, keeping taxes at the 60% increase rate, which won’t exceed double the tax rate from 2013.
status: Repealed (Repealed the 40% second period increase from Ordinance No. 8330)

GENERAL PROVISION
SEC. 2. BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS. — The Budgetary Expenditures herein proposed shall comply with the following requirements:
(a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions, nor create new positions, without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.
(b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, the use of which requires a separate appropriation.
(c) The appropriation of the Non-Office Account, being a contingency fund or backup fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed by the different departments to finish certain programs/projects that were not sufficiently funded, cannot be utilized without a specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Committee on Appropriations for approval.
(d) Payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of barangay officials attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted.
(e) As an additional funding source, any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee on Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the Sangguniang Panlungsod through the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee for authority to the Mayor to dispose the same through public bidding.
(f) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solutions and detergents) using the City Government funds should conform with Republic Act No. 9003, otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000; Republic Act No. 8749; and Republic Act No. 9275, otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence, products to be procured shall be limited to organic, biodegradable, or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco-Labeling Program of Green Choice Philippines.
(g) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons With Disability under Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons, before the release of any payment.
(h) Amendments/Changes made in the Executive Budget for FY 2017 are as follows:
•        h.1. The amount of PhP 59,856,650.00 from the MOE’s for Drug and Medicines of each Hospital — Ospital ng Maynila, Sta. Ana Hospital, Justice Jose Abad Santos Hospital, Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center, Ospital ng Sampaloc, and Ospital ng Tondo II — has been realigned to the Manila Health Department’s MOE for its medicine requirements.
(i) The Manila Traffic & Parking Bureau's MOE with Account Code No. 5-02-12-990 was increased by Two Hundred One Million Pesos, sourced from Account Code No. 1-07-03-990 of the Department of Engineering & Public Works.
(j) The Manila Tricycle Regulatory Office’s MOE with Account Code No. 5-02-99-990 was increased by Ninety Million Pesos through the transfer of funds from the Department of Engineering & Public Works, Account Code No. 1-07-04-010.
(k) Department of Engineering & Public Works: Fifty Million Pesos from Account Code No. 1-07-04-010 was realigned to Account Code No. 5-02-99-050 of the same office to support the Flood Control Program of Manila.
(l) Justice Jose Abad Santos Hospital increased its Training Expenses, Account Code No. 5-02-02-010, by PhP 1,200,000.00 sourced from the reduction in the Drugs and Medicine Expenses.
(m) Funds totaling Fifteen Million Pesos from the Office of the Vice-Mayor (for Consultancy Service), Five Million Pesos and Ten Million Pesos from Account Code No. 5-02-11-090, were conveyed to support the Medicine & Drugs requirements of the Manila Health Department.

SEC. 3. GENERAL LIMITATIONS. — 
(a) The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for Fiscal Year 2017 shall not exceed forty-five percent (45%) of the total annual income sources realized in the next preceding fiscal year;
(b) No official or employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher than the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank, as determined by applicable laws, rules, and regulations issued thereunder;
(c) No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as may be expressly authorized by law;
(d) In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career service, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Rules and Regulations implementing R.A. 7160 and the Civil Service Law, Rules, and Regulations;
(e) Positions in the official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbents holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations;
(f) No changes in designation nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed, except when the position is actually vacant and the filling of such position shall be strictly made in accordance with the Civil Service Law, Rules, and Regulations;
(g) The creation of new positions and salary increases or adjustments shall in no case be made retroactive; and
(h) The annual appropriation for discretionary purposes of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipts derived from basic real property tax in the next preceding fiscal year.

SEC. 4. ITEMIZATION OF PERSONAL SERVICES.  — The itemization of Personal Services in support of the appropriation herein authorized for personal services shall form part of this Ordinance and shall be covered by its provisions.

SEC. 5. INTELLIGENCE EXPENSES. — The intelligence expenses provided under this Ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities, and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. CHANGES IN THE ORGANIZATIONAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE MACHINERY. —  All creation, conversion, transfer, abolition, and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services, Positions/Titles, and Salary Grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 61 of the Department of Budget and Management.
(a) For a more responsive, efficient, and effective organization within several departments and offices, conversion of certain positions performing staff/non-technical functions were made as mandated by DBM Circular No. 2004-3.
(b) Likewise, effect and adopt the abolition of certain vacant positions in order to trim down the City bureaucracy to a leaner but more effective and economical organization.

SEC. 7. USE OF APPROPRIATED FUNDS. — All funds appropriated for functions, projects, and activities shall be released and used exclusively for the specific purposes for which they have been authorized. Any amendments and augmentation may be made within the calendar year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.

SEC. 8. AUTHORITY TO ADJUST APPROPRIATIONS. — No Ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.

SEC. 9. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND. — The 20% Community Development Fund shall strictly be utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the Sangguniang Panlungsod in conformity with the Local Government Code.

SEC. 10. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) CONTINGENCY RESERVE. — Except for expenses due to public utilities, rentals, insurance premiums, and food supplies expenses, a contingency reserve of 20% on the authorized 2017 appropriation for Departmental Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating therein the 20% contingency reserve.

SEC. 11. ALLOTMENT OF APPROPRIATIONS. — For effective budgetary control, authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder:
(a) No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function, activity, or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period, and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor.
(b) For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided, each calendar year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January, April, July, and October.
(c) The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer’s notification and certification that the realized income is less than what was estimated in the annual/supplemental budget, or that additional income is realized.
(d) An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Office based on recommendations made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official, the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least five (5) days before the start of each quarter.

SEC. 12. NON-WAIVER CLAUSE. — Notwithstanding the approval of this appropriation Ordinance by the Sangguniang Panlungsod, all contracts, disbursements, and awards entered into by the City of Manila, including but not limited to the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, the Universidad de Manila, and other government agencies and instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party, shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455, Paragraph B, sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.

SEC. 13. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. — If for any reason or reasons any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 14. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. — This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2017.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 3, 2017.
short_text: Ordinance No. 8515 allocates Fourteen Billion Eight Hundred Eighty Million Pesos (Php. 14,880,000,000.00) from Manila City's 2017 budget to fund the operation of various city departments and cover the city's obligations from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017.  The ordinance provides budgetary support for the continued operation of Manila City's offices and departments and specifies fund distribution across different categories, including General Funds for various offices, Social Services, and Economic Services.  It also outlines non-office expenditures, including major city projects, programs mandated by ordinances, and operational expenses.  The ordinance includes general provisions for budgetary requirements, such as rules for government positions, appropriations, fund usage, procurement, and accessibility, along with specific budget amendments.

ORDINANCE NO. 8514

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7987, AS AMENDED, BY INCLUDING THE VETERINARY INSPECTION BOARD’S VETERINARIANS, MEAT INSPECTORS, DOG CATCHERS, AND OTHER ADMINISTRATIVE PERSONNEL IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF RELEVANT PROVISIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 7305, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE “MAGNA CARTA OF PUBLIC HEALTH WORKERS,” TO PROVIDE RETIREMENT PAY, HAZARD ALLOWANCE, LONGEVITY PAY, AND OVERTIME PAY

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 1 of Ordinance No. 7987 is hereby further amended to read as follows:

"SECTION 1. The implementation of relevant provisions of Republic Act No. 7305, otherwise known as the Magna Carta of Public Health Workers, to provide retirement pay, hazard allowance, longevity pay, and overtime pay to Public Health Workers in the Manila Health Department and the five (5) City Government hospitals, namely:

Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center

Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center

Ospital ng Sampaloc

Ospital ng Tondo

Clinic of the Universidad de Manila (UDM),

and also the Veterinary Inspection Board’s veterinarians, meat inspectors, dog catchers, and other administrative personnel, is hereby authorized."

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. – This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila at its regular session on December 15, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance amends a previous ordinance to include veterinarians, meat inspectors, dog catchers, and other staff at the Veterinary Inspection Board in Manila. These employees are now entitled to the same benefits as public health workers, such as retirement pay, hazard allowance, longevity pay, and overtime pay, as outlined in the Magna Carta of Public Health Workers.

ORDINANCE NO. 8513

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE GRANT OF MONTHLY INCENTIVE ALLOWANCE TO ALL LAWYERS OF THE PUBLIC ATTORNEY'S OFFICE ASSIGNED/BASED IN THE CITY PROVIDING FREE LEGAL ASSISTANCE TO THE RESIDENTS THEREAT, APPROPRIATING ANNUALLY THE AMOUNT OF SEVEN MILLION TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PHP 7,200,000.00) FOR THE PURPOSE

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. It is the declared policy of the City Government of Manila, when its finances so allow, to provide allowances and benefits to officials of the National Government stationed in or assigned to the City, aimed at strengthening their capabilities toward the delivery of effective and necessary services to the people of Manila.

SEC. 2. The Implementing Rules and Regulations of Republic Act No. 9406, otherwise known as “An Act Reorganizing and Strengthening the Public Attorney's Office (PAO), Amending for the Purpose Pertinent Provisions of Executive Order No. 292, Otherwise Known as the Administrative Code of 1987,” grants special allowance to PAO officials and lawyers and provides funds therefor. Rule XII, Section 39 provides that local government units, subject to their capabilities, may extend financial and other support in the form of honoraria, free office space, equipment, furniture, stationery, and manpower to the PAO.

SEC. 3. Pursuant to the stated policy, the following remunerations shall be provided:

DESCRIPTION: Regional Public Attorney
QUANTITY: 1
MONTHLY: ₱17,000.00
MONTHS: 12
TOTAL PER YEAR: ₱204,000.00

DESCRIPTION: Public Attorney III
QUANTITY: 12
MONTHLY: ₱13,000.00
MONTHS: 12
TOTAL PER YEAR: ₱1,872,000.00

DESCRIPTION: Public Attorney II
QUANTITY: 17
MONTHLY: ₱11,000.00
MONTHS: 12
TOTAL PER YEAR: ₱2,244,000.00

DESCRIPTION: Public Attorney I
QUANTITY: 24
MONTHLY: ₱10,000.00
MONTHS: 12
TOTAL PER YEAR: ₱2,880,000.00

TOTAL: ₱7,200,000.00

SEC. 4. The amount of Seven Million Two Hundred Thousand Pesos (₱7,200,000.00) shall be authorized and allocated, to be sourced and taken from the Non-Office (Statutory and Contractual Obligations) Fund for the payment of the monthly incentive allowances to all PAO lawyers assigned or based in the City of Manila providing free legal assistance to its residents.

SEC. 5. Any and all ordinances that are inconsistent with any provision of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. Effectivity Clause. – This Ordinance shall take effect on January 2017.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila at its regular session on December 15, 2016.
short_text:
This ordinance allows the City of Manila to give monthly incentive allowances to Public Attorney's Office (PAO) lawyers who are assigned or based in Manila and provide free legal aid to its residents. A total of PhP7,200,000.00 will be allocated each year for this. The breakdown of the monthly allowances is as follows:

PhP17,000 for 1 Regional Public Attorney

PhP13,000 each for 12 Public Attorneys III

PhP11,000 each for 17 Public Attorneys II

PhP10,000 each for 24 Public Attorneys I
This support comes from the city's Non-Office Fund and will begin January 2017. The goal is to enhance the capability of PAO lawyers in delivering quality legal services to the public.

short_text: This ordinance allows the City Government of Manila to officially change or reclassify 281 job positions listed in the 2017 Executive Budget. The conversion follows the Department of Budget and Management’s guidelines to ensure that the city stays within the allowed budget for personnel expenses.

full_text: No Text

ORDINANCE NO. 8509

AN ORDINANCE RE-APPROPRIATING THE AMOUNT OF TWO HUNDRED FORTY- EIGHT MILLION SEVEN HUNDRED TWENTY-FOUR THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED ONE PESOS (PHP. 248,724,401.00) REVERTED FROM SALARY SAVINGS OF THE DIFFERENT DEPARTMENTS/OFFICES/BUREAUS AND RETIREMENT GRATUITY (RETIREMENT BENEFITS-CIVILIAN-NON-OFFICE) FOR THE YEAR-END BONUS PERSONAL SERVICES OF THE DIFFERENT DEPARTMENTS / OFFICES / BUREAUS, TO BE UTILIZED FOR THE PAYMENT OF 14TH MONTH PAY EQUIVALENT TO ONE (1) MONTH SALARY OF THE EMPLOYEES OF THE CITY GOVERNMENT AUTHORIZED UNDER EXECUTIVE ORDER 201 DATED FEBRUARY 19, 2016

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The amount of Two Hundred Forty-Eight Million Seven Hundred Twenty-Four Thousand Four Hundred One Pesos (PhP. 248,724,401.00) reverted from salary savings of the different departments/offices/bureaus and retirement gratuity (Retirement Benefits-Civilian-Non-Office) for the year-end bonus personal services of the different departments/offices/bureaus, to be utilized for the payment of 14th month pay equivalent to one (1) month salary of the employees of the City Government authorized under Executive Order 201 dated February 19, 2016 (attached herewith Annex "A" for breakdown).

SEC. 2. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on December 6, 2016.

ORDINANCE NO. 8505

AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE ALLOCATION OF THE OTHER MAINTENANCE AND OPERATING EXPENSES, UNDER THE MAINTENANCE AND OTHER OPERATING EXPENSES OF THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS IN THE AMOUNT OF NINETY THOUSAND PESOS (PHP. 90,000.00), TO BE USED AS PAYMENT FOR THE ALLOWANCES OF THE REGISTER OF DEEDS AND ASSISTANT REGISTER OF DEEDS

EXPLANATORY NOTE

WHEREAS, the Registry of Deeds is one of the National Government offices attached to the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, Section 458 (a) (1) (xi) of Republic Act 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides that when the finances of the City Government allow, it may provide for additional allowances and other benefits to National Government officials stationed in or assigned to the city;

WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 8442 or the Executive Budget of the City of Manila for FY 2016 provided a budget for the allowance of the Register of Deeds and Assistant Register of Deeds on the condition that an ordinance will be passed;

WHEREAS, the granting of an allowance in an ordinance will institutionalize it as well as will ensure its accountability, transparency, and enforceability: NOW, THEREFORE,   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. It is the declared policy of the City Government of Manila when its finances so allow, to provide allowances and benefits to officials of the National Government stationed in or assigned to the city, aimed at strengthening their capabilities towards delivery of effective and necessary services to the people of Manila.

SEC. 2. Pursuant to the stated policy, the following enumerations shall be provided:   

a) Monthly allowance for Register of Deed
(PHP 5,500.00 x 12 months) = PHP 66,000

b) Monthly allowance for Assistant Register of Deeds
(PHP 2,000.00 x 12 months) = PHP 24,000.00

Total: PHP 90,000.00

SEC. 3. All ordinances or parts thereof which are inconsistent with this Ordinance or parts hereof are hereby repealed, amended or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 18, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes the allocation of PhP90,000.00 under the Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE) of the Registry of Deeds, to provide monthly allowances to two national government officials stationed in Manila: the Register of Deeds (PhP5,500/month or PhP66,000/year) and the Assistant Register of Deeds (PhP2,000/month or PhP24,000/year). The funding is sourced from the FY 2016 Executive Budget under Ordinance No. 8442. The ordinance aims to institutionalize these allowances to enhance transparency, accountability, and support effective service delivery as provided under Section 458 (a)(1)(xi) of the Local Government Code of 1991.

ORDINANCE NO. 8502

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 8119 KNOWN AS THE MANILA COMPREHENSIVE LAND USE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE OF 2006 AND PROVIDING FOR THE ADMINISTRATION, ENFORCEMENT AND AMENDMENT THERETO

EXPLANATORY NOTE

This amendment to Ordinance No. 8119 or the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Manila is anchored on the basic constitutional principle that the power of legislative branch of government is to create laws and the power of the executive branch of government is to implement laws.

At present, the Zoning Ordinance gives the authority to grant variance and exceptions to the City Council upon recommendation of the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals. Considering that the grant of variance and exceptions is clearly within the implementation phase of the law, the same must be confined within the power of the City Mayor as head of the executive branch of the local government of Manila. Notwithstanding this authority given the City Mayor, it is well within the power of the City Council, in the exercise of its legislative power, to make amendments to the said Ordinance to make the law consistent with the development goals, planning objectives and strategies of the Manila Comprehensive Land Use Plan. 

Foregoing considered, it is hereby recommended for the prompt passage of this Amendment.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Paragraph 1, Section 11, Article V of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"SEC. 11. General Provisions. The uses enumerated in the succeeding sections are neither exhaustive nor all- Inclusive. The CITY MAYOR as per recommendation from the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals (MZBAA) shall, subject to the requirements of this Ordinance, and the Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR) of this Zoning Ordinance as attached herewith and made an integral part hereof allow other uses not enumerated hereunder provided that they are compatible with the uses expressly allowed." 

SEC. 2. Paragraph 1, Section 60, Article X of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:   

"SEC, 60. Deviations. Variances and exceptions from the provisions of this Ordinance may be allowed by the CITY MAYOR as per recommendation from the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals (MZBAA) only when all the following terms and conditions are obtained/existing:"    

SEC. 3. Section 61 (3), Article X of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"3. The CPDO shall conduct studies on the application and submit report within fifteen (15) working days to the MZBAA. The MZBAA shall then evaluate the report and make a recommendation and forward the application to the CITY MAYOR."    

SEC. 4. Section 61 (5), Article X of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"5. The CITY MAYOR shall take action upon receipt of the recommendation from MZBAA."    

SEC. 5. Section 62, Article X of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"SEC, 62. Approval of the CITY MAYOR. Any deviation from any section or part of the original Ordinance shall be approved by the CITY MAYOR."    

SEC. 6. Section 63, Article XI of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"SEC. 63. Zoning Permit (Locational Clearance). - All lot/land owners/land developers and business establishments shall secure a zoning permit (locational clearance) from the City Planning and Development Officer for all conforming uses and in cases of variances and exceptions from the CITY MAYOR as per recommendation from the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals (MZBAA) prior to conducting any business activity or construction on their property/land." 

SEC. 7. Paragraphs 1 and 2 of Section 73, Article XI of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"SEC. 73. Status of Approved Appeals from the MZBAA - All approved appeals from the CITY MAYOR will be classified as non-conforming uses and all the provisions under Sec. 72 shall apply.

Decisions of the CITY MAYOR shall be final and executory." 

SEC. 8. Section 78 (A), Article XI of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:   

"SEC. 78. Functions and Responsibilities of the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals (MZBAA) There is hereby created an MZBAA which shall perform the following functions and responsibilities:

A. Evaluate the report from the CPDO and submit recommendation to the CITY MAYOR on appeals on grant or denial of zoning permit/locational clearance and development permit and act on the applications on the following nature:

1. variances
2. exceptions
3. non-conforming uses
4. complaints and opposition to applications  

SEC. 9. Paragraphs 1 and 2 of Section 79, Article XI of Ordinance No. 8119 is hereby amended to read as follows:

"SEC. 79. Composition of the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals (MZBAA). The City Development committee Council Executive Committee shall create a committee immediately after the approval of this Ordinance within six (6) months which shall act as the MZBAA composed of the following members:   

1. City Legal Officer
2. City Assessor
3. City Engineer
4. City Planning and Development Officer
5. Chairman, Committee on Housing, Urban Development and Resettlement of the SP
6. Chairman, Committee on Laws
7. Chairman, Committee on Oversight"    

SEC. 10. Any ordinance inconsistent with the provisions herewith are hereby amended and repealed accordingly.   

SEC. 11. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.   

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 18, 2016.
short_text:
This ordinance amends several provisions of Ordinance No. 8119 to transfer the authority to approve variances and exceptions in zoning matters from the City Council to the City Mayor, upon recommendation of the Manila Zoning Board of Adjustments and Appeals (MZBAA). The amendments clarify the executive role in implementation while retaining the legislative powers of the City Council for future zoning revisions.

Key Changes Introduced:
Authority Shift:

The City Mayor now has the power to approve variances, exceptions, and zoning deviations, based on MZBAA's recommendation, rather than the City Council.

Affected Sections of Ordinance No. 8119:

Sections 11, 60, 61 (3 & 5), 62, 63, 73, 78(A), and 79 were amended.

Updated MZBAA Role:

MZBAA is to evaluate reports from the City Planning and Development Office (CPDO) and recommend action to the Mayor.

MZBAA handles appeals involving variances, exceptions, non-conforming uses, and complaints.

Zoning Permit (Locational Clearance):

Conforming uses: Clearance still issued by CPDO.

Non-conforming/variance-based uses: Require approval by the City Mayor via MZBAA recommendation.

Finality of Decision:

Decisions of the City Mayor on zoning appeals are final and executory.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8501

AN ORDINANCE PROHIBITING THE SALE OF CARBONATED BEVERAGES, SUGAR-BASED SYNTHETIC DRINKS AND JUNK FOODS IN ALL PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOLS WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREFOR

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Section 15, Article 2 of the 1987 Constitution provides that: "The State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them."    

WHEREAS, under Section 15 (c) of Republic Act No. 10611, otherwise known as the Food Safety Act of 2013, "The Local Government Unit shall be responsible for food safety in food businesses such as, but not limited to, activities in slaughterhouses, dressing plants, fish ports, wet markets, supermarkets, school canteens, restaurants, catering establishments and water refilling stations";

WHEREAS, the school canteen shall serve as a venue for the development of healthy eating habits of pupils and students. Thus, foods and drinks sold to pupils and students should at all times be clean, safe, healthy and free from any harmful substance that may or will affect the children's health now or in the future;

WHEREAS, stores and establishments selling food items inside schools shall help eliminate malnutrition among pupils and students;

WHEREAS, various research studies have shown that children consuming of carbonated drinks or sugar-based synthetic drinks, have developed various acute and chronic ill effects such as nutritional deficiency, obesity, dental diseases, bone pathologies and psychological illness;

WHEREAS, research studies show that junk foods are high in fat, sodium and sugar, which can lead to obesity and a range of attendant health problems, including diabetes, heart disease and arthritis;

WHEREAS, the City Government, parents and teachers should work hand and hand to eliminate malnutrition among children and to encourage healthy diet among them: NOW, THEREFORE,   

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. DEFINITION OF TERMS. As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall mean:   

a. Carbonated Beverage - any drink that bubbles and fizzes with carbon dioxide gas.

b. Sugar-based synthetic drinks - any beverage, energy drinks, sports drinks iced tea or fruit-based drinks that contain less than 50 percent real fruit juice or that which contain additional sweeteners and drinks containing caffeine.

c. Junk Foods - any food item that has low nutritional value, typically produced in the form of packaged snacks needing little or no preparation, and does not bear Sangkap Pinoy seal or has not passed the Food and Drug Administration (BFAD) approval.

d. School Canteen - refers to one of the ancillary services in the school system that sells food items to the pupils/students and serves as a support mechanism in the effort to eliminate malnutrition concerns of the school.   

e. Food-selling store- refers to any business establishment operating inside the school premises, other than the school canteen, that offers or sells beverages or food items. This includes cooperative stores and vending machines.   

f. Food and Drug Administration - refers to the government regulatory agency tasks to establish and maintain an effective health products regulatory system responsive to the country's health needs and problems.

g. Sangkap Pinoy Seal - is a strategy program of the Department of Health to encourage manufacturers to fortify their food products with three essential micronutrients (i.e. Vitamin A, Iron, and iodine) as a means to eliminate micronutrients deficiency among the populace.

SEC. 2. PROHIBITED ACTS. - The following acts shall be unlawful:   

1. Sale of carbonated drinks, sugar-based synthetic or artificially flavored juices in the school canteen, cafeteria, restaurant or other food-selling store within the premises of public and private elementary and/or secondary school.  
 
2. Sale of food item/s that did not bear Sangkap Pinoy seal and/or that did not pass BFAD approval in the school canteen, cafeteria, restaurant or other food-selling store within the premises of public and private elementary and/or secondary school. 

SEC. 3. PENALTIES. -   

a. Any person found to be guilty for violation of this Ordinance shall meet the following penalty:   

1. A fine of One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) and forfeiture of prohibited items for the first offense;   

2. A fine of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) and forfeiture of prohibited items for the second offense; and   

3. Imprisonment for a period not exceeding 30 days, a fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) and forfeiture of prohibited items for the third offense.

b. Any artificial person, business establishment, or cooperative found to be guilty for violation of this Ordinance shall meet the following penalty:   

1. A fine of Three Thousand Pesos (PhP. 3,000.00) and forfeiture of prohibited items for the first offense;   

2. A fine of Four Thousand Pesos (PhP. 4,000.00) and forfeiture of prohibited items for the second offense; and   

3. A fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) and forfeiture of prohibited items and revocation of permit to operate business for the third offense.
SEC. 4. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. Any provision or portion of this Ordinance found to be violative of the constitution or invalid shall not impair the other provisions or parts thereof which shall continue to be in force and effect.

SEC. 5. REPEALING CLAUSE. - All ordinances, rules and regulations or parts thereof, which are inconsistent or in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance, are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval and publication in a local newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 18, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance bans the sale of carbonated drinks, sugar-based synthetic drinks (like sweetened juices, iced teas, and energy drinks), and junk food (those low in nutritional value or lacking FDA approval or the Sangkap Pinoy seal) inside all public and private elementary and high schools in Manila. The goal is to protect children's health and reduce malnutrition. The rule applies to all food-selling establishments in schools, including canteens, cooperatives, and vending machines.
fines:
Individuals:

1st offense: ₱1,000 + confiscation of goods

2nd offense: ₱3,000 + confiscation

3rd offense: ₱5,000 + up to 30 days imprisonment + confiscation

Establishments/Cooperatives:

1st offense: ₱3,000 + confiscation

2nd offense: ₱4,000 + confiscation

3rd offense: ₱5,000 + confiscation + revocation of business permit

AN ORDINANCE FURTHER AMENDING SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 7987, AS AMENDED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8044, BY INCLUDING THE PUBLIC HEALTH WORKERS IN THE CLINIC OF UNIVERSIDAD DE MANILA IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RELEVANT PROVISIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT 7305, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE MAGNA CARTA OF PUBLIC HEALTH WORKERS, SO AS TO PROVIDE FOR RETIREMENT PAY, HAZARD ALLOWANCE, LONGEVITY PAY, AND OVERTIME PAY

The implementation of the relevant provisions of Republic Act No. 7305, otherwise known as the Magna Carta of Public Health Workers, is hereby authorized to include the provision of retirement pay, hazard allowance, longevity pay, and overtime pay for the Public Health Workers within the Manila Health Department, as well as for those working in the four (4) City Government hospitals: the Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center, the Gat Andres Bonifacio Memorial Medical Center, the Ospital ng Sampaloc, and the Ospital ng Tondo, in addition to the Public Health Workers at the Clinic of Universidad de Manila (UDM).”

short_text: This ordinance amends previous laws to include the public health workers at the Clinic of Universidad de Manila (UDM) in the benefits provided under the Magna Carta of Public Health Workers (Republic Act No. 7305). short_text: This ordinance creates a livelihood program for poor and less-privileged drivers in Manila by promoting the use of eco-friendly electric vehicles (e-vehicles) as a new mode of public transport. SEC. 3. Organization. — Subject to existing civil service laws, rules, and regulations, the Department shall have such divisions and organizational structure as illustrated in the organizational chart attached as Annex A hereof.

SEC. 4. Rank and Privileges of the City Architect. — The City Architect shall have the rank and enjoy the privileges of a department head in the City Government.

SEC. 5. Appointment. — Subject to existing civil service laws, rules, and regulations, the City Architect shall be appointed by the City Mayor, under whose control and supervision the former shall serve.

SEC. 6. Powers and Functions. — The Department shall take charge of the city's overall architectural planning and design and shall:
a) Formulate measures for the consideration of the City Council and provide technical assistance and support to the City Mayor in carrying out measures to ensure the delivery of basic services and provision of adequate facilities relative to architectural planning and design, as provided for under Section 17 of the Local Government Code and Rule V of the Implementing Rules and Regulations thereof;
b) Develop plans and strategies on architectural planning and design programs and projects and implement them upon approval thereof by the City Mayor;
c) Prepare and recommend for consideration of the City Council the architectural plan and design for the city or a part thereof, including the renewal of slums and blighted areas, land reclamation activities, the greening of land, and appropriate planning of marine and foreshore areas;
d) Review and recommend for appropriate action of the City Council and City Mayor the architectural plans and design submitted by governmental and non-governmental entities or individuals, particularly those for undeveloped, underdeveloped, and poorly-designed areas;
e) Coordinate with government and non-government entities and individuals involved in the aesthetics and the maximum utilization of land and water within the jurisdiction of the city, compatible with environmental integrity and ecological balance;
f) Be in the frontline of the delivery of services involving architectural planning and design, particularly those related to the redesigning of spatial distribution of basic facilities and physical structures during and in the aftermath of man-made and natural calamities and disasters;
g) Recommend to the City Council and advise the City Mayor on all matters relative to the architectural planning and design as it relates to the total socio-economic development of the local government unit; and
h) Exercise such other powers and perform such other duties as may be assigned by the City Mayor or this Ordinance.

SEC. 7. Functional Realignment. — The functions of the Urban Planning and Development Division and of the Architectural Section of the Designing Division of the Department of Engineering and Public Works shall be transferred to and absorbed by the Manila Department of Architecture. Subject to existing civil service laws, rules, and regulations, the occupants of the positions affected by this reorganization may either be absorbed in the Department or retained in the Manila Department of Engineering and Public Works.

SEC. 8. Budgetary Appropriation. — To carry out the objectives of this Ordinance, the initial amount of Thirty Million Pesos (PhP 30,000,000.00) is hereby appropriated out of the funds in the city treasury not otherwise appropriated. For each succeeding fiscal year, a budgetary appropriation for the salaries of personnel and the operations of the Department, in an amount to be approved by the City Council, shall automatically be included in the annual budget of the city.

SEC. 9. Separability Clause. — If any provision or part of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional by competent authority, the remainder or provisions not otherwise affected and dependent thereon shall remain valid and subsisting.

SEC. 10. Repealing Clause. — Existing ordinances, orders, or administrative regulations that are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, if any, are hereby amended, modified, superseded, or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 11. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in the Official Gazette or a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 28, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance establishes the Manila Department of Architecture to oversee architectural planning and design in the city. The department will handle tasks such as creating and reviewing architectural plans, coordinating with other entities, and providing support during disasters. An initial budget of PHP 30 million is allocated to support its operations. The department is also responsible for handling the reorganization of certain divisions from the Department of Engineering and Public Works.

short_text: To attract businesses and boost its economy, the City of Manila has created the "Manila Investment Incentives Code of 2014."  This ordinance establishes the Manila Investment Incentives Board (MIIB) to oversee the implementation of the code and an Investment Promotion Center (IPC) to assist investors. ORDINANCE NO. 8494

AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FREE HOUSING AT BASECO HOUSING PROJECT

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. There shall be a Baseco Housing Project funded from the Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG), Seed Grant in the amount of Thirty-Six Million Pesos (PhP. 36,000,000.00) and the counterpart road network and site development from the City of Manila.

SEC. 2. Since the funds for the housing project came from the DILG, the housing shall be transferred to the beneficiaries by usufruct only.

SEC. 3. The beneficiaries shall be chosen in accordance with the Code of Policy as approved by the Local Housing Board.

SEC. 4. Ownership of the housing project shall remain with the City of Manila. Beneficiaries shall have usufruct of the housing units, subject to the following conditions:   

1. That beneficiaries shall not sell or transfer or lease the use of the housing units. The sale or transfer or lease of the units shall be void and the city, together with the barangay officials, shall evict the transferee or lessee or any occupant who is not a beneficiary of the project;   

2. The housing unit shall then be transferred to a new beneficiary in accordance with the prioritization as contained in the validated list as approved by the Manila Social Welfare Department;   

3. That the housing units shall not be modified by extending to the front, back or sides of the housing units. Extensions shall be subject to demolition by barangay officials who shall be tasked with the maintenance of the public areas of the housing project together with the homeowners association;  
 
4. That extensions and improvements shall only be allowed vertically upon compliance with Building laws, local ordinances, rules and regulations; and  
 
5. That beneficiaries shall keep the roads clear of obstructions and illegal constructions shall be subject to immediate demolition by barangay or city officials.   

SEC. 5. Beneficiaries shall organize themselves into a homeowners association and provide for rules and regulations to maintain peace and order, traffic, sanitation, cleanliness in the housing project.

SEC. 6. The Urban Settlements Office and the Local Inter-Agency Committee shall conduct an orientation with the beneficiaries of the project on the rules and regulations for use of the housing units as contained in this Ordinance.

SEC. 7.. This Ordinance shall be strictly implemented by the Urban Settlements Office, the homeowners association and the Sangguniang Barangay of Baseco.

SEC. 8. This Ordinance shall take effect upon completion of the project and the housing units are turned over to the beneficiaries.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on June 14, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance establishes the Baseco Housing Project, providing free housing through usufruct to selected beneficiaries. Funded by a PhP 36 million DILG seed grant and city counterpart for infrastructure, the housing units remain city property. Beneficiaries must follow strict rules, including no selling, transferring, or modifying units horizontally. Violators face eviction and demolition of illegal structures. The ordinance mandates formation of a homeowners association and outlines the roles of the Urban Settlements Office, barangay officials, and other local bodies in ensuring orderly implementation.
fines: Violations (e.g., unauthorized sale, transfer, or modifications) result in eviction or demolition of illegal structures.

ORDINANCE NO. 8491

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING SEPTAGE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM IN THE CITY OF MANILA

ADMINISTRATION MEASURE

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title.
 This Ordinance shall be known as the "Ordinance establishing a Septage Management System in the City of Manila".   

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy.
 - It shall be the policy of the City of Manila to share in the responsibility of management and improvement of water quality within its territorial jurisdiction. To meet these objectives, the city shall implement measures to prevent and control water pollution to promote public health.   

SEC. 3. Sewerage and Septage Management Principles.
 - Towards this end, the City of Manila shall abide by the following sewerage and septage management principles. a. All buildings and structures whether residential, commercial, industrial establishments, government offices or institutions shall be required to have proper sewage treatment or septage management system. Untreated excreta from residential areas without septic tanks and untreated wastewater from industrial and public establishments shall not be allowed to be discharged to open drainage canals or piped drainage systems; and   

b. No wastewater shall be discharged to the environment without any proper treatment.

SEC. 4. Definition of Terms.
 - As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall be defined as follows:   

a. Desludging - refers to a process of cleaning or removing the accumulated domestic sludge or septage.

b. Domestic Sludge - refers to a solid particle of domestic sewage which settles at the bottom of the sedimentation tank and is digested by anaerobic bacteria purely from domestic sources.
 c. DENR refers to the Department of Environment and Natural Resources.   

d. DOH - refers to the Department of Health.

e. EMB - refers to the Environmental Management Bureau.

f. Septage refers to a combination of scum, sludge and liquid from household septic tanks.
 g. Hygienic Septic Tank refers to a septic tank with no openings at the bottom of the slab; closed structure so as not to allow the leaching of liquid or solid wastes to the surrounding soil or ground.   

h. Septic Tank - refers to a watertight receptacle, which receives the discharge of a sanitary plumbing system or part thereof, and is designed and constructed to accomplish the sedimentation and digestion of the organic matter in the sewage within the period of detention/retention and to allow the liquid to discharge to a leaching field, sewer lines, a combined sewerage network or directly to a secondary wastewater treatment family facility in accordance with the standards set forth by the Revised National Plumbing Code of the Philippines.
 i. Septage Treatment Plant - refers to a series of structures purely for the process of treating septage (from septic tanks) in order to comply with DENR effluent standards.   

j. Sewage refers to any wastewater containing human, animal or vegetable waste matter in suspension or solution including human excreta and urine and may possibly contain liquids consisting of chemicals solution.
 k. Sewer - refers to an artificial pipe or conduit for carrying sewage and wastewater.
 1. MWSS-refers to Manila Water and Sewerage System.   

m. Wastewater Treatment Plant - refers to a series of structure that will process the treatment of sewage, mostly from domestic origin, but may include pre-treated liquid wastes from industries and similar establishments; it may also accept the treatment of septage, provided there are facilities for accepting it and pre-treating it.

SEC. 5. Sewage Disposal System.
 All residential, commercial, industrial establishments and government institutions, both old and new ones, in the City of Manila are required to have a proper sewage disposal system such as septic tank for residences and sewage treatment facility for public or commercial establishments and government institutions. a. Existing Facilities. - All residential houses and buildings must have a hygienic septic tank, as defined in Section 4 (g) above, that is compliant with the national standards. PROVIDED, that no structure must be built on top of septic tank to ensure that it is accessible at all times. Owners of commercial, industrial and institutional buildings or facilities shall have an operational wastewater treatment facility either on-site or by service off-site. The said facility shall conform to the standards of EMB-DENR and DOH.   

b. New Facilities. No building plan for residential dwelling units, commercial, industrial, institutional, or recreational structures shall be approved unless the design of the sanitary plumbing and septic tank or wastewater treatment facility conforms to the specifications as provided by national standards. Facilities in sewered areas utilizing either combined or separate sewer systems are required to provide the appropriate pre-treatment facilities prior to discharge of wastewater to drainage. PROVIDED, that the City Building Official shall be required to evaluate the compliance of facilities to the Pre-treatment standards set by DENR. Communal or shared septic tanks can be used alternatively, whenever feasible, particularly for existing clustered structures that are highly dense and characterized by lack of or inadequate land space. The design and the manifest of ownership and joint maintenance of shared septic tanks shall require approval process by the Building Official of the city.

SEC. 6. Mandatory Desludging of Septic Tanks.
 - All owners and users of septic tanks shall be required to desludge it on an average of once every three (3) to five (5) years or when the sludge volume is around one third (1/3) of the total volume of the septic tank, whichever comes earlier. Septic tanks shall be accessible at all times. Further, no structure shall be built on top of any septic tank. Inaccessible septic tanks shall be repaired, upgraded or replaced by a new one as maybe directed by the Building Official to ensure accessibility and for purposes of desludging at the sole expense of its owner or user. The inspection and opening of septic tanks shall be done by Sanitary Inspectors or barangay officials duly authorized by Building Official and/or representative of the MWSS or any of its Concessionaire. Violation of this provision shall subject the owner and/or user of the septic tank to the penalty as stipulated in Section 15.   

SEC. 7. Design of Septic Tanks.
 - All septic tanks shall be designed to exclude stormwater/flow from downspouts and such other requirements and specifications as provided by national standards. The Building official is mandated to ensure that appropriate standard designs of septic tanks shall be enforced in the plan approvals and inspection procedures.   

SEC. 8. Regulation of Desludgers.
 Liquid and/or solid materials removed from septic tanks shall be transported by accredited septage hauler/pumper to the approved septage treatment pursuant to the regulations prescribed by the Department of Health (DOH). Unless otherwise provided by law, no septage hauler/pumper shall be allowed to collect, transport and unload or dispose of septage in other places, including bodies of water, agricultural fields, and the drainage system within the city.   

SEC. 9. Permitting Requirements.
 All entitles applying for Business and Building Permits are required to obtain an Environmental Sanitation Clearance (ESC) as part of the requirements for issuance of building permits and annual business permits from the City of Manila.   

SEC. 10. Institutional Arrangements.
 The City Environment and Natural Resources Office (CENRO) or any office as authorized by the Mayor shall have the following responsibilities in implementing this Ordinance:   

a) On Inspection Assist the City Building Official in designating field inspectors that will check on the general design, construction and maintenance requirements of septic tanks in subdivisions, commercial and business establishments. For existing commercial establishments, factories and dwelling units, it will assist the Building Official in inspecting facilities to ensure compliance with the law as to wastewater treatment facilities and/or septic tanks.

b) Database - Together with the City Planning and Development Office, it will keep a robust database of all owners/administrators of buildings, facilities and structures who have desludged their septic tanks, those that are inaccessible, those that do not have septic tanks, and those that do not have water sealed toilets, and other data that may be deemed necessary.

c) Transport of Septage - Enforce the rules and regulations set forth by the Department of Health and EMB-DENR in handling, transporting, treatment and disposal of septage. Further, it will implement an accreditation system and operational guidelines for private desludging service providers that intend to operate in the city, including but not limited to securing an Environmental Sanitation Clearance (ESC) consistent with the prescribed DOH regulations.

d) Sanitary Permits Assist the City Health Office in issuing Sanitary Permits for all treatment and collection facilities and develop their own procedures for periodic inspections of facilities and equipment, and training programs for septage workers.

e) Opening of Septage Tanks - Assist Barangay officials in opening septic tanks during inspection in coordination with the sanitary inspectors of the city.

f) Enforcement - Assist in the enforcement of sewer connections/penalties for those who are disconnected/with illegal tapping.

g) Monitoring - Perform regular monitoring of construction to prevent encroachment of easement and waterways and implement water quality monitoring activities within the area.

h) Information and Education Campaign - Implement an information and education campaign about the proper wastewater management and to increase level of awareness and commitment of the public to address problems on water pollution control, sewerage and sanitation.

SEC. 11. Desludging Fees.
 - Residential buildings and premises shall have their septage desludged and treated once every five (5) years for free by the water concessionaries in Metro Manila. All commercial/structure owners shall pay an amount of 10% of Basic Water Consumption for the desludging of their septic tanks and treatment of the septage in excess of that contained in the concessionare's contract. Further, the City of Manila may raise funds to subsidize necessary expenses for the operation and maintenance of sewerage treatment or septage facility servicing their area of jurisdiction through local property taxes and enforcement of a service fee system.   

SEC. 12. Mandatory Connection of Facilities to Sewer Lines.
 Buildings or premises producing sewage shall connect to the sewer main lines in all areas where it exists. The city shall assist the Maynilad Water Services and Manila Water Company, Inc. (concessionaire) to connect the existing sewage line found in all subdivisions, condominiums, commercial centers, hotels, sports and recreational facilities, hospitals, market places, public buildings, industrial complex and other similar establishments including households to available sewerage system. PROVIDED, that the said connection shall be subject to sewerage services charge/fees in accordance with existing laws, rules or regulations unless the sources had already utilized their own sewerage system.   

SEC. 13. Maintenance of Drainage.
 - The city shall maintain its drainage system in a sanitary state and in good repair.   

SEC. 14. Prohibited Acts.
 - The following acts are prohibited:   

Littering, throwing, dumping of waste matters in public places such as road, sidewalks, canals, esteros or parks and establishment or causing or permitting the same.

Refusal to desludge as required by this Ordinance.

Refusal of any person to connect its sewage lines to available sewerage lines.

SEC. 15. Penalties.
 - Any owner of a non-complying residence or establishment who fails to comply with the provisions of this Ordinance within one (1) year from the date of its effectivity shall be liable to pay the following fine for every violation thereof as follows:   

a. First Offense - PhP. 3,000.00

b. Second Offense - PhP. 5,000.00

c. Third Offense - Revocation of License for commercial establishment or factory

The city shall post in its bulletin board and website the names of persons or entities who violate this Ordinance more than twice. Failure to comply with the provisions herein shall result in the revocation/cancellation of business permits for commercial establishments.

SEC. 16. Funding.
 - The City Government shall allocate the necessary funds to support the implementation of this Ordinance.   

SEC. 17. Separability.
 - If for any reason, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, the other parts or provisions not otherwise affected shall remain in full force and effect.   

SEC. 18. Repealing Clause.
 - All ordinances or provisions of previous ordinances that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed.   

SEC. 19. Effectivity Clause.
 - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.   

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 17, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance creates a Septage Management System for the City of Manila to improve water quality and promote public health. It requires all buildings, whether residential or commercial, to have proper sewage treatment systems. Residential areas must have septic tanks, while commercial and government establishments need wastewater treatment facilities. Additionally, the ordinance mandates that septic tanks be cleaned (or desludged) every 3 to 5 years, and it sets fines for those who don't comply with these rules. It also outlines the responsibilities of various offices and provides funding for the implementation of these rules.

ORDINANCE NO. 8488

AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE CITY OF MANILA'S POLICY AGAINST ELDERLY ABUSE, EXPLOITATION AND NEGLECT, REDEFINING SENIOR CITIZEN'S RIGHTS, AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF    

Be it enacted by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title. This Ordinance shall be known as the "City of Manila Ordinance Against Elderly Abuse, Exploitation and Neglect".    

SEC. 2. Policy. The City of Manila hereby recognizes the inherent value and wisdom of elderly people, and promotes respect and appreciation for the continued participation and contribution of the elderly in the community.  Considering the vulnerable status of the elderly, the city shall have the duty to represent and augment the lawful rights and interests of the elderly and shall initiate actions to promote the rights, health and well-being of the senior citizens, by penalizing acts constituting elderly abuse, exploitation and neglect.    

SEC. 3. Definition of Terms. -

A. Elderly/Senior Citizen. Elderly shall constitute those persons aged sixty (60) years old and above, as defined under existing laws, which properly indicates the challenges and needs of those of an advanced age.    

B. Abuse. For purposes of this Ordinance, abuse shall mean the physical, mental or material maltreatment of an elderly person, including but not limited to beating and isolation, and deprivation of food and medication.    

C. Exploitation. - For purposes of this Ordinance, exploitation shall mean the unlawful obtaining of financial or other material benefits from the elderly for one's own benefit.    

D. Neglect. For purposes of this Ordinance, neglect shall mean the omission of proper attention, supervision, or provision of necessities to an elderly person, to such an extend that harm results or is likely to result.    

SEC. 4. Rights of an Elderly Person. The rights of the elderly people include, but are not limited to the following:

A. Right to Dignity. The elderly have the inherent right to life, dignity, and the integrity of their persons, which shall be protected by law and this Ordinance.    

B. Right to Freedom from Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation. - The elderly have the right to be free from abuse, neglect and exploitation as herein defined.    

C. Right to Freedom from Discrimination. The elderly have the right to be free from discrimination.  They shall be treated equally favorably, regardless of health status or disability, as other age groups.    

D. Right to Adequate Healthcare. The elderly have the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of themselves, including access to affordable healthcare.  Adequate and affordable healthcare includes medication, immunization and medical care such as physical therapy, surgery, nursing, check-ups.    

E. Right to Maintenance. The elderly shall have the right to access basic necessities, including but not limited to, adequate nutrition and potable water necessary for their health and well-being.  They also have the right to access basic amenities of life, including but not limited to, appropriate shelter, clothing, and sanitation as per prevailing societal standards.    

F. Right to Participation in Society. The elderly have the right to participate in education and training programs, as well as social, economic, cultural and political life.    

SEC. 5. Protection and Response Program of the City. The city, through the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs (OSCA), shall design and manage a program of protection, response and services for the elderly who have been, or are alleged to be victims of abuse, neglect, exploitation, or discrimination.  The Protection of the Elderly Program shall include elderly abuse prevention, detection, treatment, intervention, and response.    

SEC. 6. Penalty Clause. - Any person who:

A. Willfully subjects an elderly person to ill- treatment, whether physical or verbal, in such a manner as to degrade the inherent value of his person, or willfully subjects an elderly person to prolong mental or emotional harassment, or forces and to perform excessive work beyond his or her natural capacity and strength;    

B. Intentionally, causes pecuniary loss or material prejudice to an elderly person;    

C. Being a family member thereof, neglects or refuses to give attention and supervision, and to provide the basic necessities of a senior citizen, including, but not limited to, food, potable water, medicines, and others;    

D. Neglects or refuses to give aid, while being physically, financially and mentally capable, to a person of advanced age during emergency situations or catastrophic events;    

E. Treats or proposes to treat the elderly person less favorable than, under circumstances that are the same or are not materially different, the discriminator treats or would treat a person of a different age;  and   

F. Imposes, or proposes to impose upon a senior citizen, a condition, requirement or practice which is not reasonable in the circumstances, and which has, or is likely to have, the effect of disadvantaging the senior citizen.    

Shall be penalized with a fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP. 5,000.00) and/or imprisonment of not more than one (1) year, at the discretion of the court.    

SEC. 7. Who May File a Complaint. Complaints on cases of prohibited acts against elderly persons as enumerated herein may be filed by the following:

A. Offended party;    

B. Guardians/caretaker;    

C. Collateral relative within the third degree;    

D. Officer or social worker of the Manila Department of Social Welfare;    

E. Officer or social worker of the Office of the Senior Citizens Affairs- Manila;    

F. Barangay Chairman;  or   

G. At least three (3) concerned and responsible residents of the barangay where the violation occurred.    

SEC. 8. Separability Clause. If any provision of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions not affected thereby shall continue in full force and effect.    

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. All Ordinances, local issuances or rules inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.    

SEC. 10. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.    

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 17, 2016
short_text: This ordinance sets up a policy to protect elderly people in Manila from abuse, exploitation, and neglect. It highlights the rights of senior citizens, including their right to dignity, freedom from mistreatment, healthcare, and participation in society. The city will manage a program through the Office of Senior Citizens Affairs (OSCA) to provide protection, response, and services for those affected by abuse or neglect. The ordinance also outlines penalties for those who harm or fail to care for elderly citizens, with fines and imprisonment for violators.
fines: A fine of PhP 5,000 and/or imprisonment for up to 1 year for those who abuse, exploit, neglect, or discriminate against elderly citizens.

ORDINANCE NO. 8483
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A CASH GIFT OF ONE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (PhP 100,000.00) TO EVERY CENTENARIAN IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, the World Health Organization estimates life expectancy in the Philippines at 65.4 years for men and 72.5 years for women as of 2013;

WHEREAS, living to a hundred years old—about three decades past the average life expectancy—is extremely rare today, with modern lifestyles contributing to "diseases of comfort" (such as those caused by obesity and lack of physical activity), which are among the primary causes of death in the country;

WHEREAS, as our nation’s role models, having led long, distinguished, healthy, and disciplined lives, centenarians indeed deserve to be honored and granted the financial assistance they need:

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Definition.
For the purposes of this Ordinance, a “Centenarian” shall refer to any Filipino citizen aged one hundred (100) years or older who has been a resident of the City of Manila for at least one (1) year.

SEC. 2. Cash Gift.
Every living centenarian shall, within thirty (30) days from his or her 100th birth anniversary, receive a cash gift of One Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP 100,000.00) from the City Government of Manila, subject to the presentation of proper identification and any other pertinent documents that the Office of the Senior Citizen Affairs may reasonably require.

Living centenarians who reached the age of 100 prior to the effectivity of this Ordinance shall also receive the cash gift within thirty (30) days from such effectivity, likewise subject to the submission of the required identification and documents.

SEC. 3. Funding.
The initial amount necessary for the implementation of this Ordinance shall be sourced from the Special Activities Fund. Thereafter, the necessary funding may be provided annually in the city’s Annual Appropriations Ordinance.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 15, 2016.
short_text: The City of Manila will give a PhP 100,000 cash gift to every resident who turns 100 years old (centenarian). This applies to both newly turned and already existing centenarians at the time the ordinance takes effect. To receive the gift, they or their families must provide valid IDs and required documents to the Office of the Senior Citizen Affairs.

ORDINANCE NO. 8482
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING BURIAL ASSISTANCE TO THE SURVIVING HEIRS OF SENIOR CITIZENS WHO HAVE DIED AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS FOR THE PURPOSE

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Article II, Section 15 of the 1987 Philippine Constitution mandates the State to promote a just and dynamic social order that will ensure the prosperity and independence of the nation, and free the people from poverty through policies that provide adequate social services, promote full employment, a rising standard of living, and an improved quality of life for all;

WHEREAS, Article XV, Section 4 of the Constitution further declares that while it is the duty of every family to take care of its elderly members, the State may also do so by instituting social programs for them;

WHEREAS, pursuant to the foregoing constitutional principles and taking into account the fact that senior citizens are an integral part of our society, the City Council of Manila has enacted various ordinances granting benefits and privileges to them for their improvement and well-being;

WHEREAS, as a way to further honor the city’s senior citizens and give due recognition to their lifetime contributions, the surviving heirs of seniors who have died should be given burial financial assistance to help them cope with rising funeral expenses:

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Definition.
“Senior citizen” shall refer to any Filipino citizen aged sixty (60) years or older who has been a resident of the City of Manila for a period of at least one (1) year.

SEC. 2. Burial Financial Assistance.
The surviving heirs of any senior citizen who has died shall be granted burial financial assistance in the amount of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00), subject to the presentation by such heirs of proper identification and any other pertinent documents which the Office of the Senior Citizen Affairs may reasonably require.

SEC. 3. Appropriation.
The amount of Ten Million Pesos (PhP 10,000,000.00), or so much thereof as may be necessary, is hereby appropriated out of the funds in the City Treasury not otherwise appropriated, for the purpose of such financial assistance. This shall be included in the next year’s budget. For the current year, Ten Million Pesos (PhP 10,000,000.00) shall be sourced from the Special Activities Fund of the Mayor for the year 2016.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 15, 2016.
