This ordinance creates the ManilaBIZ (Manila Business Process Outsourcing and Information Technology Zone) in Sampaloc, Manila. The zone spans from España Blvd. to Sergio H. Loyola Street, and from Arsenio H. Lacson Street to Padre Noval Street. It aims to attract local and foreign investments in BPO and IT industries to generate jobs and boost economic growth. Businesses in the zone can enjoy incentives like tax holidays, duty-free importation, and real property and business permit exemptions. The Bureau of Permits will manage and oversee this zone, with support from agencies like PEZA, DTI, and DOF.

ORDINANCE NO. 8477
AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE MANILA INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL (MICTC), DEFINING ITS COMPOSITION, DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. – Policy Declaration
It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government of Manila to recognize the Information and Communications Technology (ICT) industry as a fast-growing enterprise with vast potential for local and foreign investments and employment generation, with the capacity to promote the City as an entity in the field of global competitiveness and connectivity.

SECTION 2. – Creation of the Manila Information and Communications Technology Council (MICTC)
There is hereby created the Manila Information and Communications Technology Council (MICTC) under the Office of the Mayor, which shall be composed of the following:

The Chairman – City Mayor

The Vice-Chairman – A member of the City Council, concurrently the Chairman of the Committee on Economic Development

Six (6) Members, consisting of:

Chairman of the Committee on Information and Communication Technology of the City Council

Chairman of the Committee on Education and Sports of the City Council

Chairman of the Committee on Science and Technology of the City Council

Chairman of the Committee on Trade and Industry of the City Council

A representative from the business sector

A representative from the telecommunications sector

SECTION 2-a. – Executive Committee
The MICTC shall have an executive committee, composed of:

The City Planning and Development Officer

The City Treasurer

The City Engineer

The City Assessor

The Director of the Bureau of Permits

SECTION 3. – Duties and Functions of MICTC
The MICTC shall perform the following duties and functions:

Propose and recommend guidelines and policies for the development of the ICT sector, subject to the approval of the City Mayor

Research, compile, and analyze data relevant to the ICT industry, including workforce availability and access to related entities or institutions

Assist existing and prospective ICT investors in the City

Advise the City Government on policies for promoting the ICT industry

Encourage the formation of industry associations

Consult with appropriate institutions like DOST, CHED, TESDA, and participating educational institutions

Perform other duties as required by the City Mayor

SECTION 4. – Additional Duties and Functions
In addition to the duties outlined in Section 3, the MICTC shall assist existing and interested investors through the following:

Coordinate with schools to assist in screening and training graduates for the ICT industry

Set up systems for training and retraining applicants to meet industry qualifications

Create cross-reference systems for job applicants, allowing firms to refer applicants for consideration elsewhere

Promote home-based employment opportunities

Assist in improving English language proficiency at various educational levels

Recommend or create scholarship programs for ICT-related careers

Help create systems for elderly and persons with disabilities to access ICT careers

Assist investors with business-related needs

Perform market studies and establish linkages

Coordinate with the National Government and private sector to promote vocational courses leading to ICT employment

SECTION 5. – Budget
The amount of Twenty Million Pesos (PhP 20,000,000.00) shall be appropriated from the General Fund of the City Government, not otherwise appropriated, to be used for the implementation of this Ordinance, particularly Sections 3 and 4.

SECTION 6. – Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 23, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance creates the Manila Information and Communications Technology Council (MICTC), a new body aimed at boosting Manila’s Information and Communications Technology (ICT) industry. The Council will be responsible for creating policies, promoting ICT investments, helping train workers for ICT jobs, and coordinating with educational institutions and businesses. It will also focus on increasing job opportunities, including for elderly and persons with disabilities, and helping companies find skilled workers. The city has allocated PhP 20 million to fund these initiatives.

ORDINANCE NO. 8474
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE JOINT INSPECTION TEAM TOGETHER WITH THE SYSTEMS AND PLAN INTEGRATION AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION TO CONDUCT INSPECTION, FIELD SURVEY, AND CAPTURE PHOTOS OF BUILDINGS AND/OR ANY STRUCTURE LOCATED WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA FOR THE PURPOSE OF IMPLEMENTING THE CITY’S GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM PROGRAM

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
The Joint Inspection Team (JIT) is hereby authorized, together with the Systems and Plan Integrator and Development Corporation (SPIDC), to conduct inspections, field surveys, and photo documentation of building structures and/or any structure located within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila. This is for the purpose of tax mapping and the integration of captured information into the Geographic Information System (GIS), which will be used by the city's income-generating offices.

SEC. 2.
The Office of the City Mayor, by the power and authority vested under Republic Act No. 7160, shall act as the lead agency to supervise, monitor, and ensure the success of the activities undertaken under this Ordinance, for the benefit of the constituents of the City of Manila.

SEC. 3. – Composition
The Joint Inspection Team (JIT) shall be composed of qualified personnel from the following offices:

City Assessor's Office

City Treasurer's Office

Bureau of Permits

SEC. 4. – Duties and Responsibilities
The JIT and SPIDC are specifically tasked to conduct annual inspections of:

Buildings or structures

Machineries

Mechanical contrivances and apparatuses affixed to real property

Business establishments and trade activities

This is to ensure that these properties are:

Safe for occupancy

In a clean and sanitary condition

Properly licensed or permitted

Properly assessed and charged with the appropriate taxes, fees, and charges due to the city

SEC. 5.
For effective implementation, all barangays within Manila are required to extend the necessary assistance to ensure the success and sustainability of the GIS digital data updating program.

SEC. 6.
The JIT and SPIDC shall protect the data they capture and may only submit it to authorized representatives of the City Government of Manila. They are strictly prohibited from using the data without the permission of the City Mayor and the concurrence of the Sangguniang Panlungsod, except when used for the inherent functions of their office under R.A. 7160.

SEC. 7. – Separability Clause
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining sections not affected shall remain in full force and effect.

SEC. 8. – Repealing Clause
All ordinances, rules, regulations, or parts thereof that are inconsistent with this Ordinance are hereby repealed. However, any vested rights prior to the effectivity of this Ordinance shall not be impaired.

SEC. 9. – Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 23, 2016.
short_text: This ordinance authorizes a Joint Inspection Team (JIT) and SPIDC to inspect, survey, and take photos of buildings and other structures in Manila. The goal is to support the city’s Geographic Information System (GIS) program for better tax mapping, safety checks, and licensing. The data collected will be used only by authorized city offices, and all barangays must cooperate to help implement the program.

ORDINANCE NO. 8473
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY MAYOR TO CAUSE THE ACQUISITION, EITHER BY NEGOTIATION, EXPROPRIATION, OR BY ANY OTHER LEGAL MEANS, OF A CERTAIN PARCEL OF LAND CONSISTING OF ONE THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED THIRTY-ONE SQUARE METERS AND TWENTY-TWO SQUARE DECIMETERS (1,231.22 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, SITUATED AT CORCUERA AND BALTAZAR STREETS, BARANGAY 88, ZONE 7, DISTRICT I, TONDO, MANILA, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF GENEROSA QUEENIE M. SENGCO, MARRIED TO RONALD A. SENGCO, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA UNDER TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 292110, FOR THE ACTUAL AND BONA FIDE RESIDENTS THEREAT UNDER THE LAND-FOR-THE-LANDLESS PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA

EXPLANATORY NOTE
The rights to own land and to build a home are both constitutional and natural rights.

Proceeding from this principle, it has been the consistent policy of the City Government of Manila to provide housing for its residents.

This policy applies equally to all who desire to reside in the city, regardless of the length of their stay. It is applied with greater liberality to those who have lived in the city for several decades but, for reasons beyond their control, have been unable to acquire their own home.

In this case, around one hundred families have been occupying a parcel of land measuring 1,231.22 square meters, located at Corcuera and Baltazar Streets, Barangay 88, Zone 7, District I, Tondo, Manila. For several decades, they have been paying the tax declaration on the land and have expressed sincere interest in purchasing it from the owner, Generosa Queenie M. Sengco.

It is timely and appropriate for the City Government to intervene on behalf of the residents, so that socialized housing may be established and offered at cost to bona fide residents under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
The City Mayor is hereby authorized to cause the acquisition, either by negotiation, expropriation, or any other legal means, of that certain parcel of land consisting of One Thousand Two Hundred Thirty-One Square Meters and Twenty-Two Square Decimeters (1,231.22 sq. m.), more or less, situated at Corcuera and Baltazar Streets, Barangay 88, Zone 7, District I, Tondo, Manila. Said property is registered under the name of Generosa Queenie M. Sengco, married to Ronald A. Sengco, in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila under Transfer Certificate of Title No. 292110, for the benefit of the actual and bona fide residents thereat, under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila.

SEC. 2.
The City Mayor is hereby authorized to utilize any available funds in the City Treasury or access funding facilities from other government agencies for this purpose.

SEC. 3.
The aforementioned parcel of land, once acquired, shall be for the benefit of the bona fide tenants and occupants, particularly the registered members of the Corbal Brotherhood Association (CBA).

SEC. 4.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 18, 2016.
short_text:
This ordinance authorizes the City Mayor of Manila to acquire a piece of land in Barangay 88, Tondo (measuring 1,231.22 square meters) through negotiation, expropriation, or any legal method. The land is currently owned by Generosa Queenie M. Sengco and Ronald A. Sengco and will be used for socialized housing under the Land-for-the-Landless Program.

Key Provisions:

Land Acquisition Authorization:
The City Mayor is empowered to acquire the land located at Corcuera and Baltazar Streets in Barangay 88, Tondo for housing purposes.

Target Beneficiaries:
The land will be allocated to the actual and bona fide residents currently living there—around 100 families, including members of the Corbal Brotherhood Association (CBA).

Funding Source:
The City Mayor can use available city funds or seek funding from other government agencies to finance the land acquisition.

Purpose:
The land will be used to provide affordable housing to long-time residents who have been paying taxes on the property and wish to purchase it.

(PSTODA). The new authorized stops include key street corners along Santol Street, such as intersections with Mangga Avenue, Sociego Street, Escoda Street, Vallejo Street, B. Tuazon Street, R.D. Santos Street, and L. Roces Street. This amendment ensures that these areas are formally designated as legitimate terminals for PSTODA members.

This ordinance sets the rules for managing the PAGCOR Trust Fund—the monthly financial assistance given by PAGCOR (Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation) to the City of Manila as its host city. The fund must be used only for approved socio-economic projects like livelihood training (e.g., soap-making, meat processing), scholarships, healthcare, infrastructure, peace and order, emergency relief, and poverty reduction programs. The City Mayor and City Council must jointly approve the projects and funding through an ordinance. The money must be held in a separate account, cannot be used for salaries, and all spending must follow COA rules. The Mayor acts as the fund administrator, and quarterly reports must be submitted to PAGCOR.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8446
AN ORDINANCE MANDATING THE DISCLOSURE OF THE NUTRITIONAL CONTENTS OF STANDARD MENU ITEMS IN CHAIN RESTAURANTS AND SIMILAR RETAIL FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA, PRESCRIBING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF AND FOR OTHER RELATED PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Article II, Section 15 of the 1987 Philippine Constitution mandates that:
  “The State shall protect and promote the right to health of the people and instill health consciousness among them.”

WHEREAS, in relation thereto, Section 16 (the General Welfare Clause) of the Local Government Code of 1991 mandates every local government unit to, among other things, promote the health and safety of its inhabitants;

WHEREAS, menu nutrition labeling, a current practice in some jurisdictions, has been proven to be an effective means of raising health consciousness on the part of the public, helping them make informed dietary decisions;

WHEREAS, the practice of menu labeling, moreover, encourages restaurants to improve the nutritional qualities of the food they serve to the public:

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title.
This Ordinance shall be known as the “Manila Menu Nutrition Labeling Ordinance of 2015.”

SEC. 2. Definition of Terms.
Whenever used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall mean or be understood as follows:

 (a) “Restaurant or similar retail food establishment” – A retail establishment, the business of which is to sell or serve food that is meant for immediate human consumption, i.e., to be consumed in the premises of such restaurant, while the customer is walking away, or soon after arriving at another location.

 (b) “Menu” – The primary writing of the restaurant or similar retail food establishment, including drive-through menu boards, from which a customer makes an order selection.

 (c) “Standard menu item” – Food meant for immediate human consumption, which is routinely included on a covered establishment's menu or routinely offered as self-service food or food on display. For purposes of this Ordinance, the term “food” shall include beverages.

 (d) “Temporary menu item” – Food that appears on a covered establishment’s menu or is routinely offered as self-service food or food on display for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days, whether consecutive or not, per calendar year: PROVIDED, however, that an item that is regularly offered for sale one or more days each week shall not be considered a temporary menu item.

 (e) “Food that is part of a customary market test” – Food that is marketed in a covered establishment for a period not exceeding one hundred twenty (120) days, whether consecutive or not, in order to test consumer acceptance of the product.

 (f) “Daily special” – A menu item that is not routinely listed on a menu or offered for sale by the covered establishment, and is promoted as a special menu item prepared and offered for sale only on a particular day: PROVIDED, however, that an item that is regularly offered for sale one or more days each week shall not be considered a daily special.

 (g) “Custom order” – A food order that is prepared in a specific manner, based on an individual customer's request, which requires the covered establishment to deviate from its usual preparation of a menu item.

 (h) “Variable menu item” – A standard menu item that comes in different flavors, varieties, or combinations, and is listed as a single menu item.

 (i) “Department” – The Manila Health Department.

SEC. 3. Establishments Covered.
Every restaurant and similar retail food establishment in the City of Manila that is part of a chain with ten (10) or more locations or branches anywhere in the Philippines, doing business under the same or substantially the same name (regardless of the type of ownership of the locations), and offering for sale the same or substantially the same menu items, are subject to the requirements set forth in this Ordinance.

 Menu items are considered the same or substantially the same when they are prepared using the same general recipe and in substantially the same way with substantially the same food components, even if the names of the menu items vary.

SEC. 4. Disclosure of Nutritional Information.
For each standard menu item offered for sale, covered establishments shall, in a clear and conspicuous manner, make a corresponding nutrient content disclosure as follows:

 (a) On the menu listing the item for sale, adjacent to its name, so as to be clearly associated therewith, state the number of calories contained in each serving size or other unit of measure of such item.

 (b) In a written form available within the premises of the covered establishment and to the customer upon request—with a prominent and clear statement of such availability on the menu or menu board—state the amount of the following nutrients contained in each serving size or other unit of measure of the item:   (1) Total fat;   (2) Trans fat;   (3) Saturated fat;   (4) Cholesterol;   (5) Sodium;   (6) Total carbohydrates;   (7) Dietary fiber;   (8) Sugars; and   (9) Protein.

 Covered establishments shall have a period of six (6) months from the effectivity of this Ordinance to comply with the provisions of this section and any other requirement referring to the written form described herein.

SEC. 5. Self-Service Menu Items.
In the case of standard menu items sold at a salad bar, buffet line, cafeteria line, or similar self-service facility, and for self-service items that are on display, covered establishments shall place, adjacent to each item, a sign that states the number of calories contained in each displayed item or per serving thereof. The statement of the availability of the written form described in Sec. 4(b) of this Ordinance shall, in this case, be posted in a conspicuous area of the establishment, visible to its customers.

SEC. 6. Variable Menu Items.
In the case of variable menu items, disclosure of the caloric and nutrient content shall be made for each flavor or variety of the said item. For variable standard menu items, however, whose ingredients are chosen or determined by the customers themselves, such disclosure shall be made separately for each ingredient, topping, add-on or variable component at a given quantity—whether in a posted list or adjacent to the container. There shall likewise be a visible statement of the availability of the written form described in Sec. 4(b) of this Ordinance.

SEC. 7. Non-applicability to Certain Food.
The nutrient content disclosures required by this Ordinance shall not apply to the following food items:  (a) Those that are not listed on the menu, such as condiments and other items placed on tables or counters for general use;  (b) Daily specials;  (c) Temporary menu items;  (d) Food that is part of a customary market test; and  (e) Custom orders.

SEC. 8. Reasonable Basis.
Covered establishments shall have a reasonable basis for their nutrient content disclosures, in the form of nutrient databases, cookbooks that provide nutritional information, laboratory analyses performed by laboratories duly accredited by the Food and Drug Administration, and other reasonable means.

SEC. 9. Substantiation.
Covered establishments shall provide to the Department, within fifteen (15) days upon notice, information substantiating their nutrient content disclosures, including the following:

 (a) For nutrient databases:   (1) The identity of the database used;   (2) The ingredients affecting the nutritive values of the menu items concerned, in specific amounts vis-à-vis a given serving size;   (3) A detailed listing of the amount of nutrients that each ingredient, in the specified quantities, contributes to the menu item, if obtainable from the database;   (4) A detailed listing of the nutritive values determined for each menu item;   (5) Any other information pertinent to the final nutritive values of the menu items, such as factors that might cause variations in the nutrient profile; and   (6) A statement under oath executed by the owner/majority owner, operator, manager, or other agent in charge of the covered establishment, or by a duly licensed nutritionist employed or retained by the establishment, certifying that, to the best of his/her knowledge, the information contained in the nutrient analysis is complete and accurate, and that the covered establishment has taken reasonable steps to ensure that the method of preparation and amount of each standard menu item adhere to the factors on which its nutritive values were determined.

 (b) For published cookbooks:   (1) The name, author, and publisher of the cookbook used;   (2) If available, information provided by the cookbook or from the author or publisher about how the nutrition information for the recipe was obtained;   (3) A copy of the recipe used to prepare the menu item concerned and a copy of the nutrition information for that item as provided by the cookbook; and   (4) A statement under oath executed by the owner/majority owner, operator, manager, or other agent in charge of the covered establishment certifying that the establishment has taken reasonable steps to ensure that the method of preparation and amount of each standard menu item adhere to the factors on which its nutritive values were determined.

 (c) For laboratory analyses:   (1) The ingredients affecting the nutritive values of the menu items used for the nutrient analysis, in specific amounts vis-à-vis a given serving size;   (2) The identity of the laboratory performing the analysis;   (3) Copies of analytical worksheets, including the analytical methods used to determine and verify the nutrition information; and   (4) A statement under oath executed by the owner/majority owner, operator, manager, or other agent in charge of the covered establishment, or by a duly licensed nutritionist employed or retained by the establishment, certifying that the information contained in the nutrient analysis is complete and accurate, and that the establishment has taken reasonable steps to ensure that the method of preparation and amount of each standard menu item adhere to the factors on which its nutritive values were determined.

 (d) For nutrition information provided by other reasonable means:   (1) A detailed description of the means used to determine the nutrition information;   (2) The ingredients affecting the nutritive values of the menu items, in specific amounts vis-à-vis a given serving size;   (3) Any data used in determining the nutritive values of the menu items, such as nutrition facts on labels of packaged ingredients; and   (4) A statement under oath executed by the owner/majority owner, operator, manager, or other agent in charge of the establishment, or by a duly licensed nutritionist employed or retained by the establishment, certifying that the information provided is complete and accurate, and that the establishment has taken reasonable steps to ensure that the method of preparation and amount of each menu item adhere to the factors on which its nutritive values were determined.

 A recipe may be divided as necessary to accommodate differences in portion sizes derived from the recipe and that served as the menu item, but no changes may be made to the proportion of ingredients used.

SEC. 10. Business Permit.
No business permit shall be issued to any covered establishment unless the Department certifies that such establishment has complied with the substantiation requirements of Section 9, as may be directed by the Department, and that it has submitted the following:

 (a) An affidavit of compliance with this Ordinance, executed by the owner/majority owner, operator, manager, or other agent in charge of the establishment;
 (b) Photographs or videos showing such compliance; and
 (c) Any other additional pertinent document(s) which the Department may reasonably require as proof of compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance.

SEC. 11. Penalties.
Any person or juridical entity violating this Ordinance shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than Three Thousand Pesos (PhP 3,000.00) nor more than Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00), at the discretion of the court.
  PROVIDED, that for any second and additional offenses, the maximum fine shall always be imposed.
  PROVIDED further, that in the event the violation is committed by a juridical person, the President, Chief Executive Officer, or General Manager thereof shall be liable.

SEC. 12. Separability Clause.
If any provision or part of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional by competent authority, the remaining provisions not affected shall remain valid and in effect.

SEC. 13. Repealing Clause.
Existing ordinances, orders, or administrative regulations inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, if any, are hereby amended, modified, suspended, or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 14. Effectivity.
This Ordinance shall take effect 30 days from its posting and publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila at its regular session on November 24, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance requires chain restaurants and similar food businesses in Manila with at least 10 branches nationwide to clearly show the nutritional content of their regular menu items, including calorie count on the menu and full nutrient details (like fats, sugar, sodium, etc.) in a document available upon request. This helps customers make healthier food choices and promotes transparency. Items like condiments, daily specials, or custom orders are exempted. Businesses must provide supporting data (from nutrition databases, cookbooks, or lab tests) to the Manila Health Department and meet these requirements before getting a business permit. Violators can be fined PhP3,000–PhP5,000.
fines: PhP3,000 to PhP5,000 per violation; maximum fine imposed on second and subsequent offenses. Responsible executives of violating companies may also be held liable.

short_text: This ordinance increases the monthly allowances for the officials of the Regional Trial Court (RTC) and Metropolitan Trial Court (MTC) in Manila. The allowances for the Executive Judge, judges, clerks, and assistant clerks of both courts are raised significantly. For example, the allowance for an Executive Judge increases from PhP 12,000 to PhP 20,000, while the allowance for judges and clerks of court rises to between PhP 15,000 and PhP 7,500, depending on their position. A total of PhP 15,954,000 is allocated to fund this increase.

c. Almeda Street corner Tayuman Street
d. Bambang Street corner Abad Santos
e. Yakal Street corner Bambang Street
f. Ipil Street corner Alvarez Street”

SEC. 2. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 7871 is hereby furthermore amended by including therein the Route Measure Capacity and authorized route line of Yakal Almeda Quiricada Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association, Inc., to read as follows:

“ASSOCIATION:
Yakal Almeda Quiricada Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association, Inc. (YAQUITODA)

R.M.C.: 215 Units

ROUTE:
The authorized route line of operation shall be via Yakal St. corner Quiricada St., going to Bambang St., left to Tomas Mapua St., straight ahead to Alvarez St., right to Ipil St., left to Quiricada St., straight ahead and cross to Abad Santos, left to Antonio Rivera St., left to Bambang St., left to Yakal St. and vice versa. From Bambang St. corner Abad Santos (Terminal), straight ahead to Severino St., left to Ipil St., left to Alvarez St., left to Quiricada St., Yakal St. again to Bambang St. and vice versa. From Ipil St. corner Alvarez St. going to Quiricada St., left to Yakal St., left to Bambang St., left to Severino Reyes St., left to Alvarez St. and vice versa. From terminal of Yakal St. corner Bambang St., straight ahead to Bambang St., left to Ipil St., left to Quiricada St., right to Almeda St., going to the corner of Tayuman St. and vice versa.”

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 8, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance amends two previous ordinances related to tricycle terminals and routes in Manila. It adds the loading and unloading areas of the Yakal Almeda Quiricada Tricycle Operators and Drivers Association, Inc. (YAQUITODA), which includes specific street corners such as Yakal Street and Bambang Street. It also updates the authorized routes for this association, specifying the paths that their tricycles can take, with detailed descriptions of the routes from various terminals to specific streets in the area.

GENERAL PROVISIONS

SEC. 2. BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS. - The Budgetary Expenditures herein proposed shall comply with the following requirements:
a) No department or office of the City Government shall abolish or convert existing plantilla positions, nor create new positions, without a valid ordinance and the necessary appropriation.
b) Unused appropriations cannot be classified as savings without the prior consent of the City Council, the use of which requires a separate appropriation.
c) The appropriation of the Non-Office Account, being a contingency fund or backup fund that may be utilized by the City Government to support programs that need to be addressed immediately and/or to augment the funds needed by the different departments to finish certain programs-projects that were not sufficiently funded, cannot be utilized without specific program of expenditures endorsed by the City Mayor to the City Council through the Committee on Appropriation for approval.
d) That payment for garbage hauling shall be based on trip tickets accompanied by a certification of barangay officials attesting that the garbage collection was actually conducted.
e) As additional funding source, any City Government property that is declared disposable by the Committee on Patrimonial Properties shall seek the prior consent of the City Council through the Committee on Appropriations for authority to the Mayor to dispose the same through public bidding.
f) Consultancy services and/or job order requirements for specific programs and projects of members of the City Council and the standing committees thereof shall be provided by the General Services Account of the Department of Engineering and Public Works and the Department of Social Welfare with the approval of the City Mayor upon the recommendation of the presiding Officer of the City Council, but not to exceed thirty (30) personnel per Sanggunian Member.
g) Any purchase of cleaning agents (solution and detergents) using the City Government funds should conform with Republic Act No. 9003, otherwise known as the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000, Republic Act No. 8749, and Republic Act No. 9275, otherwise known as the Clean Water Act of 2004. Hence, products to be procured shall be limited to organic, biodegradable or environment-friendly products that are approved by the National Eco- Labeling Program of Green Choice Philippines.
h) All infrastructure projects funded by the City Government are required to strictly implement the provisions on Accessibility for Persons with Disability under Republic Act No. 7277, otherwise known as the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons, before the release of any payment.

SEC. 3. GENERAL LIMITATIONS. -
a. The total amount appropriated for Personal Services for Fiscal Year 2016 shall not exceed Forty-Five Percent (45%) of the total annual income from regular sources realized in the next preceding Fiscal Year.
b. No official or employee shall be entitled to a salary rate higher that the maximum fixed for his position or other position of equivalent rank, as determined by applicable laws, rules and regulations issued thereunder.
c. No local fund shall be appropriated to increase or adjust salaries or wages of officials and employees of the National Government except as maybe expressly authorized by law.
d. In case of abolition of positions and creation of new ones resulting from the abolition of existing positions in the career services, such abolition or creation shall be made in accordance with the pertinent provisions of the Rules and Regulations implementing R.A. 7160 and the Civil Service Law, Rules and Regulations.
e. Positions in the official plantilla for career positions which are occupied by incumbents holding permanent appointments shall be covered by adequate appropriations.
f. No changes in designation or nomenclature of position resulting in a promotion or demotion in rank or increase or decrease in compensation shall be allowed, except when the position is actually vacant and filling of such positions shall be strictly made in accordance with Civil Service Law, Rules and Regulations.
g. The creation of new positions and salary increases or adjustments shall in no case be made retroactive, and;
h. The annual appropriations for discretionary purposes of the Local Chief Executive shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the actual receipts derived from basic real property tax in the next preceding fiscal year.

SEC. 4. ITEMIZATION OF PERSONAL SERVICES. - The itemization of Personal Services in support of the appropriation herein authorized for personal services shall form part of this ordinance and shall be governed by its provisions.

SEC. 5. INTELLIGENCE EXPENSES. - The Intelligence Expenses provided under this ordinance shall be used solely for intelligence activities and disbursements thereof shall be subject to existing laws and pertinent accounting and auditing rules and regulations.

SEC. 6. CHANGES IN THE ORGANIZATIONAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE MACHINERY. - All creation, conversion, transfer, abolition and other personnel actions made under Book II of this Ordinance were made in accordance with the Revised Index of Occupational Services, Positions/Titles and Salary grades as embodied under Local Budget Circular No. 61 of the Department of Budget and Management.
a. For a more responsive, efficient and effective organization within several departments and offices, conversion of certain positions, performing staff/non-technical functions were made as mandated by DBM Circular No. 2004-3.
b. Likewise, effected and adopted, is the abolition of certain vacant positions in order to trim down the City bureaucracy to a leaner but more effective and economical organization.

SEC. 7. USE OF APPROPRIATED FUNDS. - All funds appropriated for functions, projects and activities shall be released and used exclusively for the specific purposes for which they have been authorized. Any amendments and augmentation may be made within the calendar year only upon the enactment and approval of a Supplemental Budget Ordinance.

SEC. 8. AUTHORITY TO ADJUST APPROPRIATIONS. - No ordinance shall be passed authorizing any transfer of appropriations from one item to another. However, the City Mayor and the Presiding Officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are authorized to augment any item in the approved annual budgets for their respective offices from savings in other items within the same expense classification of their respective appropriations.

SEC. 9. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND. - The 20% Community Development Fund shall strictly be utilized for projects specified under the Annual Investment Plan as approved by the City Council in conformity with the Local Government Code.

SEC. 10. TWENTY PERCENT (20%) CONTINGENCY RESERVE. - Except for expenses due to public utilities, rentals, insurance premiums and food supplies expenses, a contingency reserve of 20% on the authorized 2016 appropriation for Departmental Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses shall be provided for the purpose. All department/office heads are enjoined to prepare Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment indicating therein the 20% contingency reserve.

SEC. 11. ALLOTMENT OF APPROPRIATIONS. - For effective budgetary control, authorized appropriations shall be allotted in accordance with the DBM and COA Joint Circular No. 93-2 as outlined hereunder.
a. No appropriation authorized for any department or office of the City of Manila, shall be available for expenditure until the head of each department or office shall have submitted to the City Budget Office a Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment showing the estimated amounts needed for each function, activity or purpose for which the funds are to be expended during the applicable allotment period and until an Advice of Allotment for said request shall have been approved by the City Mayor, as hereafter provided. The Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted to the City Budget Officer not less than twenty-five (25) days prior to the beginning of the ensuing calendar year: PROVIDED, That in case the annual budget is approved after December 6 of each calendar year, the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted based on the appropriations authorized in the Budget Ordinance. A revised Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment shall be submitted upon approval of the Annual Executive Budget referred to herein showing quarterly allotment of the whole authorized appropriations for the department/office.
b. For the purpose of the allotment system herein provided, each calendar year shall be divided into four (4) quarterly allotment periods beginning respectively on the first day of January, April, July and October.
c. The City Mayor may require heads of departments/offices to revise their Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment upon the City Treasurer's notification and certification that the realized income is less than what is estimated in the annual/supplemental budget or that additional income is realized.
d. An Advice of Allotment shall be prepared by the City Budget Office based on recommendation made in the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment. Upon the recommendation of the said official, the City Mayor shall approve the Work and Financial Plan and Request for Allotment and the Advice of Allotment at least five (5) days before the start of each quarter.

SEC. 12. NON-WAIVER CLAUSE. - Notwithstanding the approval of this appropriation Ordinance by the City Council, all contracts, disbursement, and awards entered into by the City of Manila including but not limited to the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, the Universidad de Manila and other government agencies and its instrumentalities under the City of Manila with any party shall be duly ratified by the City Council pursuant to Section 455, Paragraph B, sub-paragraph 1-vi of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, and in conformity with the observations of the Department of Budget and Management.

SEC. 13. SEPARABILITY CLAUSE. - If for any reason or reasons, any part or provision of this Ordinance shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions hereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 14. EFFECTIVITY CLAUSE. - This Ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2016.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 12, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance approves the budget for the City of Manila for FY 2016, totaling PHP 14,112,269,710.00, which will be used for various city operations and programs. It outlines how the funds will be allocated across different departments, including personal services, infrastructure projects, and contingency reserves. There are specific rules for spending the budget, such as ensuring funds are used only for their intended purposes, with some funds set aside for community development and emergency needs. It also includes provisions on salary limits, position creation, and the use of intelligence expenses.

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING MONTHLY ALLOWANCE TO ALL PUBLIC SCHOOL TEACHERS AND ALL REGULAR NON-TEACHING PERSONNEL OF THE DIVISION OF CITY SCHOOLS IN THE CITY OF MANILA AND APPROPRIATING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREFOR

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the City of Manila acknowledges that the public school teachers and other non-teaching personnel of the City of Manila are in the forefront of the education of its youth towards a better future;

WHEREAS, the public school teachers and regular non-teaching personnel of the Division of City Schools of Manila deserve priority in the allocation of the resources of the city, pursuant to Section 458 (xi), R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991; NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. All public school teachers and regular non-teaching personnel of the Division of City Schools of Manila shall be entitled to Two Thousand Pesos (PhP. 2,000.00) monthly allowance.

SEC. 2. The amount necessary for the grant of monthly allowance under Section 1 hereof shall be appropriated from sources in the General Fund not otherwise appropriated and certified as available by the City Treasurer.

SEC. 3. The City Mayor may declare additional special allowance on any given year not to exceed One Thousand Pesos (PhP. 1,000.00) per month to the said teachers or regular non-teaching personnel, or both, subject to the approval of the City Council and existing budgetary rules and regulations.

SEC. 4. Repealing Clause. - All ordinances, rules and regulations, or portions thereof, which are contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance or portions hereof are hereby deemed repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 3, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance grants a PhP 2,000.00 monthly allowance to all public school teachers and regular non-teaching personnel of the Division of City Schools in Manila. It also allows the City Mayor to provide an additional special allowance of up to PhP 1,000.00 per month, subject to City Council approval and budget availability.

ORDINANCE NO. 8439

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8366 OF THE CITY OF MANILA TO INCLUDE OTHER BARANGAYS ADJACENT TO AND SIMILARLY HOSTING BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS OPERATING IN THE AREAS DESCRIBED THEREIN IN THE ALLOCATION OF THE REAL PROPERTY TAX AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, the City Council of Manila, on November 21, 2014, passed Ordinance No. 8366 affirming City Council Resolution No. 110, Series of 2014, appropriating to Barangay 248, Zone 22, District II, City of Manila, the proceeds of real property tax covering the areas of Mayhaligue Street to the North, C.M. Recto Avenue to the South, Dagupan Street to the West, and Antonio Rivera Street to the East;

WHEREAS, the Honorable Mayor Joseph Ejercito Estrada has approved and signed said Ordinance on November 21, 2014;

WHEREAS, aside from Barangay 248, there are other barangays which are adjacent to and similarly hosting commercial establishments in the said areas, particularly Barangays 48, 49, and 51 under Zone 4 of District I, and Barangays 245 and 247, under Zone 22, District II, City of Manila;

WHEREAS, Section 271 of the Local Government Code, among others, provides that the proceeds of the basic real property tax, including interest thereon, specifically in cities like the City of Manila, shall be distributed seventy percent (70%) for the general fund of the city and thirty percent (30%) among component barangays, whereby the latter allocation for the barangays shall be further divided or allocated fifty percent (50%) to the Barangay/s where the property or properties are located and fifty percent (50%) equally to all component barangays;

WHEREAS, considering that Barangays 48, 49, 51, 245, 247, and 248 are equally hosting the business establishments referred to under Ordinance No. 8366 and taking into account the above provision of the Local Government Code of 1991, there is an imperative need for this amendatory Ordinance: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Re-allocation of the Area. - The areas referred to in Ordinance No. 8366 shall be re-allocated to include Barangays 48, 49, and 51 under Zone 4, District I, and Barangays 245, 247, and 248, Zone 22, District II, all in the City of Manila.

SEC. 2. RPT Shares. - Upon the effectivity of this amendatory Ordinance, the above-named Barangays shall receive and equally share in the amount equivalent to fifty percent (50%) of the thirty (30%) real property tax allocation as provided for by law (pending the passage of an ordinance providing for a comprehensive tax-mapping of the City of Manila’s 896 barangays for the purpose of real property taxation). The RPT shares rightfully received by a Local Government Unit (LGU) such as Barangays under the amended Ordinance No. 8366 shall not in any way affect the current and future RPT to be shared by the Barangays indicated herein.

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, and other issuances which are inconsistent with and/or contrary to any of the provisions of this amendatory Ordinance are hereby repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 4. Separability Clause. - If for any reason or reasons, any part or provisions of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions which are not affected thereby shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 27, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance amends Ordinance No. 8366 to include additional barangays—Barangays 48, 49, 51, 245, 247, and 248—in the allocation of real property tax (RPT) proceeds from business establishments in certain areas. These barangays will now equally share in 50% of the 30% allocation for barangays as specified by law.

ORDINANCE NO. 8437

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF ORDINANCE NO. 8163, ENTITLED: "AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING LAW ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITIES TO COORDINATE WITH THE BARANGAY CONCERNED BEFORE AND AFTER CONDUCTING A LEGITIMATE OPERATION AND PRESCRIBING PENALTIES FOR ANY VIOLATION THEREOF", BY INCLUDING THE REQUIREMENT OF COORDINATION WITH THE OFFICE OF THE MAYOR, AND THE INCLUSION OF CERTAIN GOVERNMENT AGENCIES WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNCTIONS WITHIN THE COVERAGE THEREOF, TOGETHER WITH PROCEDURES BEFORE, DURING AND AFTER CONDUCTING ENFORCEMENT OPERATIONS

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Section 1 of Ordinance No. 8163 is hereby amended, which shall read as follows:

“SECTION 1. Declaration of Policy. - It is hereby declared the policy of the City Government, cognizant of the State Policy on Human Rights and the protection of the rights of its constituency under the General Welfare Act, to deter both legitimate and bogus law enforcement operatives from preying or continuing to prey on hapless and marginalized people who lack formal education or legal knowledge, including local and foreign businessmen, pretending to be law enforcement agents serving search warrants, warrants of arrest, summons or mission orders and entering private property without legitimate orders, thus creating tension, chaos, and confusion and sowing fear among innocent victims.”

SEC. 2. Section 2 of Ordinance No. 8163 is hereby amended, which shall read as follows:

“SEC. 2. Pursuant to this policy, it shall hereby be the duty of any member of the law enforcement agencies to first coordinate with the OFFICE OF THE MAYOR in order for the office to confirm the veracity of the operations of the agencies concerned AND ASSIGN A REPRESENTATIVE to accompany or endorse the team or person enforcing the order to the barangay having jurisdiction over the area of operations and to the local police precinct.

a. The execution of any law enforcement operation by authorities who are covered by this Ordinance shall be witnessed by the local police, the duly authorized representative of the City Government, and officials of the barangay having territorial jurisdiction over the place where the operation is conducted. All law enforcers performing legitimate operations should wear their agency’s identification (ID) cards with photograph which should be visible from a distance of two (2) meters. During the operation, any person/s searched and/or arrested shall be informed by the authorities concerned of their rights and assisted by a lawyer.

b. Immediately after the operation, the basic details of the person/s arrested, the place searched, and the item/s seized shall be recorded in the logbook of the Barangay where the operation was conducted, which shall also be witnessed by the local police, the representative of the City Government, and officials of the barangay WHO SHALL INFORM THE NEAREST KIN OF THE PERSON/S ARRESTED AS TO THE PLACE OF DETENTION.

c. Any law enforcement operation shall be conducted during regular office hours. If the operation is conducted beyond regular office hours, the person arrested or the item/s seized shall be under the legal custody of the local police. Immediately on the first hour of the next working day, the police having custody of the person/s arrested or the item/s seized shall turn over the same to the law enforcement authorities concerned.

d. For failure on the part of the law enforcement authorities to coordinate with the City Government, the local police, and/or Barangay officials, the latter may refuse to honor the service of the search warrant, warrant of arrest, summons, or mission order, which shall be considered as a legal defiance.”

SEC. 3. Section 3 of Ordinance No. 8163 is hereby amended, which shall read as follows:

“Sec. 3. The following law enforcement agencies are covered by this Ordinance, to wit:

a) Members of the Manila Police District (MPD)
b) Agents of the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI)
c) Members of the Special Action Force (SAF)
d) Members of the Investigation and Detection Group (CIDG)
e) Officials of the Department of Justice (DOJ)
f) Officials of the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR)
g) Officials of the Bureau of Immigration (BI)
h) Officials of the Bureau of Customs (BOC)
i) Other similar law enforcement authorities.

Unless the incident will fall under the warrantless arrest, as provided under the law, proper service of summons, search warrants, warrants of arrest, and/or mission orders shall be observed with due process.”

SEC. 4. Section 4, second paragraph of Ordinance No. 8163 is hereby amended, which shall read as follows:

“Those covered under Section 3 hereof who shall violate the provisions of this Ordinance shall be punished with imprisonment of not less than eight (8) months but not more than one (1) year or a fine of Five Thousand Pesos (PhP 5,000.00), or both at the discretion of the court. This is without prejudice to the filing of other administrative or criminal cases provided under the law.”

SEC. 5. Effectivity Clause. - This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on November 3, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance amends a previous law that requires law enforcement authorities to coordinate with local barangays before and after conducting operations. It adds a requirement for coordination with the Office of the Mayor and expands the list of government agencies that must follow this coordination procedure. The ordinance also details the procedures that law enforcement must follow, including informing arrested individuals of their rights, keeping records in barangay logbooks, and turning over detained individuals to local police if operations happen outside office hours. Violations of the coordination process can result in penalties
fines:
Imprisonment of 8 months to 1 year

Fine of ₱5,000, or both

ORDINANCE NO. 8429

AN ORDINANCE GRANTING INCENTIVES TO PROPRIETORS OR OWNERS OF BUSINESS CORPORATIONS AND ESTABLISHMENTS THAT EMPLOY BONA FIDE RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, Article II, Section 19 of the 1987 Constitution provides that: “The State shall develop a self-reliant and independent national economy effectively controlled by Filipinos”;

WHEREAS, the same Constitution mandates the State to afford full protection to labor and promote full employment and equality of employment opportunities for all;

WHEREAS, under Section 16 of Republic Act No. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, it states that: “Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare...”;

WHEREAS, the City Council must devise a measure to promote full employment among residents of the City of Manila and ensure that they are benefited from the City’s commercial resources: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. DEFINITION OF TERMS. — As used herein, the following terms shall be understood to mean:

a. Bona fide Residents of the City of Manila — A person who is, prior to application for employment in a private business establishment, a resident for a period of at least six (6) months of a particular barangay within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila.

b. Owner of Private Business Corporation or Establishment — Refers to a proprietor or employer of, including any person acting directly or indirectly in the interest of an employer in relation to an employee, a business establishment or corporation registered or incorporated under the General Incorporation Law.

c. Proof of Residence — Refers to a certification issued by the barangay chairman attesting that a person is a bona fide resident of said barangay for a period of six (6) months or more.

SEC. 2. Coverage. — All private business corporations and establishments operating within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila shall, in the recruitment, selection, and hiring of their personnel or staff, give priority or preference to the bona fide residents of the City of Manila.

SEC. 3. Proof of Residents. — Owners or employers of private business corporations or establishments shall, in addition to other requirements for employment, require the applicant to secure and submit proof of residence and a Community Tax Certificate issued by the particular barangay where he or she is residing.

SEC. 4. Incentive for Proprietors or Owners of Private Business Corporations or Establishments. — Proprietors or owners of private business corporations or establishments that hire bona fide residents of the City of Manila shall be given a discount on the business permit fee in accordance with the following schedule:

a. Fifteen to twenty-five percent (15%-25%) of the total personnel are bona fide residents of the City of Manila, 5% discount in business permit fee;

b. Twenty-six to thirty-five percent (26%-35%) of the total personnel, 10% discount;

c. Thirty-six to forty-five percent (36%-45%) of the total personnel, 15% discount;

d. Forty-six to fifty-five percent (46%-55%) of the total personnel, 20% discount;

e. Fifty-six percent (56%) and above of the total personnel, 25% discount in the business permit fee.

SEC. 5. Execution of Certification. — Any business corporation or establishment that desires to avail of the incentives granted in accordance with the provisions of the preceding section shall, in addition to other documentary requirements for the issuance or renewal of Mayor's Permit to operate business, execute a certification under oath and signed by the president or manager, that said business corporation or establishment employed or hired such percentage as may be necessary to be entitled to the benefits granted under this Ordinance.

The certification under oath shall be accompanied by a list of employees who are bona fide residents of the City of Manila, indicating their names and addresses.

SEC. 6. Duty of the Bureau of Permits. — No discount or deduction in business permit fee shall be given by the City Bureau of Permits to any proprietor or owner of private business corporation or establishment without submitting the certification and list as required in the preceding section.

SEC. 7. Liability for Violation. — Any owner or employer of a private business corporation or establishment who willfully makes a false statement in the undertaking or certification shall be criminally liable for perjury.

Any government official or employee who granted or caused the granting of incentives to any proprietor or owner of private business corporation or establishment in the absence of the required certification and list shall be criminally, civilly, and administratively liable.

SEC. 8. Separability Clause. — Any part or provision of this Ordinance which may be held invalid or unconstitutional shall not affect the validity and effectivity of the other provisions.

SEC. 9. Repealing Clause. — All existing ordinances, resolutions, local executive orders, rules, and regulations inconsistent with any of the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed and/or modified accordingly.

SEC. 10. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 6, 2015.
short_text:
This ordinance provides incentives to business owners in Manila who hire residents of the city. The businesses get a discount on their business permit fees based on how many Manila residents they employ.

If 15% to 25% of their employees are Manila residents, they get a 5% discount.

If 26% to 35% are Manila residents, they get a 10% discount.

If 36% to 45% are Manila residents, they get a 15% discount.

If 46% to 55% are Manila residents, they get a 20% discount.

If 56% or more are Manila residents, they get a 25% discount.
fines: Business owners or employers who provide false information regarding employee residency can be charged with perjury. Government officials who approve discounts without proper certification can face criminal, civil, and administrative penalties.

ORDINANCE NO. 8426
AN ORDINANCE CREATING THE INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE IN THE CITY OF MANILA AND PROVIDING FUNDS THEREFOR

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Creation.
There shall be created an Internal Audit Service Department in the City of Manila.

SEC. 2. Functions.
The Internal Audit Service Department shall perform the following functions:

a) Advise the City Mayor, through the Audit Committee, on all matters relating to management control and operations audits;

b) Conduct management and operations audits of all City of Manila departments, bureaus, hospitals, schools and universities, and other offices as regards their functions, programs, projects, activities with outputs, and determine the degree of compliance with their respective mandates, policies, government regulations, established objectives, systems and procedures/processes, and contractual obligations;

c) Review and appraise systems and procedures, organizational structures, asset management practices, financial and management records, reports, and performance standards of all the City of Manila departments, bureaus, hospitals, schools and universities, and other offices;

d) Analyze and evaluate management deficiencies and assist the Local Chief Executive by recommending realistic courses of action;

e) Perform such other related duties and responsibilities as may be assigned or delegated by the Local Chief Executive or as may be required by law; and

f) In the conduct of management or operations audit, the Internal Audit Service shall be guided by the Philippine Government Internal Audit Manual, which forms part of this Ordinance.

SEC. 3. Organizational Structure.
The Internal Audit Service shall directly report to the Local Chief Executive. It shall be headed by a Department Head III and shall hold a co-terminous position with that of the appointing authority. It shall have three divisions: Management, Operations, and Administrative Divisions. It shall exist independently from all other departments in the local government unit.

The organizational structure in relation to other offices in the City of Manila shall be as follows:

Office of the City Administrator → Manila Health Department → Manila Department of Social Welfare → Internal Audit Service Department → Local Chief Executive

SEC. 4. The Internal Audit Department Head.
The Internal Audit Department Head shall be appointed by the City Mayor with the concurrence of the Sangguniang Panlungsod. He shall report directly to the City Mayor. He shall hold the position of Department Head III with Salary Grade 27 and a co-terminous status with the appointing authority.

Qualifications:

Education: Any of the following: Master's Degree in Accounting, Public Administration, Criminology, Information Technology/Computer Science, and other related disciplines. A Bachelor's Degree in Law would be an advantage.

Experience: Five (5) years of supervisory or relevant experience in any of the following: Public Administration, Internal Auditing, Administrative or Criminal Investigation, Forensics (e.g., Accounting, Information Technology), International Organization for Standardization (ISO) Management Systems, and other related disciplines.

Training: 120 hours of managerial training in the above-mentioned fields.

Eligibility: Career Service (Professional) Second Level Eligibility / R.A. 1080

SEC. 5. Functions of the Internal Audit Department Head.
The Internal Audit Department Head shall be responsible for:

Ensuring the efficient and effective operation of the internal audit function;

Developing strong professional relationships with the other Department Heads of the City of Manila and key stakeholders;

Leading the development of the internal audit strategic plan and annual work plan outlining objectives, priorities, and proposed internal audit coverage; and

Liaising with other external monitoring and evaluation bodies in developing internal audit plans for review and approval by the City Mayor.

SEC. 6. Internal Organizational Structure.
The Internal Audit Service shall have the following internal organizational structure:

(Refer to Ordinance No. 8426 for full organizational table.)

SEC. 7. Functions of Organizational Units.
(a) Operations Audit Division:
The Operations Audit Division shall:

Conduct operations performance audits of all departments, bureaus, and offices, and determine compliance with mandates, policies, regulations, objectives, procedures, and contractual obligations (Section 2.4b, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5);

Review systems and procedures, organizational structures, records, and performance standards (Section 2.4c, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5);

Analyze operational data to validate completeness, accuracy, and validity (Section 4.1.1.2, DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4);

Ascertain the reliability of operational information and reporting processes (Section 1.1.1, AO No. 278, s. 1992);

Determine whether results align with goals and whether programs are being implemented as planned (Section 1.1.5, AO 278, s. 1992);

Evaluate performance of personnel and units (Section 1.1.6, AO 278, s. 1992);

Recommend actions for addressing deficiencies (Section 1.1.7, AO 278, s. 1992);

Prevent and detect fraud, review misuse of property, check transactions, and perform investigations (Sections 4.1.1.4 and 4.1.1.5, DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4).

(b) Management Division:
The Management Division shall:

Conduct management audits to ensure compliance with mandates, policies, and obligations (Section 2.4b, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5 and Section 1.1.2, AO 278, s. 1992);

Appraise systems, structure, asset management, records, and performance (Section 2.4c, DBM Circular Letter No. 2008-5);

Verify financial and management data accuracy (Section 4.1.1.2, DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4);

Ensure data integrity and reliable reporting (Section 1.1.1, AO 278, s. 1992);

Confirm proper accounting and safeguarding of assets (Section 1.1.3, AO 278, s. 1992);

Promote cost-effective controls (Section 1.1.4, AO 278, s. 1992);

Evaluate performance of personnel (Section 1.1.6, AO 278, s. 1992);

Prevent and detect fraud or dishonesty, review misuse of assets, and oversee transactions (Section 4.1.1.4, DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4);

Perform investigations and assist external bodies such as COA (Section 4.1.1.5, DBM Budget Circular No. 2004-4).

(c) Administrative Division:
The Administrative Division shall:

Oversee operations and management of the division;

Submit policy recommendations to the IAS Department Head;

Implement CSC policies and related administrative laws;

Provide advisory services to the IAS Head and employees;

Develop administrative systems and procedures;

Perform other functions assigned by the IAS Department Head.

Administrative Division Sections:

Human Resource Management Section

Maintain plantilla and records;

Prepare payroll and ledgers;

Promote employee welfare and development;

Process attendance, leave, promotions, and personnel actions;

Communicate Civil Service rules;

Identify training needs for HRD Plan;

Liaise with relevant agencies;

Perform other assigned duties.

Records and General Services Section

Implement records management policies;

Safeguard official records and seal;

Maintain internal records program;

Authenticate documents and represent IAS;

Manage document flow;

Provide messenger, liaison, and janitorial services;

Perform other assigned duties.

Property and Supply Section

Maintain supply management system;

Manage custody, inventory, and distribution of supplies and equipment;

Maintain Supply Ledger Cards and prepare monthly reports;

Recommend measures for proper utilization of resources;

Perform other assigned duties.

Budget and Accounting Section

Assist in budget preparation;

Monitor financial transactions;

Process payroll and employee benefits;

Handle disbursements, vouchers, and allotments;

Perform other assigned duties.

SEC. 8. Staffing Pattern.
Internal Audit Staff shall hold career positions. Each Division shall be headed by an Internal Auditor V (SG 24). Each Division has two Sections, each led by an Internal Auditor IV (SG 22). Each Section shall have two teams composed of Internal Auditors I and II, and one Internal Auditing Assistant.

Sample Position and Qualification:

No. of Positions: 1

Education: Master’s degree relevant to the position

Experience: 4 years in management/supervisory roles

Training: 24 hours in management/supervision

Eligibility: Career Service (Professional), Second Level Eligibility

Number of Positions: 2

Education: Bachelor’s degree relevant to the position

Experience: 3 years of relevant experience

Training: 16 hours of relevant training

Eligibility: Career Service (Professional)/Second level eligibility

Eligibility: Career Service (Professional)/Second level eligibility

SEC. 9. Appropriation. The initial appropriation for the creation and personnel

ORDINANCE NO. 8424
AN ORDINANCE PREVENTING ACTS OF BULLYING COMMITTED AMONG STUDENTS IN THE CITY OF MANILA

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Section 3 (2), Article XV of the 1987 Philippine Constitution mandates the State to defend the rights of children to assistance, including proper care and nutrition, and special protection from all forms of neglect, abuse, cruelty, exploitation, and other conditions prejudicial to their development;

WHEREAS, the General Welfare Clause of the Local Government Code under Section 16 states that every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted, those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare;

WHEREAS, schools, as institutions for educating Filipino children, should establish a child-friendly environment and create a school setting that is conducive to learning;

WHEREAS, bullying committed in schools not only inflicts physical, psychological, and emotional harm to students but also creates fear among them that adversely affects their academic development and social personality;

WHEREAS, the city government must devise appropriate remedies to address the demeaning act of bullying in order to protect the well-being of students for the peace of mind of their parents and/or guardians;

NOW THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Title
This Ordinance shall be known as the “Anti-Bullying Ordinance of the City of Manila.”

SEC. 2. Declaration of Policy
It is hereby declared the policy of the City of Manila to provide measures to ensure the safety and security of children within and outside school premises.

SEC. 3. Definition of Terms
Student – An individual enrolled/registered in a public or private educational institution for formal or non-formal education.

School Personnel – Persons working for an educational institution, classified as follows:

Administrators – Persons occupying policy-implementing positions relative to the functions of the school at all levels, including those who exercise discretion in providing disciplinary sanctions.

Academic Teaching Staff – Persons engaged in classroom teaching at any level, full-time or part-time, including guidance counselors and vocational instructors.

Academic Non-teaching Staff – Persons with academic qualifications performing supplemental academic functions such as librarians, registrars, and similar staff.

Non-Teaching Personnel – All other personnel, regular or casual, not included in the above classifications.

Authorized School Activity – Any activity sanctioned and permitted by the school head and/or school administrator.

Bullying – Unwanted, aggressive behavior that involves a real or perceived power imbalance. The behavior is repeated or has the potential to be repeated.

Bully – A student or school personnel who uses superior strength or influence to intimidate another student who is younger, weaker, with disability, less confident, or otherwise vulnerable.

SEC. 4. Acts of Bullying
Bullying may be committed through verbal, written, or electronic expressions, or physical acts or gestures that cause psychological and/or emotional fear, intimidation, or humiliation. Forms include:

Physical Bullying – Hurtful and sudden physical contact such as punching, pushing, kicking, mauling, school pranks, or use of objects as weapons.

Psychological Bullying – Includes spreading rumors, threats, exclusion, extortion, forcing services, stalking, or harassment.

Emotional Bullying – Acts causing emotional stress such as name-calling, deliberate ignoring, or embarrassment based on religion, appearance, or financial status.

Sexual Bullying – Unwanted touching of private parts (legs, breasts, buttocks, or genitals) causing embarrassment, irritation, or mental torment.

Cyber Bullying – Humiliation, harassment, or intimidation via electronic means such as texts, emails, social media, and blogs.

SEC. 5. Penalties
Students aged 18 or above: 1 to 6 months imprisonment or a ₱1,000–₱3,000 fine, or both.

Students under 18: Handled per RA 9344 and its IRR.

School Personnel: 6 months to 1 year imprisonment or a ₱3,000–₱5,000 fine, or both.

Special Parental Authority – The school and its personnel have responsibility over students during school activities inside or outside the school premises.

SEC. 6. Civil Liability
Civil liability for those in authority will be governed by Article 219 of the Family Code of the Philippines.

SEC. 7. Creation of School Anti-Bullying Committee
All schools must create an Anti-Bullying Committee composed of:

School Head/Administrator/Principal – Chairperson

Guidance Counselor – Member

President of the Supreme Student Government or Central Student Council – Member

President of the Faculty Club (or representative) – Member

President of the General Parents-Teachers Association (GPTA) – Member (for elementary and secondary schools)

The committee must:

Identify disciplinary actions against bullies

Provide procedures for counseling and referrals

Inform and educate parents about anti-bullying policies and online safety

Policies must be included in student and employee handbooks and distributed to stakeholders.

SEC. 8. Handling Bullying Cases
Public elementary and secondary schools: Follow DepEd Order No. 40, s. 2012 (Child Protection Policy).

Private and tertiary schools: Follow their codes of discipline and administrative procedures, with due process.

SEC. 9. Bullying Between Students from Different Schools
The school that first receives the complaint will investigate the case.

SEC. 10. Bullying Resulting in Crimes
Handled per the Revised Penal Code and RA 9344 if bullying leads to a criminal offense.

SEC. 11. Confidentiality of Penalty Imposed
Any penalty must be in writing and included in the student's anecdotal record. The Guidance Counselor shall keep this record confidential.

SEC. 12. Policy Implementation
The School Head or Administrator is responsible for policy implementation and oversight.

SEC. 13. Separability Clause
If any part of this ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional, the rest remains in effect.

SEC. 14. Repealing Clause
All laws inconsistent with this ordinance are repealed or modified accordingly.

SEC. 15. Effectivity
This ordinance shall take effect 15 days after publication in a newspaper of general circulation.

Enacted by the City Council of Manila on September 24, 2015.
short_text:
This ordinance, known as the "Anti-Bullying Ordinance of the City of Manila," establishes rules to prevent and punish bullying among students in both public and private schools in Manila. It defines different types of bullying—including physical, emotional, psychological, sexual, and cyberbullying—and mandates schools to form anti-bullying committees, educate stakeholders, and enforce clear disciplinary procedures. Penalties vary depending on the age of the offender and whether they are a student or school personnel.

Key Provisions:

Who Is Covered:

Students (formal and non-formal)

School personnel (teachers, staff, administrators)

Types of Bullying:

Physical: Hitting, pushing, or using objects as weapons

Psychological: Rumors, threats, extortion, exclusion

Emotional: Name-calling, deliberate ignoring, mocking religion or poverty

Sexual: Unwanted touching or harassment

Cyber: Online humiliation or threats
School Responsibilities:
Establish an Anti-Bullying Committee

Define disciplinary procedures and counseling protocols

Educate students, parents, and staff

Include anti-bullying policies in handbooks

Policy Implementation:

The School Head is accountable for enforcement

Complaints involving students from different schools will be handled by the school receiving the complaint

Confidentiality of penalties is mandated
fines:
Students 18 and above: ₱1,000–₱3,000 fine or 1–6 months imprisonment, or both

School personnel: ₱3,000–₱5,000 fine or 6 months–1 year imprisonment, or both

Students below 18: Handled under RA 9344 (Juvenile Justice Law)
