ORDINANCE NO. 8423
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING TAX AMNESTY ON THE TOTAL PENALTIES AND INTERESTS BEING IMPOSED ON REAL ESTATE TAXPAYERS FOR DELINQUENCY IN PAYING REAL ESTATE TAX, WHICH COULD BE AVAILED FROM OCTOBER 10, 2015 TO DECEMBER 31, 2015 UNDER CONDITIONS STATED IN THIS ORDINANCE

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Scope. — All delinquent real estate taxpayers of real properties, including but not limited to lands, structures, and machineries within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila, are hereby granted tax amnesty on penalties and interests. They shall be given the period from October 10, 2015 to December 31, 2015 within which time frame said delinquency shall be settled.

SEC. 2. Process of Availment.

Delinquent taxpayers who want to avail of tax amnesty are required to first execute an affidavit of good faith. They shall be allowed to pay their delinquent taxes without penalties or interests for unpaid taxes within the period of January 1, 2010, to December 31, 2014.

The delinquent real property taxpayers shall register with the Real Estate Division, City Treasurer's Office, signifying their intention to avail of tax amnesty and shall execute an agreement stating the payment scheme they will avail of.

SEC. 3. Modes of Payment.

An installment of a maximum of six (6) payments can be availed of for real estate taxes with a computed value of Thirty Thousand Pesos (₱30,000.00) and above.

For installment payments, the first installment shall be paid upon execution of the Tax Amnesty Relief Agreement between the taxpayer and the City Treasurer.

Real estate taxes with a computed value below Thirty Thousand Pesos (₱30,000.00) shall be paid in full.

SEC. 4. Who May Avail of the Tax Amnesty.

Real properties that are declared for the first time and are subject to back taxes.

Real properties that are declared but the taxes due therein have not been paid.

Real properties included in public auctions but were not purchased by private persons or entities as of the date of the effectivity of this Ordinance, provided that title thereto has not been transferred to the government.

SEC. 5. No tax amnesty shall be accepted until after updated payment of the current year’s real property tax on the property being applied for has been paid.

SEC. 6. No payments for real property taxes shall be accepted under this Ordinance from any one unless a valid authority to pay or an order of payment signed by the City Treasurer is presented.

SEC. 7. The Office of the City Treasurer and the Department of Assessment are hereby directed to issue, within five (5) days upon approval of this Ordinance, the necessary rules and guidelines implementing the same.

SEC. 8. Repealing Clause. — All ordinances or portions thereof that are contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance or portions hereof are hereby deemed modified or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 9. Effectivity Clause. — This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on October 1, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance grants a tax amnesty on penalties and interest for delinquent real estate taxpayers in Manila. Taxpayers can settle unpaid real estate taxes from January 1, 2010, to December 31, 2014, without facing penalties or interest, as long as they pay between October 10, 2015, and December 31, 2015. Payments can be made in full or through installments, depending on the tax amount.
fines: None for taxes paid within the amnesty period; penalties and interest are waived.

ORDINANCE NO. 8402
AN ORDINANCE INCREASING BY ONE PESO (PHP. 1.00) THE PRICE OF EACH MOVIE TICKET ISSUED OR SOLD IN CINEMAS IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM AUGUST 15 TO DECEMBER 31, 2015, THE PROCEEDS REALIZED FROM SUCH INCREASE TO BE DONATED TO PSORIASIS PHILIPPINES, SUBJECT TO ALL APPLICABLE AUDITING RULES AND PROCEDURES

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS, psoriasis is a serious, non-communicable, genetic disease that imposes severe physical, psychological, social, and economic burdens on 1.9 million Filipinos and over 125 million people worldwide;

WHEREAS, Psoriasis Philippines is a charitable, non-profit organization dedicated to raising awareness of psoriasis and giving people afflicted with this disease the attention and consideration they need;

WHEREAS, Psoriasis Philippines relies only on the contributions of its members and donations from the public in pursuing its various programs for the benefit of Filipinos with psoriasis: NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. The price of each movie ticket issued or sold from August 15 to December 31, 2015, in all cinemas in the City of Manila shall be increased by One Peso (PhP. 1.00), for the exclusive benefit of Psoriasis Philippines.

SEC. 2. Owners and operators of cinemas in the City of Manila shall remit, to Psoriasis Philippines, on or before the 15th day of the month, all the proceeds realized from such increase during the previous month.

SEC. 3. Psoriasis Philippines shall, in accordance with applicable auditing rules and procedures, render a report and accounting to the City Government of Manila of all the sums remitted under this Ordinance.

SEC. 4. A copy of this Ordinance shall be furnished to all cinema owners and operators in the City of Manila, the Office of the Mayor, the Office of the City Accountant, and the local office of the Commission on Audit for their information and guidance.

SEC. 5. This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on August 13, 2015.

CERTIFICATION

This is to certify that CITY ORDINANCE NO. 8402, “AN ORDINANCE INCREASING BY ONE PESO (PHP 1.00) THE PRICE OF EACH MOVIE TICKET ISSUED OR SOLD IN CINEMAS IN THE CITY OF MANILA FROM AUGUST 15 TO DECEMBER 31, 2015, THE PROCEEDS REALIZED FROM SUCH INCREASE TO BE DONATED TO PSORIASIS PHILIPPINES, SUBJECT TO ALL APPLICABLE AUDITING RULES AND PROCEDURES,” was enacted by the City Council of Manila during its regular session on August 13, 2015. The same was forwarded to the Office of the Honorable Mayor on August 20, 2015.

Considering that more than ten (10) days had lapsed, without any communication that the ordinance was approved or vetoed by the Local Chief Executive, Ordinance No. 8402 shall be DEEMED APPROVED as if he had signed it, pursuant to Section 54 par. (b) of R.A. 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991.

Issued this 27th day of November 2015, in the City of Manila.
short_text: From August 15 to December 31, 2015, movie tickets in all Manila cinemas were increased by PHP 1.00 per ticket. All proceeds from this increase were donated to Psoriasis Philippines, a nonprofit supporting people with psoriasis. Cinema operators were required to remit collections monthly and Psoriasis Philippines had to provide financial reports.

This ordinance renames the Delpan Sports Complex, located in Manila’s 3rd District, as the Leonardo B. Fugoso Sports Complex in honor of the late Leonardo B. Fugoso, a respected public servant and three-term congressman of Manila. The Manila Department of Engineering and Public Works is directed to update the signage accordingly.

ORDINANCE NO. 8395
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING AND GRANTING A LICENSE TO ESTABLISH, OPERATE AND MAINTAIN A COCKPIT ARENA TO ROYAL OCTADOME, INCORPORATED, AND REGULATING GAMES OF COCKFIGHTING BY PROVIDING FOR ANNUAL FEES TO BE PAID BY THE LICENSEE, COCKPIT PERSONNEL, GAFFERS AND BET TAKERS

WHEREAS, the Royal Octadome, Inc. (ROI), a corporation existing under Philippine laws to engage in the conduct of foreign and local tourism-related activities, intends to create and operate its first state-of-the-art Sports Stadium in the City of Manila;

WHEREAS, the company endeavors to promote and enrich Filipino sports and culture, such as boxing, basketball, volleyball, sepak takraw, and cockfighting, among others;

WHEREAS, Section 458 (a)(3)(v) of Republic Act 7160, otherwise known as the Local Government Code of 1991, provides the legislative authority for the Sangguniang Panlungsod to authorize and license the establishment and regulation of cockpits;

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1. Definition of Terms
a) Cockfighting (Sabong) – Refers to the game or event known as cockfighting derby, pintakasi, or equivalent terms.

b) Cockpit (Sabungan) – A properly enclosed or fenced premises licensed for holding cockfighting events.

c) Cockfight (Soltada) – The actual fight between two pitted gamecocks.

d) Derby – A special cockfighting event wherein registered cocks are matched by weight and scored to determine a champion.

e) Hackfights – Ordinary matches between two cocks via the ulutan or pairing system.

f) International Derby – A cockfighting event involving foreign entries.

g) Regular Cockfight – A cockfight held on Sundays and/or legal holidays.

h) Special Cockfight – A cockfight allowed on non-regular days with a special permit.

i) Management – Refers to the operator/owner/licensee or any group managing the cockpit.

j) Special Permit – A permit issued by the City Government for non-regular cockfighting days.

k) Referee (Sentenciador) – A City-licensed official who oversees and declares winners in cockfights.

SECTION 2. Authority to Operate
Royal Octadome, Inc. (ROI) is hereby authorized and granted a permit/license to establish, operate, and maintain a cockpit arena anywhere in the City of Manila.

The licensee may transfer the location of the cockpit within the city upon notifying the City Government.
They may hold regular, special, international, and local derbies at any owned or rented venue in Manila, subject to payment of special permit fees.

SECTION 3. Business Permits and Taxes
The licensee shall secure a Mayor’s Permit and pay:

Annual Permit Fee: ₱5,000.00

Annual Business Tax: ₱10,000.00 (payable on or before January 20 each year)

SECTION 4. Annual Fees for Personnel
a.) Pit Manager P. 1,000.00
b.) Referee (Sentenciador) 800.00
c.) Cashiers 500.00
d.) Bet Taker (Kristo) 100.00
e.) Bet Manager (Maciador/Kasador) 600.00
f.) Gaffer 600.00

SECTION 6. Special Permit Fees

a.) Special Cockfights (Pintakasi) P. 1,500.00/day
b.) International Derby 10,000.00/derby
c.) Two-Cock Derby 4,000.00/derby
d.) Three-Cock Derby 5,000.00/derby
e.) Four-Cock Derby 6,000.00/derby
f.) Five-Cock Derby or more /,000.00/derby

Managers/operators (without permits): ₱5,000.00 fine

SECTION 8. Licensee Responsibility
It shall be the duty of the licensee to ensure all personnel obtain the appropriate permits.

SECTION 9. Duration of License
This license shall be valid for 25 years, renewable for another 25 years.
Transfers or assignments require prior approval from the Sangguniang Panlungsod.

SECTION 10. Limitations
No cockpit shall operate within 50 meters of any hospital, school, or church.

SECTION 11. Separability Clause
If any provision of this Ordinance is found invalid, the rest shall remain in force.

SECTION 12. Repealing Clause
All prior ordinances or regulations inconsistent with this Ordinance are repealed or modified.

SECTION 13. Compliance
Royal Octadome, Inc. or its assignee shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations.

SECTION 14. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect 15 days after its publication in at least two newspapers of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on April 28, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance gives Royal Octadome, Inc. official permission to open and run a cockpit arena (for cockfighting) in Manila. It sets rules for operation, defines types of cockfighting events, sets yearly business and personnel fees, and requires permits for special events like derbies. The license is valid for 25 years, renewable once, and ensures cockpits are not located near schools, hospitals, or churches.
fines:
Managers/operators without permits: PhP5,000

Annual permit and tax fees apply

Special permit fees apply depending on event type

Personnel must also pay annual fees (PhP100 to PhP1,000 each)

ORDINANCE NO. 8592
AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING ALL BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS COVERED BY ORDINANCE NO. 8173, TO ENROLL THEIR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM WITH THE CITY OF MANILA'S “EMERGENCY RESPONSE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM” BEFORE ITS BUSINESS PERMIT BE ISSUED OR RENEWED



Preamble
WHEREAS, the City of Manila, as a local government unit, is mandated by law to preserve the comfort and convenience of its inhabitants;
WHEREAS, threats from lawless and criminal elements and the dangers posed by natural and man-made calamities will always be the challenge that confronts local government officials from its day-to-day activities
WHEREAS, with the magnitude of people residing, working or just passing through the city, wit would be impossible for the city government to make a swift and rapid response in every situation to safeguard the welfare of its constituents;
WHEREAS, to address this pressing issue, the City of Manila must look for a viable solution by adopting the advancement of modern technology for effective, efficient and fast response in every emergency situation, inside the metropolis;
WHEREAS, this program can only be achieved with the support of the business sector in the community which plays a vital role in the continued economic growth and development of the city;

WHEREAS, on November 27, 2008, the City of Manila passed Ordinance No. 8173, entitled “ AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING THE INSTALLATION OF SECURITY CAMERA SYSTEMS IN ALL SHOPPING MALLS/DEPARTMENT STORES, CONVENIENCE STORES, GASOLINE STATIONS, PAWNSHOPS, MONEY CHANGERS, AND BANK/FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS, WITH MINIMUM BUSINESS CAPITAL OF FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND PESOS (HPH. 500,000) OPERATING WITHIN THE CITY OF MANILA, TO BE SET UP AT STRATEGIC LOCATIONS WITHIN THEIR ESTABLISHMENTS, AND PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION THEREOF;

WHEREAS, to give more spirit  to the intention of the framers of the afore-cited Ordinance and to maximize the full utilization of the security camera systems installed all over the city, it is imperative to integrate and/or enroll the same to the City of Manila’s Emergency Response Assistance Program: NOW, THEREFOR



Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:
SECTION 1.
This Ordinance shall be known as the “City of Manila Enrollment of Surveillance System Ordinance.”

SECTION 2. -Basis. General Welfare Clause - ‘Every local government unit shall exercise the powers expressly granted those necessarily implied therefrom, as well as powers necessary, appropriate, or incidental for its efficient and effective governance, and those which are essential to the promotion of the general welfare. Within their respective territorial jurisdictions, local government units shall ensure support, among other things, the preservation and enrichment of culture, promote health and safety, enhance the right of the people to a balanced ecology, encourage and support the development of appropriate and self-reliant scientific and technological capabilities, improve public morals, enhance economic prosperity and social justice, promote full employment among their residents, maintain peace and order, and preserve the comfort and convenience of their inhabitants’ (Section 16, Republic Act 7160)

SECTION 3.
Coverage.
This Ordinance applies to:

a.) All business establishments mentioned in Ordinance No. 8173; and

b.) All other business establishments not covered by the next preceding paragraph with a minimum capitalization of Five Hundred Thousand Pesos (PhP. 500,000.00)

SECTION 4.
Mandatory Requirement Before the Issuance or Renewal of Business Permit.
It shall be mandatory for all establishments mentioned in the next preceding section to enroll with City of Manila’s Emergency Response Assistance Program as a condition sine qua non before a business permit be renewed or issued.

SECTION 5.
Duty of the Office of the Business Permit and Licensing.
The Office of the Business Permit and Licensing is mandated by this Ordinances to issue guidelines necessary for the initial implementations of this Ordinance.
SECTION 6.
Appropriations.
The City of Manila shall appropriate such amount as may be necessary for the initial implementation of this Ordinance.

SECTION 7.
Separability Clause.
If, for any reason or reasons, any part or provisions of this Ordinance shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, other parts or provisions thereof, which are not affected thereby, shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 8.
Amendatory Clause.
All ordinances, rules, and regulations inconsistent with this ordinance are hereby amended accordingly.

SECTION 9.
Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 24, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance requires businesses in Manila with at least PHP 500,000 in capital to register their security camera systems with the city's Emergency Response Assistance Program. This is a necessary step before they can get or renew their business permits. The goal is to improve public safety and emergency response using real-time surveillance support from businesses.
fines: Not explicitly stated in this ordinance, but non-compliance may result in the denial of business permit issuance or renewal.

ORDINANCE NO. 8388
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE TITLE AND SECTION 1 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8262 BY SUBSTITUTING THE REGISTERED OWNER FROM FELIX MATEO RUNES, JR. TO DEVELOPMENT BANK OF THE PHILIPPINES, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 193707 IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
The Title of City Ordinance No. 8262 is hereby amended by substituting the name Felix Mateo Runes, Jr. with Development Bank of the Philippines, to now read as follows:

"AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY MAYOR TO CAUSE THE ACQUISITION, EITHER BY NEGOTIATION, EXPROPRIATION, OR BY ANY OTHER LEGAL MEANS, OF THAT CERTAIN PARCEL OF LAND WITH AN AREA OF FIVE HUNDRED FIFTY-THREE SQUARE METERS AND FIFTY SQUARE DECIMETERS (553.50 SQ. M.), MORE OR LESS, LOCATED IN PACO, MANILA, REGISTERED UNDER THE NAME OF DEVELOPMENT BANK OF THE PHILIPPINES, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 193707, IN THE REGISTRY OF DEEDS FOR THE CITY OF MANILA."

SECTION 2.
Section 1 of the same ordinance is hereby amended by substituting the name Felix Mateo Runes, Jr. with Development Bank of the Philippines, to now read as follows:

"SECTION 1. The City Mayor is hereby authorized to cause the acquisition, either by negotiation, expropriation, or by any other legal means, of that certain parcel of land with an area of Five Hundred Fifty-Three Square Meters and Fifty Square Decimeters (553.50 Sq. M.), more or less, located in Paco, Manila, covered by Transfer Certificate of Title (TCT) No. 193707, registered under the name of Development Bank of the Philippines, in the Registry of Deeds for the City of Manila."

SECTION 3. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on March 3, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance updates a previous ordinance (No. 8262) to correct the name of the property owner from Felix Mateo Runes, Jr. to the Development Bank of the Philippines. The ordinance involves acquiring a 553.50-square-meter property in Paco, Manila, for public use through negotiation, expropriation, or other legal means. The change ensures the correct property owner is reflected in the legal documents.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8387
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 3 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8175 BY INSERTING THEREIN THE PHRASE "THE REGISTERED MEMBERS OF THE HUWAG KANG BIBITIW, INCORPORATED SHALL BE EXTENDED PRIORITY THEREFOR"

EXPLANATORY NOTE
City Ordinance No. 8175, entitled:

“AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE CITY MAYOR OF MANILA, HON. JOSE L. ATIENZA, JR., TO ACQUIRE, EITHER THROUGH NEGOTIATION OR EXPROPRIATION, THAT CERTAIN PARCEL OF LAND LOCATED AT HERBOSA-FRANCO-TIOCO STREETS IN TONDO, MANILA, COVERED BY TRANSFER CERTIFICATE OF TITLE NO. 106367 AND REGISTERED IN THE NAMES OF ENELEA SANTA MARIA NALUS, ET. AL., MEASURING THREE THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED THIRTY-TWO SQUARE METERS AND NINETY DECIMETERS (3,832.90), MORE OR LESS, FOR RESALE AT COST OR ON INSTALLMENT BASIS TO QUALIFIED, ACTUAL AND BONA FIDE RESIDENTS/OCCUPANTS THEREAT, UNDER THE LAND-FOR-THE-LANDLESS PROGRAM OF THE CITY OF MANILA, AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS NECESSARY THEREFOR”

—was passed by the City Council of Manila on June 12, 2007. This ordinance essentially authorized the City Mayor to acquire the specified parcel of land for distribution under the City’s Land-for-the-Landless Program.

The officers and members of Huwag Kang Bibitiw, Inc., a duly registered organization with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the intended beneficiaries of the program, worked diligently for the passage of the above measure.

However, it was later discovered that the final wording of the ordinance inadvertently excluded the group from being explicitly mentioned, despite being intended beneficiaries. Upon review of the minutes of the relevant City Council sessions, it was determined that no such exclusion was ever officially made during deliberations. The discrepancy appears to be a result of simple inadvertence.

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Section 3 of Ordinance No. 8175 is hereby amended to read as follows:

“SEC. 3. The aforementioned parcel of land to be expropriated shall be resold at cost, on an installment basis, to qualified, actual, and bona fide residents/occupants thereat, under the Land-for-the-Landless Program of the City of Manila. The registered members of the district-based HUWAG KANG BIBITIW, INC., shall be extended priority therefor.”

SEC. 2.
The Office of the City Legal Officer, the Urban Settlements Office, and other related offices of the City of Manila shall take the necessary actions to carry out the provisions of this amended ordinance.

SEC. 3. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on February 17, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance updates a previous law (Ordinance No. 8175) to officially give priority to members of the group Huwag Kang Bibitiw, Inc. in buying land located at Herbosa-Franco-Tioco Streets, Tondo, Manila. The land is part of the city's Land-for-the-Landless Program and will be sold at cost or through installments to qualified residents. The change corrects an earlier oversight that left the group out of the original text.

ORDINANCE NO. 8386
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING ALLOWANCE TO THE BARANGAY CHAIRMEN OF ALL THE COMPONENT BARANGAYS WITHIN THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF THE CITY OF MANILA AND APPROPRIATING THE NECESSARY FUNDS THEREOF

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
A monthly allowance of One Thousand Pesos (PHP 1,000.00) is hereby granted to the Barangay Chairman of each of the component barangays within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Manila. The amount shall be released to them on a quarterly basis. The intention of this Ordinance is included and authorized through the Executive Budget for Calendar Year 2015.

SEC. 2.
The necessary amount to cover said allowances has been appropriated through City Ordinance No. 8372.

SEC. 3. Repealing Clause
All ordinances, rules, and regulations, or portions thereof, which are contrary to the provisions of this Ordinance, are hereby deemed modified or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 4. Effectivity Clause
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 29, 2015.
short_text: Barangay Chairmen in all Manila barangays will receive a monthly allowance of PhP1,000, which will be released every quarter. The funds for this allowance are already included in the city's approved 2015 budget.

full_text:
ORDINANCE NO. 8385
AN ORDINANCE EXEMPTING CERTAIN PROPERTIES FROM BASIC REAL PROPERTY AND SPECIAL EDUCATION FUND TAXES, AMENDING FOR THE PURPOSE SECTION 13 OF ORDINANCE NO. 8331, KNOWN OTHERWISE AS "THE 2013 OMNIBUS REVENUE CODE OF THE CITY OF MANILA"

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Article XIV, Sections 14 and 15 of the Constitution mandate the State to foster the preservation, enrichment, and dynamic evolution of a Filipino national culture, and to conserve, promote, and popularize the nation's historical and cultural heritage and resources, as well as artistic creations;

WHEREAS, in relation thereto, Section 16 (the General Welfare Clause) of the Local Government Code of 1991 mandates every local government unit to, among other things, ensure and support the preservation and enrichment of culture;

WHEREAS, the City of Manila is home to a myriad of cultural treasures and historic structures—most of them privately owned—the restoration and conservation of which the State encourages, as they represent the nation's historical and cultural heritage;

WHEREAS, private owners of some of these cultural and historic structures have used their own funds for the repair, restoration, and preservation of these properties, with very little aid coming from the government due to limited resources;

WHEREAS, such private owners are further burdened by certain restrictions imposed by law on the exercise of their ownership rights over these properties;

WHEREAS, these individuals deserve some compensation or reward for their sacrifices towards the preservation and enhancement of our historical and cultural heritage;

NOW, THEREFORE,

Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
Section 13 of Ordinance No. 8331, otherwise known as "The 2013 Omnibus Revenue Code of the City of Manila," is hereby amended to read as follows:

SEC. 13. Exemptions. The following are exempted from payment of the basic real property tax and the Special Education Fund (SEF) tax:

XXX
XXX

F. All historic structures such as heritage houses, national historical landmarks, national historical monuments, and national historical shrines, as they are defined in Republic Act No. 10086 (the Strengthening People's Nationalism Through Philippine History Act) and declared as such by the National Historical Commission of the Philippines, including the land on which they are situated; and

G. All other immovable cultural properties, as they are enumerated, categorized, and defined in Republic Act No. 10066 (the National Cultural Heritage Act of 2009) and declared as such by the appropriate cultural agency or registered in the Philippine Registry of Cultural Property, including the land on which such properties are situated.

XXX
XXX

SEC. 2.
All outstanding assessments of real property taxes on any of the aforementioned properties shall, upon the effectivity of this Ordinance, be rendered of no force and effect.

SEC. 3.
If any provision or part of this Ordinance is declared invalid or unconstitutional by competent authority, the remaining provisions not affected shall remain valid and in effect.

SEC. 4.
All other existing ordinances, orders, or administrative regulations that are inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, if any, are hereby amended, modified, superseded, or repealed accordingly.

SEC. 5.
Effectivity Clause. This Ordinance shall take effect fifteen (15) days after its publication in the Official Gazette or in a newspaper of general circulation.

This Ordinance was finally enacted by the City Council of Manila on January 29, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance exempts certain properties in Manila—specifically heritage houses, historical landmarks, monuments, shrines, and other cultural sites—from paying basic real property tax and the Special Education Fund (SEF) tax. These properties must be officially declared or registered by the appropriate cultural agencies. The goal is to support private owners who preserve historic and cultural sites using their own resources. Past unpaid taxes on these qualified properties will also be cancelled.
status: Amended (Amended Ordinance No. 8331, the 2013 Omnibus Revenue Code of the City of Manila)

ORDINANCE NO. 8382
AN ORDINANCE DECLARING THE TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION OF BARANGAY 630, ZONE 63, DISTRICT VI, MANILA, TO SPECIFICALLY INCLUDE THE AREA OF PNR RAILROAD TO THE NORTH, POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES COMPOUND TO THE SOUTH, PASIG RIVER TO THE EAST, AND PNR STA. MESA STATION TO THE WEST, WHICH INCLUDES THE EL PUEBLO AND MAUI OASIS CONDOMINIUMS (FORMERLY PHILIPPINE NATIONAL OIL COMPANY), THUS AFFIRMING CITY COUNCIL RESOLUTION NO. 67, SERIES OF 2014, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES

PREAMBLE
WHEREAS, Barangay 630, Zone 63, District VI, City of Manila, requested that their Barangay Resolution be approved by the City College of Manila, thereby allowing the release of their accumulated lawful share of Real Property Taxes from previous years, derived from commercial and industrial establishments within their territorial jurisdiction;

WHEREAS, in support of their claim, the barangay presented a resolution from the Liga ng mga Barangay authorizing the release and use of the said funds, along with their own Barangay Resolution, cadastral map, and copies of business permits and clearances issued to various establishments within the claimed area;

WHEREAS, there were no similar claims from other adjoining barangays, and Barangay 630 was able to provide clear and convincing evidence of their territorial jurisdiction, leading to the passage of City Council Resolution No. 67, Series of 2014, on March 6, 2014, affirming their request;

WHEREAS, months later, certain officials from neighboring barangays filed their opposition with the Office of the Mayor, prompting a committee hearing where all concerned barangays were notified and given the opportunity to present their position and submit supporting documents;

WHEREAS, during the hearing, the committee took note of the Audit Observation Memorandum (AOM) dated June 30, 2014, issued by the Commission on Audit (COA), which stated that:

"Notwithstanding the above resolutions, we noted the absence of a City Council Ordinance that would support the legal basis for the release of funds to Barangay 128 and Barangay 853 as required by Section 6 of the Local Government Code..."

WHEREAS, Section 6 of the Local Government Code provides that the boundaries of a barangay may only be altered by ordinance passed by the Sangguniang Panlungsod;

COMMITTEE FINDINGS & RECOMMENDATIONS
The barangay-claimants are correct in asserting their right to receive their accumulated share of Real Property Taxes from commercial and industrial establishments located within their jurisdiction.

This matter does not involve the creation, division, merging, abolition, or substantial alteration of barangay boundaries as defined under Section 6 of the Local Government Code.

In consideration of the COA opinion and to settle the matter definitively, the Committee recommends the passing of an ordinance officially declaring the territorial jurisdiction of Barangay 630 and affirming the previous resolution.

The draft ordinance should be amended through substitution to align with the above findings.

NOW, THEREFORE,
Be it ordained by the City Council of Manila, in session assembled, THAT:

SECTION 1.
It is hereby declared that all commercial and industrial establishments within the area bounded by the PNR Railroad to the North, the Polytechnic University of the Philippines Compound to the South, the Pasig River to the East, and the PNR Sta. Mesa Station to the West—including the El Pueblo and Maui Oasis Condominiums (formerly Philippine National Oil Company)—are within the territorial jurisdiction of Barangay 630, Zone 63, District VI, Manila.

SECTION 2.
City Council Resolution No. 67, Series of 2014, is hereby affirmed.

SECTION 3. Transitory Provision.
All income, governmental, and corporate services pertaining to the area mentioned shall henceforth be collected, delivered, and performed by Barangay 630, Zone 63, District VI, Manila.

SECTION 4. Separability Clause.
If any provision of this Ordinance is declared unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining provisions shall continue to be in full force and effect.

SECTION 5. Effectivity Clause.
This Ordinance shall take effect upon its approval.

ENACTED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANILA ON JANUARY 13, 2015.
short_text: This ordinance officially declares that Barangay 630, Zone 63, District VI in Manila includes the area bordered by the PNR Railroad (north), PUP compound (south), Pasig River (east), and the PNR Sta. Mesa Station (west). This includes El Pueblo and Maui Oasis Condominiums. As a result, Barangay 630 can now legally collect taxes and provide services in this area. This ordinance affirms a previous City Council resolution and resolves jurisdiction disputes with neighboring barangays.
